DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The United States is determined to uphold security commitment to Taiwan.
The China Times: The Legislative Yuan overthrew the Cabinet-proposed statute on the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
The United Daily News: Japan will offer verbal support for the "three noes" against Taiwan.
The Liberty Times: The US Senate passed a resolution on Tuesday demanding the Pentagon study the security situation in the Taiwan Strait.
The Independence Morning Post: Premier Vincent Siew said on Wednesday direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait would become a reality only after the two sides sign a peace agreement.
The Commons Daily: President Lee Teng-hui said on Wednesday the government's policy on direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait can be adjusted any time.
The China Post: Military to stay out of politics; chief of the General Staff appears in the legislature.
The China News: Downsizing clears hurdle; the Legislative Yuan passes first reading of bill without incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE ECONOMY SEEN SHRINKING IN THIRD QUARTER

TEXT.P: Singapore's economy is estimated to have shrunk 2.5 percent in the third quarter, the first of four to five likely quarters of contraction, the Business Times cited economists as saying.
Due to positive figures recorded for the first two quarters, economic growth will likely hit 0.4 percent for the year but no recovery is expected until the fourth quarter of 1999.
Forecasts for next year range from minus 1.5 percent to 0.6 percent, while the London-based Consensus Economics earlier predicted Singapore's economy would grow by 0.2 percent.

Economists cited continued deterioration in regional economies, moderation in the OECD demand growth, Japan's recession, and the likelihood of further "crisis contagion" as reasons for the negative outlook.
As a result, both Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors have come under stress, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE PUPPETMASTER

TEXT.P: He magically held time in his hands and brought history to life on stage. His legendary life was immortalized in the award-winning film "The Puppetmaster" by local avant-garde director Hou Hsiao-hsien.
During his life Lee Tien-lu was saluted as a living national treasure, won international accolades, and received a level of respect no other native Taiwan folklore artists could ever imagine having.

When he recently died at the age of 90, he had led a full and interesting life with virtually no regrets. Lee had even embarked on an acting career at the age of 75 when he began to play himself in films.
At his funeral, President Lee Teng-hui paid his personal respects to the master puppeteer and granted him an official citation.

The puppet master had also considered Bill Clinton as one of his friends. Lee Tien-lu performed "The Magic Monkey" in 1985 for the then governor of Arkansas during a goodwill trip to the United States.
According to legend, "The Magic Monkey" was one of the three disciples of high priest Hsuan Tzang, who traveled to and from India to acquire valued Buddhist scriptures during the Tang Dynasty.

Clinton had confided to Lee that it was not easy for a southerner to be elected president. Lee then told Clinton the story of the mythical monkey's ascent to the throne of the empire after a long quest fraught with difficulty, and wished him success on his own quest of becoming host of the White House someday. Magically, in the Year of the Monkey, Clinton realized his wish.
Having built a career with his two hands, the puppet master was saluted as one of the nation's living national treasures of the art world at 80.

Lee received the Time-Life Dedication to Arts Award presented in a ceremony at the Lincoln Center in New York in 1991. He also received Taiwan's highest cultural honor -- the Cultural Medal -- in 1991 for meritorious contribution to the development of Chinese culture.
Lee, born in 1909 in Taipei, started puppeteering at the age of 8 as an apprentice to his father. He first won fame in 1922 playing the lead role in several acclaimed dramas.

In 1931, Lee formed the Yi Wan Jan Puppetry Company. The company's shows often drew crowds of over 10,000. "The Seven Swords and 13 Knights," one of his masterpieces, was such a smash hit that it was the talk of the island for many years.

In an interview with the CNA, Lee once recalled that as all the shows were staged in open-air fields, his stage looked tiny and remote in front of the enormous crowds. His characters, he said, could be identified by the spectators only by the colors of their wardrobes.

It was in front of such expansive audiences 45 years ago that Lee began having to use amplifiers. He was once told that even blind people were attracted to his shows and they had "heard" every play he put on and became just as enthralled by the performances as his other fans.

All of Lee's plays were based on stories about ancient Chinese heroes or characters that inspired and enlightened the audience with familiar folklore themes and cultural truths. During the show, while his two hands were busy manipulating puppet figures, he also provided the vocalization.

Lee's mind was a storehouse of lines and lyrics comprising the personas of all the characters in the dramas he performed. Even at the age of 83, Lee could instantly conjure the image of a young country bride on the eve of her wedding feast, or a northern horseman sweeping into battle with sword drawn.
He was especially popular for his innovative martial arts sequences, acrobatic stunts, and use of modern slang mixed with classical Chinese. (to be continued...)

DOC.HEADLINE: PUPPETMASTER 2

TEXT.P: An optimistic and confident man, Lee never hesitated in trying new things. At the age of 75, Lee ventured into movies. He played himself in director Hou Hsiao-hsien's movie "The Puppetmaster." Lee needed no script for the role as he was the drama and story.

"The Puppetmaster" was Lee's third movie. He performed in two of Hou's other films -- "Dust in the Wind," and "City of Sadness." The latter was a Golden Lion Award winner in the Venice Film Festival of 1990.
People's interest in puppet theater waned as time went on, and although Lee's puppet shows continued to make headlines, they earned little money.
In 1978, Yi Wan Jan dropped its curtains for the last time.

Lee turned his stage into a school, teaching puppetry to students from countries all over the world. Lee said his students from France got the highest grades because they performed regularly in a festival of international performing arts every three years in Paris.

One Australian student, a woman born in Taiwan, was in Lee's eyes "the most respectable." She and her son gave three teaching puppet shows for charity and in international cultural events promoting Chinese cultural arts.
Asked what attributes a foreigner should possess to become his student, Lee responded they must have "a bit of the child inside," and "he must know Chinese."
Lee did not know a single word in any foreign language, but he had no difficulty in his frequent travels around the world with his students alongside to help him.

It seemed that Lee should have become complacent -- he had the presidents of the Republic of China and the United States as his friends, his sons to continue his lifelong career, a movie telling his life story, fame and a bit of fortune (he was on the government's payroll with a salary equivalent to that of a college professor).
He had only one regret, that puppetry was a dying art in Taiwan, and with it, a host of other local art forms were losing the type of nurturing environment needed for their survival.

To keep puppetry from becoming an endangered species on the island, Lee and his sons gave free shows and lessons to children in grade schools in Taipei. To Lee, children in Taiwan seemed to be doing only two things -- studying and playing video games -- with adults seemingly unconcerned about changing the situation.
"If the trend continues," he said, "Chinese will someday have to go abroad to see what Chinese puppetry is all about."

Regretting that there was not a place for preserving and cultivating new talent for local traditional performing arts, including Taiwanese opera or the Ko Tsai Hsi, Peikuan Tsu-Ti opera, and aboriginal music and dance, Lee once said there is an urgent need for the establishment of a museum and a performance hall for local traditional arts.

He even envisioned a place near Teng-hui Boulevard in Tamsui as an ideal site for the art center. Lee dreamed of a school for all the arts, with resident artists and halls of various sizes established for all kinds of performances, and a hotel with more than 500 rooms to accommodate foreign performers and spectators.
"I've sent my message to President Lee Teng-hui and he feels the way I do," Lee told the CNA reporter.

Through his strenuous efforts Taiwan's first puppet museum, the Lee Tien-lu Museum, opened in Sanchih in Taipei's outskirts late last year. The master's lifelong treasures, including a portable stage he crafted by hand and six 100-year-old puppets adorned in ancient wardrobes, are on display at the museum.
The museum, offering year-round workshops for the training of young puppeteers, actually serves as a time-space continuum of the master's puppetry.

DOC.HEADLINE: U-LAND AIRLINES SUSPENDS ALL FLIGHTS THURSDAY

TEXT.P: Unable to shield itself from its group's financial difficulties, U-Land Airlines announced a one-day suspension of operations Thursday, resulting in the cancellation of all its 14 daily domestic flights.
U-Land Air Lines, a U-Land Group affiliate, was forced to suspend services after checks worth NT$90 million (US$2.6 million) from the group reportedly bounced Wednesday.
Other companies within the group include King Textile (formerly known as Hwang Dih Lon Textile), U-Land Development and a travel agency.
According to reports, the group's textile and land development companies are facing severe financial crises.

U-Land Airlines, known for having offered NT$1 fares on flights from Taipei to Kaohsiung when it started offering domestic flight services in 1995, asked the public to bear with the company for the next seven days while it attempts to sort out its troubles.

No advance notice was given before the service suspension, reportedly enraging would-be passengers. The airline offers daily flights from Taipei to Kaohsiung, Taipei to Kinmen and Kaohsiung to Kinmen.
The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Thursday called on the airline to draft a plan to improve its operations, and CAA sources said the airline may be punished for the suspension.
U-Land Group Chairman Chou Chi-jui, 40, was not available for comment on Thursday.
Before entering Taiwan's domestic air service market, the Taichung-based group was known mainly for its construction and real-estate development interests.

The group entered the air service market after buying out a small local airline and merging with one in the Philippines. Since then the group has also pushed into textiles manufacturing, with investments in Vietnam, and tourism, by acquiring a travel agency in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRUIT BAN SPOILS SOME TRAVELERS' RETURNS

TEXT.P: Travelers returning to Taiwan were forced to dump whatever fruit they may have been carrying as a ban on bringing fruit from abroad into Taiwan went into effect on Thursday.
Customs official said a number of passengers aboard an early morning Cathay Pacific flight from South Korea had brought cartons of pears and apples with them.
After being informed of the new regulations by customs officials, the passengers had to dump the fruit into one of several disposal bins reluctantly.
Peng Tzou-kuei, chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), went to the airport to inspect the situation.
As tourism has increased over the past decade, travelers bringing fruits into Taiwan have unwittingly brought pests and plant diseases as well, Peng said.
He urged the public not to bring in fruit from overseas to ensure a safe growing environment for domestic animals and plants.
Peng said anyone attempting to bring fruit into Taiwan will be advised to throw it away. Those who refuse to do so will face fines ranging between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000 (US$867 and US$4,335).

Noting that the ban was imposed after a three-month campaign to make the public aware of the new regulation, customs officials urged the public to observe the ban and not to endanger Taiwan's agricultural environment.

The officials noted that most other nations have similar bans in place. Taiwan previously allowed people to bring in up to two kilograms of fruit, but this was found to be insufficient in preventing the introduction of diseases and pests.
Taiwan travelers most often bring back pears from Japan, durian from Thailand, and apples and grapes from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.079 against the greenback in Taipei on Thursday, closing at 34.293.
The local currency opened at 34.341 and was traded between 34.252 and 34.356.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$488.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong returned to Taiwan Thursday after a weeklong three-nation visit.
Soong spoke at the commencement ceremonies of the International Institute for Infrastructure (IHE), located in Delft, the Netherlands, at the institute's invitation.
He noted that the IHE has made contributions to Taiwan's water and resource development and said he traveled to the institute to express his appreciation.

Soong, as a chairman of the foundation set up by the institute, said that he hoped to increase personnel exchanges in water and resource development between the two nations and help nurture talent in developing countries.
Soong later traveled to Jordan and Israel to visit forestation, environmental efforts and water works construction sites.
Soong was met at CKS International Airport by Taiwan provincial government officials and Abdel-Wahhab A. Almasri, director of the Jordanian Commercial Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANSON REFUSES NEWS COVERAGE OF HER ELECTION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has run up a bill of about A$110,000 (US$68,700) to protect her from protesters and media during the federal election campaign, Queenland's Police Minister Tom Barton said.

Hanson has often clashed with journalists who have asked tough questions which she refused to answer. She has instead resorted to calling the police to evict reporters from news conferences or party functions, Barton said.
Barton said he was "disappointed" One Nation had called police to evict journalists from the party's campaign launch on Tuesday in Brisbane.
Queensland Premier Peter Beattie was even blunter, saying: "They (One Nation) should not compromise the police by inviting them to sort out this stupid political game."

"If you're in an election campaign and you release a document to the media and then you try to throw them out, well that's just frankly ridiculous. In a democracy, while the media can be a pain from time to time ... they have a very important role to play in our society in terms of informing the community and keeping the politicians on their toes," he said.
Hanson has refused any news coverage this week because she regarded the coverage as harassment to her election campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: OZONE HOLE IN SOUTHERN HEMISPHERE SAID GROWING

TEXT.P: The hole in the Southern Hemisphere's ozone layer has grown to a record size this year, according to Australian and US scientists

They said the hole of over 26 million square kilometers leaves the earth temporarily unprotected from the sun's harmful ultra-violet rays, the largest since 1994 when it measured 24 million square kilometers.
Dr. Roger Atkinson, the leader of the ozone research unit at the Meteorology Cooperative Research Center in Melbourne, said the 1998 peak occurred during the past fortnight.

In most other years, the hole has been between 20 and 22 million square kilometers while 1998 may turn out to be an anomalous year because of growing fear that global warming may be worsening the chemical reactions that destroy ozone in the stratosphere.
"The very chemicals causing ozone depletion are also very strong greenhouse gases," Atkinson said.

"Ozone itself is very important in the climate balance and so if we interfere with stratospheric ozone we may well be interfering with the radiator balance of the atmosphere," he said. "Perhaps we are seeing the first evidence that the two phenomenon -- ozone depletion and climate change -- may be interacting."
Speaking at the ozone meeting in Melbourne, Dr. Susan Soloman of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, said volcanic eruptions were also impacting on the ozone hole.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DROP ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Market (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 131.89 points to close at 6,700.20.
Affected by a drop on the New York Stock Exchange, the bourse opened at 6,760.41 points, 73.54 lower than on Wednesday's close, and continued falling until the closing bell.

A total of 1.47 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$47.76 billion, a decline from the previous session, in which an equal number of shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$55.63 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only pulp and paper issues registered a gain, moving up 0.1 percent.

Other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 3.3 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, textile issues and banking and insurance shares both at 1.3 percent and plastics and chemical stocks and contraction shares both at 1.1 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were lower as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October dropped 167 points to close at 6,620, with 2,073 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 128 points to finish at 6,605, while December futures fell 134 points to 6,601, and March futures declined 69 points, closing at 6,690.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 77, 41 and two, respectively. No transactions were registered for June futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GAS BLAST HITS AUTO INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Auto manufacturers in New South Wales and South Australia have been affected by last week's gas explosion in Victoria, leaving tens of thousands of workers idle.
Mitsubishi Motors on Wednesday announced that it was closing its two factories in South Australia because the impact of the gas crisis has continued to spread.
Auto-part makers in New South Wales have also closed their factories and ceased production after major clients such as Ford Motors and Holden in Victoria ceased production due to the gas explosion.
The cause of the explosion at Esso in Melbourne is still unknown as investigators are still collecting evidence, but the company's officials said repair of the damaged facilities is continuing.
If everything goes well, the gas plant could resume gas supply in two weeks.
Industrial sources estimated the losses from the explosion to businesses, the car industry, and other industrial and service sectors would be around A$100 million (US$62.5 million) a day.

If the crisis were to continue for a month, the losses could cost a percentage point in Australia's gross domestic product as Victoria's economy accounts for about one-third of the country's total GDP, economists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHISM GAINS RESURGENCE OF POPULARITY ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Buddhists from around the world gathered last week at a temple on Mount Wutai in Shanxi province to celebrate the religion's 2,000th anniversary in mainland China.
In a dispatch from Beijing, the Sydney Morning Herald's correspondent David Lague reported that there is a resurgence of Buddhism on the mainland after years of repression.
There are now reportedly between 200,000 and 300,000 monks and nuns and up to 300 million people who are influenced by Buddhism, making it the most popular religion on the mainland.

Temples, monasteries and holy sites were desecrated and closed during the Cultural Revolution. However, people are now seeking spiritual solace in Buddhism and other religions including Christianity after years of chasing materialism, the report said.

All religions in mainland China, including the official and underground Christian churches, are now attracting rapidly growing congregations as millions of Chinese seek meaning in their lives that the Communist Party once insisted it could satisfy.

Chinese authorities still suppress religious activity outside the officially sanctioned churches, but China is becoming a more spiritual country, even if motives are sometimes practical, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANIMAL PROTECTION LAW PASSES FIRST READING IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A draft version of the Animal Protection Bill passed its first legislative reading on Wednesday amid growing public concern over the care and protection of animals on the island.
Officials with the Council of Agriculture (COA), which drafted the bill, said the legislation is expected to be completed during the current legislative session.

The bill calls for the establishment of a council for animal protection and outlines regulations relating to animal transportation and slaughter; the management of animals for use in scientific experiments; and the selling, breeding and registration of pets.

The draft version of the bill suggests no one under the age of 15 be allowed to raise a pet and that the parents or legal guardians of pet owners younger than 15 be held accountable for the pet's welfare.

Once the bill is signed into law, those who abandon or abuse animals will face fines of up to NT$50,000 (US$1,500), while those who wager on cockfights or similar competitions will face fines ranging from NT$50,000 to NT$250,000.
The bill also requires that all pets on the island be registered and implanted with identification tags. Direct supervision of all pets while in public is mandated as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE SYMPOSIUM HERALDS ARRIVAL OF CUSTOMIZED MEDICINE

TEXT.P: The day is not far off when patients will be prescribed medicine suited to their unique genetic make-up.

This means that two people with similar ailments and symptoms will not necessary be given the same treatment. Researchers in the United States are confident that such customized treatment will be possible by 2010.
Professor John Wooley, who has been involved in what is called the genome project since it started in the 1980s, said it will help doctors better treat diseases such as cancer.

Wooley, associate director of the US Department of Energy, was one of two keynote speakers on Thursday at a symposium at the National University of Singapore on biomedical informatics, a field that combines medicine and information technology.
Wooley told The Straits Times that researchers expect to discover and study close to a million genes by the year 2005, while by 2010 they hope to have obtained samples from more than 50,000 people.
With this databank in place, doctors would have the means to administer what Wooley called "individualized medicine."
"Humans are very much alike in terms of their genetic, but each individual is also unique in his or her own right," he said.
"This, for example, explains why some people can eat more dessert and not put on weight, and why others are able to consume more alcohol and not get drunk."
"It also means that treatment which works for one person may not necessary work for the next," he said.

Citing his own experience, he said: "I was first diagnosed with cancer about 20 years ago, but the tumor disappeared when I responded positively to the treatment. But I also saw others dying because they did not."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE REMAINS WORLD'S FOURTH-LARGEST FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: Singapore has retained its position as the world's fourth-largest foreign exchange market and Asia's second largest while Hong Kong dropped two places to seventh according to a tri-annual ranking by the Bank for International Settlements.

London remained the top choice for currency traders, with an average of US$637 billion worth of currencies traded there every day. The figure represents a 37 percent increase in volume since the last survey was conducted in April 1995.
The United States, in second place, saw an average daily volume of US$351 billion. Tokyo and Singapore followed, with volumes of US$149 billion and US$139 billion, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 MORE ALLIES VOICE SUPPORT FOR ROC'S UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Four more allies of the Republic of China -- the Commonwealth of Dominica, Saint Christopher and Nevis, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Senegal -- voiced their staunch support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the United Nations on Wednesday.
Addressing a general debate session of the 53rd UN General Assembly, Dominica Prime Minister Edison James said the 21.5 million people of Taiwan aspire to be represented in the United Nations.
"They have a legitimate expectation that their country, a founding member of the United Nations, should have its membership restored. We cannot but lend them our support," James said.

Noting that the UN policy must be a policy of "inclusion," James said, "In all our deliberations and actions, as indeed in every aspect of human endeavor, the aspirations and the legitimate expectations of the people must be central."

Speaking on the same occasion, Saint Christopher Prime Minister Denzil Douglas said he believes that the time has come for the voice of the millions of Chinese people in Taiwan to be heard and factored into the international agenda.
"We believe that adequate, urgent and practical mechanisms must be developed to allow them to participate in the work of all nations," Douglas added.
He urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to conduct negotiation and adopt confidence-building measures as a way forward to improve cross-strait ties.

Douglas further said the United Nations is obligated to work with and encourage the Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to support the progress made to date, so that the advancement of the human condition transcends politics.
Meanwhile, Saint Vincent Foreign Minister Chiefton Allan Cruickshank called on all UN member states to remember the rights of the 21.5 million people on Taiwan.

"The Republic of China, both prosperous and democratic, deserves to be re-admitted as a member of the United Nations, even as it pursues the goal of reunification," Cruickshank said, adding that it is necessary that the United Nations offers the forum for discussion that will provide the framework for the peaceful reunification of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Senegal Foreign Minister Jacques Baudin said Senegal supports the ROC's accession to the United Nations and its affiliated organizations based on the principle of membership universality.
Baudin said his country has joined with other ROC allies in presenting a motion asking the UN to re-examine its 1971 Resolution No. 2758 which admitted mainland China at the expense of the ROC.

Senior leaders from 14 other countries have also voiced explicit or indirect support for the ROC's UN bid since the general debate session of the 53rd General Assembly opened on Sept. 21. They were: Burkina Faso; Latvia; Costa Rica; Paraguay; Nicaragua; the Dominican Republic; the Czech Republic; Honduras; El Salvador; Swaziland; Liberia; Belize; the Gambia; and Fiji.
Latvia, the Czech Republic, and Fiji do not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC. More countries are expected to follow suit before the general debate session closes on Oct. 2.

The UN Steering Committee rejected earlier this month the inclusion into this year's General Assembly agenda a motion presented by 15 of the ROC's allies urging the UN to review its 1971 Resolution No. 2758, which expelled the ROC to make way for mainland China.

This is the sixth consecutive year that the ROC has spearheaded its UN campaign through its diplomatic allies. Even though the bid, like previous ones, failed to make the annual General Assembly agenda, the ROC government has vowed to continue its efforts in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO EXPLAIN PURPOSE OF CRUISE MISSILE TEST

TEXT.P: Mainland China should clarify a press report that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) was scheduled to test-fire cruise missiles in the East China Sea on Thursday afternoon, a senior Republic of China official said.

"In order to demonstrate Beijing's good intentions towards cross-strait relations, the mainland should explain its motives and goals of test-firing cruise missiles at this moment," said Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Lin said the report had not yet been confirmed. "If the report is true, mainland China should take the initiative to promote military transparency by making public its purpose in test-firing cruise missiles," the scholar-turned-technocrat said.

Lin, a specialist on mainland China's military development, said the PLA began to develop medium-range cruise missiles long ago, and managed to produce a prototype in 1996 which had a maximum effective range of 1,800 kilometers.

"The mainland military has since developed an improved version of the cruise missile, but the modified model has not yet operated very successfully," Lin said, adding that a recent test-firing failed.

Lin said the cruise missile can fly at low altitude and is guided by its own computer. "The missile, usually armed with a nuclear warhead, can not only fly on a pre-set route but can also alter course in mid-flight," he explained.

He noted that the cruise missile is far more sophisticated than the M-class missiles that the PLA test-fired in the Taiwan Strait in the run-up to the ROC's first-ever direct presidential election in March 1996 to intimidate Taiwan voters.

Lin said he could not believe that Beijing's test-firing of the cruise missiles at this moment, if confirmed, could possibly be described as a sign of good intent, especially as Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland is scheduled to make an ice-breaking visit to Beijing and Shanghai next month.

"We sincerely hope that Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C.F. Koo's Oct. 14-19 mainland visit can produce concrete results to help resolve some practical issues related to the interests and well-being of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," Lin added.
SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized by the ROC government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Lin went on to say that mainland China is developing new military strategies for use against Taiwan, including an "asymmetrical warfare strategy" under which mainland China will use ballistic missiles to attack Taiwan's major cities and military bases.

Moreover, he said, mainland China is also developing laser-directed energy weapons and electromagnetic pulse bombs. "These highly advanced weaponry systems will pose a serious threat to Taiwan's security," he warned.
As for a proposed visit to the mainland by ROC President Lee Teng-hui, Lin said the realization of the proposal will hinge on mainland China's attitude and practical actions.

"It will depend on whether Beijing can show goodwill toward Taiwan on the diplomatic and military fronts," Lin stressed, adding that the title under which Lee visits the mainland is only a minor problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TO FACE STRUCTURAL CHANGES NEXT YEAR: MAC

TEXT.P: A senior mainland affairs official predicted on Thursday that mainland China will undergo significant structural changes next year.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said he made the forecast not out of any ill motivations.
As a matter of fact, Lin said, the Republic of China does not like to see any turmoil in mainland China because an unstable mainland will also adversely affect Taiwan.
Nevertheless, Lin said, the government is obligated to study and evaluate the mainland situation and inform local people of possible developments there.

Lin attributed his forecast to three factors: Mainland China has consistently undergone structural changes once every 10 years over the past decades; mainland China is simultaneously undertaking many major reform programs, which will add to uncertainty and risks; mainland China has faced many unexpected challenges since last year, including the Asian financial crisis, serious flooding and deflation.

From political, economic and social angles, Lin said, mainland China is on a downward streak. For instance, its economic growth has slowed; its credit crunch has shown no signs of abating; and the value of the mainland currency is declining in the black market.

Quoting a study released recently by the US-based George Washington University, Lin further said mainland China is at a critical juncture of significant changes and faces an uncertain, unstable future.
Lin went on to say that the time is still not right for ROC President Lee Teng-hui to meet his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin.

He further said mainland China is very likely to launch a new diplomatic offensive against Taiwan after Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo's ice-breaking visit to the mainland in mid-October.
Lin said the ROC sincerely hopes that Koo's Oct. 14-19 mainland visit will produce positive results to help resume institutionalized cross-strait dialogue.

During his mainland visit, Koo will meet with Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to discuss matters of mutual concern. Koo will also meet with mainland President Jiang and Vice Premier Qian Qichen.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE APPROVES ROC DONATION TO ASIAN DEVELOPMENT FUND

TEXT.P: Two committees of the Legislative Yuan on Thursday approved a government plan to donate US$14.85 million for the Asian Development Bank's seventh Asian Development Fund (ADF).
The total development fund amounts to US$6.3 billion, and will be loaned to less-developed countries between 1997 and 2000.

Of this figure, US$2.7 billion will come from compulsory donations by the ADB's 24 member countries. Taiwan is required to donate US$14.85 million, payable in four installments, between November 1997 and the end of 2000.

After hearing a report from Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China, the Finance Committee and the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Committee under the Legislative Yuan approved the government's plan to begin compiling a budget for the donation from fiscal 1999.

The development fund was first initiated by the ADB in 1973 to help finance projects in less-developed countries. The ROC began making donations to the fund in 1983, when it contributed US$2 million. In 1992, the ROC donated US$15 million to the sixth ADF.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CLARIFIES WIRE SERVICE'S REPORT OF TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan said Thursday that a foreign wire service probably made a mistake in a report on Taiwan's expected economic growth next year.

Taiwan's news media Thursday cited a foreign wire service as reporting that the latest economic forecast from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) called for Taiwan's economy to grow by 4 percent this year and 2 percent next year. Despite the decline, Taiwan would remain the only so-called "Asian Dragon" to achieve positive economic growth during the two-year period.

Responding to the reports, the CEPD said the wire service may have mistaken the growth rate of Australia for that of Taiwan. Figures for the two countries lay close together on a table of statistics in the IMF forecast. It is Australia, not Taiwan, that is expected to see economic growth of only 2 percent next year, officials said.

The IMF report predicts economic growth of 4 percent for Taiwan next year, but CEPD officials said the figure was too low, noting that even conservative estimates call for growth next year of between 5.3 percent and 5.5 percent.
The 4 percent figure predicted by the IMF is the most pessimistic one to date.

Thomas M. F. Yeh, director of the Economic Research Department under the CEPD, remarked that even before Asia's financial turmoil developed into a worldwide crisis Taiwan had adopted a policy of expanding domestic demand by expanding public construction projects and promoting private investment.

According to data issued in August by the Directorate General of Budget, Account and Statistics, economic growth (including the contribution of expanding domestic demand projects) will amount to 5.3 percent in 1998 and 5.75 percent for the upper half of 1999. A September forecast by the CEPD called for growth of 5.11 percent this year and 5.32 percent in 1999.

Meanwhile, the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research forecast in July growth of 5.2 percent for 1998 and 6.18 percent for 1999, while the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research forecast economic growth this year of 5.5 percent.

As for predictions from foreign organizations, reports issued in June by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) put Taiwan's annual economic growth this year and next are 5.9 percent and 6.2 percent, while the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association estimated Taiwan's economy would grow by an annual rate of 5.2 percent and 5.3 percent, respectively, during the same two-year period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE MANUFACTURER TO INVEST US$500 M. IN POLAND

TEXT.P: A Taiwan textile manufacturer announced at the end of a conference on economic cooperation between Taiwan and Poland Thursday in Warsaw that it will invest US$5 million in five year in that country, a trade official said.

He said the investment to be made by Taipei-based Acelon Corp. will create 1,000 job opportunities in Poland, which is one of Taiwan's major trading partners in eastern Europe. Trade between the two countries totaled US$444 million last year, a jump of 21.2 percent over 1996. Taiwan is Poland's biggest export market in Asia, he added.

The fourth conference on economic cooperation between Taiwan and Poland was concluded Thursday. Taiwan participants in the meeting included officials of the China External Trade Development Council, the Board of Foreign Trade of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce. The participants from Poland included Chairman Andrzej Arendarski of Poland's federal association of commerce, Governor Grzegorz Stepinski of Piotrkow Trybunalski province, and Governor Aleksander Grad of Tarnow province.
The next conference will be held next year in Taipei, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT POINTS OUT NEED TO CONTINUE IMPROVING ECON. POWER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Thursday that Taiwan needs to continue improving its economic power and international economic cooperation.
He also stressed the importance of liberalization and self-discipline in Taiwan's financial institutions, as well as balanced development of exports and domestic demand.
The president made the remarks at a reception for representatives of the delegates to the fourth congress of the World Federation of Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce.

Although the impact on Taiwan from the Asian financial turmoil is lighter than that suffered by other Asian countries, Lee said, the government has already worked out measures to cope with the constantly changing economic situations at home and abroad.

The emphasis, he said, has been placed on expanding domestic demand, stabilizing the domestic financial situation, and stimulating the economy, so as to reduce unfavorable external impact on Taiwan's economic development to the minimum.
Lee listed four objectives the government will strive to realize:

-- To continue improving economic power and quality through government-implemented remodeling projects, the establishment of liberalized and internationalized economic and trade systems, the improvement of the investment environment, and the promotion of high-tech innovation.
-- To attach equal importance to financial liberalization and a financial monitoring system, and to enforce self-discipline in financial institutions.
-- To pursue balanced development of export competitiveness and expanding domestic demand.
-- To step up international economic cooperation and continue providing financial and economic assistance to other Asian countries.
The businessmen met with Lee at the Presidential Office, accompanied by Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission under the Executive Yuan.

The president also asked the Foreign Ministry and the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission to extend necessary assistance to Taiwan businessmen in Lesotho who have suffered immense property losses during recent unrest in the southern African country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPS TAIWAN SETS UP NEW PLANT

TEXT.P: Philips Electronics Building Element Industries (Taiwan) announced on Thursday that it will hold a ground breaking ceremony on Friday for a new production plant at the Nantze Export Processing Zone (EPZ) in southern Kaohsiung County.

According to the EPZ Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, construction of the ten-story building, with a total floor space of 5,700 pings, is scheduled for completion in April 2000. The plant will manufacture very highly advanced semiconductor products.
A Philips testing and development center at the same location is already the world's largest, and the new plant is expected to sharpen the company's international competitiveness.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yin Chi-ming said the although the semiconductor sector has been hit by a global recession, several investment projects launched recently by businesses in the industry indicate that most firms are confident in the industry's future.

In addition to the new production facilities to be built in Nantze, Philips was reported earlier this week to have teamed up with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., the largest semiconductor maker on the island, for a joint investment to establish a factory in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WOULD WELCOME VISIT BY LEE IN `APPROPRIATE CAPACITY'
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Tang Shubei, vice chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) reiterated on Thursday that Beijing would welcome a visit from ROC President Lee Teng-hui, under the correct circumstances.

In an interview with Beijing-based Central TV Station which was replayed by Hong Kong's Asia TV on Thursday, Tang said that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin would like to make a trip to Taiwan, and that "Taiwan's leader," as he referred to Lee, would be welcome to visit mainland China in an "appropriate capacity."
He did not elaborate on what would constitute an appropriate capacity, saying only that the matter should be resolved before any such visit could take place.
Tang said any exchange of visits by the two leaders would be "political-charged moves, rather than ordinary trips."
He called for the two sides to open political dialogue which, instead of being limited to specific issues, should cover any ideas conducive to the reunification of Taiwan and mainland China.
Political talks can start only after consensus on their agenda has been reached through the loosely-organized dialogue, said Tang.

In a gesture seen as an olive branch to Beijing, President Lee Teng-hui offered in his inaugural speech of 1996 to make a "trip for peace" to Beijing. Remote as the chance for such a trip might be, the issue was raised again by the media now that Taipei and Beijing are set to resume high-level contacts through their respective frontmen in October, after a five-year hiatus.
However, Taiwan has made it clear that Lee will visit Beijing only if he can travel as president of the Republic of China, a demand Beijing refuses to accept, because it does not recognize the ROC.

In Washington on Tuesday, Beijing's Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan ruled out the possibility that Beijing would allow Lee to visit as ROC president. He also warned US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright not to let the Taiwan issue become a sticking point in their bilateral relations by flirting with the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION GROWTH SAID TO HIT ZERO IN 40 YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population growth is expected to hit zero in 30 to 40 years if the island's divorce rate and low birth rate continue at the current pace, according to a report carried by the Liberty Times in its Thursday edition.

Citing statistics released by the Taiwan Provincial Family Planning Research Center (TPFPRC) at a seminar, the report said a continued declining population growth will exacerbate the current labor shortage and greatly hinder the country's economic development.

According to the report, Taiwan's men and women marry for the first time at the age of 31 and 28, respectively. Of every 1,000 married couples 1.7 will divorce, while each woman of child-bearing age only gives birth to an average 1.67 babies.

Marriage at an older age and rising divorce rates are the two major factors that will keep Taiwan's birth rate at a low level, the report noted. The TPFPRC suggested that the government work out measures to provide sufficient child-care services and assistance to mothers as a way of helping to lift the island's falling birth rate.

The TPFPRC also found that the birth rate among women under the age of 20 has risen from 39 percent in 1965 to the present level of 77.2 percent, while babies born to women over 35 currently account for about 6.6 percent of the annual total, up from the 2.8 percent registered in 1988, according to the report.

The TPFPRC was quoted as saying that lowering the birth rate among teenagers and elderly child-bearing women, while increasing the birth rate for women in their child-bearing prime, is one of the biggest challenges it will have to face in the future.

The figures put forward by the TPFPRC reportedly aroused grave concern of Chan Chi-shean, director-general of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), and many of the other experts who took part in the seminar.

Chan said the DOH, in conjunction with relevant government agencies, will hammer out a new population policy for the new millennium to tackle the coming demographic changes and labor force demands, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui said on Thursday Taiwan's economic growth rate will surpass the IMF forecast.
The China Times: The U-Land Group bounced checks worth NT$140 million in two days; its debts reached nearly NT$10 billion.

The Commons Daily: DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung predicted that his party will dominate the next legislature.
The China Post: U-Land's Taichung office shuts down.
The China News: U-Land faces insolvency.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAVE BABY DWARF SPERM WHALE
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Veterinarians at a southern Taiwan center for stranded cetaceans have been dispatching e-mail messages around the world since Thursday night in an attempt to save the life of a baby dwarf sperm whale critically injured in a shark attack.

The veterinarians are giving the whale glucose and medicine intravenously, while soaking it in an antibiotics-filled solution. They are, however, unsure what to feed it, as they have never before encountered a baby dwarf sperm whale.

The whale, one meter long and most likely several months old, and its mother were found Thursday morning on the shore of Kaohsiung's Hsitzuwan Beach. The whales had scrambled there to escape a school of sharks. Both whales had sustained multiple wounds. The mother, which measured about 2.5 meters in length, died around noon after being moved fully ashore.
The baby whale was taken from Kaohsiung to the center in Pingtung, and center veterinarian Chien Chao-hua said he is glad the whale seems to be responding to treatment.
The mother's body, meanwhile, has been sent to National Sun Yat-sen University's Institute of Marine Sciences in Kaohsiung for analysis.

Among the species of whale, the dwarf sperm whale is relatively small, as are the size of the groups in which it travels. In temperament, the dwarf sperm whale is generally timid and nervous, Chien said.

Sperm whales and baleen whales are the species most often seen in Taiwan, although beaked whales, killer whales and dwarf sperm whales are sometimes spotted as well, according to Professor Chou Lien-hsiang of National Taiwan University.
The dwarf sperm whale is similar in size to the dolphin, to which it is closely related. Dolphins, whales and porpoises are all cetaceans, an order of fish-like mammals that lack external hind limbs.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGULATIONS GOVERNING MAINLAND SPOUSES STAY IN TAIWAN TO BE EASED

TEXT.P: The government will ease regulations governing the stay of mainland spouses of Taiwan residents in Taiwan who have children aged 6 years or under, an official of the Ministry of the Interior said on Friday.

Tseng Wen-chang, commissioner of the Bureau of Entry and Exit, said that under the new regulations, mainland spouses who have to take care of children 6 or under can apply to stay in Taiwan for six months and can apply to return to Taiwan as soon as they leave the island.

Currently, the government allows mainland spouses who have young children but lack permanent residency to stay for three months, after which they may receive an additional three-month extension. Mainland spouses can stay for a maximum of six months every year.
Tseng said that out of humanitarian considerations, mainland spouses will be allowed to apply to come as often as they want, although each stay will be limited to six months at most.

The number of marriages between people from opposite sides of the Taiwan Strait has jumped since Taiwan liberalized civilian exchanges with mainland China in 1988. The government began to allow mainland spouses to reside in Taiwan in 1992, with a quota set at 240. By last year, that quota had been raised to 1,800.

It is estimated that mainland spouses who apply to reside in Taiwan to take care of their children aged under 6 years will have to wait three years and seven months before they receive approval under current regulations.
The new regulations will be sent to the Executive Yuan for approval soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez said here on Thursday that his country will maintain its formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
Nevertheless, Rodriguez added that Costa Rica is interested in developing trade and economic ties with mainland China.
Rodriguez, who arrived in Washington, D.C. Wednesday for an official visit, made the statements in response to inquiries from a group of Taiwan journalists stationed here.

Costa Rican Foreign Minister Roberto Rojas Lopez met with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Tang Jiaxuan, at the United Nations headquarters in New York on Sept. 22. The move has caused Taipei's concern.

Rodriguez told Taiwan reporters that the Rojas-Tang meeting mainly focused on trade and economic affairs. "We believe that forging commercial ties with mainland China will in no way affect our diplomatic relationship with the ROC," he stressed.
Rodriguez went on to say that Rojas had discussed the issue with ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and that both sides have reached an understanding on the issue.
The Costa Rican head of state further said Costa Rica currently has no plans to change its longstanding relationship with the ROC.
Asked about the possibility of Costa Rica exchanging representative offices with mainland China, Rodriguez said Costa Rican authorities have not yet made a final decision on the matter.

Costa Rica has maintained cordial relations with the ROC. But it has been unable to shun engagement with mainland China since it became a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) in January 1997.

Beijing has consistently attempted to take advantage of its status as a UNSC permanent member to sabotage ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies and even lure away all of them. For example, it has through its private companies purchased bananas from Costa Rica with unreasonably high prices.

Because of its status as a UNSC non-permanent member, Costa Rica didn't sign a motion asking the United Nations to re-examined its 1971 Resolution N0. 2758, which admitted mainland China into the world body at the expense of the ROC. The motion was presented by 15 of the ROC's diplomatic allies in July.

Nonetheless, Costa Rican Foreign Minister Rojas still took advantage of his speech at a UN General Assembly debate session last week to throw support behind the ROC's UN bid. Rojas said he looks forward to seeing all countries around the world represented in the UN without any exception in the near future.
In Taipei, a senior Foreign Ministry official said ROC-Costa Rican relations remain firm and solid.
"Many cooperative programs between our two countries have proceeded smoothly," said Chen Ming-cheng, deputy director of the ministry's Information and Cultural Affairs.

Chen said Costa Rica has on many occasions assured the ROC that it has no intention of forging official ties with Beijing and that its economic exchanges with mainland China are confined to dealings between private enterprises.

"We are confident of Costa Rica's commitment to our country," Chen said, adding that the Foreign Ministry has also reminded Costa Rica of Beijing's political motivations behind its purchases of Costa Rican bananas.
