DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN LEADERS STAKE VICTORY ON TAX REFORM, JOBS (1)

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard of Australia's Liberal Party hopes that his tax reform package will get him re-elected for a second term, while his rival, Labor leader Kim Beazley, believes jobs will be the issue that puts the Labor Party back in power.
Analysts say the ruling coalition, comprising the Liberal and National parties, is running neck and neck with Labor.

The key issue of Howard's re-election campaign is tax reform, and to that end the prime minister has proposed a 10 percent goods and services tax (GST). The tax would enable the government to lower taxes on businesses, which Howard has said will lead to growth in exports.
Beazley, meanwhile, has focused on unemployment, vowing to trim the nation's unemployment rate, currently at 8.2 percent, to 5 percent within six years.
He said his government would create 500,000 jobs during his first three-year term through more training and through economic incentives for more investment.
To achieve his target, economists said Beazley must create a total of 1.3 million jobs. This will be difficult, as the global economy is edging toward recession, they said.
Howard described Beazley's target as "unthinkable and ridiculous."
Howard succeeded Paul Keating as prime minister in March 1996 after a landslide victory for his party in federal elections.

His settlement of native title legislation engendered significant and lingering opposition to his leadership, while his introduction of gun control legislation has enraged many gun owners, particularly farmers and hunters.

Businesses, especially large companies, are supporting Howard's tax reform plan, particularly the proposed GST, as Howard has promised to lower business tax rates from 33 percent to 30 percent after the GST is introduced.
According to analysts, low-income earners and rural Australians worry that the tax will be damaging in the long term, as the government may raise the GST rate to finance its expenditures.

Beazley warned Australian voters, especially low-income earners, against electing Howard, saying Australia should "never, ever" adopt a GST. Howard too promised not to implement a GST when he was named prime minister in 1996.
Beazley said it would be impossible for any future government to repeal or even amend it to exclude food once it had been introduced by the Howard government.
Rather than introduce a GST, the Labor Party would spur economic growth by providing job opportunities to low- and middle-income earners, Beazley said. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN LEADERS STAKE VICTORY ON TAX REFORM, JOBS (2)

TEXT.P: In Australia, there are 761,000 people out of work.
The focus on jobs is a gamble for the 50-year-old Beazley, who became a full-time federal Member of Parliament at the age of 32.

Economists have said Beazley's plan to create jobs would be easy to enact if the global economy were in better shape. But the currently ailing global economy may require two to three years to recover.
"This makes it quite difficult for Beazley to create 500,000 jobs in the first three years if he wins the Saturday election," one economist said.
Analysts said a loss for the 59-year-old Howard would bring to an end a political career that has spanned more than 20 years.

If Beazley were to lose, though, the opposition leader could still stage a comeback in the next round of federal elections, as it appears unlikely that he will be unseated as the leader of the Labor Party.
In all, 148 seats in the House of Representatives and 38 seats in the Senate are up for grabs in Saturday's election.
"This could be the closest race between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party in Australia," one election analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME OF AUSTRALIA'S CHINESE TO VOTE AGAINST LIBERALS

TEXT.P: Many ethnic Chinese, Vietnamese and Koreans in New South Wales are expected to vote against Prime Minister John Howard and his Liberal Party in Saturday's election.

In a survey, the Australian Financial Review quoted Helen Sham-Ho, member of the New South Wales Parliament, as saying that she was convinced that the Chinese community in Sydney and other cities in New South Wales are preparing to send a message that will threaten to rock John Howard in his own ethnically diverse electorate.

The Hong Kong-born Sham-Ho warned that most of the Chinese and Hong Kong-born Australians in the seat of Bennelong, about 5.4 percent of the total electorate, are voting against Howard and his Liberal candidates.
Instead, they will support candidates from the Labor Party and the newly formed Unity Party, she said.

"Racism to them is the primary thing they think about. They see it (the government's position on Australia's One Nation Party) as Howard more or less pandering to One Nation, giving it tacit approval," she said.
Sham-Ho resigned from the Liberal Party in July because of her disappointment with Howard's leadership.
In 1996 there were 340,000 Australians of Chinese origin, according to census figures. It is believed that figure may now stand at about 400,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA BANS POULTRY IMPORTS FROM NEW SOUTH WALES

TEXT.P: Mainland China has banned all poultry imports from New South Wales following reports of an outbreak of a deadly disease in Newcastle.

The ban was issued by mainland China's State Bureau of Exit-Entry Inspection and Quarantine. The bureau asked its local quarantine officers to conduct rigid and strict inspections on ships, planes and trains entering mainland China for birds or poultry products from New South Wales, the Sydney Morning Herald cited the Xinhua News Agency as reporting.
The daily said mainland China is particularly sensitive about the spread of poultry diseases after this year's outbreak of the so-called "bird flu" in Hong Kong.
About 100,000 chickens have been destroyed at two properties in western Sydney and at one at Rylstone, northwest of Sydney, in a bid to control the disease, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY DRILLS END EARLIER THAN SCHEDULED
DOC.DATELINE: Hengchun, southern Taiwan, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Gen. Tang Fei, chief of the general staff of the ROC Ministry of National Defense, announced an early conclusion to this year's combined forces military drills Friday in what he called "consideration of cross-strait relations."

Tang presided over a drill involving all three branches of the ROC military Friday. Toward the end of the exercise, Tang said further drills, scheduled to begin on Oct. 7 and Oct. 12, would be canceled in an effort to foster goodwill and prevent possible misunderstandings across the strait.

More precisely, Tang said, the Ministry of National Defense decided to conclude the annual military exercises early to prevent it from affecting an upcoming meeting between Taiwan's top negotiator, Koo Chen-fu, and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan.
Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation, is scheduled to make a fence-mending visit to Shanghai and Beijing in mid-October.

Tang urged the Beijing authorities to reciprocate Taipei's show of goodwill by exercising restraint in their military activities. News reports have said that the People's Liberation Army is scheduled to test fire cruise missiles into the East China Sea on Thursday.
Some in Taiwan have questioned the mainland's motives behind the exercise, especially at a time when cross-strait relations appear to be warming.

As for Taiwan's decision to cancel additional exercises, Tang said that while the drills are annual events, they should not be scheduled too closely to events affecting cross-strait relations. The October drills were planned several months ago, but Koo's trip and meeting with Wang were announced only recently, he said.
President Lee Teng-hui agreed with the decision to conclude the drills ahead of schedule, Tang said.

Tang called Friday's exercise, in which the military tested advanced weaponry and conducted combat readiness maneuvers, "a great success." The exercise took place in and around the southernmost county of Hengchun.

Nearly 6,000 troops from the navy, air force and army participated in the drill, together with 82 jet fighters and other aircraft, 28 warships and vessels, 128 tanks and armored vehicles and 38 pieces of artillery.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DROP ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Friday that the day's drop on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) was possibly the result of a decline in prices on the New York Stock Exchange.
He made the remarks after prices opened low and closed even lower on the TAIEX, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 266.06 points to close at 6,436.
The bourse opened at 6,512.85 points, 189.21 lower than Thursday's close, and experienced a low of 6,384.66.

A total of 1.93 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.26 billion, increasing from the previous trading session which saw 1.47 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$47.76 billion.

All eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 4.9 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 4.5 percent, textile issues at 4.3 percent, foodstuff stocks at 3.9 percent, construction shares at 3.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 3.4 percent, cement stocks at 2.8 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 2.3 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were also lower.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October dropped 222 points to close at 6,398, with 2,532 contract transactions.

Taiex Index Futures for November moved down 246 points to finish at 6,359, while December futures fell 281 points to 6,320, March futures declined 292 points to 6,300, and June futures decreased 222 points to close at 6,370.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 120, 67, 15, and one, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT INITIATIVE ON ENVIRONMENTAL PRESERVATION ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: Experts from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on disaster control and environmental preservation in mountainous regions have recently forged a cooperative relationship.

Taiwan and mainland China experts have agreed to jointly set up a framework for efforts to prevent mountain disasters, and to preserve ecosystems in forest and mountain areas, Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency reported on Friday.

Terms and conditions for personnel exchanges and joint contributions to research on dealing with environmental disasters and damage, such as that from floods and soil erosion in mountainous areas, are also laid out in the cooperation pact, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEFA FORECASTS TAIWAN'S 1999 ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 5.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The US-based Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association (WEFA) on Thursday said the International Monetary Foundation's (IMF) 4 percent assessment for Taiwan's 1999 economic growth is too conservative to reflect the actual economic development of the island.
The WEFA has estimated Taiwan's economic growth for next year at 5.4 percent, as it says the island's economy will suffer no more damage from the Asian financial meltdown, a WEFA analyst said.

He mentioned that WEFA in July lowered an earlier forecast of Taiwan's 1998 economic increase to 5.2 percent after taking into consideration the island's worsening economic performance, including the drops in foreign trade and consumer confidence.

Chang Ching, an economist of Chinese descent who is in charge of WEFA's forecast for the "Greater Chinese Economy," stressed that the IMF's key function is helping build a global financial order, rather than predicting world economic growth, a task for which WEFA is better suited.

Chang also criticized the IMF's prediction of 5.5 percent economic growth for mainland China next year, saying such a figure will be impossible unless the renminbi greatly depreciates or the Hong Kong economy collapses.
He explained that Beijing has been sparing no efforts to boost public investment, while Taiwan has also committed itself to encouraging domestic consumption.
According to the latest WEFA forecast, mainland China's 1999 economic growth will be at least 8 percent.
Beijing has recently announced that the country enjoyed 7 percent economic growth in the first half of this year.
The WEFA forecast also points out that the global economic growth for this year will slip to 2.1 percent, while that for 1999 is expected to move up a little to 2.5 percent.
Dragged down by Japan's serious recession, the 1999 economic growth for the Group of Seven industrialized nations as a whole is expected to drop to 1.9 percent, according to the forecast.

WEFA, founded in 1963, is regarded as one of the world's leading private economic forecasting institutes. It employs more than 200 economists and releases their predictions annually. These are widely used as references by private enterprises and governments around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE MORE ALLIES SPEAK IN FAVOR OF ROC'S UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Five more allies of the Republic of China on Thursday voiced their support for the ROC's bid to enter the United Nations at the general debate session of the 53rd UN General Assembly, which will close on Friday.
With the five new voices -- Chad, Malawi, Guatemala, Grenada and Solomon Islands -- the countries which have provided their support has increased to 23, compared with 22 nations last year.

Chad Foreign Minister Mahamat Saleh Annadif said he supported the proposal that says considering the changes in the international situation, and the fact that both governments co-exist simultaneously on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, it is necessary to review UN resolution No. 2758, which admitted the mainland China at the expanse of the ROC in 1971.

Speaking on the same occasion, Malawi Foreign Minister Mapopa Chipeta said that based on the principles of universally and equal respect for national sovereignty, the UN should consider the issue of the ROC's lack of UN representation.
He stressed that the ROC's participation in international community would be an important factor in international peace, stability and cooperation.
Guatemalan Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein pointed out that it is inappropriate for the 21 million people of Taiwan to have no representation in the UN.

Stein said that the aim of the UN is to protect world peace, and that its major function is to promote co-existence among all nations based on mutual respect. He lamented the fact that 53 years after the establishment of the UN, there are still people in certain lands who have no representation in the world forum.

He expressed the hope that all people in the world can be free from exclusion and discrimination, that all can be represented in the UN, and that disputes between states can be solved through peaceful dialogues.
Stein gave high marks to the ROC for its sound economic fundamentals amid the regional financial crisis.

Grenada's representative to the UN, Robert Millete, stressed the legitimacy of the ROC's bid to enter the UN and other international organizations, saying that denying the 21 million people of Taiwan UN representation is a violation of human rights.
He urged the UN to provide membership to the ROC, and to allow the nation's entry into the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, and the Caribbean Development Bank.
Solomon Islands Justice Minister Edmund Andresen also urged that the ROC be allowed to join the UN and its affiliated organizations.
He said that the UN Steering Committee earlier this month rejected putting the issue on the General Assembly agenda, which denies Taiwan's people the rights stipulated in the UN Charter.
He lauded the ROC as a politically stable, economically prosperous, and hi-tech country, which has made contributions to the region and the world.

Andresen also urged the mainland to forsake its entrenched position if it wants to complete peaceful reunification, adding that the Solomon Islands will continue to urge the UN to think seriously about the ROC's UN bid and recognize that it should have representation in the world forum.

This is the sixth consecutive year that the ROC has spearheaded its UN campaign through its diplomatic allies. Even though the bid, like previous ones, failed to make the annual General Assembly agenda, the ROC government has vowed to continue its efforts in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU DRUG TRAFFICKER NABBED; 5.51 KG OF HEROIN SEIZED
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A resident of the Portuguese colony of Macau was arrested at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport late on Thursday for attempting to smuggle a large amount of heroin into Taiwan, airport police reported on Friday.
The drug trafficker, identified as Jou Ion Chau, arrived at CKS Airport from Bangkok on a Thai Airways International flight at around midnight, police said.

Security officials found Jou to be behaving in suspicious manner, so they joined forces with customs inspectors to detain and search him, whereupon they discovered that Jou, 23, was carrying 17 packages of high-grade heroin, weighing a total of 5,511 grams. It was the largest heroin seizure in recent years, police said.
The 17 small packs of heroin were attached to Jou's waist and legs, and hidden in his shoes.

Jou confessed to police that he was commissioned by a Thai man, nicknamed Polo, to smuggle the contraband drugs into Taiwan. "Polo gave me 120,000 Portuguese escudo (about US$710) for my services. I needed the money because I had lost a lot of money gambling," Jou told police.
According to Jou, Polo told him to stay at a hotel in downtown Taipei, where there would be people to contact him to pick up the drugs.
Police officers lay in wait at the hotel until Friday morning, but nobody showed up.

It was the fifth time in the past month that CKS airport police have intercepted residents of Hong Kong and Macau attempting to smuggle narcotics into Taiwan, police said, adding that they will tighten inspections to curb such criminal operations.

Meanwhile, police warned local people not to visit casinos when they travel to Macau to avoid falling prey to international drug trafficking rings which reportedly have targeted people who lose money gambling, in order to tempt them into smuggling contraband drugs into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS TO HIT WESTERN EUROPEAN EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Asia's financial crisis is set to reduce western Europe's total net exports by US$55 billion per year, the biggest drop suffered by any of the world's trading regions, an influential newspaper reported on Friday.
The crisis is expected to add US$43 billion to the US trade deficit, and US$47 billion if mainland China makes a modest revaluation of the renminbi, the Financial Times said.

The shift, caused more by falling US exports than by a rise in the dollar value of imports, is likely to produce trade tensions with Asian countries -- but not a full-scale US retreat into protectionism, the newspaper said.

The overall economic impact of the changes in trade patterns on the US and western Europe is expected to be limited, because falls in their exports are likely to be offset by an expansion of non-tradable activities equivalent to as much as 1 percent of gross domestic product.
The expansion will be caused by an improvement in industrialized countries' terms of trade and increased capital inflows, which would lead to lower interest rates.

A study by the Washington-based Institute for International Economics estimates that currency devaluations in the rest of Asia will cost mainland China about US$12 billion in exports, and says a renminbi depreciation of about 6 percent would be enough to restore their competitiveness to the level before the region's financial crisis erupted.

Although currency devaluations in Asia will reduce exports to the rest of the region by Singapore, Taiwan and Japan, the three countries are likely to increase their overall trade surpluses, making it harder for neighboring economies to adjust, it says.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF TAIWAN PEOPLE UNWORRIED ABOUT OLD AGE

TEXT.P: Results of a recent survey show that 57.7 percent of Taiwan residents are satisfied with the government's national health insurance system, and regard it as a welfare system for old people.

Of 1,534 persons polled on the government's senior citizen policy, only 36 percent expressed worry about their health in their declining years, while 41.8 percent said they are not anxious about the matter.

The survey, commissioned by Huang Chao-shun, a legislator from the ruling Kuomintang, shows that 45.5 percent of those polled believe they will be taken care of by their spouse when they get old and sick. A further 11.4 percent said they expect to enter a home for old people in their later years.
The survey also shows that 68.6 percent of Taiwan's citizens plan to retire at between 51 and 65 years of age, most of whom expect to live off their savings and pensions.

On the question of where they will live after retiring, 61.7 percent of those surveyed said they expect to live with their spouse, and 11 percent said they will probably live with their children. Only 3.6 percent said they would be willing to live in an old people's home, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR SURGES TO NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar soared NT$0.295 to close at NT$33.998 against the US dollar on Taipei's foreign exchange market on Friday, the largest rise since the beginning of July.

Interbank trading on the greenback also rose to US$507.5 million, the largest single-day transaction over the past three-and-a-half months. Dealers attributed the increase to the US dollar's weakness.
The local currency has moved up for four consecutive days, during which its value has increased by a total of NT$0.559.
On Friday, the NT dollar opened at 34.233 and was traded between 33.98 and 34.29.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEAF BLIGHT AFFLICTS TAIWAN'S ANTHURIUM FARMS

TEXT.P: Anthurium plants grown on many Taiwan farms have fallen victim to a soil-born disease never before seen on the island, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Friday.

The bacteria which causes the ailment known as leaf blight has spread quickly throughout the island's anthurium farms, COA officials said, adding that a total of 70 hectares of farmland have been affected by the epidemic so far.

To prevent any further spread of the contagion, the COA has ordered the destruction of all sick anthurium, which are grown as ornamentals for their attractive leaves and their showy, often red spathes.
About 3.1 million infected plants have been destroyed to date, the officials said.
Taiwan currently has 331 anthurium farming families scattered throughout 12 cities and counties, and 138 of them have seen their crops infected with the disease.
It is the first time that this form of leaf blight has been found in Taiwan. Symptoms of the disease include leaf yellowing and withering, and it also curtails flowering.

The disease has so far only infected anthurium. "We have ordered the destruction of all infected plants for fear that the disease, if not controlled, may spread to other floral plants here," said a COA official.
He said the bacteria that cause the disease may have entered Taiwan through seedlings imported from the United States and the Netherlands.

Quarantine officials and anthurium farmers here have limited experience in coping with this type of epidemic. COA officials said they are helping local growers to treat plants that have been only mildly infected.
In addition to using pesticides and medicine to treat sick plants, the officials said the COA is also planning to sterilize the soil by steaming at high temperatures.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAKING CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATIONS COMPLICATED: DISSIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Beijing's demands for procedural talks to precede political negotiations are simply complicating cross-strait negotiations, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Yan Jiaqi said in an article published on Thursday.
In the article, which appeared in the Hong Kong Economic Journal, Yan commented that when Beijing and Washington ended their long-term hostility, no procedural talks were held.

According to the Beijing authorities, the procedural talks are needed to resolve issues concerning the agenda of future talks, the scope of the representatives' authority, and the way negotiations should take place.

Although the issue of relations across the Taiwan Strait is regarded by Beijing as an internal affair, and a far cry from the situation which existed between Beijing and Washington, former US President Richard Nixon's mainland China visit in 1972 still serves as a revelation today, Yan analyzed.

The willingness of Taipei and Beijing to reach rapprochement is far more important than the sophistication of the procedures themselves, said Yan, adding that any procedural talks will be void if there is no recognition of political reality, or willingness to reunify.

The article called on the Beijing authorities to recognize the fact that Taiwan is a separate political entity, and added that a peace agreement is necessary to end the state of hostility between Taipei and Beijing. At present, cross-strait economic and cultural exchanges continue to develop; however, a friendly political relationship has remained out of reach.

Yan expressed his belief that it will take time to build friendly political relations between the two sides, and that these relations will also hinge on the political and economic conditions which develop on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

The article further said the groundwork for a friendly cross-strait political relationship can be laid, so long as Beijing renounces the use of force against Taiwan and moves ahead on the road to democracy.

In response to the upcoming visit to mainland China by Koo Chen-fu, Taipei's top negotiator with mainland China and chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, the prominent dissident said that should Beijing miss the opportunity to forge a meeting between mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and his Taiwan counterpart Lee Teng-hui, it will only highlight a lack of political wisdom on the part of Jiang or the mainland's officials responsible for Taiwan affairs.
It is widely regarded that a Jiang-Lee meeting would be conducive to the signing of a cross-strait peace agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO PRESIDENT TO ATTEND NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATION

TEXT.P: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore, at the head of a high-profile official delegation, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Oct. 8 for a 10-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Friday.

President Lee Teng-hui will preside over a military honor guard to welcome Compaore on Oct. 8 at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza, said Timothy C. T. Yang, director of the MOFA's African Affairs Department.

In addition to attending the celebration of the Republic of China's national day on Oct. 10, Compaore and Lee will discuss international politics and issues of mutual concern. They are also expected to sign a joint communique to further strengthen bilateral ties.
Compaore will also meet ranking government officials and opinion leaders, including Premier Vincent Siew, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, and National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien.

The Burkina Faso president and his entourage will travel to southern Taiwan to visit cultural and economic establishments. Meanwhile, Hu and his Burkina Faso counterpart, Ablasse Ouedraogo, will ink an investment guarantee agreement to boost two-way investment and trade.
This will be Compaore's third visit to Taiwan since the two countries resumed full diplomatic relations in Feb. 1994.
Members of Compaore's entourage will include Minister of State, Environment and Water Salif Diallo, Minister of Trade, Industry and Handicraft, Idrissa Zampalegre.

Compaore is a much respected political leader in Africa because of his long-standing support of peace, democracy and freedom in that part of the world, Yang said. The Burkina Faso president also took the lead in backing the ROC's bid to join the United Nations at the world body's general assembly on Sept. 21, Yang noted.
Compaore is slated to proceed to Japan on Oct. 17, where he will chair an international meeting of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in Tokyo in his capacity as rotating OAU president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SLOVAKIA INK BUSINESS AND INDUSTRIAL COOPERATION PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) and the Slovak Chamber of Commerce (SCC) signed a cooperative agreement on Thursday to further bolster business and industrial cooperation between the two countries.

Wang Chang-ching, the top CNAIC adviser, and Peter Mihok, president of SCC, jointly inked the agreement in Slovakia's capital, Bratislava, where the first conference on economic cooperation between Taiwan and Slovakia was held on Wednesday.

During the conference, Dusan Gutan, director-general of the Division of Trade with Countries of Asia and Africa under Slovakia's Ministry of Economic Affairs, introduced Slovakia's economic situation and prospects. Jozef Cernak, a ministry official in charge of investment, also briefed the Taiwan delegates on the investment climate and opportunities in Slovakia.

Lan Chien-min, manager of the Paris branch of Taipei's International Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), addressed the meeting to explain Taiwan's countermeasures against the fallout from the Asian economic crisis.
It was decided that the second meeting of its kind will be held in Taipei next year.

The Slovak economics ministry, meanwhile, extended a warm welcome to Taiwan businesses wishing to invest in Slovakia, where they will be able to take advantage of the inexpensive but skilled labor force of the Central European country.

A 15-member Taiwan delegation, organized by the Taipei-based Euro-Asia Trade Organization, is currently visiting Slovakia after attending the fourth conference on economic cooperation between Taiwan and Poland which ended on Tuesday.
Members of the Taiwan delegation included CNAIC officials and executives from the ICBC and the Export-Import Bank of the ROC, as well as representatives of several Taiwan companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR CRITICAL OF LEGISLATURE'S ACTION ON DOWNSIZING TPG
DOC.DATELINE: Chunghsing New Village, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Governor James Soong on Friday lambasted the passing of a revised provisional draft on the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG) in the Legislative Yuan on Wednesday.
The revised draft overturned a version adopted by the Cabinet and the ruling Kuomintang Party, stripping 13 TPG sectors of powers overseeing the autonomous affairs of counties and cities.
Governor Soong, who returned from a 10-day three-country trip on Thursday, told the media he could not understand the party's handling of the draft.
First, the KMT holds a majority of seats in the legislature, he said, yet the party's legislative caucus was unwilling to support the version adopted by the KMT and the Cabinet.
Second, the interior minister did not support the draft version adopted by the Cabinet, he added.
The revised version was drafted through negotiations between the caucuses of the KMT and the Democratic Progressive Party.
Now that the draft has passed the first reading, the second reading is slated for Oct. 8.

The Executive Yuan hopes to see the draft become law by the middle of October so lawmakers can return to their constituencies early to prepare for their reelection campaigns for the year-end elections.

However, the passing of the new draft met with resistance from provincial government employees. A self-salvation organization formed by TPG employees plans to mobilize 10,000 members to lodge their protest to the Legislative Yuan on Oct. 8.
The organization held a meeting on Friday and decided to toss eggs and "ghost money" when the employees present their appeals to the Legislative Yuan.
Some KMT members will also go to the KMT Central Committee to burn their party ID cards to show their anger over the KMT's failure to protect the interests of TPG employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO GRANT PEOPLE FREEDOM OF ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: The Beijing government should grant its people freedom of association in accordance with the United Nations convenant on civil and political rights, the Beijing Preparatory Committee of the China Democracy Party (CDP) said Friday.

The committee pointed out in an open letter that certain mainland Chinese laws and regulations are inconsistent with the convenant, which Beijing has promised to sign later this year. The letter was made public by the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China.

The committee said one of the regulations governing the registration and administration of civil organizations in mainland China is in violation of the convenant, because it stipulates that no civil organization can become operational before its registration with the authorities concerned.

Under the regulation, the authorities can prevent all dissident civil organizations from coming into being, it pointed out. The Beijing preparatory committee of the CDP itself is still non-existent, because Beijing authorities have rejected the application for its registration.
Beijing should abolish all laws and regulations that are inconsistent with the convenant, if it will sign the document, the committee said.

The committee also pointed out that article 13 of the mainland Chinese law governing trade unions and article 16 of the regulations governing the administration of civil organizations are also inconsistent with the international convenant, because the former stipulates that the establishment of all local trade unions must be approved by their supervising trade unions, and the latter says that in any administrative district only one civil organization of its kind is permitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK PAPER URGES BEIJING TO INITIATE POLITICAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The Apple Daily of Hong Kong Friday urged Beijing to initiate political reforms so that mainland China's economy will have a future.
The newspaper said editorially that Beijing can take pride in its achievement in economic reforms, but it has to launch political reforms now, so that its economy will continue to grow.
It said out that long years of totalitarian rule has exacerbated the problem of corruption, which has badly hindered the economic development in mainland China.

The editorial said that, if Beijing can now begin to launch political reforms, streamline state-run enterprises, and reinstate those involved in the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy incident, the celebration of the 50th anniversary of the founding of mainland China one year later will certainly be joyful.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO US PRESSURE IN CANCELLATION OF WAR GAMES: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Defense Ministry's decision to cancel two military exercises scheduled for later this month had nothing to do with pressure from the United States, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Friday.

After maneuvers were held in Hengchung, southern Taiwan, on Friday morning, Gen. Tang Fei, chief of the general staff, announced that two additional exercises slated for Oct. 7 and 12 had been called off to foster goodwill with mainland China.
Some observers had speculated that the United States may have pressured Taiwan to cancel the military drills.
However, the Foreign Ministry spokesman told the Central News Agency that such speculation was incorrect as the cancellation "had completely nothing to do with the United States."

The main reason for suspending the military exercises was to avoid any misunderstanding as the island's chief negotiator on cross-strait affairs, Koo Chen-fu, prepares to travel to mainland China. Koo is expected to meet with his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in mid-October.
Chairman of the Cabinet's Mainland Affairs Council, Chang King-yuh, held a special meeting on Friday to discuss Koo's schedule for his forthcoming trip.
Officials participating in the meeting included those from the Straits Exchange Foundation, the Foreign Ministry and the Government Information Office. Details of the meeting were not made public.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SEND TEAM TO US FOR SATELLITE LAUNCH PREPARATIONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's National Space Program Office (NSPO) will send a team to the United States in the coming weeks to prepare for the launch of the low-orbit satellite ROCSAT-1.

The one-year integration testing for ROCSAT-1, also known as Formosa-1, is scheduled to finish on Wednesday. National Science Council Chairman Hwang Jenn-tai is expected to announce the launch date after he inspects the final testing operations.
It has been learned that Lockheed Martin Energy Systems, which signed an agreement to launch the satellite, will put ROCSAT-1 into orbit on Dec. 15.

Once the NSPO receives confirmation from US authorities on the launch date, the satellite will be sent to Cape Canaveral in Florida along with a 30-member team 50 days prior to the lift-off date to finalize pre-launch preparations.

Such preparations include testing the satellite functions, fuel filling, connection of satellite and rockets, testing of satellite and rockets, integration testing between satellite, rockets and ground control.

DOC.HEADLINE: U-LAND FLIGHTS RETURN TO NORMAL

TEXT.P: After a one-day suspension, U-Land Airlines announced that it will immediately resume all domestic flights on Friday.
U-Land Airlines General Manager Lee Chien-feng said in a news conference at the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) that the carrier will never again cancel flights without prior warning.
Lee said U-Land's 14 daily flights on three domestic routes -- Taipei-Kaohsiung, Taipei-Kinmen, and Kaohsiung-Kinmen -- will return to normal as of Friday.

In a surprise move, U-Land Airlines halted all its domestic flights on Thursday after checks totaling NT$170 million (about US$6 million) issued by a textile company and a construction firm belonging to U-Land's parent company -- U-Land Group -- bounced on Thursday and Wednesday.
The incident dealt a heavy blow to the widely-diversified group. Its headquarters in central Taichung City remain closed on Friday.

Admitting that the carrier is not in good shape financially because it purchased six airplanes over the past three years, Lee said the aviation company will continue to operate in line with its current policy. The airline will also continue with its plan to acquire Air Philippines, he added.
Lee went on to say that he is confident the group can find a resolution to its financial crisis, which was reportedly caused by over expansion.

Another U-Land Airlines executive said now is not the right time to sell the carrier as it is still operating in the red. The airline, which owns six MD-82 airplanes, has posted losses of NT$2.3 billion since it began operating in Dec. 1995.
Kuo Nan-hua, a U-Land pilot and representative of the carrier's staff and crew, assured the public of the airline's flight safety.
He said all U-Land workers have adopted a "business as usual" attitude toward the whole incident and that all problems appear to have solutions.

Although U-Land has announced the resumption of all its flights, CAA Deputy Director Chang Kuo-chen said the administration demands that the airline put forward a concrete plan detailing its operations. The carrier originally said it would reopen partial operations from Friday through Monday.
Meanwhile, the Kaohsiung-based Ever Fortune Group categorically denied speculation that it may take over the troubled U-Land Group.

Pointing out that Ever Fortune does not maintain any type of business relations with U-Land, a high-level executive with Ever Fortune said the group has no additional resources to acquire U-Land since it has poured in about NT$150 billion in three build-operate-transfer projects.
Against such a background, Ever Fortune has not made any assessment to take over U-Land, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: REACTIONS MIXED TO ABRUPT CANCELLATION OF WAR GAMES

TEXT.P: The decision to call off the Republic of China's military exercises prompted mixed reactions along party lines at the legislature on Friday.

Gen. Tang Fei, chief of the general staff, announced the cancellation of two military drills -- a rehearsal on Oct. 7 and a live fire drill on Oct. 12 -- to foster goodwill with Beijing in the run-up to a long-awaited meeting between the top negotiators on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The cancellation came amid reports that Beijing held cruise missile tests off its eastern coast on Thursday, which are seen as a response to Taiwan's planned drills. Taiwan held the first of a planned series of military exercises on Friday morning.
Gen. Tang's announcement was hailed by legislators from the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition New Party. Both parties support the eventual reunification of Taiwan and mainland China.

KMT Legislator Lee Ming-kao, convenor of the legislature's National Defense Committee, said the move underlined the importance the government attached to the scheduled meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan.

The purpose of the military exercises, which are to be a showcase for the new generation of the armed forces' combat skills, has already been fulfilled in the rehearsal staged on Friday, Lee said. He dismissed the significance of the remaining two drills saying that there are other ways to highlight military strength. He added that the general public should not make a fuss of the cancellation.

KMT Legislator and member of the National Defense Committee Ting Shou-chung credited the decision to Tang's "political sensitivity." High-profile military exercises could poison the atmosphere in the Koo-Wang meeting and make Taiwan seem aggressive in the eyes of other countries, he said.
"National security is the top priority of our national defense policy, and saber rattling, if it cannot deter military action from a potential enemy, should be scraped," said Ting.
New Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang hailed the decision as a move which was sensitive to the public's desire to ease tensions with Beijing and is conducive to cross-strait dialogue.
Noting that President Lee Teng-hui was behind the decision, Lin predicted it will earn votes for the KMT in the year-end elections.
Meanwhile, Legislator Parris Chang, a member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), ridiculed the decision as a misguided move which would not gain any goodwill from Beijing.
Chang doubted that Beijing would match the act with a similar one.

However, the official response from the DPP is more cautious. DPP Director for China Affairs Yen Wan-chin said the party would support the decision provided that the cancellation of the military exercises does not in any way relax the armed forces' training and readiness.

Given that the drills are more a demonstration of the military's newly acquired weaponry than a war game in nature, the DPP will not take issue with the military's decision to cut short the rehearsal provided that the island's security is not damaged, said Yen.

Yen cautioned that the government's bid to create a friendly atmosphere should not compromise the armed forces' readiness for any unexpected act of aggression and regular war drills should not be seen as provoking Beijing.

Criticizing the cancellation of Vice President Lien Chan's European trip for fear of irking Beijing as an unnecessary self-imposed condition, Yen said the DPP opposed cozying up to Beijing but would support any move which will reduce the possibility of military conflict with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:

The China Times: Taiwan cancels the planned display of the new generation of armed forces to cultivate a good atmosphere ahead of a high-level meeting across the Taiwan Strait.

The Independence Morning Post: The armed forces will not hold war games ahead of the Koo-Wang talks.

The China News: The Ministry of Finance says U-Land Group's financial woes will not start a banking crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOLD RESERVES WORLD'S 12TH HIGHEST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan owned 13.56 million ounces of gold reserves as of the end of August, ranking it the holder of the 12th-largest gold reserves in the world, according to the latest report from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
The United States has the largest amount of gold reserves, or 261.61 million ounces, as of August, the IMF report shows.

While gold prices have continued to decline over the past several years, official gold reserves around the world have also fallen. Global gold reserves, which totaled around 939 million ounces in 1991, dropped to a six-year low of slightly below 900 million last year. The figure had further fallen to 884 million by August this year.
US gold reserves have fallen about 100,000 ounces over the last three years, the report said.
Germany had the second-largest gold reserves at 95.18 million ounces, followed by Switzerland with 83.28 ounces, France with 81.89 million ounces, and Italy with 66.7 million ounces.
Of the top 10 gold reserves holders, eight are Western European countries. Japan is the only Asian country which made the list.

Nations ranked sixth to 10th were Holland, with 27.07 million ounces, Japan, with 24.23 million ounces, Britain, with 18.42 million ounces, Portugal, with 16.07 million ounces, and Spain, with 15.63 million ounces.
Russia, the top gold reserves holder among developing countries, owns 15.35 million ounces of gold, putting the country in 11th position of the world ranking.
Mainland China came close behind Taiwan to rank 13th, with 12.70 million ounces, the IMF report shows.
India and Venezuela were the 14th- and 15th-largest gold reserves holders, with 11.49 million ounces and 9.75 million ounces, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HAVE RAINY MOON FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Residents in northeastern Taiwan are unlikely to be able to see the full moon on Monday, the day of the Chinese Mid-Autumn Festival, or Moon Festival, the Central Weather Bureau said on Saturday.
The bureau reported that northeasterly monsoon winds are bringing abundant rain and cloudy weather to the island.

In addition, a tropical depression of low atmospheric pressure is forming over the South China Sea and may develop into a typhoon, bureau meteorologists said, noting the outer rim of the depression will effect Taiwan if it continues to expand.
Because of this, more rain is expected to fall on the northeastern parts of Taiwan, extending later into southern Taiwan, the weathermen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO TAKE BACK ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The ROC's top mainland policy planner on Saturday urged Beijing to take back illegal mainland Chinese immigrants detained in Taiwan as soon as possible.

Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the appeal during a visit to the Hsinchu Detention Center for illegal mainland immigrants, some 60 kilometers south of Taipei.

He expressed concern for the detainees, and directed the detention center management to open special telephone lines so they can contact their families on the mainland before the Mid-Autumn Festival, which this year falls on Monday.

Because of Beijing's reluctance to cooperate with Taipei, there are still 1,096 illegal mainland immigrants in various detention centers around the island, 390 of whom have been incarcerated for more than six months.

"We hope the mainland authorities will take back the mainland stowaways as early as possible in accordance with the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Red Cross Societies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chang said.

Meanwhile, Chang hailed the Ministry of National Defense's decision to cancel massive live-fire war games as a sign of goodwill to Beijing ahead of a planned visit by Taiwan's top political envoy to mainland China.
"The military's decision illustrates our sincerity in wishing to improve cross-strait relations," Chang stressed.

At the end of a rehearsal on Friday of the planned war games, Gen. Tang Fei, chief of the general staff, announced that in order not to adversely affect the atmosphere of the upcoming trip, the military has decided to cancel the Oct. 12 maneuvers -- involving the army, air force and navy in a deployment of the island's most sophisticated weaponry -- as well as a further rehearsal set for Oct. 7.

Taipei's top political envoy, C.F. Koo, a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui and head of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, is scheduled to meet his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, during his landmark Oct. 14-19 mainland visit.
"At a time when cross-strait relations are becoming warmer, we hope our two sides can reach certain consensus for the well-being of all Chinese people," Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT MARTIAL OF OFFICIALS IN CORRUPTION CASE TO BE OPEN

TEXT.P: The court-martial of four officials charged in a high-profile corruption case will be held in public on Oct. 8, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced on Saturday.

In order to ensure a fair trial for Lt. Gen. Liu Hsueh-ta, Maj. Gen. Wo Chi-kao, Lt. Col. Lee Cheng and Maj. Lee Chun-lin, the court proceedings at the ministry's Martial Law Bureau will open to the public, the MND said in a terse statement.

The four were charged in June with corruption, according to court documents. Maj. Gen. Wo was the former director of the Engineering Bureau under the General Headquarters of Combined Services Force, and two of his staffers, Lt. Col. Lee Cheng and Maj. Lee Chun-lin, leaked the maximum bid required to secure a bomb-proof ammunition depot contract to would be contractors in exchange for bribes.
Lt. Gen. Liu allegedly played the role of middle-man, and brokered the deal while serving as the chief staffer of former Chief of the General Staff Lo Peng-li.
Maj. Gen. Wo and his two staffers were arrested in March. Lt. Gen. Liu was arrested in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REACTS CAUTIOUSLY TO CALL FOR TAIWAN TMD STUDY

TEXT.P: The US administration on Friday reacted cautiously to a Congressional demand for a study on missile defenses for Taiwan, saying Taiwan's interest in the system "appears to be primarily informational."
In the administration's first official reaction to the call for the study, the State Department also reaffirmed US commitment to the security of Taiwan.
"The administration remains firmly committed to fulfilling the security and arms transfer provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act," it said in a prepared statement.

The State Department said that the United States would "continue to assist Taiwan in meeting its legitimate defense needs" in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act and the 1982 joint communique with mainland China.

On the question of Theater Missile Defense (TMD), part of a multi-billion dollar missile defense program still under development in the United States, the State Department said that Taiwan has been briefed on the concept.
It went on to say, however, that Taiwan is currently addressing its own capabilities and needs. "At this point, their interest in TMD appears to be primarily informational."
Taiwan military sources confirmed to the CNA that Taiwan has asked for information on the development of TMD, but remains non-committal on whether or not it will participate in the program.

While adopting the 1999 National Defense Authorization Bill during the past week, the US Congress authorized the Pentagon to study architectural requirements for the establishment and operation of TMD in the Asia-Pacific region in order to protect the country's "key allies" -- Japan, South Korea and Taiwan.
The Department of Defense has also been asked to report its findings to Congress by Jan. 1, 1999.

The Congressional demand came despite Beijing's objection to the deployment of any missile defense systems in the Far East, and despite the administration's concerns about a possible backlash from Beijing if Taiwan, in particular, decides to participate in the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN CHURCH LEADERS TO VISIT EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: A delegation of Canadian church leaders, led by Rev. Bill Phipps, moderator of the United Church of Canada, and Mgr. Peter Schonenbach, general secretary of the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops, will visit East Timor from Oct. 6-14, officials said on Friday.

The officials said the delegation has been jointly invited by Carlos Ximenes Belo, Nobel Peace Prize-winner and bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Dili, and the Protestant Church in East Timor. The trip is being financially supported by church groups and human rights organizations.

The delegation will visit church partners and local communities, meet with non-governmental organizations, human rights workers, community leaders, representatives of the five political parties in East Timor, and government officials.

Indonesia's President Habibie has rejected calls for a referendum on self-determination for East Timor. So far, he has offered only cosmetic reforms and withdrawn an insignificant number of troops from the former Portuguese colony.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S LABOR PARTY LEADING ON EVE OF ELECTION: POLL

TEXT.P: Australia's Labor Party (ALP) came from behind to surge ahead of the Coalition of the Liberal and National Parties in a dramatic last-minute rise of support from voters, according to public polls.
The poll, which was released on the eve of the general election, shows ALP leading the coalition under Prime Minister John Howard on 44 to 40 percentage points in primary votes.

The poll shows the coalition struggling to defend its 40-seat majority, a worrying sign for the Howard government because of the surging last-minute opposition to his 10 percent goods and services tax (GST).
Under the GST, everything except education and health will be subject to a 10 percent tax.

In the State of Victoria, where a recent gas explosion caused most of its 3.3 million population to be unable to have hot water, many voters are angry with the Howard government because it did nothing until a last-minute announcement by Howard that the Federal Government will provide a A$100 (US$62.5) million emergency gas crisis fund.

The explosion has caused tens of thousands of workers to remain idle, and has hit many key industries, leading economists to estimate that the crisis could slash Australia's economic growth by up to one percentage point. Victorian voters are expected to show their anger in Saturday's election, according to the poll.
The polls also show support for Pauline Hanson's One Nation at 7 percent, and support for the Democratic Party at 5 percent, with the remaining 4 percent going to independent candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIANS GO TO POLLS IN GENERAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: More than 12 million Australians cast their ballots on Saturday to elect a new prime minister, 148 members of the House of Representatives, and 40 members of the Senate.
The Senate has 76 seats, but only 40 are being contested.
Voting in Australia is compulsory, and anyone who fails to vote without good reason is subject to a fine ranging from A$20 to A$50 (US$12.5 to US$31.25).
Since August 30, Liberal Prime Minister John Howard and his rival, opposition leader Kim Beazley of the Australian Labor Party, have campaigned vigorously.

On Friday, the last day of campaigning, Howard said: "My final message to them (Australians) is that this change is good for the country. This change is also good for you. Your personal tax will be lower." Howard was referring to his tax reforms, including the introduction of a 10 percent goods and services tax (GST), with which he hopes to win the election.
Beazley, on the other hand, is relying on jobs and security, with a promise to substantially reduce the current unemployment rate of 8.2 percent to 5 percent in six years if he wins the election.

His eve-of-poll message was: "We've got a big task mathematically to achieve. But I think we have campaigned well. I think we're there with a good fighting chance. I urge people to vote for the Labor Party. While all political parties other than the Liberals have expressed reservations about a goods and services tax, only the Labor Party in the end is reliable."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE MINISTER HAS MIXED VIEWS ON AUSTRALIAN PM

TEXT.P: Singapore's senior minister Lee Kuan Yew has mixed views on Australia's Prime Minister John Howard, praising him for his financial help to Asian nations during the economic crisis, but criticizing him for his slow initial response to the rise of Pauline Hanson and her One Nation party.

In an exclusive interview with the Australian newspaper on the eve of Australia's federal election on Saturday, Lee said that One Nation and Hanson had caused damage to Australia's image internationally due to Howard's slow reaction.

"When she first appeared on the scene, she was bad for Australia, made worse because there was no official stand taken by the Australian government. Now, both government and opposition have taken their stands against racism. That's helped to clear things up," Lee said.
However, Lee also praised Howard for his financial help to Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea during the Asian financial crisis.

"You went out of your way to help Indonesia, as we did. There simply weren't the resources in the IMF to support President Suharto's economic policies. I am disappointed with what has happened in Indonesia. It could have been avoided," Lee said.

Lee also gave the Howard government a modest passing grade on economic reform. "That Australian government has gone as far as the Australian public will allow it to go. Prime Minister John Howard tried to get Australian unions to become more productivity-conscious. But the dock workers in Melbourne got more public support than the government in the recent industrial dispute," Lee noted.
Lee described the relations between Australia and Singapore as "good, trouble-free."

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY DIFFERENCES BETWEEN MAIN AUSTRALIAN PARTIES

TEXT.P: The main differences in the policies of Australian Prime Minister John Howard and opposition leader Kim Beazley are in four main areas, according to a survey by the Australian Financial Review.
They differ on economic management, health, industrial policy and telecommunications, employment and industrial relations.

The coalition is optimistic about Australia's economic growth, despite the impact of the Asian financial crisis, but the Australian Labor Party (ALP) under Beazley is more pessimistic about the economic growth over the next few years and has dismissed the coalition's growth forecast of 3.5 percent.

The coalition plan includes big personal income tax cuts to sweeten a goods and services tax of 10 percent. It also intends to reduce business income tax to 30 percent from the current 33 percent, while the ALP has proposed minimum changes to the tax system, placing its electoral hopes on a big-ticket tax credit plan aimed at squarely at those on low incomes.

On health, the coalition has promised a 30 percent rebate on private health insurance premiums, while Labor has committed a A$500 (US$312) million funding boost to public hospitals as the key features of its health policy.

The coalition is planning to renew efforts to deregulate the labor market by using more private mediators to settle industrial disputes, while the ALP is running a centralist platform to be achieved through the revival of the award system and arbitration.
Labor has also promised new measures to allow Australian workers to take legal action against their employers if companies use bankruptcy as a means of refusing to pay accrued entitlements.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE BACK POSSESSION OF MILITARY FORCE: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of local people support the development of Taiwan's military force, according to the results of a recent public opinion poll released on Saturday.

The telephone survey of 1,090 adult residents throughout the island, conducted by the Chinese Euro-Asia Society on Sept. 25-26, found that 84.7 percent of the respondents do not think that maintaining a deterrent force to protect Taiwan's security will adversely affect relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Poll results also showed that 70.9 percent of those interviewed believe that Taiwan's armed forces should continue combat preparedness under the current circumstances.
Meanwhile, 70.9 percent threw their support behind the proposal that President Lee Teng-hui make a "journey of peace" to mainland China to forge cross-strait rapprochement.
An overwhelming majority of 86 percent said they look forward to seeing President Lee and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin meet in an international setting.
Nearly 55 percent said mainland China's military maneuvers in the Taiwan Strait in recent years would only provoke sentiments for military confrontation.
As many as 83.1 percent of the respondents said they believe if mainland China renounces the use of force against Taiwan, it will contribute to positive development of cross-strait ties.
Sixty-three percent said they feel that Beijing's unfriendly attitude toward Taiwan in the past few years has cooled local people's willingness to help relieve flood victims on the mainland.
Slightly more than 64 percent said they think if the government were to open direct cross-strait air- and shipping-links right now, Taiwan's security would be adversely affected.
Eighty-four percent said they don't think that mainland China is entitled to determine Taiwan's future destiny which they said should be decided by the 21 million residents here.
More than 90 percent gave a thumbs-up to the proposal that Taiwan should continue seeking to join international organizations and upgrade international profile.
Eighty-five percent said even if expanding external ties will strain cross-strait relations, Taiwan should not hesitate to forge diplomatic relations with other countries.
Moreover, 78.9 percent said Beijing's consistent attempts to block Taiwan's presence in the international arena have hurt Taiwan people's feelings.

Survey results also showed that 36.7 percent of the respondents perceive themselves as Taiwanese; 14.6 percent insist themselves as Chinese; and 46.7 percent identify themselves as both Taiwanese and Chinese.

Analyzing the poll findings, Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council said the survey substantiates a MAC long-held view that if Beijing softens its attitude toward Taiwan, the percentage of local people who identify themselves as Taiwanese will decrease, and vice versa.

Lin said the results of similar MAC surveys found that the ratio of local people who perceive themselves as Taiwanese declined after Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made a visit to the mainland in April, but the percentage surged after US President Bill Clinton announced the so-called "three noes" against Taiwan in Shanghai in late June.

"And the ratio rose even further after Lin Ti-chuan, a Kaohsiung City councilwoman from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, was kidnapped and murdered on the mainland in late July," Lin said, adding that the percentage fell again after SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow made a visit to Beijing last month to set the stage for a high-level cross-strait meeting in mid-October.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOES NOT INTEND TO INVITE TAIWAN TO JOIN `NAB' EMERGENCY FUND
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States has no plans to invite Taiwan to join the international emergency rescue fund that was initiated by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) last year, US Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said on Friday.
The IMF proposed the establishment of the New Arrangements to Borrow (NAB) program in May 1996 in an effort to bail out Mexico from its economic crisis.

The program officially came into being in January 1997 as an international emergency rescue fund to help countries battered by economic woes. So far, it has 25 contributor members, including the Group of Seven, Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, Malaysia and Thailand.
Funds pledged by the 25 member economies so far total US$46 billion.

During a press conference at the Department of the Treasury, Rubin said the invitations for the 25 members to join were "appropriate." So far, the United States lags behind the other members, as it has not yet materialized its pledged funds to the program, Rubin noted.

Asked about whether Washington supports the idea of inviting other newly developed economies, such as Taiwan, to join the NAB, Rubin said only that the purpose of the press conference was not to discuss NAB expansion.
Rubin was clarifying US President Bill Clinton's recent proposal which called for a new IMF mechanism to help shield countries from economic difficulties elsewhere.
Only when the United States provides adequate funds to initiate such a new mechanism -- depending on Congress approval of the allocation -- will other countries and areas follow suit, Rubin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID SUPPLYING NUKE WEAPON DESIGNS TO PAKISTAN

TEXT.P: A US Congressional commission has confirmed that Beijing supplied Pakistan with designs for a nuclear weapon, nuclear weapons assistance, and complete ballistic missile systems, the New Delhi-based daily, The Hindu, reported recently.
"China poses a threat to the US as a significant proliferator of ballistic missiles, weapons of mass destruction and enabling technologies," the commission was quoted as saying.
The commission, headed by former Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, also accused Beijing of carrying out extensive transfer of technology to Iran's solid-fueled ballistic missile program.
"North Korea, Iran and Iraq as well as India and Pakistan now have an increased incentive to cooperate with one another," the report said.

"They have extensive access to technology, information and expertise from developed countries such as Russia and China. They also have access through commercial and other channels in the west, including the United States," it added. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY BE PRESSURED TO CANCEL MILITARY DRILLS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's cancellation of military exercises is a catalyst for friendlier ties across the Taiwan Strait and will pressure Beijing to follow suit, a mainland affairs official said on Saturday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, lauded the decision to cut short a series of military exercises, adding that the move creates an amicable atmosphere as the two sides prepare to meet for the first time in five years.
Chang Jung-kung, director of Mainland Affairs Research Department under the Kuomintang said the military's decision should be interpreted as an expression of goodwill rather than a surrender.
He refused to speculate about Beijing's possible response to the cancellation, but said it will pressure Beijing to follow suit and perhaps cancel some of its military exercises.
Meanwhile Yen Wan-ching, director of the China Affairs Department under the Democratic Progressive Party, doubted the move would invoke a friendly response from Beijing.
Noting that Beijing has not renounced the possible use of force against Taiwan, Yen ridiculed the military's move as nothing but casting pearls before swine.
Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Fei announced the cancellation of drills slated for Oct. 7 and Oct. 12 after a rehearsal for the exercises was held on Friday.

The exercises were to showcase the armed forces' newly-acquired weaponry, which was adequately displayed in the exercises, Lin said. The cancellation of the remaining drills will in no way affect the military's strength or capability, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES VISIT BY HUNGARIAN ECONOMIC MISSION

TEXT.P: An official with the Republic of China's Foreign Ministry on Saturday welcomed the planned visit to Taiwan by a Hungarian economic mission scheduled for mid-October.
R.T. Yang, director of the Foreign Ministry's European Affairs Department, said the visit will attract the attention of government officials and business executives.

As Asia's financial difficulties appear to be deepening, Taiwan businesses have been exploring alternative and new markets outside Asia, Yang said. Therefore, the government has attached much importance to the visit by the Hungarian mission.
The seven-member mission is scheduled to arrive on Oct. 12 and will depart on Oct. 15.

Among the organizations sponsoring the visit are the Hungarian Trade Office in Taipei, the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs, the China External Trade Development Council, and the Taipei-based Euro-Asia Trade Organization.

During their stay in Taiwan, members of the Hungarian mission will confer with ROC officials and meet with important business leaders. They will also attend an investment symposium titled "Hungary -- the Gate Leading To Europe" at the Howard Plaza Hotel on the morning of Oct. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA ESTABLISHES TAIWAN TRADE CENTER IN WARSAW

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) shifted Taiwan's stronghold of trade from Vienna, Austria to Poland's capital of Warsaw, leading the island's businessmen to Central and Eastern European markets.

The opening of the Taiwan Trade Center in Warsaw was celebrated in a ceremony held on Sept. 30, said R. T. Yang, director of the department of European Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

The ceremony was presided over by Lin Chen-kuo, chairman of the board of CETRA. The mayor of Warsaw, director of Asian Affairs under Poland's Foreign Affairs Ministry, and officials from Poland's Finance Ministry were among the guests at the gathering, said the MOFA official.
All of the trade office's units available for lease have been reserved, Yang noted, adding that this fact alone indicated Taiwan merchants' confidence in doing business in Eastern Europe.

Cheng Meng-sung, board chairman of Acelon Chemicals & Fiber Corp., announced at the ceremony that the corporation's Poland investments will be increased to US$493.75 million from the original US$200 million, Yang said.
The director of MOFA's department of European affairs also cited Poland's officials as saying that relations between Taipei and Warsaw have changed, and that Poland should enhance ties with Taiwan.
Meanwhile, the Economic Cooperation Convention between the ROC and Poland was held on Sept. 29 in Warsaw, which was the fourth such meeting between the two sides.

Members of Taiwan's delegation, headed by CETRA's Lin, included: Chen Ruey-long, director general of the board of Foreign Trade, Ministry of Economic Affairs; Wang Chang-ching, CETRA adviser; Lee Yung-san, chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China; and Huang Yeu-ming, chairman of the Taiwan Knitting & Textile Association.

The Polish delegation was headed by Andrzej Arendarski, president of Poland National Federation of Industry & Commerce. Its members included: Warsaw's mayor; governor of the province of Tarnow; governor of the province of Piotrkki Trybunalski; Jacek Piechota, chairman of the committee of small- and medium-sized enterprises in Poland's Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLING ENCOMPASSES STRANGE GOODS, SAYS COAST GUARD COMMAND

TEXT.P: Judging from the types of items seized by authorities, nothing is too strange to smuggle into Taiwan, sources from the Coast Guard Command (CGC) reported on Saturday.
In September, when garlic's prices surged around the island, garlic made up the bulk of the smuggled trade, followed by pig offal, CGC officials noted.
Four Taiwan vessels were found smuggling 295 cartons of cigarettes, garlic and pig offal worth about NT$17 million (US$500,000) at street value.
Other, more exotic items were also found, such animals classified as protected species. These included 17 ostriches, 580 chestnut mice, 80 squirrels, and 160 lizards, CGC officials said.

Smuggling is not limited to commercial goods. In various operations in September, authorities reported 18 cases of "human smuggling" in which 33 people from mainland China were trying to sneak into the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO EXAMINE LENDING PRACTICES

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) will audit financial institutions with poor operation records and those with heavy exposure to firms in financial trouble, a bank official said on Saturday.

The audits will take place after the Mid-Autumn Festival, CBC Deputy Governor Shea Jia-dong said. The examination has been ordered after a spate of local firms were declared insolvent due to large debts to banks.
Although the CBC's responsibility is to manage financial policies, it will begin examining institutions that have lent generously to deadbeat firms, Shea said.
He did not reveal the names of the banks that will be examined.

Institutions regulated by the CBC are 16 bills finance firms, and 13 domestic and foreign banks. However, the target of the audits will be those heavily involved with troubled firms, and those giving credit to front firms which intended to cash in on its junk stocks.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR HITS FOUR-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar continued gain ground against the weakening greenback in Taipei Saturday, rising NT$0.288 to close at a four-month high of NT$33.71.
The interbank US dollar trading hit US$324 million, the largest weekend transaction of this year.
The local currency opened at 33.818 and was traded at between 33.93 and 33.685.

The NT dollar found favor among buyers and is expected get stronger against the greenback, which recently dropped to its 20-month low against the deutsche mark and is seen entering a bearish phase in the international currency market, dealers said.
Taiwan's currency will likely surge to NT$33 against the US dollar by the end of the year, dealers predicted.

Central Bank of China (CBC) Deputy Governor Hsu Chia-tung said Saturday that he was glad to see the unit appreciate. He added that the current international currency trend -- such as the US cutting interest rates -- is beneficial to the NT dollar's stabilization.
The local unit depreciated by 15 percent to 20 percent since last July when Asian currencies underwent a meltdown.

Hsu also said he is not concerned that the NT dollar's appreciation would harm Taiwan's exports as the currency is still essentially under-valued, a situation which gives Taiwan competitive edge on export.

If the NT dollar appreciates, the currencies in Japan and South Korea, the island's major trade competitors, will also go up in line with the global trend. Therefore, their foreign trade will never threaten local exporters, the financial expert stated.
The banker further said that despite the currency fluctuations, the CBC will remain consistent in sparing no effort to preserve financial stability and economic growth in Taiwan.

Although the CBC is now imposing a loose currency policy, the bank will never allow loose capital circulation to damage the island's foreign exchange, Hsu said, stressing that the CBC will uphold a currency policy beneficial to both the fund and foreign exchange markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SHARE PRICES, FUTURES INCREASE

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rising 183.97 points to close at 6,619.97.
The bourse opened at 6,481.08 and continued its upward trading, encourage by an overnight increase on Wall Street.
A total of 2.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$71.09 billion (US$2.1 billion) during the weekend session.
Gainers outnumbered losers 416 to 35, with 38 stocks unchanged.
All eight stock market categories posted gains, with plastic and chemical shares rising the most at 5.6 percent.
Meanwhile, prices on the stock index futures also saw gains.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October soared 152 points to close at 6,550, with 2,383 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for November increased 124 points to finish at 6,483; those for December surged 130 points to 6,450; those for March moved up 119 points to 6,419; and those for June climbed 53 points to 6,350.
Contract transactions for these futures totaled 181, 56, seven, and two, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF CHINESE COMPETING IN AUSTRALIAN ELECTION

TEXT.P: A record number of Chinese Australian candidates took part in Saturday's federal election since the Commonwealth of Australia was proclaimed in 1901.

Of the 72 candidates from the newly-established Unity Party competing for seats in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia in both the House of Representatives and Senate, 17 are of Chinese descent, according to party president Peter Wong.
Among the 17 candidates of Chinese origin, three are from mainland China and the remainder are either from Hong Kong or were born in Australia and have parents from the former British colony.

The three candidates from China are Chen Bin, Tan Lin and Gao Nining. Others are Jason Li, Andrew Su, Chris Wong, Henry Pong, Matthew Wong, Tong Sumrith Somchai and Penny Tong Sunrith, all of whom are competing in New South Wales.

Contesting in Victoria are Huynh Toah, Chua Ka-sing, Geoffrey Teng, and Wellington Lee. May-yie Leung is competing in Western Australia while Henry Fong and Chris Toogood are vying in Queensland, Wong said.
"This is the first time such a (high) number of candidates from Chinese communities in Australia are contesting the seats in Parliament," Wong said in an interview with the CNA on Saturday.

He said the United Party was not established only for Chinese and Asian migrants, but it is also for other migrants from Italy, Greece, India, Israel, Arabian countries, and other white and non-white people.
"The purpose of our party is to unite all the migrants together, including white migrants. We have no racial discrimination to any race, colors, religion and cultures," he said.

The establishment of the Unity Party came after the wide showing of the One Nation party in the recent Queensland elections. One Nation, headed by Pauline Hanson, backs anti-Asian immigration and anti-Aborigine policies.
"We Chinese migrants want to show the major parties and One Nation that we have our own strength and racism will have no place in Australia," Wong said.

He admitted that the chances for victory among Unity Party candidates are slim, but he is confident that one of the Chinese candidates -- Jason Li, who was born in New South Wales after his parents emigrated from Hong Kong -- has the best chance to win a seat in the Senate.

Li, 26, is a lawyer in Sydney who formerly worked as a judge's associate at the United Nations International Criminal Tribunal for the Yugoslavia as an international law consultant to the International Commission of Jurists in Geneva.
