"Even if we win one seat, we can (show) major parties (that we have) strength so they will not ignore our existence in the future," Wong said. He said a 5 percent showing in the election will be enough to ring alarm bells in major parties.

Disappointed by Prime Minister John Howard's weak response to Hanson's anti-Asian comments, Wong quit the Liberal Party in July and launched the Unity Party which now has over 3,000 members throughout Australia.

Prior to establishing the party, Wong was a senior member of the Liberal Party's Chinatown branch in Sydney and was the chairman of the Ethnic Affairs Commission and director of the Herbal Department of the University of Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC APPRECIATES SUPPORT FOR ITS UN BID

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Saturday expressed its gratitude for the 25 countries which threw support behind Taiwan's bid to rejoin the United Nations at the general debate session of the 53rd UN General Assembly.

"We appreciate these countries for their coming forward to appeal for world attention to our reasonable demand for representation in the United Nations," said Andrew L.Y. Hsia, director of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations.

During the Sept. 21-Oct. 2 general debate session, senior leaders from the 25 countries voiced either explicit or indirect support for Taipei's UN bid from various angles, ranging from the principle of membership universality, Taiwan's capabilities to contribute to the world society, legitimate rights to regional security.

"Through their eloquent, rational debate, we believe the international community has come to a better understanding of the unreasonableness and outdatedness of the 1971 UN Resolution No. 2758, which admitted mainland China into the world body at the expense of the Republic of China," Hsia explained.

Stressing that rejoining the UN is a common aspiration of all ROC nationals, Hsia said MOFA will continue to campaign for Taiwan's UN representation with patience, pragmatism and nimble strategy that reflects the general international trends and circumstance.
Hsia also renewed his call on mainland China to drop its hegemonic, bullying mentality toward Taiwan and to cease its efforts to block Taiwan's UN accession.

"We believe the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should respect each other and cooperate in the international arena. Only by so doing can we forge mutual trust, narrow differences and create a climate favorable to eventual reunification," Hsia said.

This was the sixth consecutive year that the ROC had spearheaded its UN campaign through its diplomatic allies. Hsia said even though the bid, like previous ones, failed to make the annual General Assembly agenda, the ROC government will continue the annual campaign to enlist global support for its cause.

Hsia said MOFA has reviewed its promotional strategy annually. Local observers are watching whether MOFA will adjust its tactics after an ice-breaking visit to the mainland by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman C. F. Koo, from Oct. 14 through Oct. 19.

Meanwhile, a CNA report from New York quoted Teng Shen-sheng, head of the ROC representative office in New York, as saying on Friday that the United Nations should play a more active role in resolving the Taiwan Strait issue.
Noting that maintaining peace is the UN's top mission, Teng said the UN should understand that preventive diplomacy is the best way to prevent outbreak of military confrontation.

"If both sides of the Taiwan Strait are seated in major international organizations, including the UN, on an equal footing, they will be able to forge good will and mutual trust to pave the way for eventual peaceful reunification under freedom and democracy," Teng explained.

The 25 countries that spoke for the ROC's UN bid this year were: Burkina Faso; Latvia; Costa Rica; Paraguay; Nicaragua; the Dominican Republic; the Czech Republic; Honduras; El Salvador; Swaziland; Liberia; Belize; the Gambia; Fiji; the Commonwealth of Dominica; Saint Christopher and Nevis; Saint Vincent and the Grenadines; Senegal; Chad; Malawi; Guatemala; Grenada; the Solomon Islands; Haiti; and Sao Tome and Principe.

Latvia, the Czech Republic, and Fiji do not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC. Panama was the only ROC ally in the United Nations that didn't voice support for the bid at this year's general debate session. Nevertheless, Panama was the 15 ROC allies that signed this year's motion asking the UN to re-examine Resolution No. 2758, which expelled the ROC to make way for mainland China. The motion was presented in July.
The UN Steering Committee rejected in September the inclusion of the motion into this year's General Assembly agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN SPEAKS ON IMPROVING PUBLIC WELFARE

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Saturday urged everyone in Taiwan to participate in efforts to improve the public welfare so that "an enormous social transformation" can be achieved.
Lien made the appeal at the opening of a symposium on public welfare sponsored by the National Development Research Cultural and Educational Foundation at the Grand Hotel.
The improvement of public welfare is in line with the people's wishes and is a globally accepted goal.
Lien, who is expected to run in the 2000 presidential elections, defined public welfare as the realization of people's happiness and sense of contentment.

He said there were four guarantees in the improvement of public welfare. They are to secure people's property from being damaged by disaster, disease and theft; protect the environment from improper destruction; ensure continued economic openness allowing people to enjoy sufficient investment and employment opportunities; and to share the fruits of these endeavors equally extending assistance to the old, weak, women and children.

As to how to put these four guarantees into practice, Lien said it is important to maintain balance -- the balance between private property and public property, the balance between production and environmental protection, the balance between efficiency and fairness.
The vice president urged the public to join hands in dealing with the common problems facing society and to contribute to the success of a social transformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MORE DEATH SAID CAUSED BY ENTEROVIRUS

TEXT.P: The deadly enterovirus is being blamed for two more deaths, increasing the number of victims claimed to seven since Sept. 25, the Department of Health (DOH) reported on Saturday.
The latest victims were an 8-month-old baby in Taoyuan County who died from meningitis, and a 2 year old in central Taiwan who died of heart and lung failure, the DOH report showed.
The report also indicated that from Sept. 25 to Oct. 3, a total of 812 patients suspected of having contracted enterovirus were reported. Of these, 93 children were categorized as seriously ill.
Regarding the sudden recent spread of the virus, the DOH decided to resume its daily reports on the epidemic and call on the public to be vigilant against the enterovirus, a DOH official said.
The health department had gone from daily reports to weekly reports on the enterovirus epidemic since July 24 when the contagion was believed to be under control.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA TELLS WORLD 'STAY OUT OF OUR AFFAIRS'

TEXT.P: Malaysian politicians issued a warning calling on countries to "stay out of our affairs," as international criticism mounted over injuries Anwar Ibrahim sustained while in police custody, The Straits Times reported.
They also warned countries not to isolate Malaysia or Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad or Malaysians will close ranks behind the government, the paper said on Saturday.
Politicians were quoted as saying that foreign leaders were ready to pass judgment on Malaysia and its institutions prior to the outcome of investigations on alleged police brutality.

"This is strictly a domestic matter. Before they make uncalled-for remarks, they should attempt to get a true picture of the situation through official channels," Umno supreme council member Datuk Ibrahim Ali told The Straits Times.
The United States, Canada, Australia and other countries have voiced concern over the government's decision to detain Anwar under the Internal Security Act.
Criticism increased Thursday after Anwar was brought to court with a swollen left eye and bruises on his arm. Anwar said he was assaulted while held at police headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 NABBED FOR ATTEMPTING TO SMUGGLE HEROIN INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Three ROC nationals were arrested late on Friday for attempting to smuggle a large amount of heroin into Taiwan from mainland China, airport police said on Saturday.

Security officials at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport first spotted an 18-year-old man, identified as Tsai Tze-yuan, acting suspiciously upon his arrival on a China Airlines flight from Hong Kong at around midnight.

Security officers then joined forces with customs inspectors to detain Tsai and search his luggage. Through an extensive search, they discovered eight heroin bricks, weighing a total of 2,810 grams, under a wooden plank in his baggage.
Tsai told police that his boss, Tsai Chin-hsing, who arrived on the same flight, owned the drugs and managed to escape via a taxi after authorities detained Tsai Tze-yuan.

Airport police alerted highway police which intensified road patrols in search of the culprit. They managed to intercept the taxi carrying Tsai Chin-hsing, 38. Another accomplice, Chou-Huang Wen-pin, 41, who was also in the taxi, was arrested.
Tsai Chin-hsing told police that he was commissioned by a mainland man, nicknamed Qiyu, to smuggle the drugs from the southern mainland province of Guangdong to Taiwan via Hong Kong.

The three drug traffickers have been transferred to the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office for further questioning. Police said they will further investigate and bring to justice any other accomplice who may be involved in the case.
CKS Airport police also arrested a Macau resident, identified as Jou Ion Chau, at midnight on Thursday for attempting to smuggle 5.51 kilograms of high-grade heroin into Taiwan from Thailand.

It was the fifth time in the past month that CKS Airport police have intercepted residents of Hong Kong and Macau attempting to smuggle narcotics into Taiwan, police said, adding that they will tighten inspections to curb such criminal operations.

Meanwhile, police warned local residents not to visit casinos when in Macau to avoid falling prey to international drug trafficking rings which reportedly target people who lose money while gambling to tempt them into smuggling contraband drugs into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE HOMEMADE GUNS, AMMUNITION IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Taoyuan police raided a house in Kueishan Hsiang in Taoyuan County early Saturday morning and seized a cache of homemade guns and ammunition.
Authorities arrested Chung Fang-lung, 28, on charges of violating gun and ammunition control laws.
The owner of the house, Chang Yu-kun, and his wife Yang Lang-fang were also arrested for allowing Chung to turn the house into a make-shift ammunitions factory.

Chung was taken into custody and questioned on theft charges at the Taoyuan Detention Center several days ago. During interrogation, police discovered that Chung may have remodeled guns and sold them.
During the raid, authorities seized four remodeled pistols, five partially-remodeled ones, 20 bullets for three different kinds of pistols and remodeling tools.
Chung told police that he learned how to remodel guns and make bullets from articles in magazine he bought in flea markets.
Police said they believe two of Chung's remodeled guns had already been sold. They will continue their investigation and try to trace the flow of the ammunition to the gun owners.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S REMARKS ON CAREER BUILDING

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said here Saturday that Taiwan will try to promote democratization, modernize its financial system, streamline its government structures, and improve its administrative efficiency to welcome the coming of the 21st century.
Lee made the remarks when addressing an annual meeting of "youth career building models" from Taiwan and abroad sponsored by the Youth Career Development Association in Taipei.

Lee said Taiwan has been able to create the so-called economic miracle in the past half century mainly because it has abundant creative and diligent manpower. Taiwan is able to weather the Asian financial storm, because it has worked hard to improve its economic fundamentals for many years.

He said Taiwan has virtually no foreign debts. The businessmen of Taiwan are able to run their businesses faithfully and steadily. Taiwan's small and medium enterprises are versatile and flexible in doing business. The government's transparent financial policies have contributed to their success, he added.
Forty-four entrepreneurs, including President Stan Shih of the Acer Group, were cited in the meeting for their outstanding achievements in career building.

Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew said at the meeting that there will be bountiful business opportunities in the next century, when competition in the business world will be very keen. The best way the private enterprises can do to survive the competition is to always try to overtake themselves, he added.

All successful enterprises in the next century must be creative, flexible, and fast in doing business, he said, adding that "the future world will belong to those who dare to dream and are able to create bravely."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO FIGHT CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: The "Corruptive Behaviors Watch" Saturday issued an open letter, saying that the problem of corruption in mainland China should be discussed in the upcoming third plenary session of the 15th Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee.

In the letter to the mainland Chinese central government, the organization of dissidents from seven provinces said more than 100 million mainland Chinese are suffering from the effects of floods and unemployment, while the problem of corruption is getting worse. The letter was made public through the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China.

They said in the letter that anti-corruption should be put on the agenda of the CPC meeting, so that effective measures may be mapped out to wipe out the problem of corruption. News media should be allowed to expose corruptive behaviors, they added. The meeting will open on Oct. 12.

The Corruptive Behaviors Watch was organized recently by dissidents from Henan, Zejiang, Jiangsu, Anhui, Jiangxi, Sichuan, and Hunan provinces. Their application for registering the organization has not been approved by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories for Sunday in Taiwan's major daily newspapers are as follows:
The China Times: Second-quarter overdue loans of the banking departments of Farmers' Accociations islandwide totaled NT$90 billion.
The United Daily News: The finance ministers of G-7 countries met Saturday to discuss financial crisis.
The Liberty Times: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.288 Saturday to reach a four-month high.
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday called for accelerated national development for the next century.
The Independence Morning Post: The Taiwan Stock Market gained over 100 points and the New Taiwan Dollar climbed nearly NT$0.3 Saturday.
The Commons Daily: Poll shows over 75 percent of the public want the military to better war preparedness.
The China Post: Australian Prime Minister John Howard narrowly won re-election.
China News: The NT dollar continued its jump Saturday. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE DATE RAPE DRUG IN PUB RAIDS

TEXT.P: Taipei police seized several thousand FM2 pills, sometimes referred to as the date rape drug, during a pair of pub raids early Sunday morning.

Police, posing as patrons at popular teenage hangouts, seized more than 2,200 FM2 pills at one Roosevelt Road pub. At another pub on Nanking East Road, they seized 20 MDMA pills and a bag of marijuana.
The raids are the first sting operation Taipei police have conducted since new drug prevention regulations were enacted last May.
During the raids, police detained a total of 39 pub patrons, including Chen Kung, 55, a member of the Bamboo Union gang.
FM2, which has no color or smell, is often used by rapists to knock out their victims before they are molested. After they awaken, the victims have no recollection of being assaulted.

In addition to the FM2 pills, police seized during the raid MDMA pills and other substances. Police would not rule out the possibility that the substances were FM2 or MDMA substitutes, imported from overseas, or new FM2 and MDMA derivatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TARGETS CITED FOR KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: The major purpose of the upcoming visit by C. F. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, is to reopen constructive dialogue with the mainland, said a ranking official with the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Sunday.

The other two prime purposes of Koo's mainland trip are to improve bilateral relations and to rebuild the mechanism of two-way institutionalized talks through constructive dialogue, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing said at a seminar sponsored by Nanhua Management College.
Koo, who is the chairman of the foundation, is scheduled to begin a six-day visit to mainland China on Oct. 14.
Koo will tour Beijing and Shanghai and meet with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of official contact.

As to the question of whether the planned Koo-Wang meeting would pave the way for a summit between President Lee Teng-hui and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Wu said it is too early to speculate.
Taiwan is open, however, to all sorts of bilateral negotiations with mainland China on equal footing if Beijing respects the existence of the Republic of China, he said.

Beijing's attitude toward Taiwan after the planned Koo-Wang meeting next week will serve as the major barometer of future cross-strait ties, the SEF official explained. Should Beijing continue bullying Taipei in the international community, it will be hard for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to improve relations, he claimed.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chiu Yi-jen, secretary-general of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said he was doubtful that the Koo-Wang meeting would help bring about a Lee-Jiang summit.

As Koo's upcoming mainland trip has been defined as a "visit and tour to meet and chat with friends," Chiu predicted that the Koo-Wang meeting will not produce any concrete results, let alone clear the way for a Lee-Jiang summit.
The Koo-Wang meeting, he said, will only help the two sides to release a message that they are willing to resolve their differences through peaceful means.

While Taipei wishes to use the Koo-Wang meeting to push for the resumption of regular SEF-ARATS negotiations, Beijing's attempt to use it to clear the way for bilateral political talks will be a gargantuan task, he opined.
Chiu also said it is hard for Taiwan to ward off mainland China's "one China" offensive. He suggested the government play the "democracy card" to counter Beijing's strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL TURMOIL AFFECTING TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 50 percent of the public said that Asia's financial turmoil has had a great effect on Taiwan's economy, despite government claims to the contrary, according to survey results unveiled Sunday.

Nearly 40 percent of the public also said that their financial status has turned worse since January. More than 30 percent said that they are not optimistic about the local stock market this year, the survey showed.
The survey was conducted by opposition New Party between Sept. 30 and Oct. 2 on adults aged 20 or older. Some 1,156 effective samples were received with a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

Jaw Shau-kong, NP campaign manager, said that although government leaders have stressed that Taiwan's economy has not been affected by Asian financial storms, the survey showed that 26.9 percent of respondents said the effects were "very serious," while 31.7 percent called them "serious." Only 18.4 percent said they were "not serious" or "not very serious."

Some 32.8 percent said they were pessimistic about the stock market's performance between now and the end of the year, while only 5.9 percent said that they believed prospects are bright, the survey showed.
In addition, 39.4 percent of the people polled said that their financial status has turned worse since January, while 52.4 percent said that their situations are relatively unchanged.

Though the majority of people polled said they do not worry about losing their jobs, some 28.8 percent said that they are worried that they could lose jobs in the next year, and 35.4 percent said that they are worried that family members might lose their jobs.

The poll results also revealed approval ratings of financial officials and government leaders. Some 39.5 percent of those polled said that they have been satisfied with Finance Minister Paul Chiu's performance this year, while 40 percent said that they were satisfied with the performance of Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang.
Some 46.1 percent said that they were satisfied with the performance of Premier Vincent Siew, and some 44.4 percent said that they were satisfied with President Lee Teng-hui's performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: U-LAND AIRLINES EYES SE ASIAN MARKET FOR FUTURE EXPANSION

TEXT.P: U-Land Airlines, a member of the financially stricken U-Land enterprise group, filed a medium- and long-term operation program with the Civil Aeronautics Administration on Saturday, in which it is eyeing future expansion into the Southeast Asian market.
After discussing the matter with high-ranking U-Land Airlines officials, U-Land Group Chairman Chow Chi-jui has decided the airline will continue to operate.
To improve its financial situation, U-Land Airlines plans to sell three MD-82 carriers and then lease them back.

The airline estimated its turnover this year will reach NT$1.2 billion, up 20 percent from last year. U-Land Airlines will likely discontinue its Taipei-Kinmen and Kaohsiung-Kinmen services, as flights on both routes had average occupancy rates ranging from 50 percent to 60 percent. The airline plans to continue, however, its Taipei-Kaohsiung service.
Eyeing expansion into the Southeast Asian market in the future, U-Land Airlines now owns a 40 percent stake in Air Philippines and a 30 percent stake in Vietnamese Pacific Airlines.

U-Land plans to expand its plane flotilla by purchasing Boeing 747-400s and MD-11s, and perhaps even Boeing 777s, when it is ready to begin offering chartered flights from Southeast Asia to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: U-LAND ANNOUNCES RESUMPTION OF OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Chou Chi-jui, president of the financially troubled U-Land Group, announced late Saturday that the group will fully resume operations next week.

Speaking at a news conference at U-Land's headquarters in central Taichung City, Chou said all the group's affiliates will resume normal operations starting on Wednesday and that he will call a press conference then to make public the group's future plans.

Chou's remarks came after local newspapers reported over the weekend that U-Land members suspended operations on Friday after checks totaling about NT$170 million (about US$5 million) issued by a textile and a construction firm belonging to the group bounced on Wednesday and Thursday.

Apologizing for the damage caused by the incident, Chou vowed that "all U-Land staff and workers are committed to fully resolving the problems" and made assurances that he himself will assume responsibility to the end and will never "escape."

Acknowledging that not everything has been settled, Chou said U-Land's structure is sound and that many business groups have shown keen interest in the group. A banking consortium has also agreed in principle to extend support to the group, he added.

Meanwhile, sources familiar with the banking sector revealed that U-Land was able to resolve its financial crisis so quickly because the group had won the backing of a business group based in southern Taiwan.

Two or three business groups have shown interest in taking over U-Land's operations since the group was reported to have been saddled with financial difficulties, the sources said, though they refused to identify which ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITY PARTY LEADERS PLEASED WITH ELECTION RESULTS, BUT NO SEATS WON

TEXT.P: None of the 72 candidates of the Unity Party, including 17 Chinese Australians, were elected to Parliament, but the newly established political group performed quite well in some key electorates.

In a press release faxed to CNA on Sunday, Unity Chairman Peter Wong said: "These results show that in only 14 weeks, the people who have suffered under racism and the fear of Pauline Hanson and One Nation have stood up and been counted."
He said in a number of key seats in New South Wales, Unity has fared better than One Nation, and in many seats it fared better than the Democrats and Greens parties.

The fielding of 17 Australian Chinese candidates, who are either migrants from mainland China and Hong Kong or born of parents of Chinese descent, was the largest ever in terms of number since the Commonwealth of Australia was proclaimed in 1901, he said.
Wong said the election results had proved the Unity Party would no longer be overlooked by either the country's major parties or its media.

"This is proof that if you speak out strongly and loudly against racism, it will have an effect on the population. I challenge the major parties to speak out now, and denounce the results of One Nation in this election," Wong said.

He said: "One Nation has received continued coverage by the mainstream press for the past two years, yet with only coverage in the ethnic and some local press, Unity has in 14 weeks outpolled One Nation in key seats."

In a speech to his supporters in Sydney on Saturday night, Prime Minister John Howard said: "I want to dedicate my government to the maintenance of traditional Australian values ... including the values of tolerance and treating people decently and not discriminating against people according to their races and ethnic backgrounds."
"We are a nation of many parts and origins and we should never forget that. And we should see that is a tremendous asset," he added.

Political analysts said Howard had learned a lesson from the racial backlash resulting from his unwillingness to initially condemn Pauline Hanson when she made a speech in 1996 that was characterized as racist, anti-Asian, anti-multiculturalism and anti-foreign investment.
In an interview with CNA, Unity media adviser John Hawker revealed that the next step for the Unity Party would be to take part in the New South Wales (NSW) election on March 27, 1999.

He said the Unity did not anticipate winning any seats in Saturday's elections, as the party was formed less than three months ago. But the party performed quite impressively in the elections, he said.
"However, we are confident from the experience in this just-concluded election, we could win one to two seats at the NSW election next year," he said.
The Unity Party has now a membership of more than 4,000 people throughout Australia and Hawker said the number will continue to rise in the coming months and years.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR LABOR LEADER SAID TO BE READY TO QUIT POLITICS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will soon lose a good friend in Australian politics, as Gareth Evans, former foreign minister under the Labor government and now deputy leader of the Labor Party, has said he will soon quit politics, saying it is time to move on to something different.

He told Australian Broadcasting Corp. Saturday night, "I won't be running for the deputy leadership of the party, probably won't be running for the front bench and I'll probably be leaving the Parliament."

Evans, who retained the Victorian lower house seat of Holt, was philosophical and gracious when he made his decision. He refused to concede defeat in the Oct. 3 election but said the odds were dramatically stacked against the Australian Labor Party (ALP).
The ALP on Saturday grabbed at least 17 additional seats in the House of Representatives, boosting its number from 49 to between 68 and 70.

But the Labor Party has failed to win a majority, losing to the coalition of the Liberal and National parties under Prime Minister John Howard. The coalition maintained control, winning about 77 seats in the 148-seat House of Representatives.
"Obviously I haven't been thinking about this at all closely because we've been living in hope that we'd bring home the bacon. That doesn't seem likely now," Evans said.

"I've been in Parliament now for 20 years and I think I've had a pretty good experience, longest-serving Labor minister, along with Ralph Willis, Cabinet minister, in the country's history. I think I've had a pretty good innings," he said.
Evans was sympathetic toward Taiwan because the Republic of China is a democratic country with a highly developed economy, according to Associate Professor C. L. Chiou.
He was the only senior opposition leader to meet Premier Vincent Siew when the latter made an overnight stopover in Brisbane in July.
"The departure of Evans from politics will be a loss to the ROC on Taiwan," Chiou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION LEADER LOSES SEAT IN AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENT

TEXT.P: Controversial Member of Federal Parliament Pauline Hanson's dream of becoming a new political force in Australia turned into a nightmare as she lost her bid for a second term in Saturday's elections.

Hanson became a household name overnight after making a speech at the Parliament in September 1996 in which she demanded the government halt Asian immigration, abolish multiculturalism, stop foreign investment and substantially reduce subsidies to Aboriginal people.
Her divisive comments in Australia resulted in nationwide racial debates, which received widespread coverage not only in Australia but also in Taiwan, Hong Kong, mainland China and Southeast Asia.
She founded One Nation Party in April 1997, and the party managed to win 11 seats in Queensland's Parliament in state elections on June 13.
In Saturday's elections, however, the party won only one seat. Hanson had earlier predicted that One Nation might win as many as 12 or 13.
National Party Senator leader Ron Boswell said One Nation was all but finished as a political force.
"(Hanson) had her chance to make the big time here and she has failed," Boswell said.
Regarding the election results, Hanson told Australian media on Sunday: "I was extremely disappointed." She added, however, that the party would go on.
David Oldfield, Hanson's senior adviser, also lost his bid to capture the Senate's New South Wales seat.

Analysts said that if the party does not tone down its rhetoric, it may face political extinction. "Unless they learn from the embarrassing election result and act rationally and reasonably in the future and try to refrain from inciting racist sentiment and instead mapping out good policies for the interests of Australians, the party will be abandoned by the people," one analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN SUFFER LOSSES IN RECENT RIOTS IN LESOTHO

TEXT.P: It is estimated that Taiwan businessmen lost 100 million rand (about US$22 million) during recent riots in Lesotho, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Sunday.

Timothy Yang, MOFA's director of the Department of African Affairs, noted that riots broke out when clashes between anti-government protesters and Lesotho troops turned violent on Sept. 22. Two of Lesotho's neighbors, South Africa and Botswana, had sent troops into the country to maintain peace and stability.

Yang said that after the riots, the ROC's offices in South Africa had coordinated to evacuate all Taiwan businessmen to a town near the Lesotho-South African boarder except for members of 14 Taiwanese households located within safer industrial zones.

Yang said that Du Ling, representative of the Taipei Liaison Office in the Republic of South Africa, traveled to the town to meet with the ROC nationals and provided them with 50,000 rand on behalf of the government for emergency use.
Yang said that the government is watching closely developments in Lesotho and will take whatever measures are necessary.

Meanwhile, the head of the South African coordination office of Taiwan's largest charity organization said that on the morning of Sept. 22, the rioters began to burn and loot buildings and shops in the capital, Maseru.

Shih Hung-chi of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu-chih Foundation, said that more than 95 percent of the shops in Maseru were destroyed and that goods in the shops were plundered. Only a few factories, under the protection of the army, were spared, he added.
About 50 Taiwan-run shops and 300 mainland Chinese-run shops were burned and looted during the riots. A Taiwanese businessman surnamed Chen suffered losses of NT$60 million (US$1.76 million).
Shih said that Tzu-Chi members in Lesotho and South Africa had helped mainland Chinese in the region seek safety.
Shih said that about 500 mainlanders temporarily lived in the homes of Taiwan businessmen, while about 90 people lived in church shelters and about 40 lived in Chinese schools.

He said that after taking care of the Taiwanese and mainlanders, Tzu-Chi members visited a refugee camp, of which nearly 90 percent of the camp occupants were women and children. The group donated three tons of maize powder, 300 kilograms of cabbages and potatoes to the camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-UK ECONOMIC RELATIONS BEING BOOSTED
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Juan Mu-hua and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A British official in charge of foreign investment is scheduled to visit Taipei at the end of this month to seek further investment from Taiwan and strengthen bilateral economic relations.
Official statistics indicate that Taiwan's investment in Britain has continued to grow at a time when other Asian countries are reducing investments there amid financial difficulties.
The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said that a computer assembly plant built in Scotland by Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. will start operating soon.
The US$24 million plant occupies some 110,000 square meters, and the number of local people who will be employed there is expected to increase from 300 to 560 over the next three years.
The new plant, Hon Hai's second in Scotland, will not only become a major production center but will also serve as the headquarters of Hon Hai's European operations.
The Hon Hai group also maintains production plants in mainland China and the United States.

While Japan and South Korea has invested more in Britain in recent years than Taiwan has, the financial crisis that started last year has seen both Japan and South Korea curb investment in Britain, while the amount invested by Taiwan has grown.
As of last December, Taiwan had invested in a total of 91 projects in Britain, of which 53 involved electronics, nine involved financial services and eight involved transportation.
Besides the forthcoming visit by the British investment official at the end of October, the development bureau of London will set up its first overseas representative office in Taipei on Oct. 7.

An ROC-UK business council will also be inaugurated at the end of this month, with support from the Board of Foreign Trade under Taipei's Ministry of Economic Affairs. The council is aimed at promoting economic relations between Taiwan and Britain.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR'S RIGHT-HAND MAN RESIGNS FROM MAYOR'S RE-ELECTION TEAM

TEXT.P: A member of Taipei Mayor Chen Sui-bian's re-election team resigned Sunday after being criticized by the ruling Kuomintang for frequenting illegal pubs in Taipei.
Accompanied by Lo Wen-chia, executive secretary-general of Mayor Chen's campaign headquarters, Ma Yung-cheng announced his resignation at 10 a.m.
Ma first apologized to the people of Taipei for visiting the Holiday and Big Town pubs. He said that he had gone to Holiday at the invitation of some Taipei city councilmen.
Ma said some politicians were more interested in attacking rivals than in putting forward their opinions on political matters. Such actions, he said, reveal their hypocritical nature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-CANBERRA RELATIONS EXPECTED TO IMPROVE

TEXT.P: The substantive relations between Taiwan and Australia are very close, and will continue to improve after Australia's general election on Saturday, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said here Sunday.
Early statistical returns of ballot counting indicated that the ruling coalition of the Liberal Party and National Party had won the election. Prime Minister John Howard has proclaimed victory.

The spokesman said the cooperative relations between the two countries in the fields of economic affairs, trade, investment, culture and education, science and technology, and tourism are very close. "The relations will continue to improve on this solid basis," he said.

In 1997, two-way trade between the countries amounted to US$5,100 million. Some 130,000 Taiwan tourists visited Australia last year. About 9,000 Taiwan students are receiving higher education in Australia. The two countries regularly hold conferences on cooperation in various fields, and have signed agreements on aviation, taxation, and cooperation in science and technology research.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MALAYSIA GROWS DESPITE TURMOIL
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Y. P. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan investment in Malaysia is still growing this year despite the fact that this Southeast Asian country has been hard hit by an ongoing financial crisis in the region, Paul J. K. Tso, ROC representative to Malaysia, said on Sunday.
Citing Malaysian government tallies, Tso said Taiwan investment in Malaysia totaled US$1.5 billion in the first seven months of this year, up 89 percent from the corresponding period of 1997.

As of this July, more than 1,500 Taiwan firms have poured in about US$8.5 billion worth of investment to Malaysia, making the island Malaysia's second-largest foreign investor after Japan, said Tso while addressing the opening ceremony of the eighth conference of Taiwan businessmen in Malaysia.

Two-way Taiwan-Malaysia trade hit US$7.25 billion in 1997, with Malaysia enjoying a trade surplus of US$1.2 billion. Taiwan is Malaysia's fourth-largest trading partner, while Malaysia ranks seven for Taiwan, according to Tso.
Answering questions from reporters, Tso said he believes that the currency controls imposed recently by Kuala Lumpur will greatly help export-oriented Taiwan businesses with operations here.
Judging from relevant statistics, Malaysia, rather than Thailand, is still the most popular investment destination in Southeast Asia among Taiwan businesses, he noted.

According to Tso, Taiwan investment in Malaysia is quite diversified, ranging from electronics to chemicals and farming. Nevertheless, some Taiwan firms based in the country are being affected by an increasing shortage of labor.

Malaysia also enjoys an advantage over Taiwan in tourism exchanges, he pointed out. In 1997, around 246,000 Taiwan people visited Malaysia, up from 222,000 in 1996, while about 164,000 Taiwan residents visited Malaysia in the first eight months of this year.
On the other hand, 54,000 Malaysian people have traveled to Taiwan so far in 1998, down from 56,000 in 1997. Only 31,000 Malaysian travelers visited Taiwan between January and August of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
T0e Central Daily News: Top seven industrial nations (G-7) will work together to stem the spread of financial turmoil.
The China Times: A researcher warned doctors against prescribing aspirin to treat enterovirus.
The United Daily News: G-7 finance officials reached consensus on cooperation to solve financial crisis.
The Liberty Times: G-7 agreed to cooperate to promote economic growth.
The Independence Morning Post: Ma Yung-cheng, special assistant to Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian's campaign headquarters, resigned amid accusation that he frequented girlie bars.
The Commons Daily: Scholars said in a symposium on the downsizing of Taiwan Provincial Government that it is best to scrap the TPG to upgrade administrative competitiveness.
The China Post: Mayoral re-lection campaign suffers as aid quits.
The China News: Mayor's top aide bows out.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEBT REPAYMENT TERMS TO FELL INDONESIA'S GIANT CHINESE CONGLOMERATES

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Chinese conglomerates, stripped of their political links, may soon be only bit players in the new economic landscape as they are forced to liquidate assets to pay off huge debts to the government, which has decided to accept only cash, according to Singapore-based The Business Times.
The situation presents the authorities with an opportunity to break the hold these conglomerates have over the economy in one fell swoop.

Following in the footsteps of the Salim and Gajah Tunggal Groups -- which recently pledged to transfer assets of US$7 billion to the Indonesian government -- more than half of the country's biggest conglomerates could face the same fate, the newspaper said.

Owing billions of dollars to Bank Indonesia (BI) -- the central bank that injected more than 150 trillion rupiah (US$13.7 billion) into banks owned by these conglomerates to keep them afloat -- their owners are finding it next to impossible to honor commitments to repay the central bank with cash, analysts told The Business Times.
Having been unable to meet an earlier deadline of Sept. 21 to repay the liquidity credits granted by BI, the owners have now been given one year to raise the necessary cash.
"None of the owners has the cash to repay BI so they will have to make up by selling assets including property," said Harvey Goldstein, president director of PT Harvest International.
Ray Anthony Gerungan, deputy head of research at GK Goh Ometracto, agreed, noting that many of these conglomerates will be emasculated over the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBETAN GOVERNMENT-IN-EXILE DENIES DALAI LAMA HAD LINKS WITH CIA

TEXT.P: The Tibetan government-in-exile has denied media reports indicating the CIA had links with the Dalai Lama from the late 1950s until the early 1970s, saying there was no direct connection between the CIA and the Tibetan spiritual and temporal leader.

The New Delhi-based English newspaper The Indian Express reported from Dharamsala that Tibetan Minister of Information and International Relations T. C. Tethong said the Dalai Lama was did not receive CIA assistance, although the agency was involved with early guerrilla operations waged by Tibetan freedom fighters.
Tethong stressed that all the financial transactions during those early guerrilla operations were handled by the elder brother of the Dalai Lama, Gyalo Thondup.

While the money, reportedly as much as US$1.7 million per year, allocated for the resistance movements by the CIA was spent on training volunteers for guerrilla operations against mainland China, the subsidy earmarked for the Dalai Lama (amounting to US$180,000) was used to finance the establishment of Tibetan representative offices in Geneva and New York and for other international lobbying activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINO-SAUDI ARABIAN ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFERENCE TO BEGIN SOON

TEXT.P: The 16th Sino-Saudi Arabian Economic Cooperation Conference will be held Oct. 10 in Riyadh, sources said.
A delegation from Taiwan, to be headed by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, is expected to participate in this year's conference.
The Saudi Arabian delegation will be led by Saudi Arabian Basic Industrial Cooperation Vice President Muhammad bin Hammad Al-Mady.
Among the topics expected to be discussed during the conference are trade and investment, science and technology, transportation and vocational training.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE BILLION PEOPLE UNDEREMPLOYED OR UNEMPLOYED: REPORT

TEXT.P: A record one billion people -- a third of the global workforce -- are unemployed or underemployed, the Geneva-based International Labor Organization (ILO) said in its 1998 World Employment Report Sunday.
"Growing unemployment would bring more poverty and inequality across the world," the ILO report warned.

The ILO report pointed out that the East Asian financial crisis would increase joblessness by 10 million directly and up to 20 million indirectly this year, bringing the total of those formally unemployed, mainly in industrialized countries, to 150 million, from 120 million in the mid-1990s.

Add to that about 900 million estimated to be "underemployed" -- those who want to work more or are unable to earn a living wage -- and the ILO arrives at its one billion figure. Prospects have worsened substantially, the ILO said, since its last employment report two years ago.

The East Asian crisis, which was revealing the "dark and unacceptable face of globalization," has boosted Indonesia's unemployment rate from 4 percent to 12 percent and increased the numbers of Indonesians in poverty from about 22 million to 80 million.

In South Korea, unemployment has jumped from 2.6 percent to 7 percent, while in Thailand the jobless rate is expected to reach 6 percent this year, compared with between 1 percent and 2 percent two years ago.
Meanwhile, about 3.5 million workers are expected to be laid off in mainland China this year, according to the ILO report.

DOC.HEADLINE: DANISH TRADE OFFICE EYEING TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Danish Trade Organization's Taipei Office announced on Sunday it will seek to strengthen ties with Taiwan, as the island's economic development and its performance amid the ongoing Asian financial crisis has commanded Denmark's attention.

A spokesman for the office said that beginning on Oct. 12, it will sponsor a series of activities to mark the 15th anniversary of its founding in Taiwan as part of its efforts to provide a better understanding of Denmark to the local business community.

A number of Danish business leaders, including Transport Association Chairman Laus Peter Lange and Industrial Designer Association Chairman Frederick Rikman, will visit Taiwan and host investment seminars in Taipei and Taichung.

Denmark hopes to upgrade and enhance its economic relations with Taiwan in order to boost bilateral cooperation opportunities, since small businesses are the major driving force behind the two economies, according to the spokesman.

To those Taiwan businesses interested in developing new technologies, Denmark would be a good partner, the spokesman said, adding that the country's good location and transport services are also a great advantage for Taiwan firms seeking to edge into northeastern European markets.
Denmark has a population of 5.2 million people, and its per-capita income averaged US$36,000 in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN COMPANIES FACE CREDIT CRUNCH AS US BOND MARKET CLOSED OFF

TEXT.P: Australian corporate borrowers are facing a credit crunch because the current global financial crisis has closed US bond markets to foreign companies, analysts said.

Top Australian companies such as Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., Lend Lease, Hoyts, Star City and Citipower have tried to raise funds through syndicated bank loans, but they were shocked to find banks are insisting on borrowing margins between 45 percent and 90 percent higher than those of one year ago, analysts said.

Bankers revealed the margin they offered is between 60 and 65 basis points (one-hundredth of 1 percent) above bank bills -- half as much again as the 40 basis points or so above the benchmark paid on a similar, expired loan.

"Basically what we're seeing now is a very accelerated contraction in bank liquidity and with that, we're seeing a rather dramatic increase in pricing," one unnamed corporate treasurer told the Australian Financial Review.
He said the situation has been made worse for Australian borrowers because they have nowhere else to turn.

Until recently, many companies could look to US bond markets for help in debt financing, but the global financial crisis has closed the US bond markets to foreign companies, including those in Australia, the treasurer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE SENDS MESSAGE TO IISI'S ANNUAL CONFERENCE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 32nd annual conference of the International Iron and Steel Institute (IISI) opened in Taipei on Monday. ROC President Lee Teng-hui sent a written message to the conference to offer his congratulations.
Lee lauded the IISI's contributions to the promotion of international cooperation, information exchanges and operating environment improvements.
He said the steel industry will continue to play an important role in Taiwan's future development and said the IISI was welcomed to hold its annual meeting in Taipei.

The three-day conference opened at the Taipei International Conference Hall, with the participation of delegates from 53 member countries and more than 200 steel companies, steel associations and related research institutions.

IISI Secretary-General Lenhard J. Holschuh told the meeting on Monday that because of the fallout from Asia's financial crisis, it may take two or three years -- and perhaps as long as seven -- for the world's steel consumption to rise by 10 percent.
But he said he foresees an upturn in Taiwan's steel consumption next year because of the expected increase in Taiwan's infrastructure spending.
Holschuh put Taiwan's steel consumption this year at 20,040 metric tons, down 2.9 percent from the preceding year. For next year, however, he forecast a 5.9 percent increase.

At a meeting of the IISI Board of Directors on Sunday, USX Steel President Thomas Usher of the United States, currently an IISI vice president, was elected IISI president. He will take over the post from Francis Mer, chairman of France's Usinor Steel, after the close of the Taipei conference.
Wang Chung-yu, chairman of Taiwan's China Steel Corp., was elected as a new IISI vice president, together with current IISI Vice President Akira Chihaya, president of Nippon Steel Corp.

Wang told the media on Monday that he personally welcomed mainland China's inclusion in the IISI, as do most IISI members. He said their inclusion in the organization would help improve their steel production know-how and prevent the pollution of mainland China's environment.
On Sunday night, the IISI held a reception to welcome the conference delegates. ROC Vice President Lien Chan was among the prominent figures invited to the reception.

At the reception Lien praised the outstanding contributions the IISI has made over the past three decades. He said he believes the Taipei conference will serve to further advance the prosperity of the world's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS SPEND MORE ABROAD AS FOREIGNERS SPEND LESS IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Singaporeans spent an estimated S$9.1 billion (US$5.3 billion) abroad last year, up from S$8.2 billion in 1996 and S$7.2 billion in 1995, according to figures from the Trade and Industry Ministry.
These estimates from the Department of Statistics indicate that the amount spent by Singaporeans outside the Republic has gone up by an average of 13 percent per year over the last three years.

Not surprisingly, the bulk of overseas spending was in neighboring Malaysia, where Singaporean tourists spent about S$2.98 billion last year. That figure represents a slight decline from the S$3.09 billion spent there in 1996, though it is higher than the S$2.75 billion spent there in 1995.
The second most popular overseas destination for Singaporeans was Indonesia, where spending has increased steadily from S$1.08 billion in 1995 to S$1.29 billion in 1996 and S$1.50 billion last year.
The steady increase in the amount that Singaporeans are spending abroad contrasts starkly with amount that foreigners are spending in Singapore, based on figures from the Singapore Tourism Board.

In a report released in August, the board said that foreign tourists spend just S$4.78 billion in Singapore last year, 8.3 percent less than in 1996. The amount spent on shopping has declined as well, contributing to a retail slump. Shops in Singapore reported a 28 percent plunge in sales during the nation's recent Great Singapore Sale compared with its 1997 sale.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT MAY LIFT BAN ON BIG BANK MERGERS

TEXT.P: The coalition government of the Liberal and National parties under Prime Minister John Howard is expected to lift a ban on big bank mergers following its election-day victory on Saturday, banking analysts said.
They said a buying rush for bank stocks is likely this week in anticipation of the ban's being lifted.
They said the return of the coalition government to power for another three-year term would bolster the share prices of Australia's big four banks.

The Australian Labor Party earlier said it would continue to ban the mergers of the country's larger big banks -- including Westpac Banking Corp., ANZ Banking Corp., the National Australia Bank (NAB) and the Commonwealth Bank -- if the party won the election.
NAB has been the most vocal advocate of lifting the ban on big bank mergers. Analysts predicted that NAB would test the coalition government by trying to merge with ANZ.
"Big bank mergers are back on the agenda; that's the upshot of the coalition's win," a fund manager said.
But other analysts said there could be a gradual lifting -- rather than an immediate scrapping -- of the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: IFC ISSUES SINGAPORE DOLLAR-DENOMINATED BONDS

TEXT.P: The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced in August a series of measures to liberalize the use of Singapore dollars outside Singapore. These measures would make it easier for foreign entities to list Singapore dollar-denominated shares and to issue Singapore dollar bonds, in cases in which the proceeds would be used outside Singapore.
The aim was to develop broad and deep capital markets to attract a broad range of international issuers, investors and intermediaries.

The International Finance Corp. bond issuance is the first major bond issue denominated in Singapore dollars by an international issuer since the August announcement and also the first supra-national issue in Singapore.

"This is an encouraged development," said Koh Yong Guan, Managing Director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore. "We believe that this would help stimulate the growth of the debt market in Singapore."

Koh added that he expects more Singapore dollar bond issues by supra-nationals over the next year. "This is in line with our objective of developing as a center for the origination, listing and trading of foreign securities for the Asian region."

IFC is a member of the World Bank Group which includes the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Development Agency and the Multilateral Guarantee Agency. (Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOANS AT LOCAL BANKS REACH NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Affected by the Asian financial storm, the number of overdue loans at local banks is expected to total more than 4 percent this year.
The Central Bank of China (CBC) said that number of overdue loans in the first and second quarters amounted to 4.16 percent and 4 percent, respectively, and both figures were considered high.

CBC officials said that the percentage of overdue loans has climbed in the past five years, indicating that after the enactment of financial liberalization, monetary regulation has become lax, and regulators negligent.
The officials urged the banking sector to step up regulatory efforts to effectively cut the risks of bad loans.
They said that the rise in overdue loans can be attributed to a sluggish economy, lackluster stock market and an attempt by the banking sector to improve its performance.
The number of overdue loans at local banks in the past two years were 3.78 percent and 3.82 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE MONTHLY REPORTS ON TAIWAN'S ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy and political system are more open, competitive and mature than many of its neighbors, the latest issue of Business America Monthly said in its cover story.

John Hoover, an economic officer of the American Institute in Taiwan, the de facto US embassy in the ROC, contributed the story titled "Taiwan's Tiger is a Regional Leader" to the publication produced by the US Department of Commerce.

Hoover highlighted Taiwan's international economic power, discussed its bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), and described how the island has weathered the Asian financial crisis relatively unscathed.

As Taiwan is the world's seventh largest foreign investor, the second largest investor in mainland China and the third largest in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), it is only natural that it would want to enter the WTO, Hoover wrote.
Taiwan, as a world class trading economy and a major international investor, has much to gain from having representation at the WTO table, he added.

Hoover noted that although the New Taiwan dollar depreciated roughly about 20 percent against the US dollar over the past year, and its stock market fell along with other major international exchanges, Taiwan still racks up a perennial trade surplus, and its economy is set to grow by over 5 percent this year.

The reasons why Taiwan has emerged from the financial turmoil unscathed is because the island "is more open, more competitive, and more mature -- both economically and politically -- than many of its Asian neighbors," he said.
"Taiwan has long eschewed foreign debt, preferring to finance economic development using domestic funding and the retained earnings of its private sector," the report said.

Other contributing factors to the island's success amid the regional downturn is that Taiwan does not have an excessively overvalued, speculative real estate market, and its banking system is relatively healthy and stable, Hoover wrote.

"Structurally, Taiwan's economy differs in fundamental ways from those of its neighbors. The population is uniformly well-educated and highly skilled. The economy long shifted away form labor-intensive industries..." he added.

"Moreover, Taiwan's economy is dominated not by large conglomerates, but by tens of thousands of small- and medium-sized enterprises. Risk is therefore dispersed. Another benefit: the private sector is competitive and highly agile in adjusting to shifts in market conditions at home and aboard," the report said.

Taiwan's stable political leadership and prudent policy-making decisions were also noted in Hoover's report. He praised the island's leaders for exercising extreme care in monitoring and responding to the regional financial crisis.

Business America Monthly is the official publication of the International Trade Board under the Department of the Commerce. The cover of its September issue features an oil painting of a tiger to represent Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SCRAP BARTER TRADE OF FRUIT WITH SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will end its barter trade of fruit with South Korea this year as it goes against the grain of the World Trade Organization, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Monday.

BOFT officials said the barter trade of fruit between the Republic of China and South Korea -- which was disrupted after the two nations severed diplomatic ties in September 1992 -- resumed in 1994 and continued for three consecutive years.
Officials noted that South Korea imported a much lower amount of onions and fruit from Taiwan compared to Taiwan's imports of South Korean apples and pears, contravening the barter trade agreement.

In view of the lack of sincerity on the part of South Korea to import fruits and vegetables from Taiwan, trade and agricultural officials concluded that with such a big gap on barter trade, there was no reason to continue such a practice and barter trade consultations between the two sides was suspended in 1997.
The officials said they have notified South Korea that they will not hold barter trade consultations this year, but related trade issues will be discussed in a ROC-South Korea economic conference.

Furthermore, the practice of barter trade runs counter to the WTO norm therefore the government will scrap its barter trade agreement which is bound to be questioned by WTO members once Taiwan moves closer toward entering the world trade organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1ST HALF-YEAR LABOR PARTICIPATION RATE DOWN TO NEW LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's labor force participation rate in the first half of 1998 hit a 15-year low at 58.02 percent, according to figures released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Sunday.

The figures indicated that in the January-June period, men's labor participation rate remained high at 70.77 percent, up 0.02 percent over the same period last year. However, women's labor participation rate marked a 0.45 percent decrease to 45.38 percent.
The decline in the overall labor force participation rate in the first half of the year was no doubt caused by the drop in women's participation rate, the CEPD said.

Reasons for the decline were a protracted business slump, difficulty for aged women to find jobs or change jobs, women choosing early retirement, and the introduction of the Labor Standard's Law to the service sector that indirectly forced some women to quit the workforce, the CEPD said.
Taiwan's labor force participation shot up to a new high 60.93 percent in 1987. It began to decline in the following years and dropped to a 15-year low of 58.33 percent last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: W. AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT PLANS TO PROMOTE 'FOCUS TAIWAN' PROJECT

TEXT.P: The state of Western Australia is planning to promote a "Focus Taiwan" project aimed at enhancing trade and investment relations with Taiwan, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Australia said.
The Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) welcomed the project, deeming it beneficial to bilateral relations between the two sides.

Australia has been much affected by the Asian financial turmoil that began to sweep the region last summer, Taipei's economic office in Australia said in its report to the MOEA. It added that the monetary crisis taking place among Australia's leading Asian trade partners has prompted an economic recession in Australia.

Australian exports to mainland China alone dropped 17 percent in the first half of 1998 yet Taiwan was the third largest importer of Australian products in the first six months of this year, next to Japan and South Korea, the report indicated.

The Primary Products and Fishing Department of Western Australia's "Focus Taiwan" project aims to further develop trade relations as well as cooperative efforts between Taiwan and Western Australia in the field of agriculture, fishing and food industry sectors.

A cooperative agreement was signed last April between the Primary Products and Fishing Department of Western Australia and the Agriculture & Forestry Department under the Taiwan Provincial Government for the exchange of agricultural technology.

According to informed sources, primary items in the "Focus Taiwan" project include: increasing Western Australia's understanding of Taiwan's agricultural, fishing and food industry markets; raising the image of products of Western Australia in Taiwan's market; eliminating impediments of Taiwan's exports to Western Australia; arranging the exchange of visits by government officials and industrial personnel between the two sides; as well as the technical exchange of strategic alliances.

The Western Australia government's Primary Products and Fishing Department is also planning to establish an Agribusiness Partnership Club in Taiwan to act as an adviser to relevant cooperation and exchanges between the two sides, which will be conducive to a closer bilateral relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE PACIFIC OPERATIONS REMAIN NORMAL AMID U-LAND TROUBLES

TEXT.P: Vietnamese Pacific Airlines said on Monday the financial crisis of its business partner, U-Land Group, has not affected its operations and all its ticketing and flight services remain normal.

Vietnamese Pacific said in a news release that its business relations with U-Land Airlines, an affiliate of the group, are limited to the leasing of aircraft and agent services. There has been no impact to Vietnamese Pacific's normal operations, the release said, urging passengers to be calm.

According to local newspaper reports, U-Land Group will also resume full operations on Tuesday after U-Land Chairman Chou Chi-jui said over the weekend that he will assume responsibility to the end and that the group's financial problems are close to being resolved.
Two or three business groups based in central Taiwan and several creditor banks were reportedly willing to provide support to the troubled U-Land.

Checks worth a total of NT$170 million (about US$5 million) issued by a U-Land affiliated textile and a construction firm bounced on Wednesday and Thursday, raising grave concern from companies maintaining business links with the widely-diversified group.
U-land Airlines also halted flights on Thursday without prior warning, but immediately resumed full operations on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH PM BLAIR URGED TO HIGHLIGHT HUMAN RIGHTS IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Three mainland dissidents Monday sent an open letter to British Prime Minister Tony Blair, urging him to highlight Beijing's needs to respect human rights and protect the ecological environment in mainland China when he visits Beijing this week.

The three dissidents-- Leng Wanbao, Wang Zechen, and Xiao Lijun from the northeastern provinces of Liaoning, Jilin, and Heilongjiang-- expressed the hope that Blair will urge Beijing leaders to release political prisoners, including Shi Binhai, Fang Jue, Zhang Shanguang, Liu Xiaobo, Lihai, and Liu Nianchun.

They also requested Blair to urge Beijing to refrain from suppressing dissidents. The open letter was sent through the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China..
The dissidents also expressed the hope that Blair will urge mainland China to pay more attention to its need for ecological protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS SAID LANGUISHING IN JAIL, ON STREETS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo was languishing in an "education through labor" camp in the northeastern city of Dalian during the mid-autumn festival on Monday, his wife Liu Xia told a human rights organization.

She told the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China that her husband is suffering from duodenal and stomach ulcers, and that applications for his release on bail for treatment of the painful disease have been rejected on the ground that his chronic illness is not life-threatening.
Liu was sentenced to three years in "education through labor" camp in Oct. 1996 after he and dissident Wang Xizhe issued an open letter urging the government to initiate political reforms.

The information center also said in a press release that mainland Chinese authorities have not released another dissident, Kao Yu, for medical treatment despite her serious heart and skin diseases. She suffered two heart attacks last month and there are worsening ulcers in her skin.
Kao, a news reporter, was sentenced to six years in prison in Oct. 1993 on charges of "disclosing national secrets" in her article to Hong Kong news media.

The information center also reported that dissident Zhao Xin, his wife, and their three-year-old daughter are languishing on Beijing streets after being evicted on Oct. 4 by their landlord from the house they rented.

Kao was detained for one day after he and dissident Ren Wanding applied for registering the Beijing Preparatory Committee of the "China Democracy Party" last month. On Oct. 1 Beijing public security authorities told his landlord to evict his whole family from the house because he has no "temporary permit to reside" in Beijing, the information center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASPIRIN EXAMINED IN ENTEROVIRUS DEATHS

TEXT.P: It is too early to say that aspirin was the cause of death among children who had contracted enterovirus, the Department of Health (DOH) said on Monday.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, DOH acting director of the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, made the statement in response to a recent finding that several enterovirus victims had been given aspirin to reduce their high fevers.

Academia Sinica biomedical science assistant researcher Ho Mei-hsiang discovered that among 14 enterovirus-related deaths, six victims had taken or been injected with aspirin. Despite being widely used to reduce fever, aspirin has been banned in the treatment of sick children among the international medical community.

Ho said the use of aspirin on infants or children could cause the development of a serious condition called Reye's syndrome, a disease of the liver and central nervous system. In advanced cases, it can result in brain damage or death.
The disease, discovered in 1963 by R.D.K. Reye in the United States, kills about 30 percent to 40 percent of its victims.

Although she is not completely sure that aspirin caused the deaths of the patients with enterovirus, Ho said she knows that some pediatricians on the island are not qualified to write a treatment prescription.
Ho was commissioned by Academia Sinica and DOH to analyze about 60 deaths related to enterovirus since this summer. So far, she has completed her research in 14 cases.

Regarding the discovery, Hsu said it would be better to wait for the results of the analysis on other cases before coming to any conclusion. She noted that hospitals have been asked to find out whether children suspected of having contracted enterovirus had been given any aspirin before they were brought in for treatment.
Huang Li-ming, a pediatrist for the National Taiwan University Hospital, said he does not believe the deaths reported from May to July were related to Reye's syndrome.

Huang explained that most enterovirus victims died from heart and lung failure, as well as pulmonary edema, while patients suffering from Reye's syndrome usually die from increased pressure in their brains.
The only explanation as to how Reye's syndrome may have claimed the lives of enterovirus victims is that the disease further weakened patients' resistance to illnesses, Huang added.

Since September, there has been an increase of reported cases to the DOH of enterovirus patients. Following concern that the contagion may spread across the island again after its first outbreak this summer, the DOH has resumed its daily reports on the disease and has called on the public to be vigilant against the virus.

According to DOH's statistics, the number of victims claimed by the enterovirus reached seven since Sept. 25. Over the past 10 days, over 1,000 patients suspected of having contracted the virus were reported. Of these, 123 children were categorized as seriously ill, DOH said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVER FORTUNE MAY BAIL OUT U-LAND

TEXT.P: The Ever Fortune Group has indicated it may be willing to bail out the financially troubled U-Land Group after an executive reaffirmed Ever Fortune's commitment to U-Land affiliates on Monday.

Ever Fortune General Manager Chien Chao-han said although his company has contacted U-Land, Ever Fortune has not yet decided on its course of action and is still assessing the possibility of taking over U-Land.

Chien stressed that the most important issue is to protect customers' interests no matter which group takes control over U-Land. He called on the government and business community to provide assistance to help U-Land survive its present crisis, as it is a gargantuan task for an enterprise to grow from the scratch.

Operations of the widely-diversified U-Land -- which focuses mainly on the aviation, textile and construction sectors -- came to a halt last Friday after billions of NT dollars worth of checks issued by two of its affiliates bounced on Wednesday and Thursday.

However, U-Land head Chou Chi-jui quickly announced Saturday that the group's operations will be fully resumed on Tuesday, prompting speculation that certain business groups have agreed to bail out U-Land from its current financial problems.

Meanwhile, local newspapers reported that a business group based in the southern city of Kaohsiung will take over a construction project being launched by U-Land in central Changhua, while another group in southern Taiwan will take over the King Textile Co., the most profitable U-Land subsidiary.
U-Land Airlines announced over the weekend that it will continue to operate despite the group's financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: JP MORGAN SEES RECESSION AHEAD FOR SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The recent policy moves taken by Singapore's government have been encouraging, but will not prevent an economic recession in the city state next year, JP Morgan said in a report.
The US-based investment bank said in its latest "ASEAN Data Watch" report that the consistency and focus of Singapore's policy tack will go some way to bolster investor confidence.
"While some short-term pain can be expected, (the authorities') flexibility and prudence positively sparkles in comparsion to that displayed by other countries in the region," the bank said.
But Singapore is unlikely to escape an outright economic recession in the second half of this year and in 1999. The broad export trend is still weak and the medium-term outlook is uncertain.
"Looking ahead, the key signal of a turnaround in the global electronics cycle will likely be some establishment in prices -- very likely preceded by cutbacks in production," it said.

An increasing number of DRAM and electronics-related plants are now closing down, and this may help to stabilize prices temporarily. "But with global demand expected to slow further in 1999, the odds on price recovery continue to be long," it added.
The bank estimated that Singapore needs to cut business costs by around 30 percent to stay competitive with its key export rivals Malaysia, Taiwan, South Korea and Japan.
In addition, Singapore's reserves have dropped -- despite sustained balance of payments surpluses -- due to currency revaluation effects, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR STARTS AROUND-THE-ISLAND 'GRADUATION TRIP'

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong began on Monday what he called his "graduation trip" across the island before he leaves the post at the end of this year.

Upon his arrival at the northern city of Keelung, Soong said he felt regret that he failed to complete the rebuilding of the Keelung Harbor and Keelung's renovation project during his four-year tenure. However, he said his campaign promise to develop the harbor city during the 1995 election was mostly realized.

Soong, who was the first popularly-elected Taiwan provincial governor, will be the last elected member to the post. An appointed governor will replace Soong in late December when moves are taken to downsize the Taiwan Provincial Government.
Keelung is the first stop of Soong's final around-the-island trip as governor. During his tenure, Soong has traveled across the island twice to inspect township construction.

During his stay in the harbor-city, the governor visited the Taiwan Provincial Keelung Hospital. The hospital, which is over 100 years old, recently underwent a NT$200 million (US$5.9 million) renovation project with the assistance of the provincial government.
Soong also visited the Keelung Harbor, the island's second largest port.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILO CRITICIZES EXPORT ZONE STANDARDS

TEXT.P: The world is acquiring more and more export processing zones in response to globalization and the decentralization of industry. This rapid growth, however, has severe consequences for the 27 million people, 90 percent of them women, who work in the zones.

The Geneva-based International Labor Organization (ILO) estimates in a report that there are 845 such zones around the world. Of these, 320 are in North America -- the 213 maquiladora assembly plants in the US and the 107 Mexico. These zones export US$5 billion-worth of products a year, more than 30 percent of Mexico's total exports.
A further 225 zones can be found in Asia, including 124 in mainland China, 35 in the Philippines, and 26 in Indonesia. The numbers in Bangladesh, Pakistan and Sri Lanka are also growing.
In addition, the ILO report said, the zones are increasing in regions such as the Caribbean (51); Central America (41); and the Middle East (39).

The report said the zones are one of the main components of the foreign investment-led export-oriented industrialization strategy and a vehicle for globalization. When global production networks or chains are constructed, the zones provide the links.

The report pointed out that the zones are highly labor intensive, concentrating on garments, footwear, and electrical components, and providing jobs, especially for women, in developing countries. However, it added that "too many of them continue to be hampered by a reputation for low wages and poor working systems." The zones lead to little transfer of skills or technology to adjacent areas, it said.

"The frequent absence of minimum labor standards and poor labor-management relations have predictable outcomes," the ILO report said. These include high labor turnover, absenteeism, stress and fatigue, low rates of productivity, excessive wastage of materials, and labor unrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOUGHER PENALTIES FOR IMMIGRATION OFFENDERS IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: An amendment to Singapore's Immigration Bill, which went into operation on Monday, holds out the threat of stiffer penalties for some immigration offenses.
The new regulations have been put in place to enable Singapore immigration officials to deal more effectively with the illegal immigrant problem.
The enhanced penalties include penalties for:

-- Attempted illegal entry and departure. The penalties for attempted illegal entry and departure will be equal to those for actual illegal entry and departure. The maximum penalty for attempted illegal entry will be six months' imprisonment and a mandatory minimum of three strokes of the cane, while the maximum penalty for attempted illegal departure will be six months' imprisonment and a S$2,000 fine.
-- Abetment of illegal entry. Abettors will be punished with a mandatory minimum of three strokes of the cane, in addition to the existing penalty of between six months to two years' imprisonment.

-- Employment of immigration offenders. The maximum fine for employers (of more than five immigration offenders) will be increased from S$6,000 to S$10,000, in addition to imprisonment of between six months and two years. The maximum fine for corporate bodies that employ immigration offenders will be increased to between S$100,000 and S$200,000, from the previous S$50,000 to S$100,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENT DETAINED FOR HIS NEWSLETTER
