TEXT.P: Dissident Qin Yongmin of Wuhan, Hubei Province, was detained for one hour after his application for registering his news letter, "China Human Rights Observer", was turned down Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said in a press release that Qin filed an application with the Hubei Provincial Department of Civil Affairs for registering the news letter to coincide with Beijing's signing of the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights at the United Nations Headquarters in New York.

The information center said officials of the department turned down Qin's application right away and told him that it is illegal to do so. The officials told him to give up the plan, otherwise he will be punished by law. A few hours later he was taken away by policy from his home, and detained for one hour.
Qin said that he will continue to urge the government to abide by the international convenant and permit the registration of the news letter.

The mainland Chinese government should abolish all laws and regulations that are inconsistent with the international convenant, and enact new laws and regulations to replace them, he said, adding that the international community should see to it that Beijing faithfully observe the convenant.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Newsweek praises President Lee Teng-hui for his strong willpower.
The China Times: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications will construct 100,000 parking spaces.
The United Daily News: IMF predicts further worsening of the global economy.
The Liberty Times: The national health insurance program may undergo changes.
The Independence Morning Post: The enterovirus epidemic worsens.
The Commons Daily: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party accuses the Cabinet of vote-buying by increasing government budget.
The China Post: More smear, less policies are seen in mayoral race.
The China News: Rain triggers mudslides, 4 dead.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA URGES BEIJING TO RATIFY HUMAN RIGHTS COVENANTS

TEXT.P: Australia on Tuesday urged China to ratify the UN human rights covenants after Beijing signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) on Monday.

Despite signing the ICCPR, China appears to be backing away from allowing key individual freedoms guaranteed under a UN human rights treaty, according to a Sydney Morning Herald dispatch from Beijing published on Tuesday.

The paper quoted official Chinese media as saying that Beijing may have to curtail some rights guaranteed under the UN Covenant on Civil and Political Rights despite promises from senior Chinese government officials that the treaty would be fully implemented.

Australia Foreign Minister Alexander Downer welcomed China's signing of the ICCPR and urged Beijing to "take the necessary step to ratify and implement both the human rights covenants as soon as possible."

"The signature yesterday represents another significant step towards full adherence to international standards on human rights and complements China's signature on 27 October last year of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights," Downer said in a written statement.

Adding that he has consistently emphasized human rights in bilateral dialogue with Beijing, Downer said Canberra has demonstrated its commitment to the promotion of improved human rights standards throughout the world and Asia by pursuing dialogue with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MARKETS TUMBLE AMID GLOBAL PESSIMISM

TEXT.P: Canadian stock and currency markets tumbled on Monday in step with financial markets around the world amid continued global pessimism.
In Toronto, the TSE 300 index shed 181 points to close at 5,336. The Canadian dollar also had another bad day, falling almost half a cent to close at 64.25 US cents, the lowest level in five weeks.
The drop in the Canadian dollar came after Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard told associates that the province's general election has been slated for Nov. 30, according to Le Soleil daily.
A Quebec election is expected to cause political unrest in the rest of the country, giving currency traders another excuse to trade loonies for American dollars.

Investors blamed the latest sell-off in the stock markets on the lackluster results of a weekend meeting of the G-7 in Washington and the lack of new initiatives at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund.

Canada's Finance Minister Paul Martin said there has been progress and Bank of Canada Governor Gordon Thiessen stressed that markets will eventually focus on the continued expansion of the G-7 economies with the exception of Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANSON'S POLICIES CRITICISED BY NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has caused Australian diplomats to waste a lot of time and effort in easing concerns over her anti-Asian and anti-foreign investment policies, the Australian daily said on Tuesday.

The high profile of Hanson and her party have distracted Australian diplomats in Asia from doing their jobs and may have caused Australia to lose out on investment opportunities, the paper said in a political analysis.
After Hanson's dismal showing in the federal election, Asian media and commentators can now shift their attention to more vital topics than the policies of the One Nation leader, the Australian said.
The daily praised the Australian electorate for showing sophistication by not being influenced by Hanson's simplistic philosophy on race, international affairs and foreign investment.

Asian investors have been hit hard by the financial crisis, and Australian developers are now finding it difficult to sell property to Asians due to their declining wealth. One exception is Taiwan, the daily said, and they continue to look to Australia for investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: AN AUSTRALIAN SENATOR EXPECTED TO WIN BIG AMOUNT OF PENSION

TEXT.P: A Chinese-Australian senator lost his re-election bid on Saturday, but he is expected to win up to A$1.4 million (US$875,000) in a lifetime pension from the government, the Australian reported on Tuesday.

Bill O'Chee, a National Party whip, was Australia's youngest candidate to be elected senator when he won a seat at the age of 24 in May 1990. He will be the youngest Australian political pensioner on June 30, 1999, when at the age of 34, he steps down from office.
As he will have served for more than nine years in the Senate by that time, O'Chee is entitled to a lifetime pension starting at over A$44,000 (US$27,500) per year, the Australian reported.

Australian Members of Parliament who qualify for a pension can accept their money upon retirement or when they are defeated in an election regardless of age provided that they complete three terms or nine years of service.
O'Chee will likely receive his pension after he reaches the age of 60, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO GO AHEAD WITH IC CARD PLAN

TEXT.P: Contrary to Premier Vincent Siew's comments last week, plans for the national multi-purpose IC cards islandwide will continue as planned, a ranking government official in charge of the project said on Monday.

Kirby Chaur-shan Yang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC), said during a visit to Penghu Island that the promotion of the cards, which combine the functions of the National Health Insurance Card and the National Identification Card, will take place as scheduled.

Yang, at the head of a delegation composed of officials from the Criminal Investigation Bureau, National Health Insurance Bureau and officials in charge of households and population administration, is on island to explain and promote the advantages of the IC card
Three years ago, Penghu Island residents were the first in Taiwan to be introduced to the IC cards, and the use of the new cards has met with a positive response, Yang said.

He also addressed public concern that personal data or information from the IC cards may be obtained by unauthorized personnel, saying that precautions have been taken to ensure that this does not happen.

The planned IC cards will be limited mainly to health insurance and identification purposes, and users will be free to decide whether they want to attach additional functions to their cards, he noted.

These cards will help improve administration efficiency and prevent the forgery of personal identification documents, the RDEC chairman said. They will also be more durable than the current ID cards which are made of paper.

As to whether the multi-functional IC cards will include users' fingerprints, Yang only said that it would be legal to do so. He assured the public that the government will maintain a high-level of openness and transparency while processing the cards.

The RDEC is scheduled to sign an agreement with a contractor on Dec. 25 to produce the cards. If everything goes as planned, the first batch of cards in Taipei will be officially launched in June 1999 in the Daan district, he noted.

Yang said the RDEC will sponsor the first public briefing in Taipei on Monday afternoon to exchange opinions with experts and academics on the issue. The commission will also hold a series of seminars and publish position papers islandwide within the next three weeks to forge support, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REFUTES BEIJING'S ALLEGATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday refuted a mainland Chinese allegation that the Republic of China on Taiwan had "stolen" China's name in signing a key human rights treaty that calls for freedom of expression, religion and self-determination.
Mainland China's ambassador to the United Nations, Qin Huasun, signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights at the UN headquarters on Monday.

Qin's signing came exactly 31 years after the ROC signed the accord in 1967 when it was still a UN member state. Qin issued a statement after the signing that Taiwan's signature was illegal and "null and void."
In response, MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said Qin's statement distorted truth and twisted historical facts.

Wu said the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is one of the two accords seen as fundamental to protecting human rights. The other accord is the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.
According to UN regulations, only member states of the United Nations and its affiliated organizations or other countries invited by the UN can sign the two covenants.
The two treaties were adopted by the UN General Assembly in 1966 and went into force a decade later.
"The ROC signed the two treaties on Oct. 5, 1967," Wu said, adding that as the ROC was a UN member at that time, it was logically entitled to sign the accords.
"Qin's statement was not only confusing and misleading but also distorted facts and truth," Wu stressed.
The ROC lost its seat in the United Nations in 1971 when the world body accepted the communist government in Beijing as the sole representative of the Chinese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DROP ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and, despite regaining some ground in the day's trading, closed low on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, shedding 85.32 points to close at 6,534.

Affected by losses on the New York Stock Exchange, the bourse opened at 6,506.1 points, 113.87 lower than on Saturday's close. The index fell to 6,447.56 before rebounding to 6,534 by the closing bell.

A total of 2.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.54 billion, an increase from the previous trading session, in which 2.31 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$71.09 billion.

Three of the eight major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.6 percent and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent. Textile issues, meanwhile, remained unchanged.

The other four major categories registered losses, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by banking and insurance shares at 1.7 percent and cement stocks and foodstuff shares both at 0.9 percent.
Stock index futures were lower as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October dropped 100 points to close at 6,450, with 2,007 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 103 points to finish at 6,380, while December futures fell 100 points to 6,350, March futures declined 70 points to 6,380 and June futures decreased 100 points, closing at 6,305.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 88, 18, 23 and one, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN GROUP ACQUIRES ITALIAN SHIPPING COMPANY
DOC.DATELINE: Trieste, Italy, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Oscar Chuang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Evergreen Marine Corp. of Taiwan formally acquired Lloyd Triestino di Navigazione S.P.A. of Italy Monday, hoping to open a new chapter for the 163-year-old shipping company.
Chang Yung-fa, chairman of the Evergreen Group, signed the acquisition agreement in Trieste, the headquarters of Lloyd Triestino, in southern Italy.

More than 200 dignitaries from the two countries attended the ceremony. Local officials welcome Evergreen's acquisition of the company, hoping that the move will help the Italian shipping company upgrade its competitiveness and promote the development of the city.
Chang said that Evergreen and Lloyd Triestino have cooperated with each other over the past six years, but initially he had no desire to acquire the company.

He said that the Evergreen Group worried about the difficulties Asians would face in operating a European company and in acquiring all its shares, but the group decided to send officials to Italy to inspect the company after receiving encouragement from the Italian government.

Chang told all the staff working in Lloyd Triestino to rest assured that they will not be laid off after the acquisition, stressing that the name and personnel will remain unchanged. He also said he will hire as many local people as possible.
He said that he would spend about three to five years overhauling the shipping company to give it a fresh start.
Chang said that the size of Lloyd Triestino is only about one-tenth that of Evergreen, but he believed that it has the potential for development.
Chang said that his first step will be capital reduction and then capital increment, and he will also step up the promotion of markets in Austria, Switzerland, and East Europe.
The shipping tycoon said that Evergreen will send its fully automated ships to Lloyd Triestino in the future to help upgrade its competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar surged NT$0.253 against the greenback in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 33.457.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 33.65, and had a high of 33.446.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$718.5 million. (By Elizabeth Hsu

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH EXPECTED TO EXCEED 5 PERCENT IN 1998: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth will exceed 5 percent in 1998, and the civil consuming growth rate is also expected to be greater than 6.6 percent in the second half of this year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan announced Tuesday.
Hsu Chang-yao, director of the third bureau of the DGBAS, said that although the domestic consuming price slipped, there is absolutely no chance of igniting a flurry of deflation.

The annual growth rate of Taiwan's average consumer price index in the first nine months in 1998 was 1.3 percent, in addition to an estimated 7 percent civil consuming growth rate in 1998 and a 6.6 percent increase in civil consuming growth in the second half of 1998. These figures indicate there in no chance of Taiwan experiencing deflation, said Hsu.

Generally speaking, Hsu said, deflation refers to a negative growth in price and to consumers' deferring their purchases, resulting in a decreased willingness to consume. Hsu cited Japan as a typical example of a deflationary economy and said Taiwan's situation is different.
Under the backdrop of a currency that is rising against the US dollar, Taiwan's economic growth in 1998 is expected to exceed 5 percent, Hsu added.

Besides, according to the statistics published Tuesday by DGBAS, a 0.39 percent annual growth rate in the consumer price index in September was the lowest growth rate increase since March. It is expected that the annual growth rate of consumer prices in 1998 can be kept under 2 percent -- between 1.5 and 1.6 percent -- according to the report.

The consumer price index in September was 0.62 percent higher than August's index; compared with the same period last year, however, the annual growth rate is lower, a phenomenon that will help keep domestic prices stable, the DGBAS director commented.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE KUAN YEW FEARS NEW RIOTING AGAINST INDONESIA'S ETHNIC CHINESE

TEXT.P: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said in an exclusive interview with The Australian that he was worried about a second wave of arson and violence against the ethnic Chinese in Indonesia.
In the interview Lee said he could not rule out the imminent return of serious social disorder in Indonesia.
"The ethnic Chinese in Indonesia are fearful of a second wave of arson and violence, which can come as the food situation deteriorates," he said.
Lee said the economic crisis in Indonesia and in other Asian countries shows no signs of abating.
There are about 7 million ethnic Chinese in Indonesia. They account for about 3 percent of Indonesia's total population of 205 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN NATIONS HAIL ELECTION LOSS OF PAULINE HANSON

TEXT.P: One Nation leader Pauline Hanson's defeat in Saturday's federal legislative elections is welcome news across Asia and has given rise to better relations between Australia and countries in the region, according to The Age of Melbourne, a leading Australian daily.

In a dispatch from Bangkok titled "Asia Hails Hanson Loss" on the front page of Tuesday's Age of Melbourne, correspondent Craig Skehan reported that from Beijing to Bangkok, newspaper editorials and government officials have expressed hopes that the poor performance of One Nation will help alleviate concerns in Asia about the rise of the far right in Australian politics.
Fears of Hanson's party have reportedly affected Asian tourism to Australia and threatened to lead to a reduction in the number of foreign students who come to Australia to study, the daily reported.
A Thai Foreign Ministry spokesman said: "We welcome the rejection by an overwhelming majority of the Australian electorate of policies being put forward by the One Nation Party."

"It does away with this irritant, that suspicion on whether One Nation reflected the broader views of Australians. The majority have not succumbed. Australia really is part of the region and we are able to take them at their word when they say they want to be part of Asia," he added.

A front-page story in the official China Daily newspaper said politicians from across the Australian political spectrum had been quick to welcome the "humiliation of the far-right which split Australia over its anti-immigration and anti-Aboriginal policies."
In a previous editorial, The Nation newspaper in Thailand accused the government of Australian Prime Minister John Howard of being unwilling to adequately counter Pauline Hanson.
But the daily has changed its tune, however, as a recent editorial praised both Howard and opposition leader Kim Beazley, because "they mounted a joint assault on Hanson's racism."
"Now that the election is over and Australians have passed their verdict, we hope that the coalition will pay more attention to the Asian economic crisis and other regional issues," The Nation said.
The Asian Wall Street Journal said the election result meant outsiders would no longer be able to unfairly brand Australia as a racist country.
The daily reported Australian diplomats in Asia were relieved that the rejection of One Nation was widely reported in Malaysia and the Philippines.
They believed this would go a long way to dispelling Asian misconceptions about Australia's attitude toward the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ISSUES POSITION PAPER ON KOO-WANG TALKS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued a position paper on Tuesday to woo public support for the upcoming talks between the top negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The position paper outlined the main purposes of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo's forthcoming ice-breaking visit to mainland China and the ROC government's expectations of the future development of cross-strait relations.

Koo, a veteran business tycoon who concurrently serves as a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui and Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, will visit Shanghai and Beijing from Oct. 14 through Oct. 19. During his landmark mainland visit, Koo will meet with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

MAC, which oversees SEF operations, said in its position paper that it hopes the upcoming Koo-Wang talks will lay a foundation for the resumption of institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue and for the improvement of cross-strait ties.

Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore in April 1993 to lay a framework for regular SEF-ARATS dialogue and consultations. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended such institutionalized engagements shortly after President Lee made a landmark visit to the United States. Beijing interpreted Lee's US trip as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

The MAC position paper said the upcoming Koo-Wang talks are expected to pave the way for gradual restoration of the spirit of previous SEF-ARATS agreements and to lay groundwork for future cross-strait negotiations.
The position paper went on to say the ROC government earnestly hopes that mainland China can forsake its diplomatic suppression and military intimidation against Taiwan.

Only through these concrete actions can mainland China substantiate its intentions of improving cross-strait relations based on the recognition of the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are being ruled by two separate political entities.

"We are also hopeful that following the upcoming Koo-Wang talks, cross-strait relations will enter a new stage in which the two sides engage in frank talks and pragmatic exchanges," the position paper said, adding that the two sides should jointly seek effective ways to resume institutionalized dialogue and forge peaceful, cooperative bilateral ties in order to contribute to stability and prosperity in East Asia.
Meanwhile, MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh briefed a group of lawmakers of different political stripes on the itinerary of Koo's mainland trip.
Chang told the legislators from both ruling and opposition political parties that even though Koo's mainland trip is of great significance, it is not a very complicated mission.

"We hope local people will not expect too much and avoid adding up to Koo's burden," Chang said, adding that the primary goals of Koo's mainland trip and his talks with Wang are to normalize the long-stalled SEF-ARATS exchanges and to lay a foundation for improvement of cross-strait ties.

Chang also sought the lawmakers' understanding that the delegation to accompany Koo on his mainland trip will comprise only SEF board members and will not include representatives of any political parties. "The arrangement is mainly to avoid complicating the matter," he explained.
According to the schedule unveiled by MAC and SEF, Koo will leave Taipei for Shanghai via Hong Kong on Oct. 14 and will travel to Beijing from Shanghai on Oct. 16.

During his stay in Shanghai, Koo will meet Wang for several times for wide-ranging talks. While in Beijing, Koo will meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Vice Premier Qian Qichen and Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council. Koo will also visit Beijing University and meet with Taiwan business people with interests in mainland China as well as with Chinese and foreign journalists stationed in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LESOTHO POLITICAL PARTIES AGREE TO FORM TRANSITIONAL STRUCTURE

TEXT.P: Political parties in Lesotho have agreed to accept a proposal from the Southern African Development Community (SADC) on the formation of a transitional structure for a general election.
The SADC-proposed committee will comprise one or two members from each party taking part in the election, to be held within 15 to 18 months.

Announced after a meeting between the ruling Lesotho Congress for Democracy and opposition parties Monday, the proposal calls for the establishment of a transitional committee that would help create conditions conducive to the holding of free and fair elections for all parties.
The committee would appoint a new independent electoral commission to review Lesotho's electoral system.
The incumbent government will continue to rule until the election under the proposal.

Lesotho's political situation became chaotic late last month after opposition parties alleged last May's general election was rigged and staged protests. At the request of Prime Minister Pakalitha Mosisili, South Africa and Botswana sent troops to Lesotho to help maintain peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: STEEL BEAM MAKERS ACCUSED OF DUMPING PRODUCTS ON TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: South Korea, Poland, Russia were accused Tuesday of dumping steel H-beams in Taiwan, selling them at below-market prices, according to sources from the International Trade Commission (ITC).

Officials from ITC's Investigation Division said H sections of iron and non-alloy steel from South Korea, Poland and Russia have been dumped on Taiwan's market, causing substantive harm to domestic steel producers.
The ITC began to investigate the sale of iron and non-alloy steel H-beams from South Korea, Poland, Russia and Australia in Taiwan after receiving complaints filed by Tung Ho Steel earlier this year.
After the investigation, ITC decided to drop Australia from the list of offenders because the volume exported from that country was found to be too small to warrant possible retaliatory measures.

ITC will pass the dumping charges to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) for recognition. The MOF will then pass the charges to the Executive Yuan for final approval. If the charges stand, dumping taxes will be affixed to products from the three countries, ITC officials noted.
Meanwhile, the ITC also accused South Korea and India of dumping steel wires in Taiwan at below-market prices.
ITC officials said uncoated stress-relieved steel wires, used in making pre-pressed concrete, from South Korea and India have been dumped on Taiwan's market, hurting local producers.

Similar products from Spain were also under investigation, but they were dropped from the list of offenders after it was determined that Spain's export volume to Taiwan was too small to merit inclusion on the list.
Steel wires from South Korea and India may be hit with dumping taxes if the ITC's dumping charges are recognized by the MOF and approved by the Executive Yuan, ITC officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVER FORTUNE, HONG CHUNG TO BAIL OUT U-LAND

TEXT.P: The financially troubled U-Land Group received a new lease of life on Tuesday after two local business groups confirmed that they will bail the company out of its current crisis.

Ever Fortune General Manager Chien Chao-han said his company, along with the Hong Chung Group, have decided to jointly take over U-Land's construction division. Each will continue with one of the two construction projects being carried out by U-Land in central Changhua County, and U-Land claimed that all its customers' interests will be fully protected.

However, Chien added that Ever Fortune is not likely to take over King Textile Co. and U-Land Airlines, two major U-Land subsidiaries, because textiles and aviation are beyond the scope of Ever Fortune's businesses.
Operations of all U-Land affiliates came to a halt on Friday after checks totaling about NT$170 million (about US$5 million) issued by King Textile and the group's construction division bounced.
The group's financial turmoil was reportedly caused by too-fast expansion.

Although the incident raised grave concern among companies maintaining business links with U-Land, U-Land President Chou Chi-jui quickly announced last Saturday that the problems were almost resolved and that the group would fully resume operations on Tuesday.
Hong Chung head Lin Hung-chung said his group decided to extend a helping hand to U-Land out of a sense of social responsibility and family links. Lin is Chou's uncle.
Lin expressed the hope that Hong Chung's assistance will help maintain the livelihoods of all U-Land staff and workers and will stave off any impact on the country's economic development.
Meanwhile, U-Land Board Chairman Lin Lung-shen apologized for the damage to society caused by the incident.
As of Tuesday, operations of U-Land's headquarters in central Taichung City had returned to normal.
The group is scheduled to hold a news conference in Taipei on Wednesday to explain its current financial situation to the public and put forward a plan for its future operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-DIRECT 'THREE LINKS' ACTIVISTS TO VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan activists will leave for Beijing on Wednesday to push for the opening of direct trade, transport and communications links across the Taiwan Strait, more commonly known as the direct "three links."

Chin Chieh-shou, leader of the group who is also a Taipei County Council member from the pro-unification New Party, said on Tuesday that the Beijing visit is mainly aimed at pushing for the inclusion of the "three links" issue into the agenda for the upcoming talks between the top negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chin was referring to the planned talks between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) scheduled for mid-October. Koo is scheduled to visit Shanghai and Beijing from Oct. 14 through Oct. 19.
"We hope the Koo-Wang talks will discuss the 'three links' issue because we believe that early opening of such links will benefit Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chin said.

The group, composed of a dozen elected representatives and their aides, will pay visits to mainland China's Ministry of Communications, the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council and quasi-official ARATS. Members of the group include National Assembly Deputy Tsao Yuan-chang, Taipei City Councilor Lee Cheng-lung, and Hsinchu County Councilor Kuo Yuan-chang.
Chin said his group most looks forward to seeing direct cross-strait transport links become a reality in a gradual manner.

In the initial stage, Chin said he hopes scheulded direct ferrying services can be opened between Taiwan-held defense outpost of Kinmen and Xiamen, a port city in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian.
In the second stage, Chin proposed that Taiwan's merchant vessels and passenger planes be allowed to sail or fly to Xiamen via Kinmen.

Chin also proposed that Taiwan's merchant ships and commercial airliners be allowed to sail or fly to mainland China's inland destinations via Xiamen in the third stage and that full-fledged direct cross-strait transport links be opened in the final stage.

To highlight its cause, Chin said, his group may return to Taiwan via a fishing boat sailing directly from Xiamen to a Taiwan port. Chin would not divulge the Taiwan port that the group may land on its return voyage.
Chin and several other members of the group have been indicted on charges of violating the National Security Law for sailing directly from Taipei County's Shenao fishing port to Xiamen on Aug. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT SUISSE BANK APPROVED TO SET UP TAIPEI REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE

TEXT.P: An application by the Credit Suisse Bank to open a Taipei representative office was approved on Tuesday, the Bureau of Monetary Affairs (MOF) announced.

In a press release, the MOF indicated that at the same time, it will close the Taipei Representative Office of Credit Suisse First Boston Bank, which, like Credit Suisse Bank, belongs to the Credit Suisse Group of Switzerland.
Credit Suisse First Boston established its Taipei representative office in 1988 to take charge of duties such as information gathering and communication.

According to the Swiss business group, Credit Suisse First Boston has been commissioned to build the group's stock brokerage subsidiary in Taiwan. In order to be able to concentrate on this new mission, the bank has been discharged from its current banking operations on the island, MOF officials said.
However, in order to continue the group's efficient banking services on the island, Credit Suisse decided to pass its Taiwan banking operations on to Credit Suisse Bank, the officials said.
Statistics compiled by "The Banker" magazine show that the Credit Suisse Group enjoys US$473.832 billion-worth of assets, ranking it the fourth-largest banking group in the world.
Currently, a total of 26 foreign banks from 14 nations have representative offices in Taiwan, according to the MOF officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: IRISH TROUPE TO PERFORM TRADITIONAL SONG AND DANCE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Those who love something Irish will be given a treat when Bru Boru, a real McCoy Irish troupe of traditional singers and dancers, comes to Taiwan for three performances.
The ensemble of 22 draw its members from all walks of life and is led by Sen. Labhras O'Murchu, an enthusiast for the renaissance of Irish folk song and dance.

The Taipei Representative Office in Ireland, which helped arrange the troupe's tour in coordination with the Pacific Cultural Foundation, said it is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Oct. 12, and give one performance each in Taipei, Taichung and Tainan between Oct. 13 and 20.

The Taipei office said Bru Boru's song and dance performances are given by its members in colorful traditional costumes and with musical instruments. The troupe has toured the United States, Australia, Japan, South Korea and mainland China in recent years winning acclaim wherever they go.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE GIVES HIGH PRAISE FOR TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday had high praise for Taiwan's economy for remaining largely unscathed by Asia's economic woes.

During a brief meeting with former US Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger, Lee said Taiwan's economic growth this year and next year will definitely be much better than a recent International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecast.

Lee told Weinberger that Taiwan's economy, which is fundamentally healthy, is expected to grow steadily in the coming years because of the timely implementation of a government-directed domestic demand expansion package this year.

The president attributed Taiwan's ability to stand tall against the Asian economic turmoil to its low foreign debt, and the burgeoning democracy which has helped make government policy more transparent.

Weinberger, now chairman of Forbes magazine, expressed his admiration for Taiwan's political and economic achievements, particularly at a time when the entire Asian region is embroiled in the regional economic meltdown.
Forbes, an economic and financial bi-monthly with a circulation of 755,000, has been rated one of the top five magazines in the United States.

Weinberger, a long-time staunch supporter of the Republic of China, was defense secretary during the Reagan Administration. He was also chairman of the USA-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council between 1991 and 1994.

He wrote a number of articles in 1996 urging the US government not to sit idly by as Beijing staged provocative moves against Taiwan during that year when it conducted missile tests and live-ammunition war games in the Taiwan Strait.

In an article carried in Forbes' July issue this year, he also criticized US President Bill Clinton for "selling out" Taiwan. He said Clinton's remarks on the "three noes" during his mainland China trip seriously twisted the spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act and have gravely violated Taiwan's interests.
Weinberger is making his second visit to Taiwan this year. His last visit was in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVITE BULGARIAN ATHLETES TO TAIWAN, SAYS PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday suggested that Taiwan invite leading athletes from Bulgaria to help raise the island's sports standards and cement sports exchanges between the two countries.

During a brief meeting with Ivan Borissov Slavkov, a Bulgarian member of the International Olympic Committee (IOC), at the Presidential Office, Lee highly commended the Eastern European country for the richness of its sports talent despite its small population. Bulgaria, with a population of just 8 million, has won 47 gold medals in Olympic games over the years.

In addition to sports exchanges, Lee said, the Republic of China can lend its successful experience in economic growth to Bulgaria. Through Taiwan investment and two-way trade, Taiwan can help improve the standard of living in the country on the edge of the Black Sea.

Slavkov, who last visited Taiwan some 10 years ago, said Taiwan has made incredible achievements over the last decade. He pledged to try his utmost to help bolster sports and other exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER SPELLS OUT POLICY FOR MAINTAINING ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that his government has worked out a multifaceted policy to maintain Taiwan's economic growth.

The three major objectives of this policy, he said, are to keep the growth rate this year at 5.3 percent, to upgrade high-tech levels and protect the environment, and to strengthen international cooperation.
Siew spelt out the policy in an address to the 32nd annual conference of the International Iron and Steel Institute (IISI) at the Taipei International Conference Hall.
The three-day meeting opened on Monday with the participation of delegates from 53 member countries and more than 200 steel companies, steel associations and related research institutions.
In his address, titled "The Development and Prospects of the Republic of China," the premier said that in spite of the Asian financial crisis, "many of our economic indices have remained stable."

He said that Taiwan has not experienced the severe economic setbacks suffered by many of its Asian neighbors, and added: "We expect our economy to continue growing at a rate of 5.3 percent this year."

In order to minimize the negative effects from the worldwide economic slowdown on Taiwan's export drive and domestic economy, Siew noted, the government has worked out a program for domestic demand expansion.
This program is designed to stimulate domestic investment and assure continued growth, with the focus on increasing both public and private investment.

The premier said the government will expand the national budget by allocating an additional NT$67.1 billion (US$2 billion) for fiscal 1999 and an estimated NT$57.2 billion (US$1.7 billion) for fiscal 2000.

To ensure the smooth implementation of this program, Siew said the government will strive to maintain financial stability, eliminate obstacles to investment, and speed up the revision of related laws and regulations.

On improving levels of high-technology, the premier said that a "technology nation implementation program" has been put into effect for the new millennium, under which Taiwan's technology budget will be maintained at no less than 10 percent, so that by 2000, national spending on R&D and investment in manpower will reach levels comparable with those of most advanced countries.

Siew told the gathering that as the world's 14th-largest trading nation, the ROC seeks accession into the World Trade Organization (WTO) to ensure long-term development and to increase the process of liberalization and globalization.

He said the ROC will continue to seek close cooperation with all nations and to contribute to the world community. A successful example is the establishment of the International Cooperation and Development Fund that had seen commitments totaling US$377.4 million by June this year.

The premier pledged that Taiwan will actively engage with nations through pragmatic diplomacy, and will work with the private sector to develop "economic strategic partnerships" with friendly countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TOUTS TAIWAN'S CORRECT RESPONSE TO ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's appropriate response to the Asian crisis has been vindicated by the relatively slight impact on its economy amid the regional turmoil, Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday.

Brushing aside legislators' requests to comment on international financier George Soros' predication that Taiwan's economy is not yet "out of the woods," Siew said at the Legislative Yuan that expanding domestic demand to stimulate economic growth is a time-tested prescription recommended by many economic powers for getting out of economic difficulties, and that it will also work for Taiwan.

Dynamic domestic demand is the recipe worked out at meetings of finance ministers of the seven industrialized countries and the International Monetary Fund for containing the Asian crisis, and Taiwan has won applause for holding its own in the crisis, said Siew.
"Although we are not complacent with our performance, we will not deign to rebut Soros' point of view on Taiwan," Siew said.

Sharing Siew's opinion, P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, assured the legislature that the crisis has already run its course and that recovery is around the corner. He said the economic forecast for next year is hopeful.

Regarding Soros' view that instead of lowering interest rates, which might not be effective in staving off recession, the crisis-ravaged Asian countries should stimulate economic growth, Chiang pointed out that this is exactly the course followed by Japan, Thailand, and South Korea, especially Japan, which has earmarked 10 trillion yen for public projects as a way of enlarging domestic demand.
Given that trade with Asian states accounts for almost half of Taiwan's foreign trade, Chiang said the island can hardly isolate itself from the turmoil gripping its Asian neighbors.

He predicted that those countries will not recover from the disaster for one or two years, and said that Taiwan cannot rely on their markets to fuel its own economy. In addition, the vital role played by the psychological element in economic growth necessitates investment at home to revive confidence in the economy as a way of overcoming the crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DESCRIBES TAIWAN'S NATIONAL CONSTRUCTION WORK

TEXT.P: The people and government of the Republic of China on Taiwan are sparing no effort to sharpen the country's competitiveness, President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday.
Lee was attending the opening of the World Hakka Association's 14th annual meeting in Taipei, where he outlined Taiwan's national construction and development, categorizing them into four areas.

The island is devoted to the promotion of political democracy, Lee said, pointing out that since the lifting of martial law 10 years ago, the country has opened up for parties and mass media outlets with different political opinions, the legislature has been reformed, and the first direct presidential election has taken place.
With last year's constitutional reforms, the ROC became a member of the world's democratic community, Lee said, adding that the status will help Taiwan's efforts in globalization.

The country has never stopped in its efforts to maintain stable economic growth. The president introduced the ROC government's current efforts to build the island into an Asia-Pacific operations center, and said that although the Asian financial crisis has seriously damaged the region's economic development, it has not harmed Taiwan, because of its solid economic fundamentals.

Lee said his government has taken measures to expand the island's foreign trade and domestic demands, and added that he believes the efforts will help Taiwan avoid the regional economic recession and gain new opportunities for further economic development.

The ROC has been fighting for its position and national dignity in the international community, Lee told the meeting, adding that through the promotion of pragmatic relationships with foreign countries and bids for membership in international organizations, the whole world will know of the ROC's existence.
Meanwhile, Taipei has also never rested in work aimed at keeping the country safe, Lee said, citing the consistent upgrading of national defense systems.
Lee also talked about the pragmatic and flexible mainland China policy, which helps the promotion of cross-strait exchanges and the maintenance of the stability of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS DISCUSS CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION TO HELP ASIAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan scholar on Tuesday suggested that Taiwan take the initiative to set up a regional stability fund with mainland China to help financially stricken Southeast Asian countries.

Chu Yun-peng, director of the Institute of Social Sciences under Academia Sinica, made the proposals at a symposium on mainland China's economic development and its effect on cross-strait trade and Taiwan's investment on the mainland.

Pointing out that Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will resume talks next week with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, Chu said the two sides should use the opportunity to discuss how to cooperate to help Southeast Asian countries ride out their difficulties.

He said officials from the World Bank recently visited Taiwan and mainland China, and advocated the idea of discussing the establishment of an "Asian regional cooperation fund" during the Koo-Wang talks.
Chu also suggested bringing this issue before the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Fu Feng-cheng, a researcher with the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, agreed that it is important for Taiwan and mainland China to cooperate to extend aid to Southeast Asian countries.

But he said he did not think Beijing would agree to raising the issue with APEC because of the "one China" problem. Instead, he proposed that Taipei take five steps to promote relations with mainland China:
-- Invite Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan via a direct flight from Shanghai;
-- Support the use of domestic laws for Taiwan businessmen as a way of protecting their investments on the mainland; and
-- Strengthen cross-strait cooperation in science and technology, with a joint development of auto engines as the start, and the manufacture of a national car as the goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIZATION OF INTELLECTUALS HOLDS MEETING IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: The independent "China Development Union" held its first national congress in Beijing on Oct. 4-5 with nearly 100 intellectuals from various parts of the country participating, a human rights organization reported Tuesday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said in a press release that the union was legally registered in Hong Kong in August, and that it will study the various political, economic, and social problems that emerge in the course of national development.

In the national congress held in Beijing this week, the union called up the government to permit the registration of civil organizations and enact laws governing political parties as soon as possible.
The convening of the union's first national congress in Beijing indicates that mainland Chinese intellectuals are gathering strength to help promote political reforms in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The New Taiwan dollar surged past 33.5 against the US dollar.
The China Times: The US House of Representatives Judiciary Committee on Monday approved launching a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton.
The United Daily News: The Ministry of Finance will impose bad debts reserve requirements on all banks.
The Liberty Times: The US House panel moves to open impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, with a 21-16 vote.
The Independence Morning Post: President Lee Teng-hui took concrete actions to back Ma Ying-jeou's Taipei mayoral election bid.
The Commons Daily: Taiwan is not out of the woods yet, says George Soros.
The China Post: The Taipei City Council speaker is accused of improper behavior.
The China News: Hedge fund manager George Soros predicts that Taiwan will weaken.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE INVESTMENT GROWTH SAID TO HIT FIVE-YEAR HIGH IN 1998

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private investments will grow by a five-year high of 19.7 percent in 1998, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday.

Wang, who was speaking at a regular meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee, cited a report in the most recent issue of Newsweek magazine stating that Taiwan's economy remains stable amid a global downturn under the capable leadership of President Lee Teng-hui.

Based on estimates made by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the economics minister said Taiwan's economy would post the largest growth of 5.3 percent among the four Asian dragons for the whole of 1998. Singapore will register zero growth, while Hong Kong and South Korea will post negative growth of 4 percent and 7 percent respectively.

Although Taiwan has weathered the Asian financial turmoil, Wang stressed that the government is poised to take concrete measures to counter a global economic recession such as boosting consumer demand, developing new high-tech industries, strengthening the small business sector, as well as exploring international markets and cooperative ventures.

In the face of keen competition from other emerging countries, Wang said Taiwan must further diversify its high-tech sector into aviation, biochemical, optical electricity, and precision machinery as the island already enjoys an advantage in the information, electronics and telecommunications industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED CRIMINAL DEPORTED TO TAIWAN FROM MACAU

TEXT.P: A Taiwan gang leader, wanted on suspicion of blackmail charges, was arrested then deported to Taiwan from Macau on Wednesday.

Identified as Hsu Yiao-feng, 46, leader of the "Wan Tsui Gang," from Taiwan's southern city of Kaohsiung, the gangster was on Taiwan's wanted list for suspected involvement in illegally obtaining fire arms, as well as blackmailing businessmen and corporations with explosive devices and sulfuric acid. He fled to Macau earlier this year to avoid police capture.
Hsu has a previous criminal record with convictions on assault and battery charges. He was listed as a gangster with a very threatening social disorder.
Taiwan police arrested Hsu on Tuesday, with the cooperation of law-enforcement authorities from Hong Kong and Macau, as well as the international criminal police organization.
The case has been transferred to prosecution authorities for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-BURMESE URGE TAIPEI TO IMPROVE ID SERVICES

TEXT.P: A group of ethnic Chinese from Burma on Wednesday urged the Republic of China to improve services for Chinese-Burmese who intend to visit Taiwan or obtain ROC citizenship.

The Chinese-Burmese representatives, accompanied by Kuomintang Legislator Han Kuo-yu, called at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to describe the plight of ethnic Chinese in Burma when they try to obtain a document proving their overseas Chinese status from the ROC government.

The representatives told Chu Chien-yi, director-general of MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, that since Taipei maintains no liaison offices in Burma, the Chinese-Burmese must travel to Rangoon then to Bangkok in Thailand to apply at the ROC representative office for an ROC identification document.

This entire process takes up much time, effort and money. The cost of all this traveling for an average Chinese-Burmese is beyond imagination, said Huang Tung-yi, deputy chairman of the Association of Overseas Chinese from Burma.
In response, Chu said Burma's closeness to mainland China makes it extremely difficult to establish an ROC representative office in Rangoon without provoking Beijing.
Rangoon refuses to allow a proposed Taiwan representative office to carry the name "Republic of China." It also disagrees to an office with "Taipei" in the name, Chu noted.
Rangoon also not permits a Taiwan office to perform basic functions such as issuing visas, passports and related documents, he added.

Huang, in turn, suggested that MOFA regularly dispatch consular affairs officials from Bangkok to Burmese cities to collect application forms from potential applicants since Taipei cannot open an office in Burma.
Chu promised that he will ensure that Huang's suggestion will be assessed by relevant MOFA officials.

The number of ethnic Chinese in Burma is roughly estimated at 3 million. Many of them are offspring of former Kuomintang military officers and soldiers who fled to the mountains near the Thai-Burmese border after the Chinese communists took over the mainland in 1949. Most members of the KMT's armed forces moved to Taiwan with the central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIRLINES TO TAKE DELIVERY OF NEW AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: Uni Airlines, an affiliate of the Evergreen Group, announced on Wednesday that four MD-90 airplanes will soon join its fleet.
Representatives said the airline will begin to take delivery of the four brand new MD-90s on Oct. 20 from the Boeing Corp. The MD-90s will gradually replace the company's five BAE-146 planes.
Uni Airlines is also planning to introduce several 78-seater DHC8-400 turbo propeller planes to phase out its aging DHC8-300s.

Meanwhile, Evergreen Marine Corp. Ltd., the Evergreen Group's flagship subsidiary which operates the world's largest container cargo fleet, said it will shut down its offices in Seattle, Portland and San Francisco because of a persistent global financial morass and the rising strength of US labor syndicates.

After the closures, Evergreen Marine's Los Angeles branch office will be its remaining office on the US West Coast. The operations of the three closed offices will be relocated to the company's operations in Salt Lake City, Utah.
According to Evergreen Marine officials stationed in Los Angeles, the move is part of the group's streamline plan and will not affect the company's overall operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-EUTHANASIA DOCTOR TO OPEN MELBOURNE CLINIC

TEXT.P: The Australian medical doctor who helped three terminally ill patients die in early 1997 plans to establish a clinic in Melbourne to provide advice on euthanasia.
Victoria Premier Jeff Kennett on Tuesday said Philip Nitschke's plans would not break Victorian laws, but police and medical authorities warned that his activities would be closely monitored.
"I don't think there's any law that would stop him from setting up an advice clinic," Kennett said.
Nitschke plans to relocate his clinic from Darwin in the Northern Territory to Melbourne after the world's first euthanasia legislation in that territory was blocked last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUCENT INKS US$19M DEAL WITH FUJIAN

TEXT.P: Lucent Technologies has signed a US$19 million contract to supply an optical networking system to the Fujian Posts and Telecommunications Administration, Lucent said in a news release on Tuesday.

The Fujian administration is expanding its telecommunications network to meet the growing demand for voice and advanced telecommunication services. With the completion of this agreement, the administration will have one of the most advanced optical networks in the mainland.

Lucent's WaveStar optical networking system will enable the administration to expand the capacity of some fiber optic links by up to a factor of 16. Each DWDM link will have a capacity equivalent of up to a half a million voice phone calls -- or more than 1,000 volumes of an encyclopedia per second.

The 2,440-kilometer-long network is expected to be in service by June 1999 and will link nine key cities and a number of counties in Fujian province. The new network will enable the Fujian administration to offer its customers multiple high-bandwidth services, such as high-speed Internet access and video conferencing.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG ZEMIN TO VISIT AUSTRALIA IN 1999

TEXT.P: Chinese President Jiang Zemin, at the invitation of Australian Prime Minister John Howard, will visit Australia next year, Australian media reported on Wednesday.
The visit will make him the most senior mainland official to make such a visit. Premier Zhu Rongji currently holds the distinction after he went to Australia in 1997 when he was vice premier.
The Australian reported that Jiang will likely make the visit after attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in New Zealand in November 1999.
Jiang's visit will mark a further thaw in the relationship between the two countries, the Australian Associated Press said.

Bilateral relations between Australia and China worsened in March 1996 after the Howard administration backed the US in sending warships to the Taiwan Strait as a show of strength during the mainland's missile tests off Taiwan's shores.
Ties improved with the visits of government officials from the respective countries. Howard went to Beijing in March 1997, and extended an open invitation to Jiang at that time.
Political analysts said Jiang's trip to Canberra would further improve the relations between China and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLIMATE CHANGE, POLLUTION KILL 16,000 CANADIANS PER YEAR

TEXT.P: Air pollution and global warming have claimed about 16,000 deaths in Canada annually, a study commissioned by the David Suzuki Foundation said on Tuesday.
These deaths are "directly attributable to the burning of fossil fuels, and there's a direct connection between air pollution and climate change," the study stated.
It is the first study to definitively show the health effects of global warming, the foundation said.

The study, titled "Taking our Breath Away," said between 1980 and 1989, 28 percent more boys and 18 percent more girls were hospitalized because of asthma. Air pollution can cause asthma or make it more severe. It can also make breathing more difficult and lead to cardiac arrest.

About 8 percent of non-accidental deaths in Canada are somehow related to air pollution, the study concluded. It also suggested that there is an increased likelihood Canada may experience an epidemic of infectious disease due to global warming.
Representatives of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons, the Canadian Public Health Association, and the Canadian Institute of Child Health endorsed the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GIRL RETURNS HOME AFTER MEETING BIOLOGICAL PARENTS

TEXT.P: Aimee Butler, the Australian girl who came to Taiwan on Sept. 28 to be reunited with her biological mother, is scheduled to return home on Wednesday evening, now that she has met both her birth parents.
Butler, who today is a happy teenager, and an accomplished violinist, pianist and singer, was sold to an Australian couple 18 years ago by a Taiwan baby-selling ring.
Butler was born out of wedlock in Miaoli, some 60 kilometers south of Taipei, in 1980, according to her birth mother Yen Kan, who said that Aimee also had a twin sister who died shortly after birth.

As the girl's father showed no intention of marrying Yen or assuming the responsibility of raising the baby, Yen said that poor health and a lack of finances forced her to sell her child for about NT$10,000 (US$300).

Yen, who almost immediately regretted the sale, said she was given a few photos of Aimee and her new Australian parents, but had had no opportunity until recently of contacting the child and her adoptive parents.

Yen said the story of Kartya Wunderle, another Australian who returned to Taiwan last June to find her biological mother and succeeded in her attempt, gave her renewed hope of finding her own daughter.

At a pre-departure press conference, Butler said she has also met with her biological father, who declined to be identified in order to avoid embarrassing Yen Kan and his own family. He is now married with a family of his own. Butler said she fully understands her birth father's situation and said she had no intention of disrupting his family.
At the press conference, a tearful Yen Kan repeated her heartfelt gratitude to Aimee's adoptive parents, who have raised her daughter into a healthy, lovely, and well-educated teenager.

Yen said words cannot not describe her gratitude for the Butlers. She said she did not want Aimee to stay with her in Taiwan or disturb Aimee's life, and added that she would be the happiest woman in the world if Aimee would visit her sometimes in the future.
Wunderle, 17, stayed in Taipei after finding her biological mother. She is working at a McDonalds restaurant, but aspires to be a model.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTEROVIRUS EPIDEMIC RESURFACES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's children are suffering again as a result of the failure to eliminate the virulent enterovirus epidemic which swept the island this summer.
Over 60 children islandwide were killed by the virus during the April to July period, after which the health authority believed the virus was under control.

However, since September, when the island started experiencing cooler autumn weather, eight children have so far been reported as having died from diseases allegedly caused by the enterovirus, which had been believed to be active only in warm environments, according to Department of Health (DOH) statistics.
The sudden resurgence of the infection forced the DOH on Sunday to resume its daily reports on the epidemic which threatens the lives of the island's children.

During the recent Mid-Autumn Festival weekend, a total of 761 patients suspected of having contracted the enterovirus were reported, 46 of whom were admitted to hospital, according to Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of the department of communicable disease control under the DOH.

On Tuesday, the first working day after the holiday, 23 more children were admitted to hospital. They were among the approximately 300 people around the island who visited a doctor that day due to illness allegedly caused by the virus, Hsu said.
The latest outbreak is now centered in the southern part of Taiwan, Hsu said, adding that there is no sign of cross-infection by diseases caused by different types of enterovirus.

The type 71 enterovirus is blamed for the current epidemic, based on analyses by the Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, National Institute of Preventive Medicine, and Cheng Kung University Hospital.

Although other types of enterovirus were also discovered in the medical research, they were in the minority, Hsu said, noting that general hospitals and medical research institutes in the island's south are making in-depth studies of the potentially fatal disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.111 against the greenback in Taipei Wednesday, closing at 33.346.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 33.437, and had a high of 33.265.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$816.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SURGE ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 140.24 points to close at the day's high of 6,674.89.
Encouraged by a jump in prices on the New York Stock Exchange, the bourse opened at 6,596.48 points, 61.83 higher than Tuesday's close, and continued its upward move to close at 6,674.89.

A total of 2.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.99 billion, increasing from the previous trading session which saw 2.56 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$73.54 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 3.9 percent, textile issues at 2.7 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.6 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.4 percent, cement shares at 2 percent, construction stocks at 1.8 percent, and electrical shares at 1.6 percent.
Stock index futures were also higher.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October surged 189 points to close at 6,639, with 2,348 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for November moved up 179 points to finish at 6,570, while December futures surged 215 points to 6,565, March futures increased 165 points to 6,515, and June futures moved up 145 points, closing at 6,450.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 192, 51, seven, and eight, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SLUGGISH MANUFACTURING PRODUCTIVITY TO RECOVER NEXT OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The chief statistician at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Wednesday that the island's manufacturing sector is expected to recover its vitality next October, when the Sixth Naphtha Cracking plant begins operating.
Chang Yao-tsung made the prediction while announcing statistics on the island's manufacturing output during the first nine months of the year.

The MOFA figures show that manufacturing production during the January-September period rose 4.12 percent compared with the same period of 1997, while an 8 percent annual rise was posted in 1997 from the year-earlier level.
An overall economic recession caused by the year-long Asian financial meltdown is to blame for the decline, Chang said.

However, he added that although the latest figure shows sluggish production in the manufacturing sector, it still outpaces all of Taiwan's competitors, including South Korea, Japan, and the countries of Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING GROUP CALLS FOR `CHINESE CONFEDERATION'

TEXT.P: A Beijing-based private intellectual group issued a statement on Wednesday urging Taiwan and mainland China to jointly establish a "Chinese confederation."

In the statement made public by the Hong Kong-based China Human Rights Information Center, the "Association for China Development," composed of more than 3,000 intellectuals from Beijing, proposed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait set up a loose confederation as two political entities on an equal footing.

The association also urged the Beijing authorities to put forward the idea at the upcoming meeting between the top negotiators of the two sides. Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), are scheduled to meet in Beijing on Oct. 18.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with cross-strait dealings in the absence of official contacts.

Taiwan and mainland China should resolve their unification problem by setting up a loose confederation or implementing a "one country, three systems" scheme, the association said, adding that under the scheme, both sides would be entitled to their own independent judicial, administrative, armed forces, and foreign affairs systems.
It suggested that the confederation should have a 50-year framework, after which time a public referendum could be held so that the people of both sides could decide their future.

The statement suggested that the Taiwan authorities and political parties respond to the association's call, and urged the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party to adjust the course of its policy. It also said that the United States should use its influence to push for a summit meeting between the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to discuss the possibility of a Chinese confederation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAULINE HANSON BLAMES MEDIA FOR ONE NATION ELECTION ROUT

TEXT.P: One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has blamed the Australian media and the preferential voting system for the party's disastrous federal election result.
One Nation was the big loser in the Oct. 3 election, with none of its candidates being elected to the House of Representatives and only one candidate elected to the Senate.

Hanson said the preferential voting system was unfair, and claimed that despite the total rout, One Nation actually came third in the race because it outpolled the National Party, the Democrats, and the Green Party.
Although she lost her seat, Hanson is expected to remain the president of One Nation, allegedly with a six-figure annual salary.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAD COW DISEASE MAY HAVE SPREAD TO UK SHEEP

TEXT.P: The UK faces the risk of a new health scare after a BSE expert said the mad cow disease could be present in sheep, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday.

"There is a distinct possibility that BSE (mad cow disease) is out there in the sheep population," Professor Geoffrey Almond, chairman of the sheep sub-committee of the Spongiform Encephalopathy Advisory Committee, was quoted as saying. The committee is the BSE watchdog in Britain.

Only nine million of Britain's 42 million sheep have been tested for BSE, Almond said. None were infected but the number of tests was far too small to rule out the possibility that BSE had "gone back into sheep from cows".
UK sheep were fed BSE-contaminated meat and bone meal until a ban was imposed in 1988.

Experiments show that sheep fed with infected cattle brain can contract BSE but it is not known whether this has occurred naturally. Scrapie, a related disease, has been present in sheep for 200 years, apparently without infecting people, but spreads more easily between species.
Almond urged the UK government to step up its research into sheep. The British agriculture ministry said tests were expensive, time-consuming and it was hard to distinguish BSE from scrapie.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT HEADQUARTERS INAUGURATED AMID PROTESTS

TEXT.P: The new headquarters of the ruling Kuomintang was inaugurated on Wednesday amid boisterous protests from different political groups.
The KMT hosted a cocktail reception to celebrate the inauguration of its brand-new, gleaming 12-story building, drawing a large crowd of well-wishers.
President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman, said on the occasion that he hopes the opening of the new building will usher in a "new spring" for the 104-year-old party.

"While the KMT is willing to engage in fair competition with other political parties on an equal footing, we also earnestly hope that members of the general public will side with us and use their votes to support our cause," Lee said.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang said he was delighted to see the inauguration of the KMT headquarters building before this year's Double Ten National Day.
"This symbolizes that the destiny of the KMT is closely associated with that of the Republic of China," Chang noted.

Following a traditional Chinese practice, Lee and four KMT vice chairmen -- Lien Chan, Li Yuan-zu, Yu Kuo-hwa and Chiu Chuang-huan -- joined with staff members in making sweet rice dumplings to ward off evil spirits and usher in good luck.
Traditional Chinese lion dances, gong and drum performances, and many other exciting events were also staged to mark the occasion, adding much fanfare and a festive atmosphere to the building.

The party's candidates for the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections -- Ma Ying-jeou and Wu Tun-yi -- were also present at the reception to consolidate intraparty support for their electoral bids.

Outside the building, however, a number of opposition politicians and activists staged protests against what they called the ruling party's violations of construction regulations in building its new headquarters.

The protesters included Kao Cheng-yen, convener of the Green Party of Taiwan; New Party Legislator Chu Hui-liang; New Party Taiwan Provincial Assembly Deputy Yang Chen-hsiung; Hsu Jung-chi, head of the Voice of Taiwan Broadcasting Co.; and several Taiwan Independence Party heavyweights.

The KMT obtained a permit to construct the new building when the Taipei City Government was headed by Huang Ta-chou, a KMT stalwart. However, by the time it had been completed in January 1997, the city government had been taken over by Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Under Chen's hand, the city government declined to issue an operating permit, on the grounds that as the building occupied 6,021 square meters of land, it should have passed an environmental impact evaluation before construction began.
The resulting impasse resulted in political wrangling which lasted for more than a year before permission was finally granted in May this year to open the building.

The city government agreed to issue the permit only after the KMT scrapped its ownership of 26 sq. meters of the land on which the new building is situated to meet the requirements of the current construction law.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT WARNS OF NEW US TRADE PROTECTION MEASURES

TEXT.P: The United States is expected to impose protectionist measures on foreign trade, Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade director-general warned on Wednesday.
If the move takes place, it will be in the hope of easing America's increasing trade deficits resulting from the greenback's overwhelming strength against most Asian currencies, Chen Ruey-long said.
Chen stated that US consuming power has greatly accelerated due to the US dollar's appreciation following the outbreak of the Asian financial crisis last July.

Eyeing this large consumer market, Asian traders, including those from Taiwan, have gone full strength on their promotion of exports to the United States over the past year, Chen said, adding that Washington expects its trade deficits will surge to a historic high this year.
He put forward his analysis at a business conference attended by more than 100 representatives of local businesses.

The economics official told the participants that the fact that a number of American businesses have accused Taiwan firms of dumping over the past year raises the prospect of Washington taking more radical measures to protect US traders.
The United States is Taiwan's largest trade partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LABOR SHORTAGE LESSENED DUE TO ECONOMIC SLUMP: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's labor shortage in the non-agricultural sector lessened between January and July due to the economic slowdown, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Wednesday.

The labor shortage in the non-agricultural sector as a whole in the first seven months of this year decreased 0.4 percent to 196,000 people, said the DGBAS in its general report, adding however that the shortage in the service sector increased 5.1 percent to 82,000 people.

When broken down further according to individual sectors, the report showed a labor shortage decline of 4.3 percent, or 98,000 people, in the manufacturing sector, and a decline of 2.5 percent, or 50,000 people, in the construction sector.

The increased shortage in the service sector was attributed to the fact that this sector is closely related to domestic demand, which has been targeted by the government for expansion. In this sector, the report pointed out, the financial, insurance, and real estate sectors have suffered the most serious escalation of personnel shortages, at 15.6 percent.

Meanwhile, according to figures released by the government's employment guidance services, registered job seekers increased by 1.2 percent, or 17,000 people, in August 1998, while job vacancies decreased by 3.2 percent, or a reduction of 38,000 positions.
This development shows that there are now reduced options for those seeking a job, the DGBAS report commented.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER STRESSES NEED FOR INTERNATIONAL COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: The changing economic situation shows the need for the nation to promote private investment and increase international cooperation to maintain competitiveness, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday.

Wang made the remarks in a report on how to sustain international competitiveness amid the changing world economic situation delivered at a regular meeting of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.

He said that several factors are emerging regarding the world economy, including the knowledge that the world economy is not going to rebound in the short term, that the competitive edges of emerging market economies are changing, and that a form of neo-conservatism is beginning to emerge.
The minister noted that in the last three years, the trend toward mergers has increased dramatically. In 1997, the value of acquisitions totaled US$242.8 billion, up 25 percent from 1996.

Wang said that the financial situations of many corporations have deteriorated this year in the wake of the Asian financial storm, which has triggered more mergers, and has created more and more widely diversified conglomerates.

He also said that the competitiveness of emerging economies will decrease because of the financial storm, mainly because the dramatic drop in a nation's currency will alter the competitiveness of its products, and make it harder for emerging markets to attract long-term stable capital.

Wang went on to say that the rapid spread of the financial crisis has been attributed to capital flow running out of control. For this reason, he noted, a new conservatism is in the offing, and nations will have to find management systems that will suit their own interests and economic conditions.

As the world economy is still enduring a downturn, continued expansion of domestic demand is one way of ensuring economic growth, he said, adding that the expansion of private investment will be the prime mover behind the expansion of domestic demand.

Wang said that as the map of the competitiveness of emerging countries is changing, Taiwan must develop its technology-oriented economy, make its industrial infrastructure more healthy, and ensure a strong small- and medium-sized industry sector.

In view of the increasing number of international conglomerates, Wang also noted that domestic manufacturers will have to upgrade export competitiveness, establish international cooperation channels, and step up trade offensives into international markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT LEGISLATOR RETURNS TO THE PARTY FOLD

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang confirmed on Wednesday that former New Party Legislator Tsai Chen-yang will return to the KMT, adding that more superior and refined talents are welcome to join the ruling party.
Chang made the remarks after a tea party in celebration of the inauguration of the KMT Central Committee's new headquarters.
