He said that some people have criticized the KMT for "boastful talk" about NP lawmakers possibly returning to the ruling party. Tsai's decision, however, has demonstrated that the KMT was not boasting, as has a similar move made by NP Legislator Huang Kuo-chung, he said. The KMT does not want to draw too much attention to the matter, so as not to embarrass other political parties, he added.
Tsai said his decision to return to the KMT was based on special circumstances and had nothing to do with the New Party. He said he wished his former NP colleagues well.

Three years ago Tsai, then a KMT member, switched allegiance to the NP, joining the party because of its ideals and clean image. Difficulties later erupted, however, between Tsai and fellow NP members. As a result, he said, it became difficult for him to fulfill his party obligations.
Tsai said he hopes that by returning to the KMT, he will have more room to develop.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX F-16S RETURN TO SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Sherman Wu)

TEXT.P: Singapore, Oct. 7 (CAN) Six F-16C/D jet fighters of the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) arrived at a local air base on Wednesday, following a 15,973-km trip from Luke air force base in the United States.
A number of officers, pilots, and ground crew were on hand to welcome the jets.

The six planes belong to a group of 18 aircraft which the RSAF purchased in 1994. Their arrival brought to 10 the total number of planes to have been delivered. The F-16C/D is one of the most advanced and combat capable multi-role fighter aircraft in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARGENTINE PEOPLE SUPPORT ROC'S UN BID

TEXT.P: Many Argentine people have recently telephoned the Republic of China's representative office in Buenos Aires to express their support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the United Nations.

An ROC diplomat stationed in Argentina told CNA on Tuesday that the ROC representative office began receiving such phone calls after a major Argentine daily, La Nacion, published a letter from one of its readers criticizing the Argentine government for its opposition to the ROC's UN bid.

Norberto Alfredo Marino said in his letter to the paper that he felt regret that the Argentine ambassador to the United Nations opposed the inclusion of a pro-ROC UN bid motion into the agenda for the ongoing 53rd General Assembly plenary session.
"I simply couldn't understand why the Argentine government gave up its basic principle and ignored international justice to join the anti-ROC camp," Marino said.

He pointed out that the ROC already came into being in 1912. "Although the ROC moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949 after the Chinese mainland lost to communist hands, it has continued to exist as an independent sovereign state."

Over the past five decades, Marino said, the ROC has grown into the world's 14th largest trading nation, seventh largest overseas investor, 16th most competitive economy and seventh strongest technological power.

Moreover, Marino said, cultural and commercial exchanges between the ROC and Argentina have continued to increase in recent years. "The two countries have recently reached an agreement allowing Argentine beef and fruits to enter the Taiwan market."

In addition, Marino said, many Taiwan investors have traveled to Argentina to seek business and investment opportunities. On the other hand, he said, Argentine enterprises have also launched promotional efforts to tap into the Taiwan market.

Marino went on to say that the ROC government and people have repeatedly expressed their common aspiration for joining the United Nations and their willingness to faithfully fulfill obligations as a member of the international community.

"There is no sign that the ROC's UN bid is designed to challenge any existing UN member," Marino said, adding that the 21.8 million people of Taiwan have been discriminated in the international society and their legitimate rights lack legal protection because of a lack of representation in the United Nations.

Even though Argentina recognizes Beijing and shares important economic interests with it, the Argentine government should not have voiced opposition to the ROC's UN bid simply for pleasing the communist Chinese government in Beijing, which has often come under fire for its human rights violations.

Since Marino's letter was published last week, the ROC representative office has received a large number of phone calls from members of the Argentine public throwing their support behind the ROC's UN bid.

Fifteen of the ROC's diplomatic allies jointly presented a motion to the UN Secretariat in July asking the UN to re-examine its 1971 Resolution No. 2758, which expelled the ROC to make way for mainland China.
The UN Steering Committee rejected in September the inclusion of the motion into this year's General Assembly agenda.

This was the sixth consecutive year that the ROC had spearheaded its UN campaign through its diplomatic allies. Even though the bid, like previous ones, failed to make the annual General Assembly agenda, the ROC government has vowed to continue the annual campaign to enlist global support for its cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CDC SETS UP JOINT VENTURE WITH MITSUBISHI SHOJI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Development Corp. (CDC) and Japan's Mitsubishi Shoji held a press conference in Tokyo on Wednesday to announce the establishment of a venture capital company in Tokyo.

The new company, called CDM, was formed on July 28 of this year with a total capital of 495 million yen (US$3.73 million). Sixty percent of the capital was from CDC and 40 percent from Mitsubishi Shoji.
This is the first time an investment and trust company from Taiwan has joined hands with a major Japanese trading house to explore the venture capital market in Japan.
CDC Chairman Liu Tai-ying told the media that in addition to the general venture capital business in Japan, the new company will also strive to promote technology transfers into Taiwan from Japan.
Matsuhiko Kojima, executive director of Mitsubishi Shoji, said that Taiwan has been active in the development of some high technology sectors, such as the semiconductor industry.
He said Taiwan's dynamism would be helpful to Japanese industries now that Japan's economy has entered a deep recession.
Kojima said that in the past two years, Mitsubishi Shoji and CDC have jointly invested 700 million yen (US$5.27 million) in two Japanese high-tech enterprises.
After the new company stabilizes its management team, he said, CDM will stretch its operations into Southeast Asia.
CDC General Manager Hu Ting-wu said that the new company has no plans to acquire Japanese firms or facilities at present, though he would not exclude the possibility of future acquisitions.
The new company is starting out with a five-man staff, with Chen Jui-hsun from CDC serving as president and S. Kanzaki from Mitsubishi Shoji as vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT APPEALS TO US TO INCREASE IMF CAPITAL

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada appealed on Wednesday to the United States government to increase the capitalization of the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

He made the appeal during the opening ceremony of the 30th Economic Ministers' Meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations being held in Manila, and also stressed the need for first world countries to assist the countries that have been badly hit by the Asian financial crisis.

In issuing the call to the United States, Estrada also said that the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank play very crucial roles in containing the crisis and in restoring the economic health of the countries most severely affected.
However, he pointed out that "it is now clear that the resources of these institutions, particularly the IMF, are frighteningly insufficient."

"It is our hope that the countries which are in a position to do so, especially the United States, will soon make available their share in the capitalization of the IMF and lend support for increasing funds of the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UK AGENCIES SET UP ALLIANCE TO ATTRACT TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: UK development agencies London First Center (LFC) and Northern Development Company (NDC) have formed an alliance to attract more investment from Taiwan.

At an event marking the launch in Taipei Wednesday, Stephen O'Brien, chief executive of London First Center, said that the alliance was driven by the aim "to present a unique business opportunity to Taiwanese companies who are seeking to establish a full presence in Europe, but for whom a single investment location may not offer all that they seek."

William Tang, director of the LFC/NDC Joint Taiwan Office, said the office seeks to serve the needs of a growing community of Taiwanese investors in the United Kingdom, particularly from the electronic components and financial sectors, and the information manufacturing industry.

Tang noted that London is the financial hub of Europe with 561 global financial institutions setting up branches in the city. London will be the first choice of Taiwan financial institutions wanting to set up overseas branches in Europe, he said.

The British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei estimated that 85 Taiwan manufacturers' investments in Europe have converged in Britain. Taiwan manufacturers' investments in northern England include A.D. I., Kinpo Electronics, and China Synthetic Rubber, while there are 91 companies investing in Britain, of which 53 are in the information and electronics industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST SATELLITE TO BE SHIPPED TO FLORIDA FOR LAUNCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first satellite, ROCSAT-1, having already undergone the testing of its scientific instruments, is scheduled to be transported to Florida later this month for launch, possibly in January, said the National Space Program Office (NSPO) on Wednesday.

Instrument testing began in June 1997 after the satellite's main body was transported to Taiwan by its US manufacturer, the TRW Space & Electronics Group. The testing is the most demanding part of the assembly process, and its completion marks a milestone in the development of Taiwan's satellite program, said Chu Fei-hung, general director of the program.

Noting that TRW and Canadian consultant TELESAT had forecast that the satellite might not be ready for launch until April or May of 1999, Chu said the team managed to beat that forecast by finishing the installation and fine-tuning of equipment ahead of schedule.

TRW and TELESAT based their estimate on the fact that Taiwan has no experience in conducting such a test and on the expectation that it would take at least one year for a new laboratory in Taiwan, with a price tag of NT$600 million to NT$700 million, to be able to carry out such complicated experiments.

The testing would have been completed sooner had the manufacturers not tried to shift responsibility for manufacturing defects and dragged their feet in addressing them, said Chu at a press conference called to announce the test's completion.
The satellite features five vital components that were Taiwan made. Chu lauded the manufacturers' ability to meet the NSPO's requirements, even though all were rookies in the field.
Once launched, ROCSAT-1, which will carry three pieces of scientific equipment, will orbit the earth 14.9 times a day at an altitude of 600 kilometers and an inclination of 35 degrees, said Chu.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ALLIES SEND FELICITATIONS FOR ROC NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: The leaders of the allies of the Republic of China have sent letters and messages commemorating the ROC's forthcoming National Day, which falls on Oct. 10, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Wednesday.
President Alvaro Enrique Arzu Irigoyen of Guatemala, President Kuniwo Nakamura of Palau and Grenada President Keith C. Mitchell, have sent letters of felicitations.
Eduardo Stein Barillas, foreign minister of Guatemala and 11 members of the Russian Duma, the lower house of the Russian Parliament, also sent letters to ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu.

Greetings from the United States include ones from American Institute in Taiwan Director Richard Bush; US Sen. Richard Durbin; US congressmen Ralph Hall, Eva Clayton, Sherrod Brown, Robert Underwood and John Porter; and Indiana Gov. Frank O'Bannon, Minnesota Gov. Arne Carlson and Illinois Gov. Jim Edgar.
In addition, Guam Gov. Carl Gutierrez also proclaimed this Saturday as the Republic of China's Double Ten Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO ATTEND MEETING OF APEC ENERGY MINISTERS

TEXT.P: Yang Shih-chien, minister without portfolio, will lead a group of ROC energy officials in attending an energy ministers' meeting under the framework of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum this Friday.
Yang will also meet with energy ministers from the United States, Japan and Australia during the APEC ministerial meeting Oct. 9-10 in Okinawa, Japan.
The Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that the Republic of China will discuss future energy policy with the energy ministers of other nations.
The Republic of China will also propose increased exchanges of energy technologies and cooperation to cut the emission of greenhouse gases.
The APEC energy ministers' meeting will include discussions of the effect on the global society and economy of the Asian financial crisis and its impact on the world's energy supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE SAYS FEASIBILITY OF TAX CUT QUITE LOW

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, who is concurrently chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, said on Wednesday the feasibility of a massive tax reduction plan, as submitted by an opposition party to help stimulate the domestic economy, is quite low.
Lee made the remarks after hearing a report on the global economic and trade situation from Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang, at the KMT's Central Standing Committee meeting.

The KMT chairman said that affected by international financial turmoil, the economies of both mainland China and Hong Kong have continued to deteriorate. He urged Taiwanese investors in those areas to pay more attention to financial structures and to be mindful of the inventories of their companies' Taiwan headquarters.

In regard to international economics experts and institutions that have warned Taiwan about its economic development, Lee instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance and the Cabinet level-Council for Economic Planning and Development to coordinate closely and to come up with measures to cope with the situation.

According to news reports, George Soros, the famed hedge fund manager, said on Oct. 5 in Washington that while the worst of the Asian crisis may be over, Taiwan's economy may worsen before it gets better.

Commenting on the two-year NT$200 billion tax-cut program proposed by an opposition party, Lee said that there are three main factors that affect economic development: investment, exports and increases in consumption. He added that boosting investment and exports, as well as enlarging domestic demand, is quite important in stabilizing the national economy, making the feasibility of tax cut quite low.
Meanwhile, Finance Minister Paul Chiu said there is no room for a tax reduction.

In response to questioning by KMT Legislator from Tainan County Hung Yu-chin at the Legislative Yuan, Chiu said Taiwan's taxes amounted to only 16 percent of its gross national product (GNP), a lower percentage than those of European countries, the United States and Japan. Total tax revenue in those countries amounts to between 18 percent and 31 percent of their respective GNPs.

Chiu pointed out that at present the government already has tax reduction measures, such as the two-in-one tax system, and regulations governing the promotion of small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). He added that such measures have helped SMEs reduce their taxes and that there is no additional room for further reductions.

According to Chiu, any revision in the tax system must take into consideration the health of the national financial structure as a whole. Otherwise, he added, it will create confusion in the tax system.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S FLIGHT SCHEDULE TO AND FROM MAINLAND CHINA FINALIZED

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) released Wednesday the detailed flight schedule of its chairman, Koo Chen-fu, who will visit mainland China from Oct. 14 to 19.

According to the schedule, Koo and his entourage will leave Taipei on the morning of Oct. 14 on a China Airlines flight for Hong Kong and transit from there on a Eastern Airlines aircraft to Shanghai at 3:25 p.m.
He is slated to head for Beijing from Shanghai on Oct. 16 on an Eastern Airlines flight and is expected to arrive in Beijing at 4:30 p.m.
After a two-day stay in Beijing, Koo will fly to Tokyo on the morning of Oct. 16 aboard a United Airlines flight and will return to Taipei aboard another United Airlines flight at 9:20 p.m.

The schedule was hammered out by SEF after consultations with Koo's Beijing host, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), and has been relayed to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said SEF officials.
Koo must transit at Hong Kong and Tokyo on his way to and from the mainland because of the absence of direct air links between Taiwan and mainland China.
This will be Koo's first trip to Beijing as the head of SEF and his second meeting with ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'GO SLOW, BE PATIENT' POLICY TO BE REVIEWED UNDER CONDITIONS: SIEW

TEXT.P: The government will only review its "go slow, be patient" policy under certain conditions, Premier Vincent Siew said on Wednesday.

The review will happen when the political and economic situation in the mainland become stable, when there is a marked improvement in cross-strait relations, when Beijing respects Taiwan as an equal political entity and the fact that separate rule exists on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is recognized and when both sides of the Taiwan Strait have reached an agreement to safeguard the interests of Taiwan investors, Siew said.

Only when those conditions are met will the government review and adjust the "go slow, be patient" policy under the premise that adjustment to the policy will not affect the island's economic stability.
Siew made the remarks when he met with more than 100 representatives from more than 40 Taiwan business associations on the mainland.
Siew stressed that the government will actively take the initiative to improve cross-strait relations so as to create a favorable environment for adjusting its trade policy toward the mainland.
He urged the mainland to reciprocate so as to create more room for improving cross-strait relations.

Speaking at the meeting, held at the Grand Hotel, Siew noted that the upcoming high-level talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be an important starting point to enhance positive exchanges and rebuild mutual trust, which he said also means that cross-strait relations have entered into a major new stage.
Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, is scheduled to travel to Shanghai and Beijing and meet with Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Siew said that he has high expectations for Koo's mainland trip and his meeting with Wang, hoping the trip by Taiwan's top negotiator, which takes place Oct. 14-19, will help set a model for developing pragmatic cross-strait relations and institutionalize cross-strait consultations so as to solve many outstanding issues across the Taiwan Strait.

The premier also said that the government has worked to achieve "mutually complementary and win-win" cross-strait trade relations, adding that various measures to improve cross-strait relations have been in place already.
Regarding the government's current "go slow, be patient" policy, he also said that the policy aims to further advance cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF SPEAKS ON IMPROVEMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) under the Executive Yuan, on Wednesday spoke about the conditions for easing restrictions on expanding cross-strait relations.

He said Taiwan may start negotiations on the so-called "three links" with mainland China and reconsider its "go slow, be patient" policy if cross-strait relations improve to the extent that both sides are able to solve bilateral problems pragmatically.
Chang made the remarks when he met with representatives of Taiwan businessmen from mainland China at a seminar organized by Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
The MAC chief told the gathering that in advancing relations with the mainland, the ROC government places a priority on protecting the lives and interests of Taiwan businessmen on the mainland.
He expressed the hope that those concerns will be listed as top-priority issues when both sides resume negotiations in the future.
Chang also touched on the forthcoming talks between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, in Shanghai in mid-October.
He said he expects the talks will be fruitful, paving the way for the resumption of systematic negotiations between Taipei and Beijing.

To show Taiwan's sincerity in improving relations with the mainland, Chang pointed out that the ROC government has recently suspended military drills designed to demonstrate this nation's military power.
He urged the Beijing authorities to change their irrational policies toward Taiwan so as to build stable and healthy cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES TOKYO NOT TO HARM TAIPEI TIES IN ENGAGING MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew repeated his call for Japan not to engage itself with Beijing at the expense of Taipei in an interview to be published by the mass-circulation Mainich Shimbun newspaper on Thursday.

Noting that Washington has repeatedly assured Taiwan that there is no change in its policy toward the island, the premier vowed not to accept the so-called "three noes" approach to Taiwan declared by US President Bill Clinton, namely no support for Taiwan's independence or its separation from mainland China and no support for its membership in international groups that require statehood.

Concerned that Beijing will try to achieve a similar diplomatic coup with Tokyo by demanding the same declaration, Siew solemnly warned Japan not to harm the interests of Taiwan while engaging itself with Beijing.

Siew also reiterated Taiwan's willingness to join in the efforts of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and the Asian Development Bank to help neighboring states pull through the financial storm that has gripped the region.
The interview, written by editorial-writer H. Kaneko, is part of a two-page supplement prepared to mark the ROC's National Day, which falls on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Taiwan's stock and foreign exchange markets both rallied on Wednesday.
The China Times: Russian people staged nationwide demonstrations to push for President Boris Yeltsin's resignation.
The United Daily News: The US dollar weakened on global markets, while the Japanese yen surged past 123 against the greenback.
The Liberty Times: The US Federal Reserve may further cut key interest rates.
The Independence Morning Post: Central government agencies will take over the Taiwan Provincial Government offices in Chunghsing New Village.
The Commons Daily: Opposition lawmaker accused a group of pro-unification politicians of being behind a subversive conspiracy aimed at gaining control of the ruling Kuomintang and barring the Democratic Progressive Party from becoming the ruling party in order to clear the way for their pursuit of unification.
The China Post: The appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar continues.
The China News: Crisis may threaten banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND STABILIZES PRICES AS INFLATION DIPS

TEXT.P: Consumer goods remained mostly stable as Thailand's inflation rate dipped slightly to 9.2 percent in the January-September period, Thai officials said on Wednesday.

Inflation has been kept under the 10 percent target set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) as part of its US$17.2 billion bailout package for Thailand signed in August 1997, according to the Commerce Ministry's report.

Prices on jasmine rice, vegetables, some fruits, chicken eggs and fuel fell in the first three quarters of 1998, while prices on electricity, cooking gas, bus fares, telephone fees and clothing remained stable compared to last year.
Prices increased for meat, fish, tap water, health care and expressway fees, the report said.

The gross domestic product is expected to contract at least 8 percent in 1998, but the Thai government has won praise for implementing financial reforms, stabilizing the Thai currency, achieving a current account surplus and bringing bank interest rates down.

DOC.HEADLINE: HE AIN'T HEAVY, HE'S MY SON
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Chung Kuan is like many other freshmen beginning classes at National Tsinghua University, but unlike some of his peers he does not ride a motorbike to school, instead his mother carries him to class every morning.
Chung Kuan, 18, who has palsy from shoulders down, is academically gifted despite his physical challenges. His greatest dream since he was young was "to go to college," said his mother Lu Pao-hsiu.

During the first day of class in Tsinghua's Chinese Literature Department, the freshman class discovered that they had an additional unexpected "classmate." It was Chung's mother, who is determined to accompany Chung to classes for the next four years. She has to.

Chung's lumber merchant father, Chung Yuan-jung, drives his wife and son from Chunan to the Tsinghua campus in Hsinchu in the morning. He makes the drive again in the afternoon to take them home. Each trip takes about 40 minutes.

The elder Chung is pleased to make the journey every day. "As long as my son is happy, I'm happy," he said. Actually, Chung Yuan-jung began driving his son to and from school since Chung Kuan began to attend junior high school years ago.

Chung Kuan was paralyzed from the shoulders down not long after birth, Lu said. Chung's parents have never known what caused their son to be inflicted with such a debilitating problem. Neither medicine nor rehabilitation has helped, Lu added.

She recalled how the pressure of preparing for the university entrance exams led to the deterioration of Chung Kuan's health, making him vulnerable to influenza, pneumonia and ulcers. He has even required emergency room treatment for several times over the past year.
With his strong will, Chung Kuan has never been beaten by his illnesses. He even managed to enter the best university located nearest to his home.
