DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MADE STEAM IRON RECALLED IN US
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-made steam iron for sale in the United States has been recalled after it was found to have caused burns among its users, the US Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Wednesday.

The "Onika" steam iron was made in Taiwan for a California-based volume-discount chain and was sold for US$4 apiece beginning last January. Around 7,000 Onika irons have been sold in the United States.

The commission found through their investigation that the product's design and material are potentially hazardous. The design of the iron's steam dispenser results in frequent accidental burns and the base of the product, which weighs about 150 grams, is made of a cheap plastic material with weak fire resistance.
The commission urged consumers to stop using the device and asked for a comprehensive recall of the defective product.
All production of the steam iron has been stopped.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE TO PASS RESOLUTION SUPPORTING ROC'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US House of Representatives is expected to pass a concurrent resolution on Friday to express its support for the Republic of China's bid to take part in World Health Organization (WHO) activities.
Rep. Gerald B. H. Solomon (R-NY), chairman of the House Rules Committee who initiated the resolution, made the revelation at a reception held on Wednesday evening in his honor.
Solomon said the resolution will be put up for debate and vote on the House floor on Friday.

The veteran House heavyweight said he would be delighted to see the passage of the resolution before his retirement. Solomon will not seek re-election in the November mid-term congressional elections.

The resolution said the 21 million people of Taiwan are entitled to appropriate and meaningful participation in WHO activities. It proposed that the United States push WHO to arrange for Taiwan to have a meaningful representation in the United Nations-affiliated organization.
As Taiwan is not a UN member, it cannot become a full member of WHO. Nevertheless, the resolution said WHO can admit observers which can participate in WHO activities.

The resolution further said Taiwan's participation in WHO will not only help improve Taiwan's health care and medical services but will also contribute to the improvement of regional medical services.
A concurrent resolution mainly expresses congressional opinions or sentiments and is not binding to the executive branch.
The Clinton administration has said it will not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.

Co-initiators of the non-binding resolution also included Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, and Bill Barrett (R-Nebraska), chairman of the House Asia-Pacific Subcommittee.

The original version of the non-binding resolution called for US support for Taiwan's full WHO membership. In order to win the support of more House members, the wording was changed to participation in WHO activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG LAMENTS TPG WORKERS TAKING TO THE STREETS

TEXT.P: James Soong, governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG), said that it is regrettable that nearly 1,000 TPG workers took to the streets on Thursday.
Soong made the remark while fielding questions from Taiwan Provincial Assembly member Lin Nan-sheng of the ruling Kuomintang at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.

Lin asked about media reports that said that more than 80 percent of the TPG staff will no longer support the KMT and asked about Soong's views on their protests in front of the Legislative Yuan Thursday afternoon.

Soong said high-ranking KMT officials have not fulfilled their duty, adding that they had failed to offer solutions to the problems faced by the TPG workers, nor had they explained the situation to the workers fully, which he believed has done damage to the party.

He also denied that the islandwide tour, also known as his "graduation tour," he will take before stepping down as the first popularly elected TPG head at the end of December will pave the way for a presidential bid in 2000.
The new head of the downsized TPG will be assigned by the central government.

Soong was responding to questions from DPP Taiwan Provincial Assembly members that his tour is aimed at paving the way for a presidential run and at drumming up support for provincial assembly members who want to run in year-end legislative elections.
Soong played down his islandwide tour, saying that this will be the fifth time he has toured the 309 townships, counties and cities of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR APPRECIATION TO HELP EXPORTS, DOMESTIC PRICES

TEXT.P: A stronger New Taiwan dollar will help stabilize domestic prices and boost exports, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Thursday.

The NT dollar has continued to appreciate against the US dollar, soaring more than one dollar in a seven-day trading session, DGBAS officials said. The NT dollar was trading at NT$32.905 against the greenback at noon on Thursday. It was the first time Taiwan's currency broke the NT$33 threshold over the past six months.
The appreciation has been attributed to a weakened US dollar.

Currencies in Southeast Asia have also seen a rally recently, but the appreciation of the NT dollar is not expected to undercut the competitiveness of Taiwan products, officials said, adding that Taiwan's exports are expected to rebound in the fourth quarter.

The appreciation in the NT dollar is expected to cut the cost of importing agricultural and industrial raw materials, and crude oil -- items which account for 68 percent of Taiwan's imports, DGBAS officials noted.
They added that although international prices for such items have begun to edge up, the higher value of the NT dollar will help stabilize domestic prices.

Due to the sharp depreciation of currencies around Asia in the wake of Asian financial turmoil, imports and domestic demand have dropped. The recent rally of the region's currencies is expected to boost imports to these countries. As half of Taiwan's exports are destined to Asian nations, this will help increase the island's trade with such countries, the officials said.

Taiwan's exports to the mainland and Hong Kong accounted for 22 percent of the island's total exports. The weakened greenback will ease pressure for the mainland and Hong Kong to depreciate their currencies.
When mainland China's exports begin to pick up, Taiwan's raw materials sent to the mainland for processing will also increase which will benefit Taiwan's export figures in the fourth quarter.

However, the DGBAS officials said whether Taiwan's exports to the United States and Europe will be affected remains to be seen. Growth in exports to the two destinations from the January-August period were 1.8 percent and 9.3 percent respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CENTRAL LIBRARY ADOPTS OCLC'S FIRST SEARCH SERVICE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Central Library (NCL) recently adopted a computerized search service that offers access to a variety of data banks and academic information.

The First Search Service system from Online Computer Library Center Inc. was installed recently at the library, connecting it to a system that serves more than 27,000 libraries in 64 countries, according to the NCL.

The system allows access to more than 80 popular data banks and enables users to obtain information from books, periodicals, scholarly research articles and conference reports in various academic fields.

Abstracts and summaries of most of the articles available through the service can be viewed on a terminal screen at the library. The full text of some articles may also be viewed on-screen, while the full text of other articles can be obtained only as an e-mail or fax message.
The NCL said they welcome inquiries on the use of the advanced search system. The Taipei-based library is open Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Online Computer Library Center Inc. is the world's leading library and information center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE SURPLUS EXPECTED TO REACH US$7 BILLION THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade surplus reached US$1.1 billion in September, the third consecutive month it has topped US$1 billion, the Ministry of Finance reported on Thursday.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the Department of Statistics under the Ministry of Finance, said that he was cautiously optimistic about Taiwan's trade performance in the fourth quarter and estimated that the trade surplus this year could reach US$7 billion.
Hsu noted that the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) had estimated that this year's trade surplus would reach US$4.8 billion.

The total surplus for the first three quarters of this year, however, is US$4.69 billion. If the surplus averages US$800 million a month for the next three months, the total surplus for the year would amount to US$7 billion, down from US$7.66 billion last year.

It is estimated that Taiwan's exports in September totaled US$9.51 billion, down 12.4 percent from the same period last year, while its imports totaled US$8.41 billion, down 13.7 percent from the same period last year.

Exports in the first nine months totaled US$82.54 billion, while imports amounted to US$77.85 billion during the same period, down 8.1 percent and 7.7 percent, respectively, from the same period last year.

Hsu attributed September's decline to sharp declines in exports to Hong Kong, Japan and Association of Southeast Asian Nations members, and to decreased imports from the United States, Japan, Europe and ASEAN members.

Taiwan's largest current trade deficit is with Japan, and Hsu said it is estimated that the deficit with Japan could reach US$17.5 billion to US$18 billion this year, up from US$17.3 billion last year.

Hsu said that Taiwan should continue to promote exports to the United States and Europe so as to make up for sagging exports to Asian nations and to minimize the impact of the Asian financial storm on Taiwan's exports.
He also said that the government should continue its public construction projects to stimulate domestic investment so as to maintain steady domestic economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE EXPORTS TO EUROPE AT THREE-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: The importance of Europe as a market is hitting home stronger than before, said Tham Kock Chee, an official with the Trade Development Board (TDB) of Singapore.
He said Singapore's exports to Europe in the first eight months of this year totaled S$18.6 billion (US$10.9 billion), the highest level recorded for the same period in the past three years.
Tham said the Netherlands was the fastest-growing export market, absorbing just under 20 percent of Singapore's exports to Europe.

According to the TDB, exports to the Netherlands in the first half grew 56.6 percent while trade rose 37.5 percent. Trade with the European Union in the same period grew 3.6 percent to S$25.7 billion.
Tham said Singapore's export to Europe will continue to grow in the second half, but at a slower rate.
"When the market in this region is down, you have to look for other markets. Europe is now doing well. It is natural for us to divert our attention (from Asia to Europe)," he said.
"Singapore companies could use this downturn to source for technology and establish strategic links with European companies, to better position themselves for economic recovery in Asia."

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES PROTECTIVE PACKAGE FOR CRIME VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet on Thursday approved a package of measures aimed at better protecting the well-being of victims of violent crime.
The protective package, drafted by the Ministry of Justice, will soon be referred to various government agencies for implementation.
Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo said the package is designed to complement the crime victims protection statute which took effect on Oct. 1.

"As the protection of crime victims covers many areas and involve many technical problems, it requires concerted efforts of various central government agencies and local-level governments," Cheng said, adding that detailed measures are needed to ensure smooth enforcement of the protection law.
The grand justice-turned-minister further said the package offers action guidelines for the establishment of comprehensive protective networks for victims of various kinds of violent crime.
"The package also signifies the government's determination to intensify protection for crime victims," Cheng stressed.

The package comprises measures for rescuing, saving or assisting victims of violent crime, and for security protection, financial compensation, lawsuit counseling, educational campaign and other related services, Cheng said.

"I hope all relevant central government agencies and city and county governments will cooperate closely to better protect the legitimate rights of crime victims or their families and to improve social order.
Highlights of the package include:
-- Prohibiting sales of publications featuring real crime plots for profits;
-- Strengthening statistics, analysis and research of crime victims and their problems;
-- Offering counseling services for victims of sexual crime and domestic violence;

-- Setting up crime victims protective institutions in accordance with the crime victims protection law to help the bereaved families of crime victims or those who were injured in violent crimes to rebuild their lives;
-- Opening emergency shelters for victims of sexual crimes or commissioning private institutions to offer such services;
-- Improving medical services and psychological counseling for sexual crime victims;
-- Tightening protection of personal safety and privacy of crime victims and their families;
-- Offering financial compensation for crime victims or their bereaved families in accordance with the newly enacted crime victims protection law.

Under the new statute, family members of victims who died or were critically injured in violent crimes may be eligible for compensation of up to NT$2.37 million (US$68,497) and NT$1.05 million (US$30,347), respectively.
Some 6,000 people die as a result of violent crimes each year with 500 more being severely wounded, according to a recent government report.
The new law obliges the government to promptly pay claimants NT$400,000 in emergency funds with which to pay for the victim's funeral.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIONS "SWEEPING ISLAND" CAMPAIGN OFF TO A ROARING START

TEXT.P: More than 100 members of northern Taiwan Lions Clubs got together Thursday at the 2-28 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei to kick off an islandwide cleanup campaign.

The campaign, one of the activities marking the Lions Clubs International's annual Service Day, will have Lions roaming the streets of Taiwan's cities. Streets will be swept and garbage collected in more than 20 cities and counties in central, southern and eastern Taiwan, said Lin Ming-teh, a spokesman for the Formosa Lions Club.

Several dozen group members will travel from city to city for a total of 25 days in the campaign. At each stop, they will be joined by local Lions Club members. During that time, streets will be swept by day and recycling workshops given by night, Lin said.

Environmental Protection Administrator Tsai Hsun-hsiung greeted the Lions Club members at a ceremony at the memorial park Thursday morning. He lauded the group's efforts, saying the campaign will serve as a catalyst to bring about larger-scale cleanup action islandwide.
Tsai said the amount of garbage produced by Taiwan households exceeds 8.9 million metric tons a year. Garbage dumps, incinerators and other waste-treatment centers are nearing saturation points.
The only effective way of solving the problem is to reduce the amount of garbage generated and to improve recycling efforts, Tsai noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO DISCUSS OIL PRICE ADJUSTMENT

TEXT.P: Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is scheduled to hold a meeting on Friday to discuss whether to lower their oil prices in response to a drop in the cost of imported crude oil.

The CPC announced Thursday that its operating revenues amounted to NT$30.37 billion (US$920.3 million) in September, with a pre-tax profit of NT$3.32 billion, NT$1.32 billion above its legislatively mandated profit ceiling.
From July to September, the CPC's profits exceeded the amount permitted for a three-month period by NT$4.66 billion.
A significant increase in the amount of oil refined and a drop in production costs were the major reasons for the excess profits, officials said.
The recent appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar is making crude oil even less costly for the CPC to import, they added.
The US dollar has lost ground against the local currency for the past eight days, closing at 32.96 on Thursday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.

Despite the advantages of a cut in oil prices, the CPC officials noted, international oil price are now starting to rise. Officials said this development could influence any possible price adjustments announced by the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR RISES TO SIX-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar broke through the 33-mark Thursday, surging NT$0.379 to close at 32.967 to the US dollar, the currency's highest level in six months.
Interbank US dollar trading, meanwhile, amounted to US$955.5 million, its highest level this year.

A recent decision by the US Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates in an attempt to boost the US economy and offset economic problems abroad has resulted in the NT dollar's current eight-day appreciation streak, dealers said.
Further gains are expected in the future, dealers said, noting that more US dollar holders will seek to sell their newly weakened greenbacks.
The NT dollar opened at the day's low of 33.21 to the greenback on Thursday and peaked at 32.83 in the day's trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SURGE ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 295.34 points to close at 6,970.23.
Encouraged by gains by the NT dollar against the greenback, the bourse opened at 6,726.12 points, 51.23 higher than on Wednesday's close, and continued its upward move until the closing bell.

A total of 4.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$127.10 billion, surging from the previous trading session which saw 2.64 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$76.99 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 5.7 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 4.7 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 4.5 percent, electrical shares at 4.4 percent, construction stocks at 4.1 percent, textile issues at 3.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 3.7 percent and cement stocks at 3.3 percent.
Stock index futures were higher as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October surged 342 points to close at 6,981, with 3,281 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for November moved up 331 points to finish at 6,901, while December futures rose 380 points to 6,920, March futures increased 283 points to 6,798 and June futures surged 285 points, closing at 6,720.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 360, 52, 18 and seven, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA TO BE FORMALLY MARKETED IN TAIWAN IN DECEMBER

TEXT.P: Prices for the smuggled anti-impotency drug Viagra are declining in Taiwan, while legally imported "small blue pills" are poised to enter the local market before the end of this year, the United Evening News reported on Thursday.

The paper quoted a senior executive with the Taiwan subsidiary of the US-based Viagra manufacturing firm Pfizer as saying that if all goes well, the company will be able to legally market the magic drug in Taiwan in December.
After a careful evaluation, the executive said the company has decided to adopt a low-price marketing strategy to stem smuggling of Viagra tablets from the United States into Taiwan.

"The retail price for a 50 mg Viagra pill will not exceed NT$600 (US$18.18)," the executive said, adding that the company is also studying the feasibility of even lowering the retail price to NT$500 per tablet.
In addition to discouraging Viagra smuggling, the executive said, the low-price strategy is also aimed at attracting local men to purchase the anti-impotency drug.
"We don't expect that the National Health Program will pay for Viagra any time soon. Therefore, we must market the drug at affordable prices," said the executive.

Pfizer has applied for permission to market Viagra in Taiwan. According to government regulations, the maker must present reports on clinical tests at several local hospitals. Such reports are needed to determine local patients' reaction to the drug and the dosage most suitable for Taiwan users.

The executive said Pfizer researchers have completed a detail analysis of clinical test reports provided by Taiwan hospitals. "We'll present the analysis and other required additional documents to Taiwan's health department later this month. Once the Department of Health (DOH) finalizes its screening and issue a green light, we can market the drug within six weeks. If all goes smoothly, the four-pill pack drug will be formally marketed in Taiwan before year's end," he added.
Meanwhile, the United Evening News reported that even though Viagra has not been legally marketed in Taiwan, some 10,000 Taiwan men have managed to use the drug so far.

With legal marketing of the drug increasingly imminent, the paper said, retail prices for smuggled Viagra tablets have declined significantly in recent weeks, from between NT$1,000 and NT$2,000 per tablet to between NT$600 and NT$800. Some black market retailers even offer special discounts for those who make large purchases.
DOH officials said sales of Viagra remain illegal before the DOH formally issues a marketing permit. Violators can receive a maximum seven-year sentence plus a fine of up to NT$150,000.

However, the officials admitted that they have difficulties cracking down on illegal sales of smuggled Viagra pills because black market retailers have consistently struck such deals via cellular phones.
"We can only remind members of the general public of the dangers of using smuggled Viagra tablets," said a DOH official.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR'S APPRECIATION COULD BOOST DOMESTIC DEMAND: MOEA

TEXT.P: The recent appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the US dollar will result in an infusion of capital and the expansion of domestic demand, said officials with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Thursday.

The degree of the appreciation of Taiwan's currency has led to manufacturers selling greenbacks for NT dollars, a situation favorable to the infusion of capital into the domestic market and to a greater willingness by business people to invest, remarked the MOEA officials, adding that this development is also conducive to a reduction in the cost of imports and to the stabilization of domestic prices.

Taiwan merchants said that a stable exchange rate between the NT dollar and the US dollar is highly desirable, and they thought that an exchange rate of NT$32-NT$34 against the US dollar is a reasonable figure.

Wang Chih-kang, minister of the MOEA, noted earlier that a small-scale appreciation of the Taiwan dollar would not have much of an impact on Taiwan's exports; it would instead contribute to the stabilization of Taiwan's domestic prices.

The rise in the value of the NT dollar will not greatly affect Taiwan's exports, because Taiwan's counterparts -- other export-oriented countries -- are also seeing their currencies appreciate against a weakened US currency, Wang added.
On the other hand, an appreciation in Taiwan's currency will be beneficial to the island's importers and keep domestic prices stable, the minister remarked.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the Statistics Department of the MOEA, said that the current increase in the value of the Taiwan dollar against the US dollar -- about 4 percent to 5 percent -- is rather low compared with that of the Japanese yen, which has appreciated about 18 percent against the US dollar, rising from 150 yen to 123 yen against the greenback.

A large-scale appreciation will surely affect the competitiveness of Taiwan's exporters, said Chang. He further said that if the NT dollar rises by more than 10 percent against the US dollar, the ministry will survey the island's exporters to learn their opinions on the matter.
As the current appreciation has been relatively low, it is best that the market alone determine the currencies' exchange rate, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG PROBLEM GETTING SERIOUS IN AUSTRALIAN CITIES

TEXT.P: The drug problem in Australia's largest city, Sydney, and in other cities in New South Wales is getting more serious as the demand for drug rehabilitation centers is exceeding the supply.
A new survey shows nearly 11,700 people will seek admission to the non-government centers for treatment.

Only 3,392 people will be admitted to treatment while the rest will be turned away because of a severe shortage of places, according to Peter Connie, head of the Network of Alcohol and Drug Agencies, which conducted the survey.
He said the total capacity of the residential drug treatment sector -- mainly clinics offering long-term rehabilitation -- has not changed since 1996.
"Just 28 percent of people who inquire about a residential treatment service get one, down from 32 percent in the 1996 survey," he said.
He said more than 60 percent of drug addicts have been refused admission because there was no treatment place available.
Connie said the New South Wales needs 3,064 extra places on top of the current 2,321 places now available.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA EXPECTED TO REDUCE PAYOUTS TO POLITICIANS

TEXT.P: The Howard government is expected to put a halt to the excessive payouts to politicians drawn on their taxpayer-funded superannuation benefits following a public outcry over the generous super scheme.
John Watson, the Liberal chairman of the Senate's superannuation committee, said members of Parliament should have to wait until they turn 55 before they can access their superannuation funds.

He called for an independent inquiry to stop payments such as the A$45,000 (US$28,125) a year that Senator Bill O'Chee will earn for the rest of his life if he leaves the Senate as expected next year. By then he will be only 34 years old, the Australian daily reported.
Watson said he hoped Prime Minister John Howard would satisfy public demands to reform the generous parliamentary scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEN ESCAPING WORST EFFECTS OF FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to escape the worst effects of the Asian financial crisis, suffering only a mild recession, according to international consultants KPMG Barents.

The survey shows the Asian economic crisis could cost countries in the region US$1.5 trillion, but Australia would be mildly hit because its corporate sector was well capitalized with a sound monetary policy and realistic property values, according to Barents' global chief executive officer, Bill Haworth.
"We estimate the cost of fully addressing embedded credit losses will range from US$1 trillion to US$1.5 trillion, just within Asia," he said.
"We still expect a mild recession with demand down for Australian exports and prolonged low growth as the global economy struggles towards recovery," he said.
He said it will take between three and five years for a full recovery, but said Australia should benefit from its "safe haven" status.

He said the likely scenario for developing countries involved lower interest rates, forcing the imposition of currency and capital controls and the prospect of hyper inflation, negative real interest rates and lower savings levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY'S FORMER FIRST LADY THANKS ROC FOR YOUTH ORCHESTRA FUNDING
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Teresa Carrasco de Wasmosy, founder of the newly formed Paraguayan Youth Orchestra, on Wednesday thanked the Republic of China government for a US$100,000 contribution to the group, saying the donation has helped make her dream come true.
Teresa Carrasco, wife of former Paraguayan President Juan Carlos Wasmosy, made the remarks at an opening ceremony for the orchestra's rehearsal room.

Agustin Liu, ROC ambassador to Paraguay, who attended the ceremony on behalf of the ROC government, said the money will help the orchestra purchase instruments for its members, many of whom are from families of modest means and cannot afford to buy their own instruments.
According to Carrasco, the Paraguayan Youth Orchestra, set up on Sept. 29, is the first and the only one of its kind in South America.

Carrasco said her idea to establish the orchestra came after attending a performance by a Costa Rican youth orchestra during a visit to that Central American country in 1993 in her capacity as the Paraguayan first lady.
She mentioned the idea to ROC First Lady Tseng Wen-hui during a visit to Taiwan last year. Tseng responded enthusiastically, and promised to extend a helping hand to the orchestra, Carrasco added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES FORMER JAPANESE MILITARY LEADER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui received a former Japanese military leader on Thursday, and stressed the importance of Taiwan's strategic position as regards the security of the Asia-Pacific region.

Tateo Fukuchi, former chief of staff of the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force, was making a courtesy call to the president. He was accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan and Lin Chin-ching, chairman of Taipei's East Asian Relations Association.

Lee told his visitor that from the points of view of geography, national defense, economy, and trade, the Republic of China on Taiwan is actually the pivotal power guarding the security of the Asia-Pacific region.

He said that stability and peace in the Taiwan Strait has come to the attention of the international community, and added that the ROC has the confidence and power to bring about and maintain peace in the area.
Fukuchi echoed Lee's viewpoint, saying that from the standpoint of security, the ROC is a vital power for the maintenance of peace in the Asia-Pacific region.

Fukuchi is now an adviser to Japan's Research Council for Monetary and Financial Affairs. He said he was deeply impressed by Taiwan's conspicuous progress in politics, economy, and national defense over the past decade. This is his second visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LEADERS ARRIVE IN TAIPEI FOR ROC NATIONAL DAY FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso arrived in Taipei on Thursday evening to attend the Republic of China's Double Tenth National Day celebrations.

ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu greeted Compaore and his party upon their arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. This is Compaore's third visit to Taipei since the African country restored diplomatic relations with the ROC in February 1994.
ROC President Lee Teng-hui will preside over a grand military ceremony to welcome Compaore at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall on Friday morning.
Another foreign leader, Grenadian Prime Minister Keith C. Mitchell, was due to arrive in Taipei later on Thursday night to attend the National Day festivities.

Meanwhile, organizers of the National Day rally conducted a rehearsal at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office on Thursday. The main theme of this year's National Day is "Mind Reform -- Creating a Harmonious Society."
The rally will take place at 10 a.m. on Saturday, presided over by Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan. President Lee will deliver his National Day message on the same occasion.
A series of parades and a variety of performances along Taipei's main streets will follow the rally.
Because of the National Day events, Taipei traffic authorities on Thursday began to enforce a three-day partial traffic control in the areas surrounding the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO TO LEAD 12-MEMBER DELEGATION TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced on Thursday that Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C.F. Koo will lead a 12-member delegation to mainland China on Oct. 14.

Accompanied by his wife, Koo, a veteran business tycoon who concurrently serves as a senior advisor to President Lee Teng-hui, and his delegation will tour Shanghai and Beijing from Oct. 14 through Oct. 19.
During his ice-breaking visit, Koo will meet again with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official relations.
The MAC has expressed its hope that the upcoming Koo-Wang meet will lay the foundation for a resumption of institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue, and for the improvement of cross-strait exchanges.

Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore in April 1993 to lay a framework for regular SEF-ARATS dialogue and consultations. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended these engagements shortly after President Lee made a landmark visit to the United States in 1995.

A final namelist of the delegation has not yet been formally announced, but it is expected to include four representatives of the National Unification Council (NUC), four from the MAC, and four from the SEF.

The probable NUC delegates are: either Kang Ning-hsiang of the Control Yuan, or Michael H. H. Siao, national policy advisor to the president; Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research; Chen Po-chih, professor of Economics at National Taiwan University; and Chang Jung-kung, director of the ruling Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Research Department.

Those from the MAC are expected to be: Jan Jyh-horng, director of the Department of Research & Planning; Johnson Liu, director of the Department of Legal Affairs; Chang Yung-shan, director of the Department of Information & Liaison; and Chang Chih-yu, section chief.

The SEF delegates will probably be: Shi Hwei-yow, secretary-general & vice chairman; Wu Hsin-hsing, deputy secretary-general; Chan Chih-hung, deputy secretary-general; and Hsieh Fu-yuan, director of the Department of Legal Services.

Meanwhile, Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), called on Koo to express the hope that DPP personnel will also be allowed to take part in the upcoming trip. Chiu was accompanied by DPP Legislator Lin Cho-shui and Yen Wan-chan, director of the DPP's Department of China Affairs.
Koo said the SEF fully respects the DPP's views, and promised to convey Chiu's sentiments to the MAC for its reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOWCASE COURT-MARTIAL BEGINS FOR FOUR MILITARY OFFICERS

TEXT.P: Court martial proceedings against four officers charged in a high-profile corruption case early this year opened on Thursday, in what is set to be a showcase trial.

The four -- a lieutenant general, a major general, a lieutenant colonel, and a major -- were prosecuted for leaking classified military information to defense contractors in return for money and sexual favors.

According to court documents, Maj. Gen. Wo Chi-kao, former director of the Engineering Department at the Headquarters of the Combined Services Force, and his two staffers, Lt. Col. Lee Cheng and Major Lee Chun-lin, disclosed the maximum price of a contract for the construction of a bomb-resistant ammunition depot to a defense contractor named as the Shengpai Company, with the intent of helping it win the contract in public bidding.

Meanwhile, Lt. Gen. Liu Hsueh-ta, director of the Military Affairs Bureau at the Ministry of National Defense, was accused of playing the role of broker in the deal between Maj. Wo and Chuang Ping-huang, Shengpai's owner.
The case came to light in January when Chuang ordered the kidnapping of Maj. Wo and Lt. Col. Lee Cheng, and the bombing of Wo's house in Kaohsiung after he failed to win the contract.

In Thursday's trial, both Lt. Gen. Liu and Maj. Gen. Wo denied any wrongdoing, despite admitting to having been treated by Chuang to wining and dining at luxurious restaurants, treatment which they dismissed as "normal social behavior."

Lt. Gen. Liu said at the trial that investigators showed him the transcript of a secretly recorded telephone conversation between him and Chuang which mistakenly interpreted his use of the English word "condition" for "commission," and led to him being accused of asking for kickbacks from Chuang.

Maj. Wo also denied his earlier confession to the investigators, saying that he was coerced into making a false statement because the investigators threatened to put him in a jail cell along with drug traffickers and rapists, which would expose him to sexual attacks and insults.
He said his only sin was associating with Chuang, and that he never promised to reward Shengpai with the ammunition depot contract. He also said he has returned a NT$200,000 bribe to Chuang.

Wo said he had rejected suggestions from the two accused staffers to limit the bidders' credentials in an attempt to make Shengpai and its associated firms the only eligible competitors in the public bidding.

Lt. Col. Lee Cheng admitted having received a NT$500,000 bribe from Chuang, including a check for NT$250,000 which he deposited in the bank account of his girlfriend Chiu Jui-ling, in addition to payment of NT$100,000 for drawing a construction blueprint for Shengpai, and a loan of NT$150,000 which was not repaid because of his detention in connection with the case.
But he denied doing Shengpai any illegal favors, and contended that he was only following Maj. Gen. Wo's orders.
Maj. Lee Chun-lin, charged with leaking classified information to Chuang, argued that the information stored on 10 computer disks which he gave to Chuang had already been made public.

He said he gave Chuang the information as a thank you gift because Chuang once suggested that he postpone his wedding, which made him put off a proposed business trip, thereby avoiding a flight on a plane which later crashed.
The trial, overseen by a panel of five military judges, continues.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEWER ASIANS IMMIGRATE TO CANADA DUE TO CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Asian economic crisis has been blamed for the drop in Canada's targeted immigration as fewer people than expected will move to Canada this year, Immigration Minister Lucienne Robillard said on Wednesday.

Of the approved candidates for immigration, about 15,000 skilled applicants have decided not to leave their homes. A common problem is that many prospective immigrants from Asia do not have the money required to resettle in Canada, Robillard said.

The target for new immigrants and refugees this year was between 200,000 to 225,000, but only 180,000 to 200,000 will likely move to Canada. Despite this year's decline, the target for 1999 will remain at the 225,000 level, the minister said.
Robillard said if immigration continued to decline, it may have a long-term negative impact on Canada's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP EXPRESSES DESIRE TO ATTEND KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Chiu Yi-jen, secretary-general of the main Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), visited Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman C.F. Koo on Thursday to express the DPP's desire to participate in the long-awaited Koo-Wang meeting.

Accompanied by DPP Legislator Lin Cho-shui and DPP Mainland Affairs Department Director Yen Wan-chin, Chiu told Koo that they hope DPP representatives can take part in the meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to spell out Taiwan's diverse voices.

Koo responded that the SEF fully respects the DPP's opinion, and promised that he will refer the DPP's proposal to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the government's highest-level agency charting Taiwan's mainland policy and overseeing SEF operations.
Koo is scheduled to depart for mainland China on Oct. 14 for a six-day visit at the head of a delegation composed mainly of government officials in charge of mainland affairs.
Koo and Wang are slated to meet for the second time on Oct. 18 in Beijing after a hiatus of more than five years.

Chiu said the DPP understands it does not have the right to demand that party members be included in Koo's delegation, but that it would like Koo to reflect the DPP's voice and stance to mainland China.
According to Chiu, the DPP has a three-point statement and one requirement which Koo should relay to the mainland:
-- Taiwan in an independent sovereignty which does not belong to mainland China;
-- Taiwan and the mainland should resume negotiations to tackle issues of major concern for people on both sides as soon as possible;
-- The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should cooperate to cope with major regional affairs under an international framework;
-- Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Wang should be invited to visit Taiwan to observe the elections planned for the end of this year and witness the democratic process in action.

SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow said in response that the SEF, an intermediary body authorized by the ROC government to deal with bilateral exchanges with mainland China, is fully capable of reflecting the voices and opinions of Taiwan's 21 million people.

Shi said the SEF can study the feasibility of inviting Wang to Taiwan since any such visit would be at working level. As for inviting Jiang, he said that is outside the SEF's jurisdiction and should be decided by relevant government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO LEAVE FOR SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: A Republic of China delegation led by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu will head for Saudi Arabia on Friday for an annual bilateral economic conference.
About 50 issues have been put on the agenda of the 16th ROC-Saudi Arabia Economic and Technological Cooperation Conference, including an investment protection accord and a commercial arbitrary pact.
Lin and his delegation are also slated to visit the United Arab Emirates and Oman before returning on Oct. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPES TO STRENGTHEN TIES WITH AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China hopes to strengthen its substantive relations with Australia through bilateral cooperation so that both countries can reap the benefit.

In a reception marking the Double Tenth National Day of the ROC in Canberra on Thursday night, Dr. Liu Polun, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO), said bilateral ties between the ROC and Australia are getting closer, and that he believes they will be further strengthened through economic cooperation.

In a separate function marking the same event, Benjamin Liang, director-general of the TECO office in Melbourne, said the ROC has successfully weathered the worst effects of the Asian financial crisis through its sound economic management and huge foreign exchange reserves.

He said the ROC government will not accept mainland China's "one country, two system" scheme for the eventual reunification of the two sides, and he quoted President Lee Teng-hui's remarks which stress that reunification will only be achieved under democracy, freedom and equal distribution of wealth.
He said Australia and the ROC are natural partners because the two nations are members of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, and both are also market-driven democracies.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO HELP EXPEDITE TAIWAN'S ACCESSION TO WTO

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang on Thursday urged the US government to help expedite Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
He also expressed the hope that Washington will send high-ranking officials to Taipei to enhance bilateral relations between the two countries.
Wang made the remarks at a cocktail party hosted by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei to mark the ROC's National Day which falls on Oct. 10.
In his remarks, the economics minister pointed out four principles his ministry has worked out to deal with the changing trends in international economy and trade:
-- Continue to expand domestic demand in order to maintain the growth of Taiwan's economy;
-- Quickly develop newly emerged industries and a technology-oriented economy;
-- Upgrade the quality of Taiwan's industries and consolidate the strength of small- and medium-sized enterprises; and
-- Increase the competitiveness of export businesses and create more opportunities for international cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The New Taiwan dollar surged past 33 against the US dollar on Thursday, while the Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted index gained 295 points.
The China Times: The ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party are expected to join forces to back the passage of the statute governing the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG).
The United Daily News: The US House of Representatives authorized Thursday a wide-ranging impeachment inquiry of President Bill Clinton, making him the third chief executive in history to face the threat of being removed from office.
The Liberty Times: The Legislative Yuan is expected to pass a third reading of the statute on the TPG downsizing on Friday.
The Independence Morning Post: The New Taiwan dollar continued an upward swing to close at 32.967 against the US greenback on Thursday.
The Commons Daily: Business tycoon Hsu Wen-lung calls for government restructuring and delegation of more powers to local-level governments.
The China Post: NT$ surges past 33; local currency rally is expected to continue.
The China News: Currency, stocks skyrocket.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR ECONOMICS MEETING IN SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu on Friday left for Saudi Arabia to attend the Taipei-Riyadh Economic and Technologic Cooperation Meeting.

Lin, leading a delegation of trade representatives and economics officials, said before departing Taipei that issues on forging accords related to investment guarantees and arbitration will be on the agenda of the meeting.

Members of the Taiwan delegation include economics officials from the Board of Foreign Trade, the International Cooperation Department and the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine, as well as representatives from Chinese Petroleum Corp., Taiwan Fertilizer Co. and the semi-official China External Trade Development Council.

Lin and the mission will head for other Middle Eastern countries, including the United Arab Emirates and Oman, after their visit to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. They are scheduled to fly back to Taiwan on Oct. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP MAINLAND SPORTS OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIWAN IN MID-OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Top mainland Chinese sports official Wu Shaozu is scheduled to lead a mainland delegation to Taiwan in mid-October for an eight-day visit, sources from the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) said Friday.

Wu, president of the All-China Sports Federation, will be accompanied by seven officials from the mainland Chinese Olympic Committee and two executives of the mainland press during the visit, the second of its kind by Wu since last year, when he led a group of Olympic gold medalists to Taiwan.

The visit is also part of an exchange program between the two Olympic committees, which reached a consensus years ago on members of the two committees visiting each other on a yearly basis, according to CTOC officials.
Huang Ta-chou, president of the CTOC, led a delegation of sports officials from Taiwan to the mainland cities of Shenyang and Beijing inquitquitquitquitquitquit
During their stay in Taiwan, Wu and his group will visit sports training centers and scenic spots in southern and eastern Taiwan, in addition to meeting Taiwan sports officials for seminars.

Members of Wu's delegation will include Wu Shouzhang, vice president of the mainland Chinese Olympic Committee (COC), COC Secretary Tu Mingdeh, COC Deputy Secretary Hou Shudong and Song Keqin, liaison affairs director of the COC.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND GARLIC NOW BEING SOLD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China has been formally allowed to export fresh garlic to Taiwan to help ease off garlic shortages and soaring prices in domestic markets, sources from the Taipei County Farmers Association reported Friday.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture contracted the Central Trust Bureau to authorize the first import of 8,000 metric tons of mainland Chinese garlic recently. The imported garlic, it is hoped, will alleviate upward pressure on domestic garlic prices, which have surged in recent months.
The 8,000 metric tons of mainland garlic, all originating from the northern province of Henan, were described by association officials as "big and cheap."

The Henan garlic is now available at major supermarkets and traditional markets around the island at an average price of NT$120 per kilogram. The retail price is about 45 percent lower than that of locally produced garlic, association officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SPONSOR FOURTH WORLD ELECTRONIC FORUM

TEXT.P: The fourth World Electronic Forum (WEF) will open in Taipei on Oct. 20 and will be attended by representatives of 19 electronic information business associations from 13 countries and regions, including Taiwan.

This will be the first time the annual conference has taken place in Taiwan since it began in 1995. The conference aims to facilitate business cooperation and information exchanges among electronic information businesses around the globe.

Wu Si-chung, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturing Association, said that in the upcoming forum, a call for the promotion of free trade will be issued. Wu urged economies to solve trade disputes by negotiations rather than tariffs and trade barriers.

Citing instances in which the European Union (EU) has enacted anti-dumping measures to protect their industries against Taiwan's strong exports, Wu said the EU must admit that some Taiwan electronic products are competitive in Europe, just as the cellular phones sold in Taiwan adhere to European frequency standards, such as GSM900 and DSC1800.
Protectionist measures are not the best way to solve trade disputes, especially as the world has been moving toward freer trade, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PILOTS SMELLED SMOKE BEFORE SWISSAIR FLIGHT 111 CRASHED

TEXT.P: Canadian investigators confirmed Thursday that the pilots of Swissair Flight 111 had smelled smoke before the jet crashed early last month off Nova Scotia.

Vic Gerden, lead investigator for the Transportation Safety Board of Canada, said flight data recorders have revealed the crew decided to divert the plane to Halifax after smelling and then seeing smoke.
But Gerden said there is no indication of smoke in the passenger cabin, or of problems in handling the aircraft before the last 90 seconds of recorded data.

He added that in those 90 seconds, the flight data recorder recorded a sequence of fault codes that could provide important clues about the cause of the disaster. Those codes will take time to decipher, and they will only indicate the symptoms, not the source, of any problems experienced, he said.
The recorders stopped working six minutes before the crash, which killed all 229 people on board.
Investigators reported that phase one of the recovery operation is now complete and all accessible human remains have been recovered.
The second phase will involve using a heavy lift to recover as much of the remaining debris as possible before weather conditions deteriorate.
The pilot and co-pilot were identified by DNA recently, according to Dr. John Butt, the investigation's chief coroner. An outside agency will perform toxicology tests on their remains, he said.
To date, 78 people have been identified through dental records, X-rays and DNA testing.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK'S NEW CARD TAKES PLACE OF TRAVELER'S CHECKS, CASH

TEXT.P: Singaporeans no longer need to buy traveler's checks or carry a wad of foreign currency notes when they go abroad -- if they have the Citibank Visa TravelMoney (VTM) card.

This pre-paid disposable card, akin to a normal cash card, enables travelers to withdraw cash -- in the local currency of the country visited -- at favorable exchange rates from any of Visa's 4,440,000 ATMs in more than 120 countries.

"It is safe and convenient alternative to carrying cash or traveler's checks," said Kevin Piette, a director of Citicorp Global Product, which launched the card here on Thursday. Singapore is only the second Asian country, after the Philippines, to issue the card. It will be launched in the United States soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA, CHINA, TAIWAN COULD JOIN WTO SOON

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO), the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank pledged to facilitate the early accession of new members -- including Russia, mainland China and Taiwan -- to the WTO and to guard against protectionism, particularly in developed countries.
The three organizations also pledged greater cooperation to boost world economic stability and growth.
An increased WTO membership and a greater sense of national responsibility for problems are the best ways to resolve the current global financial crisis, WTO head Renato Ruggiero said.
"We have 33 countries which are candidates for admission," said Ruggiero.
"We have to try and speed up the process of accession, to avoid a division between countries which share rules and obligations and countries which do not share rules and obligations."
The 132 countries that are already members of WTO account for 90 percent of world trade.
Ruggiero said the common rulebook of the WTO would be more Successful in promoting economic growth than a return to protectionism.
"No country can introduce protectionist measures and continue to export to other markets," he said. The opposite approach of greater liberalization was essential, Ruggiero said.
"We have to continue preparations for further liberalization, which will begin in 1999."
The next meeting of WTO trade ministers will be held in late 1999 in the United States. The principal role of WTO is to promote free trade between member countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA RECORDS STRONG EMPLOYMENT GROWTH IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Australia experienced strong job growth in September, indicating its economy has remained resilient in the wake of the Asian financial crisis.
Employment Minister David Kemp said 41,300 jobs -- most full-time ones -- were created in September, about 10,000 more than expected.

The federal government and financial market economists said the growth augured well for increased consumer spending and improved confidence in the domestic economy over the next six months -- just as the worst of the Asian contagion is expected to hit.
Despite a surge in employment, Australia's unemployment rate however remained high at 8.1 percent in September and the figure is unlikely to fall below 8 percent before June 1999, Kemp said.

But opposition Employment Minister Martin Ferguson warned the Howard government should start explaining what they will do to create jobs before the expected 10 percent tax on goods and services is introduced at the turn of the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY SNORERS SAID IN DANGER OF HAVING HEART DISEASE

TEXT.P: Heavy snorers should visit their doctors to find out whether they are at risk of hypertension and cardiovascular disease, according to a leading Australian sleep expert.

Dr. John Wheatley, president of the Australian Sleep Association, told the Sydney Morning Herald that sleep apnea, a condition in which people persistently stop breathing for a few seconds throughout the night, can cause extreme stress on the heart.
He said that for people who stop breathing between 10 and 14 times an hour during sleep, the risk of heart disease is more than four times higher than it is for the general population.
When a person stops breathing, the body is deprived of oxygen and the nervous system is stimulated. These two conditions increase the amount of work the heart has to do.
He said being overweight and drinking alcohol -- both separately linked to heart disease -- can cause apnea because extra fat deposits around the neck may narrow the airways.

Aging, which makes muscles and tissue floppy, may cause temporary obstruction in the airways of people who have not previously had a problem. But genetics is also a factor, with some people's air passages up to a third narrower than the average, Wheatley said.
"Age 40 to 60 years is when we clinically pick up a lot of people. Their partners are very important because the snorer is usually unaware of the nighttime stuff," he said.
People who snore sometimes gasp for breath or cough after a bout of excessively loud snoring. In the morning, such people often feel groggy and unrefreshed, he said.

He said most people have some non-breathing episodes each night, especially in the first hour or two after falling asleep. But more than five episodes an hour indicate an apnea problem. About 10 percent of snorers are apnea sufferers, he said.
He suggested losing weight and abstaining from alcohol as ways for people to reduce sleep-related breathing problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STOCK MARKET, CURRENCY DOWN

TEXT.P: Australia's stock market and its currency lost ground in Friday morning trade after reports of a renewed plunge by the US dollar against the Japanese yen and heavy sales by US hedge fund operators, analysts said.
The All Ordinaries Index fell 16.8 points to 2,486.5 in morning trade from Thursday's close of 2,503.3.
The Australian dollar was trading at 61.95 US cents on Friday morning, down from its high of 62.33 US cents in London on Thursday night.
The Australian dollar had hit a two-and-a-half-month high because of a surge in the value of the Japanese yen against the greenback. The yen climbed to 114.84 against the US dollar on Thursday night.
The US dollar has fallen more than 17 percent in just two days from its level of about 135 yen early on Wednesday, analysts said.
They said the yen's resurgence has fueled a rally in the Australian dollar, which gained 4 US cents in just 24 hours.
They said the sudden strength of the Australian dollar has caused fears among stock investors that the profits of Australian companies with earnings offshore may suffer.
Analysts said aggressive selling by hedge funds sitting on a mountain of losses was behind the sharp rises in the Australian dollar and the yen.
They said investors are expected to be nervous because the stock and foreign exchange markets will likely remain volatile in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AND TAIWAN BOURSES WORKING ON DUAL LISTINGS

TEXT.P: The Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES) is working with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on dual listings, but details have not been finalized, an SES spokesman said in response to media queries.
The SES and TAIEX are working on establishing a link that will allow investors in both countries to trade stocks listed on the two exchanges.

A report in Thursday's Commercial Times of Taiwan said the two exchanges will sign an agreement at the end of this year and the tie-up will be effective starting early next year. It said the project was part of Taiwan's plan to internationalize its financial markets.
In Singapore, the proposed linkage drew a favorable response from both institutional and retail investors.
Fund managers said the idea of a single point of access to the two markets is very attractive.
"It is good news, although we still need to see the details," said Ian Li, managing director of fund management group Indocam Singapore.
"It makes a lot of sense for Singapore to do this. It will increase the breadth and depth of the market which is definitely what Singapore needs."
By market capitalization, Taiwan is the third-largest stock market in Asia after Japan and Hong Kong and is more than twice the size of Singapore's market.

With a Taiwan stock index futures contract already trading on the Singapore International Monetary Exchange, Singapore investors will also be able to take advantage of arbitrage opportunities once they are able to access the spot market in Taiwan, traders said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR SURGES TO SIX-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar gained more ground on Friday, closing the morning at 32.79 against the US dollar, a six-and-a-half-month high, according to foreign exchange market sources.
The NT dollar rallied NT$0.178 higher against the greenback in the morning session, on a heavy turnover of US$415 million.
The Taiwan currency has gained ground against the US dollar every trading day since Sept. 29, and since then the currency has surged a total of NT$1.77 against the greenback.
Dealers attributed the appreciation to exporters cutting US dollar holdings on hopes of further gains by the local currency, dealers said.
The Central Bank of China, however, may consider intervening in the market if it is felt the NT dollar is rising too fast too quickly, dealers said.

Dealers with foreign banks foresee the Japanese yen rising to 110 against the US dollar. Flat in recent weeks, the US dollar will continue to lose steam in the coming days, it has been widely speculated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC UNVEILS KOO DELEGATION LIST

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday unveiled the list of 11 delegates who will accompany Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo to visit mainland China next week.

MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng told a news conference that as Koo's Oct. 14-19 trip to Shanghai and Beijing is mainly aimed at promoting exchanges between the two intermediary bodies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the top concern in delegate selection is professional expertise and functions.

"Based on this principle, the delegates all come from institutions in charge of mainland China-related work, such as the National Unification Council (NUC), MAC and SEF," Sheu said, adding that none of them have been selected for their party affiliation.

Delegates from SEF are Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow; Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng, who is also director of the MAC's Department of Research and Planning; Hsieh Fu-yuan, director of the Department of Legal Service; and Ho Wu-liang, a section chief with the legal service department.

The delegates also include Kang Ning-hsiang, an NUC member; and three NUC researchers -- Wu Rong-i, also president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research; Chang Jung-kung, also director of the ruling Kuomintang's Department of Mainland Research; and Pao Chung-ho, also a political science professor with National Taiwan University. The NUC is a consultative body attached to the Presidential Office.

Although the pro-independence main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has on many occasions expressed its intention to send a representative with Koo's delegation, no DPP member has been included.

"We feel regret that there will be no DPP member in Koo's mission," said DPP Secretary-General Chiou I-jen. "The DPP intends to take part in Koo's delegation not out of partisan consideration. We simply hope to clearly and comprehensively express the fundamental stance and common aspirations of the Taiwan people."

Chiou said he is convinced that DPP's absence from the upcoming talks between Koo and his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) will have an adverse impact on future cross-strait interaction.
He went on to say that the DPP will call a news conference on the eve of Koo's departure for his landmark mainland visit to explain the party's views on the event.

"Incumbent and all previous DPP chairmen will be invited to attend Tuesday's press conference to give a detailed explanation of our party's stance on Koo's mainland trip," Chiou said, adding that the DPP will also make a proper response after Koo's delegation returns to Taipei.

Koo's forthcoming mainland trip is widely seen as a major breakthrough in the more-than-three-year cross-strait impasse. MAC, which oversees SEF operations, said earlier this week it is hopeful that Koo's mainland trip will help lay a solid foundation for the resumption of institutionalized dialogue and consultations between SEF and ARATS as well as for the improvement of cross-strait relations.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue shortly after ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995. Beijing interpreted Lee's US trip as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

During his upcoming mainland visit, Koo, also a senior adviser to President Lee, will hold several rounds of talks with Wang on a broad range of issues of mutual concern. He will also meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen for wide-ranging talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO KICK OFF ISLANDWIDE CAMPAIGN TOUR SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will formally kick off its campaign tour around the island Saturday.

DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung expressed the hope that candidates solicit votes through their views on various policies, instead of engaging in a war of words, as has been seen in recent days between the ruling Kuomintang and DPP candidates.

The DPP's central campaign team will comprise DPP mayors and county magistrates, legislators and National Assembly deputies. They are scheduled to roam the streets to meet with voters in the morning and appear at campaign rallies in the afternoon to drum up support for DPP candidates.

All DPP candidates nominated by the party will sign a letter in which they pledge to conduct a clean campaign, avoid entanglements with special interest groups and make public their political donations.

The campaign team will launch its first stumping tour at Taipei Dunhua Primary School Saturday night. Chairman Lin, current Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the DPP and nine DPP legislative candidates will participate in the rally.
The DPP campaign team has attached special importance to Kaohsiung City, hoping its candidate, Frank Hsieh, can beat the current mayor, Wu Den-yih of the ruling Kuomintang.
The theme of the DPP's campaign in the year-end elections will be "We Deserve a Better Life."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NET GAIN FOR MAINLAND IF YUAN IS DEVALUED: STUDY

TEXT.P: The adverse impact of a devaluation of the yuan on mainland China's trade with East Asia would more than cancel out any benefits from the move, according to a study by researchers at the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

In a recently released paper, MAS's external economies division argues that if a yuan devaluation leads to a further regional slowdown, the mainland is likely to feel the impact on its exports to, and investments from, Asia. This would likely overwhelm the benefits of more price-competitive mainland exports.
MAS said the views expressed in the paper -- titled "The Impact of the Asian Crisis on China: An Assessment" -- are those of its staff and should not be attributed to the MAS.
The paper distinguishes between the "price effect" of the Asian crisis on the mainland and the "income effect" of a yuan devaluation.
Anecdotal evidence suggests that price competition from the region has already affected selected industries in the mainland, such as textiles and steel, according to the study.
The result has intensified lobbying from some mainland industries for a devaluation of the yuan.
But the study points out that mainland exports to the United States and European Union -- regions that accounted for 31 percent of the mainland's exports in 1996 to 1997 -- remain strong.
This has helped to cushion the impact of declining export growth to East Asian countries.
But MAS researchers point out that excluding Hong Kong, the Asian tigers and Japan account for 28 percent of the mainland's exports and more than a quarter of its direct foreign investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DECLINE ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share price opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 26.06 points to close at 6,944.17.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,990.06 points, 19.83 higher than Thursday's close, but declined after strong fluctuation near the closing bell.

A total of 4.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$128.84 billion, increasing from the previous trading session which saw 4.17 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$127.10 billion.
Only two of the eight major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.8 percent.

The other six major categories all registered losses, with plastics and chemical stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.9 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.9 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, and construction shares at 0.4 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were also lower.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October decreased 81 points to close at 6,900, with 3,290 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 66 points to finish at 6,835, while December futures declined 72 points to 6,848, March futures decreased 18 points to 6,780 and June futures dropped 113 points, closing at 6,672.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 408, 43, nine, and one, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD URGES STIMULATION OF DOMESTIC CONSUMPTION

TEXT.P: The government must stimulate domestic consumption to maintain Taiwan's economic development, former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Hsu Hsin-liang said on Thursday.
Hsu, who is now chairman of Rising People Foundation, made the remarks during an address at the Keelung City Cultural Center on Taiwan's economic situation amid the Asian financial storm.

He said that he believes the world economy will gradually recover over the next two years, but added that if Taiwan is hurt too badly during the current regional financial turmoil, it will be hard for it to keep up with the pace of the rest of the world.
Hsu said that at a time when Taiwan's exports are in decline, it is necessary for Taiwan to stimulate domestic consumption to help maintain Taiwan's economy.

The former DPP chairman also said that the ruling Kuomintang's package to increase the budget for public construction by NT$190 billion (US$5.86 billion) over the next two years to expand domestic demand will be a rash way to spend money, claiming that it will only result in shoddy work.

He reiterated his own proposal to cut NT$300 billion (US$9.09 billion) in taxes over the next two years, saying that if the commodity tax and security transaction taxes are halved, this will encourage more consumption and more stock transactions.

He also said that Taiwan has strong production ability, but has become increasingly reliant on OEM production for overseas brands. This is making it more difficult for the island to create its own brands now, he pointed out.

However, Hsu stressed the fundamental factor governing Taiwan's economy will be normalized cross-strait relations, and more of a foothold for Taiwan companies in mainland China's market, adding that Taiwan will have the advantage over other nations if it makes further inroads into the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TRADE DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 10-member trade delegation from mainland China's Fujian Province will arrive here on Tuesday to promote the coastal province's investment environment.
Fujian Governor Zhang Jiakun will head the delegation, whose members include Fuzhou City Mayor Weng Fulin Kemin, and businessmen from the province.
Taipei's Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), who will host the delegation, said that the delegates will not meet with political figures while here.

As the risk to Taiwan businessmen investing in the mainland has recently increased, CNFI officials will arrange meetings between the delegation and Taiwan business leaders to exchange views on the difficulty Taiwan businessmen face in Fujian Province.
The delegation, which was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan in August, delayed its trip after a Taiwan councilwoman was kidnapped and murdered in the mainland in late July.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.144 against the greenback in Taipei on Friday, closing at 32.823.
The local currency opened at 32.87 and was traded between 32.742 and 32.888.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$665 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTREPRENEUR CRITICIZES GOVERNMENT'S REFORM CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: An entrepreneur who is well-known in Taiwan for building his Chi Mei "kingdom" into a company, a museum, and a hospital, on Friday broke his customary silence to voice discontent with the "government reform" campaign implemented by the Executive Yuan.

W.L. Shi criticized administrative authorities for excessive interference into people's lives by means of restrictive laws and regulations, despite the government reform, which he said underlines the need for the establishment of a small but efficient government.

Complicated and stringent regulations enacted to ensure orderly development of the island's business and industrial sectors seem to serve a "planned economy" system, rather than a "market economy" system, the entrepreneur said.

Shi stressed that local governments should be fully authorized to carry out administrative affairs, and urged the leaders of the country to "govern by doing nothing," following the ideas of the ancient Chinese philosopher Lao Tzi.

The Chi Mei Corporation, one of Taiwan's leading chemical producers, has the world's largest output of acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS). It is also listed as one of the top 50 businesses on the island.

Shi is noted for modeling his business administration on the teachings of Lao Tzi, and was invited by National Taiwan University to give a speech on his observations on the government's reform campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF SPELLS OUT US EXPECTATIONS FOR KOO-WANG TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States is hopeful that the soon-to-be-resumed dialogue across the Taiwan Strait will be substantive and constructive, the top US liaison officer with the Republic of China on Taiwan said on Thursday.

Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), made the statement while attending a cocktail reception marking the ROC's Double Ten National Day. The AIT is a quasi-official organization authorized by the US government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Bush said the United States looks forward to seeing the upcoming visit to mainland China by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Chairman C.F. Koo of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will help clarify any misunderstandings existing between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"We also hope to see the two sides forge a consensus to bring about deeper cross-strait dialogue and broader cross-strait cooperation," Bush said, adding he is convinced that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cooperate closely, they will certainly be able to mend their differences over both substantive and procedural issues.

Bush further pointed out four major developments in ROC-US relations over the past year, describing them as: the resumption of cross-strait dialogue; the signing of a bilateral agreement on the terms for Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization; Taiwan's ability to remain largely unscathed by the Asian financial turmoil; and the two summit meetings between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin.

Koo, accompanied by 11 mainland affairs administrators and experts, will leave Taipei for an ice-breaking mainland trip next week. Koo's Oct. 14-19 mainland visit will mark a major breakthrough in the long-stalled cross-strait relations.

During his mainland visit, Koo will meet with his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to discuss matters of mutual concern. Koo will also meet with Jiang and Vice Premier Qian Qichen for wide-ranging talks.

Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue shortly after ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995. Beijing interpreted Lee's US trip as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Senior Clinton administration officials have said they are happy to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume peaceful dialogue to resolve their disputes. They have also reaffirmed the US "no involvement, no interference" stance on cross-strait affairs.
The cocktail reception was hosted by the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C. in celebration of the ROC's National Day which falls on Saturday.
Nearly 3,000 guests, including Americans and overseas Chinese representatives, attended the reception to give their best wishes for Taiwan's well-being.
Among the well-wishers was Rep. Gerald Solomon (R-NY), chairman of the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives, who said that the long-standing US-ROC friendship will never change.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO PRESIDENT ACCORDED FULL MILITARY HONORS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui presided over a military ceremony, complete with a 21-gun salute, at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei on Friday to welcome Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore.

The head of state from the West African country arrived in Taipei Thursday evening for a 10-day state visit. This is Compaore's third visit to Taipei since Burkina Fas restored formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China in February 1994.
President Lee extended a warm welcome to Compaore, saying his visit will help boost bilateral cooperation fields in various fields.
Lee also lauded Compaore as an outstanding political leader in Africa as he has led his country in completing many major development projects.

For his part, Compaore said he is delighted to visit Taiwan again. He also reaffirmed his government's support for the ROC's bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Trade Organization.

During his visit, Compaore will exchange views with Lee on the current international situation, the ROC's relations with African states, bilateral cooperative projects and other matters of mutual concern.
The two leaders will sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitments to further promoting bilateral ties at the end of Compaore's visit.
On Saturday, Compaore will attend a grand ceremony marking the ROC's Double Ten National Day.
