Compaore is accompanied by several senior Burkina Faso officials, including Foreign Minister Ablasse Ouedraogo, on his current visit.

Following his Taipei visit, Compaore will travel to Tokyo on Oct. 17 to attend the second international African development conference in his capacity as the current president of the Organization of African Unity.
On Friday, Burkina Faso Foreign Minister Ouedraogo signed an investment promotion and protection agreement with his ROC counterpart, Jason Hu, to boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRADE VIA HONG KONG DECLINING
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Chang Yuan-hsiang and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The continuing decline of indirect trade across the Taiwan Strait via Hong Kong reflects the changes taking place in cross-strait trade, according to Hong Kong trade statistics.

Indirect trade between mainland China and Taiwan via the former British colony in the first five months of this year totaled HK$32.7 billion, a decline of 7.6 percent from the same period of last year.

Total trade from Taiwan to the mainland via Hong Kong in January through May was valued at about HK$27.3 billion, a slip of 8.9 percent, while trade from the mainland to Taiwan through Hong Kong in the same period totaled about HK$5.4 billion, a drop of 0.4 percent.

Prior to 1992, cross-strait trade was conducted primarily via Hong Kong. However, in the wake of a gradual increase in direct trade, either openly or covertly, between the two sides since 1992, indirect cross-strait dealing has fallen correspondingly.

Following the establishment in April 1997 of a direct shipping link between the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung and the mainland city of Fuzhou in coastal Fujian Province, trade volume via Hong Kong accounted for less than 60 percent of total cross-strait trade. The figure further plummeted to 55.2 percent in the first five months of 1998, a drop of 2.6 percent from the same period last year, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (I)

TEXT.P: The following is the full text of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's National Day message: Ladies and Gentlemen:

Today is the 1998 National Day of the Republic of China. We are gathered here, our hearts brimming with happiness, to celebrate the birth of our nation and, at the same time, solemnly take stock of the development of our country.

The formidable ordeals we experienced founding our country constituted a heroic chapter in modern world history, worthy of poetic praise and tears of gratitude. The recent achievements of the Republic of China on Taiwan have added one more glorious page to the history of human civilization. For 87 years, despite the incessant changes and tribulations on our national front, we have never failed to adhere to the ideals of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, our Founding Father, and, hence, have risen above the adversities and defeated the challenges. We have opened a new era of freedom and prosperity and proved to the world that truth is invincible and justice is always the winner.

In the past ten years or more, we have gone one step further to gradually push forward constitutional reform and consolidate democracy and the rule of law, in line with Dr. Sun's political ideal of "popular sovereignty." As a result, we have built a democratic system of deciding public affairs by the free will of all the people. We have carried out a "quiet revolution," winning worldwide acclaim and adding a new source of vigor to the camp of democracy. In the future, challenges may still come thick and fast from abroad and home, but we, already on the right side of history, are sure to overcome all the difficulties and stride forward to a great and brilliant future as long as we stay the course and remain united as one.

Judging from the circumstances that now surround us both at home and abroad, we must have a firm grasp of the world trend and complete the following renovations so that our national development may be further advanced well into the upcoming century.

With the recent constitutional reform as a guiding principle, we must streamline the administrative system and reinvent the government. Legislation for this purpose as well as a series of action plans have been initiated. They have to be meticulously formulated and thoroughly implemented in order to attain greater efficacy in governance and higher national competitiveness. At the same time, we should take into account the need of long-term national development and the worldwide trend of development so that we may have a more forward-looking and better-crafted system of democracy serving as a firm foundation for sustainable national development.

We are happy to note that initial headway has been made in our national effort to foster a happy, orderly and vigorous society based upon the two pillars of equity and justice. We have scored preliminary successes in educational reform, judicial renovation, and law and order. But, new ideas and new problems keep cropping up in a fast changing society such as ours. We must further improve long-range planning, continue the reform initiatives, make welfare services easily accessible, and strengthen the social security mechanism. It is hoped that the well-being of all the people will thus be enhanced on the basis of equity and justice. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (II)

TEXT.P: Good economic fundamentals have enabled us to sustain domestic prosperity and effectively cope with the sweeping Asian financial turmoil. In this regard, we have drawn worldwide attention and praise. From now on, we must devote special efforts to promoting an even healthier economic structure, removing barriers to investment, expanding the domestic market, and speeding up industrial upgrading. At the same time, we must guard against any aftershocks of the regional financial crisis and be prepared to create a new window of opportunity for our economy.

Based upon the principle of persistent defense and effective deterrence, we will continue with the military consolidation plan and the deployment of second-generation weaponry and equipment required for a modern defense force. At the same time, to ensure better security for our country, we must take advantage of our strategic position in the Asia-Pacific region and step up dialogue and cooperation with related nations in the interests of regional security and peace. As we continue our policy of national security and regional stability, our citizens must remain vigilant against any latent danger, recognize that national security guarantees safety for all, and pledge ourselves as the strongest bulwark for national security.

Our pragmatic efforts to participate in the international community, based on the ideal of mutual assistance and cooperation for world peace and prosperity, have begun to win recognition and approval from many nations. Henceforth, on the strength of our economic prowess and our democratic achievements, we will expand our presence in international organizations and activities. We will also increase international exchanges and cooperation, play a more prominent constructive role, dismantle anachronistic and unreasonable constraints on the international scene, and help shape a new world order of peace, cooperation and prosperity in the 21st century.

We are committed to the ideal of democracy, freedom and equitable prosperity in pragmatically promoting cross-strait relations. We are looking forward to constructive dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait based on the reality of divided rule. The two sides should promote mutual understanding through exchanges, dispel hostility through reciprocity, and seek eventual reunification under democracy by a gradualist approach. At the same time, we hope the Chinese communist authorities will recognize the world trend of democratization and thoroughly revamp their social and political system. For the sake of the long-term well-being of all Chinese people, they should also adopt a practical attitude, take a broader view, and foster a peaceful, stable, mutually beneficial and co-prosperous cross-strait relationship.

Ladies and Gentlemen: In the 87 years since its founding, the Republic of China has weathered an endless series of blows and trials. Throughout, it has stood tall, testifying that our nation-building spirit remains undiminished and that we have never stopped striving. Our faith and our feats have profound significance to the 21.8 million people and their descendants in the Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu area; they will also greatly influence the Chinese mainland's future course of development. Looking into the 21st century, I firmly believe that the Republic of China, with its people united in faith and in action, will shine even more brilliantly in the future.
In closing, may I wish the Republic of China great prosperity and every one of you good health and happiness. Thank you.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui's National Day address reaffirms commitments to the ideal of democracy, freedom and equitable prosperity in pragmatically promoting cross-strait relations.
The China Times: Under the joint buttress of the island's major political parties, the controversial act enjoining the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG) rammed through the legislature.
The United Daily News: The legislature finalized the TPG downsizing act.
The Liberty Times: The controversial TPG downsizing act cleared the legislature.
The Independence Morning Post: The legislature finalized a third reading of the TPG downsizing statute.
The Commons Daily: The legislature completed the legislation of the TPG downsizing act.
The China Post: Impeachment probe passes 258-176.
The China News: Impeachment inquiry against Clinton opens.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE CALLS FOR CHINESE UNITY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Friday called on overseas Chinese to unite behind the ROC's efforts for the sustained development of the nation.

In a message relayed to the Chinese community here through the local ROC representative office on the eve of the ROC's Double Ten National Day, Lee said that the ROC has pursued a new and better chapter in the country's history, driven by the enterprise of its people.

In order to face the challenges brought by the approaching 21st Century, Lee urged all Chinese to ignore their differences in party affiliation, native province, and social class, and to close ranks to pursue national development for the maximum benefit of the people.

He called on overseas Chinese to join the government's efforts to carry out fully its construction projects, sharpen the nation's competitiveness, and lay the groundwork for another "Taiwan experience" of success.
Lee said he sincerely believes that solidarity among all Chinese will ensure the realization of the ROC's goal of sustained development to for the benefit of the nation's descendants.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN POLICE ARREST MAINLAND CHINESE STOWAWAY

TEXT.P: Police on the offshore island stronghold of Kinmen arrested an illegal immigrant from mainland China on Friday, but three of his accomplices managed to escape to Taiwan by airplane.
The incident raised concern among Taiwan's law enforcement authority that the four illegal immigrants may have been assisted by a human smuggling ring.

According to an initial police investigation, the arrested man, identified as 18-year-old Wang Chien from Fujian Province, boarded a vessel destined for Kinmen on Thursday at a cost of 80,000 renminbi (US$9,664).

Two other men and one woman were on the same boat, which arrived at the offshore Taiwan territory after a five-hour voyage. They were met by two men shortly after making landfall, Wang told local police.

Wang was arrested at a photo shop as he was having his picture taken to use in forged identification. He claimed the other three stowaways, none of whom he knew, took a Far East Air Transport flight for Taipei on Friday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS WORLD'S 24TH-HIGHEST PER CAPITA GNP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan had the 24th-highest per capita gross national product (GNP) among 130 economies ranked by the World Bank in 1997, two notches ahead of its 1996 ranking, a report from the World Bank divulged on Saturday.
At the same time, the report shows, the country had the 19th-highest total GNP, one of the principal figures used to measure a country's economic strength.
According to the latest World Bank report on world development, Taiwan's GNP reached US$285.3 billion in 1997, ranking it 19th-highest, the same ranking it received in 1995 and 1996.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's per capita GNP reached US$13,233 for 1997, 24th-highest among the countries ranked. Taiwan's ranking in this area was 26th in 1996, according to the World Bank report.
The top 10 nations in 1997 in terms of GNP were: the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy, mainland China, Brazil, Canada, and Spain, in that order.
The top 10 nations with the largest per capita GNP, meanwhile, were: Switzerland, Japan, Norway, Singapore, Denmark, the United States, Germany, Austria, Belgium, and Sweden, in that order.
According to the report, mainland China posted a GNP of US$1.55 trillion in 1997, making it one of the seven largest economies in the world.
Its per capita GNP, however, was comparatively minuscule at US$860, the 82th among the 130 nations and areas.
Hong Kong, now a special administrative district of mainland China, had a GNP of US$164.4 billion last year, ranking it 26th. Its per capita GNP of US$25,280 was the 13th-largest.

If Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China were to be viewed together as the "Greater China" economy, their combined GNP, exceeding US$1.5 trillion, would be the world's fifth-largest, behind only the United States, Japan, Germany, and France.
Economies with GNPs ranking 10th to 20th were South Korea, Russia, Holland, Australia, India, Mexico, Switzerland, Argentina, Taiwan, and Belgium, in that order.

Economies with per capita GNP ranking 11th to 25th, were France, Holland, Hong Kong, Finland, Britain, Australia, Italy, Canada, Ireland, United Arab Emirates, New Zealand, Israel, Spain, Taiwan, and Greece.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND VISITING FORCES AGREEMENT SIGNED BY US, PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: While United States naval ships have been making port calls in many Asian countries in the last several years, not one American naval ship has visited the Philippines since December 1996.

This seems anomalous, US Ambassador to the Philippines Thomas Hubbard said on Friday, because the Philippines and the United States have had the longest-running cooperation, particularly in military cooperation, in Asia.

Hubbard aired this observation during an informal chat with the media following the signing of the Visiting Forces Agreement 2 (VFA2) which governs Filipino military personnel visits to the United States, either on official military business or for study.
The VFA2 complements the VFA signed in February last year which the Department of Foreign Affairs earlier this week submitted to the Philippine Senate for ratification.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATE APPROVES LEGISLATION ON RELIGIOUS PERSECUTION

TEXT.P: the US Senate unanimously approved legislation on Friday that would require the US government to monitor and take action against foreign governments that engage in systematic acts of religious persecution.

When asked to gauge how the bill might impact mainland China, Saudi Arabia, and Russia, Undersecretary of State Stuart Eizenstat said the sponsors of the bill made clear that they intend to promote religious freedom and tolerance without targeting any particular religion or region.

"With the changes that we have now negotiated," Eizenstat stressed, "the bill advances the cause of religious freedom while giving the president the flexibility he needs, and without undermining relations with important countries around the world, which have been among the causes of our objections to earlier versions of similar legislation."

The International Religious Freedom Act, passed by a 98-0 vote, would create a federal office responsible for monitoring the treatment of religious minorities in countries where the US Department of State has documented acts of religious persecution.

If a pattern of religious persecution is identified, the act provides for the US president to use a series of sanctions. These would include diplomatic responses, such as public condemnation and cancellation of scientific and cultural exchanges, as well as certain economic sanctions.

The sanctions are milder than those of earlier versions of the legislation, which the Clinton administration opposed. The legislation has been sharply debated both in the House of Representatives and the Senate.

Critics charge that it could hurt the president's ability to conduct foreign policy, make it difficult to use quiet diplomacy, and create a hierarchy of victims, where those claiming religious persecution would receive preference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIGHT ACQUIRE HELICOPTERS FROM THE US

TEXT.P: The United States announced on Friday the possible sale to Taiwan of nine Chinook heavylift helicopters, marking the fourth US arms deal with Taiwan this year.
The proposed sale, worth US$486 million, includes nine Boeing CH-47SD Chinook helicopters, three T55-L-714A spare turbine engines, contractor engineering, and technical support services.

The US Department of Defense said that Taiwan will use these twin-rotor helicopters to improve its ability to transport personnel and cargo for both military defense and humanitarian assistance purposes.

The CH-47SD is the latest and most advanced Chinook model, generally considered the world's most efficient heavylift helicopter. In one of its earlier configurations, the craft can seat 44 persons and lift up to 12,700 kilograms of cargo.
The CH-47SD features several new or improved components and systems, including a fully integrated digital cockpit management system.
Friday's announcement, pending expected Congressional approval, marks the fourth major US arms transfer to Taiwan so far this year.
In January, the US Department of Defense announced the sale of three used Knox-class frigates with related equipment and services at an estimated cost of US$300 million.
In June, the United States announced the sale of 28 sets of navigation and targeting pods to be used on Taiwan's US-made F-16 fighter aircraft. That deal cost US$160 million.
In August, the United States announced the provision of US$350 million-worth of MK-46 anti-submarine torpedoes, Stinger anti-aircraft missiles and Harpoon anti-ship missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE WILD FOREX SWINGS IN SINGAPORE FEARED

TEXT.P: Singapore currency traders are bracing themselves for further wild currency swings next week that many fear will have adverse consequences for Asian economies.
And as wrong-footed market participants take stock of what has hit them, the crucial question is what hedge funds will do -- or will be forced to do -- in the weeks ahead.

Traders speaking to Singapore's Business Times, for example, were already trying to assess the impact and veracity of talk that standing orders to sell US dollars -- from as close as at 121 yen upwards -- were starting to come in from both hedge funds and Japanese exporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PRIME RATE COULD HIT RECORD LOW NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Singapore's prime rate could hit 4 percent next year, a record low which will probably help the economy recover, or at least stem the slide in domestic consumption.

On Thursday, the United Overseas Bank shaved 25 basis points off its prime lending rate to 7 percent. This is its second cut in less than a month, and many industry watchers say that this should touch off another round of interest rate cuts.

Although not every economist agrees that the prime rate could hit such unprecedented low levels, most are of the view that lending rates will fall at least another 100 basis points from the current 7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESS FAVORS TAIWAN PARTICIPATION IN WHO

TEXT.P: The US House of Representatives is expected on Saturday to adopt a resolution calling on the administration to support Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).
The non-binding resolution, introduced on Friday by Rep. Gerald B. H. Solomon (R-NY), is likely to win overwhelming support in the House.

The measure falls short of asking for Taiwan membership in the WHO. Instead, it says that it should be US policy "to pursue some initiative in the WHO which will give Taiwan meaningful participation."
The resolution recognizes that "Taiwan does not fulfill the criteria for membership" but points out that the WHO does allow observers to participate in its activities.
Because of mainland China's obstruction Taiwan's recent bids for even WHO observer status have been unsuccessful.
The Republic of China on Taiwan lost its WHO membership in 1972 after losing its seat in the UN.

Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-OH), the original sponsor of the resolution, said that the deadly enterovirus epidemic that killed scores of Taiwan children last summer further illustrated the importance of Taiwan's membership in the WHO.
"Denying Taiwan the knowledge and expertise of the World Health Organization is a fundamental violation of its human rights," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PATRIOTS IN HONG KONG SUPPORT ROC-ESPOUSED UNIFICATION GOAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China patriots living in Hong Kong issued a joint statement on Saturday reiterating their support for the goal of China's reunification espoused by the ROC.

More than 1,000 representatives of Hong Kong's cultural, educational, press, motion picture, and business sectors got together at Kowloon's Hotel Regency on Saturday for a rally marking the ROC's Double Ten National Day.

The statement said that although Hong Kong's international status and situation have changed over the last year, their steadfast belief in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's ideal of building a free, democratic and prosperous China remain unchanged.

It expressed the hope that Hong Kong, which has weathered many twists and turns over the past year, will become more economically and politically stable, so that the special administrative region will play a more active role in pushing for China's modernization.

The statement urged the Hong Kong administration to strengthen bilateral relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong, and make more efforts to bolster Hong Kong's entrepot role between Taiwan and mainland China.
In order to bring about China's ultimate reunification, the statement called for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to bury the hatchet and help each other.

In a keynote speech to the rally, Cheng An-kuo, Taipei's chief representative in Hong Kong, said that after Hong Kong's handover to mainland Chinese rule in July 1997, Taiwan-Hong Kong relations have become part of cross-strait relations.
Cheng said he hopes that as cross-strait relations gradually improve, Taiwan-Hong Kong ties will simultaneously improve.
He also expressed regret at Hong Kong administration authorities' forcible removal of ROC national flags from Hong Kong streets on Saturday morning.

He said it is regretful that the Hong Kong authorities demonstrated disrespect towards the Hong Kong people, who displayed the ROC banners to show their respects to the memory of the ROC's founding father, Dr. Sun Yat-sen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MARKS DOUBLE TEN NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday called for the establishment of a more forward-looking and better-crafted system of democracy to serve as a firm foundation for sustainable national development.
Lee made the appeal in an address delivered at a mass rally in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei to mark the Republic of China's 87th Double Ten National Day.

"In the approach to the new millennium, we should be committed to the tasks of government restructuring and consolidation of constitutional democracy in order to upgrade national competitiveness and ensure sustainable national development," he stressed.
The president also pledged to promote peaceful exchanges and constructive dialogue with mainland China on an equal and reciprocal basis.
"We look forward to developing mutually beneficial and prosperous relations with mainland China for the sake of the long-term well-being of all Chinese people," Lee said.
He also called on the Beijing authorities to recognize the world trend of democratization and thoroughly revamp their social and political systems.

Based on the principle of persistent defense and effective deterrence, Lee said, the ROC will go ahead with its military consolidation plan and the deployment of second-generation weaponry and equipment required for a modern defense force.

Noting that Taiwan's pragmatic efforts to participate in the international community have begun to win recognition and approval from many nations, Lee said the ROC will continue to expand its presence in international organizations and activities on the strength of its economic prowess and democratic achievements.
Lee went on to say that the ROC has weathered many blows and trials since its founding as the first democratic republic in Asia 87 years ago.

"Throughout, our country has stood tall, testifying that our nation-building spirit remains undiminished and that we have never stopped striving," the president said, adding that the ROC's feats not only have profound significance to the 21.8 million people and their descendants in the Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu area, but will also greatly influence mainland China's future course of development.
"Looking into the 21st century, I firmly believe that the Republic of China, with its people united in faith and in action, will shine even more brilliantly in the future," Lee added.
The mass rally brought together thousands of local people from all walks of life as well as many foreign dignitaries and overseas Chinese community leaders to celebrate the ROC's birthday.
Among the foreign guests were Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore and Grenada Prime Minister Keith C. Mitchell.
The rally was presided over by Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan, who urged his fellow countrymen to stand united and work hand-in-hand to create an even brighter future for the country.

Prior to the rally, students from selected senior high schools and universities in major cities around the island gave colorful dancing and folk art performances, adding much fanfare and creating a youthful, exuberant and joyful festive mood.
The carnival-style performances highlighted the theme of this year's National Day celebrations -- promoting spiritual reform and creating a peaceful, harmonious living environment.
Following the rally, the student performers paraded through the streets of downtown Taipei, drawing large crowds of spectators.
Earlier in the day, President Lee presided over a ceremony in the auditorium of the Presidential Office as part of the National Day celebrations.

Later in the afternoon, many civilian troupes gave dazzling folk art and stunning acrobatic performances on the Presidential Office plaza. Meanwhile, breakthtaking massive fireworks display on the west side of Taipei has been scheduled for later in the evening.
Similar festivities were held simultaneously in other cities throughout the island to mark the festive occasion.

About 7,000 overseas Chinese representatives from 50 countries and areas around the world have come back to Taiwan to take part in various National Day celebration activities, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA VICE MINISTER ARRIVES IN RIYADH FOR ECONOMIC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Riyadh, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Yang Yi-fong & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: An ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official arrived in the capital of Saudi Arabia on Friday night to attend the Taipei-Riyadh Economic and Technologic Cooperation Meeting.

Lin Yi-fu, administrative vice minister of the MOEA, is heading a 15-member delegation of trade representatives and economics officials. They were greeted by the vice president of Saudi Arabia's state-owned Basic Industrial Company upon their arrival.
Lin said this trip is aimed at forging accords related to more than 30 items of issues with investment guarantees, shipping tariffs and merchandise examining processes at the focus of negotiations.
In addition, the exchange of visits by high-ranking officials from both sides will be on the agenda, he added.
Taipei and Riyadh take turns hosting the annual meeting for economic and technology cooperation. This is the 16th such meeting between the two sides.
Lin is Taipei's top negotiator while the vice president of Saudi's national Basic Industrial Company is his counterpart.

The presidency of the Saudi Basic Industrial Company is assumed by the minister of Saudi's Industrial and Electricity Ministry, therefore the vice president of the company is seen as the equivalent to a vice minister of a Cabinet.

Other members of the Taiwan delegation include economic officials from the Board of Foreign Trade, the International Cooperation Department and the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine, as well as representatives from the Chinese Petroleum Corp., Taiwan Fertilizer Co. and the semi-official China External Trade Development Council.
The economic meeting between Taipei and Riyadh will be held from Oct. 10-11.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC GASOLINE PRICES TO BE CUT BY 2-TO-3 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is expected to announce yet another oil price cut on Tuesday to reflect its slumping production costs, the United Evening News reported on Saturday.

The paper said the oil price consultative panel under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) already agreed on Friday to authorize the CPC to further lower prices for its products in the near future.
Barring unexpected developments, the paper said, the CPC will make a formal announcement on Tuesday and the new prices will take effect on Wednesday.
This will be the fifth time since July that the state monopoly has offered an across-the-board price cut for its products amid a downward spiral in international crude oil prices.
The evening paper quoted an unnamed member of the MOEA's oil price advisory panel as saying that the upcoming price cut will exceed 2 percent or even approach 3 percent.

The member predicted that the retail price for premium gasoline will be lowered by NT$0.3 to NT$0.4 per liter, while that for diesel will be cut by NT$0.2 to NT$0.3. The domestic gasoline price now stands at NT$17.4 (US$0.52) per liter.

Thanks to a significant increase in its production and a drop in production costs, the CPC had raked in NT$4.66 billion in excess profits between July and September. The excess profits refer to the earnings that exceed the legislatively mandated profit ceiling.

CPC sources said although international crude oil prices are rising because of the advent of winter, when the demand for oil usually rises in the Northern Hemisphere countries, the upward swing is expected to remain modest.
Moreover, the sources said, the recent appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar is making crude oil even less costly for the CPC to import.
Against this backdrop, the CPC's upcoming oil price cut may be larger than expected.

The CPC has lowered its prices by a total of 5.69 percent since July. Under current government regulations, the CPC is allowed to adjust its prices within a range of 6 percent over three consecutive months. Beyond this range, it must obtain prior approval from the MOEA's oil price consultative panel.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 LIVER TRANSPLANT RECIPIENTS CELEBRATE AT KAOHSIUNG HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Twenty children, who have undergone live-liver transplants at the Kaohsiung Chang Kung Memorial Hospital in the past few years, gathered at the hospital on Friday to celebrate their second chance at life.

The Kaohsiung hospital began conducting liver transplants in 1993 and has completed 44 liver transplants to date. The survival rate for liver transplants is 89 percent, but that for live-liver transplants is 100 percent, said Dr. Chen Chao-lung, chief surgeon of the hospital's liver transplant team.
All 20 live-liver transplant recipients were children, Chen added. In 17 cases, mothers donated their livers while fathers were the donors in three cases.

Chen noted that all the donors and recipients continue to be in very good medical condition. But as a side effect of long-term use of anti-resistance drugs, recipients have denser and darker eyebrows.

The 20 children were invited to attend a party given by the Kaohsiung hospital to celebrate their new lease on life. They sang "A Heart With Gratitude" to express their heartfelt gratitude toward the surgeons and the staff.
Transplants are the last resort for patients with liver disease. Most of the 20 live-liver recipients suffered from closed gall ducts which blocked the flow of bile into their intestines.
The waiting list for those in need of liver transplants at the Chang Kung Hospital is between 40-50 people, Chen said. He urged the public to help these people by donating their livers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRIS PATTEN INTERVIEWS LEE TENG-HUI FOR BBC
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui said in a British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) interview that the ROC's success in promoting democracy and economic liberalization can be a model for mainland China's reforms.

In an interview with former Hong Kong Governor Christopher Patten, Lee urged Beijing to take advantage of the "Taiwan experience" in promoting cross-strait ties as it is better than only considering economic interests.
Lee was responding to Patten's question on whether a democratic Taiwan can help mainland China to peacefully reform its system.

The interview is part of a special series Patten produced for the BBC regarding his five years as governor in the former British colony. Patten handed Hong Kong's sovereignty over to Beijing last year.
In the BBC program, Patten described the political and economic development of Taiwan and mainland China and how the two sides separated in a civil war in 1949.
He praised the ROC's efforts in achieving democratic progress and gaining economic prosperity, pointing out that Taiwan is one of the richest places in the Asia-Pacific region.

Patten also said although Beijing is still reluctant to recognize Taiwan's status as a sovereign entity, and most people in Taiwan do not seek the island's independence, none in Taiwan are willing to give up their freedoms, capitalist system and sovereignty.
Despite having undergone martial law for many years, Taiwan has transformed into a democratic country after voters elected their first president in 1995, Patten said.
Commenting on Beijing's economic efforts, Patten stressed he believes sooner or later the mainland will also undergo political transformation like other places in the world.
Patten's interview with Lee will be broadcasted on the BBC 2 television channel on Oct. 10, the ROC's National Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ACCEPTS CONTENDER'S CHALLENGE TO PUBLIC DEBATE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bien would accept Kuomintang mayoral candidate Ma Ying-Jeou's challenge to debate in public their agenda for the city, said Chen's campaign manager Lo Wen-chia on Saturday.

Chen, who has shunned the challenge until now, would like to confront his two competitors in public forum, but only separately, that means he would debate with Ma first, then with New Party candidate Wang Chien-shien, said Lo.
And, in response to Ma's previous demand that the it to be held the sooner the better, the first debate with Ma should be staged within three days, said Lo.
The three would appear on the same stage only after Ma and Wang have argued with each other, said Lo.
He urged Ma to response to his offer positively, instead of demanding the three argued in a forum at the same time.

Ma, through one of his staff Chin Fu-chung, welcomed Chen's long-awaited reply to his demand for debate on Aug. 26, but dismissed the three-day deadline as irresponsible because it would take more time than three days to held discussion among the three candidates on the form and way to conduct the debate and asked well-respected social bodies or mass media to sponsor it.

Chin counter-offered to hold the public debate once per week in the remaining eight weeks leading to the Dec. 5 poll. It should be conducted by the candidates themselves, rather than their campaigning teams as Chen advocated previously, and between the three candidates instead of the two.

Meanwhile Wang said he would accepted Chen's offer although he thought Lo speaking with tongue in cheek, because separate debate would deprive audience the valuable opportunity to examine the candidates' views simultaneously.

He suspected Chen's initial is aimed to weary the voters and dilute the significance of the debate. Wang also dismissed Chen's idea of having his staff to contradict other candidates' criticism in public debate as no other than having candidates' wives argue against each other.
Knowing Chen's offer to debate is but a trick, Wang said, as a minor party candidate, he preferred accepting it on Chen's terms to reject it and lost the opportunity to float his campaign promises.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN FACTOR' LARGELY DICTATES BEIJING'S ARMS PURCHASES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A well-known American China hand said on Friday that resolving the so-called "Taiwan issue" has become the main concern in mainland China's military acquisition strategy.

David Shambaugh, director of a China research program at the George Washington University, further said even though mainland China is now not strong enough to attack Taiwan, it can still use its ballistic missiles to pose a serious threat to the island.

Speaking at a seminar on mainland China's ongoing military modernization plan, Shambaugh said the foremost task of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) at the moment is to prepare for a possible attack on Taiwan under Beijing's order.
As a result, Shambaugh said Beijing's current military purchase strategy is aimed at acquiring the capabilities it presently does not have.
For instance, he said, the PLA hopes to acquire the ability in five to seven years to blockade Taiwan's major sea ports and to enable at least 750,000 of its amphibious troops to land on the island.

At the moment, Shambaugh said, mainland China's air force still cannot control the skies over the Taiwan Strait, not to mention Taiwan's air space. The combat capabilities of its naval and amphibious forces are also limited.

"However, this does not mean that mainland China cannot mount troubles or threats to Taiwan at present," Shambaugh warned, adding that Taiwan is facing increasing threats from Beijing's M-11 missiles and cruise missiles.

Taking the 1995-96 Taiwan Strait crisis as an example, Shambaugh said Taiwan's stock market plunged some 25 percent during the period when mainland China test fired several M-class missiles into waters near Taiwan.
The next time that mainland China may take "action" against Taiwan is probably in the run-up to Taiwan's next presidential election in the year 2000, he predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S DEPUTY PM TO VISIT HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Singaporean deputy prime minister Lee Hsien Loong is scheduled to visit Hong Kong from Oct. 11-13.

During his visit, Lee is expected to meet with Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa and the two will be the guests of honor at a gala charity performance by the Singapore Symphony Orchestra with benefits going to the Hong Kong Red Cross.

Lee will meet with members of Hong Kong's business community, attend a reception for Singaporeans in Hong Kong, and speak at a function organized by the Singapore Chamber of Commerce and the Hong Kong Chamber of Commerce. (Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: THIS STORY REPLACES CEPOO17 WHICH HAS NOT BEEN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen shui-bien has accepted Kuomintang mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou's challenge to a public debate, Chen's campaign manager Lo Wen-chia said on Saturday.
Chen said he would like to debate his two rivals including New Party candidate Wang Chien-shien, but only separately and within the next three days, Lo stated.
The mayor has ducked the issue of a debate since Ma first laid down the challenge in late August.

According to Chin Fu-chung, a member of Ma's campaign staff, the KMT candidate has welcomed Chen's response, but said the three-day deadline is not sufficient to organize the debate's format, media sponsors and venue.

Speaking for Ma, Chin suggested that a public debate be held every week until the Dec. 5 election. The candidates themselves should respond to comments instead of campaign staff as the mayor has suggested, and all three candidates should appear instead of only two at a time, Chin added.
New Party candidate Wang said although he is not happy with the mayor's conditions, he would be willing to meet Chen and Ma in a public debate.

Wang also noted that the public needs the opportunity to examine all three candidates' views simultaneously. He said he suspects Chen's strategy is to wear down the voters' endurance and dilute the significance of the debate with this two-man format.
He dismissed Chen's suggestion that staff members counter candidates' criticisms in the debate. He compared the scenario to having the candidates' wives argue against each other.
Regardless of these flaws in Chen's offer, Wang said as a minor candidate, he preferred accepting it to rejecting it and losing the opportunity to promote his campaign promises.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN HAPPIER FLYING GIANT FLAG THAN WINNING THE LOTTERY
DOC.DATELINE: Chungli, northern Taiwan, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Flying a giant national flag on Double Ten National Day is better than winning the lottery, said Chuang Chin-ho, a driving school owner in Chungli City.

On Saturday morning, a giant ROC national flag -- the white sun in a blue sky over a crimson ground banner -- was flying in front of Chuang's driving school next to the Chungli highway. Some drivers passing by were stunned by the size of the flag which is about 22 feet by 14 feet.
Despite being called a "nut" by some people for flying such an enormous flag, Chuang said he was exhilarated to do so on National Day.
After traveling around the world and experiencing discrimination and humiliation, Chuang said all he wanted to do on National Day was to fly a giant flag.
This year, he spent some NT$500,000 (US$14,900) to have the big banner and its post made, fulfilling his wish.
"I harbor no political gains, I simply wanted to show my respect to the nation," Chuang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS WELCOME US SALE OF NEW HELICOPTERS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Defense Ministry on Saturday welcomed the US government's decision to sell nine Boeing CH-47SD Chinook helicopters to Taiwan.
Defense Ministry officials said the deal will be effective within a month, but Boeing data indicated that the nine CH-47SD helicopters will not roll off the assembly lines until the end of 1999.
The CH-47SD helicopter is the latest and most advanced Chinook model, generally considered the world's most efficient heavy-lift helicopter.
ROC officials said the nine CH-47SD helicopters, once delivered, will form an airborne battalion within the ROC Army's airborne brigade.
The new sale, which involves the nine helicopters and other military equipment totaling US$486 million in value, was announced by the Pentagon on Friday.
ROC officials disclosed that the United States had earlier sold four Boeing B234 helicopters, the same model as the CH-47D, to Taiwan in a commercial deal.

They said the US decision to sell nine Ch-47SD helicopters to the ROC in a military deal indicated that Washington has not changed its policy of selling arms to Taiwan after President Bill Clinton's mainland China trip in June.

According to military data, the CH-47SD helicopter is capable of carrying 25,000 pounds or 37 armed personnel, with a maximum flight distance of 1,200 kilometers. It can be used for transporting troops, artillery, fuel, raw material and water, as well as for ambulance and fire-fighting missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui said in his National Day message that the Taiwan experience provides a model for mainland China's democratization.
The China Times: The United States will sell nine more heavylift military helicopters to Taiwan.
The United Daily News: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh said Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman C. F. Koo can conduct constructive dialogue with mainland leaders.
The Liberty Times: The Control Yuan will censure the Taiwan Provincial Government for borrowing too much money from the Bank of Taiwan.
The Independence Morning Post: An ethnic Chinese girl was murdered for exposing atrocities committed by Indonesian mobsters during the May rioting.
The Commons Daily: The US House of Representatives passed a resolution supporting Taiwan's participation in World Health Organization activities.
The China Post: President Lee Teng-hui calls for greater democracy.
The China News: Taiwan's Yangming Marine Corp. adds Shanghai route.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE STORY OF HUNG-MAO CHENG (FORT SANTO DOMINGO)

TEXT.P: Hung-Mao Cheng, which translated means red-haired fort, was originally called Fort Santo Domingo. It is one of the oldest places of interest in northern Taiwan and is an ideal place for vacations and recreation in the outskirts of Taipei City.

The story of Hung-Mao Cheng dates back to the end of the 15th century, when burgeoning mercantilism brought European ships to the Far East. The Portuguese headed east with the aim of reaching India and China, while the Spaniards, who had the same goal, headed in the opposite direction and accidentally discovered South America.

The Portuguese, while on their way to China, passed by the island of Taiwan and were so taken by its physical beauty they named it Ilha Formosa, or "beautiful island". However, only a few of them have landed here and stayed temporarily. Instead, the Dutch with their early sea power set to monopolize trade with China and sent troops to strategic locations in the area. They eventually invaded and occupied Taiwan during the Ming dynasty of China.

Spain had earlier invaded and occupied the Philippines in 1571 and had planned to attack Taiwan since Japan, under the administration of Hideyoshi Toyotomi, cracked down on Spanish missionaries and were mistreating them. Japan had also planned to invade Taiwan and use the island as a springboard in its attack of the Philippines.
However, Toyotomi died and Japan was ruled by Ieyasu Tokugawa who took a friendlier position toward Spain by enhancing mutual trade relations. Spain then dropped its plan to invade Taiwan.

When the Dutch occupied the Tainan region in 1624 and built Fort Zeelandia in southern Taiwan, the Spanish found their trade with both Taiwan and Japan seriously threatened. To safeguard their interests, Spanish troops launched an attack from the Philippines in 1626 and occupied northern Taiwan. They built Fort San Salvador on Hoping Island and placed Keelung under its control.

The Spaniards extended their sphere of influence gradually to Fuwei, now known as Tamsui, and in 1629 establish Fort San Domingo, totally controling the sea lane off northern Taiwan. The twin forts interlocked and protected each other and became important commercial destinations and military fortresses at the time.

However, in 1642, northern Taiwan was hit by a plague. With reduced trade activities, many Spanish people and troops withdrew from both Fort San Salvador and Fort San Domingo. The Dutch troops seized the opportunity to despatch a large number of troops to attack north Taiwan. After a six-day battle, the Spanish troops were defeated and ended their 16 years of occupation.

As the Dutch were expanding their hold on both south and north Taiwan, the Ming dynasty was collapsing and the Manchu troops rushed to fill the vacuum. Many Ming loyalists, including Cheng Cheng-kung (also known as Koxinga) escaped to southern China to resist the Manchus over the next 20 years.

Meanwhile, the Dutch gradually expanded their power to western Taiwan and colonized the island for 38 years until 1661 when Cheng Cheng-kung claimed Taiwan from the Dutch after a series of fierce battles.
Cheng choose Anping (or modern-day Tainan) as his capital, and ordered General Ho Yu to station himself at Port San Domingo to guard against the return of the Dutch.

Cheng succumbed to a serious illness and died in 1662 at the age of only 38. He was succeeded by his son, Cheng Ching. In 1683, the Manchu court sent Shih Lang, a Cheng Cheng-kung's general who had defected to the Manchu Emperor, to attack Taiwan. Cheng's navy was defeated and the Cheng family surrendered to the Ching dynasty.

Although the Manchus took over the island of Taiwan and in the following year made it a prefecture of Fukien Province, they did not send troops to Fort San Domingo. The fortress gradually collapsed due to neglect. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: THE STORY OF HUNG-MAO CHENG--2

TEXT.P: After the Manchus took over Taiwan in 1683, many officials advocated the immediate abandonment of the island because of its remoteness. The Ching court, though, finally adopted Shih Lang's suggestion to retain its rule over Taiwan. The change of policy by the Yung Cheng Emperor who banned Christianity in 1724 resulted in the repair of Fort San Domingo, and troops were sent there because of its important strategic position.

During the entire 18th century and the early 19th century, the Ching court adopted a virtual closed door policy toward the Western world. The European powers, however, were not content to allow China to remain isolated, as they coveted Chinese markets and resources.

After the so-called "Opium War" of 1839-42, the Treaty of Nanking was signed on Aug. 29, 1842. It proved to be the most important treaty in China's modern history, for it was the first of a series of unequal treaties signed with Western powers.

With the signing in 1860 of the Treaty of Tientsin, which stipulated that Fuwei (Tamsui) was to be opened for British trade and a consulate was to be established there, the British consulate in Tainan was moved to Tamsui in 1861. The consulate then moved into Fort San Domingo in 1868 after the Ching court signed another treaty in 1867 providing England a permanent lease of Fort San Domingo.

The Great Britain, which leased Fort San Domingo for 104 years without paying any rent, recognized Beijing in 1950 and asked Australia to look after Fort San Domingo. In 1972 when the Commonwealth of Australia established diplomatic ties with Beijing, the management of the fort was transferred to the United States, which in turn moved its embassy from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

The history of Hung-Mao Cheng, which was returned to the government of the Republic of China in 1980 after active negotiations with the British government, is the epitome of all the miseries and hardships suffered by China in the past few centuries.

In the summer of 1629, the Spaniards entered Tamsui. They named the place Castillo, and built Fort San Domingo. Castillo, which is located on the north bank of the estuary of the Tamsui River, is the oldest town in northern Taiwan.
In addition to its military usefulness, Castillo served as a habitat for deer and proved to be sitting atop land rich in such natural resources as coal and brimstone.

With deer-hide being a main commodity by that time, the Dutch in southern Taiwan made many attempts to drive the Spanish out of the north. Finally, in the summer of 1642, the Spaniards, threatened by a native rebellion in the Philippines, were forced to recall three-quarters of their troops from Taiwan. The Dutch then landed at Castillo and conquered it.
After the Dutch became the new rulers of Castillo, the Chinese people there described the Dutch as "red-haired" and called Fort San Domingo Hung-Mao Cheng (red-haired fort). (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: THE STORY OF HUNG-MAO CHENG--3

TEXT.P: Standing at a height of 30 Chinese feet and a circumference of 200 Chinese feet, the red-haired fort was prominent in its location on Tamsui mountain. However, most of the fortress has now collapsed.

After the Dutch were driven out by Cheng's troops, the local inhabitants, most of them farmers, disliked the place because of the heavy smell of sulfur emanating from the nearby Tatun mountain and because the surrounding areas are mostly hills and swamps, difficult for the development of agriculture.

Near the fortress sits a two-story consulate building which was built much later in a typical British colonial style of architecture. There is a marked difference between the verandahs on the first and second floors as Spanish influence was heavy at the time. The verandahs were constructed out of bricks without any concrete, and wards off the sun and rain.

Most of the construction materials used in the consulate building were produced in the region with the bricks from Chingsui, roof tiles from Fukien province, and floor boards from Java. After the British obtained rights to the permanent lease of Hung-Mao Cheng, they added observation towers and short walls on the old citadel, and changed the fortress' color to red.

The transportation of commodities in northern Taiwan used to depend heavily on the Tamsui River. Following the development of more land-bound infrastructure and the accumulation of silt in the river, the once-prosperous Tamsui which attracted greedy-eyed foreigners gradually lost its luster.

With its low tilted-roof buildings, rickety old streets and broken brick walls, it is difficult for some people to imagine Tamsui as the bustling center of trade in the region. But visit the red-haired fort during sunset and enjoy the gentle evening breeze while you watch the twilight reflect its fading light on the fortress, then you might better see how it all was in time long past.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATHS FROM KIDNEY PROBLEMS HIGHER THAN IN OTHER NATIONS: DOH

TEXT.P: A higher percentage of Taiwan's population is dying from kidney-related problems than of other advanced nations, the Department of Health (DOH) reported on Sunday.

DOH officials also said that the number of patients with kidney problems that require dialysis increased 36.6 percent over the past three years. The number of dialysis patients in Taiwan now exceeds 28,000.
That means one out of every 775 kidney patients on the island needs a kidney dialysis, a higher ratio than in Japan or the United States.

A kidney specialist said that the aging of the population has led to a higher number of cases of high blood pressure and diabetes among the old, while the increased consumption of western-style fast food has resulted in a large number of overweight youngsters. These people are more likely to develop kidney problems later.
The specialist noted that after the 1980s, kidney problems were the eighth-leading cause of death for local men and the sixth-leading cause of death for local women.

Between 1993 and 1997, 784 kidney transplants were carried out. On average one out of every 159 kidney dialysis patients has needed a kidney transplant, compared with one out of every 229 dialysis patients in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW TO MEET KOO DELEGATION ON MONDAY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew will meet with Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo on Monday to exchange views on Koo's upcoming landmark visit to mainland China.
The 11 delegates who will accompany Koo on his Shanghai-Beijing visit will also be present at the Siew-Koo meeting.

Koo and the 11 delegates selected from the National Unification Council (NUC), the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the quasi-official SEF will leave for mainland China on Wednesday for a six-day visit.

The visit marks a major breakthrough in the long-stalled relations across the Taiwan Strait. Senior ROC officials have said Koo's mainland trip is expected to help foster an amiable atmosphere and improve cross-strait ties.
MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh will formally present authorization certificates to Koo and other delegates before their meeting with Premier Siew.
SEF, a semi-official intermediary body authorized by the ROC government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties, is under MAC's supervision.
Chang said on Sunday that Koo will be authorized to conduct "constructive dialogue" with mainland authorities during his visit.

"The constructive dialogue refers to talks that will benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chang explained, adding that Koo will be authorized to freely exchange views with mainland negotiators or leaders on a broad range of issues, including such sensitive topics as the opening of direct cross-strait "three links"; Taiwan's "go slow, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China; and even the proposed exchanges of visits by top leaders on the two sides of the strait.

"Koo can also decide on his own whether to invite his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to visit Taiwan," Chang said.
He further stressed that the top goal of Koo's mainland trip is to help ease and improve cross-strait relations.
On Monday, Chang will also brief Koo and members of his mission on the basic government stance on cross-strait relations and the current cross-strait situation.
In addition to holding wide-ranging talks with ARATS Chairman Wang, Koo will also meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen during his stay in Beijing.

Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore in April 1993 to lay a framework for institutionalized cross-strait dialogue. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended such regular contacts shortly after ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995. Beijing regarded Lee's visit as a move to promote Taiwan independence.
The Koo delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei on Oct. 19 via Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ADOPTS NEW STRATEGY TOWARD TAIWAN: MAGAZINE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The upcoming mainland visit by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, is expected to improve current relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Business Week magazine reported in it newest issue.

In a bid to carry out the long-awaited second meeting between Koo and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, both Taiwan and mainland China have made compromises, said Business Week in a Taipei-dispatched story.

Taiwan canceled an annual military drill originally slated for Oct. 12, while the mainland agreed to focus the meeting on the discussion of technical matters of major concern to people on both sides, such as fishery disputes, by temporarily putting aside the controversial "one China" issue, according to the report.

Over the past three years, Beijing has showed great changes in its attitude toward Taipei, shifting from posing military threats to offering an olive branch, the report said. It attributed Beijing's changes to mainland China's strong demand for Taiwan capital and technology while in the process of its economic reforms.
On the other hand, bringing Taiwan to the track of unification will help mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin consolidate his leadership role and create a legacy in history.

Citing recent remarks made by mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan that Taiwan will be able to enjoy greater freedom than Hong Kong if it unifies with mainland China, the report said Tang's statement indicates that Beijing is seeking to sell a "one country, three systems" formula to Taiwan.

Under the scheme, Taiwan can have its own military and ranking Taiwan officials would be allowed to work for the mainland Chinese government. The report called these proposals as "very friendly" gestures to Taiwan.
The report stressed, however, that judging the situation from all aspects, time will be on mainland China's side if Taiwan continues to respond coolly to mainland China's overtures.

US President Bill Clinton's public declaration of his support for the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan during a visit to mainland China this summer has already constituted a major diplomatic defeat for Taiwan, and Taiwan will lose more diplomatic partners if it continues to turn down Beijing's "reasonable proposals," the magazine warned.

The "three noes" refer to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations for which statehood is required.
Currently, only 27 countries maintain formal diplomatic ties with the Republic of China on Taiwan. Most of the ROC's diplomatic allies are African and Central American countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF TAIWAN PEOPLE KILLED IN MAINLAND HOPEFUL OVER TALKS

TEXT.P: The families of Taiwan people murdered in mainland China have expressed their hopes that the upcoming cross-strait talks will effectively boost the protection of the safety of Taiwan people and their property in the mainland.
Their hopes rose after the government said that the meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be upgraded to a "constructive dialogue."
Lin Ping-hui, father of kidnapped and murdered Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan, said that he was still overcome with grief whenever he thought of his daughter's death.
Lin hoped that mainland authorities can put into law the protection of the safety of Taiwan people and their property.

He noted that Taiwan people who were murdered in the mainland were often handled in a case-by-case situation. In the future, there should be a law to be used as the basis to protect the interests of Taiwan people, which he said is seen as the basic solution by Taiwan people in the mainland.

He recalled his sad journey to the mainland after Lin's death in late July. Though mainland police and local government had been kind to him, he believed that it was because of the special status of his daughter. He doubted other Taiwan people would get the same kind of treatment.
As Li Guangzhi, the prime suspect of the Lin's murder, is still at large, Lin has commissioned lawyers to file criminal and civil suits in the mainland.
He said that he was informed that the case will be tried in three months and that he would definitely travel to the mainland to hear the testimony of the accomplices.
In tandem with Lin's death, a Taiwan businessman, Wang Fu-ching, was also murdered in the mainland. His ashes were returned to Taiwan but the murderer remains at large.

Wang's brother, Wang Fu-Kuan, said that there are many Taiwan people dying for unaccountable reasons. He expressed the hope that C. F. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, could convey the sense to the mainland that Beijing should protect the rights of Taiwan people there through legal channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAILS US HOUSE SUPPORT FOR ITS PARTICIPATION IN WHO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Sunday hailed the passage of a resolution by the US House of Representatives supporting its participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).
"We welcome the House resolution. It certainly will have a positive bearing on our bid to return to the WHO," said Chan Chi-shean, director-general of the Department of Health (DOH).

Chan made the remarks after the US House overwhelmingly approved on Saturday a concurrent resolution calling on the Clinton administration to support Taiwan's participation in the WHO, a United Nations-affiliated body.

The non-binding resolution was approved by a vote of 418-0. The resolution falls short of asking for Taiwan's full membership in the WHO. Instead, the resolution said it should be a US policy "to pursue some initiative in the WHO which will give Taiwan meaningful participation."
Chan said returning to the WHO is a common goal of both the ruling and opposition parties here and that the greatest obstacle to this goal lies in mainland China's opposition.
"The US House resolution indicates that the concerted efforts of our government and people in promoting our WHO bid have gradually borne fruit," Chan said.
The ROC was originally a WHO founding member, but lost its seat in the organization in 1972 after losing its UN membership in 1971.
Chan said Taiwan should not continue to be shut out of the WHO because the organization mainly deals with health issues which should not factor in any political disputes or considerations.
"Health knows no national boundary. The WHO should not reject our participation simply for political reasons," Chan stressed.

Chan said the ROC is now capable of paying the international community back for its help in the past. "We are willing to share our experience and achievements in the public health field with other countries, such as vaccination and information about some contagious diseases," he noted.
During Saturday's debate, a US House representative especially lauded Taiwan for its efforts to fight an enterovirus outbreak this summer.
Chan said the DOH has never ceased its contacts with health authorities in other countries to seek their understanding and support of the ROC's cause.

"We have sent letters to many countries around the world informing them of our experience in handling the enterovirus epidemic," Chan said, adding that health agencies in the United States and many European countries have contacted the DOH for more information about the disease.
Chan went on to say that the ROC will be able to contribute more to world health promotion and disease prevention and control if it is re-admitted to the WHO.
Moreover, Chan said WHO entry will enable Taiwan to further upgrade its health and medical services to improve health of its people.

Because of Beijing's strong opposition, the WHO consistently rejected in the past two years the inclusion into the agenda for its annual meeting of Taiwan's application for entering the WHO as an observer.
The US House resolution recognizes that "Taiwan does not fulfill the criteria for membership," but points out that the WHO does allow observers to participate in its activities.
Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), the original sponsor of the resolution, said that the House has acted to "advance our effort to help Taiwan people obtain first-rate medical care."
"The resolution approved today is a good compromise measure, reached with solid bipartisan support," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY SPIRITUAL LEADER MAY SUPPORT KMT MAYORAL CANDIDATE?

TEXT.P: The New Party's spiritual leader, Hsu Li-nung, may support the Kuomintang's Taipei mayoral candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, rather than the New Party's candidate, Wang Chien-hsien, according to reports.
Hsu would neither confirm nor deny the reports.
Responding to this development, Wang said on Sunday, "that would be purely Hsu's personal decision."
Hsu, a vice chairman of the National Unification Council, has been an influential elder within the New Party.

The China Times said on Sunday that Hsu said on Saturday that the New Party's Wang is a good candidate, but, in consideration of the nation's future development, he would support Ma in the upcoming mayoral election in December.
Hsu reportedly said that if he backs the New Party's Wang, it might negatively affect Ma and help the incumbent mayor, Democratic Progressive Party member Chen Shui-bian, get re-elected.
He reportedly pointed out that national affairs come before party affairs, and that therefore, he has made the painful choice to support Ma.
He said that a news reporter asked him on Saturday night whom he would support in the mayoral election. Instead of answering, Hsu asked the reporter "What do you think?"
Hsu said the reporter made a number of remarks and that what appeared in the paper on Sunday were the reporter's remarks.
Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said that the reports seemingly indicate that "Ma is the New Party's candidate."
Ma's campaign managers said on Sunday that although Ma is a candidate nominated by the Kuomintang, he would seek support from all parties.

They rejected the DPP's claim that "Ma is the New Party's candidate," saying that such slander was aimed at confusing the voters. Ma's aides noted that in a previous mayoral race in Hsinchu, Hsu openly sided with the DPP's candidate, Tsai Jen-chien. "Then can we say that Tsai was a New Party candidate?" they asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTBOUND, INBOUND TRAVEL DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan people made a total of 4.08 million visits overseas in the first eight months of this year, down 6 percent from the same period in 1997, according to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

In terms of the number of visits, Asian countries are the most popular destinations for Taiwan visitors, who paid 3.05 million visits to other countries in the region during the January-August period, DGBAS tallies showed. That figure, however, represents a 6.1 percent decrease from last year.

The Americas are the second most popular destination for Taiwan tourists, who paid around 500,000 visits to countries in that region during the same eight-month period, a decline of 0.6 percent from a year ago. About 140,000 ROC citizens traveled to Europe, up 4 percent on a year-on-year basis.

Among Asian countries, Indonesia experienced the largest drop in the number of Taiwan tourists. Only about 100,000 ROC citizens traveled to that Southeast Asian country between January and August, a drop of 35 percent from year-earlier levels. The decline is due to persistent social unrest and to high levels of haze there.
The number of Taiwan tourists to Hong Kong, Singapore and Macao also dropped, while the number to Japan and Thailand registered growth, the same tallies indicated.

In the meantime, the number of foreign visitors to Taiwan decreased by 6.5 percent to 1.49 million. Nearly 900,000 of them were Asian visitors, with Japanese tourists making up of the bulk, despite a fall of 12.7 percent in the number of arrivals compared with last year.

The DGBAS attributed the slide in both outbound and inbound passengers to the protracted Asian financial crisis, which has greatly affected the public's consumption power and their desire to go abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT TAIPEI MAYORAL CANDIDATES TIE IN SUPPORT RATING: POLL

TEXT.P: The two front runners in the hotly contested Taipei mayoral election tied in their support rating, according to the result of a recent public opinion poll released on Sunday.

Both incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and ruling Kuomintang candidate Ma Ying-jeou each received the support of about 30 percent of the respondents to the telephone survey conducted by the minor opposition New Party between Oct. 8 and Oct. 9. A total of 1,009 valid samples were collected in the poll.

When asked if the mayoral election were to take place on the following day, 30.2 percent of the adult Taipei residents who were interviewed said they would vote for Chen, while 29.3 percent said they would choose Ma.
Meanwhile, 5.5 percent said they would opt for New Party candidate Wang Chien-hsien, and 31 percent said they have yet to decide their favorite candidate.

New Party's top campaign manager Jaw Shau-kong said the poll results indicate that the recent resignation of former Taipei City Government Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng over his personal misdemeanor has not had any significant impact on the two front runners' ratings.
Survey results also showed that 40 percent of New Party supporters will vote for KMT's Ma instead of Wang.

The same survey found that 51.6 percent of the respondents do not believe in the DPP Legislator Yeh Chu-lan's recent allegation that a group of pro-unification politicians has targeted the Taipei mayoral election campaign as a battle ground to restore control over the KMT and to extinguish the political resources held by Mayor Chen, who is considered the most hopeful future presidential candidate of the DPP.
Nevertheless, 19.8 percent said they believe Yeh's allegation is true, and 28.6 percent said they cannot determine whether Yeh's accusation is true or not at the moment.

Twenty-three percent said they believe Ma will adopt a mudsling campaign strategy against Chen; another 22 percent said they think Chen will also adopt such negative campaign tactics; but only 2.4 percent said they believe that Wang will also follow suit.

As for the collective image of each candidate's campaign team, 19.5 percent said they believe Chen's camp is most likely to violate law or take bribes, compared to 15.6 percent who said Ma's camp is most likely to do so.
On the other hand, 23.3 percent said they believe Ma's camp is most likely to commit influence-peddling, compared to Chen camp's 17.6 percent.

Meanwhile, 25.7 percent said they think New Party's Wang is cleanest and least corrupt; 20.8 percent chose Chen; and 20.5 percent said they believe Ma's is the least corrupt among the three candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYORAL CANDIDATES AGREE TO FIVE DEBATE SESSIONS

TEXT.P: The three candidates running for Taipei mayor, incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party, Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang and Wang Chien-hsien of the New Party, will engage in five televised debate sessions in the coming weeks.
Campaign managers for the three candidates met at a Taipei hotel on Sunday to discuss the debates. Several guidelines were established during the meeting:
--Five debate sessions will be held;

--It will be proposed that the Republic of China Journalism Association and the Taiwan Reporters' Association sponsor the second, third and fourth sessions, although it was also decided that other news organizations, which would be chosen by lottery, could also sponsor the events. The fifth session will be sponsored by the Central Elections Commission or by the sponsors of the three preceding sessions; and
--The sponsors of the last four sessions will be responsible for deciding the formats, dates and locations of the debate sessions.
At the meeting, the campaign managers agreed to divide equally the cost of the debate sessions. They also agreed not to attack each other in the media over the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE AGREEMENT DRAFT UNVEILED

TEXT.P: A cross-strait peace agreement draft was unveiled on Sunday before the resumption of cross-strait talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait next week.

The draft, prepared by opposition New Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua and several scholars, calls for the renunciation of the use of force against each other to solve differences across the strait and an end to the ongoing diplomatic tug-of-war in the international arena.

The draft also called for the establishment of representative offices as well as advisory councils in each other's territory to provide advisory views and monitor respective authorities across the Taiwan Strait.

Scholars who co-signed the draft include Professors Chang Lin-cheng, Wang Hsiao-po and Lu Ya-li of National Taiwan University, Yang Kai-huan of Soochow University and Professor Tai Wan-chin of Tamkang University.

The draft said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should share sovereignty based on the "one China" policy, end the threat of military confrontation and boost the well-being of the people to create peaceful, equitable and stable cross-strait relations.

On the political front, the draft calls for the end of the use of force against each other, for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to stop engaging in diplomatic warfare and for them to join forces in taking part in international affairs and in shouldering responsibilities as members of the international community.

On the military front, the draft calls for both sides to advise each other before conducting military exercises and to invite observers from the other side to the exercises. In addition, both sides of the Taiwan Strait would not target their weapons against each other or send spies to other side under the agreement.
On the economic front, the draft calls for the establishment of direct trade, postal and transportation links across the strait and the signing of investment guarantee agreements.
Both sides would grant national treatment to people from the other side and recognize the credentials of all schools on the other side.
Legislator Lee said he hopes the draft will be used for reference by C. F. Koo, the top negotiator with the mainland, in his upcoming talks with the mainland during a visit there Oct. 14-19.

Professor Chang said that in view of the current cross-strait situation, it is impossible to implement the provisions outlined in the draft, but that if both sides of the Taiwan Strait work toward moving in that direction, the goal of peaceful co-existence can be achieved.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACKFACE SPOONBILLS BEGIN TO ARRIVE IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Endangered blackface spoonbills have begun to arrive in Tainan County in the southern part of Taiwan, bird watchers said on Sunday.

Chihku Village's Tsengwen River, located in Tainan County, is arguably the largest habitat of blackface spoonbills in the world. The endangered birds migrate each year southward to Taiwan for the winter, staying until March or April.
Huang Fu-hsing, secretary-general of Tainan County Blackface Spoonbill Conservation Society, said that 19 blackface spoonbills have been spotted since early this month.
He speculated that the figure could reach 100 by the end of the month.
The largest number of blackface spoonbills to arrive at Tsengwen River in recent years was 339, about two-thirds of the rare bird's total population, Huang said.
He said the migration of the blackface spoonbill usually peaks at the end of November or early December, which is also the time when the largest number of bird watchers migrate to Chihku.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK SUGGESTS INVITING MAINLAND PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A local private think tank on Sunday suggested that Taiwan take the initiative to invite mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to visit Taiwan in either private or official capacity.

The Rising People Foundation, headed by Hsu Hsin-liang, a former chairman of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said no prerequisite should be set for the proposed invitation to Jiang.
The foundation further said the first meeting between Jiang and ROC President Lee Teng-hui can be held in either Hong Kong or Macau in 1999.

The foundation presented the proposals three days before the departure of Taipei's top negotiator with Beijing, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo, for an ice-breaking visit to mainland China.
