Foundation Chairman Hsu said Koo's landmark visit to Shanghai and Beijing will mark a new beginning for relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"We hope Koo will take advantage of his upcoming China visit to convey a message of peace to Beijing leaders and to invite Jiang to visit Taiwan in his capacity as President Lee's special envoy," Hsu told a news conference.

The foundation also suggested that Taiwan promise to revise its current "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China under a premise that Beijing agrees to let Taiwan join the World Trade Organization ahead of the mainland.
Other proposals recommended by the foundation include:

-- Ministerial-level officials from economics and trade departments and central bank governors on both sides of the Taiwan Strait exchange visits regularly to discuss cooperative measures for addressing the lingering Asian financial turmoil;

-- A joint press conference should be held and Beijing allows its national television networks to give live broadcast on such a news conference to let people on both sides of the strait get first-hand information about cross-strait peace.

During his mainland visit, Koo will hold talks with his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), on a broad range of issues. He will also meet with mainland President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen.
Hsu said the general international situation has changed significantly since the first Koo-Wang meeting held in Singapore in April 1993.

"Following the 1995-1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, Taipei and Beijing should seek the establishment of a new order between the two sides of the strait," Hsu said, adding he hopes both sides will refer to the foundation's above-mentioned proposals in charting their future policies on cross-strait engagement and relations.

Hsu further said maintaining the status quo is the best strategy for both sides of the Taiwan Strait at the moment. "The two sides should patiently engage in peaceful dialogue under the premise of respecting the status quo and increase economic exchanges and cooperation to lay a solid foundation for the establishment of a new cross-strait order.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMEN CALL FOR TAIWAN'S WHO PARTICIPATION

TEXT.P: The US House of Representatives on Saturday overwhelmingly approved a resolution calling on the administration to support Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).
The non-binding resolution won approval by a vote of 418 to 0, one day after its introduction by Gerald B. H. Solomon (R-N.Y.), chairman of the powerful Rules Committee.

The measure falls short of asking for Taiwan's membership in the WHO. Instead, it says that it should be US policy "to pursue some initiative in the WHO which will give Taiwan meaningful participation."
The resolution recognizes that "Taiwan does not fulfill the criteria for membership," but points out that the WHO does allow observers to participate in its activities.
Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), the original sponsor of the resolution, said that the House has acted to "advance our effort to help Taiwan people obtain first-rate medical care."
"The resolution approved today is a good compromise measure, reached with solid bipartisan support," he added.
At the insistence of Beijing, the US administration has made it clear that it does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations where statehood is a requirement.

Because of mainland China's obstruction, Taiwan's recent bids for even WHO observer status have been unsuccessful. The Republic of China on Taiwan lost its WHO membership in 1972 after losing its seat in the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINT CONFERENCE ON ECONOMIC, TECHNICAL COOPERATION OPENS

TEXT.P: The 16th session of the Sino-Saudi Permanent Joint Committee on Economic and Technical Cooperation was inaugurated by Lin Yi-Fu, the ROC's Vice Minister of Economic Affairs, and by Mohamed H. Al-Mady, vice president of the Saudi Arabia Basic Industrial Cooperation, in Riyadh on Saturday.

Al-Mady congratulated the ROC delegates on Taiwan's 87th National Day and said that in the past three decades both sides have helped each other achieve many goals. He further noted that during the current global economic crisis, the economies of both countries are stronger than those of many others.
Al-Mady said he hoped that the committee could help lead the two countries to a prosperous new century.

Lin said that trade between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia has progressed steadily over the past three years. It shows the fruits of sincere cooperation and the success generated by mutual assistance.
Lin said he hopes that through the conference both countries would be able to help each other achieve more substantial progress in enhancing bilateral cooperative relations.

Lin stated that throughout this conference, delegates from both countries will conduct thorough discussions of major issues relating to commercial arbitration, visas, investment and the exchange of visits among high-ranking government officials.

Lin said he hoped the conference could result in the signing of agreements to foster bilateral economic and trade relations, including the signing of a bilateral commercial arbitration cooperation agreement; the negotiation of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia on the promotion and protection of investment; a mutual recognition agreement on product certification; and an ocean freight income tax exemption agreement.
The conference will close on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEWER TAIWANESE TOURISTS VISITING THAILAND THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Thailand is concerned that the number of Taiwanese tourist arrivals in Thailand during the first eight months of this year fell by 4.3 percent compared with the same period in 1997, while the economy of the Republic of China on Taiwan has remained relatively strong during the regional economic crisis.
Tourism Authority of Thailand officials said that only 287,348 Taiwanese tourists arrived during the first eight months of this year.
Meanwhile, the number of Indonesian tourists fell 43.84 percent to 37,591, while the number of visitors from South Korea fell by 61.55 percent to 119,669.
Japanese tourist arrivals were down 3.82 percent, totaling 640,089, while arrivals from Hong Kong were off 1 percent at 218,057.

The number of Malaysian tourists visiting Thailand totaled only 620,986, a 6.45 percent drop. Thai officials predicted that the figures could worsen over the next few months as the effects of Malaysia's strict currency controls start to sink in.

But the weak baht and the stable political and social climate in Thailand has helped to boost the overall number of tourist arrivals by 5.59 percent to 5.04 million in the first eight months this year, officials said.

The number of tourists from Europe totaled 1.37 million, a 22.26 increase from the same period last year, while the number of North American visitors totaled 343,211, an increase of 14.24 percent from year-earlier levels. The number of visitors from East Asia, however, fell 4.06 percent to 2.79 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SEES RISE IN PROTECTIONIST SENTIMENT IN BEIJING AND LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: The US government is concerned about indications that mainland China and some Latin American countries are beginning to consider protectionist trade policies, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Saturday.
The US government sees "the slight beginnings of a turning inward in some countries," the WTO report said, citing Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Peru, Colombia, Venezuela and mainland China.
The US government said it has so far seen "nothing very dramatic," but that there have been suggestions of import licensing and increases in tariffs.
"We will, of course, enforce our laws against unfair foreign export practices and adopt sensible policies in case of import surges."

The US administration will "ensure that countries like Communist China, Argentina, Chile and Brazil do not respond by reverting to protectionism; we will refuse to panic and shut off trade ourselves," the WTO report quoted US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION ON VERGE OF SPLIT AFTER ELECTION DEFEAT (I)

TEXT.P: One Nation is on the verge of a split following the embarrassing defeat of its leader, Pauline Hanson, in federal elections on Oct. 3 election as recriminations are mounting within the party.

Hanson's supporters plan to remove her former top adviser -- David Oldfield -- and her national party director -- David Ettridge. But the supporters of the two Davids counter that Hanson was directly responsible for the most serious gaffes in her election campaign.
Political analysts said that despite the stunning defeat of One Nation in federal elections, One Nation will remain a "nagging presence" on the Australian political scene.

They said Hanson failed her party by losing the election. But that does not mean the end of the party, which is often called racist because of policies that are regarded as anti-Asian immigration, anti-multiculturalism, anti-foreign investment and anti-Aboriginal people.
They said Hanson lost her election because of the 2 percent "Easytax" proposal which even she herself could not explain clearly to supporters during the election campaign.

Another contributing factor to her failure to win was Hanson's calling herself the "mother of Australians," while her eldest son said she had not been a good mother in an interview with a popular weekly magazine.
Analysts said a split of the party could happen at the general meeting of One Nation in Gold Coast, a popular resort city known for its beautiful beaches, in Queensland.
They believe Hanson's supporters will try to remove both Oldfield and Ettridge as party directors.
They will then seek the establishment of an elected 20-person national council to replace Hanson's One Nation Ltd., a company that comprises only three figures -- Hanson, Oldfield and Ettridge.
One Nation's candidate for the federal seat of Brisbane, Sam Tornatore, said Oldfield should "accept full blame" for Hanson's failed campaign and be "kicked out" of the party.
He said Oldfield's "stupid" decision to call police to evict journalists from the party's campaign launch cost One Nation many votes during the Oct. 3 elections.
He called for a reform in the party structure to make it more democratic. "We are not happy with the way things are, and changes need to be made," he said.

But Oldfield hit back, describing Tornatore's comments as "stupid and ignorant." "It is the Queensland campaign committee that directed everything that happened up there," he said. Oldfield himself lost his seat in the Senate during the elections.
A new dispute emerging between Hanson's and Oldfield's supporters is over the location of the party's headquarters.
Hanson's supporters want the headquarters to be relocated to Ipswich in Queensland, where the party was based. But Oldfield's supporters want the headquarters to remain in Sydney.

If the head office is moved, then it will diminish the influence of party power brokers -- the two Davids -- and put One Nation under the control of Pauline Hanson and Heather Hill, the only One Nation candidate to win a seat in the Oct. 3 elections.

All other party candidates lost their races, surprising many One Nation supporters and substantially reducing the party's influence and its ambition to become a force in Australian politics, analysts said.
Speaking publicly for the first time since losing her seat in Parliament, Hanson denied One Nation's failure to win any Lower House seats signaled its demise.
She was optimistic before the election, predicting One Nation could win 12 seats in the House of Representatives and six seats in the Senate.
Instead of blaming herself for the party's poor showing, Hanson shifted the blame to the Australian media and the voting system based on preferences for her stunning loss in the election.

Despite her defeat, Hanson will become the president of the One Nation Party and is expected to be paid a six-figure salary similar to that of federal members of Parliament because she will be responsible for conducting speaking tours throughout Australia, in an attempt to win more grassroots supporters.
Supporters and key party figures said One Nation still needs Hanson because she was the one who set up the party 18 months ago.
"Without her as the party president, One Nation could vanish totally," one analyst said. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION (PART II)

TEXT.P: One Nation won about 8 percent of the votes during the Oct. 3 election. Based on that percentage, One Nation will receive about A$3 million (US$1.87 million) from the federal government to reimburse party candidate for expenditures.
With the backing of her supporters in Queensland, Hanson has decided that she would take control of One Nation and "run it myself," moving the party's head office to her political base in Ipswich.

But Ettridge suggested that Hanson's name be dropped from the party name because she is no longer the leader of One Nation. He also said the party's head office should remain in Sydney where both Davids operate.

But Hanson said One Nation will become a Queensland-based party and that she will control it herself. "We have got a state executive here in Queensland and we want to expand on that. I'll be looking at heading it here in Queensland and running it here in Queensland myself," she said.
Supporters of Ettridge and Oldfield, however, say that if One Nation were to move its base to Queensland, it would become a state, rather than a national, political organization.
Analysts said the split will only worsen before any possible compromise during next month's meeting at Gold Coast.
"Let's wait and see whether One Nation is moving towards its rise or fall after its drastic loss in the October election," one analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The US House of Representatives passed a resolution with a vote of 418-0 supporting Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).
The China Times: The US House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved a resolution supporting Taiwan's participation in WHO activities.
The United Daily News: The Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures will be further revised to phase out provincial taxes.
The Liberty Times: The three Taipei mayoral contenders finally agree to engage in public debate on television.
The Independence Morning Post: The three Taipei mayoral candidates agree to attend five public debate sessions.
The Commons Daily: Scholar Tien Hung-mao said if the United States would not help the ROC "enter" the international community, and that when the ROC can no longer survive, Taiwan would be forced to declare independence.
The China Post: Ethnic overtones enter Taipei mayoral race.
The China News: Clock is ticking for Kosovo strikes.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO ALLOW IMPORT OF 200 BREEDING RAMS

TEXT.P: Responding to requests by the Goat Farmer Association, the Council of Agriculture (COA) has agreed to import 200 breeding rams.
COA officials said that in the past the council has allowed only a limited number of breeding rams to come to Taiwan so as not to have too many goats and tip the balance of supply and demand.
But with repeated requests from the association, the COA has for the first time permitted the import of a large number of rams into Taiwan next year.

According to statistics released by the Department of Agriculture and Forestry (DAF) under the Taiwan Provincial Government, there are in Taiwan at present 2,958 breeding dairy rams and 6,879 breeding rams.

COA officials said that although Taiwan Livestock Research Institute has used artificial insemination to try to relieve the current shortage of breeding rams, the Goat Farmer Association has complained about the procedure's high costs and the fact that its success rate is substandard.
The officials said that the council has therefore decided to import 200 breeding rams from the United States, Australia and Japan starting next year.
