DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPATRIATES 70 ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Ilan Detention Center repatriated 70 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants on Sunday, marking the first repatriation of people from Taiwan to mainland China in six months, police sources said.

Since all repatriations require the cooperation of mainland Chinese authorities, Sunday's delivery was considered a good-will gesture by Beijing before a visit to the mainland by Taiwan's top negotiator, Koo Chen-fu, local political observers said.

Since April of this year, Beijing has been reluctant to take back illegal immigrants. An unwillingness to do so is a violation of the Kinmen Agreement reached between the Red Cross Societies of both sides in 1990, the sources noted.
Under the agreement, the mainland is supposed to take delivery of illegal mainland immigrants within 20 days of receiving a list of the immigrants' names.

The Ilan Detention Center, one of three Taiwan detention centers for stowaways and illegal immigrants from mainland China, repatriated 110 mainlanders between January and April of this year, according to the sources. The Two other centers are located in Hsinchu, central Taiwan, and on the offshore island of Matsu.
Among the 70 detainees in Ilan, some were happy and some were sad at being repatriated.

Lin Mouqin, 29, from Pingtan, Fujian Province, has been at the center longer than any other detainee. Lin, who has been arrested twice since 1994, said he was pleased to be sent back to the mainland, adding that trying to sneak into Taiwan was not sensible.
Lin was nabbed trying to sneak into Taiwan in 1994 after paying 20,000 renminbi to a cross-strait human smuggling ring.
He was again arrested for illegally entering Taiwan with forged documents in May 1997 after paying another 20,000 renminbi to the operators. He has been in detention since then.
"I won't come again," he told reporters. "The deal is not worth it."
Nien Jiaping, another young man from Pingtan, was apparently not as light-hearted as Lin. Nien, 25, wept constantly since being told last week he would be repatriated.

Nien, nabbed upon landing on Taiwan's soil in April of this year, was diagnosed as having acute fibrosis by detention physicians in August. The center has since spent some NT$500,000 (US$15,150) on his medical bills. He has developed myoatrophy and can hardly walk.
Nien said before being sent back to the mainland that he is not sure he will be capable of receiving medical care back home or whether his condition can be treated.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUJIAN DELEGATION TO VISIT

TEXT.P: Zhang Jiakun, vice governor of mainland China's Fujian province, will travel to Taiwan on Tuesday for a 12-day visit at the invitation of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI).
A nine-member delegation, including Fuzhou Mayor Weng Fulin and provincial trade, tax and customs officials, will accompany Zhang on his Taiwan tour.

According to CNFI, the major purpose of Zhang's visit to Taiwan is to gain an understanding of Taiwan's economic development and its market-oriented economy, since Fujian province has opened its market for quite some time.

As Fujian is one of the most popular investment destinations on the mainland among Taiwan businessmen, it is good for the province's policy-making authorities to take a look at those Taiwan companies with operations there, the CNFI said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ADVANCE TEAM LEAVES FOR SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: A six-member advance team left for Shanghai on Monday to settle some technical details to ensure smooth proceeding of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo's upcoming landmark visit to mainland China.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng, head of the advance team, said prior to his departure that as Koo's Oct. 14-19 mainland visit is mainly aimed at improving the atmosphere of relations across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan basically will respect Beijing's arrangements.

After three rounds of preparatory talks in April, July and September, Jan said, Koo's mainland itinerary has largely been set. "The advance team will mainly put finishing touches on some technical issues," he noted.
Still, the advance team's workload is expected to be very heavy. It must handle all logistic support to ensure smooth progress of Koo's Shanghai-Beijing visit.

Jan said the advance team will coordinate with its counterpart from the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to ensure that all news media from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will have fair access to all related information.

According to press reports, more than 400 journalists from Taiwan, mainland China and other countries will cover Koo's high-profile mainland visit, particularly Koo's meetings with mainland President Jiang Zemin in Beijing on Oct. 18 and with his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, in Shanghai on Oct. 15-16.

The advance team is expected to set up media liaison centers and make all necessary arrangements to enable Koo to perform well before Chinese and foreign media and clearly explain the Republic of China's stance on cross-strait relations.
After the 12-member Koo delegation arrives in Shanghai on Wednesday, the advance team will leave for Beijing to clear the way for Koo's arrival on Oct. 16 evening.

While in Beijing, Jan said, the advance team will most like to know how many members of the Koo delegation can be present at the Koo-Jiang meeting and which Taiwan news media will be allowed to cover that event.
ARATS Chairman Wang was quoted by the local press as saying last week that mainland President Jiang will only meet Koo and his wife.

Commenting on the report, a senior mainland affairs official said Taiwan does not like to see such a scenario. "We hope several other delegates will accompany the Koos in meeting Jiang," the official said.

According to Taiwan's plan, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow, National Unification Council (NUC) member Kang Ning-hsiang, NUC researcher Chang Jung-kung and Pao Cheng-kang, chief secretary of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, will also be present at the Koo-Jiang meeting, which will be the highest-level cross-strait talks in five decades.
Meanwhile, the official said, the Koo delegation may shorten its visit if Beijing takes another move to squeeze Taiwan's diplomatic frontier during Koo's stay on the mainland.

Beijing announced the establishment of full diplomatic ties with the West African state of Guinea-Bissau, originally an ROC diplomatic ally, when SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan was on the mainland to pave the way for Koo's ice-breaking mainland visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS GST IMPLEMENTED BEFORE 2000 OLYMPICS

TEXT.P: Foreign tourists coming to see the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney may be hit by a 10 percent goods and services tax (GST) if the Australian government is able to get the GST legislation passed by June 1999.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello on Sunday warned the government would lose valuable GST revenue from foreign tourists if the Senate delayed the tax reform package.

The warning came as Australian Democrats Party leader Meg Lees and two independent senators declared that they would oppose the tax if food were not exempted from it. The three senators hold the balance of power in the Senate.
Costello said the government needed the legislation to be passed before June 30, 1999 to provide businesses, consumers and the Australian Taxation Office a full 12 months to prepare for the change.

"International experience shows us this -- from the time of the passing of the legislation to the time of its implementation takes about 12 months. If you were going to have a new tax system operating in Australia by July 1, 2000, you need the legislation passed through both houses of Parliament by about June 30 next year," he said.
The ruling coalition of the Liberal and National parties under Prime Minister John Howard has a majority in the House of Representatives, but lacks one in the Senate.

Costello said July 1, 2000 was chosen as the target date to implement the tax because it would enable the government to collect revenue from overseas visitors who will come to see the Sydney Olympic Games in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX REFORM COULD HELP TURN AUSTRALIA INTO FINANCIAL CENTER

TEXT.P: An ongoing tax reform drive, including a measure to lower business tax levels from the current 33 percent to 30 percent, will make Australia more attractive as a financial services center in the Asia-Pacific region, said Federal Treasurer Peter Costello on Australia's Channel 9 on Sunday.
Costello also said the present economic turmoil in the region has presented Australia with opportunities as well as challenges.
"If Asia is in recession, if the Japanese financial system looks shaky, where do you think people in this area are going to look to base their financial businesses?" he asked.
He said the tax reform measures would boost Australia's chances of becoming a regional financial center.
"Taking taxes off financial institutions and shares will be a big part of that. This will be a historic opportunity for Australia," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE OFFICIAL: RISKS NOW LIE IN US, LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: While Japan is beginning to sort out its problems, dangers to the global economy may come from new quarters: the United States and Latin America, Finance Minister of Singapore Richard Hu Tsu Tauf said.

"It may take a long time yet but it probably has bottomed out. The problem is shifting to the US now," he told The Straits Times as the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund wound to a close.
"A weak dollar is good for the region in several ways, provided it's not a precursor to a US collapse. If it means the beginning of recession in America, it's very bad for us," he said.
A strengthening yen could also help bring in more Japanese investment into the region, he added. The US dollar plunged last week against the yen.

The annual meetings, held against the backdrop of the world's worst post-war economic crisis, produced no immediate solutions to Asia's continuing economic woes or to the contagion now threatening other parts of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S THIRD QUARTER REGISTERS NEGATIVE GROWTH

TEXT.P: Singapore slipped into negative growth in the third quarter of this year, but the economy could still achieve positive growth for the year, Finance Minister Richard Hu Tsu Tau said.

Saying the indication that Singapore had registered negative growth in this year's third quarter was not surprising, Hu noted government predictions called for growth this year between 0.5 percent and 1.5 percent.

"If we take first and second quarters as positive, the third quarter must be negative, mathematically if nothing else. Fourth quarters tend to be a lot better. The third quarter will probably be the worst, statistically," he said.
The speed with which New York's Dow Jones Industrial Average and the US dollar have fallen make it difficult to predict how things will go in the near term, he said.
"And the big question mark is Japan. There is no recovery in the Asian region without Japanese recover. But here again, there are pluses and minuses," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANALYSTS DIVIDED OVER SINGAPORE'S LIKELY FOURTH QUARTER PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Singapore stocks have made an impressive start to the final quarter, but it is still unclear whether stocks will stumble or soar in the remaining months of the year, according to The Business Times.
While there is general consensus that interest rates, which usually move inversely to share prices, will fall further, views are split down the middle on how stocks will fare.

Still calling for caution is Goh Mou Lih, a strategist at Daiwa Institute of Research. But Manu Bhaskaran, managing director and group research head at SG Securities, argued for an overweight position on Singapore stocks in a strategy piece last Friday.

"It goes show how difficult it is to call a very volatile market. You stick out your neck and argues your case, but it could be anyone's guess and anyone could be right," commented another research director.

For one thing, it is unclear whether the strengthening yen, a major factor behind the recent rise in regional markets, would last. By the reckoning of many, the yen really has more to do with the unwinding of large speculative positions than with any fundamental change.

More significantly, the yen rose because the US dollar fell on recessionary fears. If the United States goes into recession next year, as forecast by JP Morgan, demand for Asian exports would collapse, hindering any recovery by Singapore's export-driven economy, Goh said.

Since the start of the fourth quarter, the benchmark Straits Times Index has gained nearly 4 percent. It ended Friday at 976.65, above the year-end target of 950 points Daiwa has set. This was not enough, however, for Goh to revise his forecast. "For the time being, it is difficult to raise the target because of all the uncertainties."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMISTS IN SINGAPORE DO NOT EXPECT A US RECESSION

TEXT.P: Economic forecasters in Singapore are watching the United States' economy closely, but most do not expect a US recession next year, even though they say the risk of one has increased in recent months.
They warn that the repercussions from a US recession would be "serious" for Asia, as regional economies depend on their export sectors to buoy growth.
So far, growth forecasts for Asian economies have mostly assumed continued robust growth in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET SERVER MARKET SET TO BOOM

TEXT.P: While sales of general computer servers are on the decline, the market for Internet server is booming, especially in most countries in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a preliminary study by Dataquest, a division of Gartner Group Inc.

Five key countries in the region -- Singapore, Hong Kong, mainland China, Australia and South Korea -- are together expected to grow a robust 141 percent this year from last year, much higher than the global growth rate of 114 percent for 1998.
Internet servers are computer servers used specifically for Internet-related applications, including e-commerce, Web hosting, messaging and collaborations.

"They are the fastest-growing niche category and should account for 20 percent of all servers sold globally this year, compared to just 10 percent last year," Saleem Bikanerwala, principal industry analyst for Dataquest Asia-Pacific, told The Business Times.
"In the Asia-Pacific, they would form about 26 percent for all servers sold this year, against 11 percent last year."
The region accounts for around 7.5 percent of the global market for Internet servers, which was worth US$6.21 billion last year and is expected to gross US$13.27 billion this year.
Singapore saw sales of US$204.2 million in servers last year, with Internet servers forming about 15 percent of the total, Bikanerwala said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEES ASIAN DEMAND FOR ENERGY RISING

TEXT.P: Asia's demand for Australian energy will weaken in the short term because of the region's financial crisis, but long-term prospects are rising, Energy Minister Warwick Parer said.
"The current financial difficulties will have a short-term dampening effect on growth in energy demand," he said.

Parer cited a forecast by the Asia Pacific Energy Research Center that indicated energy demand in the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum will rise by 41 percent between 1995 and 2010 and coal's share of regional power generation will increase from 58 percent to 66 percent during the same period.
APEC members must improve their investment regimes to attract the US$70 billion the Asian Development Bank says is needed to develop the region's gas infrastructure, he said.
APEC's energy strategy, however, would result in rising greenhouse gas emissions, Greenpeace warned.
"We don't want Asia to make the same mistake as Australia, to rely on fossil fuel," Greenpeace's Irwin Jackson said.

"There's no such thing as clean coal. Rather than marginally improving coal power generation, money would be better spent on promoting energy efficiency and developing alternative energy sources," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD URGES BEIJING TO MOVE FASTER IN ITS DEALINGS WITH TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Monday presented a banner to Koo Chen-fu, officially authorizing Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China to embark on his landmark visit to Shanghai and Beijing, which will begin Wednesday.
Chang, Taiwan's top official in charge of ROC policies toward mainland China, said Koo's forthcoming visit to the mainland is poised to give fresh impetus to cross-strait relations.
He reiterated that pushing for better cross-strait relations is not a single-handed effort. Both sides must demonstrate the sincerity and goodwill necessary to achieve better relations, he said.
He urged Beijing to show its sincerity and goodwill by accelerating the pace of concrete moves to redress differences and solve problems across the Taiwan Strait.
The visit to the mainland by Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), is a plus to the process of warming cross-strait ties, he added.

It is hoped that through the resumption of meetings between Koo and Wang Daohan, chairman of the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the level of cross-strait negotiations will gradually be heightened, so that both sides will gain an understanding of each other and be able to solve various issues arising from increased exchanges across the strait, Chang noted.
Koo met with Wang in Singapore in 1993, an event that served as an ice-breaking session between representatives from Taiwan and mainland China after more than four decades without contact.

Premier Vincent Siew received Koo and his mainland-bound team at the Executive Yuan after Koo was presented with the banner by Chang. Siew had a 50-minute conversation with Koo concerning the upcoming mainland visit.

During his talk with Koo, Siew mentioned his willingness to push for grassroots democratic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait. Commenting on the premier's remarks, Chang said that Taiwan, with its half century of experience in democratic politics and general elections, is willing and able to share its legal and democratic development experiences with mainland China.

On the "positioning" of Koo's mid-October mainland visit, Chang said Taipei has reiterated its position more than 110 times, calling for Beijing to return to the negotiating table and to help institutionalize cross-strait dialogue.
Chang said Koo has been given "broad authority" by MAC to embark on the mainland visit, which will inevitably involve "talks."

He added that Koo is authorized to talk about anything with his mainland hosts -- including peace and security developments across the strait, SEF-ARATS exchanges and issues that are mutually reciprocal -- as long as the discussions are constructive.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE SUPPORT CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT MEETING: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people support the proposal that the top leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait either exchange visits or hold a summit meeting, according to the result of a public opinion poll released on Monday.

The telephone survey was conducted by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) from Sept. 29 through Oct. 2 to probe local people's opinion about cross-strait relations ahead of an ice-breaking visit to mainland China by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo.

The poll of 1,078 adults residing throughout the island found that 39.6 percent of the respondents believe that Koo's Oct. 14-19 Shanghai-Beijing visit will be helpful to future cross-strait ties; only 10.7 percent hold a negative view.

Meanwhile, 63.1 percent said issues related to the rights and well-being of the people on both sides of the strait should top the agenda of future cross-strait negotiations, while 12.4 percent said political negotiations should take precedence over any other topics.

Most noteworthy was that the survey results indicated a significant change in local people's ethnic identification probably because of the impact of such incidents as US President Bill Clinton's declaration of the so-called "three noes" policy against Taiwan and the kidnap-murder of Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Ti-chuan in mainland China in late July.
According to the poll, 38.9 percent said they identify themselves as Taiwanese, up from 30.5 percent recorded in a similar survey conducted in May.
Another 37.8 percent said they identify themselves as both Taiwanese and Chinese. It was the first time that the percentage of this category of people fell below 40 percent.

Poll results also showed that 58.6 percent of the respondents throw their support behind the proposal that President Lee Tang-hui and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin either exchange visits or hold a summit meeting.

Nevertheless, 14.1 percent nixed such a proposal and 27.3 percent said they do not have any opinion about the overture. A marginal 0.2 percent said they would support the proposal only under the premise that Lee meets Jiang in his capacity as the Republic of China's head of state.

As much as 73 percent said they oppose the Beijing-initiated "one country, two systems" unification scheme; only 6.3 percent said they support such a formula. Similar MAC surveys conducted since 1991 on this issue indicate that local people's attitude toward the proposal has remained almost unchanged.
As for local people's stance on Taiwan's future, the latest poll found that the majority of local residents still prefer to maintain the status quo.

A total of 75.9 percent of those interviewed said they favor maintaining the status quo, including those who want to see the status quo maintained permanently and those who want to maintain the status quo at the moment and to decide either independence or unification in the future.

According to the poll, the percentage of those who favor immediate declaration of independence still exceeds that of the people who favor an immediate reunion with mainland China, 20 percent vs. 17 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS, OPINION LEADERS SHOULD NOT VISIT HOSTESS BARS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of Taipei residents believe neither government officials nor city councilors should go to hostess bars, the results of a recent survey released on Monday showed.

According to the public opinion poll, about 67 percent of those surveyed said city councilors, like government officials, should not visit hostess bars or nightclubs, citing "private morale" as the reason. Only 14 percent said they were not opposed to such conduct by city councilors.

A top aide in Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian's re-election campaign stepped down recently after he was found frequenting hostess bars. The issue stirred up a debate along with verbal attacks among the three contenders in the approach to the year-end election for Taipei mayor.

According to the survey, around 71 percent of Taipei residents expressed the hope that the political parties would stop lashing out with verbal attacks while only 13 percent said they did not mind such behavior.

Despite earlier vows to stage a clean election campaign by all three major political parties, about 50 percent said they did not believe the mayoral election would be a discreet one compared to 26 percent who expressed such confidence.

Taipei City Councilor Chen Hsueh-fen, who released the results of the poll, said she believed the survey's outcome would give all public opinion leaders the opportunity to think about the issue and moderate their behavior accordingly.
The survey was conducted through telephone interviews with 899 Taipei residents from Oct. 7-9.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVOLUTION OF TALKS ACROSS THE TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China announced in May 1991 its "one China, two political entities" policy with regard to Beijing in the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could develop ties and promote reunification on the basis of equal footing.

In November 1987, the ROC government dropped its ban on cross-strait travel and Taiwan nationals were permitted to visit their relatives on the Chinese mainland. This turned a new leaf in cross-striat ties.

Follwoing the gradual relaxation of the cross-strait situation and an increase in private exchanges, many problems have arisen. The people-to-people exchanges, the indirect trade and investment, and the cultural exchanges that blossomed in the wake of this thaw have engendered a range of issues that necessitated a more systematic approach to bilateral interaction.

To safeguard people's rights and interests, it was crucial that both sides of the strait communicated and negotiated to solve their problems. With this view, the ROC government in February 1991 estalbished the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) as the only private organization empowered by the government to handle matters of a technical and business nature with regard to the mainland.
In December 1991, Beijing set up their Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), with Wang Daohan as its chairman, to negotiate with SEF.
After over a year of interaction, Koo Chen-fu, chairman of SEF, and ARATS chairman met in Singapore and held talks in what was the first contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.

The first round of Koo-Wang talks resulted in several agreements dealing with document authentication, the handling of mail and future meetings. Provisions were made for regular and non-periodic meetings between SEF and ARATS officials.
Details of the agreement are as follows:
1. The Agreement on Document Authentication Between the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

The increasing number of private-sector exchanges between the Taiwan Area and the Chinese mainland made it necessary to present, for use on the other side of the Taiwan Strait, documents concerning the claim of rights or the receipt of payments, for resettlement or residential purposes.
However, given the different legal systems on the two sides of the strait and in particular the extensive area, it was difficult to dtermine whether a document was authentic.

Leberal authentication could adversely affect the interests of a party with genuine rights, whereas strict authentication might create inconvenience for the public. it was therefore essential that documents be authenticated trough a sumple verification process common to both Taiwan and the mainland.

Formerly, neither side had been able to provide a method of document authentication for the other siade. When handling cases of document verification, SEF had to make written requests for verification by the issuing agency on the mainland.

Not only was the exchange of correspondence time-consuming, but also no mainland agency would respond to SEF inquiries. This resulted in inefficient document authentication, a backlog of verification cases and a great deal of problems.

In the Agreement on Document Authentication Between the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, both sides agreed to send copies of documents concerning inheritance, adoption, marriange, birth, death, consignment, adacemic degree, residence, dependency, and property ownership for verification purposes to the other side.
Documents are now authenticated by comparison with copies sent by the other side, and verification may be resquested in writing in case of any doubt.

This method should provide better and more effective service for the public. SEF and ARATS also agreed to consult and provide mutual assistance in individual cases concerning non-notarized documents. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: EVOLUTION OF TALKS ACROSS THE TAIWAN STRAIT--2

TEXT.P: 2. The Agreement on the Tracing of and Compensation for Lost Registered Mail Between the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
Ordinary mail is sent across the Taiwan Strait via a third area, but registered mail service has not been established.

The difficulty in the conveyance of important correspondence has mainly been due to a lack of arrangements by either side over the scope of any cross-strait registered mail service to be offered and the tracing of and compensation for lost registered mail.

In the Agreement on the Tracing and Compensation for Lost Registered Mail Between the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, both sides agreed that the registered mail service would cover letters, post cards, aerograms, printed matter, newspapers, magazines, and letters written in Braille. Under the agreeement, registered mail, like ordinary mail, is to travel indirectly between the two sides.

Both sides agreed to provide mutual assistance to track down lost registered mail, and to respond within three months of receiving a written inquiry. To simplify matters, it is decided that anyone who sent a letter that was lost, stolen or destroyed would be compensated by the area from which the letter was mailed.

3. The Agreement on the Establishment of Systematic Liaison and Communication Channels Between the SEF and the ARATS is aimed primarily at building up a systematic form of communication and dialogue between the two agencies.

In Principle, the agreement calls for regular or irregular meetings between SEF and ARATS chairmen, vice chairmen, and secretaries-general. Department directors or office heads shall meet once every three months to discuss more timely issues in their area of responsibility.

The agencies' deputy secreataries-general, or personnel of equivalent status, will be the contact person in emergencies. In addition, SEF and ARATS shall mutually facilitate the entry and exit of SEF and ARATS personnel.
4. The Koo-Wang Talks Joint Accord.
SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan met in Singapore on behalf of their respective agencies to proceed with non-governmental talks on economic, practical, and functional matters.
The Koo-Wang Talks Joint Accord set up a priority list for topics of mutual concern that both sides agree require further discussion.

Topics to be discussed this year include repatriation of illegal immigrants, efforts to crack down on illegal activities at sea, the resolution of fishing disputes, the protection of intellectual property rights, and mutual assistance on judicial issues.

As for economic exchanges; the development and exchange of energy resources; and cultural, educational, scientific and technological exchanges, SEF and ARATS will continue to hold talks to resolve matters of concern to people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and to facilitate more orderly private exchanges between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.057 against the greenback in Taipei Monday, closing at 32.88.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.78, and had a law of 32.92.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$263.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINO-SAUDI CONFAB CONCLUDES FRUITFULLY
DOC.DATELINE: Riyadh, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Yang Yi-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The 16th session of the Sino-Saudi Permanent Joint Committee on Economic and Technical Cooperation concluded on Sunday in Riyadh with both sides pledging to further accelerate bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

Over the past two days, Republic of China and Saudi Arabian officials have reached a number of agreements on various areas, including a bilateral trade arbitration system to be devised by the two countries' private sectors to solve trade disputes, said Lin Yi-fu, vice economic affairs minister and chief ROC delegate to the annual meeting.
Riyadh also agreed to assess the feasibility of signing an agreement on the temporary admission of goods with Taipei to expedite bilateral economic and cultural exchanges.
Riyadh also welcomes Taiwan to sponsor exhibitions of turn-key plants and facilities in Saudi Arabia, Lin noted.

Taiwan, meanwhile, agreed to allow Saudi Arabian vegetables, ceramic and earthenware products to be exported to Taiwan. Saudi fruit was excluded from the agreement as the country is still listed as a fruit-fly affected country.

Taiwan also promised to provide Saudi Arabia with aquaculture information and know-how, newly-developed rice and grain species, as well as personnel in water conservancy, veterinary medicine and environmental protection, Lin added.

The Sino-Saudi Permanent Joint Committee on Economic and Technical Cooperation, technically the annual meeting on economic and technical cooperation between Taiwan and Saudi Arabia, was initiated in 1976 when the two countries still maintained formal diplomatic ties.

Under agreements forged in the annual meetings, Saudi Arabia granted loans to Taiwan to construct the Chungsha Bridge in the middle of the Sun Yat-sen Freeway. The ROC, in return, sent medical missions, agricultural technician missions, fishery technician missions, electricity missions, printing and publication missions, and other professional groups to Saudi Arabia to help develop the Middle East nation in various fields.
The annual meeting and some bilateral cooperation programs were suspended after the two countries severed formal relations in 1990.
The meetings were resumed three years later to meet demand. But since 1993, vice ministers rather than ministers from both countries have been authorized to preside over the annual meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: 186 CHARGED IN LARGE-SCALE PROSTITUTE OPERATION

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutor's Office on Monday filed charges against 186 people in connection with a large-scale prostitution ring.
Charges included violation of sex regulations as well as those for organized crime.
Prosecutor Liu Cheng-wu, who is in charge of the investigation, said this was the largest prostitution ring found in Taiwan in recent years.

In the next two months, Liu aims to bust the operation which has lured women from Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Macau, mainland China, Singapore, and the Philippines to Taiwan and forced them into prostitution.
He added that he wants to end Taiwan's reputation as a land of prostitution and deter women from regions hard hit by the Asian crisis from coming to Taiwan to work as prostitutes.

Chen Chun-hung and Liu Chiu-hsieh, the two prime suspects in the case, reportedly run ads in Southeast Asia, mainly Thailand, to entice women to come to work in Taiwan. Once these women arrive in the island, Chen and Liu allegedly seize their passports and control their movements to force them into prostitution.
The so-called "Paiho" ring has worked with international gang leaders, known as snake heads, to smuggle women into Taiwan and have them to work in 62 local inns and hotels, the prosecutor said.
Those charged included 23 women from Thailand, two from Malaysia, four from Hong Kong, three from Macau, and eight from the mainland.
The Prosecutor's Office is now tracing prostitutes from Singapore, the Philippines and Russia in connection to the ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE HAKKAS HOLD WORLD CONVENTION IN TAIPEI (1)

TEXT.P: Some 1,500 representatives of the Hakkas from Taiwan and 30 other countries in the world converged on Taipei this week to attend the 14th Convention of World Hakkas with a purpose to renew their traditional bonds.

The Hakkas are Chinese whose ancestors lived in "Chung Yuan," or China proper, comprising Hubei, Henan, Shaanxi, Shanxi, and some parts of other provinces in central and northern China. They have gradually moved to southern China and emigrated to Southeast Asia and other parts of the world during national upheavals since the fourth century.

It was estimated in 1971 by the Chung Cheng Association of Hong Kong that there were 45 million Hakkas in the world at that time. The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) in Taipei estimated in 1992 that there were 34 million overseas Chinese at that time, and that one third of them were Hakkas.

President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, and other government leaders attended the convention earlier this week to thank the Hakkas from all over the world for their support to the Republic of China, and to brief them on government policies and the current situations in Taiwan.

British preacher George Campbell said in his book, "Origin and Migration of the Hakkas," that "The Hakkas are really the most outstanding and powerful people among the Chinese nation. Their origins, migrations and various stories have indeed cultivated a family-loving psychology and a spirit of fighting against a common enemy." "The contribution of the Hakkas to the endeavor and progress of the Chinese nation will be greater and more assertive in the future," he added.

Ellsworth Huntington, an American professor of anthropology at Harvard University, also said in his book titled "The Character of Races" that "with regards to the status of the Hakkas, the first thing we notice is their dialect." "What they use is really the Mandarin language and is different from the dialects of the non-Hakkas around them, but is similar to the language presently used in Henan in Central China. From this fact, we can tell that the Hakkas originated in North China." The Hakka dialect is one of the five major dialects of China. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: THE HAKKAS HOLD WORLD CONVENTION IN TAIPEI (2)

TEXT.P: The ancestors of the Hakkas are believed to be wealthy and aristocratic people living in Chung Yuan before the early fourth century. They moved south in five major waves when China was in upheavals caused by alien invasions from the north beginning in 317 AD, 880 AD, 1127, and 1645, and by the Taiping Rebellion beginning in 1867.

As a result, they have settled down mostly in Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Jiangxi, Hunan, and Sichuan provinces in the southern part of mainland China, and also in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macao, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, Borneo, Vietnam, and several countries in Europe, America, Africa, and Australia. It is estimated that the Hakkas account for one third of the Chinese living in Hong Kong, 20 percent of the overseas Chinese in Thailand, and 16 percent in Vietnam. There are approximately 4 million Hakkas in Taiwan, about 20 percent of the population on the island.

It was estimated in 1992 by the OCAC that 88 percent of all overseas Chinese lived in Indonesia, Thailand, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Singapore, and that one third of them were Hakkas. The OCAC defines overseas Chinese as all people of Chinese descent living overseas.

The Hakkas are noted for their persistent adherence to traditional Chinese customs and values, such as patriotism, loyalty, hard working, endurance of hardship, love of freedom, and resistance to alien aggression and influence. In addition, they look upon themselves as people of high social status. This is why they do not assimilate very well into the local community and are called "guest people" wherever they live. "Hakka" means "guest families" in Chinese.

The Hakkas also attach great importance to education and family love. Because of all these virtues, many Hakkas have become effluent and reached prominence in their fields. Some of them have become successful in the political field, such as Lee Kuan Yew in Singapore, Ne Win in Burma, Arthur Chong in Guyana, Ong Yup-lin in Malaysia, and Gee Mei-lin in Mauritius. Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China; Hung Hsiu-chuan, leader of the Taiping Rebellion against the Manchu Court, and some other heroic leaders in Chinese history were Hakkas.

In order to renew the bonds among the Hakkas scattered in various parts of the world, the First Convention of World Hakkas was held in Hong Kong in 1971, and the World Association of the Hakkas was established in Taipei in 1974. The predecessor of this association was the Chung Cheng Association, which was set up in Hong Kong in 1921. The next Convention of World Hakkas will be held in Malaysia in 1999.

The World Association of Taiwan Hakkas was inaugurated in the American city of Dallas, Texas in 1997. The Hakkas in Taiwan have also established Hakka cultural centers and a Hakka radio station for the preservation of Hakka culture and customs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW OUTLINES TOP GOALS FOR KOO'S MAINLAND TRIP

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday outlined the ROC government's main expectations for a trend-setting visit to mainland China by its top negotiator with Beijing.

"We hope Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo's upcoming mainland visit will help push for the resumption of regular dialogue between SEF and its mainland counterpart, and foster an amiable atmosphere to facilitate the development of constructive ties across the Taiwan Strait," said the premier.
Siew made the statement while meeting with Koo and the 11 delegates who will accompany the senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui on his Oct. 14-19 visit to Shanghai and Beijing.

The premier also expressed hope that the two sides will implement a new way of thinking and approach in addressing cross-strait issues and rebuild a framework for bilateral exchanges that suits the current state of separation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"We earnestly hope that Koo's mainland trip will help usher in a new 'Chinese help Chinese' stage in cross-strait relations," Siew said.

He further pointed out that a major breakthrough in cross-strait ties lies in Beijing's willingness to face the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now separately ruled by two equal political entities.
If mainland authorities can respect this aspect of reality and take concrete actions to end hostility, Siew said he believes cross-strait relations will soon make great headway.
The premier went on to say that all-out modernization on both sides of the strait will be the most effective way to resolve the fundamental bilateral disputes.

"We recognize mainland China's economic reforms and open-door policy. In the meantime, we hope mainland China will gradually expand democratic experiments from the grassroots level upward to the central government hierarchy," Siew said, adding that Taiwan is willing to promote grassroots cross-strait democratic exchanges and share its experiences in the democratization process with the mainland.
Noting that a host of problems still exist between the two sides, Siew said he is convinced that many of those issues can be resolved with sincerity, patience and mutual trust.
Siew further said Taiwan is showing its "goodwill and sincerity" by sending its top envoy to the mainland to forge rapprochement.

"Koo brings our goodwill and wishes for mutually beneficial cross-strait relations, and our friendship and concerns for mainland people," the premier noted, adding that Koo's forthcoming meetings in Shanghai with his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will mark the beginning of a new phase in cross-strait ties.

For his part, Koo said he feels honored to be authorized by the government to embark on an ice-breaking mainland visit and talk with his mainland hosts to push for the resumption of institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue, and nurture an atmosphere conducive to positive cross-strait interaction. "I feel the mission is a great responsibility," he added.

Koo, a business tycoon and experienced ambassador-at-large, said he will do his utmost to clearly detail and explain Taiwan stances on cross-strait relations and on various issues raised by his mainland hosts.

Earlier in the day, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh presented a letter of authorization to Koo, entrusting him to embark on the Shanghai-Beijing visit aimed at improving cross-strait relations. The Cabinet-level MAC charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China and oversees SEF operations.
Koo will first visit Shanghai, where he will meet Wang Daohan, his mainland counterpart, for wide-ranging talks.

The Shanghai meeting will be the first between the two elder statesmen since 1993 talks in Singapore that marked the first formal contact between the sides since they split politically amid civil war in 1949.

Based on the agreement they reached, the two sides held talks on practical issues such as recognition of legal documents, until mainland China backed out in June 1995 in anger over Taiwan's efforts to raise its international profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC PORK MARKET NOT AFFECTED BY IMPORTED PORK: COA

TEXT.P: The recent slip in domestic pork prices was due to market fluctuation and not the introduction of imported US pork to Taiwan, the Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan said on Monday.
Taipei agreed to open its markets to US pork and pork offal according to a quota system beginning July 1998 as a part of its bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

However, pork consumption in Taiwan has not been affected by the availability of US pork, COA officials said. Authorities were instead taken by surprise when pork prices did not drop but instead rose steadily. Pork prices soared as high as NT$7,000 per 100 kilograms in September.

COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei, who expressed initial concern that Taipei's participation in the WTO would exert a terrible blow to Taiwan's pig farming industry, requested the COA's Animal Industry Department (AID) to investigate why pork prices rose.
AID Director Chen Bao-ji said the hike in pork prices was due to a seasonal factor and pork prices normally fall after the Mid-Autumn Moon Festival, which took place recently.
AID officials also pointed out that people in Taiwan are not used to US pork. They said US pork gave off an unusual smell which is attributed to the different methods in raising hogs.
US hogs are not washed as they are in Taiwan, AID officials said, adding that male hogs in Taiwan are castrated when they are 14 days old so no male hormones affect the quality of the meat.
Frozen pork imported from the US is competitive only in terms of price, the COA commented, adding that Taiwan consumers have not switched their preference for cheaper pork at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN, FUTURES UP ON TAIPEI MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 23.72 points to close at 6,920.45.
Encouraged by the appreciation of the Japanese yen, the bourse opened up 80 points to the psychological level of 7,000 but later weakened and moved down near the closing bell.
With the international financial situation still full of uncertainties and a prevailing wait-and-see sentiment, Monday's market turnover amounted to only NT$77.97 billion.
A total of 155 stocks gained ground, 252 registered losses and 81 remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were higher.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 35 points to close at 6,935, with 1,613 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for November increased 37 points to finish at 6,872, while December futures declined nine points to 6,831, and March futures rose 35 points, closing at 6,850.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 271, 24, and 12, respectively. No transactions were registered for June futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ PROBING ALLEGED MAINLAND CHINA CAPITAL IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo said on Monday that law enforcement authorities are investigating allegations that mainland Chinese capital has flowed into Taiwan to support several candidates' electoral bids.
The grand justice-turned-minister made the statement in response to an interpellation by an opposition lawmaker during a Legislative Yuan Judiciary Committee meeting.

During the session, Legislator Tsai Huang-lang of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said mainland China is reportedly using its capital to support several candidates in Taiwan's critical year-end elections.

"Beijing is doing so in an attempt to foster influence in Taiwan's legislature," Tsai claimed, adding that mainland capital is being brought into Taiwan either by Taiwan businesspeople or by brokers who often travel across the Taiwan Strait.

Tsai said he suspects that three candidates for the year-end Legislative Yuan elections in central Taiwan constituencies may be using capital provided by mainland authorities or Beijing-affiliated business groups to finance their campaign activities. "Two of the candidates may be businesspeople with interests in China," he noted.

Tsai admitted that he still does not have enough evidence to substantiate his suspicions. "Nevertheless, the data already in my hands is enough to prove that my suspicions are not totally unfounded," he added.
Tsai then presented all his data to Cheng, and asked the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) to investigate the financial sources of the three candidates under suspicion.
In response, Cheng said allegations about possible involvement of mainland capital in the year-end elections have been rife in local society in recent months.

"I have heard of that. As law enforcement authorities are already investigating such reports, I can't divulge any details at the moment," Cheng said, adding that the MOJ will do its utmost to prevent mainland involvement in the upcoming elections.
Meanwhile, Cheng said he has received numerous phone calls from unidentified persons threatening to take action against him since he assumed his current post on July 15.
Cheng said he thinks the intimidating phone calls may come from members of criminal rings, as he has launched several crackdowns on organized crime and vote-buying in the past few months.

The soft-spoken minister further reaffirmed his determination to eradicate involvement of violence, money and criminal rings in the Dec. 5 elections for the Legislative Yuan and for the mayors and city councils of Taiwan's two special municipalities, Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Cheng went on to say that law enforcement authorities will actively investigate vote-buying charges as long as they can acquire clear information regarding "who, what, when, where, and how."

Noting that the upcoming legislative elections will be the first after the suspension of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly elections, Cheng said competition for a seat in the legislature is very fierce and that the electoral outcome is crucial to Taiwan's future development.

Against this background, Cheng said the MOJ will spare no effort to stem involvement of violence, money and gangsters to ensure that only capable candidates with a clean image and reputation will be able to enter the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA VOWS STRONG ACTION AGAINST KIDNAPPERS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada, who is currently on a visit to Singapore, pledged on Monday to take the steps necessary to apprehend kidnappers who prey on wealthy businessmen, particularly Filipino-Chinese.

The president has ordered the Presidential Anti-Organized Crime Task Force to come down hard against criminal syndicates without jeopardizing the safety of kidnap victims, Press Secretary Rodolfo Reyes said in an interview with a Manila-based radio station.
Reyes is a part of Estrada's official delegation which is on a four-day state visit to Singapore.

Estrada has also directed a committee to keep him abreast of the situation while he is abroad and give him updates on kidnapping cases in Mindanao, National Security Adviser Alexander Aguirre said in a separate radio interview in Manila. One of those cases involves the kidnapping of a Taiwan businessman's family.

On Sunday, Filipino-Chinese groups gathered to call for government action after the recent kidnap and murder of a businessman. Wilson Ong was abducted on Aug. 26 and killed by his captors after his family failed to raise the 50 million pesos ransom demanded. The kidnappers dumped Ong's bullet-riddled body in front of his textile factory in Valenzuela on Oct. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EFFORTS TO OBTAIN WHO MEMBERSHIP UNCEASING

TEXT.P: The director-general of Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) said on Monday that he cannot foresee when the ROC will enter the World Health Organization (WHO), but stressed that the department will not cease in its attempts to obtain membership.
Chan Chi-shean made the remarks while answering questions in the legislature on Taiwan's efforts to rejoin the WHO.
The ROC was originally a WHO founding member, but lost its seat in the international organization in 1972 after losing its United Nations membership in 1971.
On Saturday, the US House of Representatives unanimously approved a resolution that expresses the parliamentary body's support to the ROC in its efforts to join the WHO.
"Does the DOH have a timetable for joining the WHO?" asked Huang Tsiou-chu, a legislator from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, after being made aware of the US support.
Chan answered that his department cannot say when the country will be able to obtain WHO membership, but will never stop its promotional work in this regard.

In conjunction with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the DOH over the past several years has made efforts to persuade the ROC's foreign allies to voice their support for Taiwan's WHO membership at WHO meetings.
These efforts will never cease, and nor will DOH efforts to promote Taiwan's cooperation and exchanges on health care with foreign countries, Chan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER DENIES REPORT ABOUT NUCLEAR WASTE DISPOSAL

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) denied a newspaper report on Monday that it will commission mainland China to dispose of its nuclear waste.
Taipower said unless mainland China changes its "one China" policy toward handling Taiwan's nuclear waste, Taipower is unlikely to strike any deal with the mainland.

A Taipower executive recalled that the company once commissioned its subsidiary, the Electricity Research and Experiment Center, five years ago to explore the feasibility of entrusting a suitable mainland agency to treat its radioactive waste.

"Negotiations between the two sides originally proceeded smoothly. But later, the situation changed due to Beijing's insistence that the deal be struck under its so called 'one China' policy. That means Taipower should recognize that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China," the executive said.
As a state-owned enterprise, the executive said, Taipower must abide by the Republic of China's law and policy. "Therefore, we stopped our talks with the mainland," he stressed.

As Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Chairman C. F. Koo of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, will leave Taipei on Wednesday for an ice-breaking visit to the mainland, local media have again shown interest in the possibility of commissioning mainland China to handle Taipower's nuclear waste.
The Taipower executive, however, insisted that the nuclear waste disposal issue is not on Koo's agenda for his meetings with his mainland hosts.
"There are so many far more pressing cross-strait issues to be discussed by Koo and his mainland hosts. The nuclear waste issue will not become a topic during Koo's mainland trip," he asserted.

The executive further said Taipower is still seeking possible destinations at home and abroad for permanent disposal of its nuclear waste, including North Korea, Russia, the Marshall Islands, and Wuchiu, a small islet of the Taiwan-held Kinmen Islands, which lie closer to the southeastern mainland coast that to Taiwan.

Taipower once signed a contract with North Korea to ship 20,000 barrels of low-grade nuclear waste to that country for permanent disposal. The planned shipment, however, has been stalled because of some technical problems and strong opposition from South Korea and several other countries on environmental protection grounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC URGED TO CLEAN UP CORRUPTION IN CHINESE RURAL AREAS

TEXT.P: The "Corruptive Behavior Watch," a dissident organization, Monday urged the Communist Party of China (CPC) to clean up corruption in the rural area in order to prevent the relations between farmer and government from getting worse.

The dissident organization issued an open letter to the Presidium of the Third Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee of the CPC, which opened in Beijing Monday, through the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China.

The open letter said that corruption is rampant in the rural area, and that the central government should clean up such corruption, reduce tax and other burdens on farmers, and promote democracy in the rural area. Agricultural and rural problems are high on the agenda of the three-day CPC Central Committee plenum, according to recent news reports from the mainland.

The Corruptive Behavior Watch was organized by nine dissidents from seven provinces. They filed an application with the Ministry of Civil Affairs in Beijing on Sept. 23 for registering the dissident organization, but the ministry has not given any reply, An Jun, one of the organizers, said.
The organization has nearly 100 watchers and a number of watch stations in 14 provinces, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESPOND POSITIVELY TO TAIPEI'S BID TO WHO

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Medical Professional Alliance (TMPA) on Monday urged mainland China to respond positively to the ROC's bid to enter the World Health Organization (WHO) in the coming cross-strait talks.
The TMPA has sent representatives to Geneva to lobby for Taiwan's entry to the United Nations' health body for the past two years.

TMPA President Teng Chao-fan said the outbreak of the foot-and-mouth disease and enterovirus in Taiwan showed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could complement each other in pushing for disease prevention and improved public health conditions.
He added that Beijing should consider lending its support for Taiwan's WHO bid so as to pave the way for the establishment of a communicable disease control mechanism for the greater China area.
The TMPA is now planning to set up a Taiwan international health foundation and will work with the government to assist with international health efforts, Teng said.
He said the idea has gained support from several local major hospitals which have pledged to nurture local talent in public health and provide medical services.
Meanwhile, Department of Health (DOH) Director General Chan Chi-shean said on Monday he will continue with efforts to try to pry open the door to the WHO next year.
Chan made the remarks after the US House of Representative passed a resolution over the weekend supporting Taiwan's participation in the WHO.
Although the passage of the resolution has no binding power on the US administrative branch, Chan said it demonstrates the ROC's efforts to return to the WHO have borne fruit.
In addition to the WHO, the DOH is also applying to join the Pharmaceutical Inspection Corporation/Scheme (PIC/S) to try to boost the export of Taiwan pharmaceuticals.
Hu You-pu, director of DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs, said he believes Taiwan's chances of gaining entry to the Geneva-based organization is high.

The biological and pharmaceutical industries are expected to be the star performers in the next century, Chan said. With this view, local pharmaceutical companies should pool their sources, streamline marketing efforts, and take part in international experiments to boost the competitiveness of Taiwan's pharmaceutical industry, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DOES NOT INTEND TO USE US CONGRESS INFLUENCE TO AID WTO ACCESSION

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang has promised a US official that Taiwan has no intention of using the influence of the US Congress to aid Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
A ranking official with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) disclosed on Monday that Wang made the promise during talks with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky.

In order to avoid causing unnecessary trouble to the Clinton administration, the official said, Wang told Barshefsky that Taiwan would not take the initiative to seek congressional influence over the WTO issue.
Last Saturday, the US House of Representative passed a resolution, 418-0 to call on the Clinton administration to support Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).
This support for Taiwan to participate in the international organization is believed to have put some pressure on the Clinton administration.

It has been eight years since Taiwan first applied to rejoin the WTO. Taipei has urged the US government on numerous occasions to help expedite its accession, but seems to have been less willing to employ the influence of the US Congress.
This year, Taiwan has made some remarkable progress in its WTO efforts, concluding bilateral talks with the United States in February, with Switzerland in May, and with the EU in July.
To date, there are only three WTO members -- Canada, Hong Kong, and the EU -- with which Taiwan has yet signed formal bilateral agreements.

After finishing the bilateral negotiations, the entry process will move to multilateral talks. Taiwan expects that the next working group meeting will be held at the end of this year, and hopes that the US government will help expedite the process.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCA CHAIRMAN TO ATTEND APEC MEETING ON WOMEN'S AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: The chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) will lead a Taiwan delegation to attend the first ministerial meeting on women's affairs under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Lin Cheng-chih on Monday revealed that in addition to participating in all the discussions at the two-day meeting, which will open on Thursday in Manila, the delegation will also put forward reports on the role of women in industrial development.

At the meeting, representatives from 18 APEC members will discuss issues into the following three categories: women and industrial technology; women and small-and medium-sized enterprises; and women and the development of manpower resources.

Lin said her delegation will also conduct bilateral meetings with several other APEC member states, including Singapore, the Philippines, and New Zealand, to discuss issues on cooperation and cultural exchanges.

Before taking the position as CCA chairwoman, Lin served as the director of the ruling Kuomintang's Department of Women's Affairs for several years. This experience makes her well-qualified to lead the delegation.

The delegation includes: Lee Cher-jean, director of the Managing Information Systems Department under the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission; Liu Hsiao-yu, director of the Information Panel of the National Science Council; Y.L. Liu, director of the Manpower Planning Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development; and Lai Hsin-yien, chief of international affairs of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.
The delegation is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVIEW OF DEVELOPMENTS IN KOO-WANG CONSULTATIONS SINCE 1993

TEXT.P: The 1993 round of talks between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), resulted in several agreements which went into effect on May 29 of that year.
Following the 1993 Koo-Wang meetings in Singapore, the two sides, represented by the SEF and ARATS, held seven rounds of functional talks and three rounds of secretary-general-level talks.

These meetings focused largely on practical issues, and led to a number of agreements in areas such as the repatriation of hijackers, illegal immigrants, and fishing disputes. Dates for future talks were also settled.

Just as cross-strait relations were becoming less tense, and the ROC government was actively promoting friendly relations with the Chinese mainland, the Chinese communists released a white paper titled "The Taiwan Question and the Reunification of China" on August 31, 1993.

This move demonstrated mainland China's rigid stance toward the ROC on Taiwan, according to Chang Liang-jen, former director of the Department of Cultural Affairs at the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Chang, who is now SEF's deputy secreatry-general, noted that the various issues arising from private exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are extremely complex.

Nonetheless, he recalled, they were discussed in full during the Koo-Wang talks, and were given priority in order of magnitude and urgency. According to this priority list, the following topics were to be discussed by the end of 1993:
-- repatriation of people entering the area of the other party in violation of pertinent regulations, and related issues;
-- joint efforts to combat smuggling, hijacking, and other crimes;
-- consultations on the handling of fishing disputes at sea;
-- protection of intellectual property rights of the two sides; and
-- mutual assistance between the judicial organs of the two sides.

Both parties agreed to select a different time and place to continue discussions on economic issues, on which the two sides have widely divergent views, and to further discuss cultural and scientific exchanges. The priority issues to be discussed in future talks were thus clearly delineated.
In order to fulfill the agreements, an SEF delegation made a trip to Beijing on Aug. 28, 1993, hoping to discuss the five subjects specified above.

Due to time limitations, the SEF proposed that "mutual assistance between the judicial organs of the two sides" and "repatriation of people entering the area of the other party in violation of pertinent regulations and related issues" be discussed first. The SEF was also willing to discuss the other three priority issues agreed upon in the Koo-Wang Talks Joint Accord.

ARATS, however, proposed that either the agenda stipulated in the joint accord be "rearranged," or priority issues for 1993 should be "specifically arranged." ARATS also proposed a timetable that would have had both sides discussing 13 issues in the last four months of 1993.
Among the 13 subjects raised by ARATS were issues which fell outside the scope of the Koo-Wang Talks Joint Accord, such as the opening of Taiwan's labor market to mainland workers.

During the August talks in Beijing, the SEF delegates fully respected the opinion of their ARATS counterparts, and stated that if specific conclusions were reached by the end of that year, ARATS' new proposals could be discussed.

The ARATS delegates, however, insisted that a timetable for holding talks on economic issues had to be set, and they were willing to listen to, but refused to speak about, the two previously agreed-upon priority issues of "repatriation of illegal immigrants" and "judicial assistance." (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: REVIEW OF DEVELOPMENTS IN KOO-WANG CONSULTATIONS SINCE 1993 (II)

TEXT.P: The non-interactive nature of the discussions stripped the talks of any meaning. Both sides should have followed common practice by simply abiding by the agreements already reached, according to Chang.
Making random changes, advancing unreasonable interpretations, and changing the order of the talks as one pleases are all inappropriate behavior, he added.

ARATS' attempt to rearrange the agenda under the pretext of carrying out agreements reached during the earlier Koo-Wang talks was in stark violation of the Koo-Wang Talks Joint Accord. In addition, discussing generalities was of no help at all in solving the practical problems at hand.

Faced with these less than ideal circumstances, the SEF delegation chose to return to Taipei on Sept. 3, earlier than originally scheduled. Although the talks in Beijing failed to reach any conclusion, the SEF remained willing to continue consultations in line with the Koo-Wang Talks Joint Accord.

The other six consultations were held from Nov. 2 to 7, 1993 in Xiamen; from Dec. 18 to 24, 1993 in Taipei; from March 25 to 30, 1994 in Beijing; from July 30 to Aug. 2, 1994 in Taipei; from Nov. 23 to 27 in Nanjing; and from Jan. 22 to 27, 1995 also in Nanjing.
At a preparatory meeting held from May 27 to 28, 1995 in Taipei, it was decided that a second round of Koo-Wang talks would be held on July 20, 1995, in Beijing.

Both sides agreed that the talks would cover issues such as the implementation of accords signed during the first round of talks, Taiwan investment rights in mainland China, and a wide range of unofficial exchanges.
Unfortunately, the mainland authorities postponed indefinitely this second round of Koo-Wang talks in June 1995, and staged their notorious test-firing of missiles into the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENTARIAN URGES TAIPEI-BEIJING RAPPROCHEMENT

TEXT.P: Rapprochement with Beijing would give Taiwan more leeway in exploring ties with foreign countries, because mainland China's objections are the main cause of the island's marginalization, a visiting member of the European Parliament said on Monday.

Beijing's huge market of 1 billion people gives it an inflated status in the eyes of European states, and has prompted these states to sideline the human rights agenda in their engagements with Beijing, said Viviane Reding, a member of the European Parliament (EP) from Luxembourg, and president of the pro-Taiwan EP-Taiwan Intergroup.

Strong pressure from Beijing also explains the difficulty senior Taiwan officials have had in visiting Europe recently, said Reding, adding that a normalization of ties between Taipei and Beijing would ease mainland China's opposition to Taipei's efforts to enhance its international profile.

Although calling it an important step, Reding warned against reading too much into the forthcoming meeting of Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan, the respective chairmen of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

She said it is only natural for people with the same language and culture to get together, and added that rapprochement can occur naturally and smoothly only when mainland China parallels Taiwan in its economic and democratic development.

She said she finds it inexplicable that Taiwan has been excluded from the United Nations in spite of its dynamic economic strength and its 21 million population, "much, much bigger" than the 450,000 people of her native Luxembourg.

To remedy this mistake "stemming from past political factors," Reding said she favors Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, and the United Nations Children's Fund, as well as other UN agencies, to pave the way for the country's full integration into the international community.

Although a supporter of a European Parliament resolution earlier this year to set up a trade representative office in Taiwan, Reding refused to speculate when the words of the proposal will be translated into deeds, because it is up to the European Union Ministerial Council to decide whether to proceed with the plan.
After attending celebrations for the ROC Double Ten National Day, the head of the EP-Taiwan Intergroup which groups some 100 European Parliament members, will leave Taiwan on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT: SEF-ARATS MEETING HAS PROFOUND SIGNIFICANCE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Monday that this week's mainland China trip by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will have profound significance.
Lee said the system that has been implemented in the Republic of China on Taiwan is "not only a symbol of liberty and democracy, but also a goal mainland China should strive for."
The president made the remarks at a presidential tea party in honor of representatives of overseas Chinese communities who had come to Taipei for the ROC Double Ten National Day festivities.

Koo is leaving for Shanghai later this week to resume his talks with Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). After the talks in Shanghai, Koo will proceed to Beijing to meet with mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.
Lee stressed that the ROC is an independent sovereign country and a political entity equal to mainland China.

Only under such a basis and common consensus, he said, will the two sides be able to enter consultations to solve common problems. "Otherwise, the 1.2 billion people on the mainland may not be able to genuinely free themselves from socialism and communism."

The president lauded his visitors for their deep concern over the ROC's national development. He said his government will in turn do its utmost to help overseas Chinese in the economic, cultural, and educational fields.
Lee said that over the past decade, the ROC has made remarkable achievements in political democratization and social reform, achievements of which the people of the mainland should be aware.

The president said that the government will continue to work toward building up a civilized, modern country, and expressed the hope that overseas Chinese everywhere will continue to support the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNGARY AND DENMARK LOOKING FOR TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Representatives from Hungary and Denmark on Monday held separate trade workshops in Taipei, with the aim of attracting investment from Taiwan.
In the Hungarian workshop, Tibor Melega, leader of the East European country's bureau of trade and investment promotion, recommended his country's investment environment.
He said that Hungary is expected to join the European Union by 2002, an incentive that will facilitate Taiwan businesses wishing to gain a foothold in the European market.

Melega also pointed out that foreign investment has never stopped in Hungary. Half of the world's top 50 enterprises have investments in the country, he cited, noting that this fact proves his country enjoys a commendable investment policy and environment.
The Hungarian trade promotion delegation also included Vice Economic Minister Gyorgy Gilyan.

Meanwhile, in the Danish trade promotion workshop, Klaus Peter Lange, chairman of the Scandinavian country's Transportation Association, called on Taiwan to use Copenhagen, the capital of Denmark, instead of Holland's Amsterdam, as its major distribution center in Europe, saying that Copenhagen can help Taiwan traders save on cargo transportation costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MEETS WITH GRENADA PREMIER, EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday lauded education as the basis of a country's infrastructure, saying Taiwan's economy owes much to its investment in education.

At a banquet hosted by Siew on Monday evening in honor of visiting Grenada Premier Dr. Keith C. Mitchell and his wife, Siew said education has produced high-quality personnel resources which have helped the Republic of China transform from an agriculture state into a industrialized state.
Mitchell agreed with Siew's opinion, saying that many countries lag behind in development despite rich natural resources, because of the shortage of skilled manpower.

He said he was impressed by the hospitality displayed by the people of Taiwan, and by the development Taiwan has made. He also thanked the Republic of China for the aid it has extended to his Caribbean country.
Mitchell arrived here on Friday to attend the ROC Double Ten National Day celebrations.

Earlier in the day, Siew received four German members of the European Parliament -- Dr. Guenter Rinsche, Brigitte Langenhagen, Dr. Peter Michael Mombaur, and Anne-Karin Glase -- with whom he exchanged views on trade, education, and women's participation in politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui spells out meanings of the upcoming Koo-Wang meetings.
The China Times: Premier Vincent Siew said Taiwan is willing to promote cross-strait grassroots democratic exchanges.
The United Daily News: The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) proposed additional round of Koo-Wang talks.
The Liberty Times: Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, C. F. Koo, will leave for mainland China on Wednesday; democracy will be Koo's trump card.
The Independence Morning Post: President Lee Teng-hui touted Taiwan's achievements in democratization.
The Commons Daily: President Lee Teng-hui said Taiwan and mainland China are equal political entities.
The China Post: Yugoslavia condemns NATO.
The China News: Cross-strait summit marks the beginning of a new era: Siew.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SETS LOW-KEY LINE FOR KOO-WANG TALKS

TEXT.P: Beijing has determined that the talks between the top negotiators on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be set amid a "ceremonial reception" and "low key media reports," a Hong Kong paper reported on Tuesday.

The Ming Po daily cited sources as saying mainland authorities laid down this particular framework because they do not believe the Koo-Wang meeting will produce any substantive breakthrough in bilateral ties.

The report came as Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), is set to begin a six-day mainland visit on Wednesday. Koo is scheduled to meet with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Shanghai on Sunday for the first time in more than five years.

Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin will receive Koo in Beijing in a ceremonial reception. Jiang will not discuss any concrete issues with Koo, and mainland media will make brief reports about their meeting, the paper reported.

A meeting was held on Monday in Shanghai in which scores of municipal and Communist Party officials in charge of Taiwan affairs and state security decided on the type of reception and reaction to Koo's visit, according to Ming Po.
An ARATS official who spoke to the paper on condition of anonymity, said the coming Koo-Wang meeting will not resolve practical matters but should have a positive impact on cross-strait dealings.

The official said the root problem in bilateral relations is the question of jurisdiction. Mainland China has realized that political differences are the major hurdle in two-way exchanges, so it favors starting political negotiations to address Taiwan people's aspiration for peace and safety.
But as the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not yet begun procedural talks for political negotiations, Koo's meeting has been defined as only "a visit and tour," the ARATS official said.
