DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S FIRST DIAMOND MINE BEGINS PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: Canada's first diamond mine will begin production on Wednesday in the Northwest Territories.

The Ekati mine lies 300 kilometers northeast of capital city Yellowknife. It has taken developers two years, C$800 million ( US$520 million) and 800 workers to bring the mine into production after geologists discovered gems in the area seven years ago.
The mine will provide about 830 permanent jobs over its projected 22-year life. About 70 percent will be filled by northerners, and 30 percent by aborigines.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PM TO ATTEND APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard is set to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Kuala Lumpur next month despite possible boycotts by the Philippines and Indonesia.
Howard believes the APEC summit is critically important to rebuilding the stricken economies of East Asia and the task could be undermined if some of APEC leaders do not attend.

Indonesian President B.J. Habibie and Philippine President Joseph Estrada have both indicated they may not attend the meeting over Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's treatment of former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Abrahim.
Anwar was fired from his post and arrested last month on charges of treason and sex offenses. This is seen by some leaders as an effort by Mahathir to undermine his rival.
Habibie has canceled a scheduled visit to Malaysia later this month and Foreign Minister Ali Alatas has said Indonesia has yet to make a decision on whether it would attend the APEC meeting.
Howard is expected to urge leaders at the meeting to reaffirm their support for open trade and investment in the region.
Malaysia and Indonesia have imposed some restrictions on foreign investments in reaction to the Asian financial crisis while Howard believes efforts to maintain a free trade regime are important.

Officials close to the prime minister said Howard is optimistic about the prospects of economic recovery in East Asia if countries continue their commitment to a free trade aside from reforming their financial systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PLAN TO TAX FOREIGN TOURISTS CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: Tourism industry chiefs have strongly criticized the Australian government's attempt to target foreign tourists with a 10 percent goods and services tax or value-added tax when Sydney hosts the 2000 Olympic Games.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello on Sunday said the government had set a target to introduce the GST by July 1, 2000 so it could cash in on the influx of foreign tourists.
However, the Australian Democrats Party and other parties have opposed the government plan and vowed to block the legislation in the Senate.
Tourism leaders warned the government that the Australian tourism industry will side with the Australian Democrats senators, who want tourist packages bought overseas to be exempt from the GST.

Don Larkin, acting head of the Tourism Council Australia, on Monday accused Costello of treating foreign tourists as a "milch cow" and "making a mockery" of the Howard government's promise for the new tax system.

"Taxing tourists is an easy short-term money grab for the government," he said. "However, in the long-term it will threaten the viability of one of Australia's fastest growing industries and its second-largest exporter."
Australia expects to attract more than six million tourists by the year 2000 when the Olympic Games take place in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S ECONOMIC GROWTH STUNTED BY ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Asian economic crisis is expected to drag down Australia's gross domestic product growth below the 2.75 percent target in fiscal 1998-99 and boost the country's unemployment rate, forecasters said.
The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said the GDP growth would fall to 2 percent, well below the official target made earlier this year.

ABARE's worst case scenario was included in a report on energy demand given to the energy ministers of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum at the weekend, according to the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday.

The new forecast of 2 percent growth is based on the assumption that the economic turmoil in Asia will continue for a longer period than previously expected with more severe ramifications for the 21 APEC countries.

Australia's unemployment rate is expected to rise sharply and the budget will slide back into a deficit over the next 18 months as the country will be swept up in the unfolding global crisis, according to the Syntec Economic Services, a leading forecasting consultant in Australia.

In its five-year forecast, Syntec predicted that the jobless rate would rise to 8.7 percent by June 1999 before rising further to 9 percent by the middle of 2000. The Howard administration's predicted that unemployment would fall to only 8 percent by June next year.
The current jobless rate is 8.2 percent with about 761,000 people out of work.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC OIL PRICES TO BE LOWERED BY 2.99% FROM WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced yet another oil price cut on Tuesday to reflect its declining production costs.
Starting on Wednesday, retail prices for a variety of petroleum products will be lowered by an average of 2.99 percent, a CPC spokesman said.
This is the fifth time since July that the state monopoly has offered an across-the-board price cut for its products amid a downward spiral in international crude oil prices.
Altogether, the CPC has slashed its product prices by a total of 8.68 percent since July.

As the domestic oil market will be deregulated next year, some market analysts and officials with the Fair Trade Commission said CPC's repeated price cuts are partly aimed at discouraging private enterprises from entering the local market.
The CPC, however, refuted such speculation, saying that the allegation is biased and unfair.

"We have lowered prices partly to reflect slumping oil refining costs and partly to upgrade our competitiveness in preparation for the impending market liberalization," a CPC spokesman said, adding that the company's efforts to sharpen its competitive edge should not be interpreted as a move to prevent prospective competitors from entering the market.
Formosa Plastics Group, one of Taiwan's leading private conglomerates, is poised to market its oil products early next year.

After Wednesday's adjustment, the retail price for premium gasoline will fall marginally to NT$17 (US$0.52) per liter from the current NT$17.4, while fuel oil prices will be lowered by NT$168 per kiloliter to NT$4,002.
The price for research octane number (RON) 95-unleaded gasoline will decline to NT$16.8 per liter from NT$17.2 and the price for RON-92 unleaded gasoline will be cut to NT$15.8 from NT$16.2.
The price for high-grade diesel will drop to NT$12.1 per liter from NT$12.4, while normal-grade diesel will slide from NT$11.2 to NT$10.9.

Meanwhile, the wholesale price for household-use liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) will edge down to NT$9.93 per kilogram from NT$10.33, and the retail price for vehicle-use LPG will dip to NT$10.1 from NT$10.3.
The CPC spokesman said the new prices were calculated based on two criteria -- crude oil prices at NT$13 per barrel and a currency exchange rate of NT$32.89 against the US dollar.

The spokesman said although international crude oil prices rebounded in September, the appreciation of the NT dollar against the greenback has helped offset the increase in the CPC's crude oil import costs.

The CPC has conducted weekly reviews of domestic petroleum prices since March in an attempt to have its prices fluctuate in tandem with international crude oil prices and the local currency's exchange rate against the greenback.

The company first offered a 1.57 percent cut in prices for its products on July 1, and again trimmed its prices by an average of 1.28 percent on July 22. It announced a further 1.53 percent cut on Aug. 12, and another 1.31 percent reduction on Aug. 26.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) hailed the CPC's price cuts, saying the move will help slow the growth of domestic consumer prices.

DGBAS officials said there is still room for domestic oil price reductions as rises in international crude oil prices in the coming winter season is expected to remain limited and the NT dollar may continue appreciating against the greenback.
The officials predicted that the domestic inflation rate will fall below 1.5 percent this year.

Despite the oil price reduction, Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), also a state monopoly, said it will not follow suit in cutting its electricity prices because oil prices account for a limited portion of its power generation costs.
Nevertheless, Taipower said it will adjust its pricing structure in the near future to offer different prices at different time slots and charge higher power rates for big electricity users.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slumped NT$0.239 against the greenback in Taipei on Tuesday, closing at 32.119.
The local currency opened at 32.99, and was trade between 32.951 and 33.152.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$391.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DECLINE ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 11.23 points to close at 6,909.22.

Encouraged by a surge by the New York Stock Exchange, the bourse opened at 6,997.91 points, 77.46 higher than on Monday's close, and peaked at 7,023.18. From there, however, the bourse entered a slide that lasted until the closing bell.
A total of 2.88 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.52 billion, an increase from the previous trading session, in which the turnover totaled NT$77.97 billion.
Three of the eight major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks rising the most at 0.7 percent, followed by electrical shares and construction stocks both at 0.4 percent.

Five categories registered losses, with plastics and chemical shares and pulp and paper issues both moving down the most at 2.6 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.9 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were lower as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October dropped 83 points to close at 6,852, with 2,387 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 62 points to finish at 6,810, while December futures declined 31 points to 6,800, March futures decreased 90 points to 6,760 and June futures rose 15 points, closing at 6,736.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 511, 40, nine and one, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN EXPECTS KOO TO CONVEY ROC'S GOODWILL TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: ROC Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh said on Tuesday that he hopes Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), will convey the ROC's goodwill to the mainland during his visit there Oct. 14 to 19.
Koo will leave for Shanghai on Wednesday to resume talks with Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), that were begun in 1993 in Singapore.
After the Shanghai talks, Koo will proceed to Beijing to meet with President Jiang Zemin and other Beijing officials.

Chang, who met with the media to indicate the government's expectations from the talks, said he believes the talks will attain the goals laid down by ROC Premier Vincent Siew when he received Koo and members of his mainland-bound delegation on Monday: the promotion of exchanges between SEF and ARATS, the resumption of bilateral systematic negotiations, the cultivation of a friendly atmosphere and the development of constructive relations.
Chang also expressed his hope that Beijing will resume negotiations on issues related to the interests of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In addition to participating in formal talks, Koo will engage in some sightseeing and visit with a variety of mainland officials and representatives during his six-day trip. Chang said the visit will afford Koo a good opportunity to convey the ROC government's position, as well as the thoughts of the people of Taiwan, to the mainland.

The MAC chief said the ROC has existed for 87 years, and a division of rule between the two sides of the strait is not only a historical truth but also a political fact. Because of this national division, he said, the Republic of China has been striving for reunification with the mainland.

Chang pointed out that the ROC government's basic national policy is to pursue liberty, democracy, the equality of wealth and eventual reunification based on rationality, peacefulness and equality of status.
He said that Beijing should respect the present division of rule and search for ways to improve cross-strait relations.
He noted that any attempt by Beijing to block the ROC's diplomatic activities, to attempt military intimidation or to isolate Taiwan politically would only hurt bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON CROSS-STRAIT JURISPRUDENCE EXCHANGE OPENS

TEXT.P: A seminar on cross-strait jurisprudence exchange, co-sponsored by Soochow University and the Law Association of China, opened Tuesday at the downtown campus of Soochow University.

Representatives of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, including Lu Ren-fa, ROC state public prosecutor general under the Supreme Court, and Sun Wanzhong, executive vice president of the mainland's Law Society, expressed their hopes that the seminar would be beneficial to furthering the understanding of and exchanges by both sides of the strait.

Lu, a Soochow University graduate, pointed out at the seminar that since the opening up between the two sides, both civil contacts and commercial engagements have increased greatly. In the face of this new trend and environment, remarked Lu, it is necessary for academic sectors of both sides to research and resolve differences and misunderstandings across the strait.

On the other hand, Sun -- who served director of the Bureau of Legislative Affairs under mainland China's State Council for many years -- said that economic development, social stability and cultural prosperity all hinge on the protection of the rule of law, which is based on the study and research of scholars.

Sun further said that although there were differences between the two sides, the fact that people on both sides of the strait share the same cultural and historical traditions, as well as a common language, means the normal development of bilateral relations can be expected as long as a cross-strait engagement and exchanges continue.
Wu Hsin-hsing, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), attended the meeting on behalf of SEF Vice Chairperson and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow.
Wu noted that the current separation between Taiwan and mainland China can be seen as going back 103 years to 1895, when Taiwan was ceded to Japan under the terms of the Treaty of Shimonoseki.

Differences in concepts, ideas, laws and regulations, as well as in administrative systems, between the two sides is inevitable, Wu added. The SEF deputy secretary-general expressed his hope that the two-day seminar will serve as an opportunity for both sides to learn about the differences between and similarities of their systems of jurisprudence.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING REPATRIATES 4 TAIWAN FUGITIVES ON EVE OF KOO'S VISIT

TEXT.P: Mainland China repatriated four Taiwan fugitives via the Republic of China's defense outpost of Matsu Islands on Tuesday.
Local observers said it was a gesture of goodwill from Beijing on the eve of new talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Administration said the repatriation was conducted in accordance with the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Red Cross Society on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1990.
A total of 47 Taiwan outlaws have been repatriated from mainland China since the agreement was signed, said a CIB official.

Under the escort of mainland Chinese Red Cross Society officials, the four Taiwan fugitives were sent to Matsu, which lies closer to the southeastern mainland coast than to Taiwan, Tuesday morning. The fugitives were later escorted back to Taiwan by CIB agents.

"We appreciate mainland China's cooperation in helping crack down on crime," the CIB official said, adding that the CIB hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can cooperate even more closer in fighting crime.

The repatriation came a day before the departure of Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, C. F. Koo, for a six-day visit to mainland China. During his stay in Shanghai and Beijing, Koo will meet with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, and mainland President Jiang Zemin. Their meetings will be the first high-level cross-strait encounters in more than three years.

According to CIB tallies, 192 Taiwan outlaws, including some convicted criminals, are still hiding in mainland China. Among them are movie and cable television operator Yang Teng-kuei; Bamboo Union Gang leaders "White Wolf" Chang An-lo and Huang Hai-ju; and Huang Shang-feng who allegedly seriously injured prosecutor Chang Chin-tu a few years ago.

The CIB official said Taiwan outlaws who have managed to flee to the mainland mostly hide in Donguan, Guangzhou, Shenzhen in Guangdong Province; Xiamen and Fuzhou in Fujian Province; Shanghai; and Hainan.

The official said many of those fugitives are still directing their henchmen in Taiwan to conduct illegal business operations or criminal activities, and some of them have collaborated with mainland criminal rings to conduct cross-strait drug trafficking or human and firearms smuggling.

"We hope mainland authorities will pay attention to these developments and coordinate with Taiwan to establish a joint crime-fighting framework to stem cross-strait criminal activities," the official said.

The four fugitives repatriated on Tuesday were identified as Wang Pao-lien, 42, who had been sentenced to 14 years in prison on charges of drug trafficking before she fled the island; Chen Chung-cheng, 36, who has been wanted for alleged involvement in several robbery cases; Shen Ching-hsiang, 33, who had been sentenced to receive reformatory education in accordance with an anti-organized crime law before he fled to the mainland; and Yen Lien-hsing, 26, who has been wanted for alleged involvement in an armed robbery.

DOC.HEADLINE: RADIO MOSCOW PRAISES TAIWAN FOR DEMOCRATIZATION

TEXT.P: Radio Moscow said over the weekend in its Mandarin commentary, titled "The Process of Democratization in Taiwan," that Taiwan has made remarkable achievement in democratization since it lifted martial law in 1987.

The commentary, which was made on the occasion of the national day of the Republic of China on Oct. 10, said the ideas of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the republic, have always been remembered by his countrymen. The ideas have become "the basis of the democratic government on Taiwan," it added.

The lifting of martial law and abolition of the "Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion" in 1987 marked the beginning of informal contacts between Taiwan and mainland China, the commentary said.

In the next year, Taiwan lifted the ban on the registration of new mass media and on political demonstrations. Two years later, Taiwan lifted the ban on the formation of new political parties. Political pluralism has been established in Taiwan as a result, it added.

Taiwan has revised the Constitution in several steps in the past few years to facilitate political reforms, it said, adding that constitutional amendments have enabled the direct election of the President of the country. Lee Teng-hui became the first popularly-elected president in Chinese history in March, 1993, the commentary said.

"Of course, this doesn't mean every problem of Taiwan is resolved... Reform is continuing," it said, adding that "despite difficulties and obstacles, Taiwan is able to conduct political affairs within the scope of democracy, and this is what Taiwan people can be proud of."

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA LEADER TO ATTEND WORLD TRADE CENTERS ASSOCIATION MEETING

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), Lin Cheng-kuo, left for Spain on Tuesday to attend the 29th annual meeting of the World Trade Centers Association (WTCA), slated for Friday.

The WTCA, founded in 1968 in the US city of New Orleans, is the only global, non-profit and non-political organization aimed at enabling its members to promote trade and expand economic ties. It has recruited a total of 326 members from 98 countries and areas.
CETRA sponsored the WTCA's 25th annual meeting in 1994.
The current meeting marks the first time Lin has participated in the five-day WTCA meeting in his capacity as CETRA's chairman.
Lin has formerly served as ROC finance minister.
Lin will head to Chile to attend an annual conference of the Trade Promotion Organization, at which he will also deliver a speech, after his visit to Spain.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAILS BRITISH ENVOY'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said on Tuesday they are pleased to learn that the British representative in Taiwan has been promoted as the new British ambassador to the Philippines.

The British Foreign and Commonwealth Office announced on Monday that Alan Collins, director-general of the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei, will become the British ambassador to the Philippines starting in December.
Collins, a senior career diplomat, assumed his Taipei post in 1995.
MOFA officials said substantive relations between the Republic of China and Britain have improved greatly under Collins' efforts.
Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, substantive ROC-British relations have proceeded smoothly in an amiable, pleasant atmosphere.
"We appreciate Collins' efforts in promoting bilateral exchanges and cooperation over the past few years," said a MOFA official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The official further said Collins' promotion indicates that the British government attaches great importance to his achievements in promoting Taiwan-British relations.
"It also indicates that in the minds of the Britons, Taiwan is as important as other Asian countries," the official said.

With Taiwan's growing economic strength and its successful democratization, the official said, major European countries have attached ever increasing importance to their ties with Taiwan and have sent senior diplomats to serve as their de facto ambassadors to Taiwan.

For instance, incumbent director of the French Institute in Taipei (FIT), Gerard Roland Chesnel, was French ambassador to Laos. And former FIT Director Jean-Paul Reau is now French ambassador to South Korea.
Current Director-General of the German Trade Office in Taipei Hilmar Kaht is also an ambassadorial-level German official.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS KOO-JIANG MEETING PRIVATE IN NATURE

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said on Tuesday that cross-strait exchanges should be monitored by the whole of society and that the upcoming meeting between Taiwan's top negotiator and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin should be seen as private in nature.

Speaking at a news conference called by the DPP on the eve of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu's long-awaited visit to mainland China, Lin said Koo's planned meeting with Jiang should be viewed as private, since Jiang will only receive Koo and his wife.
Koo will embark on a six-day visit to the mainland on Wednesday at the head of an 11-member delegation composed mainly of government officials in charge of mainland affairs.

Lin said the DPP is not opposed to cross-strait engagement and dialogue, but added that the process should be subject to social monitoring. He stressed that in principle, the DPP does not object to a possible summit between ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Jiang, but said the two leaders should avoid meeting in private.

DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen, however, said that time is not yet ripe for a much speculated Lee-Jiang meeting due to a dispute over Lee's status in any such meeting. Taiwan insists he must travel as "president of the ROC," while Beijing balks at this demand.

Yen Wan-chin, director of the DPP's Mainland Affairs Department, said the party will do its best to play the role of monitor in cross-strait talks, despite the fact that no DPP member is included in Koo's delegation.

He called on the SEF and its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- to exchange institutionalized branches to deal with problems arising from bilateral exchanges, saying it would help protect the rights of the people on both sides and that the proposal is a reflection of the DPP's mainland policy, which favors across-the-board dialogue with the mainland.

Legislator Shih Ming-te, a former DPP chairman, lamented the absence of DPP representatives in Koo's delegation. He said the DPP stands firm in its pursuit of Taiwan independence and that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resolve their disputes through negotiation.

Legislator Chang Chun-hung stressed the importance of peace in the Taiwan Strait. He said cross-strait tensions have raised grave concern around the world, and suggested that the two sides jointly launch a military satellite and cooperate on the economic front.
He demanded that Koo fully relay the opinions of all Taiwan's people to his mainland counterparts during his tour.
Legislator Lin Cho-shui claimed that Koo and his delegation are not entitled to make any response to, or compromises on, issues related to unification, or the "one China" controversy.

He urged Koo to stick to President Lee's ideal of sharing Taiwan's democratization experience with the mainland, and called on SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow to keep his promise to fully reflect Taiwan's stance.

Criticizing Jiang's decision to receive Koo and his wife in private, Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung described the meeting as a bad arrangement. He said Koo's visit to mainland China only forms part of the exchange process, and should be transparent to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES KOO DELEGATION CONVEYS SENSE OF TAIWAN PEOPLE

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday expressed its hope that C. F. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, conveys the sense of the Taiwan people during his upcoming mainland trip.
The DPP made the appeal in a press conference held on the eve of the first high-level cross-strait talks in five years.
DPP heavyweights, including DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, former party Chairman Shih Ming-teh and Legislators Chang Chun-hung and Lin Tzou-shui, participated in the conference.

The DPP also proposed that Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), invite his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association of the Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to come to Taiwan to witness year-end city council, mayoral and legislative elections.

The DPP urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume consultations on issues that are related to the interests of the people across the Taiwan Strait, including judicial assistance, investment guarantees, business arbitration and joint crackdowns on criminal activities as soon as possible, adding that these issues should not be affected by political concerns.

The DPP suggested that SEF and ARATS set up branch offices in the mainland and Taiwan, respectively, and that such offices be authorized to handle issues related to people on both sides of the strait.

The DPP also proposed that both sides of the Taiwan Strait, under the framework of international organizations, engage in consultations to devise a strategy to deal with the current financial turmoil in Southeast Asia and to establish a mechanism that will effectively ensure peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region.

For this reason, the DPP suggested that Taiwan and mainland China propose at November's Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting that all rim nations in South China sea send ministerial-level officials to attend a proposed economic cooperation conference on the South China Sea.
The DPP asked the Taiwan delegation to insist that the island of Taiwan is a sovereign state and to ignore calls for reunification from Beijing.

During the first talks between Koo and Wang in Singapore in 1993, talks that set up the framework for regular dialogue across the strait, the DPP sent a delegation to the city-state to protest the talks.
The DPP was worried that those talks might touch such issues as unification and that Taiwan's interests might be compromised.
Although the DPP was excluded from Koo's 12-member delegation, it has made friendly proposals to Beijing and expressed its wishes that the meeting will prove a success.

Koo's delegation should reflect fully the sense of the people of Taiwan, the DPP said, citing the results of a recent public opinion poll that indicated 77 percent of the people in Taiwan do not support the "one country, two systems" formula advocated by the mainland, while 84 percent of the people insist that the fate of Taiwan should be decided not by mainland China but by the 21.3 million people of Taiwan.

The results of that poll also revealed that 83.1 percent of Taiwan people believe mainland China should renounce the use of force against Taiwan, while 92 percent think Taiwan should join international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES GRENADA PREMIER, EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT MEMBERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday the Republic of China is willing to use its experience in agricultural development to help Grenada further improve the quality of life for its people.
Lee made the remarks when receiving Grenadan Premier Keith C. Mitchell who is visiting Taipei to attend the ROC Double Ten National Day celebrations.

Accompanied by Foreign Minister Jason Hu, the Grenada prime minister, his wife and entourage, including Vice Finance Minister Meryl Forsyth, Vice Agriculture Minister William Joseph, Agriculture Ministry Advisor Einstein Louison, and agricultural expert Orgias Campbell, paid Lee a courtesy call at the Presidential Office.

The president briefed his guests on the history of Taiwan's industrial development. He suggested that in addition to agricultural cooperation, the ROC and Grenada should enhance exchanges in other fields such as vocational training, culture and sports, and to promote understanding and friendship between the people of the two countries.
Mitchell thanked Lee for the aid the ROC has extended to his Caribbean country. He also stressed that Grenada will continue to support the ROC in the international community.

Later in the day, Lee also received four members of the European Parliament -- Guenter Rinsche, Peter Michael Mombaur, Anne Karin Glase, and Brigitte Langenhagen. He asked his guests to speak up for the ROC in the European Parliament, and to support the ROC's bid to joint international organizations.

He also urged the European Union to actively develop cooperation and exchanges with the ROC in the fields of trade, economy, science and technology, environmental protection, information, and culture and education.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PC EXPORTS TO EUROPE POST SIGNIFICANT GROWTH

TEXT.P: Europe imported a total of 2.18 million personal computers from Taiwan in the first half of this year, up 77.2 percent form the same period of last year, according to the latest official statistics.

The statistics released on Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that Taiwan exported a total of 7.97 million PCs during the first six months of this year, up 49 percent from the same period of 1997, and making the region Taiwan's second-largest market for PCs.

Taiwan's total PC production volume reached 8.24 million units in the January-June period of this year, registering a 48.5 percent surge in comparison with the year-earlier level. Of those, 270,000 were sold on the island, the statistics show.

DGBAS officials said the significant growth could be attributed to a world trend for low-priced computers and global demand for computer upgrades following the launch of Microsoft's Windows 98 operating system.
North America was the island's largest PC market, importing 3.15 million PCs from January to June, up 39.4 percent from the same period of last year.

Taiwan's PC exports to the Asia-Pacific region amounted to 1.98 million in the first six months of 1998, up 50 percent from the same period of 1997, but registering as a decline in growth due to the Asian financial crises, the DGBAS tallies show.
Desktop PCs accounted for 5.7 million units of the exported PCs, up 60.6 percent, while notebook PCs accounted for 2.54 million, a 27 percent rise.
The statistics also reveal that the total PC production value of the island hit US$7 billion in the first half of this year, up 34.6 percent from the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPATRIATES 215 ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China repatriated 215 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants on Tuesday from its front-line offshore outpost of Matsu, marking the first repatriation from Taiwan to mainland China in six months.

Meanwhile, four suspected criminals from Taiwan were repatriated from the mainland to Matsu. The four -- three men and one woman -- were flown back to Taiwan and turned over to police in the afternoon, Matsu police sources said.

As all repatriations require the cooperation of mainland Chinese authorities, Tuesday's delivery was considered a goodwill gesture by Beijing before a visit to the mainland by Taiwan's top negotiator, Koo Chen-fu, local political observers said.

Since April of this year, Beijing has been reluctant to take back illegal immigrants to Taiwan. An unwillingness to do so is a violation of the Kinmen Agreement reached between the Red Cross Societies of both sides in 1990, the sources noted.
Under the agreement, the mainland is supposed to take delivery of illegal mainland immigrants within 20 days of receiving a list of the immigrants' names.

The 215 mainlanders have been detained in four ROC detention centers for stowaways and illegal immigrants from mainland China. Two centers are located on Matsu and one each is located in central Taiwan's Hsinchu and eastern Taiwan's Ilan.
As of Tuesday afternoon, there were still some 200 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants in the two Matsu detention centers awaiting repatriation.

Of the 215 mainlanders, one woman, Yang Caixia, is a wanted criminal from the island province of Hainan. Yang married a Taiwanese man, Chao Yi, in 1992. She and her husband returned to her hometown in April 1996. One night that June, Yang killed Chao while he slept and dumped his body in a reservoir. She sneaked back into Taiwan on a fishing boat three days later. Soon after that, she was nabbed and sent to a Taiwan detention center, Matsu police authorities said.

Besides the four Taiwanese criminals who were repatriated Tuesday, there are still 192 suspected Taiwan criminals whom police believe are hiding in the mainland. Some have been able to maintain their cross-strait criminal enterprises by remotely controlling their operations, according to the police authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO EXPECTS GROWTH IN WORLD TRADE TO HALVE

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO), which in March predicted only a "small dent" in global output from the Asian crisis, now expects the growth in world trade to halve this year.
The volume of merchandise trade is unlikely to grow by more than 4 percent to 5 percent in 1998 compared with an exceptionally high 9.5 percent last year, according to the WTO report.

In dollar terms, trade may stagnate this year or even decline, a situation that reflects the strength of the US dollar, the slump in oil prices, and the depreciated currencies of Asian countries that are important exporters of manufactured goods.

The WTO's economists originally thought it might be possible to contain the crisis to the five countries most seriously affected -- South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines. Provided the rest of the world kept markets open, these countries were expected to begin an export-led recovery this year.

However, the worsening situation in Asia, Japan's failure to surmount recession, and the "contagion" effect in other emerging markets, including Russia and Brazil, have forced a reassessment. This is in line with downward revisions of global output growth forecasts by the IMF and others to no more than 2 percent to 3 percent this year.

Of the five worst-affected countries, only South Korea and Thailand have managed to increase export volumes substantially -- by 30 percent and 15 percent respectively -- in the first half of this year from the year-earlier level.

Since imports by Asian countries are still contracting, exports from the region are going mainly to Europe and North America. In an article published recently, Renato Ruggiero, WTO director-general, again called on the West to keep markets open and resist calls for protectionism in response to widening trade deficits with Asia.

In the first half of 1998, according to the WTO report, US imports from Asia rose 9.5 percent in dollar terms, while exports fell by 14.5 percent. Exports from the European Union to the five most affected Asian countries fell by 40 percent, while imports increased 12 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIES WITH MAINLAND CHINA DICTATE TAIWAN'S POLICIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's troubled relations with mainland China dictate most of the island's international and domestic policies, according to an article which appeared in Tuesday's edition of the Asian Wall Street Journal.

The article, carried in a special advertising section prepared to mark the World Economic Forum, a seminar held in Singapore between Oct. 12-14, said Taiwan and mainland China are closely intertwined in economy but bitterly divided in politics.

Taiwan, which was involved in a civil war with communist China and has been deemed by Beijing as a renegade province for most of the past five decades, has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the mainland, and more than 1.5 million Taiwanese visit mainland China each year, according to the article.
This makes mainland China the primary recipient of Taiwan investment, and its number two trading partner after the US, said the article.

But the trade ties have failed to persuade Beijing to give up its attempts to isolate Taiwan diplomatically. It regularly hectors any country that displays anything close to recognition of Taiwan, said the journal.

While counting partly on its investment in mainland China for its solid performance in the Late 1990s, Taiwan is worried that its increasing economic dependence on the mainland will lead to erosion of its de facto sovereignty, and pursues a "go slow" policy regarding investment in the mainland, in order to keep a rein on ties, said the article.

The political relationship between Taiwan and mainland China has taken a recent turn for the better, but Taiwan is still carrying on a curious charade: struggling for global recognition while rejecting the unwanted embrace of "mother China," said the article.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA MEMBER WINS NOBEL PRIZE FOR PHYSICS

TEXT.P: A former president of Taiwan's highest-level academic institute, the Academia Sinica, on Tuesday lauded fellow member Daniel Tsui's winning of the 1998 Nobel prize for physics.

Tsui, a 59-year-old Chinese-American, is a professor at Princeton University, New Jersey. He won the Nobel Prize in conjunction with two other physicists -- Prof. Robert Laughlin of Stanford University, and Prof. Horst Stoermer of Columbia University.
They were awarded the prize for "discovering that electrons acting together in strong magnetic fields can form new types of particles, with charges that are fractions of electron charges."

Upon learning of Tsui's achievement, former Academia Sinica President Dr. Wu Ta-you said it was "very encouraging news," and added that improvement of the environment through scientific research is an endless task in which Taiwan should continue its efforts.
Dr. Wu, now a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui, said that although he is not acquainted with Prof. Tsui, he is happy to see a fellow Academia Sinica member winning the Nobel Prize.
Prof. Tsui is the sixth Chinese-American to have won the Nobel Prize. The previous winners are Yang Chen-ning, Lee Tsung-dao, Samuel Chao-chung Ting, Lee Yuan-tseh and Steven Chu.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED OVERSEAS BANK APPROVED TO OPEN INTERNATIONAL OPERATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday approved an application from Singapore's United Overseas Bank (UOB) to begin international financial operations in Taiwan.

The approval brings to 73 the number of banking institutes on the island which provide international financial services. Of those, 38 are local banks, while the other 35 are branches of foreign banks.
The UOB has the 114th-largest capital in the world. It set up its Taipei Branch in January of 1995, according to the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN TO SELL TAIWAN DEMOCRACY TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China said on Tuesday he will take the opportunity of his imminent visit to the mainland to sell Taiwan's democratic evolution and economic transition.
Koo Chen-fu, a veteran business tycoon and chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), is scheduled to leave for the mainland on Wednesday for a six-day visit.

He is expected to meet with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Shanghai on Wednesday and Thursday, marking the first cross-strait rendezvous between the top negotiators from both sides in more than five years.

At a press conference prior to his departure, Koo said he will meet various mainland Chinese officials for constructive talks. He said these talks will afford him a good opportunity to let the mainland people know how much the ROC has achieved in democratic evolution and economic transition over the last half-century.
It has been 11 years since the two sides began to engage in cross-strait exchanges at the private level, after nearly four decades of no contact, Koo said.
During the past 11 years, there have been gains in cross-strait exchanges and negotiations, but twists and turns were never scarce, he noted.
Koo is scheduled to join Wang, both octogenarians, in a performance of the famous Peking opera "Kung Cheng Chi," or "The Bluff," in Shanghai on Thursday.
"Kung Cheng Chi" is an intriguing play which tells the story of figures in the Three Kingdoms period of China between A.D. 222 and A.D. 265.

Koo said he is intrigued by the play, a story of a war of wits, and added that joining Wang in the performance carries great significance in cross-strait relations, which he said can do without violence.

Koo recalled that in his first rendezvous with Wang, in Singapore in April 1993, the SEF and ARATS reached four agreements which laid the framework for future exchanges and regular meetings across the Taiwan Strait.

Unfortunately, he said, he and Wang failed to meet again for the second round of talks scheduled for 1995, because Beijing unilaterally suspended the talks in protest against President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States in June 1995, which Beijing viewed as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Koo said the time has finally arrived for him to meet Wang for the second time. Over the last three years, Taipei has called for a resumption of cross-strait talks more than 100 times, and he personally offered last November to take the initiative to travel to the mainland to resume the talks.
He said he hopes that his imminent meetings with Wang will pave the way for resuming the long-stalled talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR LAUDS PRESIDENT FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO DEMOCRACY
DOC.DATELINE: Wufeng Township, Taichung County, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: James Soong, governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG), said on Tuesday that President Lee Teng-hui has made outstanding contributions to the development of democracy in Taiwan.

Soong made the remark while answering interpellations from Taiwan Provincial Assembly member Yang Tai-soon of the opposition New Party at an Assembly meeting. The first popularly elected TPG head also stressed that he will leave the TPG when his term of office expires on Dec. 20.

Commenting on his position as a member of the ruling Kuomintang Central Standing Committee, he said that according to the system, he has office tenure, but that if the KMT decides to remove him from the committee simply because he is no longer governor, he will have no reluctance in giving up the position.

Soong said that the KMT has played a very important role in the development of Taiwan, and that thanks to the persistency of the KMT, Taiwan has been able to avoid falling under the control of the communist regime in Beijing.

However, he went on, if the ruling party wants to continue its development, it should follow current trends, and make sure any policy-making and advocacy should comply with the popular wishes of the public.

In answering interpellations from assembly member Chao Liang-yen, also of the New Party, Soong suggested that during the upcoming year-end elections, candidates who really love Taiwan should stress the superiority of Taiwan, rather than become embroiled in provincialism and inter party fighting, or espouse the "priority for Taiwan" slogan advocated by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
He added that candidates should also stress that Taiwan's systems and concepts are better than those of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHIEF TO MEET MAINLAND CHINESE PRESIDENT ON OCT. 18

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China and chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing on Oct. 18.

In a press conference held on Tuesday prior to his departure for the mainland on Wednesday, Koo said the final lineup of the delegation which will be accompanying him during the meeting with Jiang has yet to be decided.
"Our team won't be large, but all the participating members will be chosen based on their expertise," he said.

In Shanghai, Koo said, he will meet with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), on three occasions between Wednesday and Thursday.

When asked why Chang Jung-kung, a researcher of the National Unification Council (NUC), and Kang Ning-hsiang, an NUC member, were included in his delegation, Koo said Chang is a well-known mainland China hand, while Kang, who used to be a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, is a living witness of Taiwan's democratic evolution.

Koo said that if given the chance, he would like to talk about grassroots democratic exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China when he meets with Jiang. He may also invite mainland people to Taiwan to witness for themselves the year-end general elections, he noted.
"Seeing is believing. Only by seeing it for themselves at first hand will the people of the mainland understand what Taiwan democracy is all about," Koo stressed.

Asked what he will say if the mainland side asks him about China's reunification, Koo answered that first, he will clarify the fact that China has yet to be reunified. And second, he said, he will emphasize that the reunified China sought by the ROC is a China unified under democracy.

Koo also noted that although he and his delegation will travel via Hong Kong, they will stay for only about two hours. "No formal reception nor press conference will be held during the stopover," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERIA EXTENDS INVITATION TO ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui met on Tuesday with Myudueh Morkonmana, speaker of Liberia's parliament, who extended to the Republic of China's head of state an invitation to visit the African state.
Morkonmana is in Taipei at the head of a Liberian delegation which attended last week's celebrations for the ROC's Double Ten National Day.
Lee told Morkonmana that as an agro-economist, he would like very much to tour Liberia and offer some advise on economic development.
The president also told his visitors that the ROC would like to extend agricultural and medical aid to the war-torn state to help it recover from the ruins of seven years of civil war.
He expressed thanks to Morkonmana and his entourage for visiting the island on its national day, and asked them to convey his personal greeting to Liberian President Charles Taylor.

Morkonmana reconfirmed his country's commitment to its friendship with the ROC, depicting it as a long-lasting relationship rather than a relationship of convenience. He also reiterated the African state's firm support for Taiwan's various bids to enter international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, C. F. Koo, leaves for Shanghai Wednesday for an ice-breaking visit.
The China Times: Academia Sinica academician Daniel Tsui won the 1998 Nobel Prize in physics.
The United Daily News: Chinese-American scientist Daniel Tsui was awarded the 1998 Nobel Prize in physics.
The Liberty Times: Academia Sinica academician Daniel Tsui shared the 1998 Nobel Prize in physics with one American and one German scientists.
The Independence Morning Post: Strong typhoon Zeb is expected to strike Taiwan Wednesday night.
The Commons Daily: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party reiterated Taiwan's independent sovereignty on eve of high-level talks across the Taiwan Strait.
The China Post: Heavy rains seen as Zeb on course to hit Taiwan.
The China News: Taiwan team emphasizes division; negotiators en route to China in hopes of resuming systematized cross-strait talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOP ENVOY LEAVES FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top negotiator with Beijing left for mainland China on Wednesday for the highest-level talks across the Taiwan Strait in more than five years.

"I'll bring Taiwan's goodwill to the mainland," Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo said prior to his departure for Shanghai via Hong Kong to meet his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Stating that he fully knows the people of Taiwan have pinned high hopes on his visit, Koo said he believes if both sides face current political reality and treat each other respectfully on an equal footing in discussions on matters of mutual concern, cross-strait peace and prosperity will be boosted.

The veteran ambassador-at-large said more than five years have passed since he first met Wang in Singapore in April 1993 and that regular cross-strait consultations have also been suspended for over three years.

"We are pleased to see mainland China finally respond to our repeated appeals for the reopening of communication channels between the two intermediary bodies on the two sides of the strait," Koo said, adding that he hopes both sides value the opportunity of his mainland visit to usher in a new era in cross-strait relations.

Koo, a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui, said the top goals of his Shanghai-Beijing visit is to promote SEF-ARATS exchanges, push for the resumption of systematized SEF-ARATS consultations and improve cross-strait ties.
Koo, 81, is heading a 12-member delegation on his landmark mainland visit.

The 11 other delegates are SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow; National Unification Council (NUC) member Kang Ning-hsiang; and NUC researchers Chang Jung-kung, Wu Jung-i and Pao Chung-ho; Pao Cheng-kang, chief secretary of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC); Jan Jyh-horng, director of the MAC's Research and Planning Department; Liu Teh-hsun, director of the MAC's Legal Affairs Department; Tsai Ying-wen, an adviser to MAC; Hsieh Fu-yuan, director of the SEF's Legal Service Department; and Ho Wu-liang, a section chief with the SEF's Legal Service Department.
Koo's wife, Yen-Koo Chou-yun, their son Koo Chi-yun and daughter Koo Hui-chun are also accompanying Koo on the visit.
A composed man, Koo is widely respected and leads a proud and prosperous business family. He is well versed in the arts and culture. He is also a Peking opera lover.

Because of Taiwan's extraordinary status, Koo, head of one of the island's largest business groups, often attended international meetings that senior ROC leaders were barred from going to. In the past three years, Koo has represented President Lee at the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
The Koo delegation is scheduled to arrive in Shanghai at around 4 p.m. Koo will deliver a brief speech upon his arrival at the Shanghai airport.

Koo will meet with his mainland counterpart, Wang, at Shanghai's posh Peace Hotel at 5 p.m. The two elder statesmen are expected to deliver speeches on the occasion. Wang will host a dinner party in honor of the Koo delegation following their first meeting.
Following his Shanghai visit, Koo will travel to Beijing on Oct. 16 afternoon. He is expected to meet with mainland President Jiang Zemin on Oct. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO EASE MAINLAND INVESTMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: Taipei should ease its policy governing Taiwan investment in mainland China as soon as possible, Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) Chairman Kao Chin-yen urged on Wednesday.

Kao, who also heads Taiwan's largest food processing company, the President Group, called on the government to review its present "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy amid improving ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. He predicted that Taipei would do so next year after bilateral relations turn for the better.

Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, is due to arrive in Shanghai Wednesday afternoon for a six-day mainland visit. It is the first such trip since cross-strait relations hit a low ebb after President Lee Teng-hui paid a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995.

Koo's planned meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, will be the second of its kind after the two met for the first time in Singapore in 1993.

Meanwhile, Zhang Jiakun, vice governor of mainland China's Fujian province, said Taiwan and Fujian should enhance bilateral cooperation and investment since the southeastern mainland province is one of the most popular destinations among Taiwan businesses in recent years.
Zhang made the remarks after his arrival in Taipei on Wednesday morning. He is on a 12-day visit to the island at the invitation of the CNFI.

The main purpose of this trip is to exchange opinions with Taiwan business leaders and to promote Taiwan investment in Fujian, Zhang said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should work together to tackle the current Asian financial crisis.

The vice governor will call on Formosa Plastic Group Chairman Y. C. Wang and Yulon Group Chairwoman S. W. Wu later in the afternoon. The two business groups and the President Group are the three leading investors in Fujian province.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO MAKES TRANSIT STOP IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Huang Wen-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, C. F. Koo, arrived in Hong Kong at 10:40 a.m. Wednesday on his way to Shanghai for the highest-level talks across the Taiwan Strait in more than five years.
Koo, chairman of Taipei's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, received warm welcome from Paul Kwok-wah Yip, the top adviser to Hong KOng Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa.

Taiwan's representative to Hong Kong, Cheng An-kuo, and Xing Keuishan, a department director at the Hong Kong office of Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency, also greeted Koo and his delegation at the airport.
Yip conveyed Tung's regards and best wishes to Koo. For his part, Koo expressed his gratitude for the hospitality the Hong Kong government accorded him on his transit stop.
Koo, also Taiwan's veteran ambassador-at-large, said he has deep feelings for his ongoing visit to the mainland, his first cross-strait trip in 50 years.

Koo said the main purposes of his current mainland visit is to push for the resumption of institutionalized cross-strait consultations and to foster an amiable atmosphere for future cross-strait engagements.
Koo will meet his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Shanghai.
The first Koo-Wang meeting was held in Singapore in April 1993 during which time the two elder statesmen signed several agreements to lay a framework for SEF-ARATS dialogue and consultations.
Beijing, however, suspended such contacts in mid-1995 in anger over Taiwan's efforts to upgrade its international profile.

"It has been more than five years since I first met Wang and cross-strait dialogue has also been suspended for more than three years. I have many things to talk with Wang. I earnestly hope my visit will help improve the atmosphere and lay a solid foundation for future cross-strait rapprochement," Koo said.
Koo was accompanied by 11 other Taiwan delegates on his mainland visit.
The Koo delegation left Hong Kong for Shanghai at around 1:20 p.m. The delegation is scheduled to arrive in Shanghai at around 4 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE CONFIDENCE IS NEEDED ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT: SIEW
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More confidence and mutual trust is required between Taiwan and mainland China if long-term stability is to be maintained in the Taiwan Strait and East Asia, ROC Premier Vincent Siew said.

Commenting on Taiwan Strait relations as well as other issues in an exclusive interview with the Rotterdam Dagblad daily recently, Siew said, "We hope to be treated equally and no longer be excluded from the international community."

"I personally attach great expectations on China's reunification under a democratic system. To achieve that goal, however, requires tremendous patience, as well as common wish of the people of the two sides," Siew told J. Prins, the daily's editor-in-chief.

The widely-circulated Rotterdam Dagblad devoted a full page to the interview as a part of its series of special reports marking the Republic of China's National Day on Oct. 10. Prins traveled to Taipei in August to conduct the interview.

Premier Siew, who assumed office last September, has successfully led Taiwan in limiting the effects of the Asian financial meltdown and its aftermath while other leaders in the Far East have failed to do so, Prins said.

Prins noted that although Taiwan's overall economic growth figures have dropped, its economy is still growing. Premier Siew's greatest accomplishment over the recent months has been in helping regain Taiwan's confidence, he added.

While the people of Taiwan are proud of their economic prosperity earned through hard work as well as social and political stability, they keenly expect to be respected and recognized by the world community, Prins wrote.

Siew has become one of the guides of the Taiwan miracle, Prins continued. With his knowledge, effort and unswerving determination, Siew has shown himself capable of clearing up complicated situations. This talent is akin to turning the poverty-stricken island with a high population density into a nation which is frequently acclaimed as one of the world's economic powerhouses, Prins said.
In the interview, Siew said perhaps Taiwan's economic miracle can convince mainland China that under a market-oriented economy, the mainland Chinese people can also lead better lives.
On relations across the Taiwan Strait, Siew said Taiwan wants to be a good neighbor and is willing to engage in any kind of negotiations.

"The age of using horrible terms such as communism, fascism and terrorism has passed and the last thing we want to do is to remember those terms," Siew said. He added that civilized people and countries talk while diplomatic pressure and military intimidation must be put to an end.
Siew told Prins that the "one country, two systems" formula Beijing applies to Hong Kong is not at all suitable for Taiwan.

"The ROC on Taiwan is not a colonial area, instead, the ROC is a sovereign country with its own Constitution. We have a plural-party political system and a popularly-elected president. We have our own history and our own defensive system," Siew noted.

On how Taiwan has managed to limit the blows inflicted by the Asian crisis, Siew cited several actions including measures to stabilize foreign exchange rates, minimize room for financial speculation and adopting an easy-credit policy to prevent interest rates from being driven up. The fact that Taiwan does not rely heavily on foreign capital is an added advantage to remaining relatively unscathed by the crisis, he added.
Despite all these actions, Siew admitted that Taiwan, which maintains close economic ties with Southeast Asian countries, has more or less been adversely affected by the Asian economic turmoil.

"The Taiwan currency has depreciated, stock markets fell and the island's exports to Japan and Southeast Asia have declined 20 percent," the premier said. Nevertheless, he added, Taiwan's performance has been the best among other economies in the Far East.

Siew lamented that as a country with foreign exchange reserves exceeding US$83.66 billion, Taiwan is barred from extending financial assistance to its neighbors simply because it is not a International Monetary Fund member.
"We would like to help, but we cannot because we are not acknowledged as a sovereign state.... The ROC is a sovereign country, but it is excluded from the international community," he continued.

As the 14th largest trading country in the world, Taiwan is not recognized, and not allowed to extend a helping hand. It is indeed too bad for the countries which are seeking financial aid to try and recover, Siew said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UN BID TO CLEAR WAY FOR UNIFICATION

TEXT.P: Taipei's bid to join the United Nations will help ensure peace and security in the Taiwan Strait, thereby paving the way for China's eventual unification, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.

Refuting Beijing's charges that Taipei's UN bid is a covert move aimed at creating "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," Hu stressed that Taiwan wishes to lay a cornerstone for cross-strait negotiations through such efforts.
Hu made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan briefing for the Foreign Affairs and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committees on the government's strategy to join the world body.

Admitting that trying to gain entry to the UN is a gargantuan political task, the foreign minister pointed out that the mainland's growing economic clout and Beijing's increasing diplomatic offense are making it more difficult for Taiwan's bid in the short term.
However, Hu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue to promote the island's bid to enter the UN as it is in the best interest of Taiwan people.

According to Hu, MOFA has outlined three major directives to achieve the goal. First, it will cement the support of ROC diplomatic partners. Second, Taipei will encourage ROC diplomatic allies to continue putting the issue of Taiwan's UN entry on the agenda for the world body's discussions in the coming years. Third, MOFA will try to reduce opposition from other UN members.

In addition to 23 ROC diplomatic partners, Latvia, the Czech Republic, and Fiji all voiced support for Taiwan's membership at the session of this year's UN general debate, an indication that the issue has commanded greater attention among countries friendly to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US COULD HELP AVOID CONFLICT IN TAIWAN STRAIT ISSUE

TEXT.P: Conflict between mainland China and Taiwan would be more likely if the United States does not deter mainland aggression and promote democracy, an analysis released by the Heritage Foundation on Tuesday said.
The study's author, Stephen J. Yates, is a China policy analyst with The Asian Studies Center, a Washington-based think tank.

Yates wrote that although President Bill Clinton and his administration have stated that the "three noes" Taiwan policy was a reiteration or clarification of a long-term US policy, the president in fact changed US policy toward Taiwan.

Clinton stated while in Shanghai on June 30, "We don't support independence of Taiwan, or two Chinas, or one China one Taiwan. And we don't believe that Taiwan should be a member of any organization for which statehood is a requirement."

The statement reflects an appeasement to the Beijing government. It was a far cry from March 1996 when the US upheld the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act and sent aircraft carriers to the Taiwan Strait as China was conducting live missile tests off the coast of Taiwan's two most important ports, Yates noted.

"The administration's new policies will make conflict with China more likely in the future and undermine US credibility," he said, adding that by failing to protect security and promote freedom in Taiwan, the administration's Taiwan policy runs counter to long-standing US interests in the Asia-Pacific region and violates the spirit if not the letter of US law.
To restore clarity and consistency to the US' Taiwan policy, Yates suggested that the Clinton administration and Congress adopt the following positions:

-- Promote the process and not the outcome in the cross-strait dispute. The US should not take a policy position that prejudices the outcome of the standoff between mainland China and Taiwan. It should neither endorse nor oppose Taiwan's independence or reunification with the mainland, but it should insist that any eventual resolution of this conflict come through peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.

-- Distinguish between long-term obligations and short-term administration policy. To avoid miscalculation and miscommunication with Taipei and Beijing, the administration should make clear to both governments which aspects of the US' Taiwan policy constitute binding long-term obligations and which reflect the administration's own interpretation of how best to implement those obligations.

-- Deter Beijing's military aggression. The US must recognize that China's military modernization efforts and willingness to use force to impose its will on Taiwan are the primary sources of danger and instability in the Taiwan Strait. Adequate deterrence, specified in the Taiwan Relations Act, is the best guarantee against military intimidation or attack.

-- Promote Taiwan's democracy in China and abroad. If the US is to have any credibility in advocating democracy on the Chinese mainland, it must properly recognize and reward the Taiwan people for their success in establishing a democracy in their republic.

Yates concluded that if the Clinton administration wishes to avoid military conflict in the Taiwan Strait, it must shelve the restrictive recommendations in its 1994 Taiwan Policy Review and faithfully implement the spirit and the letter of the Taiwan Relations Act.

"Only when the United States resolves to deter aggression and promote democracy will the 50-year standoff in the Taiwan Strait be likely to find peaceful resolution with the consent of the Taiwan people," he wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL PARTY LEADER SAYS ONE NATION REMAINS AN ELECTORAL THREAT

TEXT.P: Despite its dismal showing in the Oct. 3 election, the One Nation Party remains an electoral threat to all major parties, the leader of the National Party warned.
Deputy Prime Minister and Trade Minister Tim Fischer said conservative parties should not be complacent despite One Nation's failure to win seats in the House of Representatives.
"There's no room for complacency. We have to take the chance of dealing (One Nation) out once and for all," he said.

He asked members of the National Party, particularly maverick members of parliament, to continue to push for a comprehensive tax reform including the introduction of a 10 percent goods and services tax as well as the sale of government-owned telecommunications giant -- Telstra.
Fischer and his deputy leader John Anderson were seriously at risk of losing their election bids from the challenge of One Nation candidates.
Bill O'Chee, a National Party whip who is of Chinese descent, lost his election bid for Senate in Brisbane to a One Nation candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUPERT MURDOCH SEES GLOBAL DEFLATION

TEXT.P: As the financial crisis sweeps international markets, the world may be moving toward a period of deflation, media magnate Rupert Murdoch said on Tuesday.
Murdoch, executive chairman of News Corp. Ltd., told shareholders in a general annual meeting in Adelaide, "There is no doubt we have seen great shocks and we may see more shocks yet."
"I think underneath all this financial shock there is a lot of deflationary forces," he said.
Murdoch questioned how much governments and central bankers will be able to counter such forces, or whether deflationary forces will overpower such efforts.
"We are in a new paradigm today ... governments can maybe soften the effects of violent movements in markets, but not much else. You cannot stand against the tide," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MUST RENOUNCE USE OF FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN: JAPAN PAPER

TEXT.P: Beijing could greatly improve its relations with Taipei if it were to renounce the possible use of force against Taiwan as a means for reunifying China, the English-language Japan Times said on Wednesday.

The article titled "Rejecting Force as a Cross-Strait Option" was written by US expert on Chinese affairs, Ralph A. Cossa. It said although both sides have cautioned against expecting too much in the coming Koo-Wang talks in Shanghai, the mere fact that talks are resuming is promising.
Cossa is executive director of the Pacific Forum CSIS, a Honolulu-based policy research institute affiliated with the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.

He identified two core issues that must be addressed before real progress in cross-strait reconciliation can be achieved. One, he said, involves each side's different interpretation of "one China," and the other concerns Beijing's refusal to renounce the use of force as a means of achieving reunification.

Taiwan accepts "one China" as a goal but not as a current reality. Two separate political entities exist today with neither one exercising jurisdiction over what President Lee Teng-hui calls "one divided China," says Cossa.

Lee's statement in an August 1998 Asian Wall Street Journal editorial -- which refuted allegations that Taiwan was pursuing "independence" or "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" -- should help set the stage for a more productive cross-strait dialogue and may even provide a key to defusing the use-of-force issue, the article said.
The use-of-force issue creates problems not only in Taipei but also with Washington since US acceptance of "one China" is predicated on peaceful resolution, Cossa noted.

Both sides of the Taiwan Strait have proven they can coexist with different interpretations of "one China." What is now needed is a mutually acceptable common definition that addresses both mainland sovereignty concerns and Taiwanese aspirations, Cossa suggested. Putting the use-of-force issue behind them will facilitate this all important dialogue, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO ARRIVES IN SHANGHAI TO REOPEN KOO-WANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his entourage arrived in the mainland Chinese city of Shanghai at 3:42 p.m. on Wednesday to add new momentum to the promotion of cross-strait ties, stagnant for more than three years.
They were greeted at the airport of Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), among others.
Later, Koo are expected to attend a news conference, and to meet with Wang Daohan, chairman of ARATS, at the world famous Peace Hotel.
At 6:30 p.m. another press conference will be held at the hotel, following which Wang will host a dinner party in Koo's honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRACING FOR TYPHOON ZEB

TEXT.P: Local people were battening down the hatches on Wednesday in anticipation of an onslaught by typhoon Zeb, as the storm, which has already slammed into the northern Philippines, gained momentum and headed for Taiwan.

Zeb was centered 540 kilometers south-southeast of Hengchun, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, at noon on Wednesday, and reported to be moving in a northwesterly direction at a speed of 18 kilometers per hour, the Central Weather Bureau (CBC) said.
With a radius of 350 kilometers and packing center winds of 55 meters per second, Zeb is expected to begin affecting the entire island by late Wednesday night, CBC weathermen reported.

They said that while the southern counties of Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Taitung are expected to bear the brunt of the typhoon's strong winds, the entire island can expect torrential rains in the coming two days.
Zeb, the strongest of the eight storms to visit Taiwan this year, is expected to sweep over the island on Thursday and Friday.
As of Wednesday noon, heavy seas whipped up by Zeb had already killed one man, an angler, and left two missing, presumed drowned, in eastern Ilan County.
In Pingtung County, schools were closed on Wednesday afternoon and air traffic to and from southern and eastern cities was disrupted by canceled flights.

In the southern port of Kaohsiung, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau has organized an ad hoc typhoon command center, and has suspended shipping between Kaohsiung and the offshore islands of Penghu (the Pescadores) and Kinmen.
Ships plying the Bashi Channel and the southern part of the Taiwan Strait were reported to be seeking shelter at the port.
Weathermen issued a three-day typhoon alert for the entire island, as they expect Zeb to gain in force and bring potentially damaging torrential rains.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG MEETING BENEFICIAL TO SEF-ARATS DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The upcoming meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan is unlikely to be substantive, but will be beneficial to future cross-strait talks, according to a mainland jurist.

Zhao Binling, a jurist with the Shanghai-based China Law Society, expressed his hope that the Koo-Wang meeting, which began on Wednesday, will reach some common understanding, especially pertaining to the law.

Koo left Taipei on Wednesday morning at the head of a 12-member delegation for a six-day visit to mainland China. He is scheduled to hold a series of meetings in Shanghai with Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Zhao cited the recent high-profile murder of Taiwan councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan in mainland China as a case in point. Disagreements over the handling of the affair were attributed to a lack of measures for dealing with cross-strait economic and trade disputes.

In view of the rapidly expanding economic and trade volume between the two sides, similar disputes can be expected to occur in the future, Zhao said, which makes the need to strengthen exchanges of opinions across the strait all the more pressing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA AMBASSADOR TO TURKEY: NO RENMINBI DEVALUATION

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Ambassador to Turkey Yao Ruangyi said on Wednesday that there will be no devaluation of his country's currency, despite the global economic crisis.
Yao, who was visiting Bursa, a textile city in western Turkey, also said that the volume of trade between Turkey and mainland China should be increased.
Pointing out that trade volume between the two sides was US$600 million in 1997, Yao said that the goal is to double this amount within the next two years.
He suggested that Turkish businessmen can establish commercial relations with their mainland Chinese counterparts, especially in the fields of energy, agriculture, food, construction, and textiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEENSLAND STUDYING WAYS OF BOOSTING TRADE WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Australia's Queensland state government is to begin sending young government recruits to Taiwan and other Asian countries to study ways of boosting trade and other relations.

A statement faxed to the CNA on Wednesday said the Queensland government is to offer up to six scholarships per year for six-month placements in overseas trade offices as part of moves to increase trade with Asia.

Taiwan is one of Queensland's major Asian trading partners, and the state's exports include coal, seafood, sugar, and other agricultural products, while its imports from Taiwan include computers and components.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.158 against the greenback in Taipei Wednesday, closing at 33.277.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 33.137, and had a low of 33.3.
The interbank US dollar reached US$390 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXAMINATION YUAN PRESIDENT VISITING JAPAN

TEXT.P: Hsu Shui-teh, president of the Republic of China's Examination Yuan, is making a private visit to Japan, Examination Yuan officials revealed on Wednesday.
The officials said Hsu left on Tuesday and is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Sunday.

Hsu's Japan visit is being treated as a sensitive issue, due to the fact that no formal relations currently exist between Taipei and Tokyo. The officials declined to disclose details of the visit, saying only that their president was making the visit at the invitation of the Eisenhower Scholarship Foundation.

Hsu, who has previously served as ROC representative to Japan, still maintains friendly relationships with many Japanese politicians, and the Examination Yuan officials said that during his stay, he will probably call on some of his Japanese friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STOCK PRICES FALL, CURRENCY EDGES UP

TEXT.P: Australia's stock market, hit by falls in other major markets on Wednesday, closed lower while its currency edged higher.
The All Ordinaries Index dropped 22.9 points to close at 2,465.6, compared to Tuesday's close of 2,488.5.
The Australian dollar rose to 62.85 US cents, up from 62.36 US cents on Tuesday.
Analysts attributed the stock market fall to volatility in the Asian markets caused by a series of portfolio changes by large Japanese fund managers and profit taking which trimmed previous gains.
The Australian dollar consolidated its strength after Japan announced a rescue package for its banking sector, which gave a positive signal that a global credit crunch can be avoided.
