DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN PAPER REPORTS ON KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China on Wednesday resumed their semi-official meeting after a three-and-a-half-year hiatus, according to a report in Germany's mass-circulation daily Die Welt newspaper.

During the six-day meeting, which began in Shanghai on Wednesday, Taiwan aims to address issues involving technical problems relating to bilateral contacts, while Beijing is preparing to broach discussions on China's reunification, the newspaper report said.

Die Welt said that while both Taiwan and mainland China profess reunification to be their ultimate goal, the two sides have differing conditions on how reunification should take place. Beijing favors the "one country, two systems" formula that it imposed on Hong Kong in July 1997, but Taiwan scoffs at this idea, saying that "Taiwan is not a colony."

Through mediation from the United States, the paper said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have recently begun to make gestures of goodwill, paving the way for Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, to travel to Shanghai to meet with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
The Koo-Wang meeting, the first of its kind in more than five years, will move north to continue in Beijing after Shanghai, the paper said.
The report said a majority of countries in the world, including Germany and the United States, have succumbed to Beijing's pressure, and do not maintain diplomatic ties with the ROC.

In its attempts to end its international isolation, Taiwan hopes to engage again in negotiations with Beijing. Taiwan has continuously demonstrated goodwill in this regard, including a call by President Lee Teng-hui for "constructive" dialogue between the leaders of the two sides, and the cancellation of planned war games prior to Koo's trip.

In the series of meetings, Taiwan is hoping to broach "practical subjects," including the security of the lives and property of Taiwanese business people on the mainland, thorough investigation of crimes committed on Taiwan people visiting the mainland, and direct cross-strait postal links, the report said.
Beijing, meanwhile, expects to touch on the reunification issue, which Taipei says cannot be discussed as long as the mainland remains under communist rule, according to the newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN POLICE MAKE RECORD SEIZURE OF HEROIN FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Australian police and naval personnel on Wednesday seized about 400 kilograms of heroin worth about US$250 million in the port of Macquarie in New South Wales, the biggest haul in Australia's history.
After boarding a freighter at the port, police arrested fifteen people on smuggling charges, including ethnic Chinese and Indonesian crew members, and two residents of Hong Kong.
Police said the contraband was smuggled into Australia from mainland China by an international syndicate with members in mainland China, Hong Kong, and the Golden Triangle region.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE PRESIDENT SAID TO MEET KOO IN `FAMILY SETTING'
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin will meet Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, C.F. Koo, and his wife, in a "private family setting" on Oct. 18, a Hong Kong daily reported on Wednesday.
The Sing Tao Yih Pao quoted unnamed sources as saying that mainland authorities will not agree to Taiwan's request that several members of Koo's entourage be present at the meeting.

The sources said Jiang will host a private family dinner in honor of the Koos, adding that the arrangement is a goodwill token underscoring the mainland leader's respect for Koo's contributions to the promotion of rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait over past years.

The sources further said Jiang's decision to meet the Koos betrays the fact that he attaches great importance to the reopening of high-level contacts between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- after a more-than-three-year impasse.

SEF Chairman Koo, Taiwan's veteran ambassador-at-large and a senior adviser to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, arrived in Shanghai via Hong Kong on Wednesday afternoon to meet his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, for the highest-level cross-strait meeting in more than five years.
After several meetings with Wang, Koo and his 11-member entourage will travel to Beijing on Oct. 16 to continue their ice-breaking mainland visit.
Meanwhile on Wednesday, the English-language Hong Kong Standard daily reported that mainland China has formulated a three-phase strategy to press for cross-strait political talks.

According to the strategy, the paper said, mainland China will push for political dialogue in the initial stage, followed by consultations on procedural issues which will pave the way for full-fledged political negotiations.
The paper said the Beijing authorities attach great importance to Koo's current mainland visit because they regard it as a prelude to the opening of cross-strait political dialogue.

The paper further said mainland leaders believe that President Lee's plans to make a "journey of peace" to the mainland and to meet with Jiang will become a reality only after the two sides come to terms on procedural issues related to eventual political negotiations.
Koo and his delegation are scheduled to end the high-profile mainland visit on Oct. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE IMPRESSED BY DEMONSTRATION OF ROC NAVAL POWER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy on Wednesday conducted joint landing exercises for some 6,000 overseas Chinese who were touring Taiwan after attending the ROC Double Ten National Day festivities last Saturday.
The exercises, dubbed the "Chiao Tai Maneuvers," featured joint landing operations by tanks and troops.
The visitors, representing overseas Chinese communities from around the world were said to be impressed by the demonstration of naval power.

Prior to the drills, the overseas Chinese visitors inspected various warships, accompanied by Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, and Navy Commander-in-Chief Adm. Wu Shih-wen.
About 40 ships and submarines were on display, as well as equipment belonging to the "frogmen" surveillance task force.
The joint landing exercises were staged at the Hua Hsing Marine Corps base. Powerful M109 artillery was also mobilized to back up the landing operations.
An Marine Corps honor guard also put on a display for the visitors, earning thunderous applause.

The maneuvers, designed specially to demonstrate the ROC's naval power for overseas Chinese, have not been held for several years, but naval authorities said afterwards that because of the positive reaction this time, they will consider holding them again in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO CALLS FOR SOLUTION OF URGENT PROBLEMS
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen & Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Wednesday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume negotiations to help the people of both sides to solve their urgent problems.

Koo made the remarks at a press conference shortly after his arrival in Shanghai at the start of a historic six-day visit to mainland China. He also pointed out that after nearly a half-century of separation, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have had people-to-people contact since 1987.

Taipei and Beijing have established the SEF and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), respectively, Koo said, adding that five years ago, he and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan signed the Koo-Wang Talks Joint Accord which promoted cross-strait visits by people and bilateral trade.

The SEF chairman said that upon arriving in Shanghai, he saw the bustling trade and the prosperity of the city, but pointed out that as cross-strait exchanges have increased rapidly, so too have the number of problems related to exchanges and visits. He added that the SEF and ARATS should start helping people to solve their urgent problems by resuming negotiations, and to solve general problems related to cross-strait relations.

SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow, National Unification Council researcher Chang Jung-kung, and Mainland Affairs Council advisor Tsai Ying-wen were also present at the press conference.

Answering questions from the assembled journalists, Koo said that previous cross-strait negotiations have touched on political issues, and that his coming meetings with Wang will not be restricted to any particular topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUJIAN TRADE DELEGATION WELCOMES FPG INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: A visiting trade delegation from mainland China's coastal Fujian Province on Wednesday welcomed Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) to invest in the mainland, saying "the bigger the investment, the better."

But Fujian Vice Governor Zhang Jiakun, traveling at the head of the delegation, said that FPG Chairman Y.C. Wang will have the ultimate decision as to how much money will be invested and in which sector.

FPG's plan to invest in a US$3.2 billion thermal power plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, has been stalled by the ROC government's "go slow" policy regarding investment in mainland China. The policy bans large-scale investment in mainland China's major infrastructure projects.
The group has therefore transferred its stake in the proposed project to foreign companies, and is biding its time, waiting for the government to relax the ban, when it plans to buy back its stake.
Zhang said that although the problem has yet to be resolved, construction work for the plant has been proceeding smoothly.
Zhang said that what Fujian provincial authorities can do now is create favorable conditions and improve the investment environment to lure investors from around the world.
He also said that the mainland is revising regulations governing the protection of the interests of Taiwan businessmen.

The 10-member delegation, at the invitation of Taipei's Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), arrived here on Wednesday for a 12-day visit. It aims mainly to attract more investment to the province which lies directly opposite Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DROP ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 90.1 points to close at 6,819.12.

Affected by declines on the New York Stock Exchange and the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar, the bourse opened at 6,857.82 points, 51.4 lower than at Wednesday's close. The index fell as low as 6,784.14 before climbing to 6,819.12 by the closing bell.

A total of 1.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.89 billion, a decrease from the previous trading session, in which 2.88 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.52 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only foodstuff shares registered a gain, rising 0.2 percent.

All other categories lost ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 3.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.7 percent, cement stocks and textile issues both at 1.2 percent, electrical shares at 0.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.2 percent and construction stocks at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were lower as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October dropped 77 points to close at 6,775, with 2,224 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 70 points to finish at 6,740, while December futures decreased 90 points to 6,710 and June futures dropped 144 points, closing at 6,580.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 606, 34 and two, respectively. No transactions was registered for March futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STEPS UP DIPLOMATIC OFFENSIVE AGAINST ROC: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that he has received as yet unsubstantiated information that mainland China is stepping up its efforts to lure away the Republic of China's diplomatic allies.

"Mainland China reportedly will adopt a double-faced strategy against Taiwan during and after the current ice-breaking visit to the mainland by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, C. F. Koo," Hu said at a Legislative Yuan Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee meeting.
"That means Beijing, while agreeing on the one hand to reopen contacts across the Taiwan Strait, is simultaneously intensifying its diplomatic offensive against Taiwan on the other," Hu explained.
The minister went on to say that Beijing once vowed to lure away all of the ROC's diplomatic allies before the advent of the next century.
"I don't think Beijing will be able to realize its goal," Koo said. "Nevertheless, I believe that Beijing's efforts to court our allies will reach a peak in the coming year."
Hu said Taiwan may be hurt by Beijing's move. "But I simply can't believe that Beijing will succeed in its attempt."

In the face of Beijing's mounting diplomatic offensive, Hu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will do its utmost to let mainland leaders understand that its hostile move against Taiwan is "unnecessary and unfeasible.

"We hope mainland leaders will finally come to understand that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not waste their precious resources in a zero-sum game in the international arena," Hu stressed.

Through MOFA's strenuous efforts over the past year, all of the ROC's diplomatic allies in the United Nations managed to voice explicit or indirect support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the UN at this year's UN General Assembly debate session.
"This indicates that our all-out efforts to consolidate relations with our diplomatic ties have borne fruit," the minister added.
The ROC was forced out of the UN in 1971 after the world body gave the "China" seat to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY SUGGESTS KOO SEEK CLARIFICATION FROM WANG OVER REMARKS

TEXT.P: Jaw Shau-kong, a heavyweight within Taiwan's New Party, suggested on Wednesday that Taipei's top negotiator with the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, seek clarification from Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan over reports that Wang has said "one China" does not necessarily refer to the People's Republic of China (PRC).
Wang is also reported to have said mainland China will not resort to force in its dealings with Taiwan as long as the island does not declare independence.

Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), left for a six-day visit to the mainland Wednesday at the head of a 12-member delegation. Koo is scheduled to hold a series of meetings with Wang in Shanghai.

After his talks with Wang, Koo will meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen. Qian is seen as being one of the mainland's senior-most officials in charge of Taiwan affairs.

Both Hsu Li-nung, the New Party's spiritual leader, and Liang Su-jung, president of the Association for the Promotion of Peaceful Unification, have visited mainland China within the past year, and both have said Wang has told them that "one China" does not necessarily refer to the PRC; that the official name and national anthem of a united-China-to-be can be discussed between the two sides; and that Beijing will not resort to force as long as Taipei does not declare independence.

Jaw remarked that what Taiwan people most worry about is that "one China" means the PRC and that Taiwan is merely one of China's provinces. He expressed his hope that Koo will seek clarification of these points during his meetings with Wang.

If Wang admits to having made these remarks, it would help to ease lingering doubts held by the people of Taiwan. If Wang were to deny having said those things, his denial would still help to clear the air, Jaw said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF ASIAN LIBERALS AND DEMOCRATS CONFERENCE TO OPEN FRIDAY

TEXT.P: A five-member delegation representing Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), to be led by DPP Central Standing Committee member Wu Nai-jen, is scheduled to arrive Thursday to participate in the two-day Council of Asian Liberals and Democrats Conference, which will open Friday.

On behalf of the leader of the Democrat Party, Thailand Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai will deliver an opening speech Friday morning. The theme of this conference will be political approaches to the region's financial crisis.

In the plenary session on Friday morning, three academicians and one journalist will discuss the political underpinnings of the Asian crisis. Thai Deputy Foreign Minister Sukhumbhand of the Democrat Party will chair the session.

In the plenary session on Saturday morning, four panelists including Martin Lee, the leader of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, will discuss the global and regional implications of the Asian crisis. Thai Foreign Minister Surin Pitsuwan of the Democrat Party will chair the session.

In a later plenary session, four panelists, including Abhisit Vejjajiva from the Democrat Party; Professor Ryaas Rasyid, head of the Indonesian government's political reform team and rector of the Institute for Government Affairs; the DPP's Wu; and Kim Nai-jen, a member of the South Korean Parliament, will discuss political and democratic reform at a session to be chaired by Hong Kong's Lee.
Saturday afternoon, the participating parties will explain their response to the Asian crisis before they sign a draft statement and hold a press conference.
Thailand Foreign Minister Surin Pitsuwan will speak at the closing ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL INVITES NOBEL PRIZE-WINNING PHYSICIST TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chao Jen-ho, chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, on Wednesday sent his congratulations to Chinese-American physicist Daniel Tsui on his winning this year's Nobel Prize for physics.
Tsui, 59, is a professor at Princeton University, New Jersey. He is a fellow of Academia Sinica, the premier academic research institution in the Republic of China on Taiwan.
In his message, Chao also invited Tsui to visit Taiwan at his convenience. Chao said Tsui's achievement is not only Tsui's personal honor but also an honor to all Chinese.

Tsui was awarded the Nobel Prize together with Professor Robert Laughlin of Stanford University and Professor Horst Stoermer of Columbia University for "discovering that electrons acting together in strong magnetic fields can form new types of particles, with charges that are fractions of electron charges."

Meanwhile, Academic Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1986, said in Puli Township in central Taiwan on Wednesday that Tsui is an outstanding scientist and that his winning the Nobel is to be expected.

Lee encouraged young men in Taiwan to follow the model set by Tsui and dedicate themselves to scientific research. He also expressed the hope that the quality of Taiwan's scientific research will improve so as to cultivate a new generation of Nobel Prize winners.
Tsui is the sixth Chinese-American to have won the Nobel Prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE FAIR ENDS IN TURKEY

TEXT.P: The two-day "1998 Autumn Taiwan Textile Fair in Istanbul" ended successfully Wednesday, with nearly 800 Turkish buyers visiting, according to Director Peter Huang of the Taiwan Trade Center Istanbul Office.

The exhibition was organized by the Taiwan Textile Federation and sponsored by the Taiwan Trade Center Istanbul Office. Huang told CNA that 26 exhibitors, selected for the creativity and high quality of their products, presented their wares at the show.
According to Huang, the exhibition aimed to introduce Taiwan's high-quality products to Turkey.

Huang pointed out that globalization has become the necessary measure adopted by Taiwan's textile industry. In addition to the internationalization of production and sales, Taiwan's manufacturers have endeavored to reduce costs and improve the quality and the designs of their products to meet the demands of international textile markets, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA TO PUSH FOR `ASEAN PARLIAMENT'

TEXT.P: The Philippines and Indonesia have agreed to push for the establishment of an "ASEAN parliament" to ensure "deeper and more meaningful" exchanges among member countries on political issues, a Philippine official said on Wednesday.

At a press conference in Indonesia after bilateral talks between Manila and Jakarta on Tuesday, Philippines Foreign Secretary Domingo Siazon Jr. said the two countries have also committed "to intensify cooperation in political areas."
"Maybe in the future we can have an `ASEAN Parliament,' patterned on the European Parliament," Siazon said.
Siazon, who conferred for more than an hour with his Indonesian counterpart Ali Alatas, expressed confidence that such a set up would strengthen relations among ASEAN countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SAYS BEIJING MAY CONTINUE DIPLOMATIC STRANGULATION

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that there is no sign that mainland China will relax its efforts to stifle Taiwan in the international arena.
There is also no guarantee that Beijing will not slap Taiwan in the face again after the first high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in more than five years, Hu said.

But he stressed the importance of communication between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, saying Beijing needs to understand that Taiwan seeks deserved space in the international arena, not independence.
He made the remarks while reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Committee on Taiwan's strategy to seek to join the United Nations.

But legislators were more concerned with the high-level cross-strait meeting as C. F. Koo, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, left on Wednesday for Shanghai via Hong Kong to meet with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
Hu said that not only is there no sign that the mainland will relax its attempts to strangle Taiwan diplomatically, there is evidence that such efforts will be stepped up.

Hu urged Beijing to have a consistent strategy if it wants to ease cross-strait relations. It cannot be soft and harsh at the same time -- on the one hand expressing hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can conduct talks, while at the same time trying to strangle Taiwan diplomatically, he said.
He stressed that he could not be sure that Beijing will demonstrate goodwill and sincerity after the Koo-Wang meeting.
Legislator Alice Kao of the opposition New Party asked if the Koo-Wang meeting would bring a truce to the diplomatic tug of war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Hu said the public should not hope for too much from the Koo-Wang meeting, saying that a truce would not bring about real understanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The important thing is that both sides of the Taiwan Strait communicate with each other, he said.
Taiwan has to let the mainland understand that the island needs breathing space in the world and is not trying to create "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas" or seeking independence, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO HOPES TO FIND RIGHT TRACK FOR CROSS-STRAIT DEVELOPMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said on Wednesday that he hopes to meet with his mainland counterpart to find an appropriate track for the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Koo made the remarks at a press conference in the Portman Ritz-Carlton Hotel shortly after his arrival in Shanghai. He noted that during his six-day visit to mainland China, he will have several meetings with Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Reviewing cross-strait relations, Koo said that after nearly a half-century of separation, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have had person-to-person contacts since 1987. In order to handle problems arising from the exchanges, Taipei and Beijing established SEF and ARATS.
Five years ago, Koo said, he and Wang met in Singapore and signed four agreements, laying a solid foundation for future exchanges and systematic negotiations.

The SEF chairman said that upon arriving in Shanghai, he saw the bustling trade and prosperity of the city, but pointed out that as cross-strait exchanges have increased rapidly, so too have the number of problems related to exchanges and visits.

He added that SEF and ARATS should resume negotiations to help the people of both sides to solve their urgent problems, as well as to work to solve problems related to cross-strait relations as a whole.
Koo and his entourage arrived at Shanghai airport at 3:42 p.m. He was accompanied by Tang Shubei, vice chairman of ARATS, to the press conference at the hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-AMERICAN NOBEL LAUREATE IS MODEST ABOUT HIS ACHIEVEMENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Princeton, New Jersey, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Professor Daniel C. Tsui of Princeton University said on Tuesday he is his usual self even after learning that he is a co-winner of the 1998 Nobel Prize in physics.
A modest yet humorous scholar, Tsui said jokingly at a news conference that one cannot be "too serious about" the Nobel Prizes.
Tsui, a devout Christian, later added: "We should always be grateful as our lives have many, many beautiful things."
He described scientific research as a funny, interesting and challenging work. "What a good thing that you are even regularly paid for doing such an interesting job."
Tsui has been teaching physics at the electric engineering department of the ivy-league Princeton University since 1982.
The Chinese-American scientist said his quiet, simple daily life will not have any change after becoming a Nobel laureate.

Tsui's colleagues and students at Princeton University praised Tsui for his devotion to his research and teaching career. "He is a diligent, serious scholar and teacher," said Harold Shapiro, Princeton University president.

Tsui was born in Henan in northern China in 1939. He and his elder sister managed to flee to Hong Kong in 1951. After completing his high school education on scholarship in Hong Kong, he came to the United States in 1958 to attend Augustana College in Rock Island, Illinois. He received his doctorate in physics from the University of Chicago and was appointed a professor at Princeton in 1982.
Tsui will share the US$978,000 prize with two other US-based physicists for discovering how electrons can change their behavior, work that can lead to further advances in microelectronics.
The two other outstanding scientists are Robert B. Laughlin of the United States and Horst L. Stoermer of Germany.

They discovered that ordinary electrons acting together in strong magnetic fields and very low temperatures can condense into new types of composite subatomic particles that function as a fluid, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said. Subsequently, other researchers confirmed their experiments and directly observed these new composites, known as quasiparticles.
According to the citation, the three men discovered a new form of ``quantum fluid'' _ fluids such as liquid helium that have certain properties in common, such as superfluidity.
What makes these fluids important for researchers is that they can reveal more about the inner structure and dynamics of matter.
It is ``yet another breakthrough in our understanding of quantum physics and to the development of new theoretical concepts of significance in many branches of modern physics,'' the academy said.
Mansour Shayegan, a colleague of Tsui's at Princeton, said all three have done wonderful work. "They have essentially discovered a new state of condensed matter,"' he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS' WANG POLITICAL CAREER SPANS HALF CENTURY

TEXT.P: Wang Daohan, who met with Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu in Shanghai, is commonly regarded as a "state teacher" of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

Currently chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) of mainland China, Wang was born in Anhui province in March of 1915 and graduated from Shanghai Jiaotong University.
In 1938 Wang joined in the Communist Party's army and served the party in a political, as well as in a military, capacity during the Eight-Year War of Resistance Against Japan.

From 1946 to 1949, Wang filled a variety of posts, including that of vice director of the finance and construction departments under the Jiangsu-Anhui remote-district government, political commissar for the central China and Shangdong military regions and director of finance for the Anhui administration.

After the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, Wang served as vice minister of the mainland's machine-building industry, vice minister of foreign economic liaison affairs and vice minister for the state commission on import-export management.

Between 1980 and 1985 Wang served as secretary of the Shanghai Municipal Committee, Shanghai vice mayor and Shanghai mayor. Succeeded by Jiang as mayor of Shanghai in 1985, Wang formally retired from politics.

But he never really retired from government service and was hired one year later as a consultant to the Shanghai city government. In 1991 he was tapped to head ARATS, an intermediary body set up to handle cross-strait affairs.
Wang served as a deputy to the fifth and sixth National People's Congress. He also holds several honorary titles, such as honorary chairman of the board of Shanghai Jiaotong University.

According to mainland media reports, Wang likes to read. Even though he generally works until midnight, Wang is said to frequently grab a book from the stack piled in front of his bed and read a little before falling asleep.

Wang has said that visiting book stores is his main hobby and that he buys new books every month. His wide-ranging reading interests encompass everything from literary criticism to scientific and technological theories.

Wang met with Taiwan's Koo in Shanghai Wednesday, after Koo arrived from Taipei for a six-day visit to the mainland. This is their first meeting since 1993, when Koo and Wang engaged in historic talks in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO BRING POLITICAL NEGOTIATIONS TO TABLE: FORMER DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said on Wednesday that mainland China does not expect tangible results to come from the first high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in five years.

What Beijing has in mind is to formally bring political issues to the negotiating table in meetings between C.F. Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, Hsu said.
Hsu said Beijing hopes the Koo-Wang meeting will signify the start of political dialogue and does not expect the meeting will result in anything tangible.
Hsu said that both sides could state their stances and that Taiwan should not give only perfunctory answers during these meetings.

He said that political dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not target only other side, but should also target the world. If Taiwan does not take advantage of this opportunity to publicize its cause internationally, it risks even stronger pressure in the future.

On the development of cross-strait relations after the Koo-Wang meeting, Hsu reaffirmed his two proposals. He suggested that the leaders across the Taiwan Strait meet with each other, adding that the very act of meeting will have rich political implications.
He also proposed that Taiwan agree to direct trade, postal and transportation links with the mainland in exchange for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization before mainalnd China's.
Hsu called Koo the ROC's best envoy, adding that the meeting between Koo and mainland President Jiang Zemin is a boon for the ruling Kuomintang in the face of year-end elections.
He explained that Beijing is extending an olive branch to President Lee Teng-hui by arranging such a meeting, which will allow Lee to take credit for easing cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESUMPTION OF SYSTEMATIZED NEGOTIATION CHANNEL SUGGESTED

TEXT.P: Chang Jung-kung, a researcher with the National Unification Council (NUC), said on Wednesday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume systematized negotiations to determine the extent of political barriers between Taiwan and mainland China.

Chang made the remarks after the first meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), at the Peace Hotel.
Chang, who is the deputy spokesman of Koo's delegation, also conveyed the view of Kang Ning-hsiang, another NUC member, at the meeting.

Kang said that in the past few years, more than 12 million Taiwanese people have visited the Chinese mainland and invested about US$20 billion. This has shown Taiwan's goodwill toward the mainland and its sincerity in improving cross-strait relations. He also noted that Taiwan has said it would not resort to force to resolve the cross-strait issue.

Chang said Koo suggested in his meeting with Wang that both sides should resume a systematized negotiation channel and that through negotiations the extent of the political barriers between the two sides of the strait can be determined.

Chang said the determination of such barriers could be helpful to future SEF-ARATS negotiations by expanding the number of topics that may be discussed, as well as by building confidence between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF RESUMING CROSS-STRAIT CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu on Wednesday stressed the importance of resuming the cross-strait consultation channel that has been suspended for three years.
He made the remarks in his first round of talks with Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), at Shanghai's Peace Hotel.
The main points of Koo's remarks during the talks, which lasted more than an hour, were disclosed to the media by SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-you.
Koo expressed the hope that the Shanghai talks would "create a good atmosphere" to promote normal operations by SEF and ARATS and eventually lead to the resumption of cross-strait consultations.

He said he earnestly expects that the current mainland trip will help pave the way for a second round of Koo-Wang negotiations. Koo and Wang held their first round of negotiations in Singapore in April 1993.
During their meeting, Koo and Wang frankly expressed their views on several important issues of mutual concern.
On the development of cross-strait relations, Koo said both sides should resume use of the consultation channel to continue the discussion of topics shelved by the suspension of the consultations.

The mainland side said cross-strait relations have entered a "political dialogue" period and that the "three links" -- a reference to direct trade, transportation and communication links -- should materialize promptly.

Koo said the two sides should be regarded as having equal political status and deserving of mutual respect, a condition that would produce more substantive results in upcoming bilateral consultations.

Koo pointed out that the Republic of China on Taiwan has already renounced the use of military force to solve cross-strait problems and that it has been engaging in active exchanges with the mainland.
On the other hand, he said, Beijing has not abandoned the use of force against Taiwan and has continued to obstruct Taiwan's participation in international activities.
Such moves, he said, would only deepen the antipathy of the Taiwan people and would not help to build mutual trust.

Koo told Wang that democratization and modernization have become irresistible trends in the world and that Taiwan is willing to share its experiences in political reform and economic development with the mainland.
The day's talks were held in a what was called a "quiet atmosphere."

Koo told Wang that the most important thing in the development of cross-strait relations at present is to resume use of the consultation channel, based on the agreements reached during their 1993 negotiations.

Wang indicated his hope that both sides would start to engage in political talks. But Koo suggested that SEF-ARATS consultations be resumed first. If difficult political issues were to then arise, both sides could approach discussions with a rational attitude, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS OFFICIAL TALKS ABOUT ENDING CROSS-STRAIT HOSTILITY

TEXT.P: Tang Shubei, vice chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), said in Shanghai on Wednesday that ending cross-strait hostility is the best way to protect the people's interests.
He made the remarks to the media at Shanghai's Peace Hotel after the first round of talks between ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
In order to formally terminate hostilities between the mainland and Taiwan, Tang said that both sides should begin to engage in political talks.
The ARATS deputy rejected Taiwan's claim that it has already renounced the use of military force and ended hostilities toward the mainland.
He cited Taiwan's reluctance to establish direct trade, transportation and communication links and its restrictions on mainland investment as evidence to substantiate his allegations.
Tang suggested that both sides discuss the development of cross-strait relations to safeguard the country's sovereign and territorial integration under the "one China" principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO WELL PRACTICED IN THE POLITICAL ARTS

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, who left for Shanghai Wednesday at the head of a Taiwan delegation on an "ice-breaking mission," is the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a semi-official institute with a government mandate to deal with mainland China.
Koo was born Jan. 6, 1917 in Tamshui, northern Taiwan, to a highly esteemed family that immigrated from Fujian, mainland China to Changhua, Taiwan.

He attended the Taipei Imperial University when the island was governed as a colony by Japan, and graduated from National Taiwan University, successor to the Taipei Imperial University, in 1940 after the island had been handed over to the Republic of China. He pursued postgraduate study at Tokyo's Japan Imperial University, the predecessor of Tokyo University.

While a freshman at the Taiwan Imperial University, Koo inherited his family's huge assets after his father died. Because of Koo's successful management skills, those assets have mushroomed into one of the most influential conglomerates in Taiwan, comprising some 91 companies.
Koo was ranked in 1990 by Forbes magazine as among the world's 181 billionaires and in 1998 as the 11th-richest person in Taiwan.

He is active in politics as well as in the business world, having had good relations with Taiwan's leaders over the years. His rich business experience and good command of both English and Japanese have aided him in his capacity as an envoy of President Lee Teng-hui. Koo attended a summit meeting of economic leaders in the Asia-Pacific region in 1995, 1996 and 1997 in place of Lee, who was excluded from the meetings as the result of pressure from Beijing.

With the full trust of President Lee, Koo was appointed SEF chairman in 1990. As SEF's chairman, Koo is Taiwan's point man in dealing with Beijing in the absence of formal ties. He was also named as a senior adviser to the president in 1991.
Koo is a well-known lover of Chinese opera, to which he was introduced as a child.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRECAUTIONS TAKEN AGAINST TYPHOON ZEB
DOC.DATELINE: Chungshing Village, Nantou, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Government on Wednesday set up its typhoon monitoring headquarters at a government building in Chungshing Village, and reminded the public to take precautions against Typhoon Zeb.

According to the Central Weather Bureau's latest report, Taitung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, as well as the offshore islet of Lanyu and Green Island, are all expected to be within Zeb's radius by late Wednesday, while the entire island is expected to be under the typhoon's influence by Thursday.

The report indicated Typhoon Zeb has weakened into a middle-strength tropical storm after whipping the northern Philippines. It is moving toward the southern part of Taiwan at about 15 kilometers per hour and has a radius of 350 kilometers.
Meteorologists said people living south of Hualien and Chiayi, as well as those in Penghu, should expect strong wind and torrential rains over the next two days.
The county governments of Taitung, Hualien and Pingtung have all announced government services and school activities will be suspended Thursday.

In anticipation of Zeb's approach, TransAsia Airways and UNI Airlines have canceled all their domestic flights on Thursday. Far East Air Transport will suspend all domestic flights on Thursday, except two Taipei-Makung morning flights, three Taipei-Kinmen morning flights and eight morning flights between Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTOR-TURNED-SOCIAL WORKER SUN YUEH HONORED

TEXT.P: Upon receiving an honorary doctoral degree in the humanities from a US university, former actor Sun Yueh attributed the honor to the grace of God.

Armstrong University in Berkeley, California, conferred the degree on Sun at Taiwan's National Library Wednesday. Witnessing the ceremony were representatives from such non-profit organizations as the John Tung Foundation, World Vision of Taiwan and the Organ Transplant Foundation, organizations to which Sun has extended a helping hand over the years.
Sun said that his life changed course after he learned the grace of God and that all credit for his achievements should go to the Almighty.
He, 68, said that receiving the doctoral degree would change nothing and that he will continue to follow the guidance of the Lord.

Rev. Chou Lien-hua, in presiding over the ceremony, noted that in the history of the Chinese performing arts, only Mei Lan-fang, a famed Chinese opera star, and Sun have been conferred with honorary doctoral degrees in the humanities.

He said that Mei was recognized because of his artistic achievement, while Sun has impressed others not only with his performances but also with his devotion to social work and charities in nearly two decades.

Sun, who rose to fame by playing rogues and scoundrels in the early days of motion pictures, won a Golden Horse Award -- Taiwan's equivalent to the Oscar -- for Best Actor in the picture "Veteran Mo's Second Spring."
Sun retired from the motion picture business after his conversion to Christianity in 1981. Since then he has devoted most of his time to charity causes.

Since retiring he has agreed to appear only in advertisements for charities or social causes and is best known his participation in an anti-smoking campaign in cooperation with the John Tung Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA TO CONSIDER ABANDONING US DOLLAR FOR TRADE

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada and Indonesian President Bacharuddin Jusuf Habibie agreed Tuesday to study ways to enhance trade between their two countries by using local currencies instead of dollars, Malacanang said Wednesday.

"During our casual talks (with Habibie), we proposed that products produced by the Philippines and Indonesia and traded between our two countries won't use dollars any more so we can save on our foreign currencies," Estrada said.

Estrada said the practice of using local currencies for trade between two member-countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is already being used between the Philippines and Malaysia.
"Mr. Habibie and I agreed that our economic managers will study the mechanics of using our own currencies in trade between our two countries," Estrada said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNAN URGES RIVAL PARTIES IN LESOTHO TO RESOLVE PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan Wednesday urged rival political parties in Lesotho to work to resolve outstanding issues so that a climate conducive to free and fair elections can be created.
In a statement read at multiparty talks Wednesday morning, Annan said "the UN stands ready to provide any assistance that will make the process a success."

The multiparty talks are being held in Lesotho's capital, Maseru. A spokesman for the Southern African Development Community said delegates of the ruling Lesotho Congress for Democracy and opposition parties will discuss how to make sure all parties have an equal chance in Lesotho's elections, to be held in 15 to 18 months.

The parties have said there will be robust debate on the issue of a government of national unity, which would rule the country until new elections are held. The opposition parties want the formation of such a government, but the ruling party has rejected the idea.
Lesotho became chaotic last month when supporters of opposition parties staged demonstrations, claiming May's general election was rigged. South Africa and Botswana intervened militarily on Sept. 22.

After the situation stabilized, the ruling party and opposition alliance began talks early this month. They agreed to hold new elections but disagreed on whether the ruling Lesotho Congress for Democracy should rule the country or whether a government of national unity should be established to rule the country until new elections are held.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE FOREIGN MINISTER WILL VISIT MAINLAND OCT. 15 TO 18

TEXT.P: The Minister for Foreign Affairs of Singapore, Professor S Jayakumar, will make an official visit to mainland China from Oct. 15 to 18 at the invitation of the mainland's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Tang Jiaxuan.
Jayakumar will visit Beijing, Shanghai and Suzhou during his trip. The purpose of the visit is to "further strengthen friendly bilateral relations and to promote greater cooperation."
In Beijing, Jayakumar will call on mainland Vice Premier Hu Jintao and meet with other mainland leaders, including Vice Premier Qian Qichen and Tang.
Jayakumar will also sign the Land Exchange Agreement for the chancery and consulate premises with Tang and the Memorandum of Understanding on Legal Cooperation with Procurator-General Han Zhubin.

In addition, both Jayakumar and Foreign Minister Tang will witness the signing of a Reciprocal Training Program, under which officials with the two countries' foreign ministries will receive training in the other country.

Jayakumar will also meet with Singaporeans living and working in Beijing and officiate at the opening ceremony of the Tai Ping Yang Underwater World, a joint venture between Singapore-listed Alliance Technology and Development Ltd. and Beijing Simulation Center, a unit of the Chinese Ministry of Aerospace.

In Shanghai, Jayakumar will meet local leaders and Singaporean businessmen. He will also make a visit to Suzhou where he will tour the Suzhou Industrial Park and meet with the leaders of Jiangsu and Suzhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo met with Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Shanghai on Wednesday.
The China Times: Koo and Wang divided over status of Taiwan.
The United Daily News: No consensus reached in the first day of Koo-Wang talks.
The Liberty Times: Koo dashed Beijing's hopes for political breakthrough.
The Independence Morning Post: No conclusion reached in the first-round of Koo-Wang talks.
The Commons Daily: Former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said that China gives a favor to Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang by arranging a meeting between Koo and mainland President Jiang Zemin.
The China Post: Island braces as typhoon Zeb hits.
The China News: Koo, Wang meet again in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG DWARF SPERM WHALE DIES

TEXT.P: A dwarf sperm whale which was grounded off Kaohsiung City Harbor two weeks ago died early Thursday morning despite efforts to save it.
Officials of the proposed Marine Life Museum said the exact cause of death has yet to be determined pending the results of an autopsy.

They suggested the whale died after experiencing difficulty in adjusting to its new environment. Since Tuesday, the whale began exhibiting emotional strain and was ramming itself against the walls of the pool which contained it.

The whale was about 6 months old, and weighed 25 kilograms when it was rescued by fishermen in Hsitzu Bay, Kaohsiung on Oct. 1. Upon examination, the whale was found to have sustained numerous injuries and subsequently was sent to the museum for treatment the next day.
Museum officials said the young whale had appeared to be recovering well and was being fed powdered baby formula and squid. They said they did not expect it to die so soon.
This was only the third time in the world that a baby whale born in the wild was being fed by humans, officials said, adding that they regretted that it did not work out.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO VISITS MAINLAND'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT FLAGSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo and CNA reporters)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Koo Chen-fu, and his entourage on Thursday visited the Pudong new district in Shanghai, mainland China's flagship of economic development in the 1990s.

Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday for the highest-level meeting across the Taiwan Strait in more than five years. Koo's tour of the mainland's largest city marked the veteran ROC ambassador-at-large's first visit to Shanghai in 53 years.
Koo's first stop of his Shanghai tour was not to visit his hometown, but instead the eight-year-old Pudong new district.

Pudong has been undergoing swift expansion since the late mainland paramount leader Deng Xiaoping went there in 1992 and instructed officials to develop it into a bellwether of economic development in the Yangtze River region and the Changjiang Delta area.

Under a strong push from the mainland authorities, Pudong turned into a showcase of reforms in the mainland during the 1990s. Its gross domestic product has grown 20 percent annually over the last several years, as compared with 7 percent to 10 percent growth posted by the city of Shanghai.
Koo and his party visited the Shanghai Stock Exchange Building located in Pudong's Lujiazui finance and trade area.

While at the fully-modernized stock exchange, Koo, founder of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, advised his Shanghai friends to observe laws and jurisprudence while keeping management transparent so as to usher the influential stock market onto higher-level operations.
Meanwhile, Koo's wife Yen Chuo-yun and daughter, who are accompanying him on this landmark trip, visited the Soong's family plot in a cemetery located in suburban Shanghai.
Yen, who is from a wealthy and respected Shanghai family, said Madame Chiang Kai-shek had asked her to sweep the tombs of her parents. Madame Chiang, Mayling Soong, is now living in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORST OF ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS SAID OVER

TEXT.P: The worst of the Asian financial crisis is over but recovery will progress slowly, the Los Angeles Times cited finance leaders and analysts as saying on Wednesday.
Recent signs have indicated that the worst appears to be over in the 15-month meltdown which has affected markets around the world, Mark Magrier wrote in the front-page article.

Stabilized Asian currencies and stock prices, declining interest rates and increased political resolve in Japan and elsewhere have contributed to growing optimism that the region has ended its downward spiral.
"I think it's going to be a long, hard road (to recovery)," said Brian Lippy, managing director of Tokai Asia Ltd., a hedge fund backed by Japanese capital. "But there's now some cautious optimism.
The most dramatic step has been Japan's approval this week of bank reform legislation and a beefed-up bailout, after months of political paralysis, wrangling and false starts.
Asia's recovery is very much dependent on continued US and European growth and Japanese stability. And Japan has given plenty of false starts before, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WELCOMES RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAITS DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Washington on Wednesday welcomed the resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait and reiterated its hope for a peaceful resolution to differences between the two sides.
Calling it a "positive development," James Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said the United States welcomes efforts by both sides "aimed at restoring a meaningful and substantive dialogue."

Commenting on scheduled meetings between Taiwan and mainland Chinese negotiators this week, the highest-level in more than five years, Rubin also reiterated the US position of not prescribing a solution to the cross-strait differences.

"Obviously the future is a question for the Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to resolve," he said, adding that the United States has an abiding interest that any resolution be peaceful.
Asked what Washington wants the two sides to achieve, Rubin said only that the goals are for the long-term issues to be resolved peacefully.
In the meantime, he said, the United States hopes that "concerns each side has about behavior or actions of the other can be discussed, talked through, and avoided if at all possible."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC, SEF REFUTE TANG'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued a statement Thursday, refuting a senior mainland Chinese negotiator's remarks on the root cause of the rupture of bilateral talks in mid-1995.

An emotional Executive Vice Chairman Tang Shubei of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), said in Shanghai on Thursday that Taiwan should be blamed for the disruption of cross-strait talks more than three years ago.

Tang made the accusation at a news conference held after an hour-long meeting in Shanghai's historic Peace Hotel between C.F. Koo and Wang Daohan, the two elder statesmen charged with shepherding Taiwan-mainland China ties in the absence of formal channels.
Commenting on Tang's allegation, the MAC said it was Beijing, not Taipei, that unilaterally shut the doors to cross-strait consultations.

The MAC pointed out that ARATS and its Taipei counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), held preparatory talks in Taipei in May 1995 to pave the way for a second meeting between SEF Chairman C. F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.
Tang himself came to Taipei for the preparatory talks, and the two sides reached consensus on eight key points for the proposed second Koo-Wang meeting, the MAC said.

However, ARATS formally informed SEF a month later of its decision to indefinitely postpone cross-strait consultations on the excuse that the atmosphere for bilateral engagement was spoiled by ROC President Lee Teng-hui's private visit to the United States in June 1995.

Over the past three years, the MAC said, mainland China has repeatedly balked at Taipei's call for the resumption of systematic dialogue and meetings between SEF and ARATS, the two quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
"This is a historical fact that nobody can deny," the MAC stressed in its statement, adding that Tang was wrong to blame Taiwan for the rupture of cross-strait dialogue.
"It was Beijing, not Taipei, that had reneged on the agreements signed by Koo and Wang during their historic first meeting in Singapore in April 1993 on systematic SEF-ARATS dialogue," the MAC noted.
During the lapse in talks, the MAC said, senior ROC officials from President Lee down had on more than 100 occasions called for an early resumption of systematic cross-strait consultations.

"ARATS had not responded to our appeals until February this year when it informed SEF that it agreed to reopen bilateral dialogue," the MAC said, adding that ARATS should not try to distort the facts.
Meanwhile, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing rebutted Tang's allegation that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have reached a consensus on the so-called "one China" principle.
"Tang's comment is misleading," Wu asserted.

He recalled that Beijing raised the "one China" principle when SEF and ARATS officials held talks in Beijing in March 1992 on some practical issues arising from increasing cross-strait civilian exchanges.
At that time, Wu said, SEF negotiators made it clear that the "one China" issue had nothing to do with bilateral talks on practical or technical matters.
The two intermediary bodies then started a lengthy exchange of views on the "one China" issue through fax and letters.
With the MAC's authorization, Wu said, SEF finally reached a consensus with ARATS that each side can make verbal explanations of its own definition of the "one China" concept.
According to Beijing's definition, there is only one China -- the People's Republic of China, and Taiwan is part of it.

However, Taipei sees "one China" as a goal rather than a current reality, and regards "China" in abstract terms -- as a historical, geographical and cultural entity but definitely not as the PRC, which by no means can be said to include the whole of China.

Taipei also insists that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now separately ruled by two equal governments and that the two sides can be unified only under the principles of freedom, democracy and equitable prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SINGAPORE JOINT STOCK LISTING COULD BEGIN MID-1999

TEXT.P: The plan allowing investors in Taiwan and Singapore to trade shares listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) and Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES) may begin by the middle of 1999, TSE Chairman C.Y. Lee said.

Speaking to reporters after a panel discussion on regional stock exchanges during the World Economic Forum, Lee said a 10-member negotiating team from the TSE is currently in Singapore to work out details of the dual listing plan. Issues that need to be ironed out include different regulations, reporting standards and disclosure policies.

SES President Lim Choo Peng said the pact with the TSE was not designed to compensate for the end of trading in Malaysian shares on Clob International as the plan was hatched before the start of the Asian crisis.
According to Lee, Singapore shares will likely be traded in New Taiwan dollars on the TSE, while Taiwanese stocks will trade in Singapore dollars on the SES.

The TSE, which closes earlier than the SES, will stay open longer for the trading of Singapore stocks. The plan is to include all TSE and SES stocks at the start, but over time, these might be reduced to stocks that are more liquid, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SAID TO SUGGEST LEE-JIANG MEETING AT APEC

TEXT.P: US pressure is said behind Taipei's suggestion that ROC President Lee Teng-hui and mainland President Jiang Zemin meet at the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leaders summit in Kuala Lumpur next month, the Australian reported.
Greg Sheridan, the daily's foreign editor, quoted Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi as saying the APEC summit would be a perfect setting for the two leaders to meet.
"APEC doesn't require enormous preparation, whereas a meeting here or in Beijing would," Su said.

The proposal will not likely be accepted by Beijing as it has long opposed Lee's direct participation in APEC, Sheridan wrote. However, the renewed flexibility both sides are showing each other is partly a result of US pressure as Washington has asked Taipei and Beijing to create a calm atmosphere across the Taiwan Strait, he added.

Sheridan said that while mainland China wants formal negotiations to lead to reunification with Taiwan, Taipei wants to delay the talks on reunification and instead discuss practical arrangements such as shipping and trade. If both sides understand the other side's differing agenda, any discussion should be useful, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN STOCK EXCHANGES FACE KEY ISSUES: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Top Asian Pacific stock exchange officials gathered in Singapore Wednesday under the auspices of the World Economic Forum to discuss promoting greater transparency, improving corporate governance and increasing regional cooperation.
"No market can survive without making itself more efficient, more transparent," said Yoshiaki Kaneko, senior managing director of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

The Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) has already embarked on a series of reforms, said SET chairman Amaret Sila-on. Quarterly reports must now include cash flow statements and related party transactions, and must be consistent with annual reports. Listed companies must also form external audit committees by the end of 1999.

In South Korea, listed firms must provide consolidated financial statements by 1999 and these must meet international accounting standards, said Hong In-kie, chairman and chief executive of the Korea Stock Exchange.
While it might be too early for a regional alliance because of major differences among individual exchanges, there is room for greater cooperation, said Kaneko.

Also calling for greater cooperation, Chiu Lee-hon, chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, said there is a need for stock exchanges to jointly look into the participation of large funds in emerging markets.

Meanwhile, Michael Shepherd, vice-chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX), noted that regional bourses exchanged information during the course of the regional crisis. The ASX has bilateral pacts with several Asian exchanges and hopes to enlarge these to multilateral agreements, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA TO USE THEIR CURRENCIES IN TRADING

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada and Indonesian President B.J. Habibie agreed on Tuesday to study ways to enhance trade between the two countries primarily by using their own currencies instead of US dollars.

During casual discussions, the leaders decided that goods traded between the two sides will not be paid for in US dollars so as to save foreign currency reserves, Estrada said in a news conference. This is a practice already in use between the Philippines and Malaysia.
The Philippine president traveled to Batam Island, which is being developed into an industrial center by Jakarta, at Habibie's invitation.
Estrada, accompanied by a small Philippine delegation, left Singapore for Batam after delivering a keynote speech at the 7th East Asia Economic Summit sponsored by the World Economic Forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELGIUM RADIO BROADCASTS REPORT ON KOO-WANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: As the top two negotiators on both sides of the Taiwan Strait met in Shanghai on Wednesday, halfway across the globe, Belgium's VRT Radio 1/Actueel reported that the relationship between Taiwan and the mainland was dancing on a tightrope.
Mike De Mulder, a journalist for the Dutch radio station, described the background in the antagonistic relationship between the two sides to listeners in Belgium and Holland.

Communist forces gained control of mainland China through military force in 1949 and compelled the Republic of China government to flee to the island of Taiwan. Since then, Beijing's communist leaders and Taipei's ruling Kuomintang have both claimed formal representative status as China, Mulder said.

During the Mao Zedong and Chiang Kai-shek eras on the mainland and Taiwan, strongly antagonistic sentiments dominated cross-strait relations. But the hostility eased after Chiang's eldest son and successor, Chiang Ching-kuo, began to implement reforms in pursuit of democracy and economic competitiveness.
After gradual political changes, the two sides across the Taiwan Strait began to pursue a course of peaceful engagement.
As time passed, Mulder said, talks began as well as cross-strait exchanges.

However, relations soured after ROC President Lee Teng-hui went to the United States on a private visit in 1995. Beijing, furious at what it saw as a veiled attempt to promote Taiwan independence, suspended talks between the two sides slated for later that year.

In 1996, Lee won a landslide victory, becoming the first popularly-elected president of Taiwan. However, ahead of the election, Beijing launched live missiles in waters off Taiwan's coast in an attempt to intimidate the electorate and further isolate Taiwan politically.
Subsequent attempts at cross-strait communication were blocked by deadlock.
With the latest meeting of Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan, top negotiators for Taipei and Beijing, the stalemate is apparently broken, the Dutch observer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS CRITICIZE KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Legislators from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday criticized the high-level meetings between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait just as they began.

Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, led a 12-member delegation to Shanghai on Wednesday for a six-day mainland visit. Koo met with his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, for the first round of talks later that day.

Legislator Yeh Chu-lan said remarks made by Tang Shubei, ARATS vice chairman, indicate there is a carrot-and-stick strategy at work among mainland leaders as they hold flowers in one hand and a sword in the other.

Tang said on Wednesday that political negotiation across the Taiwan Strait has begun. He also harshly criticized Taiwan's ban on three direct links -- trade, transportation and communication -- with the mainland, and its imposed investment limits on the mainland.

But Yeh said the mainland's strategy allows the people of Taiwan to clearly see Beijing's attempts to push Taipei to the political negotiation table. She asked Koo's delegation to clearly convey the wish of the 21 million people on Taiwan for an independent state to the mainland.
Beijing wants to define the meetings as political negotiations that would lead to the reunification of Taiwan and the mainland, while Taipei has wanted to talk about pragmatic matters.

Legislator Hung Chi-chang said that Tang's remarks highlight the fact the mainland still wants to strangulate the maneuvering space of Taiwan diplomatically under its "one China" principle, and Taiwan could not accept it.
Legislator Lin Cho-shui said that Taiwan's delegation should take the offensive instead of defensive posture, should not avoid political dialogue, and should use its trump card of democracy.
Koo Kuan-min, brother of Koo Chen-fu, said the mainland wants to continue to block Taiwan's breathing space in the international arena.

Koo Kuan-min, who has long been devoted to Taiwan independence, said although mainland China is important to Taiwan, the island should not wrongly assess the situation nor have too high expectations on these talks.

He said the real focus of the high-level meeting across the Taiwan Strait is his brother's meeting with mainland president Jiang Zemin, which may upgrade Taiwan's status and even that of his brother. But he questioned what price Taiwan should pay for such a meeting.

He stressed that Beijing wants to block Taiwan diplomatically, and said that if Taiwan has to consult with the mainland for everything, it would have no room to maneuver in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON ZEB REIGNS SUPREME OVER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Zeb, the strongest of the eight storms to visit Taiwan this year, is expected to encompass the entire island by midnight Thursday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported on Thursday.

In addition to strong winds, Zeb is expected to produce torrential rains over the next two days. Rains resulting from the typhoon could cause flash flooding, landslides and mud flows, CWB weather forecasters said.

Zeb was centered 250 kilometers south of Hengchun, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, at noon Thursday and is moving in a northerly direction toward central and northern Taiwan at a speed of 15 kilometers per hour, weather forecasters said.

After whipping through the northern Philippines, Zeb has weakened into a middle-strength typhoon, with its radius shrinking from 350 kilometers on Wednesday to 300 kilometers by noon Thursday. But the typhoon is still packing center winds of up to 45 meters per second.

The typhoon whipped through Pingtung early Thursday morning, battering the southernmost county of Taiwan with high winds and heavy rains. Statistics indicate 10.4 centimeters of rain fell in Pingtung within a few hours. No casualties have been reported.
The county governments of Pingtung, Taitung and Hualien announced government services and school activities would be suspended Thursday.
Heavy rains and the anticipation of Zeb's approach have disrupted air traffic to and from southern and eastern cities, as well as the offshore islands of Penghu, Green Island, Lanyu and Kinmen.

Far East Air Transport, which operated two flights each on its Taipei-Makung, Taipei-Kinmen and Taipei-Kaohsiung routes Thursday morning, joined all other domestic airlines in suspending all afternoon and evening flights.
International flights departing from and arriving at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, however, have not been affected by the typhoon.

As of noon Thursday, one fisherman was missing and presumed to have drowned in Taitung, one worker was killed by a fallen object and four others were stranded, while more than 4,000 homes islandwide were without electricity, according to the typhoon monitoring headquarters of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
The weather bureau warned people in central and northern Taiwan to be on guard, as Zeb is expected to sweep across the island in a northerly direction Thursday evening.

In the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau has organized an ad hoc typhoon command center and has suspended shipping between Kaohsiung and the offshore islands of Penghu and Kinmen.
In central Taiwan, more than 100 merchant vessels and fishing boats have sailed into Taichung Harbor and nearby Wuchi Port to seek shelter.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN TAIWAN DELEGATES TO MAINLAND TO ATTEND SECOND KOO-WANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Cheng Chun-liang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Beijing on Thursday agreed to allow seven members of Taiwan's mainland delegation to attend the second round of talks between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan.

The delegates who will attend the talks are Koo and his wife, Koo Yen Chuo-yun; SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow; Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng; two researchers with the National Unification Council -- Wu Rong-i and Pao Chung-ho; and Tszi Ying-wen, an adviser to the Mainland Affairs Council.

Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei and Zhang Zhiqun, director of Shanghai's Taiwan Affairs Office, are expected to participate in the talks, which are slated to take place from 4:15 p.m. to 5:45 p.m. Thursday at Jinjiang Tower Hotel.

The Taipei side is expected to mention the island's experience in political and economic development and the promotion of democracy. It has been learned that Taiwan delegates will also explain the reason why Taipei has maintained its ban on direct trade, transportation and communication links with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.281 against the greenback in Taipei Thursday, closing at 32.996.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 33.252, and had a high of 32.94.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$674.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS PRO-DEMOCRACY BODIES EXPRESS VIEWS ON KOO-WANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By K.C. Hwang and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The ultimate resolution of the cross-strait issue will hinge on the democratization of mainland China, according to a joint declaration made by pro-democracy organizations on Wednesday.

In response to the current meeting between Taipei's top negotiator with the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, a pair of groups working to promote democracy in mainland China -- the Overseas Preparation Committee of the Chinese Democracy Party and the Chinese Democratic Justice Party -- issued a joint declaration in New York.

Mainland political dissidents now living abroad have taken note of calls made by ROC Premier Vincent Siew to enhance the exchange of democratization experience, according to the statement. The declaration calls for the collaboration of various political bodies across the strait to promote mainland China's democratization, thus laying the foundation for a final resolution of the cross-strait issue.

In addition, it said that any suggestion or decision regarding Taiwan's future must respect the wishes of Taiwan's 21 million people. Likewise, any suggestion or decision regarding the well-being of the mainland's 1.2 billion people should reflect the wishes of those people, according to the statement.

Representatives of opposition parties both in Taiwan and in the mainland should be allowed to participate in future cross-strait meetings. This is the only way for the meetings to be acceptable to all people on both sides of the strait, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved down slightly on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropping 19.24 points to close at 6,799.88.
Trading was relatively light, as Typhoon Zeb swept across the island.
The bourse opened at 6,828.88 and fluctuated between 6,784.7 and 6,839.94.
A total of 1.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$5.4 billion (US$163.6 million).
Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 144, with 99 stocks unchanged.
Paper and pulp issues posted the largest gain, moving up 1.7 percent, while foodstuff stocks rose 0.5 percent.

Plastic and chemical shares dropped the most at 1 percent, followed by construction issues, which fell 0.8 percent; cement stocks, 0.7 percent; textile shares, 0.6 percent; and financial stocks, 0.3 percent. Electrical stocks remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN WELCOMES RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi on Thursday welcomed the resumption of high-level dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and expressed his hope that both sides continue the dialogue in the future.
Obuchi made the remarks while answering questions by Japanese journalists at the official residence of the premier.

Japanese media have widely reported on the first meeting between Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, in more than five years.
Koo, who led a delegation to Shanghai Wednesday, is on a six-day visit to the mainland.
The stance of Japan on cross-strait relations has been that it hopes that both sides can resolve their differences peacefully.
Obuchi's words that both sides should peacefully resolve their differences through dialogue reaffirmed his country's position.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HAS NOT RULED OUT INVITING ARATS CHAIRMAN TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taipei has not ruled out the possibility of inviting Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to visit Taiwan after Taipei's top envoy to the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, concludes his meetings with Wang, said ROC mainland affairs policy-making officials on Thursday.

Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), did not mention the invitation during his meeting with Wang Wednesday. It is possible, however, that Koo will issue the invitation during his meeting with Wang Thursday afternoon, according to the sources.
The date of the visit must be discussed between Koo and Wang or between SEF and ARATS, Taipei officials said.

To improve cross-strait relations and enhance the systemization of a channel for negotiation between the two sides, a consensus has been reached among Taipei's policy-making officials that cross-strait visits by the top officials of both bodies are necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT GAP SEEN WIDENING: REPORT

TEXT.P: There has been economic integration between Taiwan and mainland China in the past decade, but the gulf between the two sides in political, social and cultural terms is widening, according to an unnamed Western analyst.

In a dispatch from Beijing titled "Thaw Across Taiwan Strait," The Australian reported the current talks between representatives from Taiwan and mainland China in Shanghai showed signs of a thaw in the ice-cool relations between the two sides.
The talks resumed following a long period of suspension since the first contact was made in Singapore in 1993.
But few analysts believed the talks would produce any breakthroughs in the short- or medium-term.

The daily quoted a Western analyst in Beijing as saying "The big conundrum is that there has been a decade of economic integration, but the gulf between the two in political, social and cultural terms is widening all the time."

"Taiwan sees itself as a rival central government and Beijing sees the situation as one central government and one provincial government -- there can be no breaching that gulf unless they can fudge that central contradiction," he said.
The analyst said that, for the past 49 years, Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province and has yet to rule out the use of force to achieve its ultimate goal of reunification.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE YUAN COULD APPRECIATE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Western observers have underestimated mainland China's historic sense of self-containment and Chinese economists predict the yuan will not be devalued, but will instead appreciate, despite the marginal impact of the Asian economic crisis on the mainland.

In a dispatch from Beijing, Australian Financial Review correspondent Rowan Callick reported that a recent AT Kearney survey revealed the following truths, unlikely as they may seem, about mainland China's economy:
--Mainland China no longer cares about joining the World Trade Organization;
--Mainland China is being only marginally affected by Asia's financial turmoil;
--Mainland China is "marketizing" its economy -- but its private sector, beyond the farms, is struggling to survive; and
--More than one-third of all international companies operating in mainland China are losing money.
