The daily reported that as a reward for mainland China's apparent self-sacrifice in maintaining the value of its currency, and in order to lock mainland China into any fresh attempts to regulate the global economy, US Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin is considering inviting mainland China to join the G7.

The daily quoted two Chinese economists as predicting that mainland China's central bank will begin to offload its foreign exchange holdings of about US$140 billion to make way for the purchase of treasury bonds to help stimulate the economy, which will in turn drive the yuan higher.
The daily reported mainland China has been shielded from the adverse impact of short-term capital flows by the non-convertibility of its currency.
The economists said the yuan could appreciate between 10 percent and 15 percent in the next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA EXPECTS LITTLE FROM KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: The historic meeting that began Wednesday between the negotiators of mainland China and Taiwan "will not likely result in any significant move toward the Communist government's goal of taking back Taiwan," a major Canadian newspaper reported Wednesday.

Although no major results are expected from the talks, the visit by Taiwan's Koo Chen-fu is "a significant thaw in the often- fractious relations between the tiny but well-armed island and its giant neighbor to the north," wrote Globe and Mail correspondent Miro Cernetig.

Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is expected to give Koo a message on reunification for Koo to deliver to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, the daily reported, noting Jiang's meeting with Koo will be "the only such contact from Beijing's top leader since Mao Zedong's army drove out" Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist forces in 1949.
This is the first report by a major Canadian newspaper on the historic meeting between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS VIOLATE MALAYSIA'S NEW CURRENCY RESTRICTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Chin Yok-pin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Malaysian Customs officials at Sabah's Kota Kinabalu Airport recently confiscated a total of 33,000 ringgit (US$8,684) from four Taiwan tourists.
Malaysia on Sept. 1 announced new currency restrictions that stipulate no more than 1,000 ringgit may be taken into or out of Malaysian territories by either local residents or foreigners.
Travelers are permitted, however, to carry as much foreign currency, including traveler's checks, as they wish, provided they register their holdings. The restrictions went into effect Oct. 1.
Violators risk confiscation of their money, fines and imprisonment, according to customs authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO MEETS TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN SHANGHAI
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Huang Wen-tsung and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said in Shanghai on Thursday that he expects mainland China and Taiwan will discuss measures to protect Taiwan businessmen on the mainland at an early date.

The top negotiator for Taiwan arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday at the head of a 12-member delegation for talks with Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
The Taiwan Enterprises Association in Shanghai played host to a luncheon in honor of Koo and his delegation at a local restaurant.
The president of the Taiwan Enterprises Association, Yang Ta-cheng, said that some 3,000 Taiwan companies have been doing business in Shanghai and have invested more than US$3 billion in the city.
He joked that more than half of the Taiwan investors in Shanghai had begun to turn a profit, but that doing had either turned their hair gray or cost them their hair altogether.
Koo praised the Taiwan businessmen for their contributions to the development of the mainland's economy and to the promotion of favorable exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland.

Because cross-strait relations have not yet been normalized completely, Koo expressed the hope that his mainland trip will lead to discussions on the protection of Taiwan businessmen's interests on the mainland at an early date.
Along with the growth of cross-strait trade, Koo said that the number of trade-related disputes has increased as well. As of the end of August, he said, SEF had handled some 480 such cases.

Koo said he expects the mainland and Taiwan will engage in discussions on the protection of Taiwan's investments on the mainland. This will also be helpful for the improvement of the mainland's investment climate and for the creation of a society whose laws are fully enforced, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REGARDS KOO-WANG TALKS AS 'CONSTRUCTIVE DIALOGUE': MAC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China regards the ongoing talks in Shanghai between the top negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait as "constructive dialogue," a senior mainland affairs official said on Thursday.

Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the statement in response to a senior mainland Chinese negotiator's remark on Wednesday that cross-strait "political dialogue" has got under way.

Sheu said as Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of the Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), didn't detail what the "political dialogue" means, he could not make any comments.

Nevertheless, Sheu said the ROC government considered as "constructive dialogue" the current talks in Shanghai between C. F. Koo and Wang Daohan -- the two elder statesmen charged with shepherding Taipei-Beijing ties in the absence of formal channels.
"As the current Koo-Wang meetings provide a forum for the two sides to exchange views freely and frankly in a calm, amiable atmosphere, we consider them as 'constructive dialogue,'" Sheu said.
Noting that straight talks are better than mutual suspicion, Sheu said candid explanations of each side's basic stances on various issues will help boost mutual understanding.
Commenting on Tang's allegation that Taiwan should be held responsible for the disruption of cross-strait talks in mid-1995, Sheu said Tang was wrong to place the blame on Taiwan.
"It was Beijing, not Taipei, that unilaterally shut the doors to cross-strait consultations more than three years ago," Sheu said.

He pointed out that ARATS and its Taipei counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), held preparatory talks in Taipei in May 1995 to pave the way for a second meeting between SEF Chairman C. F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.
Tang himself came to Taipei for the preparatory talks, and the two sides reached consensus on eight key points for the proposed second Koo-Wang meeting, Sheu recalled.

However, ARATS formally informed SEF a month later of its decision to indefinitely postpone cross-strait consultations on the excuse that the atmosphere for bilateral engagement was spoiled by ROC President Lee Teng-hui's private visit to the United States in June 1995.

"This is a historical fact that nobody can deny," Sheu stressed, adding that it was Beijing, not Taipei, that had reneged on the agreements signed by Koo and Wang during their historic first meeting in Singapore in April 1993 on systematic SEF-ARATS dialogue.
Responding to Tang's calls for an end to cross-strait hostilities and the opening of direct mail, trade and transportation links, Sheu said the ROC's stances on such issues are quite clear.

"Our stance on the direct 'three links' is that they can be opened only when the safety and well-being of the people on both sides of the strait can be well protected and quaranteed," Sheu said, adding: "Taiwan is willing to negotiate the 'three links' issue only if Beijing can face up to the reality that the two sides of the strait are now separately ruled by two equal governments or entities."

As for the end of hostilities, Sheu said, Taiwan already renounced the use of force in resolving cross-strait issues in May 1991 when President Lee declared the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion.

"It is contradictory that Beijing, while calling for an end to cross-strait hostilities, has been unwilling to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and has continued its relentless campaign campaign to try to isolate the ROC by blocking the nation's presence in the international community," Sheu explained.
Sheu went on to say that the two sides already reached a consensus after the first Koo-Wang meeting that each side can hold its own definition of the "one China" concept.

"Beijing should not unilaterally force us to accept its 'one China' concept, and should instead recognize the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been separately ruled by two equal governments since 1949," Sheu said, adding that with this recognition, the two sides can then treat each other on an equal footing and enable bilateral ties to make headway.

Sheu also urged Beijing to resume systematic SEF-ARATS dialogue and consultations as soon as possible to address practical matters related to the protection of personal safety and legitimate rights and interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG SAYS KOO WILL CONVEY PEOPLE'S ASPIRATIONS TO BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Wufeng township, Taichung County, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said Thursday he believes C.F. Koo, chairman of Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), will convey the aspirations of the people of Taiwan to Beijing.
He made the remarks during questioning by Taiwan Provincial Assembly member Chou Hui-ying of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
Chou had asked whether Song, during a recent visit to Singapore, had asked senior minister Lee Kuan Yew to convey a message to Beijing.
Soong replied that he would neither recklessly stir up trouble for Singapore nor introduce apprehension into its dealings with Beijing.
"We should respect other countries instead of asking for trouble," he added.

Song said that in a side-by-side comparison, Taiwan's political system is superior to the mainland's. The validity of Taiwan's system, in line with current global trends, has been affirmed throughout the world, he said.
Taiwan's economy is more advanced than the mainland's as well, he said.

Commenting on the Taipei mayoral race, Soong said candidates should focus on issues rather than engage in verbal attacks or "battles of saliva." He also warned against raising ethnicity as an issue in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE MEMBERS FROM KOO'S DELEGATION WILL MEET WITH JIANG ZEMIN
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Five members from Taipei's delegation to the talks between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan will meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing on Oct. 18.

SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-you disclosed this at a press conference on Wednesday night. He said the namelist was still being reviewed between SEF and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
But it has been learned that the five members who will represent the Koo delegation to meet with President Jiang are Koo Chen-fu, Mrs. Koo, Kang Ning-hsiang, Chang Jung-kung and Shi Hwei-you.

Koo arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday at the head of a 12-member delegation to hold talks with Wang Daohan at the Peace Hotel. Both sides frankly exchanged views on various issues related to the development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S WIFE VISITS SOONG FAMILY PLOT ON BEHALF OF MADAME CHIANG
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The wife of C.F. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, paid a visit to the graves of the parents of former ROC first lady Madame Chiang Kai-shek at a cemetery in suburban Shanghai on Thursday.

Koo-Yen Chou-yun, who arrived with her husband in Shanghai on Wednesday for the highest-level contacts across the Taiwan Strait in more than five years, told reporters that she was visiting the grave at Madame Chiang's request.

As secretary-general of the National Women's League of the Republic of China, Mrs. Koo said she maintains regular contact with Madame Chiang, who founded the league decades ago and has lived in New York since the passing of her husband, Generalissimo Chaing Kai-shek.
"After learning that I was to visit Shanghai, Madame Chiang asked me to lay a wreath before her parents' graves to convey her tribute and remembrance to them on her behalf," Mrs. Koo said.
Accompanied by her daughter and personal aides, Mrs. Koo arrived at the Soong family plot at 11 a.m.

She first laid a wreath before a tombstone bearing an inscription saying that it was erected in the name of the six Soong children in August 1932. Mrs. Koo then placed a bouquet of fresh flowers before the grave of Madame Chiang's father, Soong Yao-ju, and another before the grave of her mother, Ni Kuei-chen.

Because of political reasons, Madame Chiang, whose maiden name is Soong Mayling, has not set foot in mainland China for 50 years. "She has told me on many occasions that her mother, a devout Christian, has had profound influence on her marriage and career. Madame Chiang said she still feels pain and grief when she remembers her mother," Mrs. Koo said.

Madame Chiang was once considered the most powerful woman in China. Her life has been inextricably linked with the history of modern China and Taiwan. She became widely known in the West as a spokeswoman, in elegant English learned at Wellesley College in Massachusetts, for the Chinese cause against the invading Japanese in the 1930s.

After the Chinese communists took control of the mainland in 1949, Madame Chiang and her husband retreated to Taiwan. The couple became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbol. Generalissimo Chiang served as ROC president until his death in Taipei in 1975.

The tomb of Madame Chiang's elder sister, Soong Qingling, is located on the right of her parents' graves. Mrs. Koo, however, didn't lay a bouquet before her tomb. "Madame Chiang didn't ask me to do so," Mrs. Koo explained.
Soong Qingling, widow of the ROC's national founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen, once served as communist China's honorary president. She died in 1981 at age 88.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND'S OLYMPIC COMMITTEE CHIEF TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Wu Shaozu, president of Beijing's Olympic Committee, will lead a nine-member delegation to Taiwan via Hong Kong on Friday, according to press reports from Beijing.
The reports said Wu will come to Taiwan for an eight-day visit at the invitation of Huang Ta-chou, president of the Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee.
Wu's main purpose in coming is to attend the second cross-strait sports exchange symposium, to be held on Oct. 22.

Major topics to be discussed at the symposium will include the creation of unified windows for sports exchanges; the exchange of visits by researchers on physical education; the training of a new generation of athletes and the unification of the sports terminology used by the two sides.
The visiting delegation will also visit Ilan's Tungshan River, a training center for athletes in Tseying, Mt. Ali and Kenting during their stay in Taiwan.
Wu will also be invited to attend the closing ceremony of the 1998 Straits Cup Golf Tournament on the evening of Oct. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTINUING TALKS ARE SUCCESSFUL TALKS: NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: The current talks between Taipei's top negotiator with the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, are significant not because any concrete results are expected from them but because they will be regarded as a success as long as they do not reach an impasse, said a heavyweight within Taiwan's New Party.
Wang Chien-shien, the New Party's candidate for Taipei mayor, remarked on Thursday that the cross-strait dialogue can be seen as a success as long as it does not end in a stalemate.

If the discussion of political issues proves too difficult, practical matters of mutual concern can be discussed instead, he said. The most important thing, he said, is that discussions not be regarded as a game to be won or lost.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO DELEGATION MUST CONVEY TAIWAN'S STANCE: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Chiu Yi-jen, secretary-general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said on Thursday that the prime task for C.F. Koo's delegation in mainland China is to firmly express its position instead of focusing on other details.

Chiu was referring to remarks made by Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), who claimed on Wednesday that the meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo and his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, represents the start of cross-strait political negotiations.
Tang's remarks provoked widespread criticism in Taiwan, and he was accused of adopting a tough stance toward Taiwan.
Koo embarked on a historic visit to mainland China on Wednesday at the head of a 12-member delegation. Soon after his arrival, he had the first of several meetings with Wang.
The Koo-Wang meeting represents a major improvement in bilateral ties after a hiatus of more than five years, although no breakthrough is expected to result from this round of discussions.

Mainland China has insisted on focusing the meeting on discussion of political issues based on the "one China" principle, while Taiwan said technical issues of major concern to the interests of the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait should take precedence on the agenda.

In contrast to the strong criticism at home, Chiu said Tang's remarks should not have come as a surprise, and that the Taiwan delegation should have been able to foresee such a development. He added that Taiwan should not waste time on issues such as the mainland side's attitude, manners, or courtesy.

According to Chiu, the most important thing for Koo's delegation to do is to firmly spell out its viewpoints to the mainland. He hailed the delegation's performance as "on the right note so far," and asked the public not to judge Koo and his entourage too harshly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PETA HAILS TAIWAN'S ENACTMENT OF ANIMAL PROTECTION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US-based People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) hailed on Wednesday the passage by Taiwan's legislature of a tough animal protection law.
The animal rights promotion group said the new legislation marks an initial victory in its campaign for protecting the large number of stray dogs in Taiwan.

PETA President Ingrid Newkirk presented a basket of fresh flowers to the Republic of China's representative office in Washington, D.C. to express the group's happiness and appreciation of the passage of the island's first animal protection legislation.
Newkirk said she is delighted to learn that the ROC's Legislative Yuan has finally completed a third reading of the much-anticipated animal protection law on Tuesday.

"We hope Taiwan will then take positive steps to streamline its some 70 stray animal shelters or pounds now that the new act has provided its administrative agencies a solid legal basis to crack down on unethical treatment of animals," Newkirk said.

Meanwhile, the PETA has launched a worldwide campaign, asking all animal rights activists to write letters to senior ROC officials to push for immediate improvement of the management of Taiwan's public stray animal shelters.

The organization also unveiled on its Internet website the residential addresses, E-mail addresses and fax numbers of several ROC officials, including Premier Vincent Siew, the Taoyuan County magistrate, and the mayors of Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Sanchung and Chungho cities.
The PETA said Taiwan should immediately clean up its public stray animal shelters to offer a clean living environment for stray animals.

The organizations also proposed several other measures that Taiwan should take immediately, including offering adequate food and water to dogs kept at the public shelters; stopping the use of "cruel methods" to kill ailing stray dogs; separating stray dogs based on their gender and size; cooperating with experienced animal protection groups to gain expertise in managing animal shelters.
The PETA has lobbied strongly in the past two years to push Taiwan to legislate an animal protection law.
Under the new law, people who fail to treat their pets ethically will face harsh punishment.
According to official tallies, Taiwan currently has about 1.7 million stray animals, mostly dogs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TO WOO TAIWAN, BEIJING HAS TO CHANGE ITSELF: COLUMNIST

TEXT.P: Taiwan won't have much interest in closer ties to mainland China until Beijing's political system starts to look more like that of Taiwan, a columnist said in an article carried Wednesday by the Philadelphia Inquirer.

In the article dispatched from Taipei, titled "Beijing finally sees that voters will determine Taiwan's future," Trudy Rubin said threats and scare tactics won't persuade Taiwanese to reunite with the mainland. Divided from the mainland since 1949, Taiwan has developed into a democracy with no interest in speedy reunification with a communist regime, the columnist said.

She said Beijing seems to have recognized the crucial fact about Taiwan: This island is a democracy, whose future political behavior depends not on one strongman, but on its voters. "And muscle-flexing won't win support from the Taiwanese people." Polls show that Taiwanese overwhelmingly support the status quo, with only about 15 percent favoring reunification later on.

To score points with the Taiwanese, mainland China will have to become more attuned to dealing with a democracy, she said, adding that Beijing will have to get more sophisticated in its understanding of Taiwanese politics.
The columnist quoted a Taiwan political researcher as saying that "The only solution that Beijing has is to change itself in order to attract Taiwan to be closer to China."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA: TAIWAN IS ROC TERRITORY WITHOUT ANY DOUBT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has been a sovereign country since its founding in 1912, and Taiwan is the territory of the Republic of China without any doubt, Roy Wu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said Thursday.

The spokesman made the statement when asked by the press to comment on the remarks made Wednesday by mainland Chinese negotiator Wang Daohan that the "political status of Taiwan" should be discussed on "the premise of one China."

Wu said historical facts as well as the Cairo Declaration of 1943, the Potsdam Declaration of 1945, and the agreement on Japan's surrender signed on the US battleship Missouri on Sept. 2, 1945 have all clearly attested that Taiwan is the territory of the Republic of China, whose government has existed since 1912 without a moment of interruption.
The unilateral remarks made by the communist Chinese negotiator about the so-called "political status of Taiwan" is historically baseless, and is not acceptable, the spokesman said.
Wang made the remarks when he met with his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the semi-official Strait Exchange Foundation, in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL NOT CUT INTEREST RATES: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Despite the global trend toward more relaxed interest rates, mainland China will not cut interest rates again for fear of aggravating capital flight from the country, a senior mainland China treasury official said on Thursday.
Previous interest rate cuts have not been effective, said Lou Jiwei, executive vice minister of finance, who was in Singapore for the World Economic Forum's East Asia Economic Summit.
According to Lou, the current interest rates are not very high. Companies with good fundamentals can live with them, and those in bad shape will not be helped by another cut.
Mainland China has cut interest rates five times in the past two years, but has failed to stem the economic slowdown.

Any new cut now would be detrimental to the stability of the renminbi's exchange rate in view of the high interest rate environment, particularly in Hong Kong - the chief destination of the mainland's capital flight, Lou noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TAKES ASBESTOS DISPUTE WITH FRANCE TO WTO

TEXT.P: Canada has decided to take a dispute with France over asbestos to the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO).

Canada's International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi and Natural Resources Minister Ralph Goodale said they were asking the WTO to establish a dispute settlement panel for the resolution of the Canadian complaint against the French ban on chrysotile asbestos, according to reports from the WTO on Thursday.
The French ban was introduced on January 1, 1997.
In a statement, Marchi said: "Last May, we formally requested and obtained consultations with France, the first step in the WTO dispute settlement process.

"Unfortunately, this process did not enable Canada and France to find a mutually satisfactory resolution to this issue and we believe that it is time to have the WTO rule on this dispute which we have been attempting to resolve for the past two years."

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG MEETING HOLDS PROMISE: SINGAPORE NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: According to a article in Singapore's The Straits Times on Thursday, both mainland China and Taiwan have proved they can co-exist with differing interpretations of "one China."

The article said the visit to mainland China of the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), C.F. Koo, marks the long-overdue resumption of high-level cross-strait dialogue between the SEF and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), headed by Wang Daohan.
Both sides have cautioned against expecting too much from this meeting, but the mere fact that they are meeting again is promising, the article said.
Taiwan accepts "one China" as a goal but not a current reality, and points out that two separate political entities exist, with no one exercising jurisdiction over the other.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO CALLS ON SHANGHAI BOURSE TO LIFT RESTRICTIONS ON TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Huang Wen-tsung & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), called on Thursday for the lifting of restrictions on Taiwan investors, who currently can purchase only B stocks on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
After touring the Shanghai Stock Exchange, the visiting SEF head said broader access to the Shanghai bourse for Taiwan investors will facilitate their integration into the local business sector.

Noting the difficulties involved in establishing and running a stock exchange, Koo emphasized the importance of cast-iron and comprehensive regulations to regulate stock transactions, and the need for transparency in the management of the bourse, according to Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of the SEF, who is a member of the 12-strong delegation accompanying Koo on his historic four-day trip to mainland China.
Shi quoted the Taiwan business tycoon as saying that opaque management will add to investors' frustration, already high because of the ups and downs of stock prices.

Since both Taiwan and mainland China have weathered the Asian financial storm with relative little damage, Koo suggested that the two sides jointly invite their harder-hit neighbors to find a way to help them get through the crisis.
Koo, who arrived here on Wednesday, visited the Pudong commercial area in suburban Shanghai, and a financial center, earlier on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY TO REPUBLIC OF SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE NAMED

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Thursday approved the appointment of Hsiang Yen-chu as ambassador of the Republic of China to the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe.
He will succeed Amb. Sainting Kung, who is concurrently ROC ambassador to Burkina Faso.

Hsiang, 55, a graduate of National Chengchi University, is a career diplomat who has served in Uruguay, Costa Rica, and Portugal. Prior to his new appointment, he was deputy director of the Central & South American Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO FORMALLY INVITES WANG TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Tseng Tsung-liang, Yang Hui-chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu on Thursday formally invited his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, to visit Taiwan at an "appropriate time."
Wang, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), accepted Koo's invitation verbally and said he would be happy to visit Taiwan at the appropriate time.

Speaking on behalf of Koo, SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-you told the media that it is hoped that Wang will be able to visit Taiwan at the end of November or in early December, so that he can observe the campaigns for the year-end legislative elections.
Shi said Koo's invitation, and Wang's acceptance, were made during the second round of discussions between Koo and Wang which took place on Thursday afternoon in Shanghai.

Questioned about the issue, ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei said that November or December may be too soon to allow arrangements for such a visit to be made, pointing out that it took several months to organize Koo's current mainland trip after ARATS extended its invitation.
He declined to suggest the most appropriate time for Wang to visit Taiwan, saying only: "Chairman Wang has not given us any instructions," on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT INVESTIGATING ROLE OF MAINLAND CHINA CAPITAL IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo said on Thursday that the government is actively probing the role of mainland Chinese capital in Taiwan's year-end elections.

Responding to inquiries raised by Legislator Tsai Huang-lang, Cheng said the Investigation Bureau under the Justice Ministry has gained some information regarding the issue, but that he could not divulge details because the probe has already started.

Earlier this month, at an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, Tsai claimed that mainland Chinese capital has infiltrated the campaigns for Taiwan's legislative elections, as well as the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral and council elections, both slated for December, in the following ways:
-- cultivating certain candidates around the island to serve as mainland China's spin doctors.

Tsai also handed Cheng the names of three candidates who will take part in this year's legislative election in central Taiwan, and asked him to immediately investigate their alleged links with mainland capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS DEPUTY: KOO, WANG REACH FOUR-POINT CONSENSUS
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The second round of discussion between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Shanghai on Thursday is said to have produced a four-point consensus.
Tang Shubei, ARATS vice chairman, told the media that the four-point consensus is as follows:

-- The SEF and ARATS have decided to engage in dialogues to discuss diverse subjects, including political and economic issues. Concrete arrangements for dialogues will be made through consultations between SEF and ARATS leaders;

-- The two organizations have decided to further step up bilateral exchanges, including exchanges of visits by missions headed by SEF and ARATS leaders, board directors and supervisors, advisers, and deputy secretaries-general;
-- The two organizations will strengthen assistance in incidents involving the lives and property of Taiwan people when visiting mainland China, and vice-versa; and
-- Koo invited Wang to visit Taiwan. Wang expressed his appreciation and said he would be happy to visit Taiwan at "an appropriate time" to gain more understanding of the Taiwan situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG TALKS PROMISING: US EXPERT

TEXT.P: Both mainland China and Taiwan have proved that they can co-exist with differing interpretations of "one China," according to an American expert in Asian security affairs.

Ralph A. Cossa, executive director of Pacific Forum at the Washington-based Center for Strategies and International Studies, wrote in the latest PacNet Newsletter that both Beijing and Taipei have cautioned against expecting too much from the long-overdue resumption of high-level cross-straits dialogue, but the mere fact that the Koo-Wang talks have finally resumed is promising.

Both Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), are highly trusted close personal advisors to their respective presidents. The decision to schedule a courtesy call for Koo with mainland China's President Jiang Zemin is a sign of the importance that Beijing attaches to resumption of the talks, Cossa said.

There are a number of outstanding issues to be addressed, including the eventual signing of a peace treaty between the two sides. But there are two core issues that must also be addressed before real progress toward cross-strait reconciliation can be experienced, noted Cossa.
One involves each side's different interpretation of "one China," and the other concerns Beijing's refusal to renounce the use of force as a means of achieving reunification.
Defusing the "use of force" issue could help improve the atmosphere for cross-strait dialogue and remove a major impediment in Sino-US cooperation, said the expert.

One option is for Beijing to issue a statement that, "as long as Taiwan continues to pursue the goal of eventual reunification and rejects a `two Chinas' or `one China, one Taiwan' solution, Beijing can envision no scenario under which the use of force would be required to bring about this mutually-desired end state," Cossa said.

He explained that implicit in such a statement is the recognition that a change in Taiwan's currently stated policy would negate this pledge. But also implicit is a continued willingness by Beijing not to force the issue or establish an artificial timetable or deadline for reunification.

This would help create a more positive atmosphere and perhaps open the door for a bit more flexibility regarding the "third no" of President Bill Clinton's policy toward Taiwan, which is especially important to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, according to Cossa.

Neither side appears to fully understand or appreciate the other's concerns. The fact is, any long-term solution must take Taiwan domestic attitudes and conditions into account, just as Taipei (no less than Washington) must continue to recognize the unyielding nature of Beijing's commitment to eventual reunification, said Cossa.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB DIRECTOR HEADS FOR US

TEXT.P: Wang Kwang-yu, director of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, departed on Thursday for the United States to attend an international police meeting in the state of Utah.

In addition to the 10-day conference during which Wang will exchange opinions with his counterparts from around the world on crackdowns on international crime, the Investigation Bureau head will also visit the US Federal Bureau of Investigation to seek opportunities for bilateral cooperation.

As the FBI has already shifted the main focus of its operations to the field of intelligence gathering, Wang may also ask the FBI to send officers to Taiwan to give lessons to Criminal Investigation Bureau personnel, according to reliable sources.

Earlier this year, Wang visited Russian law enforcement agencies, the sources said, adding that his current visit to the FBI will help Taiwan to further strengthen its crime-fighting and intelligence abilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS AGREES TO WEIGH COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN IN FIGHTING ENTEROVIRUS

TEXT.P: The Association for Relations Across Taiwan Straits (ARATS) has agreed to consider the possibility of cooperating with Taiwan to fight enterovirus, said Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), on Thursday.

In the second round of discussion between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, Koo raised a number of issues, including the idea of joint research into a vaccination for the enterovirus which plagues both Taiwan and mainland China. ARATS agreed to study the proposal said Shi, who also attended the meeting.
Both sides also agreed to beef up exchanges at various levels between the two agencies set up by Taipei and Beijing to handle cross-strait affairs.
Koo, who is currently in Shanghai on an ice-breaking trip to boost ties with mainland China, met with Wang for the first time in five years on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROUNDUP OF C.F. KOO'S MAJOR ACTIVITIES IN SHANGHAI ON THURSDAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu on Thursday concluded his second round of discussion with Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) in Shanghai.
Their wide-ranging discussions have rebuilt the basis for the two semi-official organizations to resume formal consultations after a five-year hiatus.

Unlike Wednesday's first round of discussions that featured different views on the issue of political status, the meaning of "one China," and ways of developing cross-strait relations, Thursday's meeting produced some concrete results.

Koo extended an invitation for Wang and his wife to visit Taiwan "at an appropriate time." Wang accepted the invitation, and said he looks forward to making such a visit to gain more of an understanding of Taiwan.
SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-you said he hoped Wang would be able to visit Taiwan in November or December, so that he can observe at first hand the campaigns for the year-end legislative elections.
But ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei ruled out the possibility of a visit at such short notice, citing the extensive arrangements which would have to precede such a visit.
In Thursday's talks, Koo and Wang were reported to have reached consensus on another three points:

-- The SEF and ARATS will engage in dialogue to discuss diverse subjects, including political and economic issues. Concrete arrangements will be made through consultations between the leaders of the two bodies;
-- The two organizations will step up bilateral exchanges, including exchanges of visits by missions to be headed by SEF and ARATS officials; and
-- The two organizations will strengthen assistance in incidents involving the lives and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainland, and vice-versa.

In addition to the talks with the ARATS chairman, Koo visited the Shanghai Stock Exchange on Thursday morning, where he urged the Shanghai authorities to lift the restrictions on Taiwan investors, who currently can purchase only B stocks there.

Koo also attended a luncheon given in his honor by the Taiwan Enterprises Association in Shanghai, where he expressed the hope that the mainland and Taiwan will discuss ways to boost the protection of Taiwan investors on the mainland at an early date.
Meanwhile, Koo's wife, Koo-Yen Chou-yun, paid a visit to the graves of the parents of former ROC First Lady Madame Chiang Kai-shek in suburban Shanghai.
Mrs. Koo laid a wreath on behalf of Madame Chiang, who now resides in New York.
On Thursday night, the Wangs invited the Koos to a Peking Opera at a famous Shanghai theater. Several members of Koo's delegation were also invited.

Koo arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday at the head of a 12-member delegation. He will leave for Beijing on Friday to meet with Beijing officials. He is also scheduled to meet with mainland China's President Jiang Zemin on Oct. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Consensus reached on four points on the second day of the Koo-Wang meeting; both sides agreed to promote exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
The China Times: Beijing's top envoy Wang Daohan agreed to visit Taiwan; consensus on four points reached.
The United Daily News: Taiwan's top negotiator C. F. Koo invited his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, to observe Taiwan's year-end elections.
The Liberty Times: Four conclusions reached on the second day of the Koo-Wang meeting in Shanghai; mainland envoy Wang Daohan agreed to visit Taiwan.
The Independence Morning Post: Wang appeared to be annoyed when Koo mentioned the 1945 Potsdam Declaration concerning Taiwan's sovereignty issue.
The Commons Daily: Taiwan's top envoy C. F. Koo reiterated in Shanghai that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now separately ruled by two equal governments.
The China Post: Typhoon Zeb wreaks chaos and death.
The China News: BankBoston shuts Taiwan office.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZEB FORCES CKS AIRPORT TO CLOSE

TEXT.P: Sharp winds packed by Typhoon Zeb forced Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport, located in Taoyuan County, to suspend all operation Friday morning.

The airport closed at 9:30 a.m. As a result, EVA Airways flight 031, bound for Taipei, was redirected to Hong Kong. Meanwhile, 562 travelers aboard China Airlines flights transiting in Taipei were forced to remain at the airport.
All Taiwan's domestic airlines had likewise suspended all flights Friday morning, although some planned to resume operations Friday afternoon.
Authorities said the CKS International Airport is not expected to reopen until 2 p.m. Friday.
Preliminary statistics by airport authorities indicate that about 10,000 air travelers have been stranded by Zeb, which is sweeping across Taiwan.
Zeb is currently at sea, 100 kilometers north-northeast of eastern Taiwan's Hualien County. It is moving in a north-northeasterly direction at 22 kilometers per hour.
Zeb's 300-kilometer radius is covering the entire island, the Central Weather Bureau reported, and the storm is not expected to move away from the island completely until Saturday morning.
Weather forecasters said heavy rains and wind gusts are bombarding the northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOP ENVOY LEAVES SHANGHAI FOR BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, C. F. Koo, left for Beijing on Friday after a two-day high-profile visit to this booming mainland city.
Koo, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his entourage left for the mainland capital aboard an Air China flight at 1 p.m.

Koo, also a senior adviser to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, is expected to deliver a brief speech upon his arrival at the Beijing airport at 3 p.m. He will also give a news conference at Shangri-La Hotel at 4:30 p.m.
Koo's itinerary in Beijing on Friday also includes attending a cocktail reception hosted by the mainland government-backed Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) in his honor.

Koo is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Sunday. Koo's wife and three members on Koo's entourage -- Shi Hwei-yow, Kang Ning-hsiang and Chang Jung-kung -- will also present at the Koo-Jiang meeting.
Before his departure for Beijing, Koo and his entourage visited a major Shanghai tourist attraction -- the Yuyuan, a traditional Chinese-style garden.
Accompanied by his wife, son, daughter and an 11-member entourage, Koo arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday for the highest-level talks across the Taiwan Strait in more than five years.

During his stay in Shanghai, Koo held two rounds of talks with his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, in an effort to resume regular cross-strait dialogue that Beijing unilaterally broke off in mid-1995.

During Thursday's meeting, Koo and Wang, the two elder statesmen charged with shepherding Taipei-Beijing ties in the absence of official channels, managed to reached a four-point consensus on the improvement of bilateral relations.
The four-point deal included that Wang, an 84-year-old ex-mayor of Shanghai and mentor to mainland President Jiang, agreed to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time at the invitation of Koo.
The three other key points of the agreement were:
-- SEF and ARATS will reinforce bilateral exchanges at various levels, including exchanges of visits by their staff members;
-- SEF and ARATS will strengthen cooperation and assistance in incidents involving personal safety and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainland, and vice versa.

DOC.HEADLINE: LA TIMES REPORT ON KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: With half a century of strained relations separating them, Taiwan and mainland China appear to be edging back toward common ground with a nudge from the United States, the Los Angeles Times reported Thursday.

Representatives of the two sides sought to lower expectations of any concrete results during meetings that will continue Friday in Shanghai, but played up the significance of the fact that they were talking at all.

Envoy Koo Chen-fu, head of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, was reported as pointing out that it was important to start building mutual trust, saying, "It is better to start talking sooner rather than later."

Both sides indicate they are working toward eventual reunification. For mainland China, now that Hong Kong has returned to the motherland, pressure is mounting to bring Taiwan back into the fold. Despite Taiwan's democratic government, Beijing insists on reunification.

But Taiwan has vowed not to return to mainland until it becomes democratic. In the near term, Taiwan is increasingly interested in bolstering economic ties -- its business people have invested about US$38 billion in the mainland, according to the report.

While Koo's spokesman publicly declared that the envoy will stick to technical issues such as trade restrictions and fishing disputes, mainland officials insist that the meetings will touch on reunification as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA EXPECTED TO CHANGE AIRCRAFT INSULATION

TEXT.P: Canada will likely act in step with a recommendation made by the US Federal Aviation Administration to change the type of insulation used in aircraft.

The FAA recommended Friday that insulation blankets made of Mylar be replaced with ones made of another material because of the danger of fire. The recommendation comes after the crash of a Swissair passenger jet last month off Nova Scotia.
The FAA said it was making the recommendation in response to the crash.
Although investigators are still looking into the cause of the crash, there is speculation that it may have been due to a fire.
Mylar insulation is similar to what is used in homes. It is placed, either in a blanket-like form or as a foam, between the inner and outer skin of a plane to keep out the cold and to muffle noise.
The FAA said the insulation can catch fire if exposed to high heat, like that of a spark from a wiring short.
The agency has asked that the change be implemented in all airplanes flying into the United States. This could mean new insulation for the world's fleet of 12,000 passenger aircraft.
An official with the Air Transport Association of Canada, which represents the nation's airline industry, said he expects Canada will adopt the FAA's recommendations for its planes as well.
"Airlines fly all over the world, and it's nice to have a global standard whenever possible," the official said.
Mylar insulation blankets allowed fires initiated by electrical shorts to spread rapidly aboard three different aircraft from 1993 to 1995. All fires occurred on the ground, and no one was injured.

The doomed Swissair MD-11 had undergone a major overhaul in August 1997, two months before the airline received McDonnell Douglas' recommendation that the insulation be replaced "at the next convenient grounding."
Canadian investigators said the Mylar insulation would be examined along with several other parts of the airplane, including its electrical-wiring insulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TOLD NOT TO ACCEPT BLOOD DONATIONS FROM BRITISH

TEXT.P: Although there is no evidence that Creutzfeldt Jakob disease can be transmitted through blood, a committee on bioethics wants Canada's blood agency not to accept blood donations from anyone who has lived in Britain since 1980.
Bayer Corp.'s Advisory Council on Bioethics said Thursday it is worried that people who ate British beef could carry a new form of CJ disease -- the human brain disorder linked to mad cow disease.
New variants of CJ disease from Britain have been found in tonsil and appendix tissues, which means it is possible that the disease can be spread by blood, according to scientific reports.

Burleigh Trevor-Deutsch, the head of the Bayer council, said people in the United Kingdom may have been exposed to mad cow disease, which was known to be present in some British beef before the government took action against it in the mid-1990s.

Trevor-Deutsch said those people should not be allowed to contribute blood in Canada. The danger that the disease can be transmitted through blood has already forced Britain to import all of its plasma from outside the country.
Doug Kennedy, a senior adviser on blood issue with Health Canada, said his department's researchers will look at the Bayer recommendation in detail.
Bayer makes most of the blood products used in Canada.

But the Canadian Blood Services said refusing plasma products from anyone who has lived in Britain would result in a severe blood shortage in Canada. A spokesman said the agency would then have to import blood from the United States, which is still accepting blood donations from the British.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SAID ONE OF BEST HOLIDAY DESTINATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks seventh among the top 20 holiday destinations in terms of price competitiveness, according to a survey by the Tourism Council of Australia.
Indonesia topped the list, followed by Thailand, mainland China, Malaysia, South Korea and Turkey. Singapore ranked eighth, followed by Australia and Spain, according to the survey.
The survey is based on the prices of accommodations, tours and food and drink.
Australia has improved its travel competitiveness since 1985 in every area except shopping, taxis and conventions, according to the survey.

But the expected introduction of a 10 percent goods and services tax worries the Australian travel industry because it will increase the financial burden of foreign tourists, according to the council.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PRC TALKS SUBJECT OF SCRUTINY IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Australia is deeply concerned about the talks between Taiwan and mainland China in Shanghai this week as both countries are major trading partners, although Canberra maintains a one-China policy.

In an editorial titled "China, Taiwan Talks Already a Success" on Friday, The Australian said the talks "are the subject of intense scrutiny by Australia and other Asia-Pacific nations keen to see some progress on what remains one of the most worrying and intractable security issues for the region."
"For Australia, both China and Taiwan are important trade partners," the editorial said.
"Politically, Canberra's relationship with Beijing turns on a handful of key issues: Taiwan, Tibet, human rights and Australia's support of US military policy," it said.
Australia switched its recognition from Taipei to Beijing in late 1972, but maintains close economic ties with Taiwan.
While the newspaper said it would be naive to expect much to come from the talks, the mere fact that the two sides are talking is an encouraging sign.

The scheduled meeting between mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Taiwan's representative, Koo Chen-fu, on Sunday "shows China is serious about resuming a dialogue that essentially has been in abeyance for five years. If things go well at the weekend, there is scope for further progress when the two sides take part in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Kuala Lumpur next month."
"A lessening of regional tensions is a first priority, but there are important economic issues at stake," the editorial said.

"Given the downturn in foreign direct investment inflows resulting from the Asian financial crisis, China needs all the fresh Taiwanese capital it can attract. Likewise, Taiwan needs continued access to the Chinese market," the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO WORK WITH TAIWAN ON TMD STUDY

TEXT.P: The US Department of Defense welcomes a Congressional mandate for a Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system study and will work closely with Taiwan on the issue, a senior Pentagon official said Thursday.
Answering questions from Taiwan reporters, Kurt Campbell, deputy assistant secretary of defense for Asia and the Pacific, also welcomed the resumption of dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China.
Calling it a "good sign," he said he hoped that both Taiwan and the mainland would conduct the dialogue in a respectful way.
Regarding the TMD study, Campbell said the Defense Department has in the past held "very close consultations with Taiwan on all aspects of its defense needs, including the TMD."
"So we think that this is a logical step and I welcome it, and we will work closely with our Taiwan counterparts," he said.
He made the comments after Congress asked the Defense Department to study the architectural requirements for the establishment and operation of TMD system in the Asia-Pacific region.
As part of the study, the Defense Department is required to produce a report before Jan. 1, 1999. Campbell would not comment on whether the study could be completed on time.

In response to questions both before and after speaking on security in East Asia at Johns Hopkins University in Washington, Campbell also reiterated the United States' commitment to Taiwan's defense needs.
He said that the Congressional mandate would "make it very clear that the United States stands behind its commitment."
In his speech, Campbell pointed out that North Korea and Taiwan are two issues that require careful handling.

While the United States should be active in helping to deal with the situation in the Korean Peninsula, he said, the right approach to the Taiwan issue would be for Washington to "keep a hands-off policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CEMENT INDUSTRY MOVING TO INCREASE INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The current move toward a resumption of cross-strait talks has prompted Taiwan's cement industry to make plans for increased investment in mainland China, according to informed industry sources.
With production at home having reached full capacity, and with domestic demand in decline, Taiwan's cement entrepreneurs have already been covertly expanding into the mainland market for some time.

According to the sources, the Taiwan Cement Corp. intends to invest in as many as five plants in southern China; Asian Cement plans to offer its products in the mainland market; while Chia Hsin Cement's plant in the mainland has already been selling its products back to Taiwan.

The Taiwan Cement Corp., the island's biggest cement company, carried out indirect investment in the mainland via its subsidiary in Hong Kong. Its planned new investments are expected to give the company total annual production of 5 million metric tons when they go into production in mid-1999.

Other cement companies with stocks in the domestic stock market, such as Universal Cement, Lucky Cement, Hsing Ta Cement, and Southeast Cement, are also evaluating the possibility of investing in the mainland.

In the wake of the discussions on a resumption of talks between the two sides, and a perceived loosening on the part of the Taipei authorities of the "no haste, be patient" policy, the cement industry will surely accelerate their moves toward the mainland, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK RATING AGENCY DOWNGRADES RISK RATING FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Huang Kuan-chun and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Thomson BankWatch, the world's largest bank rating agency, on Friday downgraded its sovereign risk rating outlook for Taiwan to AA from AA+ Stable.

Anand Adiga, sovereign risk analyst with Thomson BankWatch, explained that while Taiwan has done better than most other Asian economies in dodging fallout from the regional financial crisis, the country's financial markets and economy have nevertheless been negatively affected.

"Even though the economy has fewer structural problems than others in the region, the country's capacity to absorb adverse conditions has been diminished, necessitating a one-notch downgrade in its risk rating at this stage," he added.
The bank rating agency also downgraded its senior debt rating for the Bank of Taiwan to AA from AA+

According to the agency, Taiwan's exports are likely to decline this year for the first time in almost two decades, while several banks and firms will have to absorb sizable losses on investments in several Asian countries. Consumer confidence is also falling due to uncertainty in financial markets.

"While Taiwanese banks are stronger than many others in the region, there is generally not a great deal of capacity to absorb sizable bad loans if the economy slows more than anticipated," the agency added.

The financial services company also stressed that Taiwan's AA rating is supported by the country's substantial foreign exchange reserves, a sizable current account surplus, low levels of net external debt, a relatively sound banking sector, and the entrepreneurial strength of the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP APPROVES OF INVITATION TO ARATS HEAD TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday responded positively to Koo Chen-fu's invitation to his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, to visit Taiwan to observe the year-end legislative elections here.

However, Yen Wan-ching, director of the DPP's Department of China Affairs, expressed skepticism as to whether Wang will come, and cited past experience which shows that Beijing has always shied away from acknowledging the fruits of Taiwan's democratization.

Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), extended the invitation to Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), during their second round of discussions on Thursday.

While Wang accepted the invitation to visit Taiwan at an "appropriate time," Tang Shubei, ARATS Vice Chairman, said that the end of the year would be too soon for arrangements for such a visit to be made.
Yen said he does not think Wang's trip to Taiwan in December will take place, and that Tang's statement that more time is needed to arrange the trip is merely an excuse.

Yen said that Beijing views Koo's trip to mainland China as a "journey of political dialogue" and will use every opportunity to highlight this stance in the international arena. However, Yen added, as long as Taiwan's delegation states its own position, and stresses firmly that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are independent of each other, then it will not fall into "the trap set by the other side."

Unlike Wednesday's first round of Koo-Wang discussions that featured different views on the issue of political status, the meaning of "one China," and ways of developing cross-strait relations, Thursday's meeting resulted in some concrete agreements.

According to Yen, this represented an about-face on the part of Beijing, and is aimed only at demonstrating a more eased approach after setting up its basic tone of seeking political dialogue the previous day, in preparation for Koo's meeting with mainland leaders scheduled for the coming weekend.
Koo is scheduled to meet with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, Vice Premier Qian Qichen and Premier Jiang Zemin over the weekend.

Yen said he believed that the four-point consensus reached on Thursday has more style than substance, and added that the agreement reached on increased exchanges between the SEF and ARATS is too vague, and was basically nothing more that a political gesture.
Yen also said that it is a pity that both sides have not reached any tangible result on the protection of the rights of the peoples on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG MEET SIGNIFIES CONTINUED CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE: US EXPERTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Several US China hands said on Thursday that the significance of the consensus reached on Thursday between Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, and his mainland counterpart, is that cross-strait dialogue will continue.

Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), reached a four-point consensus during their second round of discussion on Thursday, including agreement on increased exchanges and dialogue.
Three American scholars -- Ralph Clough, professor at Johns Hopkins University, and Nancy Tucker and David Brown of Georgetown University -- described the consensus as a welcome sign.
They agreed that the resumption of contact and dialogue after a hiatus of five years is in itself a good development.

Tucker said that most important purpose of Koo's trip to mainland China will be to improve the cross-strait atmosphere. Any agreement reached, therefore, will be a good thing rich in symbolic significance.

On Koo's scheduled meeting with mainland leaders in Beijing over the weekend, Brown predicted that mainland President Jiang Zemin, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, and Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin under the State Department, might have some major announcements to make, pointing out the tendency of Chinese negotiators to leave the most important thing to the finale.

Tucker also said he believed that Jiang could use his meeting with Koo to show goodwill to Taiwan, but she would not speculate on whether Jiang will say that everything is open to discussion, including the name and the national anthem of the nation.

Both Brown and Clough said that in the wake of the high-profile murder of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan in the mainland in late July, the consensus reached on the protection of the personal safety and property of Taiwan visitors to the mainland is most noteworthy.

Koo and Wang agreed that SEF and ARATS will step up assistance regarding the protection of personal and property safety of Taiwan people in mainland China, and vice-versa, according to ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei,

Brown and Clough also noted that Taiwan has long been asking the mainland to sign investment agreements, but said that as no details in this regard were disclosed in the consensus, it will have to wait until future cross-strait discussions.
Clough predicted that Koo's meetings with mainland leaders in Beijing will just be "get acquainted meetings," and said they will not go beyond the original stance stated earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN DEAD, SEVEN MISSING AS TYPHOON ZEB BATTERS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Seven people had been killed, one had been seriously injured, and seven had been reported missing as of Friday noon, since Typhoon Zeb started battering Taiwan Thursday, according to the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center.

The center said that a total of 13 counties and cities around the island have sustained casualties and damage, with at least 10 people having been slightly injured by falling billboards and collapsing houses.

Several hundred people have been trapped by floodwaters and mudslides triggered by heavy rains and winds which have also destroyed four houses and damaged many others, the center reported, adding blackouts had affected 1.15 million households islandwide.
Citing Taiwan Power Company's reports, the center said that as of Friday noon, more than 632,000 homes were still without power.
Changhua County, central Taiwan, was the most seriously affected area, with over 207,000 households hit by power failure, the center said.

Meanwhile, marine police reported that the Taiwan-registered "Yi Ho" had broken from its mooring in Taichung Harbor, and had drifted south without power into the seas off the Changhua coast. Rescuers had been thwarted by the heavy seas.
Four members of the 23-person crew, who had tried to seek help by putting out in a small motorboat, were reported missing.

Weathermen reported at Friday noon that Taiwan is now entirely under the 300-kilometer radius of Zeb, which was centered about 80 kilometers southeast of Ilan, moving north-northeast at a speed of 22 kilometers per hour.

Southern Taiwan is expected to be out of the storm by Friday afternoon, but Zeb, the strongest of the eight typhoons to visit the island this year, is not expected to leave until early Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND NEGOTIATOR DENIES `3 EMPTIES' STRATEGY
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior mainland Chinese negotiator has denied a report that Beijing will adopt a "three empties" strategy to put an additional squeeze on Taiwan's diplomatic space, a visiting Taiwan delegate said here on Friday.

"Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), told me on Thursday that mainland Chinese authorities have not formulated a so-called `three empties' diplomatic strategy against Taiwan," said Prof. Pao Chung-ho, a researcher with Taiwan's National Unification Council (NUC).

The "three empties" strategy refers to Beijing's attempts to lure away all of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies by the turn of the century, to block any opportunity for Taiwan to join any international organization or activity, and to eliminate all the bargaining chips and clout that Taiwan has used to seek an equal footing with Beijing.

Pao, a political science professor at National Taiwan University who is currently accompanying Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Chairman C.F. Koo of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on an ice-breaking visit to mainland China, said he raised the "three empties" topic when he discussed cross-strait issues with Tang.
"I proposed to Tang that Beijing stop its diplomatic offensive against Taiwan and abandon its `zero-sum' tactic in handling international affairs related to Taiwan," Pao said.
The professor said he also told Tang that there should be room for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to co-exist and even help each other in the international community.

Tang was quoted as telling Pao that Beijing has no plan to lure away all of the ROC's 27 diplomatic allies. "Nevertheless, Tang added that mainland China cannot reject any other country which wishes to forge diplomatic ties," Pao said.

In response to SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow's complaint that mainland China has often criticized ROC President Lee Teng-hui's remarks about cross-strait affairs, Tang said such criticism is mainly for domestic consumption.

Tang was quoted as having assured Shi that mainland China has taken steps to improve the situation. According to Shi, Tang said mainland China has recently stopped publishing editorials critical of Lee.

Shi is also a member of the entourage accompanying Koo on his six-day landmark mainland visit aimed at pushing for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue that Beijing unilaterally broke off more than three years ago.
Koo and his 11-member entourage left Shanghai for Beijing on Friday to continue their mainland visit.
During his stay in Shanghai, Koo held two rounds of discussions with his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, in an effort to thaw cross-strait relations.

After the meetings on Wednesday and Thursday, Koo and Wang, the two elder statesmen charged with shepherding Taipei-Beijing ties in the absence of official channels, managed to reach a four-point consensus on the improvement of bilateral relations.

The four-point agreement included that Wang, an 84-year-old ex-mayor of Shanghai and mentor to mainland President Jiang Zemin, accepted from Koo an invitation to visit Taiwan at "an appropriate time."
The three other key points of the agreement were:
-- SEF and ARATS will reinforce bilateral exchanges at various levels, including exchanges of visits by their staff members;
-- SEF and ARATS will strengthen cooperation and assistance in incidents involving the personal safety and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainland, and vice versa.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPORTS TO TAIWAN, M'LAND AND HONG KONG TO DECREASE US$3 BILLION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: US exports to Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong will plummet by as much as US$3 billion in 1998, part of a total drop of US$31 billion in exports to Asia as a whole, US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky said on Thursday.
The decline of US exports to Asia will result in a threat to the employment and economic growth of the United States, the trade representative added.
In a speech at the National Association of Manufacturers, Barshefsky remarked that the Asian financial turmoil has become world's most serious monetary crisis in 50 years.
She observed that two-fifths of the container ships leaving Los Angeles at the moment are empty. US exports to Japan alone will slip by US$8 billion, she said.

This development is posing as a threat to employment and economic growth across the US, Barshefsky commented. The priority of Washington is to collaborate with the International Monetary Fund to stabilize the foreign exchange rate of the battered Asian countries and to restore their economies, she added.

Barshefsky pointed out in her address that because the global economy is under the shadow of the Asian financial storm, the biggest challenge to the US trade policy is promoting a more open world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF DELEGATION ARRIVES IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) delegation, led by its chairman, Koo Chen-fu, arrived in Beijing at 2:50 p.m. from Shanghai.

They were greeted at the airport by Zhang Jingcheng, vice chairman and secretary general of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), who escorted them to their accommodation at the Tiaoyutai Guest House.
In Shanghai, Koo and his delegation were seen off at the Hongchiao Airport by Shanghai Deputy Mayor Zhou Muyao, while Tang Shubei, ARATS executive vice chairman, accompanied them to Beijing.
The SEF delegation will take part in a reception hosted by ARATS at the Tiaoyutai Guest House on Friday evening, and tour historical sites around Beijing on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S OLYMPIC COMMITTEE PRESIDENT STRANDED IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Beijing's Chinese Olympic Committee President Wu Shaozu was stranded in Hong Kong on Friday en route to Taiwan, which was storm-bound by Typhoon Zeb.
Traveling at the head of a seven-member delegation, Wu left Beijing for Hong Kong on Friday morning, and planned to reach Taiwan later that afternoon.

However, Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport was closed because of the typhoon, forcing the delegation to postpone its itinerary for one day, Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) executives said.
Wu has been invited to Taiwan by CTOC Chairman Huang Ta-chou for a Taiwan visit.
During his upcoming stay on the island, Wu will attend the second cross-Taiwan Strait sports conference, according to the CTOC.
The closure of CKS triggered chaos at Hong Kong's recently opened Chek Lap Kok Airport, reports from Hong Kong said, adding CKS was not expected to reopen until Friday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF-MILLION FAMILIES REMAIN BLACKED OUT

TEXT.P: A total of 485,000 Taiwan households islandwide were still without electricity at 4 p.m. on Friday after typhoon Zeb raged across the island.

During a visit to the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) to obtain the latest information on outages around the island, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang instructed Taipower workers and staff to resume electricity supplies as soon as possible, and thanked them for their hard work during the typhoon.

Strong winds and heavy rain brought by Zeb had forced Taipower's first and the second nuclear power plants in northern Taiwan to suspend operations. The No. 3 nuclear power plant in the south of the island was only operating at about 30 percent of its normal capability as of Thursday noon, but operations returned to normal after urgent repairs had been carried out.
The crash of the three nuclear power plants had caused temporary blackouts to more than 1.7 million households around the island, according to Taipower.
Zeb was the strongest of the eight typhoons which have affected Taiwan this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE OFFICIAL SEES NO CHAIN REACTION AFTER BANKBOSTON PULLOUT

TEXT.P: A decision by BankBoston Corp. to close its Taiwan office will not ignite a chain reaction among other foreign banks, Vice Finance Minister Sean Chen said on Friday.

The US banking corporation announced on Wednesday that it was closing its Taiwan office, as well as others in India, Japan, and the Philippines. Chen said the closures were part of the company's operational strategy and an isolated case.
About 111 jobs will be eliminated because of the closures, 99 of which are in offices located in Asia.

In response to a question as to why Japanese banks have chosen to remain in Taiwan although their profits may be lower than those of BankBoston, Chen said due to bustling two-way trade between Taiwan and Japan, there are many Japanese businesses in Taiwan. Therefore, Japanese banks have a greater client base compared to BankBoston, as there are fewer US companies from the New England area on the island.
In addition, Chen said, each bank has a different strategy. He added that the BankBoston is planning to extend its business in developing economies and therefore decided to shut its Taiwan office.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PLEASED TO SEE PROGRESS IN CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Friday it is pleased to see that exchanges between the two government-backed intermediary bodies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have taken a step forward.

MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng made the statement after Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) reached a four-point consensus in Shanghai on Thursday on resuming disrupted dialogue.

"We are delighted to learn that SEF and ARATS have agreed to step up dialogue on diverse subjects, including both political and economic matters, and reinforce exchanges of visits by their staff members at various levels," Sheu said, adding that the consensus will help thaw the more-than-three-year cross-strait impasse.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

SEF Chairman C.F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan agreed to work toward repairing their ruptured dialogue in the four-point deal sealed at a plush Shanghai hotel on Thursday, the most important step since Beijing unilaterally broke off talks in mid-1995.

The four-point consensus included that Wang, an 84-year-old ex-mayor of Shanghai and mentor to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, accepted from Koo an invitation to visit Taiwan at "an appropriate time."
The three other key points were:
-- SEF and ARATS will resume dialogue on political, economic and other matters of mutual concern;
-- The two bodies will reinforce bilateral exchanges at various levels, including exchanges of visits by their staff members; and
-- SEF and ARATS will strengthen cooperation and assistance in incidents involving the personal safety and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainland, and vice versa.

Sheu said Koo originally hoped that Wang would visit Taiwan either in November or early December to observe three critical elections on the island scheduled for Dec. 5 -- elections for the Legislative Yuan and for the mayors and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung, Taiwan's two largest cities.
However, Wang's deputy, ARATS Executive Vice Chairman Tang Shubei, said a visit by Wang in November or December would be too soon.
"We'll respect Wang's opinion and arrange for his visit at his convenience," Sheu said.

He further pointed out that under the agreements signed by Koo and Wang during their historic first meeting in Singapore in April 1993, SEF and ARATS chairmen can meet regularly to discuss matters of mutual concern.

Moreover, the vice chairmen of the two bodies should meet once every six months and their deputy secretaries-general should meet once every three months to review operations of the two organizations and practical matters arising from increasing cross-strait civilian exchanges.
"We hope that following Koo's current goodwill mainland visit, Beijing will abide by these previous agreements and gradually resume systematic SEF-ARATS dialogue and exchanges," Sheu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZEB CAUSES OVER US$57M IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Zeb has so far caused an estimate of over NT$1.89 billion (US$57.27 million) in agricultural losses in Taiwan since Thursday, the Taiwan Provincial Department of Agricultural and Forestry said on Friday.

The storm, packing strong winds and torrential rains, caused about NT$1.64 billion in crop damage; NT$111 million in destroyed fields; NT$9.8 million in lost livestock; and NT$106 million in fishery products, the department said.
Pingtung, Changhua, Taitung, and Hualien Counties were the most seriously affected areas, the department said. All have qualified for government relief funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LOBBYING ASEAN OBSERVER STATUS FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest opposition party will lobby the Council of Asian Liberals and Democrats (CALD) to support the island's bid to become an observer of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
Wu Nai-jen, a Central Standing Committee member of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the statement upon his arrival in Bangkok on Friday to attend a two-day annual CALD conference.
"We hope Taiwan can be admitted into ASEAN as an observer. If so, ASEAN can serve as an informal channel for dialogue across the Taiwan Strait," Wu said.
Mainland China is an ASEAN dialogue partner.
Wu said more mutual understanding and mutual trust are needed for cross-strait dialogue to proceed smoothly and bear fruit.

He further pointed out that Taiwan can never follow in the footsteps of Hong Kong to accept the Beijing-initiated "one country, two systems" unification formula, stressing that Taiwan's history is completely different from Hong Kong's.
Wu said Hong Kong has conceded to Beijing over the democracy issue after it reverted to communist China's rule on July 1, 1997.
"Taiwan cannot accept the 'one country, two systems' scheme because it violates the self-determination principle," Wu noted.
The CALD groups major liberal and democratic parties in Asia. The pro-Taiwan independence DPP is a CALD founding member.
Wu will present a paper on Taiwan's history and the DPP's stance on the island's future at the annual CALD conference, which opened here on Friday.

Another DPP delegate to the conference, Lin Chung-cheng, will suggest the establishment of an Asian community fund to help promote Asian financial stability and regional cooperation. Lin said the ROC government has expressed intention to help finance the fund.
