DOC.HEADLINE: 23 CREW MEMBERS OF PANAMANIAN SHIP RESCUED

TEXT.P: Authorities on Friday rescued 23 crew members of a Panamanian cargo ship which was drifting at sea for several hours off Taiwan's central Changhua County.

Amid strong winds and torrential rain brought on by typhoon Zeb, the Panama-registered Elite Leader drifted from Taichung Harbor where it was docked after developing engine problems at noon. It drifted southward to the coast off the Changpin Industrial Zone in Changhua County.
A total of 23 crew members, including 19 Taiwan officers and four Hindu workers who boarded a life boat to seek assistance, were rescued by around 5:30 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMIC MINISTER CHANG RECEIVES BRITISH TRADE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Minister Chang Chang-pang on Friday received Tony Hutton, British secretary of trade and industry, saying that he hoped Britain would support the ROC's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Accompanied by Alan Collins, director general of the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei, the visiting Hutton paid a courtesy call to Chang at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

They exchanged views on such issues as WTO and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum. The ROC and the European Union have completed their consultations on the ROC's WTO bid, but the agreement document remains to be signed. Chang said he hoped Hutton could help speed up the process so the ROC could join the WTO at an earlier date.

Hutton lauded Taiwan's sound industrial structure and well as its financial system which have enabled the island to come out of the region's financial crisis relatively unscathed. Taiwan's example is worthy of study by other countries, he added.

Chang highly praised the British government for its efforts in promoting economic reform in recent years and in encouraging foreign investment. He added that for those Taiwan businessmen intending to invest in the United Kingdom, the MOEA would provide the appropriate assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO REALIZE DEMOCRATIZATION OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's chief negotiator Koo Chen-fu Friday urged "all friends on the mainland" to try to understand Taiwan's achievement in promoting democracy in the past five decades.

Koo, chairman of the semi-official Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), said at a press conference in Beijing that he and his 12-member party want to understand the current situation of the mainland after its 20 years of economic reform. Koo is visiting mainland China at the invitation of his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

"We also want all friends on the mainland to understand Taiwan's achievement in democratization over the past 50 years," Koo said, adding that the two sides should have more contacts, more dialogues, and more opportunities to understand each other. "This is a must for promoting mutual understanding, cultivating friendship, and building mutual trust." Koo said he has already invited Wang to visit Taiwan to see for himself.
Koo said that SEF and ARATS officials agreed Thursday in Shanghai to increase contacts and dialogues, and that they would be busy making arrangements for exchange of visits.

Koo also said that while in Beijing he and his party hope to have good opportunities to meet with "the very important misters concerned" and have candid dialogues with them so that the two sides will positively and correctly understand each other. "We hope to find out proper ways to narrow the gap between us and to promote cross-strait relations in a correct and constructive way." A Beijing leader once called President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China "Mr. Lee" in a formal statement.

Koo and his party arrived in Shanghai Wednesday and proceeded to Beijing Friday for sightseeing and meeting with their mainland Chinese counterparts. Koo is also scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Vice Premier Qian Qichen, and Director Chen Yunlin of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the communist Chinese State Council during his three-day stay in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE FELICITATES POPE
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui sent a congratulatory message to John Paul II, as the religious leader celebrates his 20th anniversary as pope.
President Lee hailed Pope John's contribution and efforts to world peace and wished him good health.
Lee's message was submitted to the Holy See on Thursday by the ROC Embassy at the Vatican. The Vatican is the ROC's sole diplomatic ally in Europe.
Pope John Paul II, who was born in Poland, became the first non-Italian pope in 1978 since Adrian VI of the Netherlands.
Over the past 20 years, the pope has made 84 overseas trips and visited 117 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: US COMMANDER AWARDED MEDAL IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: A US commander-in-chief was awarded with the Meritorious Military Service Medal in Singapore on Friday.

Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defense of Singapore, Tony Tan, presented Commander-in-Chief of the United States Pacific Command Adm. Joseph Prueher with the medal at a ceremony held at the Ministry of Defense.
Prueher won the medal for his efforts and contribution to better ties and friendship between the US Armed Forces and the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF).

Since assuming his appointment in 1996, Prueher has personally overseen and encouraged the development of closer links between the SAF and the US Pacific Command. His support for annual staff meetings between the two sides has resulted in many new initiatives.

Prueher's support has also contributed to the smooth and successful conduct of the ongoing Commando Sling series of exercises between Republic of Singapore Air Force and the US Pacific Air Force, and led to an expansion of the exercise series to include the Royal Australian Air Force. The first trilateral exercise in this series was successfully conducted in May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA SAID CONSIDERING CAPITAL CONTROLS

TEXT.P: Bankers and traders suspect Indonesia is considering limited capital controls which may force exporters to repatriate their earnings.

Indonesia has faced severe capital flight and a growing trading surplus has failed to spark an influx of dollars as exporters have preferred to retain earnings in foreign currency offshore, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.

Officials would not confirm any decision but one central bank employee was quoted as saying that Ginandjar Kartasasmita, the coordinating minister for finance, economy and industry, had forwarded such a proposal to the central bank.

However, officials have denied any plans to impose capital controls similar to those in Malaysia. Many Indonesians feel their relatively open capital flow system aggravated the rapid collapse of the currency during the height of the Asian crisis, the WTO report said.

Publicly, Ginandjar has toyed only with introducing a reporting requirement for dollar purchases, but bankers said the government may feel a forced conversion of export earnings into rupiah at the central bank would be an alternative to full capital controls.

Bankers said such a requirement could work in the short run, costing exporters an added double conversion in and out of rupiah. But they said it could hurt those who have dollars abroad as collateral for letters of credit as most Indonesian letters of credit are no longer accepted.
More serious, they said, is a risk the introducing of such a restriction could be interpreted as a first step to more capital controls, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO TO TAKE UP LEE-JIANG MEETING IN TALKS WITH JIANG
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By CNA Reporters & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: When Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu meets with mainland President Jiang Zemin on Sunday, he may propose a meeting between Jiang and ROC President Lee Teng-hui, Koo told reporters on Friday.
Speaking at a news conference at a Beijing hotel, Koo said both Lee and Jiang have indicated a willingness for a top-level meeting, and it would be "a very good thing for them to meet."
However, he noted that so far no further plan has been worked out, and there is a need to create some conditions. If convenient, Koo said, he will discuss this issue during his meeting with Jiang.

Koo, accompanied by his entourage, flew to Beijing from Shanghai on Friday afternoon after concluding two days of discussions with his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the PRC's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Replying to reporters' questions, Koo said Lee did not give him a personal message to deliver to Jiang.

He also said Jiang is believed to be fully aware of the progress Taiwan has made in its democratization process, and as "democracy will be the best way to bring Taiwan and the mainland closer," Taiwan would be willing to share its experiences with the mainland in this regard.
Koo expressed the hope that Beijing will abide by the agreements reached in the 1993 Koo-Wang talks in Singapore, otherwise, it may affect the power of any new agreements to be signed in the future.
On the "three links" issue, the top negotiator for Taiwan pointed out that both Taiwan and the mainland still have a "sense of hostility" and there is a lack of mutual trust between the two sides.
If the "sense of hostility" is removed now, he said, "I think the three links (a reference to direct cross-strait trade, transport and communications links) can be realized tomorrow."
Regarding his meeting with Jiang, Koo said he has previously met with the leader during informal summits of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forums over the past few years.

He said, "All sorts of issues can be discussed" during his meeting with Jiang this time. But "we are not to press the other side to accept our views. Both sides must be tolerant and speak out what they really want to say, so as to promote mutual understanding for the solution of problems."

Koo evaded the question of whether he would invite Jiang to visit Taiwan, saying that his invitation to ARATS Chairman Wang to visit the island will be a first step for other Beijing leaders to follow.

He said some conditions must be created for the realization of a Lee-Jiang meeting. For instance, such a meeting must gain the support of the people from both sides, and their meeting must bear guiding and substantive significance.

Koo and Wang held two rounds of discussions in Shanghai on Wednesday and Thursday. Koo defined the discussions merely as dialogues which covered a wide range of topics including practical, economic and political issues.

Koo admitted the two sides still have different interpretations over the "one China" issue. He said this issue cannot be immediately solved, but instead will be solved gradually through discussions based on "reality" and "historical truth."

Koo and his delegation will visit several historical and cultural sites in Beijing on Saturday. They will meet with President Jiang on Sunday and leave for Tokyo on Monday as they make their way back to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO SHOW NO HOSTILITY TOWARDS TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Huang Wen-chung & Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Beijing must show with greater sincerity that it harbors no hostility towards the people of Taiwan, Chang Jung-kung, a researcher with the National Unification Concil (NUC), said on Friday.

Chang is a member of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) delegation visiting the mainland led by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu. Chang made the suggestion after Koo briefed the media following the delegation's arrival in Beijing.

Commenting on Koo's remarks that after the removal of cross-strait hostility, the "three-links" can be carried out the next day, Chang said it was a methaphor to highlight the serious nature of Beijing's hostility.
Since 1991, Chang noted, Taiwan has renounced the use of force in settling cross-strait impasse. However, up to the present, the move has yet to obtain goodwill response from Beijing, he added.

Especially during 1995 and 1996, Beijing has shown particularly strong military hotility towards Taiwan. In addition to exhibiting no hostility as a goodwill gesture, Beijing must show more sincerity in its intentions to the people of Taiwan, Chang said.

In addition to military hostility, He added that Taiwan people often feel they have suffered as a result of Beijing's pressure on the international community, therefore, possitive cross-strait interaction should include military, political and diplomatic aspects.

As for the so-called "three-links" (a reference to direct cross-strait trade, transport and communications links), Chang said the issues should be discussed after Beijing eliminates "hostility" towards Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZEB TO LEAVE TAIWAN FRIDAY NIGHT

TEXT.P: After hammering Taiwan with torrential rainfall and strong winds, Typhoon Zeb is expected to leave the island Friday night and ground warnings are expected to be lifted early on Sunday, forecasters said on Friday.

Zeb, which has weakened and been downgraded to a light typhoon, carried maximum wind speeds of 33 meters per second. The center of the storm was located at sea 170 kilometers east-northeast of Yinan in eastern Taiwan and was moving in a north-northeasterly direction at 7:00 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau said.
Typhoon ground warnings have been lifted in areas south of Tainan City and in the offshore island of Penghu on Friday afternoon, but the warnings are still in effect in other areas.

Zeb has brought down more than 700 millimeters of rain to the mountainous areas of the island, and 448 millimeters in downtown Taipei. Flooding has occurred in low-lying areas especially in Hsichih, Taipei County, a town situated by the Keelung River.

Nearly half of the town was submerged in waters three- to five-meters deep. Scheduled trains on the cross-island railway, which travels through Hsichih, was disrupted as segments of the rail line and the train station were submerged under flood waters.

Premier Vincent Siew inspected the flood-stricken areas of Hsichih on Friday morning. He blamed some of the most serious flooding in the area in a decade on the blockage of the Keelung River caused by the dumping of waste soil and gravel by nearby construction projects.
After Hsichih, Siew toured Liotu, a part of Keelung City, which has also been inundated by flood waters.

Although the government recently built a pump station in Liotu to help avoid flooding, the pump did not work during the storm and was instead overwhelmed by the heavy rainfall. Also submerged were the Liotu Industrial Area and a sewage treatment plant.
Earlier in the day, Siew visited a typhoon shelter at the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of Interior.

Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian also made his rounds throughout the city on Friday. He visited low-lying areas in Nankang, and Neihu districts, comforting evacuees whose houses were either submerged in water or damaged by mud slides.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SUPPORTS KOO, WANG'S FOUR-POINT CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: ROC policy-making authorities on Friday voiced their support for the four-point consensus reached by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, in Shanghai on Thursday.
The authorities said the consensus will be helpful for the maintenance of peace and is compatible with the ROC government's framework of developing constructive relations with the mainland.

Koo and Chairman Wang of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) agreed to engage in dialogue; to strengthen bilateral exchanges; to step up assistance for Taiwanese on the mainland in the event of problems; and Wang accepted Koo's invitation to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.
The high-level authorities said they would be glad to see a successful Taiwan visit by Wang.
As long as Koo and Wang fulfill their mission of creating an favorable atmosphere and building a channel for mutual consultation, the future of cross-strait relations will be bright, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Typhoon Zeb swept Taiwan, leaving NT$1.9 billion in agricultural losses.
The China Times: Typhoon Zeb wreaked havoc on Taiwan, leaving at least 23 dead, 41 injured and 14 missing.
The United Daily News: Typhoon Zeb left a trail of destruction in Taiwan; Taipei County's Hsichih Township was flooded; 5 residents in Taipei buried by mudslides.
The Liberty Times: China is conducting military exercises against Taiwan while the island's top envoy is on a goodwill visit there.
The Independence Morning Post: Typhoon Zeb left Taiwan after killing at least 16 people.
The Commons Daily: Analysts said the United States is invisible partner in the current landmark cross-strait talks.
The China Post: Typhoon Zeb leaves 12 dead, NT$1.9 billion in agricultural losses.
The China News: Fed cuts interest rates; stocks soar.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO EXPLAIN ROC STANCE AT 11:30 A.M. ON KOO-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will hold a news conference at 11:30 a.m. Saturday to brief media on the Republic of China's stance on an upcoming meeting between a senior Taiwan envoy and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

The press conference comes on the eve of the scheduled meeting in Beijing between Chairman C. F. Koo of Taipei's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and Jiang in the highest contact on Chinese soil between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
Vice Foreign Minister David Lee will preside over the press conference.
Koo, a billionaire tycoon, flew to Beijing from Shanghai on Friday at the head of a 12-member Taiwan delegation. His Oct. 14-19 mainland visit is aimed at thawing cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO AND HIS DELEGATION VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his 12-member delegation on Saturday took part in a number of activities in Beijing as part of an ice-breaking visit to mainland China.
Their itinerary included a visit to the Biyuen temple in the Hsiangshan district of suburban Beijing to pay respects at the memorial to Dr. Sun Yat-sen, father of the Republic of China.

Later in the day, the delegation was scheduled to meet with Chen Yunlin, mainland China's director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, who was also to host an evening banquet for his Taiwan guests.

After the banquet, Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, and a big fan of Chinese opera, was expected to attend a Peking opera featuring 12 different plays illustrating Chinese historical and literary stories.
The Taiwan group was also scheduled to open a press conference at 11:30 p.m. to talk about their Beijing activities.

Koo arrived in Shanghai from Taiwan on Wednesday at the head of the 12-member delegation. He left for Beijing on Friday, and is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRTY-SEVEN DEAD OR MISSING AS TYPHOON ZEB LASHES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A total of 23 people were killed, 14 were reported missing, and at least 41 others were injured as Typhoon Zeb swept through Taiwan on Thursday and Friday, the Central Typhoon Monitoring Headquarters reported on Saturday.

Zeb, the strongest of eight tropical storms to visit Taiwan this year, has pounded the entire island with gusting wind and torrential rain over the last 60 hours, leaving in its wake a record number of deaths, and devastating property damage islandwide, according to the headquarters, established under the Ministry of Interior.
Of the dead and missing, five were in the Taipei suburb of Neihu, where two hillside households were buried by a landslide. Rescuers spent more than 24 hours unearthing the victims' bodies.
Eight crewmen of a Singaporean freighter which sank on Friday morning off Chuwei in the northern county of Taoyuan were still missing as of Saturday noon, and were presumed drowned.

Two other freighters, both Panama-registered, were grounded off Tamshui, in Taipei County, and Lukang, central Taiwan, respectively. All the crew of the two ships were rescued and reported to be in good condition, according to officials from the monitoring headquarters.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, Zeb, which killed 74 people in the Philippines before raging across Taiwan, was charted about 60 kilometers south of the main Japanese island of Kyushu as of 11:45 a.m. on Saturday, and was moving northeast at a speed of 35 kilometers per hour, posing a great threat to Japan.

Zeb brought more than 700 millimeters of rainfall to mountainous areas of Taiwan, and 450 millimeters fell in Taipei. Flooding has occurred in low-lying areas, especially Hsichih, Taipei County, a town situated on the banks of the Keelung River. As of Friday night, more than 10,000 Hsichih households were inundated.

Local authorities there announced that government offices and schools would remain closed on Saturday, making it one of only two towns islandwide to suspend normal operations a day after the typhoon left the island, along with the northernmost city of Keelung.
Islandwide, nearly 500,000 households were left without power on Friday, and some 95,000 telephone lines were out of order.

The typhoon has so far caused an estimated NT$1.9 billion (US$57.5 million)-worth of agricultural and fishery losses in Taiwan since Thursday. Of the total, crops suffered some NT$1.6 billion in damage. Average wholesale prices of local vegetables shot up 24 percent on Saturday to NT$24.6 per kilogram from NT$19.9 posted three days ago.

Southern Pingtung, central Changhua, and eastern Hualien and Taitung counties were the most seriously affected areas in terms of agricultural losses. All have qualified for government relief funds or loans, said the Agricultural and Forestry Department of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

In related news, the Ministry of National Defense has over the last two days mobilized 1,611 soldiers and some 100 vehicles, rubber boats and other equipment to help evacuate 85 patients and residents of 96 households around the island trapped by flooding.
The armed forces will continue its relief work islandwide on Saturday, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA AID TO HELP RUSSIANS, UKRAINIANS THROUGH WINTER

TEXT.P: Canadian authorities announced on Friday that Canada will provide C$1.8 million (US$1.17 million) in humanitarian aid to Russia and Ukraine this winter.

Diane Marleau, minister for international cooperation, said: "The collapse of the ruble has driven up prices for food, heating fuel, clothing, and transportation, bringing hardship to hundreds of thousands of people in Russia and Ukraine."
The financial crisis, coupled with recent crop failures, means people will face severe food shortages this winter. She said Canada's support will "help respond to some of their basic needs."

The Canadian assistance will be managed by the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies over the next six months. The aid will be distributed in cooperation with the Red Cross societies in Russia and Ukraine.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18 CHARGED IN AUSTRALIA WITH HEROIN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Seven Hong Kong Chinese and 11 Indonesians have been charged with smuggling 400 kilograms of high-grade heroin worth US$250 million into Australia, according to court records.
The 18 men, aged between 21 and 50, were charged by a court in New South Wales with importing a commercial quantity of heroin, aiding the importation of heroin, and possession of a prohibited drug.
The heroin, which was seized at a port in NSW on Thursday, represented the biggest haul in Australia's history.

Along with the heroin, police also seized a 40-meter freighter which police believed was purpose-built for drug smuggling because of its modified, long-range fuel tanks, and sophisticated communications and radar equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC SUMMIT SHOULD NOT BE HELD IN MALAYSIA: US ANALYST

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton has been urged by a US analyst to seek a new location for the upcoming Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit.

Richard Fisher, acting director of the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, said this would send a strong message to Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed regarding both his brutal treatment of former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and his economic policies that violate free-market ideals.

Mahathir is ill-suited to host the upcoming APEC summit, because he has long criticized free trade and Western values, and his treatment of Anwar, who had earned respect throughout Asia and in the United States for his efforts, has upset many APEC members, noted the senior policy analyst.
Anwar's trial, scheduled to end just two days before the beginning of the APEC meeting, will be a distraction for the summit's participants if it is held in Malaysia, Fisher said.

Beset by domestic distractions, the Clinton administration has not adequately protested the treatment of Anwar or responded to Mahathir's challenge to America's leadership role in APEC. In the midst of the most serious Asian economic crisis since World War II, the United States and APEC cannot afford to let their interests in Asia be threatened by Mahathir's protectionist policies, added Fisher.

He pointed out that the presidents of the Philippines and Indonesia have reportedly considered boycotting the summit to protest Mahathir's treatment of Anwar. Changing the summit venue would send a firm message to Mahathir about his actions and allow Washington and APEC to focus on advancing APEC's goals, such as lowering trade barriers, Fisher added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S CENTRAL BANK CUTS INTEREST RATE

TEXT.P: Canada's central bank on Friday lowered the interest rate to 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent, after the Federal Reserve Board in the United States cut two key rates on Thursday by a quarter of a point.
The Fed cut the overnight rate on loans between banks, the federal funds rate, to 5 percent. It also cut the discount rate on its own loans to banks by a quarter point to 4.75 percent.
It was the second bank rate cut by the Bank of Canada in as many months. On Sept. 29, the bank cut its rate to 5.75 percent from 6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES PRESIDENT ANNOUNCES STATE OF CALAMITY

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Friday night declared six provinces under a state of calamity following damage sustained from typhoon Zeb.
The president released six million pesos each in calamity funds to the devastated provinces of Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, Pangasinan, La Union, Isabela, and Cagayan, all on northern Luzon Island.

The death toll from the typhoon had risen to 35 on Friday, with 12 injured and 13 missing. Over half a billion pesos of harvestable crops and infrastructure projects were destroyed, according to the National Disaster Coordinating Council.
The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical Astronomical Services Administration said the eye of the typhoon was forecast to be 270 kilometers east-northeast of Taiwan by Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC URGES BEIJING TO CLARIFY 3 DIPLOMATIC INCIDENTS

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Minister David Lee on Saturday asked mainland Chinese authorities to clarify three incidents concerning their diplomatic strangulation strategy against the Republic of China on Taiwan.

Lee made the appeal on the eve of a scheduled meeting in Beijing between Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, C.F. Koo, and mainland President Jiang Zemin, in the highest-level contact on Chinese soil between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1949.
Lee said the call is not expected to have any impact on the Koo-Jiang meeting scheduled for Sunday.

"We felt compelled to request mainland China's diplomatic authorities to clarify some recent incidents after learning that a senior mainland negotiator with Taiwan said Beijing has no plans to lure away all of the ROC's diplomatic allies before the year 2000," Lee said.

Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), said in Shanghai on Thursday that Beijing has not formulated a so-called "three empties" diplomatic strategy against Taiwan, nor does it intend to lure away all of Taiwan's 27 diplomatic allies by the turn of the century.

Tang reportedly made the remarks while meeting with a Taiwan delegate who is accompanying Chairman Koo of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on a Shanghai-Beijing visit aimed at thawing cross-strait relations.

Responding to Tang's denial, Lee said the ROC government should give mainland Chinese authorities due recognition if they can truly abandon their "zero-sum" thinking in handling issues related to Taiwan's activities in the international arena.
Nevertheless, Lee said, factual developments seem to contradict Tang's statement.

The senior diplomatic official said he hopes mainland authorities will clarify a report that immediately prior to Koo's departure for his mainland trip, they had used every possible means to tempt one of the ROC's allies to forge official ties with Beijing within two weeks of Koo's return to Taiwan.

Lee said mainland China had even told the ROC ally that forging diplomatic ties with it would not affect exchanges between SEF and ARATS, the two quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait ties in the absence of official channels.

Lee would not divulge the name of the country that Beijing is wooing strenuously. "We must protect the source of our information," he said, adding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is fully aware of the terms offered by the mainland, as well as many other technical details relating to the proposed deal.

Lee said his ministry has made every possible effort to shore up relations with the ally in question. However, it remains uncertain whether or not the ally will switch its diplomatic recognition in the near future.
MOFA sources said the incident represents just the tip of the iceberg of mainland China's double-faced strategy toward Taiwan.

While the media over the past few weeks has focused mainly on the preparations for Koo's landmark mainland visit, the sources said, MOFA has received information that Beijing is stepping up wooing Taiwan's diplomatic allies, in an attempt to persuade them to switch their diplomatic allegiance.
The two other incidents Lee asked Beijing to clarify were:

-- Did mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen ask all mainland diplomats at the Aug. 24-29 mainland overseas mission chief conference to launch an all-out campaign against Taiwan on the diplomatic front and to do their utmost to lure away all of Taiwan's diplomatic allies as soon as possible?

-- Did the mainland authorities order their delegation to a women's affairs ministerial-level meeting sponsored by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Manila on Oct. 16 to demand the organizers delete the official title of the chief ROC delegate to the conference?
The ROC representative at the meeting was Lin Cheng-chih, chairperson of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs.

Both Taiwan and mainland China are APEC members. Taiwan joined the regional economic cooperation forum under the name "Chinese Taipei." According to Lee, the mainland delegate to the just-concluded APEC women's affairs meeting had also demanded the organizers delete the word "Taiwan" in Lin's home address listed in the roster of the participants.
