DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE WELCOMES CONSENSUS IN CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The consensus between Taiwan and mainland China to continue dialogue and exchanges is helpful to "building trust and reducing tension," the US government said on Friday.

"The White House welcomes reports that the two sides have reached consensus to discuss political and economic issues, to strengthen exchanges, and to work together on cases involving safety and property," a National Security Council (NSC) spokeswoman said.
The White House also welcomes reports that Wang Daohan, head of mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, has agreed to visit Taiwan.
"These steps should help the process of building trust and reducing tension between the two sides," the spokeswoman said.
The consensus was reached during meetings in Shanghai on Thursday between Wang and his Taiwan counterpart, C.F. Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation.
The NSC spokeswoman said that President Bill Clinton has urged both sides publicly and privately to "resume a constructive dialogue and to develop contacts and exchanges designed to reduce tensions."
"The administration's policy has been designed to create an atmosphere favorable to such contacts and exchanges," she said. "We're pleased by this step forward."
In a statement issued earlier this week, the US State Department also welcomed the resumption of cross-strait dialogue after mainland China postponed talks scheduled for June and July, 1995.
No further comments are expected from the State Department until next Monday, after Koo has concluded his visit to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CHINA HAND GLAD TO SEE THAW IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Chu Lusheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The meeting between top negotiators across the Taiwan Strait in Shanghai is providing Taiwan and mainland China with an opportunity to help thaw the cross-strait impasse, an expert with a US-based think-tank said on Friday.

Michael Swaine, a China expert with the Rand Corporation, a Los Angeles-based defense think-tank, said that while the Clinton administration is promoting a "fourth no" policy -- no force against Taiwan by mainland China -- the meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, has come at the right time.
The Koo-Wang meeting is a good start which is conducive to reducing tension across the Taiwan Strait and resuming long-stalled dialogue, Swaine said during an interview with the CNA.

Swaine, director of the Rand Corp.'s Asian-Pacific policy research, said that according to his assessment, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is unlikely to renounce the threat of force against Taiwan.

Jiang, however, is definitely pondering the viability of resorting to "less force" against Taiwan, because peaceful resolution of the cross-strait conflict is the one and only resolution that Washington has so far supported, and also the international community's common expectation of Jiang, Swaine noted.

Swaine said Koo's trip to Shanghai and Beijing is conducive to easing the cross-strait impasse. If the landmark visit can initiate channels for normal and regular communication across the Taiwan Strait, it is beneficial to peaceful resolution of the conflict, he added.
Although he does not foresee Koo's visit resulting in any major breakthrough in cross-strait relations, Swaine said Wang's agreement to visit Taipei was a breakthrough.
Wang, the 84-year-old ex-mayor of Shanghai, and mentor-friend of Jiang, has a certain degree of influence on the mainland president, Swaine said.

Koo's current mainland China tour, which features person-to-person contacts between high-level officials from both sides, is sure to have a positive and far-reaching impact on cross-strait relations, Swaine concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD HAVE SELF-DETERMINATION: COLUMNIST

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the right to self-determination, but the international community is timid in the face of mainland China's bluster, according to an Australian columnist.

In an article titled: "Bullying Taiwan is Irrational and Counter-productive," Greg Sheridan says the chief constraint on Taiwan is the implacable hostility of mainland China, which still regards Taiwan as a renegade province that must be brought under Beijing's rule.
"Beijing has never renounced the use of force to bring Taiwan under mainland rule," he says.

"Really, the international community is grotesquely timid in the face of Chinese bluster," he said, adding: "Taiwan deserves the right to self-determination. Instead, in order to curry favor with Beijing, the world persists with the charade of the `one-China' policy."
He notes the main constraint on mainland China's behavior is the United States, which, under its Taiwan Relations Act, is committed to maintaining Taiwan's security.

He believes the recent remarks by US President Bill Clinton, in which he explicitly repeated Beijing's "Three Noes" policy -- no independence for Taiwan, no "two Chinas," and no Taiwan membership of international organizations requiring statehood -- have distressed the people of Taiwan.
Sheridan believes China's bullying of Taiwan costs the rest of the world, including Australia.
"Beijing, for example, has prevented Taiwan from joining the World Trade Organization, so the 14th-largest trading economy in the world is not integrated into the global trading system," he says.
"Similarly, Beijing has prevented international organizations from accepting generous Taiwanese offers of financial assistance to victims of the Asian economic crisis."
"Further, if Taiwan itself were to get into trouble, the International Monetary Fund could not assist it because Beijing has blocked its membership," he adds.
He notes that mainland China wants reunification to result from the current discussions between representatives from Taiwan and mainland China in Shanghai.
"But Taiwan wants less tension, more international space, and the postponement of reunificaiton forever," said Sheridan, who also stressed that "absolutely no one in Taiwan desires unification."

"There are few things less attractive than bootlicking dressed up as high principle, which is what we mostly get when we hear blather about `one-China,'" he says, adding: "Taiwan's people have every right to determine their future, and we all have a stake in their decision."

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LINKS NEGOTIATIONS TO COME AFTER PEACE PACT: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taipei will weigh opening the three currently banned direct links with mainland China only after Beijing agrees to sign a peace agreement with Taiwan and ends attempts to isolate the island, a top official said on Saturday.

Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, Taipei's top agency in charge of policy toward the mainland, was referring to direct transportation, communication and trade links between Taiwan and mainland China.

Sheu's comments come after Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said at a news conference upon his arrival in Beijing on Friday that the three links can immediately open after hostility between Taipei and Beijing ends.
Koo is in the middle of a visit to the mainland and is scheduled to meet with mainland President Jiang Zemin on Monday.
Sheu dismissed the issues of how many members of Koo's delegation will attend the meeting, where it will take place, and in what capacity Jiang will be meeting with Koo as irrelevant.

Instead, Sheu emphasized that a meeting between Koo and Jiang will be a step toward the positive development of cross-strait ties as it provides Koo with a rare opportunity to convey Taiwan's perspectives to Jiang.

Jiang reportedly intended to meet only with Koo and his wife, but Taiwan has insisted that others be included in the meeting to avoid criticism from those in Taiwan who are suspicious of a possible secret deal between the ruling Kuomintang and Beijing.
Although details of the Koo-Jiang meeting are still under negotiation, Taiwan will not insist on a specific number of attendees, but the Koos will definitely be accompanied by others, Sheu said.
At the invitation of Beijing's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Koo and his delegation arrived in Shanghai for a six-day mainland visit on Wednesday.
During a meeting between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, a series of agreements were made in addition to an invitation by Koo for Wang to visit Taiwan, which Wang has accepted.

Koo suggested that Wang visit Taiwan during its legislative and city council elections slated for early December, but ARATS officials said it was not an appropriate period for Wang's visit and there was not enough time to arrange such a visit. Sheu said Wang could visit at another more convenient time for both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO PRESIDENT RECEIVES MILITARY HONORS UPON DEPARTURE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday bade farewell to Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore at the end of Compaore's nine-day state visit to Taiwan.

Under sunny skies on the tail end of Typhoon Zeb, Lee hosted a grand farewell ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei. Compaore was accorded with full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute followed by the national anthems of the ROC and its African ally.

Prior to the ceremony, Lee met with his Burkina Faso counterpart at the Presidential Office to discuss issues of mutual concern. The leaders then signed a joint communique to reiterate the two countries' common wish of expanding mutual cooperation.
According to the joint communique, Lee vowed that the ROC government would seek peaceful unification of those on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait through negotiations.
The communique also touched on the Asian financial crisis. Taiwan has shared with its ally what steps it has taken to avert disaster and maintain the region's economic stability and development.

Compaore expressed his full recognition of the ROC's key role in Asia's economy, encouraged Lee to continue in joint effort with other Asian leaders to boost confidence of the people in the region and those in other regions around the world.

The joint statement noted that each country's respective foreign ministers have signed two agreements on the mutual promotion and protection of investments as well as visa application issues in the hopes of promoting future exchanges.

The African president also reiterated that his government and all people of Burkina Faso support the Republic of China's complete membership of all international organizations of the world, including the United Nations.

In the interest of a peaceful and harmonious existence, Lee and Compaore both stressed the importance of respecting the principle of national independence, sovereignty and territorial rights as a part of the joint communique.
Compaore and his entourage arrived in Taiwan on Oct. 8 to attend the ROC's Double-Ten National Day celebrations at Lee's invitation.

During his stay on the island, the African leader met with Speaker of the National Assembly Fredrick F. Chien, Premier Vincent Siew and Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason C. Hu. Compaore also traveled to southern Taiwan to attend cultural and economic sites.
This marked Compaore's third visit to Taiwan after the resumption of diplomatic relations between the two countries on Feb. 2, 1994.

Other members of the visiting delegation included Salif Diallo, minister of state, environment and water; Ablasse Ouedraogo, minister of foreign affairs; Idrissa Zampalegre, minister of trade, industry and Handicrafts; Alphonse Ouedraogo, permanent secretary of six engagements; Leo Yougbare, director of protocol; and Burkina Faso journalists covering the visit.

Compaore and his entourage left Taipei on Saturday for Japan, where the leader will attend the Second Tokyo International Conference of African Development in his capacity as rotating chairman of the Organization of African Unity.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO VISITS DR. SUN YAT-SEN'S MEMORIAL, BEIJING UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: C. F. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, paid a visit to a memorial hall dedicated to Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the Republic of China's national founding father, on Saturday.
Accompanied by his wife and several members of his entourage, Koo arrived at the Biuen Temple in suburban Beijing at around 9 a.m.
Koo laid a wreath before a statue of Dr. Sun to pay his tribute to the late ROC national leader. He then browsed through Dr. Sun's manuscripts and calligraphic works exhibited in the memorial hall.
The billionaire tycoon charged with shepherding Taipei-Beijing ties in the absence of official channels said Dr. Sun was a great patriot and the vanguard of China's democratization and modernization.
"To push for China's modernization, Dr. Sun advocated the Three Principles of the People, offering a rightful direction for China's development," Koo said.

As the Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are pursuing modernization, Koo said, they should base on Dr. Sun's ideals in establishing a democratic system and developing economy to realize Dr. Sun's goals of popular sovereignty and equitable distribution of wealth.

Koo went on to say that Taiwan has evolved into a full-fledged democracy, with its senior leaders, from the president down, elected by all of its citizens. "Taiwan has also protected private ownership and promoted economic liberalization in an effort to realize Dr. Sun's ideal of equitable prosperity."
Koo said Taiwan is more than willing to share its experience in implementing Dr. Sun's thoughts and ideals so as to lay a solid foundation for positive interaction across the Taiwan Strait.
Later in the day, Koo and his wife visited Beijing University. The first president of the university, Yen Fu, was the grandfather of Koo's wife Koo-Yen Chou-yun.
The Koos laid a wreath before a statue of Yen Fu at the university's library to express their respect and remembrance to their ancestor.
Yen Fu was the first Chinese scholar to translate British biologist Thomas Henry Huxley's writings about organic evolution into Chinese to help advance scientific development in China.
Koo and his 11-member entourage flew to Beijing from Shanghai on Friday to continue their six-day ice-breaking mainland visit aimed at thaw long-stalled cross-strait relations.

Koo, a senior adviser to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Sunday, in the highest-level contact on Chinese soil between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND NOTARIES MEET IN CROSS-STRAIT WORKSHOP
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Notaries public and related judicial officials from Taiwan and mainland China met Friday and Saturday in Beijing for a cross-strait notarization workshop.

As Taiwan's top negotiator, Koo Chen-fu, and his delegates are visiting Beijing, the cross-strait notaries public's meeting is of special significance, said Wang You-feng, a counselor and public relations director of the Republic of China's Judicial Yuan. Wang is leading the Taiwan notaries public group to the mainland meeting.

Wang said during the last two days, participants from the two sides have exchanged views on notarization and related affairs, particularly on the notarization of marriages and inheritances across the Taiwan Strait, the authority and liability of notarized documents, and problems involving defected notarized items.

Taiwan was represented by 15 delegates, from the Judicial Yuan as well as the high and district courts around the island for the two-day workshop, while mainland China had 34 delegates from 17 provinces and cities present at the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: QIAN QICHEN TO BE REPLACED IN TAIWAN AFFAIRS GROUP: REPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Qian Qichen, mainland Chinese vice premier, is expected to be replaced as the current deputy head of the Central Leading Group for Taiwan Affairs in the Communist Party of China (CPC), sources said.
Qian is scheduled to meet in Beijing with Taipei's top envoy Koo Chen-fu, who is visiting the mainland.

However, Qian's meeting with Koo is said to be his last appearance in the capacity of the CPC's top policy-making official for Taiwan affairs. Zeng Qinghong, director of the General Office of the CPC Central Committee, has been tipped to replace Qian, sources said.
Huang Wenfang, former director of the Taiwan Affairs Department in the Xinhua News Agency in Hong Kong, said professional diplomats are not usually considered the ideal personnel for Taiwan affairs.

Professional diplomats are seen as having an "occupational disease," they insist too much on principles and have a lack of dexterity, Huang said. Qian was foreign minister before he assumed the post in the Central Leading Group for Taiwan Affairs.
The difficult and harsh experiences across the Taiwan Strait over the past couple of years, only serves as evidence of how a professional diplomat typically deals with Taiwan affairs, Huang added.

As Zeng, a favorite of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, will likely replace Qian, there are high expectations that the mainland's handling of Taiwan affairs will be more smooth, remarked the former official of Xinhua's Hong Kong branch office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX WEIGHTED INDEX UP 101 POINTS

TEXT.P: Share prices went up sharply on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, in a favorable reaction to gains made in New York after the US Federal Reserve's decision to drop key interests rates.
The weighted price index, the market's key barometer, closed at 6,901.19, up 101.31 points over Thursday's close. The market was closed on Friday due to the severity of Typhoon Zeb.
A total of 2.41 million shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86,610 million (US$2.63 billion).

All main eight categories of shares posted gains in hectic trading -- up 2.6 percent for plastic and chemical shares; up 1.3 percent for cement stocks; up 0.9 percent for foodstuff stocks; up 1.4 percent for textile shares; up 2.5 percent for electrical stocks; up 0.6 percent for paper and pulp issues; up 0.8 percent for construction issues; and up 0.6 percent for financial shares.

The futures market also saw big gains on Saturday. The index closed at 6,908 or up 148 points for October's delivery, up 165 points to 6,875 for November's delivery, and up 104 points to 6,860 for December's delivery.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR MOVES UP AGAINST GREENBACK

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved up against the US dollar on Saturday amid intervention by Taiwan's Central Bank of China. It closed at 32.894, rising NT$0.102 over Thursday's close.
In reaction to the US Federal Reserve's decision to cut key interest rates on Thursday, commercial banks and some traders began to sell the greenback at the start of the trading.
The local currency opened at NT$32.89, and at one point went as high as NT$32.786.
Fearing that the currency might rise too quickly, the Central Bank of China intervened and bought US dollars to keep the NT dollar close to NT$32.894.
Turnover topped US$374 million, marking the largest weekend trading this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FED'S CUTTING RATE BENEFICIAL TO BLOBAL ECONOMIC STABILITY: CBC

TEXT.P: The Federal Reserve's slashing of key US interest rates on Thursday will be beneficial to world economic and financial stability, said senior official of the Central Bank of China.

Fed's move, the second time within half a month, highlighted the fact that the US government has been aware of the impact of global financial crisis on the US economy, which has to be responded as soon as possible.

The US central bank cut the federal funds overnight bank lending rate to 5 percent from 5.25 percent. It also cut the discount rate to 4.75 percent from 5 percent. That move brought official rates to their lowest level in four years.

The loose money policy adopted by the Fed, is likely to exert much pressure on primery industrial countries such as Germany and France to lower their interest rate. It is thought to be in line with the expectations of international financial organizations, namely the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REGARDS KOO-JIANG MEETING AS CONSTRUCTIVE DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China deems the scheduled meeting in Beijing between its senior envoy C. F. Koo and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin as "constructive dialogue," a negotiator said here on Saturday.

"The Koo-Jiang meeting is expected to be meaningful communications without a specified agenda," said Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) who is accompanying Koo on a six-day mainland visit aimed at thawing relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Koo, an elder statesman and billionaire tycoon, is scheduled to meet Jiang at the Diaoyutai State Guest House on Sunday afternoon, in the highest-level cross-strait contact on Chinese soil since 1949.

"We think it will be helpful and conducive to the development of cross-strait relations if both sides can frankly express their stances on matters of mutual concern," Shi said, adding that candid exchanges of views can help foster mutual understanding.
For instance, Shi said the four-point consensus reached between SEF Chairman Koo and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, was a constructive development in cross-strait engagement.
Koo and Wang, the two octogenarian charged with shepherding cross-strait ties in the absence of official channels, sealed the four-point deal in Shanghai on Thursday.

"Even though the consensus has yet to be codified, it will serve as a guidepost for the future interchange between the two government-backed intermediary bodies that Koo and Wang head," Shi explained.

According to the deal, Wang, an ex-mayor of Shanghai and mentor to Jiang, agreed to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time. Meanwhile, SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will step up dialogue, increase exchanges at various levels and assist each other in handling incidents involving personal safety and property of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Shi said the consensus marks a step forward toward the resumption of systematic SEF-ARATS dialogue and consultations, broken off by Beijing in mid-1995.

Shi further said he hopes SEF-ARATS dialogue channels codified in the agreements reached in the first Koo-Wang meeting in Singapore in 1993 can resumed normal operations as soon as possible to facilitate bilateral exchanges and ease cross-strait situation so as to create a favorable climate and conditions for a summit meeting between ROC President Lee Teng-hui and mainland President Jiang.
Koo and his 11-member entourage flew to Beijing from Shanghai on Friday. Sunday's Koo-Jiang meeting will be a climax of Koo's current mainland trip, which will end on Oct. 19.
Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of mainalnd China's State Council hosted a dinner at the Great Hall of the People in honor of the Koo delegation on Saturday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BOOSTING ITS MILITARY AS IT TRYS TO ANNEX TAIWAN

TEXT.P: While Beijing seeks to reunify with Taiwan, it continues to bolster its military strength through boosting its high-technology weaponry, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

The People's Liberation Army (PLA) has reportedly spent US$800 million to buy Sovremenny-class guided missile destroyers from Russia. These 7,200-tonne warships are armed with 50 Sunburn supersonic anti-ship missiles that naval experts say are extremely difficult to intercept, the daily reported.
When these warships are deployed, mainland China will immediately raise the stakes in any future conflict over the Taiwan Strait.

In addition, the PLA has also bought four advanced kilo-class conventional submarines from Russia. Those along with the PLA's Chinese-made Song-class submarines could form the core of a dangerous threat to Taiwan or US naval forces, the paper reported.

Beijing is pressing for the reunification issue with Taiwan as it sees the island as the final target once it gets both Hong Kong and Macau back in its fold. Hong Kong was returned to Beijing rule in July 1997, and Portugal will hand over Macau in December 1999.

While representatives make efforts to meet and discuss political and practical issues, China's military modernization is aimed at allowing the PLA to deter any declaration of independence by Taiwan and allow them to dominate key sea lanes that carry the bulk of East Asia's trade, the paper said.
Analysts continue to believe that the 160-kilometer waterway between mainland China and Taiwan will remain one of the most dangerous flash points in Asia, it concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE CHINA' REFERS TO ROC: SEF OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) believes the Republic of China is "one China," although it refrains from referring to it in correspondence with its mainland counterpart, a SEF official said on Saturday.
SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow, who is accompanying SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu on a ice-breaking mission to Beijing, was speaking to Taipei-based journalists covering the visit.
He said the thorny issue of "one China" emerged several times in the 1992 negotiations between SEF and its the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

Both sides agree there is only one China. However, Beijing believes it is the sole legitimate representative of the one China, while Taipei insists that the one China is divided into two parts -- the mainland and Taiwan. Meanwhile, SEF believes the ROC is the one China.

As no consensus was reached on the issue and the 1993 meeting between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan went ahead anyway, Shi said SEF believed ARATS "agreed to disagree" over the definition of one China by allowing the meeting to go ahead.
Although SEF refrains from referring to "one China" in its correspondence with ARATS to avoid any awkwardness, it has never shifted away from its stance that the ROC is the "one China," Shi added.

SEF did not hesitate to refer to Sun Yat-sen as "the founding father of the Republic of China," when Koo visited Sun's tomb in Beijing early on Saturday, Shi noted. Even the mainland acknowledges Sun as the founder of the ROC, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO SHOULD TALK TOUGH IN MEETING WITH JIANG: DPP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Saturday it does not expect to see any consensus reached in Sunday's meeting between a senior Taiwan envoy and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

Chairman C. F. Koo of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), who is currently on an ice-breaking visit to mainland China, is scheduled to meet Jiang on Sunday afternoon at Beijing's Diaoyutai State Guest House.

"The Koo-Jiang meeting will be yet another climax of cross-strait political dialogue. We hope Koo and other Taiwan delegates present at the meeting will not hesitate to express Taiwan's basic stances on various political issues," said Yen Wan-chin, director of the DPP's China Affairs Department.
Yen said the Taiwan delegation should not be afraid to dispute Jiang's views about Taiwan's independent sovereignty or any other related issues.
"If Jiang mentions Beijing's one-China policy, Koo should never hesitate to make it clear that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been separately ruled by two equal governments," Yen said.
The senior executive from the pro-independence party said Koo should even take the initiative to push for China's democratization and the "internationalization" of cross-strait issues.

Yen said Koo can also take up such topics as Taiwan's demands for President Lee Teng-hui to attend the annual leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, and for joining the ASEAN Regional Forum and the Council on Security Cooperation in the Asia-Pacific.
Meanwhile, Legislator Chou Po-lun, the DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, said the government has not authorized Koo to make any promises on political issues.

"The government has just authorized Koo to conduct 'constructive dialogue' with Beijing," Chous stressed, adding that Koo should focus on discussing with Jiang such issues as protection of Taiwan investors' personal safety, property and other legitimate rights as well as ease of cross-strait animosity.
Chou further said need not rush to touch on any political issues with Jiang. "More important, he should not make any concession that might undermine Taiwan's sovereign status," he added.

Koo, accompanied by an 11-member entourage, left for Shanghai on Wednesday for a six-day mainland visit aimed at thawing bilateral ties. The delegation arrived in Beijing on Friday following its two-day stay in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW DECLARES CHANGHUA A DISASTER AREA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew declared the flood-stricken Changhua County in central Taiwan a disaster area, making it eligible for special government aid.
The premier made the decision after visiting the county and learning first-hand of the damages caused by Typhoon Zeb which swept across the island on Thursday and Friday with heavy winds and rain.

Siew, accompanied by Chairman of Council of Agriculture Peng Chuo-kui and Changhua Magistrate Juan Kang-meng, inspected Yenpu township and was briefed by local officials about the level of crop damage in the region.
Compensation as well as soft loans will be offered to farmers affected by the destruction to help them recover from the crisis, Siew said.
Meanwhile, the Council of Agriculture estimated the agricultural damages across the island at about NT$3.68 million (US$111 million), which includes the destruction of crops, poultry and fishery.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN LEADER ZHIRINOVSKY TO VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Vladimir Zhirinovsky, leader of the Russian Liberal Democratic Party, and his 40-member delegation will arrive here Sunday for a five-day visit at the invitation of Secretary General John Chang of the ruling Kuomintang Central Committee.

Officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) in Taipei said the visit will greatly help improve the substantive relations between the two countries. Members of the delegation will include 10 Russian parliamentarians, officials of Liberal Democratic Party, and journalists.

While here, they will visit government leaders and officials of the ruling Kuomintang to exchange views on how to strengthen the substantive and friendly relations between the two countries and increase the exchanges between the two parties. They will also visit economic establishments in Taiwan.
Liberal Democrative Party is the third biggest political party in Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui urged cross-strait negotiation to promote lasting peace.
The China Times: Two more members added to Taiwan's top negotiator Koo Chen-fu's scheduled meeting with mainland China President Jiang Zemin Sunday afternoon -- Shi Hwei-you, vice chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation; and Chang Jung-kung, director general of the Department of Mainland Affairs Research of the Kuomintang.
The United Daily News: Koo Chen-fu said the mainland China has to recognize the state of separate rule on both sides of the Taiwan Strait first before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can engage in political dialogue.
The Liberty Times: President Lee stressed that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are independent of each other.
The Independence Morning Post: Koo said that there is no way to continue negotiation if the mainland would not recognize the status of the Republic of China on Taiwan.
The Commons Daily: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs questioned the sincerity of the mainland when it is attempting to lure one of ROC's allies two weeks after Koo finishes his mainland trip.
The China Post: Human error linked to floods, landslide deaths.
The China News: Typhoon Zeb claims lives in Neihu.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWIAN OFFICIALS TO ARRIVE FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Harry Thomson, minister of health and population of the Republic of Malawi, and W.O.O. Sangala, Malawi's secretary for health and population, will arrive in Taiwan Monday for an eight-day visit.

During their stay, the Malawian officials will call on National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason C. Hu, Department of Health Director-General Chan Chi-shean and other government officials.
They will also visit several medical establishments on the island before leaving on Oct. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPANISH CONGRESS DEPUTIES TO ARRIVE FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Julio Padilla Carballada and Manuel Arqueros Orozco, deputies of the Congress of the Kingdom of Spain, will arrive in Taipei Monday for a weeklong visit.

While in Taiwan, they will call on Deputy Minister of Justice Chiang Hao, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin, Government Information Office Deputy Director-General Chang Pin-nan and other government officials.
They will also visit several cultural and economic establishments on the island before leaving on Oct. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATE WARNS MAINLAND OF WIDENING GAP

TEXT.P: National Unification Council (NUC) researcher Chang Jung-kung warned mainland China on Sunday of the widening gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, urging the mainland to hasten its democratization if it wishes to unify with Taiwan.

Chang, vice spokesman of an 11-member delegation accompanying Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu on his current mainland tour, stressed that Taiwan is willing to discuss any subject with mainland China as long as the mainalnd becomes a democracy.

Chang made the remarks at a news conference after a meeting between Koo and mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen Sunday morning. During the meeting, which lasted more than one hour, Qian reiterated Beijing's "one China" policy, while Koo criticized Beijing's efforts to isolate Taiwan internationally.
In addition to Chang, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow, NUC member Kang Ning-hsiang and NUC researcher Pao Chung-ho were also present at the occasion.

Rebutting Qian's remarks during the meeting that the mainland has never done anything to isolate Taiwan in the international community, Chang said that time will tell whether this is true, adding that Taiwan will "listen to Beijing's words and watch its deeds" in the future.

Pointing out that the mainland's bullying of Taiwan has made the people of Taiwan feel increasingly adrift from the "one China" claimed by Beijing, Chang warned that the problem will worsen if Beijing continues to employ such a strategy to counter Taiwan.

Chang called on Qian to pay greater heed to the development, as the mainland Chinese vice premier is the chief proponent of Beijing's use of military force, diplomatic battles and economic links to deal with Taiwan.
Pao lamented Beijing's insistence on sticking to its "one China" principle, which claims that the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate government representing the whole of China.
Pao also disagreed with Qian's contention that Taiwan's narrowed space in the international arena is a result of international trends.

Calling on the mainland to face the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are two independent political entities under separate rule, he said Koo's declaration that "China is still divided" is by no means aimed at promoting Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND'S REFUSAL TO RECOGNIZE ROC HARMFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: A spokesman for a high-level Taiwan delegation in mainland China said on Sunday that mainland China's campaign to isolate Taiwan diplomatically is harmful to cross-strait relations. Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation.(SEF), said that before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can unify under a system of democracy, each side should have its own space in the international community.

He made the statement after SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, met with mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen Sunday morning in the Diaoyutai State Guest House in Beijing.

According to Shi, Koo told Qian that if the mainland deliberately refuses to acknowledge the existence of the Republic of China, it would not only be impossible for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in political dialogue, it would elicit negative feelings from the people of Taiwan toward the mainland.

While Qian stressed that there is only one China, of which Taiwan is a part, and that the sovereignty of China is indivisible, Shi, in a conference after the Koo-Qian meeting, said that mainland China still has not accepted the fact that the two sides of the strait are under separate rule and has refused to recognize the existence of the Republic of China.

Shi mentioned Beijing's "three empties" strategy toward Taiwan. The strategy refers to Beijing's attempt to lure away all the ROC's allies by the turn of the century, to block Taiwan from joining any international organizations and to eliminate all the bargaining chips and clout that Taiwan has amassed in its efforts to seek an equal footing with Beijing.

In addition, Shi said that those mainlanders visiting the Republic of China have not paid due respect to its system, which he said has incited aversion toward the mainland and has become an hurdle to the development of cross-strait relations.

Shi said that before the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under democracy, both sides should learn to cooperate with each other, saying that this would make the Chinese on both sides of the Taiwan Strait stronger and more powerful internationally.

He expressed the hope that Beijing would forego zero-sum thinking, which would mark the first step in terminating hostilities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and create favorable conditions for future unification under a democratic system.
Asked whether the atmosphere in the Koo-Qian meeting was volatile, Shi said the ROC delegation firmly stated its stance in a peaceful manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR LEAVES FOR BUENOS AIRES

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan will leave for Buenos Aires on Monday to attend the 38th board member meeting of the Central American Bank for Economic Integration (CABEI) to be held in the Argentine capital.
A delegation composed of officials from the Finance Ministry, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the CBC will accompany Perng on the trip.

The annual CABEI conference is slated to open on Friday, which will be attended by Perng's counterparts from five founding member countries -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica -- and three other non-regional states -- Mexico, Argentina and Colombia.
CABEI was set up in 1961 in Tegucigalpa, Honduras with an aim to boost social development and economic integration in Central America.
The Republic of China joined CABEI in 1992 as a non-regional member in the hope of further strengthening exchanges and cooperation with countries in that region.
Perng is scheduled to return to Taipei on Oct. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED NOT TO OBSTRUCT TAIPEI'S JOINING KEDO

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said on Sunday that the Republic of China is interested in joining the Korea Peninsula Energy Organization (KEDO) and that he hopes Beijing will not obstruct the ROC's efforts to join the organization.

Koo made the remarks when meeting with mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen. He told Qian that several countries have suggested that Taipei join KEDO to fulfill its duty as part of the Asia-Pacific region.

"We are actively considering the feasibility of joining KEDO at the suggestion of some members of the international community," Koo was quoted as saying by SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow, who relayed Koo's remarks to the media at a press conference after the meeting.
Shi said Koo's remarks drew only a brief response from Qian, who pointed out that KEDO was organized by the United States and that Beijing had no involvement with it.

Set up by the United States, Japan, South Korea and North Korea in 1995, KEDO was intended to build two nuclear reactors for North Korea to provide Pyongyang with energy resources and to halt its nuclear development program.

Koo pointed out that Japan and South Korea, both affected by Asia's financial turmoil, have suspended their contributions to the project. Some countries have suggested Taiwan join the organization to help foot the bill.
To avoid the possibility of nuclear proliferation in northeast Asia, Koo said, Taipei is willing to consider the suggestion that it join KEDO.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO SAYS TAIWAN INVESTMENT VITAL TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu said in Beijing on Sunday that investments by Taiwan businessmen have become an important source of hard foreign currency for mainland China.
Koo made the remarks at a luncheon given in his honor by Taiwan businessmen in the capital city.

He said that statistics from Beijing indicate total projected investment by Taiwan businessmen in mainland China as of the end of June stood at US$39.3 billion, of which US$18.4 billion has already been put into practice.

Meanwhile some 1,500 Taiwan enterprises have announced investments in the city of Beijing totaling US$2 billion, of which US$1.3 billion has already been invested. That figure makes Taiwan the fourth-largest foreign investor in Beijing.

Koo said that many Taiwan businessmen have complained about being investigated by mainland authorities as part of the mainland's efforts to combat smuggling and tax fraud. Koo said he has indicated Taiwan's concerns over these investigations to Beijing on several occasions.
The SEF chairman expressed the hope that his mainland trip would lead to the resumption of the systematic consultations between Taiwan and the mainland that have been suspended for three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO TELLS QIAN HOW TO PAVE WAY FOR FUTURE REUNIFICATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's chief negotiator Koo Chen-fu said here Sunday that Taiwan and mainland China should respect each other, tolerate each other, and try to gradually improve their relations through exchanges, cooperation, and consultations so as to create favorable conditions for future democratic reunification of China.
Koo, chairman of the semi-official Strait Exchange Foundation, made the remarks when he met with mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

Koo said Beijing should recognize the historical fact that China has been under separate rule since 1949, and refrain from isolating Taiwan from the international community, so as to alleviate Taiwan people's aversion to Beijing.

He pointed out that in the world there are many opportunities for the Chinese on the mainland and Taiwan to support and cooperate with each other. "If we do so, it will not hinder the future democratic reunification of China. On the contrary, it will help increase the strength of Chinese in the world community," he added.

Koo, who is on a six-day visit to Shanghai and Beijing at the invitation of his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan, pointed out that Taiwan was reverted to the Republic of China in 1945 in accordance with the Potsdam Declaration, and that the mainland and Taiwan have been under separate rule since the end of civil war in 1949. Beijing has to recognize the undeniable historical fact that "China has been under separate rule since then," he said.
Koo and several members of his 12-member delegation are scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOP NEGOTIATOR MEETS JIANG ZEMIN

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, talked for more than one hour in a high-profile meeting Sunday afternoon.
They began their meeting with friendly conversation, talking about the weather in Beijing and Chinese opera, of which Koo is a devoted fan.
Jiang also asked Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), how long had he been away from the mainland. Koo answered that it has been 55 years since he has been to the mainland.

Photographers were given five minutes to take pictures of the meeting between the two, the culmination of Koo's "ice-breaking" mission to the mainland before the photographers were led out of the meeting hall of the Diaoyutai State Guest House.

Present with Koo at the meeting were his wife, Cecilia Koo; Shi Hwei-yow, SEF's vice chairman; Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the Department of Mainland Affairs Research of the Kuomintang; and SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng.

In addition to Jiang, four mainland officials, including Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the State Council, and Li Yafei, deputy secretary general of the Association For Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), were present at the meeting.
Speaking on the arrangement of the Koo-Jiang meeting, Tang said earlier that Koo's mainland visit officially ended after his meeting with mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen Sunday morning.

But Chen and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan suggested Jiang meet with Koo, as Koo has previously met with Jiang on several occasions and as the mainland respects Koo's contributions over the years to the promotion of cross-strait relations, according to Tang.
The meeting, Tang said, was not officially connected with Koo's visit.

SEF had suggested that Control Yuan member Kang Ning-hsiang be permitted to attend Koo-Jiang meeting, but mainland officials declined because of Kang's past affiliation with Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Koo will conclude his six-day mainland visit Monday and return to Taipei Monday night via Tokyo.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN ARRESTED TRYING TO SMUGGLE COUNTERFEIT US CURRENCY INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A man was arrested at CKS International Airport as he attempted to smuggle 288 counterfeit US 100-dollar bills into Taiwan, police said Sunday.
Police arrested Taipei County resident Lin Chin-wei, 51, who flew to Taiwan from mainland China via Hong Kong aboard a China Airlines flight.
Police, who had been tipped off, found the phony bills in Lin's luggage.

Lin told police that a Taiwan man surnamed Lee had given him NT$400,000 (US$11,765) to purchase the counterfeit money. Lee was to introduce Lin to prospective buyers for the money, Lin said. But upon further questioning, Lin made statements found contradictory by police.
The police have referred the incident to the Taipei Prosecutor's Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO SAYS MAINLAND'S DEMOCRATIZATION IS KEY TO REUNIFICATION

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu told the media in Beijing on Sunday that mainland China's democratization will be "the key to China's reunification."
Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland met the press after an hour-and-a-half meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin at the Diaoyutai State Guest House.
Koo said he expressed at the meeting his views on important issues related to cross-strait relations, while Jiang voiced his opinions as well.
Koo said each side listened to the other with a "frank, sincere and tolerant" attitude and that the talks were conducted in a "friendly and free atmosphere."
If both Taiwan and the mainland are on the road of democratization, "China's reunification will not constitute a threat to neighboring Asia-Pacific countries," Koo said.

Koo said his delegation went to the mainland with goodwill to witness the fruits of reforms enacted by the mainland over the past two decades and to make the mainland aware of the results the political and economic reforms Taiwan has carried out over the past 50 years.
Koo said he explained to Jiang the process of Taiwan's democratization and indicated the willingness of the Taiwan people to share with the mainland their democratization experiences.

During his talks in Shanghai with Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan last week, Koo invited Wang to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time. Wang accepted the invitation.
During his meeting with Koo, Jiang said Wang's Taiwan trip is "feasible."
Other members of Taiwan's visiting delegation present at the Koo-Jiang meeting were Koo's wife, Shi Hwei-yow, Chang Jung-kung and Tsan Chih-hung.

Koo told the media that because Taiwan and the mainland have been under separate rule for half a century, the two sides have different views on vital issues. "We are not afraid of different opinions. We want to continue making contacts. This is a conclusion reached through the exchange of views," he said.
Koo led a 12-member delegation to the mainland on Oct. 14 for what he called an "ice-melting trip."

Through his talks with Jiang and other Beijing officials in the past few days, Koo has come to understand the importance of "constructive dialogues" and the need for "continued and higher-level dialogues," he said.
Koo and his entourage will depart for Tokyo on Monday and will return to Taipei Monday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG ZEMIN URGED TO LAUNCH POLITICAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Kang Ning-hsiang, a member of the Taiwan delegation visiting Beijing, said here Sunday that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin may make a mark in Chinese history if he will initiate political reforms.

Kang said he would express the hope that, under Jiang's leadership, Beijing will respect human rights, lift the ban on the establishment of opposition political parties, and promote other aspects of democracy, if he were given a chance to meet with Jiang.
With political reform, mainland China will be more successful in economic reform, Kang said.

Kang, who is on the 12-member delegation led by Taiwan's chief negotiator Koo Chen-fu to Beijing, made the remarks at a press conference after Koo and four members of the delegation met with Jiang in the afternoon. Kang, who is a member of the National Unification Council in Taipei and has friendship with many leaders of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, was not allowed to attend the meeting for unknown reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN LIBERAL DEMOCRATIC PARTY CHIEF VISITING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vladimir Zhirinovsky, head of the Russian Liberal Democratic Party, arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a five-day visit aboard a privately chartered plane.

Upon arriving at CKS International Airport, Zhirinovsky said that it is significant for both nations that a Russian plane has landed in the Republic of China after 50 years without direct flights between the two.

Zhirinovsky said his visit is aimed at increasing cooperation, particularly economic cooperation, between Russia and Taiwan, as well as promoting exchanges by members of Russia's Parliament and Taiwan's legislature.

Zhirinovsky's delegation, which includes Russian members of parliament, Liberal Democratic Party officials and journalists, came at the invitation of John Chang, secretary-general of the ROC's ruling Kuomintang.
Zhirinovsky said that his party knows well of ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Chang and has great respect for the two.
As to which ROC government officials he may invite to Russia, Zhirinovsky said he would reveal at the end of his visit the names of people to be invited.
Zhirinovsky's delegation will fly to Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan on Tuesday and from there return to Moscow later in the week.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO PROPOSES COOPERATION ON SOLVING ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu said in Beijing on Sunday that during his talks with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, he proposed cross-strait cooperation to help solve the Asian financial crisis.
He also suggested that leaders from both Taiwan and the mainland meet with each other at international conferences, such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, made the remarks at a press conference held after his meeting with Jiang at the Diaoyutai State Guest House. Koo did not, however, indicate Jiang's response to his proposals.
Koo said ROC President Lee Teng-hui and President Jiang had indicated their willingness to meet each other and that such a meeting should be held in a format acceptable to both sides.

Koo will conclude his six-day trip to the mainland Monday. He said his mission went to the mainland with "goodwill" and hoped to go home with "friendship," so as to build mutual trust and eradicate hostility.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO SAYS HIS VISIT HAS 'OPENED DOOR' FOR CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, said on Sunday that his visit to the mainland has "opened a door" for continued consultations and exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the remarks at a banquet given at the Shangri-La Hotel in Beijing to show his appreciation for his host during his mainland visit, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Koo, in addressing the guests, said that he had come with goodwill and that he hopes to take back friendship to Taiwan. He also said that efforts by SEF and ARATS to promote cross-strait relations will pay off in the future.

ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei noted that during Koo's visit, he has met his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, in Shanghai; Chen Yunlin, director of Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council; and Communist Party Political Bureau member Qian Qichen in Beijing.
Koo also met with Party General Secretary and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin Sunday afternoon in a meeting with a friendly atmosphere, Tang said.

He said Koo's visit to the mainland will have a positive effect on exchanges between SEF and ARATS, adding that he and Shi Hwei-yow, SEF's vice chairman, will continue to work on a four-point consensus reached during the Koo-Wang meeting.
The four-point consensus includes an agreement by Wang to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time at the invitation of Koo.
The there other key points of the agreement were:
-- SEF and ARATS will resume dialogue on political, economic and other matters of mutual concern;
-- The two semi-official intermediary bodies will reinforce bilateral exchanges at various levels, including exchanges of visits by their staff members; and
-- SEF and ARATS will strengthen cooperation and assistance in incidents involving the personal safety and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainalnd, and vice versa.
Koo will leave Beijing Monday morning and return home via Tokyo in the evening, ending his "ice-breaking' mission, the first high-level contact between the two sides in three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DESCRIBES VICE PREMIER QIAN QICHEN AS `WITHOUT REMORSE AT ALL'

TEXT.P: A high-level official at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Sunday expressed regret over the "one China" remarks made by Chinese mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen and said Qian was "without remorse at all."
Vice Foreign Minister David Lee on Saturday asked mainland Chinese authorities to clarify three points concerning their diplomatic strangulation strategy against the Republic of China.
The request did not receive a reply from Beijing.

Both Qian and Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), repeated calls for direct trade, transportation and communication links and repeated their insistence that there is only one China.
The MOFA official, who preferred to remain anonymous, said the absence of a reply from Beijing was to be expected. He described Qian as ferocious and very stubborn.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROUNDUP OF SEF CHAIRMAN KOO'S BEIJING TRIP

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu's Beijing trip marked another peak with his talks with mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen and President Jiang Zemin on Sunday.

In his morning talks with Qian, the SEF chairman stressed that the major obstacle to the improvement of cross-strait relations is the mainland's policy of denying the existence of the Republic of China on Taiwan.

Koo urged Beijing to acknowledge the historical fact that Taiwan and the mainland have been under separate rule for 50 years. He said Beijing should stop quelling Taiwan's international activities. Otherwise, it will cause the Taiwan people's aversion and distrust toward Beijing.
Koo expressed the hope that both sides will be able to participate in international affairs for the sake of world peace, and to forgo zero-sum thinking as the first step to terminate hostility.

Qian reiterated Beijing's "one China" principle, and called on Taiwan to engage in political negotiations and to realize direct cross-strait trade, transport and communication links as soon as possible.
He said Koo's mainland trip carried some "positive significance" because face-to-face talks could help dispel misunderstanding and boost mutual understanding.

In his talks with Jiang at the Diaoyutai State Guest House on Sunday afternoon, Koo explained the process of Taiwan's democratization and indicated the willingness of the Taiwan people to share with the mainland their democratization experiences.
The top negotiator for Taiwan later told the media that the mainland's democratization is the "key to China's reunification."
He pointed out that if Taiwan and the mainland are on the road of democratization, "China's reunification will not constitute a threat to neighboring countries."
The Koo-Jiang meeting was conducted in a "friendly and free atmosphere," and each side listened to the other with a "frank, sincere and tolerant" attitude.
Almost all major important issues related to cross-strait relations were taken up at the meeting.

Koo also proposed cross-strait cooperation to help solve the Asian financial crisis and suggested a meeting between ROC President Lee Teng-hui and President Jiang at international conferences, such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Koo led a 12-member delegation to Shanghai from Taipei on Oct. 14 to start what he called "ice-melting trip."
After two rounds of talks in Shanghai between Koo and Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on Oct. 14-15, a four-point consensus was reached.

Under the agreement, the SEF and ARATS will engage in dialogues, step up bilateral exchanges of visit and strengthen mutual assistance for the solution of incidents. Wang also accepted Koo's invitation to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.

Koo said on Sunday that his mission came to the mainland with "goodwill" and hoped to leave the mainland with "friendship," so as to build mutual trust and eradicate hostility. He said he was happy that the mainland trip reopened the door for cross-strait dialogues.
The visiting delegation will depart Beijing for Tokyo on Monday morning and return to Taipei on Monday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL COMMENTS ON KOO'S TALKS WITH QIAN, JIANG

TEXT.P: Su Chi, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said on Sunday that the different views between Taipei and Beijing remained unresolved, but the two sides will continue to make contacts.

A task force on cross-strait relations held two rounds of meetings on Sunday to review Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu's talks with mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen and President Jiang Zemin.

Members of the task force included Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yu, Su Chi, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee and other officials from the MAC, the Foreign Ministry, the SEF and the National Security Council.
Most members declined to make comments. But Su Chi told the media that after Koo's talks with Beijing leaders, the basic stands of the two sides remained unchanged.
He pointed out that as Koo had stated, different views remained unresolved, but the two sides will continue to maintain contacts and exchanges.

Vice Foreign Minister Lee said Taipei was not surprised that Qian denied Beijing's plot to quell Taiwan's international activities. He stressed that the ROC will continue to do what it should do, regardless what Beijing would have said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Taiwan's top envoy to Beijing C. F. Koo debated democratic issues with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
The China Times: Koo proposed that ROC President Lee Teng-hui and mainland President Jiang Zemin meet at the 1998 APEC leadership conference in Malaysia in November; Jiang shun any response to the proposal.
The United Daily News: Koo proposed a Lee-Jiang meeting in an APEC setting.
The Liberty Times: Koo's "ice-melting" visit to mainland China drew to an end on Sunday; Koo met Jiang in Beijing to discuss democratization.
The Independence Morning Post: Koo and Jiang had a consensus on promoting a Lee-Jiang meeting.
The Commons Daily: The Koo-Jiang meeting failed to narrow cross-strait differences.
The China Post: Koo holds landmark meeting with Jiang.
The China News: Koo closes trip with Jiang meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN'S TRIP TO MAINLAND HERALDED AS A BREAKTHROUGH
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Yang Huei-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu's mainland China trip marks a breakthrough in Taiwan-mainland China relations, which have been at an impasse for more than three years, a Kuomintang official said Monday.

Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the Kuomintang's Mainland Research Department, said the visit is a breakthrough in cross-strait relations, coming at a time when regular and systematic dialogue between the two government-backed intermediary bodies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait remains stalled.
Chang, who accompanied Koo to the mainland, is also a researcher with Taiwan's National Unification Council.

Like a meeting five years ago in Singapore between Koo and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Koo's current mainland visit is breakthrough in cross-strait relations, Chang said.
Chang, who was present at a meeting between Koo and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Sunday, said three things have become clear as a result of Koo's visit.

First, Koo's visit represents a breakthrough in relations, even though the two sides of the strait have never formally ended hostilities and there has been no regular dialogue between SEF and ARATS, Chang said.

Over the past five days, Koo, who is Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland and a senior adviser to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, has met with Jiang; mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen; Chen Yunlin, a top mainland Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs; and ARATS' Wang.

Second, the visit has marked the emergence of a constructive cross-strait dialogue. Taipei took the initiative, pushing for Koo's mainland visit as early as one year ago. Despite the fact that it took 11 months for the visit to be realized, Koo has met with key mainland leaders and has talked with them in an atmosphere that Koo has described as "friendly and free," Chang said.

Despite a lack of agreement in the Koo-Jiang meeting, both sides have fully expressed their respective positions, which is conducive to further understanding between the two sides, Chang said. This development is in line with a call made by ROC President Lee in his National Day speech on Oct. 10 for constructive cross-strait dialogue, Chang said.

Third, Taiwan, which is widely known as a full-fledged democracy, is awaiting the democratization of the mainland. "The mainland's democratization is the key to China's reunification, and only by accelerating their steps will conciliation between the two sides be possible," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE ASKS SIEW TO REPORT ON KOO'S MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan decided on Monday to invite Premier Vincent Siew to report on Friday on a just-concluded landmark visit to mainland China by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, C. F. Koo.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh, the Cabinet's chief mainland policy planner, and Chairman Koo of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) are also expected to field questions at Friday's legislative session about Koo's meetings with senior mainland leaders during his Oct. 14-19 "ice-melting" visit.

The legislative caucuses of the three major domestic political parties gave different evaluations to the performance of the 12-member Koo delegation during its Shanghai-Beijing visit aimed at thawing a more-than-three-year hostile freeze in relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Wang Ling-lin, the ruling Kuomintang's legislative whip, said Koo and his entourage managed to clearly express the Republic of China's basic stance on many critical issues.
"We are satisfied with the delegation's performance. We believe the visit will help Beijing better understand Taiwan's basic stance," Wang said.
New Party whip Chen Yi-hsin criticized senior mainland leaders' stiff, tough attitude in discussing some sensitive political issues with Taiwan negotiators.
"Beijing's high-handed attitude would only hinder cultivation of mutual trust for further engagement," Chen said.

Chou Po-lun, head of the legislative caucus of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said it was regrettable that issues related to the protection of personal safety, property and legitimate rights of Taiwan investors and tourists in mainland China had not been discussed during Koo's visit.
Chou cautioned local people not to hold overly optimistic expectations of future development of cross-strait relations after Koo's mainland trip.
"China remains a risky place for Taiwan investors. Local business people should not lightly launch new ventures there to avoid possible financial losses," Chou said.
The legislative whip of the pro-independence party also blasted the ruling party for failing to recruit any DPP member in Koo's entourage.

Chou said mainland China's President Jiang Zemin met Koo in his capacity as the Chinese Communist Party's general secretary. "As Koo is a member of the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee, Sunday's Koo-Jiang talks appeared to be a party-to-party meeting," he said, adding that such arrangements were very inappropriate.

"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should conduct government-to-government dialogue, not party-to-party (KMT-to-communist party) talks," he insisted, adding that the DPP will ask Premier Siew on Friday to explain why Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's mainland research department was included in the Koo's entourage while no DPP representative was included.
