DOC.HEADLINE: TOP TAIWAN NEGOTIATOR RETURNING HOME AFTER SIX-DAY MAINLAND VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By CNA reporters and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu, left Beijing Monday for home via Tokyo after a six-day, landmark visit to the mainland.
Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said he went to the mainland with Taiwan's "goodwill" and was returning with the mainland's "friendship."

He has called his mainland visit an ice-melting, as opposed to an ice-breaking, one, as whatever ice may have existed was broken during Koo's earlier meeting with Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore in 1993.

Koo, 81, accompanied by his wife, their two adult children and SEF officials, departed from Beijing International Airport at 10:30 a.m. for Tokyo, where they will transit for about four hours before heading for Taipei at around 6:30 p.m.
Koo will meet with members of the Chinese, Japanese and Western media while in Tokyo to explain the purpose of the group's visit to the mainland and the ROC's position on cross-strait relations.
Along with senior SEF officials, including SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow, Koo will proceed to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council immediately after arriving in Taipei to report on the visit.

A successful business tycoon, Koo is Taiwan's veteran ambassador-at-large, having represented President Lee Teng-hui at leadership meetings held within the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in the past three years.
During his visit in Beijing, Koo met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin at the Diaoyutai State Guest House on Sunday for a talk that lasted for an hour and a half.

According to Koo, he indicated during the meeting with Jiang Taiwan's willingness to share with the mainland its democratization experiences. He also proposed cross-strait cooperation to help solve the Asian economic crisis, and suggested a meeting between President Lee and President Jiang at an international conference, such as an APEC summit meeting.
In Beijing, Koo also met with mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen and Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of mainland China's State Council for talks on issues of mutual concern.
During his stay in Shanghai on Oct. 14 and 15, Koo met three times with his mainland counterpart, ARATS' Wang. They reached a four-point consensus on cross-strait relations.

Under the agreement, SEF and ARATS will resume their long-stalled dialogue, accelerate bilateral exchanges and visits, and work to ensure the safety of people from one side of the strait while visiting or living on the other. Wang also accepted an invitation by Koo to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.

In addition to meeting mainland Chinese officials for talks, Koo, who has lived in both Shanghai and Beijing, also toured scenic, historical and economic establishments in the two major Chinese cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION'S VISIT TO BEIJING REPORTED IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Mainland China and Taiwan may be trying to patch up a decades-old feud, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) reported Sunday.
"The two countries have just wrapped up a series of high-level meetings" in Shanghai and Beijing, the CBC noted in a brief news report.
The report initially appeared on the CBC's web site, though an updated version was delivered later on its Newsworld station.

The meetings between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, and senior mainland officials were the highest-level talks since the Nationalists relocated to Taiwan in 1949, the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KYRGYZSTAN TO BECOME WTO MEMBER

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World Trade Organization's General Council agreed to adopt a working party report on, and Recommended protocol for, the accession of Kyrgyzstan into the world trade body, it was learned Sunday.

WTO members concluded negotiations on Kyrgyzstan's goods and services trade and adopted the draft protocol of accession and the working party's draft report in July 1998. The documents constitute the set of WTO obligations, tariff concessions on goods and specific commitments on services made by Kyrgyzstan during almost two and a half years of negotiations with other WTO members.

Esengul Omuraliev, head of Kyrgyzstan's Inter-Ministerial Commission on the WTO, signed the protocol of accession agreement after the adoption of the protocol by the General Council. Kyrgyzstan will become a WTO member 30 days after it notifies the WTO Secretariat of the completion of its ratification proceedings.

Kyrgyzstan first applied for WTO membership in February 1996. A working party was established in April 1996 and its first meeting was held in March 1997. Of the new republics created after the dissolution of the former Soviet Union in 1991 that are currently seeking WTO membership, Kyrgyzstan is the first to have completed its negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATVIA TO BECOME WTO MEMBER

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World Trade Organization's negotiations on the accession of Latvia to the world trade body Were concluded successfully after the WTO's General Council adopted Latvia's working party report and protocol of accession, it was learned Sunday.

The WTO's General Council concluded that the working party on Latvia's accession had completed its work on the package of accession documents, thereby allowing Latvia to sign the accession protocol agreement.

Valdis Birkavs, Latvia's minister of foreign affairs, signed the protocol of accession agreement after the adoption of the protocol by the General Council. Latvia will become a WTO member 30 days after it notifies the WTO Secretariat of the completion of it ratification proceedings.
The working party on Latvia's accession to the then-General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs was established in 1993 and was converted to a WTO working party in 1995.

In September 1998, it adopted by consensus the draft report, protocol of accession and the schedules of concessions on goods and services. Latvia has agreed to bring its economic and trade regime into conformity with WTO rules and obligations in all areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN TO HELP PHILIPPINES TRACK STORM PATHS

TEXT.P: To help minimize the adverse effects of typhoons in the Philippines, the United Nations (UN) has offered to enhance the Estrada administration's weather forecasting capabilities with the use of its hi-tech satellite system.

Secretary Orlando Mercado of the Department of National Defense (DND) said the United Nations plans to hook up its satellite system with that of the National Disaster Coordinating Council (NDCC), enabling the government to better track the paths of future storms.
The United Nations is providing the service free of charge, said Mercado, who is also chairman of the NDCC.
"They want to help because a similar initiative in China was able to minimize the number of casualties with the use of satellite forecasting," Mercado said in a recent radio interview.
Mercado was referring to the abnormal swelling of the Yangtze River in mainland China last August, which killed some 2,000 people.

The UN proposal would be a great help to the government's disaster-relief operations, considering that the recent La Nina-induced typhoons are just the start of series of super howlers expected to hit the country by the end of December, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PRIME MINISTER RESHUFFLES CABINET

TEXT.P: Fresh from his victory in federal elections Oct. 3, Prime Minister John Howard reshuffled his Cabinet, introducing six new faces and dumping three ministers in a bid to focus his administration on jobs, rural and regional services, reconciliation with the country's Aborigines and the Olympic Games.
In a press conference on Sunday night, Howard described the changes as a significant renewal of the federal government to "take on the challenges of a new term and a new century."
Tim Fischer remains unchanged as deputy prime minister and trade minister. Other ministers retaining their positions are Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and Treasurer Peter Costello.

Two of the new faces are Defence Minister John Moore, who took over from the retiring Ian Machlahlan, and Industry, Science and Resources Minister Nick Minchin, who is replacing Warwik Parer, who resigned. Meanwhile, Andrew Thompson has been replaced as sports minister by Jackie Kelly.

Howard won a second three-year term in the Oct. 3 election, in which the coalition government comprising Howard's Liberal Party and the National Party managed to fend off a challenge by the Labor Party. The coalition's majority in Australia's House of Representatives, however, dropped from 41 seats to 15.
There are now 65 Liberal members of parliament (MPs) and 16 National MPs, compared with 66 Labor MPs and one independent in the 148-seat House of Representatives.

Political analysts said Howard has reshaped his Cabinet with one main aim and one main constraint. The aim is to win the next election. But he faces the challenge of figuring out how to win back the one million votes lost to the One Nation Party during the Oct. 3 election.
The Howard government will also face opposition from other parties in getting passed his tax reform package, especially a proposed 10 percent goods and services tax, by the Senate later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEANS SEE AUSTRALIA LOSING 'SAFE HAVEN' STATUS

TEXT.P: European institutional investors believe Australia is losing its status as a "safe haven," according to a new report.
The report by EuroScan 98 has found that European institutional investors with a combined investment total of US$15 billion in Australia no longer consider the country a safe haven for investment.

The proportion of respondents who expressed a willingness to increase their investment in Australian equities has dropped to 35 percent from 56 percent in a survey in 1997, according to the same report.

About 20 percent of the institutions said they planned to reduce asset allocations to Australia, indicating that, in the past 12 months, expectations regarding Australia's economy have changed significantly.
"Some 79 percent respondents expect the Australian economy to deteriorate in the next 12 months. This is largely attributable to Australia's trading relationship with Asia," the report said.

The EuroScan 98 report was prepared by the Sydney-based investor relations company Orient Capital, which surveyed 50 institutions based in Amsterdam, Dublin, Edinburgh, Frankfurt, Geneva, Glasgow, London, Paris, Rotterdam and Zurich.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TAKES PART IN TEXTILES CONFERENCE IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A group of leading textile manufacturers from the Republic of China are taking part in a three-day International Textile Manufacturers Federation (ITMF) conference that starts Monday in Melbourne.

The ROC delegation includes Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Textile Corp. and William Shan, president of the Chung Hsing Textile Corp. Among the other ROC delegates are chairmen of various textile industry associations.

About 200 delegates from nearly 30 countries, including the United States, Switzerland, Japan, South Korea, India, Pakistan, Indonesia and Australia, will attend the meeting, Shan said Monday in an interview with CNA.
This year's theme is "Changing Face of Asia" after the Asian economic crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEANS NOT READY TO PICK UP ASIAN STOCKS

TEXT.P: More than eight out of 10 respondents in a survey of European financial experts believe it is too early to invest in the region's stock markets.

Twenty-nine percent of respondents said that, over the next one to two years, Korea will lead other markets in the region, while 27 percent said Japan will lead, 26 percent said Hong Kong will lead and 21 percent said Singapore will lead. Twenty-four percent, meanwhile, said they did not have an opinion.

The survey, conducted by Anglo-French market research firm Taylor Nelson Sofres, allowed respondents to provide more than one answer to a single question. The latest "Eurobarometer" reading was taken by polling financial experts in eight European countries. A total of 206 respondents took part in the telephone survey.

A majority of those polled, 78 percent, said that despite the current crisis in the region, Asian stock markets continue to posses strong long-term potential. Most bullish were the French, with 91 percent saying Asian markets possess growth potential.

Almost half of the respondents said Asia is at its worst point in the regional economic and financial crisis, while just under one-quarter felt the worst was over. But 28 percent said the worst was yet to come.

Nearly one-third of those polled said the key sign of economic recovery in the region would be an upturn in financial and economic indicators. About one-quarter said the region's recovery hinges on Japan being able to clean up its banking sector and strengthen its currency.
The survey took place before the recent strengthening of the yen against the US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTISTS SEE GIANT SNAILS AS A THREAT

TEXT.P: Giant snails the size of a man's fist are a threat to Australia, as they are likely to invade the country and devastate the environment and the nation's rice industry, according to Australian scientists.
They said the golden apple snail, which varies in size from that of a golf ball to a tennis ball, could pose a threat to Australia as great as those of cane toads or carp.

Golden apple snails are the world's largest freshwater snails and many Australians regard them as a popular aquarium pet, according to the scientists working with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO).

They said the golden apple species, native to South America, has proved to be highly adaptable, devouring everything from fish tank algae to rice to taro roots. The snails have done as much as US$1.2 billion worth of damage to rice crops in the Philippines.

Geoff Baker, one of the snail experts at the CSIRO, said golden apple snails are a voracious, uncontrollable pest that have arrived at Australia's northern doorstep and can enter the country at any time.
The snails are now present in parts of Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, mainland China, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Japan.
Golden apple snails were imported from South America as "Asian escargot," but proved an unpopular dish. The snails ultimately escaped into rice fields, Baker said.

"If it is established in Australia ... it has the potential to spread across the continent, invading and ravaging our native river systems and the A$500 million (US$312 million) rice export industry," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLD SHINES AS A SAFE HAVEN FOR INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Gold is expected to become a safe investment haven again as more investors fear that economic slowdowns are spreading and financial risks escalating, market analysts said.

The Australian Financial Review on Monday quoted Dinsa Mehta, managing director of commodities for Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, as saying that gold seems to have found a higher trading range, now going for around US$300 an ounce.
The daily reported Asia's economic slowdown and banking crisis has spread into Eastern Europe, South America, United States and Europe.

The rapidly expanding interest rate spread between government debt, particularly US government debt, and other forms of debt, such as corporate debt, is evident that there has been a very dramatic change in the world's risk profile, said US Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan.
Analysts said gold has historically been bought as a hedge against inflation and that the metal could play a major role again in times of crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND TO OVERTAKE US GDP BY 2015: OECD

TEXT.P: Mainland China is likely to overtake the United States as the world's largest economy in about 15 years, according to a new study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).

In 2015, mainland China's gross domestic product (GDP) will reach US$9.41 trillion, surpassing the US$9.34 trillion GDP of the United States. By then, the mainland will regain its historical position as the world's largest economy, projects the OECD study.

Using OECD quantitative measurement techniques never before applied to the mainland and "rather conservative forecasts" of 5.5 percent annual GDP and 4.5 percent per capita growth, "China would probably reach US levels of total GDP by 2015," accounting for about 17 percent of world's GDP, said the study.

The projected 4.5 percent capita growth, the study stresses, is conservative in that it was the average growth rate achieved by Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Singapore and Taiwan "in the 20 years after they reached China's 1995 level of income."

The OECD study, written by economic historian Augus Maddison and released last month, noted that mainland China has been the world's leading economy in nine of the 10 centuries in the last millennium.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WILL DISCUSS TAIWAN'S PARTICIPATION IN KEDO
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: There are signs that the United States is not ruling out Taiwan's participation in an international project to build two nuclear reactors for North Korea, sources indicated.

The Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) was launched in 1995 by the United States, Japan and South Korea in a bid to halt future possible development of nuclear programs by Pyongyang.

Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, said Taiwan is interested in joining KEDO during his meeting with mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen on Sunday in Beijing. Koo also said he hoped Beijing would not obstruct Taiwan's efforts to join the organization.

In recent testimony before the US Congress, US special envoy to the Korean Peninsula Charles Kartman said the United States would discuss the possibility of Taiwan helping to finance KEDO. He added that he wanted to continue discussing the issue.
Kartman was responding to questions by Benjamin Gilman, chairman of the House Committee on International Relations, on whether Taiwan will contribute to KEDO.
Kartman said KEDO is facing financial problems. The economic turmoil that has swept through Asia since mid-1997 has also depleted potential financial sources.

Japan suspended its promised US$1 billion to the project after North Korea fired what was believed to be test missiles over Japan in late August. But the United States and South Korea persuaded Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi to resume contributing to the organization.

Outsiders have known very little about the discussions in the US about Taiwan's possible financing of KEDO. Observers are intrigued that Koo would sound out the mainland's reaction to such a possibility in his meeting with Qian. Koo's remarks in the meeting were made public by his aide, Shi Hwei-yow.

The United States has stated that it would not support Taiwan's bid to join international organizations in which statehood is a requirement. While KEDO's ultimate purpose is political, it has been a three-party organization concerned with economic activities -- the building of nuclear reactors as its main task.

Although a nod from the United States could almost translate into the participation of Taiwan in KEDO, Washington must take into account Beijing's reaction as it holds sway in the four-way talks on the two Koreas.

KEDO was established with the goal of building two light-water nuclear reactors for North Korea by 2003 in exchange of North Korea's promise to scrap its nuclear development program. It has been estimated that the project will cost US$4.6 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCES FOR LEE-JIANG MEETING AT APEC SUMMIT ARE SLIM: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Despite a thaw in relations across the Taiwan Strait, the top leaders from both sides are not expected to meet any time soon, not to mention at an upcoming regional summit meeting, a senior official said on Monday.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said although both ROC President Lee Teng-hui and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin have expressed a desire to meet each other, the prospects for such a meeting remain unclear.

During a meeting with Jiang in Beijing on Sunday, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China C. F. Koo proposed that the two leaders meet at the 1998 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum scheduled for mid-November in Malaysia. Jiang, however, didn't make any response to the proposal.

Judging from Beijing's consistent tough policy toward Taiwan, the official said, a Lee-Jiang encounter in an international setting like the annual APEC summit meeting is not likely in the near future.
Both Taiwan and mainland China are APEC members. Because of Beijing's opposition, President Lee has been barred from attending the annual APEC informal leadership meeting.

In the past three years, Lee consistently appointed Koo to represent him at the annual APEC summit meeting. The official predicted that the president may continue to name Koo, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to attend the upcoming APEC meeting in Kuala Lumpur on his behalf.
As for the possibility of Lee and Jiang exchanging visits, the official said the proposal has not yet entered a planning stage.
"The prospects for a Lee-Jiang meeting will not become clear until after Wang Daohan, top mainland negotiator with Taipei, visits Taiwan some time next year," the official said.
Wang, an 82-year-old ex-mayor of Shanghai and mentor to mainland President Jiang, has accepted an invitation from Koo to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.

Koo originally hoped that Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) would visit Taiwan in the run-up to the island's Dec. 5 elections for the Legislative Yuan and the mayors and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
"As mainland authorities have been reluctant to recognize Taiwan's achievements in democratization, Wang is not expected to visit the island until the first half of next year," the official said.

Before Wang's visit, ARATS Executive Vice Chairman Tang Shubei is expected to come to Taiwan to set the stage for Wang's arrival. "Tang may visit the island early next year to discuss technical details concerning Wang's visit," the official said.

Tang visited Taipei for the first time in May 1995 to arrange for a planned second Koo-Wang meeting. Although the two sides managed to reach consensus on several key points, Beijing unilaterally suspended the proposed Koo-Wang meeting in anger at Taiwan's efforts to break out of diplomatic isolation.

Koo's just-concluded mainland visit marked the first high-level cross-strait contact in more than three years. Even though the two sides still failed to bridge their wide differences, Koo's Oct. 14-19 visit marked a new beginning in cross-strait engagement after a long impasse.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP, FUTURES DOWN ON TAIPEI MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high on Monday but moved down later at the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX), with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 3.37 points to close at 6,904.56.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,944.14 points, 42.95 higher than Saturday's close.

A total of 1.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.41 billion, decreasing from the previous trading session which saw 2.41 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$86.61 billion.

Half of the eight major categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by construction stock at 1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.7 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent, while cement shares remained unchanged.
Other major categories registered losses, with textile issues moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 0.4 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were lower as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October declined eight points to close at 6,900, with 641 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 12 points to finish at 6,863, while December futures decreased five points to 6,855, and June futures dropped 12 points, closing at 6,740.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 1,051, 24, and five, respectively. No transactions were registered for March futures.
Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for Monday were 6,908 for October; 6,875 for November; 6,860 for December; 6,815 for March; and 6,752 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS HAIL TOP ENVOY'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang legislators on Monday hailed Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu for his efforts as he winds down his ice-breaking mainland China tour.
KMT Legislator Chen Hung-chi said the six-day trip was successful because Koo had firmly conveyed Taiwan's position in meetings with top Chinese leaders.
Koo met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen on Sunday in separate meetings.

The atmosphere during the Koo-Jiang meeting was cordial, with the two sides falling short of discussing any concrete issues such the "one China" dispute. However, in Koo's earlier meeting with Qian, the mainland vice premier reiterated that Beijing is the sole legitimate Chinese government representing the whole of China, while Koo criticized Beijing's attempts to isolate Taiwan in the international community.

Judging from Qian's remarks, Chen said it was obvious the mainland is continuing with its hard line toward Taiwan. Chen said Taiwan should take a "business as usual" attitude in face of such a situation as the long-running stalemate in cross-strait relations cannot be resolved in the short term.
As long as Taiwan and the mainland continue exchanges and contact by forswearing their prejudices and differences, the two sides are likely to find a common ground between them, he said.

Legislator Lin Cheng-tse said it was nothing new that Beijing has maintained its traditional hard line toward Taiwan because there have always been hard liners in the Communist Party favoring such a strategy to Taiwan.

As Taiwan and mainland China have been separated for nearly half a century, it is normal that there are misunderstandings between both sides, Lin noted. Because of this, it would take time for the relationship to be mended, adding that Koo's historical trip represents a breakthrough in bilateral ties.
"I am personally optimistic about the future development of cross-strait ties," he said.

Both Chen and Lin contended that Taiwan cannot give way to pressure from Beijing even in the face of a hardline policy. Taiwan should continue to improve its relations with the mainland while promoting substantive ties with other foreign countries, they said.
"Don't expect your rival to be kind to you. A country must count on the support of its people to be able to protect them," Lin stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY HEAVYWEIGHT APPROVES KOO'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: The New Party's candidate for Taipei mayor on Monday hailed the performance of Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, saying the meetings with mainland leaders have helped ease tension between the two sides.

Wang Chien-shien said he approved of Koo Chen-Fu's performance as the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation's historical meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing on Sunday was conducted in a cordial atmosphere. Koo also met mainland Chinese Vice President Qian Qichen earlier in the day.

As the two sides have shown they are able of maintaining a cordial climate and have agreed on future exchanges, Koo's trip to the mainland can be considered a success, Wang said. The New Party candidate also called on the public to not judge the SEF delegation's performance too harshly.
However, Wang warned that it is too early to predict any change in cross-strait ties, stressing that the most important thing for Taiwan to do is observe subsequent developments.

The pro-unification party heavyweight said the New Party favors maintaining the current status quo under the "unification" framework, but it does not support imminent unification with mainland China. He urged the public not to misunderstand the New Party's stance on the issue.
Wang said he would be willing to debate the issue with mayoral contenders from the other political parties as the topic is of paramount importance to Taiwan's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOOD COMPANIES EYE EUROPEAN GOURMET MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan food producers are eyeing the European market where only fine or gourmet foreign foods have succeeded.

A total of 18 leading food companies from Taiwan began their promotional drive in the International Fair of Food in Paris on Sunday with displays of their high-end food products which include confectionary, tea, green algae, ready-to-serve food, frozen seafood and frozen vegetables.

Taiwan food products have stolen part of the show in the first day of the largest food exposition in Europe. More than 40 European food companies and importers have registered to attend a Taiwanese food workshop scheduled at the fair on Wednesday, said the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), which organized the Taiwan food makers and exporters delegation to Paris.

The Food Processing Industrial Association of France hosted a lunch in honor of the Taiwan delegation on Sunday. During the gathering, food processing manufacturers and exporters from both sides reached a consensus on promoting technology cooperation and exhibition exchanges, according to CETRA officials.

The International Fair of Food in Paris takes place once every two years. This year's event involves participation by 4,500 companies from 88 countries and areas, and is expected to attract some 150,000 buyers and visitors during its five-day run.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP IN GENERAL POSITIVE OF KOO'S MISSION

TEXT.P: Amid some criticism, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday expressed generally positive statements about the first top-level contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in three years.

Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, wrapped up a six-day tour to the mainland in which he met with high-level officials such as Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

Yen Wan-chin, director of DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, said Koo's trip has helped re-establish cross-strait exchanges. He said that such exchanges are a positive development for the international community and for both sides of the strait, adding that it is also in line with the DPP's policy of multi-directional cross-strait dialogue.
Yen said it was a good thing that the Koo delegation, in its meetings with the mainland officials, highlighted cross-strait differences.

The thinking and stance on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are different, and the meetings were a chance to let the other side understand the differences, which would be helpful to future dialogue, Yen said.

Yen was most positive about Koo's meeting with Jiang in Beijing on Sunday, during which Koo spent much time discussing the democratic progress in Taiwan. Koo stressed that if the mainland wants to further develop, it has to bravely chose the road to democracy.

If both sides all tread the road of democracy, a unified China will not pose a threat to Asian neighboring countries, Koo told Jiang in the meeting which capped his ice-breaking mission to the mainland.
Yen also said Koo's trip has let the other side of the Taiwan Strait know that Taiwan has excelled in its democratization and international cooperation.

However, Yen criticized Koo's trip as unsatisfactory because Koo has set "a China under separate rule" as the basic tone of talks, which he believed could mislead the world to think that Taiwan is supporting Beijing's "one China" concept.

The DPP has repeatedly said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should be independent of each other, that democratic progress will replace unification progress, and supported the use of international cooperation to break away from the diplomatic blockade imposed by Beijing.
Koo, at the invitation of his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan, visited Shanghai and Beijing from Oct. 14-19. Koo and his delegation returned home via Japan on Monday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG MEETING RAISES CURTAIN FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: COMMENTATOR
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Wang Man-na and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu's mainland China trip has raised the curtain for cross-strait political talks, a Chinese political observer said in Hong Kong on Monday.
Huang Wenfang, former director of the Taiwan affairs department under the Xinhua News Agency's Hong Kong bureau, made the comment in an interview with the Central News Agency.

He said although Koo and Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) indicated their different views on the "one China" issue, both sides achieved better than expected results.

For Taiwan, Huang said, Koo's mainland trip virtually revived the channels for cross-strait communications that had been suspended for three years. Beijing, meanwhile, got to engage in political talks with Taipei in the Koo-Wang meeting.

Huang said the difference over the "one China" issue emerged again during Koo's talks with mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen on Sunday. He said political differences between the two sides can not be narrowed in a short time, and the best way for this to be achieved is to let history solve the differences.

The political observer said the Koo-Wang talks clearly indicated that Taiwan and the mainland had sincerity to hold political discussions. But he said that the two sides have not yet removed their hostilities and there is still a lack of mutual trust.
Huang said Beijing holds the key to the improvement of cross-strait relations, and better understanding toward Taiwan by Beijing can help the promotion of bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, EUROPEAN INVESTORS SAID WARMING UP TO ASIA AGAIN

TEXT.P: A rally on major Asian stock exchanges on Friday has attracted the attention of US and European investors to the region, The Business Times reported.
While the 8 percent surge has made fund managers take notice after months of slides, few are ready to jump back in and load up on Asian equities in a big way.
European-based fund managers, fearing that the surge reflects a "dangerous" rally in a global bear market, are particularly cautious and prefer to sit on cash for now.
However, some US funds have pointed out that the recent heavy fund redemptions have created pools of liquidity which are just waiting for the dust to settle before they move back in, the report said.

"Friday's gains, along with the signing into law of Japan's bank rescue bill should give measure of confidence that Asia is finally working its way through its problems," said Albert Golding, international investment strategist at Worthington Management in the US.
"People are slowly starting to show an interest in putting money into these markets again," he said.
Still, many traders said Friday's rally did not signal that foreign investors were returning to the region. Instead, they attributed the bulk of the buying to local retail investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG MEETING CONCLUDES AS EXPECTED: HK SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The results achieved in Taipei top envoy Koo Chen-fu's mainland China trip were expected by both sides of the Taiwan Strait, said a scholar from the City University of Hong Kong.

Cheng Yu-shuo, chair professor of political science of the City University of Hong Kong, told CNA on Monday a breakthrough on the issue of reunification was not expected by either side in Koo's meeting with his counterpart, Beijing's Wang Daohan.

The primary purpose of the meeting, said Cheng, was to foster a less hostile atmosphere and was in response to the international community. The four points the two sides agreed upon were basically as outlined by Beijing and Taipei in advance.
The professor said both sides backed down somewhat to foster such an atmosphere.

Taiwan, which wants talks to focus only on practical issues, has not ruled out a discussion on political matters. Koo has also invited Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, to visit Taiwan at appropriate time. Meanwhile, the mainland agreed that the two sides continue with future talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEHMAN PUTS REGIONAL BANKS' PROBLEM LOANS AT US$1.2T

TEXT.P: Problem loans in Asian banks has been estimated at over US$1.2 trillion, not including banks in mainland China and India, The Business Times cited a Lehman Brothers report as saying.

While Japan accounts for the lion's share of the bad or doubtful banking debts at US$1.1 trillion, the percentage of problem loans to total loans is vastly higher in Association for Southeast Asian Nations countries and the burden of recapitalizing banking systems there will be far greater relative to the size of the economies concerned than in Japan, the report said.

Lehman Brothers analysts said Asian governments will need to play a major role to help meet the cost of what is estimated to be a US$386 billion bill for recapitalizing regional banking systems. Even then, the problem of tackling a huge burden of corporate debt outside the local banking system, in Indonesia and elsewhere, remains to be tackled.

The 60 trillion yen banking rescue package passed last week by Japan's Parliament allows 25 trillion yen or US$212 billion for recapitalizing banks, but the Lehman report suggests that Japanese banks will require US$386 billion for recapitalization purposes.
Other analysts suggest at least US$300 billion and the implication is that either the government will have to provide more funds or the banks will continue laboring under bad debt for some time.

For Asia, the outlook is far more bleak, the report suggests. While Japan's official bank recapitalization package amounts to around 5 percent of GDP (or 12 percent if the cost of rescuing failed banks is included) the cost of recapitalizing banks in Indonesia and in Thailand will amount to a massive 31 percent of GDP in both cases. In South Korea, the preemption will be 19 percent of GDP and in Malaysia 17 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENT DETAINED FOR READING CIVIL RIGHTS CONVENANT

TEXT.P: Dissident Cai Gueihua of Shanghai was detained for 10 hours by police after being found reading the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights at a park in Shanghai with other dissidents.
The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said in a press release that Cai was taken away from his home Sunday morning, and was released 10 hours later.

The police did not show any identification when they entered Cai's home, and used force in order to take him away, the information center said, adding that he staged a hunger strike in the police department because he believed the police took him into custody in an illegal way.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN REFUTES QIAN'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen on Monday refuted Beijing's claim that Taiwan's linking of national unification to mainland China's democratization is unrealistic.

Noting that economic liberalization, political democratization and market globalization are three prevailing international trends, Chen said mainland China should take concrete steps to improve bilateral relations and pave the way for eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under freedom and democracy.
Chen also rebutted mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's allegation that Taiwan's suffering of diplomatic setbacks is an "international trend."
In the post-Cold War era, Chen said, the general world trends are characterized by freedom, democracy, detente, reconciliation and peace.

"The hostile diplomatic suppression and strangulation strategy adopted by Beijing against Taiwan is by no means a historical trend," Chen stressed, adding that Beijing's continued diplomatic offensive against Taiwan will only hinder the development of cross-strait ties.

Chen went on to say that the Republic of China government basically recognizes the just-concluded mainland visit by its top negotiator with Beijing C. F. Koo as a "new beginning" for long-stalled cross-strait relations.
"Koo's Oct. 14-19 mainland visit has helped open a door for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue broken off by Beijing more than three years ago," Chen said.
Nevertheless, Chen said, more concrete actions other than dialogue should be done in bridging wide differences and forging cross-strait rapprochement.
"Deeds speak louder than words. We hope Beijing will take positive steps to show its sincerity to improve cross-strait relations in the wake of Koo's 'ice-melting' mainland visit," Chen said.
The career-diplomat-turned-spokesman further said pointed rhetoric voiced by mainland negotiators concerning the ROC's status during Koo's visit betrayed Beijing's persistent hostility toward Taiwan.

"Beijing's denial of the ROC's existence is a principal obstacle to the development of bilateral ties," Chen said, adding that the ROC, as an independent sovereign state, must safeguard its national identity, dignity and safety.

Stressing that the ROC has become a full-fledged democracy, Chen said Beijing cannot force Taiwan to accept its "one China" definition. "Our country's future can be decided only by our people," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SUBMITS CANDIDATE LISTS FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTION

TEXT.P: After a six-hour meeting, the Kuomintang's screening committee on Monday approved the name lists for candidates vying for Legislative Yuan seats reserved for national constituencies and overseas Chinese communities.
Both name lists will be submitted to the ruling party's Central Standing Committee meeting to be held on Tuesday for approval.

For the legislative election, the single nontransferable vote (SNTV) will be employed. Normally, several representatives are elected from a single constituency which is demarcated essentially on the existing administrative boundaries. In a given constituency, each voter casts only one vote and several of the leading candidates are selected.

Since the Legislative Yuan election in 1992, a certain number of seats have been reserved for a national constituency and overseas Chinese communities. These seats are allocated by proportional representation.

However, Taiwan voters do not vote directly for candidates on the party lists. They instead vote in SNTV districts, and the votes obtained by the candidates are aggregated nationally according to party affiliation.

The seats for the national constituency and overseas Chinese communities are then distributed proportionally among the parties which capture at least 5 percent of total valid votes nationwide. At present, 22 percent of the seats in the Legislative Yuan are filled this way.

The quota for the year-end legislature election for national constituency is 41. The KMT estimated that it should be able to capture more than 50 percent of total valid votes nationwide and win 22 to 24 of the 41 seats.
A total of 155 KMT members had applied to be listed. Of the total, 40 were approved by the screening committee. They include:

Yao Eng-chi, Chen Chien-chih, Kao Yu-jen, Hung Chao-nan, Lee Min-kao, Chen Chung-tsan, Cheng Feng-shih, Hung Hsiu-chu, Wong Chung-chun, Lin Kuo-lung, Wang Ling-lin, Tseng Chen-nung, Chen Chieh-ju, Yang Chi-hsiung, Chin, Tseng Chen-li, Chou Cheng-chih, Yu Huai-yin, Hsu Su-yeh, Liu Kwang-hua, Lee Cheng-chung, Tsai Lin-li, Liao Feng-teh, Lee Chuan-chiau, Yao Kao-chiau, Hung Jui-chih, Su Huo-teng, Chen Seng-suen, and Cheng Mei-lan.
A total of 16 incumbent KMT legislators are on the list, while other incumbents, such as Ke Yu-chin and Tsai Pi-huang, are excluded.
Meanwhile, the ruling party estimated it will win five seats reserved for overseas Chinese communities and recommended eight candidates out of a total of 70 contenders.

They are: Hung Tu from San Francisco, Fan Yang-sheng from New York, Yang Chuo-chou from Japan, Kuan Wo-nuan from New Orleans, Wu Sung-po from South Africa, Huang Lin-chih from Germany, Shueh Sheng-hua from Canada, and Sun Kuo-hua from San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: KING OF SWAZILAND TO VISIT ROC ON THURSDAY

TEXT.P: His Majesty King Mswati III of the Kingdom of Swaziland is scheduled to visit the Republic of China from Oct. 22 to 27, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) press release said on Monday.
Swaziland has been actively enhancing its relations with Asian countries in recent years, it said. King Mswati III will visit Malaysia and Japan before arriving in the ROC.

During his stay in Taiwan, His Majesty will exchange views with President Lee Teng-hui on current international affairs and matters of common concern to the ROC and Swaziland. His Majesty will also meet ROC government officials and visit cultural and economic facilities.

The ROC has had a close and friendly relationship with Swaziland, said the MOFA, adding that in September, President Lee sent Ding Mou-shih, secretary general of the National Security Council, as his special envoy to attend the celebrations marking the 30th anniversary of independence of the Kingdom of Swaziland and the 30th birthday of His Majesty the King.
At 1998's UN general assembly session, Swaziland again spoke in support of the ROC's bid to join the UN and other international organizations.

This year is also the 30th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic ties between the ROC and the Kingdom of Swaziland. His Majesty Ming Mswati III's visit at this time therefore carries great significance.

King Mswati III's delegation to the ROC will include Albert H. Shabangu, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade; Absalom M. Dlamini, Minister of Economic Planning & Development; Dr. Sishayi S. Nxumalo, Chairman of the Swaziland Investment Promotion Authority; and several business leaders. His Majesty is scheduled to leave the ROC in the afternoon of Oct. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER REBUTS BEIJING'S CLAIM OF NON-INTERFERENCE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Monday rebutted mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's claim that Beijing has not tried to suppress the ROC in the international arena.
The foreign minister also said that if the Beijing authorities do not stop circulating rumors, Taipei "will consider revealing the facts."

Hu was responding to remarks made by Qian on Sunday to Chairman Koo Chen-fu of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) that "Taiwan always says its international space is suppressed. In fact, it is an unavoidable result of the development of an impartial situation."

Hu revealed to the media that the ROC Foreign Ministry has asked Beijing to explain several issues, including the "three empties" policy (referring to a Beijing plot to lure away all the ROC's allies by the turn of the century).
He said he was hoping for a "friendly response" from Beijing, but added that his ministry was still awaiting an answer.

Hu said that the purpose of seeking the explanation from Beijing is to let the international community see that Beijing is inconsistent in words and actions, and has been playing a "double-faced" strategy against Taiwan.

Questioned on the proposed ROC participation in the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO), Hu said that some foreign countries have expressed the hope that Taiwan will be able to make some contribution.

He said that joining KEDO would be consistent with ROC government policy, and would be good for all the countries of the region. However, he added that the matter is still in the planning stages, and that no concrete proposal has been worked out.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ACKNOWLEDGES RESULTS OF KOO'S MAINLAND TRIP

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Monday acknowledged the achievements of Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing C. F. Koo during his just-concluded visit to mainland China.
The council, however, expressed regret over Beijing's refusal to bravely face up to the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are separately ruled by two equal governments.

"Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo's Oct. 14-19 mainland visit has been fruitful," MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng said, adding that the visit has allowed for a resumption of high-level face-to-face communications to avoid the misunderstandings that can easily arise from the dissemination of second-hand information.

In addition, Sheu said, Koo has managed to reach a four-point consensus with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, on the promotion of exchanges between the two government-backed intermediary bodies they head.

According to the four-point deal sealed in Shanghai on Oct. 15, Chairman Wang of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) agreed to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.

SEF and ARATS have also agreed to step up consultations on a range of issues of mutual concern, increase exchanges at various levels and reinforce assistance in handling incidents involving personal safety and property of Taiwan visitors to the mainland, and vice versa.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official channels. SEF is under MAC's supervision.

"General speaking, Koo has accomplished the goals set forth by our government concerning his landmark mainland visit," Sheu said, adding that the government has expected Koo to push for a resumption of regular and systematic SEF-ARATS dialogue, foster an amiable atmosphere and improve cross-strait relations.

Sheu went on to say that even though the two sides still failed to bridge their wide differences over some critical political issues, Koo's visit has helped forge a foundation for constructive bilateral dialogue in the future.

"We hope systematic dialogue channels between SEF and ARATS set forth in the agreements signed during the first Koo-Wang meeting in Singapore in April 1993 will gradually resume normal operations to facilitate further upgrading and improvement of cross-strait ties for mutual benefits," Sheu added.

The senior mainland policy planner also reiterated that the ROC has been an independent sovereign state since 1912. "The ROC has continued to exist even after its seat moved to Taiwan in 1949. This is a historical fact that nobody can deny. We hope mainland China will pragmatically face up to this cold reality and recognize the state of separate rule on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to pave the way for closer cross-strait relations and cooperation," Sheu urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S TRIP TO M'LAND SHOWS JIANG'S POSITION NOT STABLE

TEXT.P: A trip to mainland China by a top Taiwan negotiator indicated that mainland President Jiang Zemin's position in power is not stable, a Bangkok-based English daily said.

Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, concluded his much-anticipated trip on Monday. Koo's trip must not be overplayed because there are still major constraints inside China. One of them is the position of President Jiang, The Nation said

Jiang can not appear to be too soft on Taiwan, even though he has become more flexible as he continues to further consolidate his leadership and power in the party and the powerful People's Liberation Army. That helps explain the current radical shift in China's policy, said Kavi Chongkittavorn, executive editor-in-chief of The Nation.
"Apparently, the better the China-Taiwan ties, the lesser constraints it would have on Bangkok's relations with the two Chinas," he stressed.

Titled "Beijing swaps missiles for manners," the article said that such a drastic turnaround, which came without Taiwan having to accept that it is a part of mainland China, is due to political developments backed by public opinion in China and Taiwan and coupled with international pressure, mainly from the US and Europe, on pressing for less tension in the Asia-Pacific region.

Beijing's military exercises and missile tests in the Taiwan Strait three years ago tarnished China's reputation and its efforts to promote an image of a benign power, the article said. It also confirmed the Taiwanese public sentiment that Beijing leaders can not be trusted.

Discussing on the democratic atmosphere in Taiwan, he said the Taiwanese are debating their future more openly and vigorously. "Politicians, including President Lee, have to take into account such public sentiments when negotiating Taiwan's future."

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS IN TAIWAN URGED TO LOWER INTEREST RATES

TEXT.P: Shea Jia-dong, deputy governor of the Central Bank of China in Taipei, Monday urged all commercial banks in Taiwan to lower the interest rates on loans to their customers in accordance with the actual market situation.

He said the central bank believes the time is ripe to lower the interest rates. This the first time a high-ranking central bank official has made such remarks since the central bank lowered the discount rates and bank reserve requirements on Sept. 28.
The central bank will gradually lower bank reserve requirements in the future in order to stimulate domestic demand, he said.

Addressing a meeting of high-ranking managing officials of commercial banks, Shea also said that the central bank wants to keep the exchange rates of Taiwan currency stable, but it will not take intervention measures unless it is absolutely necessary to do so.
He predicted that the economic growth rate will reach 5.0 percent in the least this year, and reach somewhere between 5.3 percent and 5.5 percent next year due to the increase in domestic demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PUBLISHER'S GROUP TO COMBAT COPYRIGHT VIOLATORS ON TAIWAN CAMPUSES

TEXT.P: An American publisher's association is retaining a local lawyer to defend against copyright violations by Taiwan universities and students, according to a university newsletter.

"University Journal," published by National Chengchi University, said that in a letter relayed by the Ministry of Education to local universities, The Association of American Publishers (AAP) warned that it has retained a local lawyer to raid copy shops around campuses to find out if they are photocopying publications of AAP members in violation of Taiwan's copyright law.

Noting that copyright infringement is punishable by jail terms ranging from six months to three years and a fine of up to NT$300,000 (US$9,090.9) under local law, the AAP, which represents some 200 US publishing firms, professed its determination to enforce its members' copyrights.
Although schools and teachers are permitted to photocopy in part copyrighted work to use as teaching materials, the law prohibits excessive or complete reproduction without copyright approval.

Complete reproduction of foreign textbooks is rampant among Taiwan university students who want to save money, especially in the wake of the NT dollar's depreciation against the greenback over the last year. They generally sidestep the law by copying a book in installments, a practice which fuels the booming photocopy industry around the nation's campuses.
The AAP warned in its letter that its lawyer will be visiting photocopy stores without notice, and will hire private detectives to conduct surveillance.

In addition to the massive infringement of foreign copyright by photocopying, the University Journal pointed out that the illegal reproduction of computer software is another crime widespread among university students, and could be another issue of concern to foreign copyright owners.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENBACK RISES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.016 against the new Taiwan dollar on the local foreign exchange market on Monday, to close at NT$32.91.
A total of US$296.5 million was traded.
The greenback opened at NT$32.84, and was traded at between NT$32.825 and NT$32.945.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN KILLED IN LANDSLIDES IN TAIPEI COUNTY TOWNSHIP

TEXT.P: More than 500 rescuers spent 11 hours on Monday to unearth a total of seven bodies killed by a mudslide which occurred on Saturday night in Wuku Township, Taipei County.

The incident, which also damaged two factories and two houses, followed another landslide which killed five people in the Taipei suburb of Neihu when typhoon Zeb swept through Taiwan on Thursday and Friday.
The victims in the Wuku disaster were named as Yang Ying-chieh, Chung Siu-chu, Hsu Sun-yao, Hung Teh-tien, Wu Chun-cheng, and Hsu Kwang-wang. The seventh body, a male, had yet to be identified.

Taiwan Governor James Soong and Taipei County Chief Su Tseng-chang visited the scene to express their concern and condolences to the bereaved. Su said the cause of the incident was still under formal investigation.

Meanwhile, Lu Ren-fa, state public prosecutor-general, said that under an order from Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo, his office is investigating 10 cases of illegal activities involving land development and sand and gravel extraction.

Lu revealed that he met with public prosecutors in Taipei, Taoyuan, Changhua, Yunlin, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties on Oct. 17 to discuss ways and means, as well as timing, of enhancing investigation of breaches of land conservation laws.
He added that a large-scale investigation will be launched within a short period, and that the guilty parties will be sent to Green Island prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN PLANT FIRE KILLS FIVE

TEXT.P: A fire which ripped through two plants in Taoyuan County early on Monday claimed the lives of four Thai workers and a local security guard.
The four laborers, three of whom were female, were identified as Thon Gphoon, 33, Jamliang Thachain, 38, Jvlawan Ritth Thong, 33, and Lengan Thtam Seksante, 28.
A Taiwanese security guard, Chang Chung-hsing, 55, was also killed, police said, adding that several others suffered from smoke inhalation.

The fire broke out at about 3:15 a.m. in the Kueishang industrial area, Taoyuan. A textile factory and an adjoining plant producing adhesive tape were immediately engulfed by the blaze which was exacerbated by the flammable materials and volatile petrochemical products stored there.

Although about two dozen fire engines and more than 300 firefighters from nearby towns were called in, they were kept at bay by the sporadic fierce explosions of ten tanks of methybenzene which caused flames about 30 meters high, in addition to billowing toxic smoke.
It took nearly seven hours for firefighters to control the blaze, by which time the two plants had been almost razed.
A search of the scene found the charred bodies of three workers on the textile plant's severely damaged fourth floor dormitory, while the other two bodies were found elsewhere among the debris.
Although surviving workers from the two plants blamed each other for the disaster, the cause is still under investigation, said police.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT PREPARED TO GIVE UP SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: With Taiwan's top envoy declaring Taiwan a "sovereign state and a modern democracy" in Beijing, any hope mainland China had of quickly absorbing Taiwan evaporated on Sunday, a major Canadian newspaper reported on Monday.

In a dispatch from mainland China's capital, the Globe and Mail said that the continuing hard line from Taiwan, coming after its highest-level talks with mainland China's government in five decades, "did not go down well with Beijing."
The daily said Beijing is offering Taiwan what it calls "one government, two systems" -- the same that Britain accepted as a sufficient guarantee of future independence for Hong Kong.

Koo Chen-fu, who wrapped up a five-day visit to the mainland on Sunday, said Taiwan's 21.5 million inhabitants will accept "nothing less than full status as a sovereign and democratic state," it noted.

On the other hand, it quoted Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait Vice Chairman Tang Shubei as saying on behalf of the Beijing regime: "There is only one China. It is a world trend to recognize mainland China and it will continue."
Taiwan is a special challenge to the Beijing regime because it has its own modern military and freewheeling democracy, the paper pointed out.
Despite each side's inflexibility, the daily quoted observers as saying the past five days of discussions, the first on Chinese soil, have yielded a better chance of reconciliation.
Mainland Chinese representatives will likely be officially greeted in Taipei next year to continue talks about improving relations, the paper also said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO BE BRIEFED BY SEF CHAIRMAN ON MAINLAND CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui will receive the Taiwan Straits Foundation (SEF) delegation headed by Chairman Koo Chen-fu on Tuesday to hear a report on the mission's just-concluded trip to mainland China.
Koo and his delegation visited Shanghai and Beijing on Oct. 14-19, making him the first head of the government-authorized civilian intermediary body to pay a trip to the mainland in 50 years.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies authorized by Taiwan and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts.
Koo explained Taiwan's basic position on several key issues to the mainland leaders during a series of meetings.

During their discussions, Koo and Wang reached a four-point consensus, agreeing that: the SEF and ARATS should engage in dialogues; increase bilateral exchanges, including exchanges of visits by missions headed by officials of the two bodies at different levels; provide more assistance in incidents involving the lives and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainland, and vice versa; and that Wang should accept an invitation from Koo to visit Taiwan at "an appropriate time."

However, no breakthroughs were made on several thorny issues, including the definition of the "one China" principle, Beijing's recognition of the reality that both sides are now under the rule of two separate governments, and Beijing's renunciation of the threat of force against Taiwan.
It is expected that Lee will deliver a statement on the development of cross-strait relations after hearing Koo's report.

Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew will also make a complete evaluation of Koo's mainland trip, and will spell out his expectations for future Taiwan-mainland China ties, when he answers interpellations at the Legislative Yuan within the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN AFFIRMS SEF CHAIRMAN'S ACHIEVEMENTS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Monday affirmed the achievements made by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his delegation during their six-day visit to mainland China.

Chang said Koo had frankly exchanged views with Beijing's leaders, disseminated the Republic of China's basic stance and principle regarding mainland affairs, and also listened to the opinions of the mainland side.
He described Koo's "ice-melting trip" as the start of "constructive" cross-strait dialogue, successfully paving the way for continued contact, communication, and dialogue.
The MAC chairman lauded the Koo delegation for its achievements, especially in disseminating Taiwan's experiences in democratization and in presenting several constructive proposals.

But he expressed regret that Beijing failed to recognize the political reality that Taiwan and the mainland are under separate rule, and failed to display its goodwill in the fields of diplomatic and military affairs, especially regarding its attempts to thwart Taiwan's international activities.
Chang paid his respects and gave his encouragement to all the members of the Koo delegation that left for Shanghai on Oct. 14 and returned to Taipei via Tokyo on Monday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC POSITIVE OF SEF CHAIRMAN'S MAINLAND CHINA TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 19 CNA) Taiwan's highest government agency in charge of mainland China affairs late on Monday said that the trip to mainland China by Taipei's top negotiator with Beijing has had a positive outcome.

"The ice-melting trip by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu has reopened the door to constructive dialogue between the two sides of the strait," the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a statement.

Koo and his delegation returned to Taipei on Monday night after concluding a six-day trip to the mainland. During visits to Shanghai and Beijing, he met with several high-ranking mainland Chinese officials, including Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan, Vice Premier Qian Qichen and President Jiang Zemin, in what was described as the highest-level contacts between Taiwan and the mainland in 50 years.

Koo and Wang reached consensus on increasing cross-strait dialogue and exchanges of visits, and for providing necessary assistance to incidents involving the lives and property of people from Taiwan and the mainland visiting each side of the Taiwan Strait.
Wang also agreed to visit Taiwan at "an appropriate time."
"The ROC government is positive of the agreement reached between Koo and Wang, and is willing to develop cross-strait ties under this framework," the MAC statement read.

In the statement, the MAC spoke highly of the performances of Koo and his delegation, saying they have properly expressed Taipei's stance on several key issues, and have successfully disseminated Taiwan's democratization and economic development experience.
"The visit has paved the way for a resumption of the institutionalized cross-strait negotiations which have been suspended for three years, and we welcome this development," it added.

However, the MAC expressed regret over Beijing's failure to respond to several Taipei proposals, such as those for cross-strait democratic exchanges at the grassroots level, agricultural cooperation, and a joint Taiwan-mainland role in regional affairs.

"We also understand that serious differences still exist between the two sides on some fundamental issues, such as the definition of the `one China' principle, Beijing's refusal to face up to the reality of a divided China, and Taiwan's international stature," it said.

The statement reiterated that Beijing in the future should renounce its attempts at diplomatic suppression and military menace against Taiwan, and respect the fact that the two sides are now under the rule of two separate governments.

"It is our deep hope that both sides will from now on enter into `frank consultations,' through which the shelved institutionalized negotiations can be resumed, and peace and cooperative relations be established between the two sides," the MAC statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN REVEALS IMPRESSIONS OF SIX-DAY MAINLAND CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu told assembled media in Taipei on Monday night that during his talks with Beijing officials, each side presented its opinions frankly and without hesitation.
Despite this, Koo said that each side was "very tolerant" of the opinions of the other side. "This will be helpful to the future development of cross-strait relations," he noted.

The SEF chairman said that both sides admitted that there are differences between them, but stressed: "We will not retreat, but will instead continue to make contact to try to solve these difficulties."

Koo's 12-member delegation left Taipei for Shanghai on Oct. 14 for a six-day "ice-melting trip" to the mainland with the aim of resuming the formal cross-strait consultations that had been suspended for three years.
The mission returned to Taipei via Tokyo on Monday night. Koo met the media, accompanied by Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh, shortly after his return.

During his stay on the mainland, Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing held talks with Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Vice Premier Qian Qichen, and President Jiang Zemin.

He told the media that his mission had attained the two objectives set forth prior to the trip -- to engage in dialogue toward reviving systematic cross-strait consultations, and to create a harmonious atmosphere to improve cross-strait relations.
Koo said that a four-point consensus was reached during his talks with Wang in Shanghai on Oct. 15, and that Jiang had also indicated his approval for the consensus.

Under the terms of the consensus, the SEF and ARATS will engage in dialogue, step up exchanges of visits at various levels, and strengthen mutual assistance to solve problems concerning the safety and property of the people from both sides of the straits while visiting the other side. Wang also accepted Koo's invitation to visit Taiwan "at an appropriate time."
Koo also disclosed that during this talks with Jiang on Sunday, the mainland president indicated his deep interest in cross-strait agricultural cooperation.

When asked about the possibility of a meeting between ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Jiang at November's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum conference, Koo said that there is a need to create better conditions, and that more time is required before this can be achieved.

Summing up the results of his mainland trip, Koo said the most important point is that relations have now returned to the state of three years ago, and that exchanges of views in a frank and open manner are once more possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing C. F. Koo returned to Taipei after a six-day fruitful mainland visit.
The China Times: The ROC government acknowledged the results of Koo's "ice-melting" visit to mainland China.
The United Daily News: Koo said mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is interested in cross-strait agricultural cooperation.
The Liberty Times: Koo said he hopes to see a Lee-Jiang meeting before ROC President Lee Teng-hui's current tenure expires in the year 2000.
The Independence Morning Post: Koo said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait remain divided over the "one China" concept.
The Commons Daily: Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chen Tien-mao moved his legal residence to Taipei to signify his determination of not to seek reelection.
The China Post: Bridge dispute holds up flood prevention plan.
The China News: Probe begins in Taipei County landslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: US STATE DEPARTMENT WELCOMES CROSS-STRAIT 4-POINT CONSENSUS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US State Department on Monday welcomed the four-point consensus reached in the just-concluded talks between the top negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The State Department said in a statement that Taiwan envoy Koo Chen-fu's landmark visit to mainland China and the top mainland negotiator Wang Daohan's consent to visit Taiwan at an "appropriate time" were positive developments.

Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), struck the four-point deal with his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Shanghai on Oct. 15 to pave the way for gradual resumption of regular dialogue broken off by Beijing more than three years ago.
During his Oct. 14-19 "ice-melting" mainland trip, Koo also met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen for frank talks on issues of mutual concern.
Although the two sides failed to bridge their wide gaps on some fundamental issues, Koo's visit has helped thaw bilateral ties.
The Department of State statement reads as follows:

"We welcome the positive development from Mr. Koo's visit to the People's Republic of China. We understand that the two sides have reached a four-point consensus, which include the visit of the PRC's top negotiator Wang Daohan to Taiwan at an appropriate time and increase exchanges between SEF and ARATS.

"We welcome this consensus and the decision by Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan. We believe dialogue, contacts and exchanges between the two sides provide important means toward the peaceful resolution of differences between Taiwan and the PRC. Mr. Koo's meetings not only with his direct counterpart but also with President Jiang Zemin and other PRC leaders demonstrate the seriousness being attached to this process."
