DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN HAILS KOO'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan should not be afraid of holding political talks with the mainland, former chairman of the leading opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Tuesday.
Hsu Hsin-liang also hailed Koo Chen-fu's efforts during his recent tour of the mainland and meetings with top-level officials in his capacity as Straits Exchange Foundation chairman.

Koo, Taiwan's first top envoy to visit the mainland in nearly 50 years, successfully conveyed Taiwan's friendliness to the mainland and has brought back friendship during his six-day, ice-breaking mission, Hsu said.

Pointing out that the government had long neglected to foster friendship with the mainland, Hsu urged the government to recruit and cultivate more talent like Koo for future cross-strait negotiations.
Koo's meetings with top Beijing leaders on Sunday in Beijing showed that Taiwan does not have to be worried about conducting political talks with the mainland, Hsu said.

He added that a meeting between President Lee Teng-hui and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin should be set as the prime task for the next phrase of relations. A Lee-Jiang meeting would help the two sides of the Taiwan Strait further ease tension between them, he noted.
Koo met with Jiang and vice deputy Qian Qichen in separate meetings on Sunday. The atmosphere in Koo-Jiang meeting was cordial, but Koo and Qian had a pointed exchange on the "one China" issue.

As Koo and Qian touched on political issues during their meeting, the former DPP head said this should boost Taiwan's confidence. Taiwan's democratization and political reality will put the island in an advantage in cross-strait discussions, Hsu said.

But he predicted that the focus of cross-strait talks will shift back to negotiations on technical issues such as economic affairs as it will take a long time for the two sides to reach any consensus on the political front.
Commenting on Beijing's demand that Taiwan allow direct "three links" -- trade, transport, and communications -- with the mainland, Hsu said the government should handle the three issues separately.

The government can commission the private sector to negotiate postal services with the mainland, Hsu suggested. Taiwan should also seek Beijing's agreement not to block the island's entry to the World Trade Organization in exchange for the easing of Taipei's restrictions on Taiwan investments in the mainland.
Hsu, who stepped down from the top post in the DPP, favors a broad engagement with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LA TIMES REPORTS ON KOO-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: The meeting in Beijing between Taipei's top negotiator and Chinese President Jiang Zemin marks the highest level of contact between the two sides in 50 years, the Los Angeles Times reported on Monday.
In its second story on Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu's mainland visit, the paper described the tour as a cautious rapprochement between Taipei and Beijing.
"The ice is not completely broken, but we hope it has melted a bit," Koo told a packed news conference after his meeting with Jiang.

Koo, 81, told reporters that he and Jiang frankly exchanged views on key issues. They talked about democracy extensively, and Koo expressed the hope that mainland China will eventually be able to "share Taiwan's experience" in promoting democracy. Beijing described Sunday's 100-minute meeting as cordial. (Lu-sheng Chu)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR COUNTRIES SEEN AVOIDING RECESSION IN 1998

TEXT.P: Taiwan, China, Australia and Vietnam are the only four countries that will likely avoid economic recession by the end of 1998, a prominent Australian economist predicted.

In a speech to a meeting of Australian and Japanese business leaders in Melbourne on Monday, Professor Ross Garnaut, director of the Asia Pacific School of Economics and Management at the Australian National University in Canberra, said the Asia-Pacific's economic crisis bore uneasy parallels to the 1930s Great Depression.
While the two events are not identical, both were sparked by the "implosion" of import trade, he said.

"By the end of this year, only China, Taiwan, Australia and perhaps, precariously, Vietnam among western Pacific economies will have avoided recession," he predicted. The economist described the current crisis as a western Pacific crisis rather than an Asian or East Asian crisis.
He noted that the economies of Malaysia, Thailand, South Korea, Indonesia and Japan were hit badly since the middle of 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO TALKS SEEN A POLITICAL COUP FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The meetings between Taiwan's top mainland negotiator and mainland officials mark a political coup for the Taipei government, the Sydney Morning Herald said in an editorial.

The fact that Beijing has resorted to courting Taipei instead of bullying it into submission and reunification, is more significant than any results produced from negotiations, the paper said. The talks could never have been expected to produce very tangible results, it added.
"Nothing could have shown the government in Taipei to better advantage than to have it projected in such direct contrast with the government in Beijing," the editorial stated.

Koo Chen-fu, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) chairman and Taiwan's senior envoy, had only to insist that reunification was impossible until China reaches Taiwan's state of democratic development. Such insistence forced Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen to acknowledge Taiwan's interests.

"Taiwan now practices capitalist system and after the reunification Taiwan may retain the capitalist system while the mainland of the motherland practices socialist system," Qian was quoted as saying. "By reunification, we mean to safeguard the state territorial integrity and sovereignty, not to argue over systems."

The editorial noted that Qian's remarks were profoundly pragmatic, unimaginable only a few years ago when Beijing railed against the "renegade province" in the most strident terms and denounced the Kuomintang as "brigands" who ruled it.

"Last week's talks help Taiwan, especially by making clear how different is its position compared with Hong Kong's. The more Beijing relies on the Hong Kong comparison, the more it underlines the difference," the paper stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONEY BROKERS TO ENTER SINGAPORE GOVERNMENT BOND MARKET

TEXT.P: The Singapore government bond market will be opened to money brokers for the first time in the next few weeks under the administration's push to promote the debt market, The Business Times reported.
Markets players said they also hope to attract retail investors to the triple-A bonds in the process.

Under the arrangement, primary dealers in Singapore government securities (SGS) -- which are bonds issued by the Singapore government -- will provide bid and offer prices to brokers who will act as intermediaries in the interbank market.
The new arrangement will start off with two money brokers, Exco AP Singapore and Prebon Yamane. Additional SGS brokers are expected to participate as interest in the SGS market grows.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS WORK LONGER HOURS BUT ARE LESS PRODUCTIVE

TEXT.P: Singaporeans work more hours each year than people in the United States and Europe, but are not as productive, according to The Straits Times.
Workers here put in an average of 2,028 hours a year, about 5 percent to 15 percent more than those in the US and Europe.
The figure was 1,916 hours a year in the US, 1,839 hours in Britain, and 1,699 in Germany.

However, when it comes to productivity, each Singaporean worker contributes about US$26 per hour to the country's gross domestic product, while his counterpart produces US$32 in the US, US$26 in Britain and US$35 in Germany.
David Arkless, vice-chairman of the employment service Manpower, presented the figures which he cited from the World Competitiveness Yearbook 1998 at a conference on human resources here recently.
He said productivity in Singapore was suppressed by an inflexibility in the local labor market, contributing to the discrepancy in figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: HABIBIE ENVOY CONDEMNS ATTACKS ON ETHNIC CHINESE

TEXT.P: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie's special envoy who is in Australia to court foreign investment to the troubled Southeast Asian country, condemned the targeting of ethnic Chinese for crimes earlier this year.

James Riady, a leading businessman of Chinese origin with the Lippo Group, told a meeting of the Australian Business Chamber in Canberra that the Jakarta government condemned the criminal attacks on ethnic Chinese during the political and economic turmoil in May.
"What happened in May this year is regrettable and upsetting. The government has strongly condemned what has happened," he said.

Leading a high-level group of Indonesians to Australia for the first time since Habibie took office, Riady called on Australia to be more courageous about investing in Indonesia. He said the Indonesian government was determined to separate economics from politics and end "cronyism" in Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS APEC MEMBERS TO ACCELERATE ECONOMIC REFORMS

TEXT.P: Australia will urge all members of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to speed up economic reforms to beat the current Asian financial crisis, the Australian reported on Tuesday.

Quoting senior government officials, the paper said Prime Minister John Howard is expected to push all the APEC members to implement reforms in a major swift from the freer trade and replacing it with moves to greater economic and financial transparency.
The timing of Australia's strategy is crucial as it comes a year after financial crisis engulfed most APEC members, exposing the weakness of their fast-growing economies.

Howard believes the APEC leaders' summit in Kuala Lumpur, which begins on Nov. 12, will be a test of APEC's success. This has fueled Australia's intense efforts to help seize the agenda, the paper reported.

Howard, his deputy prime minister Tim Fischer and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer all want Australia to "hold the line" on trade liberalization, ensuring that the regional community keeps reducing trade barriers according to agreed long-term goals, the report said.

Australia will also push APEC leaders to commit themselves to reinforcing their financial systems by adopting the Basel principles of banking supervision, a set of international rules for assessing the strength of banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: RATE CUTS WON'T STAVE OFF RECESSION: ECONOMISTS

TEXT.P: While the latest round of cuts in bank prime lending rates here has given a psychological boost to the stock market, it alone cannot help Singapore as recovery hinges on external factors beyond its control, economists said.

With domestic demand accounting for one-third of gross domestic product, Singapore's economy is driven by external demand and multinational corporations that do not fund their operations locally and are not sensitive to domestic interest rates, they said.

Economists expect Singapore's economy to expand just 0.4 percent in 1998. Estimates for 1999 range from a contraction of 1.5 percent to a growth of 0.6 percent. Most of these calculations are based on a further fall in interest rates.

Over the last month, the local Big Four banks cut their prime lending rates twice to 7 percent, but economists point out that real interest rates, which are adjusted for inflation, are still high because the inflation rate has turned negative.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S EXTERNAL TRADE WEAK IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Singapore's external trade remained weak in September as total trade at current prices fell by 9.2 percent, reflecting declines in both imports and exports -- 16.9 percent and 0.9 percent respectively.

As in preceding months, the sluggish performance was due to lackluster market conditions for electronic and related products, as well as fallen demand from Asian economies hit by the financial crisis.

Non-oil domestic exports expanded marginally by 1.4 percent in September, half the growth rate in August 1998. The overall growth was due to the 6.0 percent increase in non-electronic exports which offset the 0.6 percent decline in electronics exports.
Of the key electronic products, personal computers, printers and consumers electronics bore the brunt of the sluggish global demand conditions, contracting by double-digit rates.

Although exports of disk drives grew by 10.5 percent, there are no clear indications if this can be sustained. The main non-electronic exports which performed well in September were disc media products up by 14.7 percent, compounds for pharmaceuticals at 50.7 percent growth, and medical apparatus with 28 percent growth.
The domestic export of oil continued to decline in September. It fell by 15.3 percent due to depressed oil prices and weak demand from major Asian markets such as Hong Kong and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFIED CHINA A PRIORITY WITH BEIJING: PAPER

TEXT.P: Beijing has made unification with Taiwan a priority now that talks between the two sides have been restarted, a Bangkok-based English daily said in its editorial on Tuesday.
With Hong Kong back in its fold and Macau returning to its authority in December next year, Beijing has firmly turned its attention to Taiwan, The Nation said.

Talks between Taiwan's top negotiator Koo Chen-fu and mainland President Jiang Zemin took place on Sunday in Beijing. Koo met with his Beijing counterpart Wang Daohan last week and forged a four-point agreement on future meetings among other issues.

Entitled "More Talks Better Than No Talks," The Nation editorial said the resumption of talks is a pivotal confidence-building measure which will lead to a true ironing-out of differences. However, a meeting between Jiang and ROC President Lee Teng-hui is premature at the moment because neither side is willing to give way to the other, the paper said. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS' REACTIONS TO KOO'S MISSION MIXED

TEXT.P: Reactions were mixed in the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday to Taiwan's top negotiator Koo Chen-fu's recent meetings with high-level mainland officials.

Koo, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, returned on Monday from a six-day ice-breaking trip to the mainland. During his visit, Koo met with his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan, Vice Premier Qian Qichen and President Jiang Zemin.

Legislator Tsai Ming-hsien of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Koo failed to convey the public opinion of Taiwan people. He cited public polls showing that 76 percent of the Taiwan public do not approve of Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, while 83 percent believe the fate of Taiwan should be decided by Taiwan people.
New Party Legislator Chen Yi-hsin said the KMT tried to highlight the fact that Taiwan was not a troublemaker nor the culprit in soured cross-strait relations, but the aim obviously fell through.
Chen said the most noteworthy result of the highest-level contact between the two sides in three years was the clarification that "one China" refers to "the Republic of China."

Yang Chi-hsiung of the ruling Kuomintang said the most important element in the meetings was that Koo clearly stated the stance of Taiwan people to mainland leaders which will help ease cross-strait tensions and have a far-reaching impact on the development of relations between the two sides.
KMT Legislator Lin Cheng-tze also said constructive cross-strait dialogue should not fear differences, saying that Koo's delegation will help ease cross-strait relations.

KMT Legislator Lee Wen-lang said if the nation cannot formulate a consensus on mainland policy, then it will be problematic when Beijing's top Taiwan negotiator, Wang Daohan, visits the island. Wang promised to visit Taiwan at an "appropriate time," during his meeting with Koo in Shanghai last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES ZHIRINOVSKY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday welcomed a Russian parliamentary delegation visiting Taiwan and expressed the hope that the visit will help boost cooperation and exchanges between Russia and the Republic of China.
Lee made the remarks as he welcomed the delegation, headed by Liberal Democratic Party leader Vladimir Zhirinovsky, at the Presidential Office.
Zhirinovsky extended an invitation for Lee to visit Russia. Lee said he appreciated the invitation and would go at an appropriate time.

Zhirinovsky said that Russia is well aware of the political and economic developments achieved by the Republic of China and greatly admires the nation, especially its ability to implement reform gradually and in a way that takes into account the need for political stability and economic development. He said it would be worthwhile for Russia to emulate this approach.

Russia is currently in the midst of enacting painful political and economic reforms, he said. But with its abundant natural resources and solid industrial base, the country expects to weather its present difficulties, he added.
Zhirinovsky said the Republic of China and Russia could complement each other and that there is ample room for the further development of their economic and cultural relations.
The Russian ultranationalist, invited to visit Taiwan by Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang, arrived Sunday aboard a chartered Russian Vnukovo Airlines jet.
It is believed to be the first direct flight between Moscow and Taipei in half a century.
After leaving Taipei, the delegation will visit Kaohsiung before concluding its five-day visit and returning to Moscow on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.013 against the greenback in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 32.897.
The local currency opened at 32.902. and was traded between 32.89 and 32.98.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$318 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS TAKEN DELIVERY OF 103 F-16S
DOC.DATELINE: Fort Worth, Texas, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Lockheed Martin Corp. said on Monday it has delivered a total of 103 F-16 jet fighters to the Republic of China on Taiwan, including 30 twin-seater F-16Bs.
Eighteen of those planes are now at the Luke Air Base in Arizona for training ROC Air Force pilots, two other F-16s are at an air base in California for further flight tests.
A spokesman for the American warplane manufacturer said the delivery of the remaining 47 F-16s ordered by Taiwan will be completed by October 1999.
Former US President George Bush announced the sale of 150 F-16s to Taiwan in September 1992, including 120 single-seater F-16As and 30 twin-seater F-16Bs.
The US$5.8 billion deal is part of Taiwan's 10-year military modernization plan aimed at upgrading the island's defense capabilities in the face of persistent military threat from communist China.

When the first Taiwan-ordered F-16 rolled off the assembly line some two years ago, Lockheed Martin Corp. rejected Taiwan media's request for coverage. But the company took the initiative to invite Taiwan journalists stationed in the United States to tour its warplane production facilities in Fort Worth, Texas on Monday.

Joseph W. Stout, communications director at Lockheed Martin's Fort Worth plant, said the company rejected Taiwan media's coverage two years ago mainly because of the US State Department's demand for a low-profile approach to the F-16 deal in an apparent attempt to avoid offending Beijing. Mainland China has consistently opposed arms sales to Taiwan by any other country.

Stout pointed out that F-16s are high-performance warplanes. "However, it seems to us that most Taiwan people are not fully aware of F-16's merits and advantages. Some Taiwan media have even given misleading reports. Therefore, we decided to brief Taiwan journalists on F-16's merits by inviting them to visit our plant," he explained.

Troy Pennington, a test pilot at the Fort Worth plant, said the F-16 Block 20 fighters purchased by Taiwan can compete with any other model now in service in countries around the world, including Russian-made Su-27 fighters that mainland China is deploying.
Pennington, a former US Marine Corps F/A-18 pilot, said F-16 fighters have five times replaced engine models since they were first marketed in the late 1970s.

Noting that F-16s have undergone continued mid-life upgrades, Pennington said the Taiwan purchased F-16 Block 20 model is equipped with a cockpit radar color monitor and many other sophisticated devices. "Some of their facilities are even more advanced than those installed on F-16 C/D models now in service in the US Air Force," he added.
Dain M. Hancock, chief manager at the Fort Worth plant, said he will visit Taiwan later this year to probe whether the ROC Air Force has encountered any problems after taking delivery of the F-16s.

Hancock said F-16 is the safest, single-engine and multi-role fighter plane in the US Air Force history. In 1997, the F-16 accident rate in the United States was 2.7 mishaps per 100,000 flight hours, while the fighter's world average accident rate was 3.7 mishaps per 100,000 hours.
Hancock said he still didn't know the cause of the crash of an ROC Air Force twin-seater F-16B earlier this year.

George York, a cockpit integration program leader, said Taiwan has not informed the Fort Worth plant of any problems concerning the search for the wreckage of the ill-fated fighter and the bodies of the two pilots on board.

Taiwan launched extensive search and rescue operations after the F-16B lost contact with the military flight control center on March 20 when the plane was on a routine training flight over the skies of the Penghu Islands off the southwestern Taiwan coast. Neither the wreckage of the plane nor the bodies of the two pilots aboard have ever been recovered.

A total of 3,900 F-16s have so far been produced and hundreds more are expected to roll off the assembly line before 2010. By then, F-16 will become the most widely used advanced warplanes. Nineteen countries around the world, including the United States, have deployed F-16s. Asian countries that have deployed F-16s include South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore and Taiwan. Japan has deployed F-2 jet fighters which were patterned after F-16s.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1998 ECONOMIC GROWTH REVISED UPWARD BY RESEARCH INSTITUTE

TEXT.P: A fourth quarter economic forecast issued by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research on Tuesday adjusted upward the ROC's annual economic growth rate in 1998 to 5.25 percent.

The institute attributed the ROC's economic gains to the government-planned stimulation of domestic demand. The increase in demand will likely boost economic growth for the fourth quarter to 5.08 percent, which in turn may lift growth for the year to 5.25 percent, according to the forecast.
Looking ahead to next year, the institute said the economic declines being experienced by most east Asian nations would likely bottom out and that they would begin to rebound.
The institute forecast economic growth next year of 5.35 percent for Taiwan.

Among the economic growth forecasts offered for Taiwan, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics predicted in August that Taiwan's economy would grow 4.8 percent this year. If the effects of the stimulation of domestic demand were taken into account, however, that figure could stand as high as 5.3 percent.

The Council of Economic Planning and Development, meanwhile, predicted in September 5.11 percent growth; the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research estimated in July 5.5 percent growth; and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicted in October growth of 4 percent for Taiwan this year.

Next year's economic growth has been put at 5.32 percent by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, while the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics estimated 5.75 percent growth for the upper half of 1999. The IMF, however, has predicted growth of only 3.9 percent for Taiwan next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SAYS TIES STRONG WITH PANAMA, COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Tuesday categorically denied that Panama and Costa Rica will sever their diplomatic ties with the Republic of China at the end of this year.

Hu called groundless rumors that the two countries would disappear from the list of the ROC's diplomatic allies after Taiwan holds elections Dec. 5. New legislators, and mayors and councils of metropolitan Taipei and Kaohsiung will be elected in the three-in-one elections.
He promised to take responsibility if the defections occur.
Hu made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to questioning about the rumors by Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
The foreign minister admitted that Beijing has tried to lure Panama and Costa Rica away from the Republic of China over the past several years.

So far, he said, the two longtime ROC allies have shown great friendship toward Taiwan. He said cordial and close relations between Taiwan and the two countries will remain unchanged, at least in the near future.
Hu asked Chien to stop spreading such injurious rumors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS TAKEN DELIVERY OF ALL 60 MIRAGE 2000-5S

TEXT.P: The ROC Air Force has taken delivery of all the 60 Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters ordered from France and will hold a ceremony at the Hsinchu Air Base in northern Taiwan on Nov. 26 to mark the formation of its first Mirage wing, military sources said on Tuesday.
Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min will personally preside over the Mirage wing commissioning ceremony, the sources said.

Under a project dubbed "Flying Dragon," the Air Force struck a deal with France in 1993 for purchasing 60 Mirage 2000-5s and 960 MICA medium-range air-to-air missiles and 480 short-range Magic air-to-air missiles to arm the advanced fighters.
The deal cost a total of NT$167.6 billion (about US$5 billion).

The delivery was originally scheduled to be completed by the year 2000. In consideration of Taiwan's combat preparedness, the French contractor Dassault Corp. has sped up production and advanced its delivery schedule.
The last batch of Mirage 2000-5s arrived in Taiwan earlier this month and the Air Force has finalized all delivery formalities with French authorities, military sources said.

In the course of delivery, the Control Yuan once launched an investigation into suspected irregularities involving the Ministry of National Defense's speedy payment to the Mirage supplier. The investigation didn't uncover any irregularities. As the New Taiwan dollar has depreciated significantly against the US dollar over the past year, the Defense Ministry's speedy payment has saved a large amount of money from the exchange rate fluctuation.
The first Taiwan-ordered Mirage 2000-5 rolled off the assembly line in May 1996 and was shipped to the eastern Hualien port in May 1997. The first Mirage squadron was commissioned in last October.

Mirage 2000-5 fighters are high-performance warplanes suitable for high-altitude air combat. The Mirage deal is part of Taiwan's 10-year military modernization plan aimed at beefing up the island's air defense capabilities and ensure its air supremacy.
The commissioning of the 60th Mirage plane and the first Mirage wing on Nov. 26 will mark a new milestone in Taiwan's military build-up.
In addition to the Mirage deal, Taiwan has also purchased 150 US-made F-16s and 130 locally built Ching-kuo Indigenous Defense Fighters to replace its aging fleet.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YORK BASED MAINLAND DISSIDENTS HAIL KOO'S MAINLAND CHINA TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Flor Wang and K.C. Huang)

TEXT.P: The trip to mainland China by top Taiwan envoy Koo Chen-fu represents a new beginning in cross-strait ties, a group of mainland pro-democracy activists based here said on Monday.

Describing Koo's recent visit to Shanghai and Beijing as heralding a new starting point in bilateral ties after a hiatus of more than three years, the "China Peace" group said it welcomes the replacement of confrontation with dialogue between Taiwan and the mainland.

Koo, in his capacity as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, returned from the mainland late on Monday after concluding his historic six-day visit. While there, he met with top mainland Chinese leaders, including President Jiang Zemin, Vice President Qian Qichen, and his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

The group, however, urged mainland China to hasten its democratization, pointing out that Beijing's leaders should realize that the mainland's democratization is a prerequisite for Taiwan to agree to unification.

Because of wide differences in the political systems and the ways of life between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, "China Peace" contended that unification will take a long time, and added that before the two sides start official negotiations on the issue, both should first meet the following requirements:
-- democratize the territory under the jurisdiction of each side by implementing multi-party systems and popular elections at all levels, including the presidency; and
-- conduct negotiations on peaceful unification only after the majority of people on both sides approve the move via public referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND WELCOMES KOO'S MEETING WITH JIANG IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Thailand is pleased to see a new atmosphere of warmth in the recent dialogue between Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing.
Kobsak Chutikul, a Thai Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Thailand hopes that the meeting will lead to the resolution of differences that will in turn bring prosperity to the region.
The atmosphere of warmth will lead to reduced tensions between Taiwan and mainland China and promote trade and investment, the spokesman added.
The Thai senior diplomat noted that Thailand observes a "one-China policy," although it will continue to increase trade with and investment in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE SATISFIED WITH KOO DELEGATION'S PERFORMANCE: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people are satisfied with the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) delegation's performance during its "ice-melting" visit to mainland China, according to the result of a public opinion poll released on Tuesday.

The telephone poll of 2,401 adult residents throughout the island, conducted by the ruling Kuomintang on Oct. 17-19, found that 73 percent of the respondents said they are satisfied with the SEF delegation's performance during its Oct. 14-19 Shanghai-Beijing visit.
SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized by the government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Eighty-three percent of those interviewed said they know meetings between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
As high as 85 percnet of the respondents said they believe the just-concluded Koo-Wang talks will help improve cross-strait relations.

Sixty-three percent said they feel mainland authorities were friendly toward the SEF delegation, while 30 percent said they don't think that Beijing authorities were friendly toward the Taiwan delegation.

Survey results showed that 71 percent of the respondents support the proposal that President Lee Teng-hui make a "journey of peace" to the mainland; and 65 percent said Lee should visit the mainland in his capacity as the Republic of China's president, while 18.1 percnet said Lee can visit the mainland as "Taiwan's top leader."
Meanwhile, 86 percent said they welcome a planned visit to Taiwan by ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, an 82-year-old ex-mayor of Shanghai and mentor to mainland President Jiang Zemin.

Fifty-two percent said they are satisfied with the govenrment's policy toward mainland China, while 40 percnet said they were either "very dissatisfied" or "dissatisfied" with the govenrment's mainland policy.

The poll also found that most people support the govenrment's "no haste, be patient" policy toward mainland China-bound investment, but 35 percent said the government should gradually ease restrictions on cross-strait investment.

About 50 percnet said economic issues should take the precedence over any other topics in future cross-strait talks; 25 percent said practical issues should top the agenda; and only 8.5 percent said political issues should be given the top priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH TIED TO GOVERNMENT PLAN TO SPUR DEMAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth hinges to a great extent on the effectiveness of a government-backed plan to spur domestic demand, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research said on Tuesday.

If the plan works, Taiwan could achieve economic growth of 5.44 percent this year and 6.12 percent next year. Those figures, however, could drop to 5.06 percent and 4.57 percent, respectively, if the plan does not work, according to institute researchers.

Under the plan, issued by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, public investment would increase by NT$18.4 billion this year and NT$73.2 billion next year. Before issuing the plan, the council had predicted economic growth for Taiwan of 5.25 percent this year and 5.35 percent next year.

If the plan goes awry, however, the consequences will be severe, the researchers said, as total investment in Taiwan next year could grow by a mere 2.6 percent over this year. Such scant investment growth would likely be accompanied by recession in Taiwan's civil consumption and import sectors, the researchers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL MEETING OF WORLD ELECTRONIC FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The fourth annual meeting of the World Electronic Forum (WEF) opened in Taipei on Tuesday, attended by 30 representatives of electronic information business associations from 13 countries and areas.

This is the first time that the annual meeting has taken place in Taiwan since it began in 1995 with the aim of discussing world trade policies in electronic information and information exchanges around the globe.

In an address delivered at the opening ceremony of the two-day conference, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said that despite its status as an unofficial international organization, the WEF plays a key role in the cooperation of the electronic and information sector worldwide.

Liu revealed to those attending his prediction that the future trend of the electronic industry will focus on the development of products which are not only personalized, digitized and multi-media, but are also endowed with all the characteristics of the so-called three-C products -- computer, communications and consumer products.
Later in the opening ceremony, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturing Association (TEEMA), Wu Si-chung, called for the prevention of "overblown trade disputes."

Citing instances in which the European common market has complained about alleged dumping of Taiwan-made 3.5-inch floppy disks, optical fibers, and several other electronic products, Wu said that some of Taiwan's products happen to be very competitive in Europe, just as the cellular phones sold in Taiwan adhere to European frequency standards.
But he has never seen any Asian countries enacting anti-dumping measures against cellular phones or systems from Europe, despite their overwhelming presence in the region, Wu said.
The first WEF annual meeting took place in the United States in 1995. Since then, 34 countries and areas have joined the international organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TALKS ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said Monday that cross-strait relations can be improved with sincerity and goodwill, and that the democratization of mainland China will greatly help improve the relations.
The president made the remarks when he received Taiwan's chief negotiator Koo Chen-fu and members of his delegation, which visited Shanghai and Beijing Oct. 14-19.

Lee said that, since it will take quite a long time to resolve some of the basic differences between the two sides, it will be wise for them to respect each other, increase their exchanges and constructive dialogues on an equal footing, gradually step up their cooperation, and recognize the reality that China is now under separate rule. The two sides should hold dialogues on all matters involving the safety and interests of the people, he added.

Lee expressed deep appreciation to Koo, chairman of the semi-official Strait Exchange Foundation, and members of the delegation for the good job they did during the visit. Koo and his delegation visited mainland China at the invitation of his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan, Chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Koo and Wang reached a four-point agreement on Oct. 15 in Shanghai, under which the two sides will continue to hold dialogues and increase exchanges, and work together to solve the problems involving the safety and property of the people. Wang also agreed to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.

Lee said the agreement may become a good beginning of a new relationship between Taiwan and the mainland. Taiwan would be glad to share its experience in promoting democracy with the mainland, Lee said, adding that, mainland China will be able to make even greater achievement in economic development through dem0cratization. The two sides "can talk about anything," when the mainland is in the process of democratization, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER HEAD PROPOSES TAIWAN-MAINLAND CHINA IT COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Stan Shih, founder of the Taiwan-based Acer Computer Co., on Tuesday proposed a strategy of cooperation between the information technology (IT) sectors of Taiwan and mainland China.

Shih said Taiwan makers of electronic products should stop worrying about their weakening market hold in the face of increasing mainland Chinese competition. Instead, he said, they should think about relocating part of their operations to the mainland, to take advantage of the mainland's inexpensive land and rich human resources.
By joining hands, he added, Taiwan and mainland China can expect their competitiveness to double, enabling them to cut into world markets more decisively.
Shih made the remarks in a keynote speech to the fourth World Electronics Forum which opened in Taipei on Tuesday.

He said the greatest challenge to Taiwan's IT industry is its lack of a huge domestic market. Although Taiwan-made IT products are marketed worldwide, owning a market as vast as the Chinese mainland is the only way to make any Taiwan product a world-renowned brand name, he continued.

Noting that major IT businesses around the world, including dynamic random access memory chip makers and IC silicon wafer manufacturers, are approaching their lowest ebb, he said Taiwan makers should learn to stay cool, and conserve their energy to tide them over the cold winter, adding that the only way out in the face of the current worldwide recession is to try to cut overhead costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE INDUSTRY IN GREATER CHINA FACING HARD TIMES

TEXT.P: The textile industries in Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong are facing difficult times with falling exports in 1998 as a result of the Asian economic crisis, according to a leading ROC exporter.

In a speech at a meeting of the International Textile Manufacturers Federation in Melbourne on Tuesday, William Shan, president of the Chung Hsing Textile Corp., said the Asian crisis has affected the textile industries in Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong, and that it could take some time before they recover.
He said Taiwan's textile exports were worth US$16.6 billion in 1997, while its imports remained at the 1996 level, giving the country a surplus of US$13 billion from its textile and apparel trade.
But the Asian crisis has caused Taiwan's textile exports to drop at a rate of 5 percent to 20 percent in different sectors, including man-made fiber, yarn, fabrics and garments, he said.
He estimated mainland China's total losses in textile exports at US$240 million in 1997 and said the figure could be much higher this year.
Hong Kong' textile industry also is facing a hard time, with a drop in the number of factories and workers due to the impact of the Asian crisis, Shan said.

In addition, he went on, a number of importing countries, including the European Union, Turkey, and Mexico, have filed dumping allegations against Hong Kong exporters, causing exports to fall this year.
In 1997, Hong Kong's textile exports were worth US$38.5 billion, Shan said, but warned that the figure will drop this year.
About 200 delegates from 28 countries are taking part in the three-day conference in Melbourne.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-ROC TIFA MEETING SLATED FOR OCT. 26-29

TEXT.P: Taiwan will raise at least seven major issues during the forthcoming bilateral consultations with the United States on the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA), an ROC trade official said on Tuesday.

Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Chen Ruey-long will head the Taiwan delegation at the consultations, while the United States will be represented by Bob Cassidy, an assistant trade representative in charge of Southeast Asian affairs.
The meeting is scheduled to be held in Washington, D.C. from Oct. 26-29. Taiwan and the United States signed the TIFA agreement in September 1994.

Chen said Taiwan will seek US support for its bid to join the World Customs Organization; try to persuade the US to sign an agreement on customs affairs cooperation with Taiwan; and ask Washington to review related policies so that Taiwan can be removed from its Special 301 watch list of countries with unfair trade practices.

Other topics Taiwan will broach for discussion include: the signing of an agreement on toxic waste transshipment; the US cancellation of an import ban on Taiwan shrimp; and an intensive US probe of anti-dumping charges, Chen added. He said the Taiwan delegates will try to gain further understanding of whether related US anti-dumping investigations are violating World Trade Organization rules.

Taiwan will also discuss issues concerning intellectual property rights protection, since the US has accused Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers of counterfeiting, and has demanded that Taiwan-originating silicon wafers be engraved with special identifying marks, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH SLOWS AS DEVELOPMENT ACHIEVED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A World Bank report shows that Taiwan has enjoyed an average 6.4 percent annual economic growth rate over the past eight years, a record which ranks the island 18th in the world.

Taiwan was defined by the World Bank as a country enjoying high income in 1990, since which time the "Asian tiger" has never recorded double-digit growth rates in its economy, according to the report on global development.
Prior to 1990, Taiwan astonished the world with remarkable economic growth rates, which surpassed 10 percent annually on 14 separate occasions during the 40-year period which ended in 1990.

The figures seem to prove that the more economic development a country achieves, the less economic growth it will enjoy, the report said. It expanded on this conclusion with figures pointing out that in the 1980's, the world average economic growth amounted to 3.1 percent, while the number fell to 2.3 percent during the period from 1990 to 1997.
It is also expected that the 1998 figure will drop to the lowest ever, due to the impact of the Asian financial meltdown, the report said.

According to the International Monetary Fund's latest prediction, the average economic growth rate of developing Asian economies will register at 1.8 percent this year, while that of the four Asian tigers -- Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan -- will post negative 2.9 percent growth, the lowest since the end of World War II.

The World Bank report also indicates that mainland China enjoyed the world's largest average economic growth rate -- 11 percent -- over the past eight years, ahead of Malaysia, with 8.7 percent; Vietnam, with 8.6 percent; and Singapore, with 8.5 percent.
Among the four Asian tigers, Singapore ranked first, followed by South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING HITS BACK AT FORMER HONG KONG GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Mainland China has struck back at Chris Patten for his book -- East and West -- as the last British governor of Hong Kong promotes his best-selling book in Australia.

"From vilifying Chinese leaders and leadership and accusing the world of kowtowing to China for economic benefits, to diminishing the importance of the China market and toadying to those who fervently spread the `China threat,' the retired governor has done everything he can to hurt the feeling of the Chinese people with extremely provocative language," said a commentary in the official China Daily.
The commentary described Patten's account of his time in Hong Kong as a "portrait of a narrow-minded, retired politician who vents his spleen over those who opposed his perverse actions."

In a speech in Sydney on Monday, however, Patten said his book is not "a kiss-and-tell memoir," but an ambitious examination of the challenge presented by the emergence of mainland China, and a demolition of the idea that there was an "Asian miracle" driven by "Asian values."
"If Confucius were alive today, he would have been locked up and allowed out just before (China's) Olympic bid," he told the Sydney Morning Herald newspaper.

"He is scorned in mainland China as the snake, the liar, the whore, the tango dancer. He is, in the peculiar vernacular of official Chinese vitriol, the man condemned for a thousand antiquities," the daily reported.
However, the report went on, his book is on the best-seller lists of the New York Times, The Sunday Times of London, and the Sydney Morning Herald.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIALOGUE WITH MAINLAND CHINA HAS WIDESPREAD SUPPORT: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Despite Beijing's increasingly strident calls for political negotiation with Taipei, the two sides should for the moment continue with their constructive dialogue, ROC President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday.

A continuation of constructive dialogue is the most practical way of handling thorny cross-strait relations, and this idea has gained widespread support among the Taiwan public, Lee said during a meeting with Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu, and the members of the delegation which accompanied him on his landmark visit to Shanghai and Beijing from Oct. 14-19.
Great differences still exist between Taiwan and mainland China from almost every point of view, and perfect resolutions to these differences are unlikely in the near future, Lee said.

Taking the "one China" issue as an example, he said, since the two sides are unlikely to reconcile and reach a consensus on the issue in the short term, the most pragmatic way to solve the issue at the moment is to face the reality of "a separated China," treat each other with respect, and continue exchanges and dialogue on an equal footing.
Lee suggested that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should expand and enlarge their cooperation on points of agreement while respecting each other's differences.
He urged both sides to accelerate exchanges on one hand, but to try to maintain stability across the Taiwan Strait on the other.

The president expressed sincere gratitude toward Koo and his delegation for their commendable performances in the just-concluded trip. He was particularly effusive in his appreciation of Koo, his senior adviser, for his calm, sagacious, yet firm attitude when talking with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and other political leaders in Beijing.

Lee noted that although mainland China can boast of remarkable economic achievements over the last several years, any economy which is solid and sustainable should be backed up by democratic politics. In this regard, he said, if the mainland embarks on democratic reforms, negotiations on any subject will be much easier to realize.
Lee reiterated that the cross-strait differences are unlikely to be redressed overnight, but stressed that Koo's mainland trip symbolizes the beginning of a new era in cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1998 FOREIGN ORDERS EXPECTED TO POST NEGATIVE GROWTH

TEXT.P: Foreign orders received by Taiwan companies are declining because of the Asian financial meltdown, and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) expects orders for this year to post negative growth.

If the expectations prove to be founded, it will be the island's first negative growth in foreign orders since 1982, MOEA officials said on Tuesday. However, they added that the value of foreign orders for September is expected to hit US$10 billion.

On Wednesday, the MOEA is to soon release statistics on foreign orders for Taiwan businesses for September. Officials pointed out that it is presently the island's traditional high season for exports, which means that more orders can be expected over the next few weeks.
In August, Taiwan received about US$9.98 billion-worth of foreign orders, down 2.18 percent from the year-earlier level. This was the sixth consecutive drop since March, the MOEA officials said.
Although orders for September are expected to be higher in comparison to August figures, they are not expected to surpass the US$10.89 billion recorded last September, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday urged Beijing to face up to the "state of separate rule" on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and to conduct cross-strait dialogue on an equal footing.
The China Times: President Lee Teng-hui said as long as mainland China democratizes, everything can be discussed.
The United Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui called for planning for the next stage of cross-strait relations.
The Liberty Times: President Lee urged Beijing to pragmatically recognize a "divided China."
The Independence Morning Post: President Lee said mainland China's democratization is crucial to reunification.
The Commons Daily: President Lee said differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait remain wide.
The China Post: President Lee said cross-strait constructive dialogue must continue.
The China News: SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow said 'one China' refers to the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOURISM MAP RESHAPED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourism map has been reshaped this year as a result of a variety of factors both at home and abroad, sources from the Tourism Bureau reported Wednesday.

The number of overseas leisure trips taken by ROC nationals this year has declined substantially, while the numbers of foreigners visiting the island and domestic travelers have increased, a bureau official said.
Asia's economic woes, the depreciation of the Taiwan currency and the introduction of a five-day work week have all contributed to the changes, the official said.

In the first nine months of this year, Taiwan people made 4.53 million trips overseas, down 6.77 percent from the 4.85 million posted in the corresponding period last year. Overseas spending declined a whopping 17.29 percent or US$715 million, the official noted.
The dip in the number of overseas trips and spending by Taiwan travelers marks the first negative growth in 11 years.
The officials attributed the decline mainly to the depreciated New Taiwan dollar and booming domestic tourism development, thanks to the five-day work week.

According to Tourism Bureau statistics, Taiwan travelers made 45.92 million visits to 110 tourist attractions islandwide in the January-August period this year, up 10 percent from the year-earlier levels.
Meanwhile, the number of foreign visitors coming to Taiwan in August and September grew a slight 0.39 percent compared to the same period last year, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S US MARKET SHARE RANKS FIRST AMONG FOUR ASIAN TIGERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to the United States accounted for 3.5 percent of the US market in the January-August period, the latest statistics of the US Department of Commerce (DOC) indicated.
Although the figure showed a drop from the same period last year, it was the highest among the four Asian tigers -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore.
South Korean products took 2.6 percent stake of the US market, Singapore 2 percent, and Hong Kong 1.1 percent, the statistics show.
Hong Kong exports to the United States in the first eight months of the year surged 8.6 percent from the same period last year, ahead of Taiwan's 3.3 percent and South Korea's 2.6 percent.
Singapore's exports to here during the eight-month period dropped 15.8 percent from the same period of last year, the figures said.

Effected by the Asian financial meltdown, which has resulted in a serious economic recession in the region, the report said, US exports to Asian countries, with the exception of Japan and mainland China, dropped 2 percent in the January-August period against the same period in 1997.

The DOC figures also showed that mainland China's market share in the United States during the first eight months of this year climbed to 7.4 percent from the 6.7 percent of last year, a new high record.
It is expected that cheap goods from the economically-emerging mainland will further make a push in the US market with the approach of the Christmas holiday spending, according to the DOC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER WARNS OF BEIJING'S PLOT

TEXT.P: Despite a recent landmark trip to mainland China by top Taiwan envoy Koo Chen-fu, Beijing has not eased its attempts to bully Taiwan in the international arena, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Hu said Taiwan must let the international community know that despite the perceived thaw in cross-strait relations, Beijing is still trying to isolate Taiwan.

According to Hu, Beijing began stepping up its diplomatic war against Taiwan since last summer. Beijing aims to lure away all of the island's diplomatic partners before the end of this century, and is pumping up its military to intimidate Taiwan, he added.
Improved ties are important to both sides of the Taiwan Strait, but it will not produce any concrete results if the mainland lacks sincerity, Hu said.

He urged Beijing not to use its "one China" definition to block Taiwan's activities in the international arena, as Beijing should realize that it would only cause resentment among the people of Taiwan, leaving Beijing responsible for the possible consequences in the long run.
In addition, Hu also reaffirmed that ties with Costa Rica and Panama remain solid. He attributed the stable relations to a visit to both countries by Vice President Lien Chan earlier this year.
