DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PARTICIPATES IN BOARD OF TRUSTEES MEETING OF BCIE IN ARGENTINA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The ROC Central Bank of China governor will attend the 38th meeting of the board of trustees of the Central American Bank of Economic Integration (BCIE) scheduled to be held in Buenos Aires on Oct. 22-23.

Governor Perng Fai-nan will lead a delegation which will include Vice Finance Minister Chen Chung; Larry Wang, ROC Representative in Argentina; Lo Ping-chang, executive secretary of the Non-Profitable International Cooperation Fund and others.

Economists from the Interamerican Development Bank, World Bank, and the International Monetary Fund will offer analyses of the international financial crisis and its consequences for Latin American countries at the two-day meeting.
Argentine President Carlos Menem and Enrique Iglesias, president of the Interamerican Development Bank will deliver keynote speeches at the opening session.

The meeting will be presided over by outgoing chairman of the BCIE board of trustees who is also economics minister of Guatemala, Juan Jose Serra. In the coming year, Serra will be replaced by Argentine Economics Minister Roque B. Fernandez.

It is the first time the meeting has taken place in Argentina since it became an extra-regional member of the bank in 1995. The Republic of China, Mexico and Colombia are other three extra regional members.

Founded on Dec. 13, 1960, the bank is composed of five member countries -- Costa Rica, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala. At the end of June this year, the bank's actives totaled US$2.8 billion and net capital amounted to US$969.7 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN DAILY SEES TYRANT PINOCHET MEETING JUSTICE

TEXT.P: Former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet richly deserves to spend time behind bars for his misdeeds despite his advanced age, The Montreal Gazette said in an editorial on Tuesday.
After interrupting the nation's long history of democratic rule, Pinochet, now 82, presided over a campaign of terror against his political opponents and presumed opponents.
Pinochet's accomplishments in improving Chile's economy pale in comparison to the pain and bloodshed he inflicted on so many people, the editorial noted.
Even if Pinochet were never to spend a day in jail, the international legal effort against him is worth it, both as a matter of simple justice and as a deterrent to others.

Some may argue that the former dictator should be left alone. "But that would be wrong, just as it is wrong to let elderly Nazi war criminals off the hook, just because they managed to escape justice until their sunset years," the Gazette said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER ORDERS TOTAL US$10.38 BILLION

TEXT.P: Export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers reached US$10.38 billion in September, with orders from both Europe and the United States posting single-month record highs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported on Wednesday.
Orders from the United States and Europe totaled US$3.64 billion and US$2.06 billion, respectively, MOEA officials noted.

The value of September orders coming from the United States was an increase of 7.02 percent, or US$240 million, over the year-earlier levels. Machinery, information technology products and telecommunications equipment made up the bulk of the orders.
September orders from Europe posted an increase of 7.28 percent, or US$140 million, over the same month of last year, with electronics products topping the list, ministry officials said.
However, orders from mainland China, South Korea and Southeast Asia all diminished in September.

Although the value of orders received in September was higher than those of July and August, it represented a decline of 4.7 percent, or US$420 million, from the same month of 1997, when the monthly export orders totaled US$10.9 billion, said Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department.

Owing to the Asian economic crisis which has battered most of Asia's economies, Taiwan's export orders received this year may post the first annual negative growth in 16 years, Chang noted. Taiwan's export orders have continued to record negative growth for seven consecutive months since March, he added.

Despite the fact that October, November, and December are supposed to be peak months in terms of exports, Chang said he does not expect export orders to pick up significantly in the last quarter because the impact of the Asian economic turmoil is still being felt. In addition, he pointed out, the US dollar continues to depreciate, which will drive down America's domestic demand, and in turn, export orders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON BABS' OUTER RIM EXPECTED TO AFFECT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Babs has expanded to 250 kilometers, and its outer rim is expected to affect Taiwan by Friday, bringing torrential rain to the north and northeast, the Central Weather Bureau reported on Wednesday.

The medium-sized tropical storm was centered some 510 kilometers east-southeast of Manila on Wednesday morning, or 1,100 kilometers south-southeast of Hengchung, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, the bureau reported.

The typhoon, packing maximum center winds of 43 meters per second, is moving north at a speed of 15 kilometers per hour. Weathermen said Babs is taking a course similar that taken by typhoon Zeb, which left a trail of destruction through the Philippines, Taiwan and Japan last week, killing more than 100 people.
Meteorologists predicted that if Babs remains on its present course, it is expected to hit Taiwan by Sunday, adding, however, that its outer rim will reach the island by Friday.
Taiwan is now under the influence of the autumn northeasterly monsoon winds from the Pacific, which bring moisture and cool air, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCELED PHILIPPINE-MALAYSIAN MEETING NOT POLITICAL: ESTRADA

TEXT.P: The cancellation of a meeting between ministers in the Philippines and Malaysia does not indicate a deterioration in relations between the two sides, Philippine President Joseph Estrada said on Tuesday.

Estrada has been vocal in his criticism of the jailing of former Malaysia Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim last month despite Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's calls to not interfere in the internal affairs of Malaysia.

The ministers' meeting was postponed due to scheduling conflicts, Estrada said, adding that he was looking forward to a fruitful meeting with Mahathir during the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit to be held in Kuala Lumpur in November.
The Philippine president also said he does not think his statements on Anwar would jeopardize the interests of about 300,000 Filipino workers in Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA SAYS HE'S NOT INTERFERING IN MALAYSIAN AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada defended his personal support for former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and said he is not interfering in that country's internal affairs.
Estrada said in an interview that he was concerned with human rights and due process of law.
"I am not interfering with their internal affairs, I am just voicing my own opinion as a friend of Anwar," he added.

Anwar was fired from his post and arrested last month on charges of treason and sexual deviance. He appeared in court with bruises on his face and arm which caused an outcry from the international community.

Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad lashed out at Estrada and Indonesian President B.J. Habibie after the two called for Anwar's release and threatened to boycott the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit to be held in Kuala Lumpur in November.

Mahathir has reportedly assured Estrada that Anwar is being treated well and that the Philippine president may visit Anwar if he wishes. Estrada responded by saying he would attend the APEC meeting and may visit Anwar if his schedule permits.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH OF CONTAINER CARGO PROCESSED IN TAIWAN HARBORS SLOWS

TEXT.P: The volume of container cargo processed in harbors in the Taiwan area during the first eight months of 1998 registered a scant 4.8 percent growth compared with the same period of last year, said the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Wednesday.
However, the volume of transit freight recorded growth of over 20 percent, according to DGBAS figures.

Among the 5.77 million TEUs (Twenty-foot Equivalent Units) handled in Taiwan harbors from January to August 1998, exports accounted for 1.86 million TEUs, or a slip of 1.6 percent from the same period of last year; imports accounted for 1.75 million TEUs, or a drop of 5.9 percent from the same period of 1997; while transit freight accounted for 2.16 million TEUs, an increase of 22.9 percent, according to the DGBAS statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: XIAMEN IS MAINLAND'S TAIWAN HUB: REPORT

TEXT.P: Xiamen has become mainland China's main hub for Taiwan affairs as over 2,000 organizations have set up offices to handle exchanges between Taiwan and the port city in Fujian province, a radio station reported on Wednesday.

The mainland's Strait Voice said Taiwan travelers have paid a total of 1.7 million visits to Xiamen since Taiwan lifted the ban on travel across the Taiwan Strait in 1987. The number would be over 2 million if transit stops were added, accounting for about one sixth of overall visits to mainland China by Taiwan travelers.
Xiamen has always been among the top five mainland destinations for Taiwan visitors, and one of the busiest ports in cross-strait exchanges, the report said.
As of the first half of this year, Xiamen residents have paid 3,783 visits to Taiwan for private purposes. Meanwhile, 703 persons from around 180 Xiamen-based groups have visited Taiwan since 1992.
Xiamen Deputy Mayor Zhang Zongxu, at the head of a trade delegation, traveled to Taiwan last July, becoming the first official delegation from mainland China ever to visit Taiwan.

A total of 517 Taiwan-Xiamen couples have married over the past 20 years. Taiwan nationals have bought more than 3,000 houses in Xiamen, and 125 Taiwan students are currently studying in the southeast port city, according to the radio report.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SHOULD VALUE TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Australia should value its economic ties with Taiwan and the island's democracy because it is the future of all of China, the Australian Financial Review said in an editorial on Wednesday.

"Taiwan is in almost every sense a country. It elects its own government, raises its own taxes, has its own armed services -- which would be a match for mainland invaders -- and prints its own currency," the editorial said. "It holds the world's fourth-largest reserves and is the 14th largest trading nation."
Beijing has not had a long history of direct rule over Taiwan, any more than Port Moresby has over Bougainville, or London over the Falklands, it added.
Because of Taiwan's accomplishments, Beijing's "one country, two systems" principle which is applied to Hong Kong, would never work for Taiwan, the editorial noted.

"Now, more than ever, Asia needs the models of success that both China and Taiwan hold out. They need to find ways to live together more comfortably," it said. "China must renounce its right to use force and Taiwan must permit direct communications, even though this would be a blow to Hong Kong."

"Pressure on Taiwan will increase next year as China prepares to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the People's Republic of China on Oct. 1. President Jiang Zemin -- who was not amused to receive a mild lecture on democracy from his Taiwanese guest, Mr. Koo Chen-fu -- views taking over Taiwan as his great potential claim to historical greatness," the editorial added.

"Taiwan may be small by comparison with China, but it has a bigger population than Australia and (its) trade with Australia is booming. It is important that Australia is seen to value not just those growing economic links but the model that Taiwan holds out to the emerging mainland of a thriving, pluralist democracy, whose leading high-tech sector symbolizes its role as a China of the future," the editorial concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH PRESIDENT IMPRESSED BY BEAUTY OF CHINESE OBJETS D'ART
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: French President Jacques Chirac visited the Grand Palais in Paris on Sunday to view the ancient Chinese art treasures from Taiwan's National Palace Museum, the European First Radio Station reported on Tuesday.

Chirac reportedly spent more than three hours browsing the dazzling art collection from the Republic of China on Taiwan, including calligraphic works, paintings, jade items, bronze pieces, porcelains and other artifacts.
The report said Chirac was deeply impressed by the beauty and exquisiteness of the Chinese art objects on display.
Chin Hsiao-yi -- director of the National Palace Museum, who is in Paris to prepare for the exhibition of selected Chinese art treasures -- reportedly accompanied Chirac on the tour of the exhibits.
Chin confirmed the report and said Chirac is well-versed in Chinese culture and arts, particularly in Sung Dynasty jade pieces, calligraphy and paintings.
"Some 30 calligraphic and brush painting masterpieces from the Sung Dynasty (960-1279 A.D.) were selected at Chirac's suggestion for the current Grand Palais exhibition," Chin said.
The exhibition of priceless art treasures from Taiwan, called "Memoirs of an Empire: Treasures of the National Palace Museum," officially opened on Tuesday.

Chirac chose to privately view the exhibition ahead of the formal opening of the show in an apparent effort to avoid offending Beijing, which is extremely sensitive to official contact with Taiwan by any country which maintains diplomatic ties with it, the radio report said.

The inaugural ceremony for the exhibition of the 344-item collection of art works from the National Palace Museum was jointly presided over by French Culture Minister Catherine Trautmann, Chairperson Lin Cheng-chih of the ROC's Council for Cultural Affairs and Chin.
More than 4,000 well-wishers, including French officials, art connoisseurs and celebrities attended the grand opening ceremony.
Speaking on the occasion, Trautmann said this was the first time France has exhibited the most precious cultural and artistic legacies from Asia.
"The items on display are not only treasures but also symbolize the essence of thousands of years of Chinese culture," the French minister said.

She thanked the ROC government, its representative office in Paris and the National Palace Museum for helping organize the exhibition, the first of its kind in Europe in more than 60 years. A collection of selected ancient Chinese art objects was exhibited in London in 1935 when the National Palace Museum was still in Beijing.

Trautmann said the exhibition marks yet another step forward in cultural exchanges between the ROC and France. On behalf of the French government, Trautmann conferred a cultural medal to Chin in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of bilateral cultural exchanges.

The exhibition at the Grand Palais, the venue for the 1900 World Expo, will last thorugh Jan. 25 next year. The rare arts show is expected to attract 300,000 art lovers in France and even neighboring European countries to take a glimpse into Chinese cultural and arts heritage.

Before the exhibition was officially opened, the ROC representative office in Paris invited reporters from 11 French papers and 60 major news organizations in other European countries to view the precious art collection.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, FRANCE SIGN ACCORD ON PLASTICS COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Plastic industry associations in Taiwan and France have entered a cooperation agreement which will allow the two countries to work closely and exchange expertise in technological innovation.
Representatives from the Taiwan Plastic Machinery Association and Taiwan Plastic Manufacturers Association along with the French Plastic Industrial Federation were the signatories.

Tuan En-lei, director of Taiwan Trade Center in Paris and promoter of the cooperation agreement, said the pact will open a channel for Taiwan plastic industrial firms to develop further trade partnerships in the European market and source new advances in the technology of plastics.

France, with a producing capacity of US$41 billion a year, is the second largest plastics industrial country in Europe after Germany, and fourth in the world after the United States, Japan and Germany. It has 28 regional plastic industrial associations which form the National Plastic Federation.

Emmanuel Paturel, chairman of the French Federation de la Plasturgie said he hoped to broaden the sources of raw plastic materials and equipment through the cooperation partnership agreement with Taiwan and open up an avenue to the Asian Pacific market.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM MIGHT RAISE ANWAR'S ARREST WITH MAHATHIR

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard might express opposition to the arrest of Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim when he meets Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad during the APEC leaders summit in Kuala Lumpur in November.
Anwar was arrested in September and is facing corruption and sexual charges.
Mahathir has repeatedly warned other countries against interfering in Malaysia's treatment of Anwar.
Political analysts believe Howard's direct expression of opposition could lead to further tensions in bilateral relations between Australia and Malaysia.

Howard has tried hard to improve ties with Mahathir following strained relations after former Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating said the Malaysian leader was "recalcitrant" because he refused to attend the first APEC leaders summit in Seattle in 1992.
"If Howard raises the issue of Anwar, he could risk straining relations with Mahathir again," one analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENSIONS SEEN ARISING AT APEC SUMMIT OVER MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Tensions are expected to mount if Malaysia proposes new rules designed to control international capital flow at an APEC leaders summit in Kuala Lumpur next month, according to political analysts.

The analysts said Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is expected to raise the issue at the summit because Malaysia is one of the Asian countries hit hardest by the free capital flow during the Asian financial crisis last year.
But several countries, including Australia, would oppose too-heavy international regulation.
However, Australia is expected to agree with some sort of compromise involving greater scrutiny of the behavior of hedge funds.
The United States has openly criticized Malaysia's domestic capital and currency restrictions, and has argued against the need for a new international system of controls.
Australia is expected to send a high-level delegation to the summit scheduled to begin on November 12, to be led by Prime Minister John Howard.
Howard, who has played a low-key role in APEC activities in the past, is expected to change his attitude toward the regional organization, which was initiated by Australia in the late 1980s.
"Our fundamental goal is to preserve APEC -- to keep it as a vigorous and active and credible regional organization," one Australian government official told reporters.

He said APEC is regarded as a crucial regional economic organization, and added that Australia is pushing to prevent a loss of momentum and stalling -- particularly by Japan and mainland China -- over the liberalization of key markets such as food, fisheries and forestry.

APEC has so far failed to play a major role in providing financial help to any of its members hit by the Asian crisis. Only the International Monetary Fund has played a major role in that respect. But the IMF now finds it difficult to come to the rescue because the crisis has spread to Russia and Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SURGE ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 172.7 points to close at 7,021.42.

Encouraged by a continuing rise on several other stock markets, the bourse opened at 6,859.78 points, 11.06 higher than Tuesday's close, and climbed throughout the trading session to break the 7000-point psychological barrier.
A total of 2.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.38 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving up the most at 4.6 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 3.1 percent, both textile issues and construction stocks at 2.8 percent, cement shares at 1.9 percent, electrical stocks at 1.2 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.8 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.6 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were also higher.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October surged 242 points to close at 7,054, with 926 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for November rose 249 points to finish at 6,999, while December futures moved up 235 points to 6,985, March futures increased 185 points to 6,920, and June futures surged 136 points, closing at 6,788.
Contract transactions for the three futures totaled 351, 70, seven, and two, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S MAINLAND CHINA TRIP A POSITIVE DEVELOPMENT: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The visit to mainland China of Koo Chen-Fu, Chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), is a positive development for cross-Taiwan Strait relations, said Michael Oksenberg, a senior fellow at Stanford University's Asia/Pacific Research Center.

The meetings between Koo and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and other Chinese high-ranking officials, were very significant because they started to deal face-to-face with political issues that have divided the two sides since the 1950's, commented Oksenberg.
It is always better talking about political issues in person than shouting across the strait, said the expert on Chinese affairs.
Oksenberg said he believes that eventually, "leaders of the two countries" should meet, but the timing and place should be best decided by the two sides themselves.

Admitting that two sides of the Taiwan Strait are deeply divided on many issues, Oksenberg said he remains confident that both sides are moving gradually to surmount their differences to reach a peaceful accommodation.

Noting that there is more room for accommodation, Oksenberg said that the realistic route for Taiwan to secure the international space that it certainly deserves is cooperation with the mainland, not opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION INDEX RECORDS HIGH GROWTH

TEXT.P: The Taiwan manufacturing production index in September 1998 registered 139.14, second only to the historic high of December 1997, according to figures issued by the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Wednesday.
The figures highlight the fact that Taiwan's capital-intensive and high-tech industries have fared quite well, despite last year's financial turmoil.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the Statistics Department, said that this can be primarily attributed to the health of the telecommunication industry, and to the resumption of normal production in the petrochemical industry, as well as its newly developed production capacity.
However, Chang pointed out that although there was a rise in September's manufacturing production index, skirmishing over market price has been harsh and unforgiving.
In addition, he said, a number of factors are outwith Taiwan's control, such as the weaker US currency, which has caused a decline in US demand.

Meanwhile, Southeast Asian countries still need time to recover from the financial crisis, which means Taiwan's manufacturing production in the fourth quarter is unlikely to enjoy easy growth, Chang predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC BRIEFS FOREIGN ENVOYS ON KOO-WANG TALKS

TEXT.P: Mainland China's democratization is crucial to the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a senior mainland affairs official said on Wednesday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the statement while briefing 47 foreign ambassadors or representatives stationed in Taipei on the just-concluded visit to the mainland by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Koo Chen-fu.
Lin told the foreign diplomats that Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), has managed to achieve three concrete results during his Oct. 14-19 Shanghai-Beijing visit.

For one thing, Lin said, Koo's ice-melting visit marked the beginning of constructive dialogue across the Taiwan Strait. "Such dialogue enabled the two sides to face up to their fundamental differences and agree to continue face-to-face consultations," said the mainland affairs expert-turned-technocrat.
Secondly, Lin said, the two sides have agreed to reinforce dialogue and exchanges.
"Thirdly, the two sides reached a four-point consensus," Lin said.
The four-point deal was sealed by Koo and his mainland counterpart, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Shanghai on Oct. 15.

Under the terms of the consensus, Wang agreed to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time. The three other key points include that the two intermediary bodies respectively headed by Koo and Wang -- SEF and ARATS -- agreed to resume dialogue, increase exchanges at various levels and strengthen mutual assistance in handling incidents involving the lives and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainland, and vice versa.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Lin also briefed the foreign envoys on Koo's meetings with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen, as well as on the ROC's stances on some fundamental cross-strait disputes.
Lin said while mainland China insists that the so-called "one China" refers to the People's Republic of China, Taipei stresses that the one China refers to the Republic of China.

"Basically, we hope Beijing will bravely face up to the reality of a 'separately ruled China,'" Lin said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been separately ruled by two equal governments for the past five decades.

Lin said Koo had briefed mainland President Jiang on Taiwan's experience in economic development and democratization. "We hope mainland China will democratize to narrow the gaps in political systems between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."

The senior mainland policy planner told the foreign envoys that democracy is what mainland China needs badly. "Mainland China has undergone economic reforms for nearly two decades. Its economy is now at a crucial juncture. If it fails to democratize, its economic development will hit snags and be stalled," Lin explained.

He further stressed that mainalnd China's democratization will provide a common basis for the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "This is why ROC President Lee Teng-hui has said if mainland China democratizes, everything can be discussed," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIALOGUE WITH MAINLAND CHINA SHOULD BE CONTINUED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan should continue having constructive dialogue with mainland China, in order to overcome the long-running stalemate in bilateral ties, ROC President and Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui said on Wednesday.
As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are still widely divided on many basic issues, Lee said the major task for current cross-strait relations is to continue constructive dialogue.
The ruling KMT, Lee pointed out, must adopt a flexible policy to keep up with the latest trends to help resolve the problems of major concern to the people of Taiwan.

He made the remarks at a weekly meeting of the party's elite Central Standing Committee after hearing a report by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu on his recent landmark visit to mainland China.

Praising Koo's performance and hard work, which he described as clearly conveying Taiwan basic stance on many key issues to mainland China's leaders, Lee said that Koo's visit has paved the way for a resumption of institutionalized communication channels between the two sides after a hiatus of more than three years.

Turning to the four-point consensus reached during Koo's meetings with top mainland Chinese leaders, Lee said it is a good beginning, and encouraged KMT members to continue working hard on the issue to create a "win-win" situation for both sides.
Speaking on the same occasion, Premier Vincent Siew said mainland China's democratization is a prerequisite for Taiwan to consider unification with the mainland.

Stressing that Taiwan is deeply concerned about mainland China's democratization, Siew said that Taiwan is willing to share its experience in this aspect in an effort to build a constructive relationship with the mainland.

The premier also hailed the performance of Koo's delegation in mainland China. The historic visit has set a new benchmark in bilateral ties, and has opened the way for future constructive dialogue between the two sides, he said.

Koo returned to Taiwan on Monday after concluding a six-day ice-melting tour to Beijing and Shanghai at the head of a 12-member delegation. The SEF chairman is the first top Taiwan envoy to visit the mainland in nearly 50 years.

Although the two sides remain sharply divided on many crucial fronts, such as the "one China" dispute and "separate rule on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Siew said the two sides must continue their communications and dialogue in order to better deal with new developments.

Koo, for his part, said his visit has buttressed the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are two independent political entities under separate rule. He said his frankness in spelling out Taiwan's stance in this vein can be viewed as a watershed in cross-strait exchanges.

According to Koo, his talks with mainland Chinese leaders about Taiwan's democratization and the invitation to observe Taiwan's December elections which he extended to his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, should have had an impact on the Beijing leadership.
SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow, a member of Koo's delegation, said Wang's agreement to visit Taiwan, probably in spring rather than December, is of great importance to both sides.

The delegation's trip has successfully guided cross-strait ties onto the track of constructive dialogue, which is additional proof that the KMT is capable of adequately handling cross-strait affairs and exchanges, Shi asserted.

Citing a public opinion poll released on Tuesday by the Far Eastern Economic Review, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said the KMT is Taiwan's most trustworthy political party to deal with mainland China.

According to Lin, the survey found that 42 percent of the Taiwan people have confidence in the KMT's ability to handle mainland China affairs, in contrast to 9 percent which support the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party. Only 1 percent of the respondents have the same confidence for the pro-unification New Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE PLEDGES TO RAISE OVERSEAS CHINESE WELL-BEING

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui pledged on Wednesday that the government of the Republic of China will continue to enhance its services to overseas Chinese in order to improve their rights, interests, and well-being.
Lee made the remarks in a written speech delivered at a meeting in celebration of the 46th Overseas Chinese Day.

The president pointed out that over the last 50 years, the ROC, with the joint efforts of all its compatriots at home and abroad, has succeeded in creating a world-famous economic miracle, and a political reform miracle, laying a solid foundation for future national development.

Looking at the coming millennium, Lee said national modernization construction and a restructured government will consolidate the island's democratic system, raise national competitiveness, safeguard economic prosperity, speed up industrial development, and increase the quality of life for the people.

He added that the government will also promote world peace, cooperation and prosperity, develop pragmatic diplomacy to expand its international profile, and work for peaceful and equal cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges to create lasting well-being for all Chinese people.
The president gave high praise to overseas Chinese for their outstanding contributions to the nation over the years.

He expressed his hope that at the crucial moment of facing the challenges of a new millennium, overseas Chinese everywhere will continue to support the ROC government in its various construction projects, and work hand-in-hand and with one heart with their compatriots at home for a more brilliant future for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE RECOVERING GRADUALLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade recovered slightly in the first half of October, but was still far away from the level of last year, according to customs statistics.

In the 15-day period, the island registered exports of US$4.81 billion, imports of US$4.42 billion, and a surplus of US$387.5 million, which are 29.4 percent, 24.1 percent, and 60.7 percent lower, respectively, than the same period of last year, said Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the Statistics Department at the Ministry of Finance.

Given the economic recession prevailing in the international community, the plunge in Taiwan's foreign trade was natural, and the extra good performance last October has only contributed to the sharp percentage slide, said Hsu.
Another reason behind the plunge is the fact that customs offices were only open for 11 days in the first half of October, compared to 12.5 days in the corresponding period of last year, said Hsu.

However, Hsu said there is a sliver lining, in that the average value of goods clearing customs per day during the period, at US$437.7 million, has continued an upward trend from US$396 million in June, US$397 million in July, US$402 million in August, and US$413 million in September. Hsu said this is a solid sign of recovery in exports.

If the pace can be maintained for the rest of the month, the gap in exports between this October and last October will have narrowed to 13 percent, compared to 12.4 percent recorded for September, said Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER STEP FOR MAINLAND CHINA AND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The mere fact that Taiwan and mainland China have started talking again, instead of hurling insults at each other, is itself an achievement, Singapore's The Business Times said in its editorial on Wednesday.
Given their history, it would have been too much to expect any breakthrough in the reunification process in the just-ended unofficial talks between the two sides, the paper said.

So the promise of further exchanges -- including a dialogue on political issues hitherto anathema to Taiwan -- is the most significant outcome of the six-day visit to the mainland by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), it went on.

Koo's historic trip marked the highest level of exchange between the two sides in almost 50 years, and represented the end of the period of confrontation that began in July 1995, when the mainland conducted a series of missile tests across the Taiwan strait.
Koo's discussions with his mainland hosts saw some straight talking. If anything, both sides stuck to their respective criteria for reunification, the paper said.
Their positions may remain intractable, but other factors are changing, and will shape the reunification process, the editorial concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ISSUES INSTRUCTIONS ON SOIL CONSERVATION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday demanded the restoration of areas damaged as a result of Typhoon Zeb, and a thorough investigation of the floods and landslides that killed several people around the island last week.

Lee issued the instruction after being briefed by Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen on typhoon Zeb, which left a trail of destruction across the island, killing 23 people and causing more than NT$2 billion (US$60.98 million)-worth of agricultural losses.

Of the victims, five were killed in two hillside houses buried by a mudslide in the Taipei suburb of Neihu. That incident, as well as floodwater that inundated Hsichih township of Taipei County and many other low-lying areas in northern Taiwan, shocked the head of state.
Lee, who has expressed grave concern over soil conservation on hillside land, said he feels sorry for the people who have lost lives and property because of the typhoon.
Lessons must be learned, the president said, stressing that effective improvements in disaster relief capabilities, and stringent measures to ensure soil conservation, must be put into effect.
Meanwhile, Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo inspected damage caused by illegal logging and agriculture on hillside land around Wulai village of Taipei County.
Cheng was accompanied by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa and Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao, as well as Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chan.

Looking at the blatant evidence of illegally logged hillside areas on the outskirts of Taipei, where soil conservation has been listed as the top priority, Cheng declared his solid determination to crack down on those responsible.
He stressed that punishment will be imposed to those damaging the country's valuable land resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.054 to NT$32.843 in trading on Wednesday against the New Taiwan dollar after intervention from the Central Bank of China (CBC).
A total of US$520.5 million changed hands in the day's trading.
The greenback, which rebounded on international markets, opened high at NT$32.901, and fluctuated between NT$32.841 and NT$32.966.
It neared the NT$33 level at one point during the day but fell after the CBC intervened.
Dealers said the CBC obviously intended to keep the US currency between NT$32.5 and NT$33.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESS REITERATES SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S WTO BID

TEXT.P: The US Congress has urged State Department officials to publicly support Taiwan's membership to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The US Congress made the call in the fiscal 1999 authorization bill it passed on Monday.

The bill noted that mainland China, by taking over the rule of Hong Kong in 1997, has enjoyed substantial WTO privileges through the WTO membership of the former British colony. Mainland China is still far from being admitted to the world trade body as progress in negotiations is slow.

Since the US administrative branch has made public its intention to make mainland China a WTO member, the US government should also support the WTO admission of Taiwan, which is better qualified than mainland China, it added.
Taiwan has nearly completed all the scheduled WTO negotiations with other countries, and is the eighth largest trading partner of the United States, the bill noted.

But despite having made significant progress in negotiations for its accession to the WTO, Taiwan has yet to offer acceptable trade terms in the agricultural and certain other market sectors, it said.

"It is in the economic interest of the United States consumers and exporters to Taiwan to complete those requirements for accession to the World Trade Organization at the earliest moment," the bill said.

The US administration has publicly said that it would throw its support behind Taiwan's WTO bid, adding that it would not oppose the membership of the island simply because mainland China is not admitted to the WTO.
Mainland China has insisted that its membership must come one step ahead of Taiwan's.

Taiwan applied to join the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade (GATT), the predecessor of the WTO, under the name of "the Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" in 1990, and was awarded observer status in 1992. The mainland submitted its GATT application 11 years ago, but progress has been slow due to its failure to meet WTO requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT KOO-WANG TALKS SHOULD TAKE PLACE AS SOON AS POSSIBLE: RESEARCHER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: The top two negotiators on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume their talks as soon as possible in order to normalize relations, a researcher suggested on Tuesday.

Chang Jung-kung, researcher of National Unification Council, told a news conference at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States that Taiwan is waiting for democracy to take root in Chinese mainland. He added that the speed of future cross-strait unification will depend on economic and democratic developments on the mainland.

Chang's comments came after Taipei's Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Beijing's Wang Daohan, chairman of Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) met in Beijing and forged a four-point agreement last week.
Only when the mainland speeds up its democratization that unification of the two sides of the strait can be realized, benefiting the Asia-Pacific region, the researcher said.

Chang, who was a member of Koo's delegation which visited the mainland recently, stressed that although Taiwan's democratic structure is not perfect, it still has significance to the development of China.
Taiwan's experiences are valuable to the mainland which is why Koo suggested sharing them, particularly its democratic experiences, with the mainland at a grassroots level, Chang said.

In April 1993, Koo met Wang in Singapore and held talks in what was the first contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949. Beijing severed ties when they postponed the second round of Koo-Wang talks scheduled for June 1995.

Koo's visit to the mainland and subsequent meetings with Wang and other top-level officials including mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, was a breakthrough step in the development in cross-strait relations, Chang noted.

According to Chang, who also served as deputy spokesman in Koo's delegation, the recent meeting between Koo and Wang was the latest example showing Taiwan's sincerity in its continued efforts to improve the cross-strait relationship.

Chang said that both Jiang and Vice Premier Qian Qichen have expressed affirmation for the four points Koo and Wang forged during their meeting. He added that since both sides has resumed contact, they should continue their engagement in constructive dialogue.

The mainland affairs expert pointed out that although enhanced exchanges between SEF and ARATS will be conducive to reducing tension across the Taiwan Strait, the next Koo-Wang talks should take place as soon as possible in order to systemize negotiations. In this way, he added, the cross-strait relationship can develop further.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS REPATRIATED TO MAINLAND CHINA VIA MATSU

TEXT.P: A total of 206 illegal immigrants were repatriated on Wednesday to mainland China through Matsu, a frontline island of Taiwan, in the second repatriation in as many weeks and the fifth this year.

The mainlanders, who entered Taiwan illegally or overstayed their visas, were sent to mainland China aboard a ferry after their identifications were double-checked by officers of the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and mainland China.
They were sent to Matsu on Oct. 11 and were originally scheduled for deportation on Oct. 16, but the repatriation was delayed due to bad weather and rough seas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE MISSION FROM TAIWAN SEMI-CONDUCTOR INDUSTRY TO VISIT US

TEXT.P: A large mission from Taiwan's semi-conductor industry will visit the United States to promote strategic cooperation with their US counterparts.

The delegation will consist of senior executives from 12 semi-conductor firms in the four major fields of IC design, IC manufacture, wafer manufacture, as well as IC packaging and testing. They will leave for the trade-promotion trip on Dec. 7 and stage a presentation in San Francisco, followed by two days of trade negotiations.

The mission, organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), will led by CETRA Secretary General Ricky Y. S. Kao. An advance team composed of CETRA officials has already arrived in the United States to make arrangements for the mission's visit and is gathering support from US firms for the promotional event.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S INFLATION HITS 0.7 PERCENT IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Canada's annual inflation rate was the lowest since last December, hitting 0.7 percent, down from 0.8 percent in August, Statistics Canada (Statscan) reported on Wednesday.
The annual rate compares the month's consumer price index (CPI) with that of the same month in the previous year. The last time a lower annual price increase was recorded was in May 1962.

Consumer prices fell 0.2 percent month-on-month, or between August and September, marking the largest monthly decline this year. The latest drop is not unique as monthly declines were seen five times last year.

The annual increase in the CPI has slowed since June 1998. The modest CPI increase in September was due primarily to moderate increases in fresh fruit prices and in travel accommodation rates, Statscan noted.
Officials attributed the 0.2 percent decline in the CPI from August to September to lower prices for fresh fruit and vegetables, electricity, travel accommodation, computers and air transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PREDICTS MAJORITY WIN IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTION

TEXT.P: The three major political parties on Wednesday drew their respective pictures for the year-end election results, with the ruling Kuomintang confident of winning over half of the 225 seats in the new legislature.
Wednesday was the last day for candidates to officially register to run in the elections.
Ranking KMT officials predicted that the party will be able to garner 120 seats, including national seats, non-regional seats, aboriginal seats and overseas Chinese seats.

On the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, KMT Secretary General John Chang said KMT candidates are expected to win both. Incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, and KMT candidate, is enjoying a handsome lead over his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and New Party (NP) competitors, he added.
Chang also predicted the KMT would win over half of seats in the Taipei City Council.

The DPP, the island's largest opposition party, was more conservative about its predictions for the elections. Facing the establishment of the Independence Party by some maverick DPP members, the party said it would win 80 legislative seats or 33 percent of the votes, almost the same as the previous legislative election in 1995.
The NP, however, said it would win 30 seats, but stressed much needs to be done for it to achieve this goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday ordered a thorough investigation into the causes of recent flooding and landslides which claimed several lives.
The China Times: Registration for the year-end three-in-one elections closed on Wednesday; a total of 623 candidates will vie for seats up for grabs.
The United Daily News: Tunglung Metal Co.'s assets were secretly removed; its owners may face charges of fraud.
The Liberty Times: A total of 625 hopefuls registered for the year-end three elections.
The Independence Morning Post: 625 candidates will compete in the upcoming three critical elections.
The Commons Daily: A large number of contenders registered for the three-on-one elections.
The China Post: The government vows stringent curbs on hillside property development.
The China News: Candidates for the year-end elections all registered.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECESSION UNLIKELY IN TAIWAN, SAYS SENIOR BOA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An economic recession will not likely occur in Taiwan, nor is the term "Asian economic crisis" applicable to the island, a senior official of the Bank of America (BOA) said on Wednesday.

Andrew F. Freris, a board director and president of BOA Asia, said traditionally an economy can be considered in recession if it undergoes negative growth for two consecutive quarters. To date, the economies of Taiwan, mainland China, the Philippines, Singapore and India have not been plagued by the phenomenon.
Freris said it is not practical to view Asia as one country when assessing investment climate and prospects. "You have to make the assessment based on the respective economies' individuality."

In his speech made at the American Chamber of Commerce on the prospects of the Asian finances, Freris forecast that Taiwan's economy will grow by 5 percent in both 1998 and 1999 despite the regional economic woes.

Freris discounted the usual stereotype of the Taiwan economy with exports being the backbone of its growth. He said domestic consumption and investments are virtually the prime movers of the island's economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S PRAGMATIC DIPLOMACY UNCHANGED: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The government's pragmatic diplomacy policy remains unchanged after the recent high-level contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.
Hu said the government will not unilaterally cut nor increase overseas visits by ranking officials simply because the highest-level talks across the strait were held after a hiatus of three years.
Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator to the mainland, met with his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan in Shanghai during the first leg of his mainland visit which took place from Oct. 14-19.

The two reached a four-point agreement which included increased exchanges between the two intermediary agencies they head. Koo also spoke with President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen in separate meetings in Beijing.
Hu said public perception that the two sides reached rapprochement in Koo's "ice-melting" trip was misleading as Beijing's attempt to squeeze Taiwan diplomatically has only increased unabated.
The number of official government overseas visits will not be affected by the Koo-Wang meeting, the foreign minister said, adding that such visits will not be deliberately decreased or increased.

Hu said amid Beijing's relentless suppression of Taiwan, many considerations must be made in the overseas visits by ranking officials. Visits may be cut in the run up to the year-end elections as officials will be busy with their duties as well as stumping for candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE-MALAYSIAN DEFENSE MEETING RESCHEDULED

TEXT.P: A postponed joint defense meeting between the Philippines and Malaysia has been rescheduled for Nov. 8-10 in Manila, Philippine presidential spokesman Jerry Barican announced on Wednesday.

Kuala Lumpur earlier canceled the meeting amid speculation that diplomatic relations between the two were strained by the war of words over the jailing of former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim. Philippine President Joseph Estrada had been vocal in his support for Anwar while Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad accused Estrada of meddling in Malaysia's internal affairs.

Barican expressed confidence that diplomatic relations between the two countries remain intact. "The president will go to Malaysia, confer with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the other Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation leaders," he stated.
"President Estrada is looking forward to a very productive visit to Malaysia," Barican said.
Kuala Lumpur has notified Estrada and Defense Secretary Orlando Mercado that the earlier cancellation of the meeting was in no way related to the issue over Anwar's arrest, the press secretary noted.
According to the Malaysian Defense Ministry, the meeting was canceled due to financial and scheduling constraints.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ECONOMY SAID LIKE A FORCED-FED DUCK

TEXT.P: Mainland China's economy has been compared to a forced-fed duck as Chinese and Western economists challenge the rosy official statistics Beijing has projected, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

Government spending and increased lending to state-owned enterprises could only further damage a debt-ridden banking system which is already technically insolvent, the report said. This in turn could increase the risk of a financial crash in China.

Despite this threat, a spokesman for the State Statistical Bureau said the mainland's economy had picked up speed in the third quarter to reach 7.6 percent and now had the momentum to reach the official target of 8 percent for the full year.

However, some economists point to conflicting figures and flaws in the method of calculating output and question the likelihood that China can achieve the 8 percent growth target authorities have forecast to avert an economic crisis.

"I think it is utterly impossible. Some foreign experts think China's economic growth is at most 3 percent, but I don't think that is correct either. China's economy is like a forced-fed duck," economic commentator Peng Ming was quoted as saying. He added, "It's bloated. The real rate of growth is negative."

Peng and other economists point to misleading growth figures that include huge stockpiles of unsalable goods, mountainous bad debt in banks that should be written off, poorly planned public works and empty commercial and residential developments.

Industrial output had grown 8 percent in the first three quarters of this year, but electricity generated rose only 2 percent. Experts questioned the validity of Chinese growth figures because industry is reliant on electricity. Consumer spending jumped 6.3 percent in the first nine months compared with the same period last year, but retail prices fell 2.5 percent, the daily reported.

Economists believe officials and regional leaders in China have submitted bogus figures just to match the target set by Premier Zhu Rongji, who wants the growth rate to create more jobs and absorb workers from collapsing state-owned industries, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN BUILDERS SEE DOWNTURN IN HOUSING INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Australia's US$32 billion housing industry is shrinking, residential contract construction is declining and a 10 percent goods and service tax threatens further uncertainty, the Australian Financial Review reported.

Large builders in Sydney, Queensland and other states expect a drop in their business and are prepared to lay off workers and reshape their organizations to cope with the downturn in demand, the paper said.

BIS-Shrapnel's director of building services Bob Mellor said he expected new housing activity across Australia to drop from about 160,000 starts in 1999-2000 to just 120,000 in the "pretty tough year" of 2000-2001, the Review said.

Mellor and other builders said the 10-percent goods and service tax (GST) -- to be introduced July 1, 2000 -- is a wild card for the housing industry because buyers will have an additional financial burden when buying homes.
The booming housing sector in Sydney from 1996 to 1999 is expected to slow after the end of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games as demand is expected to weaken.

In New South Wales, transactions of all types of residential property -- new and old houses, units and land -- have continued to slide. In Queensland and other states, the boom is non-existent and builders are already forecasting a downturn in housing business.
The only city still active in housing construction is Melbourne. But builders expressed doubt as to whether such strong gains would continue momentum in the months to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEND LARGE TRADE PROMOTION DELEGATION TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan, facing a record trade deficit with Japan, is planning to send a large trade delegation to Japan to address the problem.

Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan reached nearly US$13.32 billion in the first three quarters this year, up 7.3 percent from the same period last year, statistics released by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) showed. Last year's trade deficit with Japan was US$17.33 billion.

The figures were presented in a government-sponsored conference on the promotion of trade with Japan in Taipei on Thursday. Other discussion topics included case studies of successful businesses operating in Japan and the introduction of technology from that country.

Lee Shang-Chia, secretary general of Sino-Japanese Economic Trade Foundation, said the most effective way to address the trade deficit issue was to send a large delegation to Japan to promote increased trade with Taiwan, and allow local businessmen to meet with their Japan counterparts.

Noting that many of the key technologies of Taiwan manufacturers have been in Japan's hands, he said introducing Japanese technology to the domestic businessmen would help reduce the trade deficit at its source.
The government is planning to send a delegation to Japan on Nov. 15 to learn more about their technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND KING ARRIVES IN TAIPEI ON VISIT

TEXT.P: King Mswati III of the Kingdom of Swaziland arrived in Taipei on Thursday for a six-day state visit, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu met King Mswati III and his entourage at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon their arrival.
Swaziland has been actively enhancing its relations with Asian countries in recent years, a MOFA official said. King Mswati III visited Malaysia and Japan before arriving at the Republic of China.

During his stay in Taiwan, the King will meet with President Lee Teng-hui to exchange views on current international affairs and matters of mutual concern. He will also meet ROC government officials and visit cultural and economic establishments.

The ROC and Swaziland have maintained close ties, the MOFA official said. In September, President Lee sent Ding Mou-shih, secretary general of the National Security Council, as his special envoy to attend the celebrations marking the 30th anniversary of independence of the Kingdom of Swaziland and the 30th birthday of the King.
At the recent UN General Assembly session, Swaziland again spoke in support of the ROC's bid to join the UN and other international organizations.

This year also marks the 30th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic ties between the ROC and the Kingdom of Swaziland. The King's visit to Taipei at this time therefore carries great significance, the official noted.

Members of King Mswati III's entourage include Albert H. Shabangu, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade; Absalom M. Dlamini, Minister of Economic Planning and Development; Dr. Sishayi S. Nxumalo, Chairman of the Swaziland Investment Promotion Authority; and several business leaders.
The Swaziland delegation is scheduled to conclude its visit on Oct. 27.
