DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 33.63 points to close at 6,987.79.

Encouraged by gains on the New York Stock Exchange, the bourse opened at the day's high of 7,068.03 points, 46.61 higher than on Wednesday's close. Shares moved down later in the day, though, because of heavy selling pressure near the closing bell.

A total of 2.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$85.37 billion, a decrease from the previous trading session, in which 2.98 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.38 billion.
Only two of the eight major categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.1 percent.

Other major categories registered losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares and textile issues both at 1.1 percent, foodstuff stocks and electronics shares both at 0.7 percent and bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were lower as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for November declined 44 points to close at 6,955, with 2,243 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 45 points to finish at 6,940, while March futures decreased 95 points to 6,870 and September futures dropped 350 points, closing at 7,000.
Contract transactions for the futures totaled 60, six and five, respectively. No transactions were registered for June futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY ON EUROPE VISIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday confirmed a press report that the Republic of China's first lady is currently on a visit to France.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said Tseng Wen-hui, wife of President Lee Teng-hui, left for France on Wednesday for a four-day visit.

"During her stay in Paris, Mrs. Lee will attend a Sino-French Cultural Award presentation ceremony and visit the Grand Palais where a collection of selected ancient Chinese art treasures from the ROC's National Palace Museum is being exhibited," Wu said.
The spokesman stressed that Mrs. Lee's France visit focuses on sightseeing and cultural activities.

The annual Sino-French Cultural Award is jointly sponsored by the ROC's Council for Cultural Affairs and the Institute of France, the highest French academic body, to honor European organizations or individuals dedicated to research of Chinese culture and language.
The award went to the Ricci Institute this year for its compilation of a grand French dictionary of the Chinese language.
As the ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with France, Mrs. Lee's visit is kept at a low profile.

Wu said Mrs. Lee is scheduled to leave France for the Vatican on Oct. 26 in the company of a 33-member Taiwan aboriginal music chorus. Mrs. Lee will present felicitations, on behalf of President Lee, to Pope John Paul II on the 20th anniversary of his coronation. The Taiwan aboriginal chorus will perform before the pope to pay tribute to him.
Wu said Mrs. Lee and her entourage will stay in Italy for four days. The Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
On her return trip, Wu said, Mrs. Lee will make a transit stop in Vienna.

Mrs. Lee's current visit marks the ROC first lady's first trip to Europe. Diplomatic observers said although the trip is of a private nature, it still carries much significance to the government's efforts to break out of the diplomatic isolation imposed by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.035 against the greenback in Taipei Thursday, closing at 32.878.
The local currency opened at 32.902 and was traded between 32.855 and 32.91.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$250 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BECOMES INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT FOR THAI EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan has become one of the most important markets for Thai imports, as the Southeast Asian nation is struggling to battle back against a regional economic crisis.

Taiwan, the United States, the European Union, Australia and Africa imported increased quantities of Thai products from January to August of this year, while Japan, Hong Kong, mainland China, South Korea, Association of Southeast Asian Nation member states, Eastern Europe and the Middle East are among the countries and territories that have brought in fewer Thai goods during the period, officials with the Thai Ministry of Commerce said.
The report noted that the regional crisis in Asia has lowered Asian countries' purchasing power, while Russia's financial crisis has weakened imports from East Europe.

The prices of several key Thai industrial goods, such as gems and jewelry; shoes and accessories; and integrated circuits were reduced significantly to enable them to compete with products from South Korea and mainland China, the ministry said in a report.
Earnings from integrated circuit exports totaled US$1.47 billion, from gems and jewelry US$888 million and from shoes and accessories US$613 million.
The ministry said that the average price of exports, especially farm and agro-industrial goods, saw a 15 percent decline over the first eight months of this year, despite rising export volumes.

The export value of frozen and processed chickens fell by 20.5 percent over the period, while the export value of rubber dropped 36.8 percent. Export volumes, meanwhile, rose 46.4 percent and 10.6 percent, respectively.
Exports from Thailand in the first eight months of this year have declined by 5.2 percent to US$35.96 billion compared with the same period last year.
Imports to Thailand have dropped during the period by 36.8 percent to US$28.49 billion. This has resulted in a trade surplus of US$7.4 billion for the eight-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US DEFENSE SECRETARY SEES QUICK RECOVERY FOR SINGAPORE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Singapore's "great strength" will ensure a quick recovery from what will prove only a temporary economic downturn, said former US Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger.
Now chairman of Forbes magazine, Weinberger was in Singapore Wednesday to gather information for a column he writes for the US business magazine.

Weinberger, along with the grandson of the magazine's founder, met Wednesday with Prime Minister Goh Chok tong and attended meetings with the Trade Development Board and the National Science and Technology Board.
"Singapore has accomplished so much and has such great strength that I can't believe it will be down for very long," said Weinberger.

He said that Singapore's present condition is due mainly to the problems of some of its neighbors. He also cited developments in mainland China as affecting the region's ability to recover from its present economic slump.
"A lot will depend on whether China remains intent on sustaining economic growth, or whether it moves towards an aggressive foreign policy -- though I don't believe they will do that.

"There will be differences, too, in the rates of recovery around the region, and those governments that encourage and reward growth and are eager to have foreign trade with countries that are strong and follow free market principles, will succeed," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND FRENCH FOOD BUSINESSES FORGE COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Representatives of four Taiwan food business associations on Wednesday reached in Paris consensus on cooperation with French food industry representatives.
During the near year, the two sides will impose information, personnel and technological exchanges in an attempt to boost trade.

The cooperative agreement was forged during a workshop jointly held by the Taiwan Confectionery, Biscuit and Floury Food Association, the Taiwan Frozen Vegetable and Fruit Manufacturers Association, the Taiwan Frozen Seafood Exporters Association and the Taiwan Processed Food Manufacturers Association.
More than 40 French importers, wholesale traders and supermarket representatives in charge of purchasing affairs attended the workshop in hopes of obtaining information on the food market in Taiwan.
During the workshop, French representatives from the frozen food industry expressed their interest in Taiwan's current efforts to develop the sector.

As Taiwan's frozen food industry is experiencing difficulty in exporting its goods to industrially advanced nations with stringent environmental protection laws, the French businesses promised to send experts to Taiwan to help businesses improve the quality of their frozen food storage techniques.

Meanwhile, a Taiwan trade delegation of 18 traders and producers in the food and beverages sectors has won a total of US$10 million worth of orders and follow-up orders during the three-day International Food Fair, which opened Monday in Paris.
Taiwan products displayed at the biannual food festival included frozen vegetables and fruits, frozen processed food, seafood, tea, cakes and biscuits, as well as ready-to-go food.
In addition to promoting Taiwan food products, the delegation also studied the trade and economic climate of the European market for possible future market expansion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND GROUP TO RECRUIT 10 M. MEMBERS IN FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: The "China Development Union," an independent organization of mainland Chinese intellectuals, plans to expand its membership to 10 million in five years, a dissident group said Wednesday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said in a press release that, if the plan is successful, the union will become the biggest opposition political force in mainland China.
The union, which was registered in Hong Kong in August, held a "national congress" in Beijing early this month with some 100 representatives from various parts of the country participating.

The union, which claims to have 4,000 members at the present time, plans to expand its membership to 100,000 by the end of next year, and to 10 million in five years, the information center said, adding that it is unclear at the present time whether the government will tolerate the expansion plan.
The organization has set up a "human rights committee" and an "anti-corruption committee" with a purpose to help promote national development, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER NAVAL PATROL SHIP CHRISTENED

TEXT.P: Another locally built 500-ton-class naval patrol vessel was christened and launched on Thursday at the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp.'s (CSBC's) shipyard in Kaohsiung.
Navy Deputy Commander-in-Chief Shen Fang-hsiang personally presided over the christening and launching ceremony for the new CSBC-built offshore patrol ship.
The vessel, christened the Feng-chiang (Phoenix River), was the third Chin-chiang-class coastal patrol ship built under the ROC Navy's Kuanghua No. 3 warship building program.

The Feng-chiang will undergo a series of navigation tests and weaponry installation following its launch , naval officials said, adding that the Navy will take delivery of the ship only after it ascertains that the craft's quality and overall equipment meet its requirements.
The officials said the Chin-chiang-class patrol boat, standing 61 meters long and nine meters wide, possesses high mobility and requires neither a large crew nor large maintenance costs.
The vessel, armed with advanced image scanning and sonar systems, will be responsible for offshore surveillance and regional patrol after it is commissioned into service, the officials said.
During wartime, the officials said, the ship can be armed with additional weaponry systems and coordinate with mainstream warships in conducting interception and anti-landing operations.
The ship can also be charged with rescue missions and protection of local fishermen.

Under the Kuanghua No. 3 program, the Navy has commissioned the CSBC to build a total of 11 offshore patrol ships patterned after the locally-designed, 500-ton-class Chin-chiang vessel, which was commissioned on Dec. 1, 1994.

The first of the program's 11 Chin-chiang-class vessels, christened the Tan-chiang, was launched in June and is scheduled to be delivered to the Navy late this year. The second ship, named Hsin-chiang (New River), was launched in August. Construction on several other Chin-chiang-class vessels have also got under way. All of the 11 ships are scheduled to be completed by May 2000.
The Kuanghua No. 3 project is part of the Navy's warship modernization plan aimed at upgrading Taiwan's naval defense capabilities and safeguarding the waters surrounding the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS ENTERING NEW STAGE

TEXT.P: In the wake of a trip to mainland China by Taipei's top envoy, Koo Chen-fu, cross-strait relations are entering a new stage of development, in which the government should be in control and forge a plan accordingly, said Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday.

The Executive Yuan is scheduled to hold a meeting on mainland affairs operations on Nov. 2, and Siew said he is willing to hear suggestions from all administrative quarters aimed at achieving mutually-beneficial cross-strait relations.

The premier made his remarks after the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) delivered a report on Koo's mainland trip at the Cabinet's weekly meeting. Koo, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), returned Monday from a landmark six-day visit to mainland China.

Siew said that the success of Koo's delegation is beneficial to the normalization of the operations between the two sides and that it lays the groundwork for the resumption of institutionalized communication.
Siew said he appreciated the efforts of the delegation, and he praised MAC and SEF as well.

Since cross-strait relations are entering a new stage of development after Koo's mainland visit, and as a constructive dialogue is being started, exchanges between Taipei and Beijing will take on a new form, said Siew.
The government should do its best to resolve matters concerning the rights and interests of people from both sides, Siew added.
The activities of and opinions expressed by Koo's delegation while in the mainland should be explained to Taiwan's domestic sector at an appropriate time, Siew said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADMINISTRATIVE GUIDELINES FOR FISCAL 2000 MAPPED OUT

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Thursday passed administrative guidelines for fiscal 2000, giving top priority to a comprehensive policy to beef up national strength, democratic politics and social stability.

"The plan will push for governmental restructuring and the strengthening of relations between the central and local governments," an Executive Yuan official said in the preface to the administrative guidelines. Fiscal year 2000 begins July 1, 1999.

Over the past year, the official said, Taiwan has managed to achieve stable economic growth in the face of the Asian economic crisis and has witnessed higher-level democratic politics and social stability.

For the upcoming year, the government will continue to bolster national security, enhance democratic reforms, accelerate cross-strait interactions, win more support from the international community and explore greater business opportunities for the private sector, the official noted.

The plan, which contains guidelines in 18 sections, will help secure national survival and sustainable development; promote cross-strait exchanges; accelerate economic growth; bolster social security; raise the public's standard of living; reasonably clarify the rights and responsibilities of the central and local governments; and promote educational reforms, the official continued.
In the face of Beijing's stepped-up schemes to isolate Taiwan, the Executive Yuan will continue to seek participation in international organizations and activities through more effective channels.

As to the much-talked-about national pension system, the government will provide payments of NT$2,000 a month to those ROC citizens 65 years old or older starting in 2000. So-called smart cards, which will function as combination identity and national health insurance cards, will be introduced by then also, the official said.
On the upcoming return of Macao to mainland Chinese rule, the official said the government will work to promote trade and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and the Portuguese enclave.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN, SINGAPOREAN NAVIES TO HOLD JOINT EXERCISES

TEXT.P: More than 600 officers and enlisted men, as well as seven ships from the Royal Australian Navy and the Republic of Singapore Navy, will participate in this year's Ex Singaroo 98 exercise, which will be held in the waters off Northern Australia from Oct. 23 to 30.

Ex Singaroo is the fourth exercise in the annual Singaroo series, which is conducted alternately in Australia and Singapore. Australia's Navy is hosting the exercise this year. The opening ceremony, in Darwin on Oct. 23, will be jointly officiated by the Maritime Commander Australia, Rear Adm. Chris Ritche and the Singapore Navy Fleet Commander, Rear Adm. Lui Tuck Yew.

The exercise will provide the navies of Australia and Singapore with the opportunity to work together in the areas of anti-submarine warfare, anti-surface warfare and anti-air warfare. Ships participating in this year's exercise include the Australian Navy's guided missile frigates HMAS Canberra and HMAS Newcastle, and the Fremantle-class patrol boats HMAS Launceston and HMAS Geelong. The Royal Singapore Navy will deploy its missile corvettes, the RSS Victory and RSS Valour.

The air forces of both countries will be providing air support for the exercise. The aircraft participating include the Republic of Singapore Air Force's Fokker-50 Maritime patrol aircraft and the Royal Australian Air Force's F/A-18 fighters, P3C Orion maritime patrol aircraft and the Fleet Air Defence training support aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PRIME MINISTER REAFFIRMS NEED FOR TOLERANCE, EQUALITY

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard on Thursday reaffirmed the essential principles of tolerance and of the decent and equal treatment of all Australians, irrespective of their background.

In a speech at the "Richness in Diversity: People of Australia" exhibition in Sydney, Howard said Australia has succeeded in its absorption and integration of the various ethnic groups living in the country.
Every man and woman in Australia "is entitled to equal treatment irrespective of their racial, national, religious, ethnic or other origin," Howard said.
"Any kind of racial discrimination is abhorrent to the Australian value and to the Australian way of life," he said.
In the past five decades, 5.5 million people from 150 countries have migrated to Australia, he said.
He said Australia has its own advantages compared with Europe and North America.

"We have characteristics and assets that no other country in the world has. And we have an opportunity, if we use those characteristics and those assets in an effective way, we have an opportunity to achieve things that no other country can achieve," he said.

"We are seen in Asia as having the advantages without the disadvantages of our European and our American associations. We are seen in Europe and in North America as having insights into the politics and the culture and the life of the nations of the Asia-Pacific region," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP POLL FINDS WIDE SUPPORT FOR 'ONE TAIWAN, ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: The majority of local people support the use of "one Taiwan, one China" to describe the current relations across the Taiwan Strait, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Thursday.

Quoting the results of a public opinion poll conducted by the party on Oct. 19-20, the DPP said 52 percent of the respondents favor using "one Taiwan, one China, and two countries" to portray the current state of cross-strait relations, while 31 percent disagree with such a concept.
The pro-con ratio for using "two Chinas, two countries" to depict cross-strait relations was 48 percent to 32 percent, according to the poll.

Meanwhile, 42 percent gave a thumbs-up to the statement that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait now exist two equal governments, but an almost equal 40 percent said they oppose using such a concept to describe current cross-strait ties.
Only 4 percent agreed with the statement that Taiwan is a local government under China, but an overwhelming 79 percent said they cannot accept such a concept.

Analyzing the poll results, the DPP said most Taiwan people perceive Taiwan and China as two countries on an equal footing. As for the various descriptions of cross-strait ties, such as "one Taiwan, one China," "two Chinas" and "two equal governments," most people do not precisely discern their differences.

The telephone poll of 991 adults residing across the island also found that 47 percent felt mainland Chinese leaders showed a hostile attitude toward Taiwan during top Taiwan envoy Koo Chen-fu's high-profile visit to mainland China; only 31 percent said they felt mainland leaders were friendly.

According to the same survey, 26 percent said they felt the Koo delegation had clearly expressed that the current state of cross-strait relations is "one country, two equal governments" during its mainland visit; 14 percent said they felt the Koo delegation had conveyed the message of "one Taiwan, one China;" 5 percent said the delegation had conveyed the message of "two Chinas;" 6 percent said the delegation expressed a message of "Taiwan is a local government under China;" while 47 percent said they don't know what message the delegation has convened during it Oct. 14-19 mainland visit.

Quoting the poll results, DPP Secretary-General Chiou Yi-jen said the Koo delegation apparently has not accurately conveyed most local people's perception of the current state of cross-strait to Beijing leaders -- "Taiwan and China are two separate countries on an equal footing."
Chiou further said the ruling Kuomintang's "one China" policy has made local people unable to think clearly about Taiwan's identity and status.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES LIBERIAN FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday received visiting Foreign Minister Monie R. Captan of the Republic of Liberia.
During a meeting at the Presidential Office, Lee said that the Republic of China is willing to offer its own experience in democratic development to help mainland China with its political reform.

Captan was accompanied by ROC Foreign Minister Jason C. Hu, Liberian Amb. John Cummings, Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, and Su Chi, deputy secretary-general to the president.
Lee told his guests that democracy is the trend of national reform and development, the only way forward, and that only with democracy can the nation enjoy bright prospects for the future.

Captan, who arrived in Taipei after attending an international meeting on African development issues, expressed his support for the position laid out by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation, in his meeting with Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

President Lee expressed his appreciation for an invitation from Liberian President Charles Taylor to attend the 151st Independence Day celebration activities which was held on July 26 in Liberia. Lee said he would be glad to visit Liberia at "an appropriate time."
Because of the close relationship between the two countries, Lee said the ROC is willing to do its best to help Liberia in its construction and development programs.

On behalf of the government and the president of Liberia, Captan expressed appreciation for the ROC for its assistance in the past. He also pledged Liberia's continuing strong support for the ROC' position in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBS INKS ACCORDS WITH TWO FOREIGN RADIO STATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Broadcasting System (CBS) on Thursday signed accords with Liberian and New Zealand broadcasting companies to expand cooperation.

Gloria Wan-chin Chu, chairwoman of the CBS Board of Trustees, inked a memorandum of understanding with John Cummings, Liberian ambassador to the Republic of China, who represented the Liberia Communications Network.
The two sides agreed to exchange English-speaking programs periodically to introduce each side's culture, society, and music to the other.

Meanwhile, CBS manager H.L. Lin singed a similar agreement with Y.C. Liu, manager of the Auckland-based AM 990 Chinese radio station, agreeing to provide free CBS news information and other programs to AM 990.
AM 990 is the only round-the-clock Chinese broadcasting service in the Auckland area of New Zealand's North Island. It also publishes a monthly Chinese-language magazine.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC ABLE TO HARASS TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC ACTIVITIES: REPORT

TEXT.P: The military of mainland China is now able to badly harass Taiwan's shipping and economic activities, although it is still unable to invade the island successfully, the International Institute of Strategic Studies (IISS) in London said.

The IISS said in the latest issue of Military Balance that mainland China's military strength is growing, but it will take several more years to make a significant advancement. Its ability to project conventional forces beyond its borders is still limited, too.
The yearly report said however that mainland China can easily harass Taiwan's shipping and economic activities and is able to seize Taiwan's small offshore islands near the mainland.
Mainland China could be able to significantly increase its military strength in the next 10 years because of its efforts to acquire foreign military technology, it added.

The report pointed out that Taiwan is also trying to increase its defense capability. Taiwan has acquired a new generation of weapons, including US-made F16 jet fighters, French-made Mirage 2000-5 warplanes, high speed frigates and other warships, and the Patriot air-defense missile system.

Because many of the new weapons were delivered last year, Taiwan ranked second on the list of the world's major arms importers with US$7.7 billion in 1997. Saudi Arabia ranked first with US$11 billion in the year. The two countries accounted for 39 percent of the world's arms trade last year, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY MEMBERS SET UP `NEW WOMEN'S ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: Female candidates from the opposition New Party (NP) for the year-end elections on Thursday formed the "New Women's Alliance" in Taipei, and denounced "hereditary politics based on male chauvinism."

Incumbent legislators Kao Huei-yu and Chu Huei-liang, incumbent Taipei City Councilor Chin Li-fan, along with Huang Shan-shan and Chen You-hsueh, both of whom will seek city council seats in the upcoming elections, jointly set up the alliance, and pledged to sweep aside barriers to women in political society built from the male perspective.

They criticized hereditary politics, blaming the system for allowing corruption, bribery and dishonest behavior in politics, all of which, they claim, are rotting the island's democratic political environment. They pointed out that although many different people are chosen to represent the people, most of them come from just a few families.

These few families control the island's politics, the NP members alleged, adding that not only the ruling Kuomintang, but also the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), suffer from this problem, which is damaging the democracy that the island has been striving for.
The New Women's Alliance will try to eliminate the problem and stamp out dishonest behavior in society, according to Kao, spokeswoman for the alliance.

The New Party is Taiwan's third-largest opposition party. It was established as a result of opposition to the so-called "undemocratic practices of the KMT and the DPP in their advocacy of Taiwan independence."

NP candidate for Taipei mayor Wang Chien-shien attended the press conference called to announce the establishment of the alliance, and lent his support to the group. He also spoke of his policies relating to women's affairs, and pledged that if elected as mayor of Taipei City, he will hire a large number of female employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA INK ACCORD TO BOOST SPORTS EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The Olympic Committees on both sides of the Taiwan Strait on Thursday signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) agreeing to boost bilateral exchanges.

Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee President Huang Ta-shou and his mainland Chinese counterpart Wu Shaozu inked the accord on behalf of their respective organizations during the Second Cross-Strait Sports Exchange Seminar being held in Taipei.

According to the six-point MOU, Taiwan and mainland China will increase exchange of visits by athletes, coaches, academics and sports experts. The two sides will also jointly sponsor a youth summer camp in 1999 for youngsters from both sides to meet for sports exchanges.

Both Huang and Wu pledged to strengthen two-way sports exchanges based on the current framework which has been in place for the past ten years. They said this will help further enhance bilateral understanding and upgrade each other's sports levels.
Wu arrived in Taipei on Oct. 16 at the head of a nine-member delegation for an eight-day visit at Huang's invitation. The major purpose of Wu's visit is to attend the seminar.

Wu expressed appreciation for the warm reception extended to his delegation, and promised to extend the same treatment to Huang next year when the head of Taiwan's Olympic Committee attends the Third Cross-Strait Sports Exchange Seminar slated for Oct. 1999 in Beijing.
Taiwan and the mainland began to hold the annual symposium last year, during which the two sides agreed to take turns sponsoring the meeting each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERIAN PRESIDENT DECORATES EXAMINATION YUAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The president of the Republic of China's Examination Yuan, Hsu Shui-teh, was decorated on Thursday by the Republic of Liberia in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of friendly relations between the two countries.

On behalf of Liberian President Charles Taylor, Foreign Minister Monie R. Captan bestowed the "Order of the Star of Africa, the Grade of Grand Commander" upon Hsu at a ceremony held at a Taipei hotel.
Representing ROC President Lee Teng-hui, Hsu led a delegation to Monrovia on July 26 this year to take part in celebrations marking the 151st National Day of the West African country.

Those on hand to witness the ceremony included Secretary-General of the National Security Council Ding Mou-shih, Examination Minister Chen Ching-jang, Personnel Minister Cheyne J.Y. Chiu, and Deputy Foreign Minister Lee Ta-wei.
Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew expressed appreciation to Captan for Liberia's support for the ROC's bid for membership of the United Nations last month.

In an address to a general debate session of the 53rd UN General Assembly on Sept. 25, Captan said the UN should resume the ROC's membership based on the principle of membership universality set forth in the UN charter.

In July this year, Liberia joined other ROC allies in presenting a motion urging the UN to review its 1971 Resolution No. 2758, which admitted mainland China at the expense of the ROC. However, in September, the UN Steering Committee rejected the inclusion of the motion into this year's General Assembly agenda.

Both Siew and Captan expressed satisfaction over several cooperation projects which are proceeding on schedule. The projects are based on a joint communique signed by presidents Lee and Taylor when the latter visited Taiwan last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO TOLD TO BE FLEXIBLE WITH POOR NATIONS

TEXT.P: Members of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) should make it easier for the poorest nations to join the body by adopting a "fast-track approach," said Rubens Ricupero, secretary-general of the UN Conference on Trade and Development.
This could be done by WTO members keeping their market access requests in bilateral negotiations on goods and services to a minimum, Ricupero said.

Launching his agency's latest annual report on 48 of the world's least-developed countries (LDCs), Ricupero said the poorest nations must be integrated into the world economy, but lamented that what has been done so far "is too little."
He said that to facilitate the entry of LDCs, members of the WTO should be more flexible with their requests.
Of the 48 LDC nations with an average annual per capita income of US$765 or less, 29 are full WTO members. Eight are observers, of which four are seeking entry.
WTO officials admit the process is slow, but point out that they have boosted their technical assistance efforts for the world's poorest nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON ALERT IN MANILA AS BABS APPROACHES

TEXT.P: Typhoon Babs is continuing to move slowly towards the Philippines' capital of Manila, but is expected to weaken slightly after crossing Quezon Province, according to the Philippine Atmospheric Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration.

At 4 p.m. on Thursday, the eye of the typhoon was located over Lamon Bay, or 100 kilometers east-southeast of Infanta, Quezon, with sustained winds of 150 kilometers per hour near the center and gusts of up to 185 kph. It is expected to move west-northwest at 11 kph.
If the typhoon maintains its present course, the eye of the storm will be about 80 kilometers north of Manila by midday Friday.

Earlier on Thursday, the typhoon battered the Bicol region, causing total blackouts and heavy flooding in several towns and districts. Damage to crops and public property is expected to be extensive, although no official reports from the National disaster Coordinating Council have been forthcoming.
The government has issued a full typhoon alert in Central Luzon, particularly in Manila. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MOST TRUSTED TO HANDLE CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 40 percent of the people of Taiwan think the ruling Kuomintang is most capable of handling cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, according to the results of a survey made public on Thursday.

According to the public opinion poll carried out by the KMT, only 7 percent and 1 percent, respectively, of the respondents think the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the pro-unification New Party are up to the task.

About 32 percent of Taiwan's people believe that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are more widely divided in terms of democratic than in economic development, while 20 percent think the two sides are sharply divided in economic development, according to the survey. Some 30 percent said they think there is a big gap between the two sides on both the political and economic fronts.

As to the question of the best venue for a meeting of the leaders of the two sides, around 54 percent said Taiwan and mainland Chinese leaders should meet in an international setting or in a third country. Some 11 percent favor a meeting in Taiwan, ahead of 6 percent and 3 percent who would prefer such a meeting to take place in Hong Kong and mainland China, respectively.

Some 34 percent of the respondents think the two sides should first clinch a peace agreement if a systemic negotiation mechanism is set up, followed by 24 percent who said the two sides should first address issues related to investment guarantees and travel security, the survey found. About 20 percent contend that Taiwan and the mainland should cooperate in crime fighting, battling the financial crisis, and agriculture.

On the issue of Taiwan's unification with mainland China, 46 percent said Taiwan should discuss the issue with the mainland only after the other side of the Taiwan Strait becomes a full democracy. Twenty-one percent said Taiwan can conduct talks on unification while at the same time pushing the mainland toward democratic reform, according to the poll.
Only 4 percent said they could accept unification with the mainland before it becomes a democracy, in contrast to 8 percent who said Taiwan need not unify with the mainland.

As to the question of whether Taiwan and mainland China should discuss unification under the "one China" framework, 72 percent said "no," while 13 percent said "yes." Only 7 percent said it depends on the definition of "one China."
The survey was conducted by telephone on Oct. 17-19 among 1,087 people islandwide over the age of 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOWNSIZED PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT WILL REMAIN PUBLIC ENTITY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Government will remain a public juristic person, or legal entity, after being downsized, the Council of Grand Justices said on Thursday.

With its interpretation of the Republic of China's Constitution, the council delivered a blow to the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and its "ally of convenience" at the legislature, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), both of which advocate the abolishment of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

Council Interpretation No. 467 said that although the Ninth Article of Additional Articles of the Constitution provides for the streamlining of the Taiwan Provincial Government, and rids it of its legislative and administrative powers under the Constitution, the provincial government is still a part of the hierarchy of autonomy, and that giving it a status as a public entity of non-autonomous organization is out of the question.

That means the provincial government is a subject capable of exercising rights and bearing responsibility within the scope of its authority which is not transferred by law to the central government or the local government under the streamlining program, according to the interpretation.

The council decision has raised as many questions as it has answered, with provincial government supporters hailing it as a victory, while its opponents either denounced it as flawed, or vowed to press for modification of the law.

The interpretation clashed with a statute railroaded through the Legislative Yuan by the KMT and DPP on Oct. 9 under the auspices of the government's modernization program which strips the provincial government of its status as a legal entity.
The statute on streamlining the provincial government denied it any capacity as a functioning individual, despite the Additional Articles of the Constitution which provided to the contrary.

The minor opposition New Party, which sees the marginalization of the provincial government as a step toward de facto Taiwan independence, turned to the Council of the Grand Justices for an explanation after it failed to scuttle the statute at the legislature.

New Party Legislator Hau Lung-ping, who initiated the motion for constitutional interpretation, lauded the decision, saying that it vindicates the New Party's claim that the downsizing of the provincial government is not the same as abandoning it altogether.

Party leader Chen Kuei-miao said the statute on streamlining the provincial government which was contradicted by the grand justices should be declared null and void unless it can be revised in line with the council's interpretation.
Meanwhile, the DPP denounced the interpretation as "unconstitutional."

The head of the DPP working group on the issue at the Legislature, Lin Chu-shui, chastised the council as "unwise and dodging its constitutional role" as the final arbitrator of constitutional disputes.
"Instead of being a troubleshooter, the council is whipping up more disputes by this interpretation," said Lin.

DPP Legislative Whip Chou Po-lung vowed to push ahead with the party's program to "get rid of the provincial government" by moving to alter the rules concerning local self-government, in defiance of the interpretation.

The KMT leader at the legislature, Jao Ying-chi, took the setback in his stride, however, saying that the statute on provincial downsizing will be modified according to the Constitution, rather than being shelved as demanded by the New Party.
"The KMT will abide by the decision of the Council of Grand Justices, but the statute will not be scrapped totally," he said.

The Ministry of Interior, which is spearheading the government's efforts to downsize the provincial government, and has insisted all along that the reformed provincial government should no longer be a public legal entity, emphasized that the task of transferring the business of the provincial government to central and local government agencies is already under way and will not be affected by the interpretation.

The government spokesman, Director General of the Government Information Office Chen Chien-jen, refused to comment on the issue, saying only that the Executive Yuan is studying the implications of the interpretation.

Taiwan Provincial Governor and KMT member James Soong, an outspoken critic of the party's advocacy of cutting down the provincial government, also maintained his silence, while the Director of the Information Office at the Taiwan Provincial Government, Chen Wei-Jen, said the provincial government will have no comment until the full implication of the interpretation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The Council of Grand Justices ruled on Thursday that the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG) is still a local government entity but has lost its status as a local autonomy.
The China Times: The Council of Grand Justices issued a ruling on the TPG status.
The United Daily News: Grand Justices ruled that the TPG is no longer a local autonomy but remains a government entity.
The Liberty Times: The Council of Grand Justices ruled that the TPG remains a public entity but has lost its status as a local autonomy.
The Independence Morning Post: The TPG can retain its status as a public entity.
The Commons Daily: Poll finds that more than 50 percent of local people oppose the "one China" concept.
The China Post: The budget package was passed on Thursday after marathon session.
The China News: Tong Lung Metal Industry Co. collapses.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNGARIAN PRIEST IN TAIWAN TO BE HONORED
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Dr. Imre Zsoldos, a Hungarian priest who has spent nearly 40 years teaching and doing missionary service in Taiwan, will be cited by Hungarian Prime Minister Vikto Orban on Friday in recognition of his lifelong devotion to education.

The Hungarian government is scheduled to hold a ceremony Friday marking the country's 1956 Uprising Day. Zsoldos' being cited on Friday carries great significance to him because he himself was a victim of that civil uprising and had to flee the country as a result.
After the eruption of Hungary's civil war in 1956, Zsoldos studied in Austria, the United States and France. He then traveled to Taiwan, where he has spent almost all his adult life.

Prime Minister Orban became acquainted with Zsoldos in June of 1997 when he visited Taipei as an opposition political leader from Hungary. Zsoldos was invited by the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs to act as an interpreter between Orban and the Taipei government. Orban has said that he was profoundly impressed by Zsoldos' language skills.
Zsoldos speaks seven languages: Hungarian, French, German, Russian, Spanish, English and Mandarin.
Orban met Zsoldos again this year when Zsoldos returned to his hometown for a vacation in August.
Orban, who was named prime minister in June, wants Zsoldos to return to Hungary eventually so that he can share his expertise and experiences in international affairs to help the Hungarian people.

Zsoldos, who holds a Ph.D. in linguistics from Georgetown University in the United States, was assigned by his Catholic superior to Taiwan in 1964 to help found Fu Jen Catholic University in the Taipei suburb of Hsinchuang.

He founded the French department and a graduate institute for French studies at Fu Jen, and headed the French department for 11 years before being appointed dean of the university's College of Foreign Languages.
Zsoldos said he likes Taiwan and is particularly moved by the warmth, patience and perseverance the Chinese living on the island have shown.

Taiwan has long recognized Zsoldos' devotion to his "second fatherland." President Lee Teng-hui received him and several other foreign missionaries in May in recognition of their unselfish contributions to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELATIONS WITH HAITI REMAINS FIRM: MOFA

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and the Caribbean nation of Haiti remain firm and solid, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said on Friday.

Chen Ming-cheng, deputy director of the MOFA's Department of Information and Cultural Affairs, made the statement in response to reports that mainland Chinese Ambassador to the United Nations Qin Huasun made a secret visit to Haiti earlier this week.
Chen said MOFA has ordered the ROC Embassy in Haiti to look into the main purposes of Qin's visit.

"We are concerned about Qin's move. Nevertheless, we don't think that Qin's visit would jeopardize our relations with our longtime ally," Chen said, adding that ROC-Haiti relations have remained strong and show no signs of weakening.

"Haiti's President Rene Preval just made a state visit to the ROC in April and its Foreign Minister Fritz Lonchamps also voiced explicit support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the United Nations during the just-concluded UN General Assembly debate session," Chen said.
Moreover, Chen said, scores of cooperative programs struck during Preval' Taipei visit have proceeded smoothly.

The senior MOFA official went on to say that the ROC is currently assisting Haiti in building an export processing zone, undertaking a nationwide forestation program, establishing a vocational training center and expanding agricultural production.
"All these programs have made headway. We see no signs that our relations with Haiti are facing a crisis as some media have reported," Chen stressed.

Chen said although Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Koo Chen-fu, made a goodwill visit to mainland China earlier this month to forge cross-strait rapprochement, Beijing has not eased its diplomatic offensive against Taiwan.
On the contrary, Chen said, Beijing has stepped up efforts to lobby the ROC's 27 diplomatic allies to switch diplomatic allegiance. Panama, Costa Rica and Haiti are all Beijing's priority targets.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA COMMITTED TO ECONOMIC ADVANCEMENT STRATEGY

TEXT.P: South African President Nelson Mandela said his government remains firmly committed to its growth, employment and redistribution (GEAR) strategy, even though it has been forced to revise its targets.

Mandela said that international financial crises had negatively affected South Africa's growth. "That we are weathering the storm can be ascribed to a variety of factors, including a sound financial sector, political stability and good economic policies. But we must not rest on our laurels," he said.
He said the government would remain firmly committed to its structural approach and would not deviate from it.
Mandela said South Africa was counting on the financial sector to maintain the strength and discipline that has so far served it well.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAN FRANCISCO CHRONICLE ENDORSES MATT FONG FOR SENATE

TEXT.P: In California's heated race for the US Senate, Republican candidate Matt Fong received a huge boost on Thursday as The San Francisco Chronicle publicly endorsed him, calling Fond "the real fighter that California needs in the US Senate."

Citing Fong's position on issues ranging from taxes to the environment to abortion, the Chronicle editorial said a senator from the nation's largest state should be reaching for major accomplishments.

Fong's opponent, incumbent Democrat Barbara Boxer, has failed to do so, according to the paper. "Her influence on Capitol Hill never really reached a level commensurate with the size and economic clout of this state."
Perhaps the most telling sign of Boxer's lack of major accomplishments is that, after six years in the Senate, her campaign relies heavily on negative ads against Fong, it added.

With his moderate politics and engaging style, Fong stands a good chance of being an effective voice on issues important to California in the GOP-controlled Senate,/the editorial said of its decision to recommend Fong. In 1994, Fong was elected state treasurer. Fong, who did a commendable job as treasurer, is ready to represent California in the US Senate, concluded the editorial.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN OFFICIAL SPEAKS AGAINST TRADE BARRIERS

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard has called on Asian leaders not to be tempted into raising trade barriers just because their countries are suffering from the Asian financial crisis.

In a plea to regional governments, the private financial sector and international organizations, Howard on Thursday night called for the region to trade its way out of the current crisis through growth, not protectionism.
"We confront an unprecedented degree of instability in international financial markets. The impact on Australia's region has been colossal," he told an international banking meeting in Sydney.
He said the crisis had caused massive unemployment, food shortages, family hardships and malnutrition.
"The internal political pressures created by these developments are immense. Relationships between countries are tested," he said.

The key to resolving the Asian crisis is through sustainable growth, and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit meeting in Kuala Lumpur next month should focus on addressing the problems, Howard said.
"The first thing APEC can do is make sure regional economies and markets stay open," he said. He said APEC must stand against the view that trade barriers must be raised in bad times.

"Open markets provide the opportunity for economic growth and the enormous benefits from it. The worst possible response to the crisis would be to put up the shutters. We saw the consequences of this sort of policy in the Great Depression of the 1930s," Howard said.

"I would like APEC to challenge others to enter a new broad-based round of trade negotiations in the World Trade Organization," he said. "The second vital step for APEC economies is to take decisive action to improve the transparency and accountability of government and corporate decision making. The third vital step for APEC is to put its weight behind proposals for reform of the international financial architecture," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISS AUSTRALIA PAGEANT TO BE SCRAPPED

TEXT.P: The Miss Australia pageant will be scrapped in January 2000 because of a lack of sponsorship, ending its run of more than 70 years.

The beauty contest, which began in 1926, has sagged in recent years under the combined weight of women's changing expectations, feminist outrage, public ennui and a man who mocked the pageant by entering and winning the fundraising title, organizers said.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Friday quoted Margaret Rohan Kelly, chair of the Miss Australia Company, as saying that it had become impossible to attract sufficient interest and that fundraising had become increasingly difficult.
"The awards were brilliant for their time, but times have changed," said Kelly, the 1967 title winner.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOOMY OUTLOOK SEEN FOR AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: The prospect of Australia's economy is looking increasingly gloomy, but the country is expected to escape from the clutches of recession, according to recent economic surveys.

Although most private sector economists in Australia do not see the Australian economy slipping into recession as a result of the global financial crisis, they see weakening domestic activity over the next 12 months, according to The Australian Financial Review.

The leading economic indicator of a study by Columbia University's Center for International Business Cycle Research is now forecasting a 2.4 percent contraction in the Australian economy. That indicator provides a guide to the level of activity in the economy over the next six to nine months.
The coalition government of Prime Minister John Howard has set the growth of the nation's gross domestic product in 1998-99 at 2.75 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEES A SLOWDOWN IN GROWTH OF CONTAINER CARGO

TEXT.P: Asia's economic woes appear to be taking a toll on Taiwan's port business, even though the country has suffered less than most others in the region, according to The Business Times.

The volume of container cargo processed in Taiwan during the first eight months of 1998 registered a scant 4.8 percent growth over the same period last year, figures from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show.

Total box shipments equaled 5.77 million 20-foot containers (TEUs). Exports totaled 1.86 million TEUs, down 1.6 percent from the same 1997 period. Imports, at 1.75 million TEUs, were off nearly 6 percent.
Transshipments jumped 23 percent to 2.16 million TEUs. Some analysts say that reflects the still small but growing indirect trade with mainland China.
Becuase Taiwan forbids direct shipping links with the mainland, trade between the two has historically passed through Hong Kong, which was a British territory until last year.
Trade between the mainland and Taiwan via Hong Kong in the first five months of this year totaled HK$32.7 billion (US$4.19 billion), a decline of 7.6 percent from the corresponding period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNESCO MISSION TO INSPECT URANIUM MINE IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) will send a mission to inspect a uranium mine near the Kakadu National Park in Australia's Northern Territory to see whether mining there would pose a threat to the environment.
The Aboriginal owners of the territory, named Jabiluka, have successfully petitioned the United Nations to send a UNESCO mission to inspect the site.

Energy Resources of Australia (ERA) has been permitted to mine the uranium by Prime Minister John Howard's coalition government, and mining is proceeding at Jabiluka near the park, despite a series of protests by Aborigines and their Australian supporters over the past few months.
The Australian government, however, has said the mining will not pose any danger to the national park.
Australia is one of the world's few producers and exporters of uranium for nuclear power generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETAIL SALES SLIDE IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: With a projected addition of some 170,000 square meters of retail space this year, retail sales in Singapore per square meter this year are an estimated S$6,500, down 19 percent from last year.
The estimate by the Department of Statistics (DOS) is based on data from Jones Lang Wooton (JLW) and the sector's performance in the first eight months of this year.
In a paper titled "Retail Trade Performance 1994-1998," released Thursday, the department noted that total retail sales shrank 13 percent from January to August 1998, compared with a year ago.
The analysis excludes sales of motor vehicles and sales at petrol service stations, as its focus is on consumer spending, a DOS officer said.
JLW data on net additions to retail space, excluding additions to cinemas and food courts, show an increase of about 8 percent this year to 2.3 million square meters.
Retail space grew at barely 1 percent annually between 1994 and 1996, but has since picked up again.
Retail sales -- already lackluster in 1994 as Singaporeans diverted their spending to assets and travel abroad -- have worsened sharply over the past year, in step with the region's turmoil.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW REPEATS CALL FOR JAPAN NOT TO HARM TAIPEI TIES

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday repeated his call for Japan not to harm the interests of the Republic of China as it increases engagement with Beijing.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Siew said Taipei's stance of not accepting the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan voiced by US President Bill Clinton cannot be made more clearly. To Siew's knowledge, he said, Japan fully understands Taipei's position.

Siew said Taipei has tried through many channels to convey to Tokyo its wish that Japan does not engage itself with Beijing at the expense of Taiwan when mainland Chinese Jiang Zemin visits Japan in late November.
He made the call amid concern that Japan will adopt a policy identical or similar to the one expressed by the United States.

Noting that Washington has repeatedly assured Taiwan that there has been no change in its policy toward the island, the premier vowed not to accept the so-called "three noes" policy. The policy's three provisions are no support for Taiwan's independence, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood.

Siew gave a thumbs-up to the recent meeting between Chairman Koo Chen-fu of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, saying that it was a step forward in cross-strait relations.
Relations still have a long way to go, however, as there are still huge differences between the two sides, Siew noted.
He stressed the importance of Beijing's respect for the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are two distinct political entities under separate rule.

Beijing's recalcitrant "one China" sovereignty concept and its reluctance to face up to the reality of a "separated China" has made it difficult for the two sides to redress their basic differences, he noted.

If Beijing continues its schemes to isolate Taiwan in the international community and to intimidate Taiwan militarily, chances for a breakthrough in redressing cross-strait differences are slim, Siew said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER AUSTRALIA WINS LARGE NOTEBOOK COMPUTER TENDER

TEXT.P: Acer Australia Computer has recently won the world's second-largest tender for supplying laptop computers to the Australian state of Victoria.
Patrick Lin, managing director of Acer Australia, said in an interview with CNA that his company will supply 85 percent of the total, or 30,000 laptop computers.
Victoria's Education Minister, Phil Gude, said in a statement that the order was "the second-largest tender for laptop computers in the world."

Regarding the delivery of the computers, Lin said that "10,700 teachers, or one-third of all our teachers, will receive their computers this year, with the rest being delivered progressively over the next five years."
The order is the largest tender won by an Acer branch outside Taiwan, he said.
Acer will start delivering its notebook computers to the Victoria government next month, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SENEGAL AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: Ahmed Tijane Kane, Senegal's new ambassador to the Republic of China, presented his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui on Friday at the Presidential Office.

Kane was accompanied by John Feng, director-general of the Department of Protocol under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the ceremony was witnessed by Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, and David Lee, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister.

Lee welcomed Kane to his new post, and said that both nations have enjoyed cordial relations since the establishment of diplomatic ties in 1996. He expressed the hope that Kane's arrival will further boost bilateral cooperation.

Touching on the just-concluded highest-level contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in five years, Lee said that engagement with mainland China is based on two principles: that the ROC, as a sovereign state, is on an equal footing with mainland China; and that mainland China should be given a better understanding of Taiwan's democratization.

The president said the ROC cannot accept the attempts by the mainland to isolate the ROC internationally, and added that cross-strait problems should be solved through dialogue rather than through military confrontation.

Kane said that he identified with Lee's stance and offered his support. He pointed out that he has worked in the mainland, and has some understanding about the mainland's double-faced way of handling situations.

Lee pointed out that over the last decade, the ROC has been treading the path of democratization and economic development, and said he hoped to work with Senegal in this regard. He also expressed admiration for Senegal's democratic achievements.

Kane said the ROC's friendship is very important to his African nation, and added that with cooperation between the two nations already showing some substantial results, both sides should be able to strengthen cooperation and exchanges in the future.
Kane reaffirmed Senegal's support for the ROC's bid to join international organizations, and said he believes the ROC's efforts in the international arena will win it more support and friendship.
Kane, 57, has been a roving ambassador since 1996. He has previously served as ambassador to South Korea, Thailand, Australia, Guinea-Bissau, Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso, and Niger.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT AGRICULTURAL EXCHANGES SHOULD NOT AFFECT LOCAL

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural exchanges should not affect domestic agricultural development, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Peng Tzou-kuei said on Friday.

Peng made the remarks on proposed cross-strait agricultural exchanges as he accompanied President Lee Teng-hui on a visit to a national agricultural technology exhibition held at National Taiwan University.
Peng said that cross-strait agricultural exchanges should be implemented in a gradual manner under the premise that Taiwan's agricultural development should not be affected.

Peng also said that the government's stance on the issue is stated clearly in Lee's six-point peace proposal of 1996, which says Taiwan would use its experience in agricultural development to help mainland farmers.
During his tour of the exhibition, Lee said that agricultural technology should be combined with agricultural production for the benefit of farmers islandwide.

The president, himself an expert in agroeconomics, showed keen interest in exhibits on biotechnology, and automation system. He also spent a great deal of time at a booth demonstrating the technique of implanting computer chips in pets, and at various innovative poultry-raising exhibits.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved down NT$0.02 against the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 32.898.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.868, and had a low of 32.92.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$311 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOBLESS RATE STANDS AT 2.98 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate stood at 2.98 percent in September, marking a slight decline of 0.07 percentage points from August, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Friday.
During September, a total of 285,000 people were out of work, 7,000 less than in the previous month, DGBAS officials said.
The officials said the nation's overall workforce hit nearly 9.26 million in September, up about 92,000 from the same month of 1997, and down 29,000 from August this year.
According to the latest DGBAS tallies, the number of first-time job seekers who failed to obtain work in September was 13,000 less than the figure posted in August.

Although both the unemployment rate and the number of jobless dropped in September, the number of people who lost their jobs in September because of workplace closure or business downsizing increased by 17,000 over the year-earlier levels, the officials noted.

Taiwan's jobless rate in September was relatively lower than the other major economies in Asia, the DGBAS officials said. Japan's unemployment rate was 4.3 percent in August, while Hong Kong's stood at 5.0 percent, and South Korea suffered 7.4 percent, they noted.
The DGBAS statistics also show that Taiwan's labor participation rate stood at 57.83 percent in September, 0.26 percentage points lower than that of August.
On average, the island's labor participation rate was 58.01 percent between January and September this year, the lowest level in 16 years, the officials noted.
The labor participation rate is the ratio of the working population to the population aged 15 and over.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHIEF TO REPRESENT PRESIDENT LEE AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: P. K. Chiang, the ROC's chief economic planner, will represent President Lee Teng-hui at the 1998 summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Friday.

"Chairman Chiang of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will attend the Nov. 17-18 APEC informal leadership meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia's capital, on behalf of President Lee," said MOFA spokesman Roy Wu.

The Malaysian government sent a special envoy to Taipei earlier this month to forward an invitation to President Lee, Wu said, adding that Lee had told the Malaysian envoy his decision to name Chiang to represent him at the annual APEC summit meeting.
Wu said Lee has made the decision in respect of the host country's desire and with a view to maintaining a harmonious, amiable atmosphere at the meeting.
Because of Beijing's opposition, Lee has been unable to personally attend the annual APEC gathering. Instead, he has to name a surrogate to attend the meeting.
In the first two APEC summits held in 1993 and 1994, respectively, Lee appointed then-CEPD Chairman Vincent Siew to represent him on the occasions.
From 1995 through 1997, Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, served as Lee's surrogate at the annual APEC summit.

As Koo, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), just concluded an ice-melting visit to mainland China, Lee decided to name Chiang to take part in this year's APEC leadership meeting on his behalf.

Koo, an 81-year-old billionaire tycoon and seasoned ambassador-at-large, met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Beijing's top negotiator with Taipei, Wang Daohan, during his Oct. 14-19 landmark mainland visit.

Wu denied that the government's decision to name Chiang instead of Koo to the APEC summit has anything to do with consideration of the new situation across the Taiwan Strait in the wake of recent Koo-Wang talks.

Meanwhile, Wu said the ROC delegation to the annual APEC senior officials meeting will be headed by Andrew L. Y. Hsia, director of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations. And the ROC delegation to the APEC ministerial meeting will be led by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Finance Minister Paul Chiu. Both meetings will be held Kuala Lumpur ahead of the informal leadership meeting.

APEC is a regional economic cooperation forum dedicated to promote free trade, investment and capital flow. It currently has 18 full members -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, mainland China, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AND BEIJING SHOULD CONDUCT ECONOMIC EXCHANGES: FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Rising People Foundation (RPF), a private non-profit organization, suggested on Friday that Taipei should demonstrate its goodwill toward Beijing by initiating a discussion on Taiwan's "three links" ban.

The discussion could be raised during a proposed visit to Taiwan next year by Wang Daohan, Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan. In exchange, the RPF suggested, mainland China agrees that Taiwan could become a member of the World Trade Organization before mainland China.

RPF director Sisy Chen of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) unveiled the proposal at a RPF conference held in Taipei to discuss cross-strait relations in the wake of the just-concluded Koo-Wang discussions in Shanghai.
Taipei and Beijing should first conduct negotiations on trade and economic issues as a way of fostering constructive interaction, Chen said.

She suggested that the "three-links" issue could be "torn apart" and each point negotiated separately, and that Taiwan could formulate various negotiation strategies to prepare for a resumption of the cross-strait dialogue suspended by Beijing in 1995.

Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu, made an "ice-melting" visit to the mainland on Oct. 14-19. During the visit, his mainland counterpart Wang informed him of Beijing's demand for political talks between Taiwan and mainland China, and for talks on Taipei's lifting of the ban on direct trade, postal, and transport links with the mainland.
Koo responded to Wang's demands by saying that as soon as mutual trust has been established between the two sides, the "three links" issue can be taken up.

Citing the Koo's remarks, RPF Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said at the RPF conference that he believes the best way to change the mainland is to forge friendly links with the authorities there and to make peaceful efforts to change them into an organization which respects human rights and democracy.

The former DPP chairman stressed that the issues of human rights and democracy is expected to play a more and more important role on the international political stage. Taiwan is at an advantage in this situation because it has achieved democracy, while Beijing has not, Hsu said.
He added he believes international trends will force mainland China's leaders to come to the negotiating table to resolve cross-strait disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS CHAIRMAN MIGHT VISIT TAIWAN LATE 1999: MAINLAND CHINA SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A visit to Taiwan by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), might occur by the end of 1999, according to an expert from mainland China.

Hong Kong's Da Kung Pao newspaper carried an article on the just-concluded discussions between Wang and Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu by Xu Shiquan, director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies under the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, and one of those responsible for advising Beijing on policy decisions regarding Taiwan.
Xu gave the following four-point summary of the results of the Koo-Wang meetings:
-- Differences still remain between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait;
-- The atmosphere has improved somewhat;
-- Some new hope has emerged from the meetings; and
-- There is still a long way to go on the road to conciliation.

He expanded on his summary by saying that the new hope refers to the consensus reached between the two sides, which leaves the way ahead open for the discussion of any topic. It also refers to Wang's acceptance of an invitation from Koo to visit Taiwan, he said.
The form of Wang's visit to Taiwan should be similar to that of Koo's trip to the mainland, so that the two men can exchange views in a free and unrestrained style, Xu continued.

He pointed out that mainland China's President Jiang Zemin was acting in his capacity as the General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China during a meeting he had with Koo. Likewise, he said, ROC President Lee Teng-hui could meet with Wang in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang.

Commenting on the intense speculation regarding the likelihood of a meeting between Lee and Jiang, Xu predicted that a direct meeting between the two leaders seems unlikely in the near future, due to the lack of a clear objective for any such meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SHARE PRICES, FUTURES BOTH MOVE UP

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed high on Friday following a surge on Wall Street, rising 67.67 points to close at 7,055.46.
The bourse opened at 7,029.44 points and reached the day's high of 7,088.39 at one point before falling again to the closing figure.
Gainers outnumbered losers 259 to 139, with 95 stocks remaining unchanged.
In all, 2.78 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$95.6 billion (US$2.9 billion), up from the NT$88.38 billion traded during Thursday's session.

Of the eight major stock categories, both technology and banking issues posted the largest gains of 1.3 percent, followed by textile shares which rose 1 percent; construction stocks, 0.9 percent; and plastic and chemical shares, 0.4 percent.
Foodstuff issues dropped 1.1 percent and paper-making stocks slid 0.2 percent, while cement shares remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also climbed.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December rose 60 points to close at 7,015, with 2,586 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 53 points to finish at 7,000, while those for March dropped 24 points to 6,882, those for June remained unchanged at 6,841, and those for September slumped 158 to 6,842. Contract transactions for these futures totaled 61, 2, 1, and 3, respectively.

The reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 6,955 for November; 6,947 for December; 6,906 for March; 6,841 for June; and 7,000 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, AUSTRALIA CONDUCT NAVAL EXERCISE

TEXT.P: The Republic of Singapore Navy (RSN) and the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) on Thursday began a two-day training exercise codenamed "PASSEX" in the South China Sea.

Two RSN missile corvettes and one RAN frigate took part in the exercise which included anti-submarine warfare, ship maneuvers, and night encounters. They were supported by two RSN missile gunboats. An exchange of personnel between the participating ships also took place.
The exercise is designed to enhance cooperation between the two navies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE SIGNS DEFENSE AGREEMENT WITH SOUTH AFRICA

TEXT.P: An agreement covering Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) personnel deployed in South Africa was signed on Friday by Singapore's Acting High Commissioner in Pretoria, Bernard Baker, and South African Secretary of Defense, Pierre Steyn.

This is the second defense agreement between Singapore and South Africa. The first, an agreement on military cooperation in areas such as military training and defense industry and technology, was signed in November last year.
The new agreement marks another milestone in bilateral defense ties, and paves the way for SAF training in South Africa.

The Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) will deploy its first unmanned aerial vehicle detachment to a South African air base for training next month. The six-week training program will involve more than 50 RSAF personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO SEND GROUP ABROAD TO EXPLAIN RESULTS OF TALKS

TEXT.P: Taipei has decided to send a publicity group to the US, Japan and European countries to explain the results reached in top envoy Koo Chen-fu's just-concluded trip to mainland China.
The delegation will also make clear the ROC government's mainland policy and its position in handling cross-strait relations.

Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman and spokesman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), noted that the publicity group will include members of Koo's delegation which mainly included personnel in the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF). The group will leave between late October to early November.

Chang Jung-kung -- vice spokesman of Koo's delegation, director of the Mainland Operations Department of the ruling party Kuomintang, and researcher of the National Unification Council -- is now in Washington D.C. to address the delegation's mission.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the MAC, and Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of secretary-general of the SEF, as well as relevant officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will leave for the US, Japan and European countries in late October. They will focus on publicizing the results of the Koo-Wang meeting and international propaganda, according to informed sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENT CHEN SENTENCED TO SEVEN YEARS IN PRISON

TEXT.P: Dissident Chen Zengxiang of Shandong Province was sentenced Tuesday to seven years in prison because he tried to collect information about political prisoners, a dissident group said Friday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said in a press release that Chen was sentenced on charges of "divulging state secrets," and that the authorities concerned did not disclose the nature of the secrets divulged by him. The real reason for his imprisonment is that he tried to collect information about political prisoners in the province in eastern China, the information center said.

It pointed out that many Shandong students and workers who took part in the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement are still in prison, and Chen wanted to collect information about them. For example, Chen Lantao is still imprisoned, because he was sentenced to 18 years after he was arrested for making a speech on the street during the Tiananmen incident.

Another Shandong dissident, Li Hai, was sentenced to nine years in prison after he was found in possession of a list of political prisoners in the Second Prison of Beijing. The mainland Chinese government has long classified information about political prisoners as high secret, the center said.
Chen, 44, was nabbed by police on May 23. His family has been barred from seeing him since then. He was tried in secret, the center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND SECURITY OFFICER SAID INVOLVED IN SMUGGLING DRUG TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Law enforcement authorities have managed to break two cases involving smuggling contraband drugs to Taiwan from mainland China over the past week, the Taichung Prosecutor's Office in central Taiwan reported on Friday.

Tu Ta-jen, a chief prosecutor with the office, said initial investigations show that the two drug traffic cases were masterminded by the same ring and that at least a mainland Chinese public security officer was suspected of involvement in the illegal operations.
"We hope mainland authorities will pay more attention to the illegal narcotics trafficking across the Taiwan Strait and cooperate with Taiwan to stem such criminal activities," Tu said.

Under Tu's leadership, a special team composed of Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) agents, police officers and military police, intercepted a 50-year-old man Chang Liang-chiang at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Thursday night, who intended to smuggle 20 kilograms of amphetamines from the mainland into Taiwan. The drugs were hidden in Chang's baggage.

Investigators said this was the sixth time that Chang tried to smuggle amphetamines into Taiwan from the mainland. He had been targeted for intensive monitoring since he managed to smuggle a fifth batch of amphetamines into Taiwan on Sept. 25. He left for the mainland on Oct. 19 and returned to Taiwan last night.

Chang confessed to investigators that he had successfully smuggled a total of 50 kilograms of amphetamines into Taiwan in five installments so far this year. Each time he could earn NT$50,000 for his trafficking services.

According to Chang, a public security officer in the southern mainland city of Guangzhou personally escorted Chang to board a passenger plane for returning to Taiwan via Hong Kong on Thursday to shun mainland customs inspection.
