On Monday, investigators also arrested a Taiwan man, identified as Yang Chun-shen, at a northern Taiwan port, who intended to smuggle 11 kilograms of amphetamines into Taiwan from the mainalnd by a fishing boat.
MJIB agents said they managed to uncover underground amphetamine factories in Taiwan in 1996 and 1997. However, no such production facilities have been uncovered on the island so far this year.

"We have been tipped off that all local amphetamine plants have been relocated to the mainland and that many experienced amphetamine production workers have also moved to the mainland," said an MJIB official.
He said the ring which masterminded the latest two drug trafficking cases has consistently recruited jobless middle-aged Taiwan men with no criminal records to "transport" amphetamines into Taiwan.

Law enforcement authorities said they will make further investigation into the ring's operations and bring to justice all masterminds and accomplices in order to completely topple the drug trafficking ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN PRESIDENT CALLS FOR MORAL RENEWAL

TEXT.P: Corruption, violence and abuse are evils that will be rooted out only when South Africans turn the tide against the moral degeneration that is sweeping the country, President Nelson Mandela said on Thursday.
Speaking at the first "Moral Summit" in Johannesburg, Mandela said the summit represented the moral renewal of the nation and would help different groupings seek common ground for national action.

The participants, comprising political and religious leaders, signed a code of conduct for people in positions of responsibility, committing themselves to principles such as incorruptibility, integrity, openness, and respect.
The meeting also called on South Africans to live honestly and positively, to be considerate and kind, to respect other people's beliefs and cultures, and to promote harmony and non-violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA PLANNING ANTI-DUMPING MONITORING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Friday it will set up a monitoring system to help Taiwan businesses head off dumping charges by foreign competitors.

MOEA officials said the ministry has commissioned the Chinese National Federation of Industries to devise a system as part of the government's efforts to help local enterprises take preventive measures to avoid potential dumping charges.

US-based Micron Technology has filed a complaint with the US Department of Commerce and the US International Trade Committee accusing nine Taiwan dynamic random access memory (DRAM) circuitry makers of selling their products at below fair market prices in the United States.

Citing statistics by the US Commerce Department, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu said Taiwan is the third largest source of DRAMs in the US with a 7 percent market share, behind Japan and South Korea.

Taiwan exported US$242 million worth of DRAMs to the US in the first half of this year. The figure stood at US$427 million for the whole of 1997, up from US$349 million in 1996 but down from US$455 million in 1995.
Lin has urged the nine Taiwan companies to collect evidence and information to defend themselves as the US Commerce Department will decide whether to investigate Micron's charges within 20 days.

According to MOEA officials, ROC trade officials stationed in the US alerted the local industry in May and June to the greater number of Taiwan-made DRAMs being sold to the US at lower prices for three months in a row.

The officials said the government is also unhappy with the situation since increased competition in the international community has forced Taiwan firms to slash product prices to maintain a competitive edge.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI GOVERNMENT TO HELP LOCATE FIRE VICTIMS' FAMILIES

TEXT.P: The Thai Labor and Welfare Ministry is trying to locate the families of four Thai workers who were killed in a factory fire in Taoyuan in Taiwan, ministry officials said on Thursday.
Thongphoon Wanprasert, Chamlieng Prachian, Julawan Rithaisong and Saeksan Lensantia were killed in a 10-hour fire which destroyed the Laiwei Textile Co. Ltd.

The owners of the factory are willing to pay the victims' families more compensation than the law requires. They have offered to pay 475,200 baht (NT$12,505) to the families of the first three workers who were off duty at the time of the fire. The amount is five times their salary to cover funeral expenses plus 20 times the amount fixed for compensation, Somchai Wattana, director general of the Ministry's Job Placement said.
The family of Saeksan Lensantia, who was on duty, will receive five times his salary plus 40 times the amount fixed for compensation, he added.
In addition, the 70 Thai workers who survived the fire will continue to receive a salary until the factory resumes operations. Each will also receive 2,000 baht for clothing and other expenses.

Somchai said that the families of the four Thai workers should present a letter of consent, marital certificate, identity card, and house registration papers in English and endorsed by the Thai Foreign Ministry and the Taipei Economic and Trade Office In Thailand.
According to Thai statistics, there are 150,000 Thai workers in Taiwan. Between January and September alone, some 78,648 Thais arrived in Taiwan to work. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT CHIEF TO DISCUSS DRAM DUMPING CHARGES WITH US OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Friday it will assist local computer chip makers in persuading the US government not to accept a dumping charge against them.

Micron Technology Inc., the world's largest dynamic random access memory (DRAM) semiconductor manufacturer which accounts for 50 percent of total annual US DRAM production, filed a petition with the US federal International Trade Commission (ITC) and the Department of Commerce (DOC) on Thursday, asking the US government to levy anti-dumping taxes on Taiwan-made DRAMs.
Micron accused nine Taiwan DRAM manufacturers and four chip designing companies of exporting their products to the United States at prices below fair market value or production costs.

According to the US anti-dumping regulations, the DOC must decide before Nov. 10 whether or not to launch an investigation into Micron's dumping charges against the 13 Taiwan companies. Meanwhile, the ITC is required to mete out an initial ruling by Dec. 7 on whether the alleged dumping practices have afflicted any damage to the US DRAM industry. And a final decision on whether to impose anti-dumping taxes on Taiwan products will be available by next July.
Responding to Micron's dumping charges, BOFT Director-General Chen Rui-lung said he will discuss the issue with relevant American officials during his upcoming visit to the United States.
Chen will be the chief ROC delegate to an annual meeting under a Taiwan-US Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) to be opened in Washington, D.C. on Monday.
During the four-day meeting, Chen said he will exchange views with US Assistant Trade Representative Robert Cassidy on the dumping charge issues.

"We'll remind American authorities that their anti-dumping investigation process must meet the requirements of the World Trade Organization and complies with the principles of transparency, fairness and reasonableness," Chen said.
Chen said he was not surprised by Micron's accusations. However, he said, Micron's action will only deal yet another blow to the battered global semiconductor industry.

Noting that key problems facing the world DRAM industry are a shrinking market demand and overproduction, Chen said the most effective way to tackle the industry's woes is coordination among major manufacturers around the world. "Dumping charges cannot help resolve the industry's problems," he stressed.

Micron also filed dumping charges against Taiwan's static random access memory (SRAM) chip makers two years ago which eventually prompted the US government to levy punitive anti-dumping taxes on major Taiwan SRAM makers.
Local manufacturers said Micron's accusation was unfair because Taiwan accounted for a mere 6.7 percent of total US DRAM imports last year.

Taiwan is America's third largest DRAM import source, but its sales to the US market lag far behind the top two suppliers -- Japan and South Korea. Taiwan exported US$427.01 million worth DRAMs to the United States in 1997.

The 13 Taiwan companies listed in Micron's dumping petition are Vanguard, Nan Ya Technology, Mosel-Vitelic, Winbond, Acer, Powerchip, United Microelectronics Corp., Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., Macronix International Co., Alliance, Etron Technology, Taiwan Memory Technology, and G-Link Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER FOREIGN INVESTMENTS IN TAIWAN TOTALED US$370 MILLION

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and foreign investments entering Taiwan in September totaled US$370 million, up US$130 million or 54 percent from the previous month, the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Investment Commission said on Friday.

The number of overseas Chinese and foreign investment projects in September decreased 14 percent over the previous month, indicating the scale of individual investments has expanded, the statistics showed.
The top five sources for foreign investment entering Taiwan in September were Hong Kong, British territories in Central America, the United States, the Netherlands and Japan.
The top five industries were electronic and electrical product manufacturing, wholesale and retailing, financial and insurance, chemical manufacturing, and the service sector.

In the same month, Taiwan businessmen's investments made abroad amounted to US$446 million, an increase of US$200 million or 82 percent over the previous month. However, the number of investment projects decreased 18 percent, the statistics revealed.

Affected by Asian financial turmoil, Taiwan businessmen had not made any investments in Indonesia or the Philippines in September, but investments in zero or low tax rate areas in Central America are still on the rise, the Investment Commission said.
The top four industries Taiwan businessmen chose when investing abroad in September were finance and insurance, electronic and electrical product manufacturing, international trade, and textiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S APEC REPRESENTATIVE VOWS TO DO HIS BEST

TEXT.P: The representative President Lee Teng-hui chose to represent him in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Malaysia next month, vowed on Friday to do his best at the meeting scheduled for Nov. 17-18.

Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang told reporters he has attended five APEC ministerial-level meetings since 1993, but this will be the first time he will represent President Lee at the informal leadership meeting.
Chiang described it as a good opportunity for him to exchange views with the leaders of the member countries on behalf of President Lee, and said that he will do his best.
According to Chiang, the four major topics to be discussed at the meeting are as follows:
-- how to realize the promise for liberalization in some specified sectors ahead of schedule;
-- how to step up exchanges of human resources and scientific and technical cooperation, so as to solidify the economic development basis of the member countries; and
-- foster electronics industry exchanges and cooperation.
Chiang said it was regrettable that Lee is unable to attend the APEC meeting as the government had tried hard to convince the host country to invite Lee to the annual gathering.
The chairman said he will take advantage of the meeting to share with foreign leaders Taiwan's experiences in riding out the current wave of Asian financial storms.
Asked whether Lee offered any instructions on his expected meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Chiang did not give a direct reply.

He noted that he will have the opportunity to chat with the leaders of other member countries, but said cross-strait affairs should be handled by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
In the past three years, Lee sent SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu as his representative at the APEC informal leadership meeting.
Ahead of the gathering, ROC Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang and Finance Minister Paul Chiu will represent the ROC at the ministerial-level meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO REJECTS US APPEAL OVER SHRIMP IMPORT BAN

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has rejected a US appeal to ban the import of shrimp caught in nets that ensnare and kill thousands of endangered sea turtles every year, the Geneva-based organization said.
The WTO Appellate Body stated that a US embargo on shrimp imports from India, Malaysia, Pakistan and Thailand amounted to arbitrary and unjustifiable discrimination.

In April, the WTO ruled that the restrictions were an illegal attempt to impose US standards on other countries. The four named Asian nations claimed that the US ban was being applied in a discriminatory manner and represented an unfair trade barrier.

The countries have declined to stop measures that safeguard turtles. Environmentalists say failure to equip shrimp nets with US$75 turtle-excluder devices causes the deaths of 150,000 turtles a year worldwide.
Although faulting the United States for the way its rules were carried out, the WTO panel upheld the right for members to adopt conservation laws.
The US government insisted that the law was implemented in an even-handed manner, and said the ruling would not affect US efforts to promote sea turtle conservation.
The WTO decision was denounced by environmental groups including the Sierra Club, the Earth Island Institute and the Earthjustice Legal Defense Fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: EL SALVADOR EMBASSY DENIES HARBORING FRAUD SUSPECT

TEXT.P: Both the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the El Salvador Embassy to Taipei denied that a business tycoon suspected of making off with company funds was hiding at the embassy.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the El Salvador Ambassador David Ernesto Panama denied that Fan Fang-quei, the honorary consul-general of El Salvador, was seeking political asylum at the embassy.

Fan does not hold an El Salvador passport or travel document, nor does he have diplomatic immunity, Panama was quoted as saying. Fan has not applied for an El Salvador visa, and has not contacted Panama in the last month.
Wu said MOFA respects the ambassador's statement and takes him at his word.

Fan, who is the former chief of executive of the listed company Tong Lung Metal Industry, is suspected of making off with more than NT$6.3 billion (US$190.9 million) worth of certificates of deposit and stocks from the company's coffers.
The case was uncovered early this week after Tung Lung's stock nose-dived on the bourse for two straight weeks over rumors that Fan was experiencing a financial crisis.

A raid on the company by auditors from the bourse's watchdog, the Securities and Futures Commission, on Tuesday found that more than NT$6.3 billion worth of certificates of deposit and stocks were unaccounted for.
Fan has been missing ever since, and is wanted by investigators.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY PRESIDES OVER AWARDS CEREMONY IN PARIS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ROC first lady Tseng Wen-hui represented ROC President Lee Teng-hui at the third ROC-France Cultural Prize in Paris on Thursday.

During the awards ceremony at the Institut de France, Teng relayed a message from Lee and expressed the hope that cultural exchanges between Taiwan and France will further cement bilateral friendship.

She also congratulated the Institut Ricci Taipei-Paris for winning the cultural prize and praised the award as an annual event that has helped boost two-way cultural and literature exchanges over the past three years.
"President Lee has expressed the hope that such bilateral exchanges can be expanded to other fields in the future," she said.

The ROC-France Cultural Prize, sponsored by the ROC's Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), is awarded each year to a French scholar or research institution for outstanding study and research in Chinese culture.

Pierre Messmer, director of the Institut de France and former French prime minister, thanked Tseng for attending the award ceremony and said he was honored to be received by President Lee in May in Taipei while working on screening this year's winner of the ROC-France Cultural Prize.

Messmer also congratulated the president for being nominated for this year's Nobel Peace Prize, saying it was proof that Lee's contribution to the ROC's democratization has won international recognition.

Tseng, who arrived in Paris in the morning, will visit the Grand Palais on Friday to view an exhibition of ancient Chinese art treasures from the Taipei-based National Palace Museum currently being displayed.
Tseng and her entourage, which includes CCA Chairwoman Lin Cheng-chih, are scheduled to proceed to the Vatican on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI THROWS STATE DINNER FOR VISITING SWAZILAND KING

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui held a state banquet in honor of visiting King of Swaziland Mswati III on Friday at which the two vowed to further develop ties between the two countries and face the challenges of a new century.

President Lee made note of the 30 years of diplomatic ties the two sides share and expressed gratitude for Swaziland's support for the ROC, particularly standing up at the United Nations in favor of Taiwan's entry to the international organization.

Speaking on the ROC's aid program to Africa in 1960s when the island was able only to help its African allies with agriculture technology, Lee said Taiwan's development in the last decades enabled it to help its allies in other fields.
He vowed to help Swaziland in its national pursuit of peace, progress and prosperity.
Meanwhile, Mswati expressed thanks for the warm reception he and his entourage has received and pledged to support Taipei's bid to boost its profile on the international stage.
The king arrived in Taiwan for an official visit on Thursday and is slated to leave on Tuesday. This is his fifth trip to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Prosecution authorities applied for detaining Tong Lung Industrial Metal Chairman Fan Fang-yuan.
The China Times: Israel and the Palestinians reached a deal on the next stage of Middle East peace on Friday.
The United Daily News: Tong Lung Chairman Fan Fang-yuan was taken into custody.
The Liberty Times: US President Bill Clinton helped break a Middle East impasse; Israel and the Palestinians struck a peace deal on Friday.
The Independence Morning Post: Tong Lung Chairman Fan Fang-yuan came forward for prosecution questioning.
The Commons Daily: President Lee Teng-hui said on Friday that engagement across the Taiwan Strait should be based on an equal, democratic footing.
The China Post: Typhoon Babs kills 92 in the Philippines.
The China News: Micron Technology sues Taiwan chip makers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON BABS NOT CERTAIN TO HIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A local meteorologist said on Saturday that it will not become clear until Monday whether the typhoon, which has killed 86 people in the Philippines, will hit Taiwan.
Chen Lai-fa, director of weather forecasting at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), said that Sunday night will be a key period in the monitoring of typhoon Babs.
However, he warned whether or not Babs hits the island directly, it will definitely bring torrential rain to the north and northeast.

According to a CWB morning report, Babs was centered over the sea 540 kilometers south-southwest of Hengchun, Taiwan's southernmost area, moving in a northwesterly direction at a speed of 11 kilometers per hour.
Babs might move toward either the north or north-northwest in the next few hours, Chen said.
Between Friday midnight and 9 a.m. Saturday, the outer rim of Babs had brought 102 millimeters of rain to Rotung in northeastern Taiwan, the largest recorded effect of the storm.
The downpour will accelerate by Sunday, the CWB warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOCK TYCOON ARRESTED FOR ALLEGED EMBEZZLEMENT

TEXT.P: The board chairman of the Tong Lung Metal Group, Fan Fang-yuan, was arrested on Saturday morning after admitting that some NT$7.7 billion (US$235 million) had disappeared from the group's holdings, according to the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB).

Taipei District Prosecutor Chiang Tong-yuan, who led the MJIB investigation of the Tong Lung crisis, said Fan was taken into police custody because he signed every Tong Lung check for funds which have been relocated, and could not explain where the money had gone.

Concerned that Fan may have colluded with his younger brother Fan Fang-kuei, president of the group, who has disappeared recently, and several company executives close to the two brothers, Prosecutor Chiang ordered Fan's arrest and denied him visitation rights.
Chiang has also issued subpoenas requiring Fan Fang-kuei and three other company executives to appear in court.

Chiang and MJIB agents searched several companies affiliated with the group, as well as the executives' residences, and confiscated several account books. The investigators are seeking to determine whether the company is involved in insider trading or other illegal transactions of its assets.
The Tong Lung Group, one of the largest hardware manufacturers in Taiwan, is the maker of the famous "Lucky" brand locks.

Tong Lung's financial crisis came to light after investors discovered that Tong Lung President Fan had disappeared, along with much of the company's bonds and assets which were under Fan's management.

According to local media reports, Fan, who is an honorary consul of El Salvador, was hiding in the El Salvador Embassy in Taipei to escape arrest, although this was denied by embassy officials, who also denied that Fan enjoys any diplomatic privileges.
Others speculated that Fan has fled to Canada, where his wife and children reside.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMENTS ON HUMAN RIGHTS CONFERENCE IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: A US newspaper staff writer stationed in Beijing has written a column in which he comments on Beijing's first international conference on human rights.

Henry Chu of the Los Angeles Times indicated that the Beijing regime has long held that the most fundamental right is the freedom from want of food and shelter. Political liberties, the argument goes, come afterward.
This reasoning was heard this week from the Beijing delegates, scholars, and government officials, who outnumbered attendees from all other countries combined.

A Western diplomat in Beijing who monitors human rights contrasted the present situation with the hostility three years ago whenever the issue arose. at that time, Beijing cut off all such discussions with US and Western Europe, which together proposed official condemnation of Beijing's human rights record at the United Nations in Geneva.
Last year, the communist regime revived the discussions with European nations -- though not with the US -- and raised hopes that the tension might at last be melting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR WARNS AGAINST BEIJING'S ATTEMPT TO MILK KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Beijing is trying to get the maximum propaganda mileage from its just-resumed contacts with Taiwan, in order to dilute its image on the international stage as hostile toward the island, a local scholar warned on Friday.

In a seminar on the impact of the meeting between Taipei's top negotiator with mainland China Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan, Chiu Chao-lin, a researcher at the Academia Sinica, said that although Taipei has pulled its own weight in organizing the meeting, Beijing is trying to snatch all of the credit, misleading the world into believing that it made greater concessions to accommodate Taiwan.

Alerting the ROC government to Beijing's attempt to put its own spin on the Koo-Wang meeting, Chiu said that Beijing may try to dissuade Taiwan's major supporter in the world, the United States, from selling arms to Taiwan by creating a false perception of rapprochement brought about by the meeting.

She also warned that Taiwan will back itself into a corner if it resists political dialogue with Beijing, because that will give the international community an impression of stubbornness which will make it difficult to win allies' endorsement. She pointed out, however, that political dialogue does not necessarily mean talks on reunification.
Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said at the seminar that economics is still an important factor that glues the two sides together despite their political rivalry.
Although cross-strait trade has slowed recently, Wu pointed out that Taiwan pumped US$16.3 billion-worth of investment into mainland China in the first eight months of this year.

In addition to the political disputes which strain bilateral ties, mainland China's stalling on reform of state enterprises, rising unemployment, and the absence of investment protection, have also raised concern among Taiwan investors in mainland China, said Wu.

Wang Ming-yi, a political reporter for the China Times newspaper, described the Koo-Wang meeting as the beginning of a political dialogue between Taipei and Beijing, and said it represents a bold step which marks Taiwan's new self-confidence.

He predicted that Beijing will not halt its attempt to isolate Taiwan from the rest of the international community, since diplomatic competition has become a traditional part of the contest between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER OF S. AFRICA NATIONAL ASSEMBLY VISITS BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Speaker of South Africa's National Assembly, Ms. Frene Ginwala, arrived in Beijing on Thursday for a weeklong visit to mainland China, according to the South African Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
In a statement issued on Friday, the ministry said that since her arrival, Ginwala has met with President Jiang Zemin and other high-ranking mainland Chinese leaders.
The statement said that during the meetings, Ginwala stressed the importance of forging a constructive partnership that will give attention to the problems of developing countries.
She focused on opportunities for mainland investment in South Africa, particularly in the fields of industry and agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOUGHER RULES ON GAS SULFUR URGED IN CANADA

TEXT.P: The Canadian government on Friday pledged to cut sulfur levels in gasoline by about 90 percent by the year 2005, but environmentalists are not satisfied.

The Friends of the Earth (FOE) criticized the minister for hitting the sulfur target "in slow motion." "Canadians will have to suffer through extra summers of bad air before we see results," said Beatrice Olivastri, chief executive officer of the FOE. Olivastri and other greens want the government to reach the target in three years.
Stewart acknowledged that action had to be taken to reduce air pollution, which is believed to contribute to respiratory problems for many Canadians.
Prices at the pump will rise only about one cent per liter because of the changes, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PATENT APPLICATIONS IN US SURPASS THOSE OF JAPAN, GERMANY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan submitted more than 6,400 patent applications to the US authorities last year, third-highest among the countries and areas which applied for US patents in 1997, according to statistics of the US Department of Commerce (DOC).

In 1997, the number of patent applications in the United States broke the 230,000 mark, a new high. In terms of foreign applications, those from Japan made up the bulk, followed by Germany, Taiwan, France, and Britain.
According to the statistics, the DOC issued more than 124,000 patents last year, up 1.9 percent from the previous year. Of these, 54,000 were obtained by foreign applicants.
Taiwan was granted 2,597 patents last year, up 178 from the previous year. The figure accounted for 2.1 percent of foreign applications.
The official tallies also show that in 1997, mainland China submitted 215 patent applications in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA CUTS SULFUR LEVEL IN GASOLINE

TEXT.P: Canada's Environment Minister Christine Stewart was scheduled to announce on Friday a dramatic reduction in the level of sulfur in gasoline.
The amount of sulfur in a liter of Canadian gasoline varies from 540 parts per million (ppm) in Ontario to 200 ppm on the prairies.
Ontario government sources said Stewart would announce a cut in the sulfur content to 150 ppm by the year 2002.

However, environmental groups want sulfur content cut to 30 ppm in three years. Sulfur is a major component of smog. They cite studies that conclude that smog induces lung diseases which are killing hundreds of Canadians a year and that smog has led to a growing number of people suffering from asthma.

On Oct. 19, Canada's federal, provincial, and territorial energy and environment ministers meeting in Halifax achieved significant progress in their fight against air pollution by signing the Canada-Wide Acid Rain Strategy for Post-2000.

Last June, Canada signed agreements with European countries, the United States, and countries of the former Soviet Union, committing to reduce atmospheric emissions of 16 Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) and three heavy metals (lead, mercury, and cadmium).

The POPs and Heavy Metals Protocols are the first major multinational, legally binding agreements to place controls on emissions of the hazardous air pollutants which particularly affect northern Canadians.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ASKED TO REDUCE IMPORT DUTIES ON THAI SHRIMPS

TEXT.P: Thailand has asked Beijing to reduce import duties of 70 percent on Thai shrimp, but Beijing refuses to talk with the Thai side, Thai official sources said on Thursday.
Mainland China was once the world's biggest shrimp-farming nation, but activities dropped off, and in 1992, it began importing shrimp to meet local demand.
Mainland China now imports 40,000 tons of shrimp per year, half of it from Thailand, accounting for 10 percent of all Thai shrimp exports.
Meanwhile, exports of frozen Thai shrimp to the European Union could fall by as much as 40 percent from last year's level if preferential tariffs are withdrawn, a Thai official said.
He said that the EU's plans to raise tariffs from January 1 would have a serious impact on Thai agricultural exports, particularly frozen shrimp.
Next year, the EU will tax fresh shrimp at 14.4 percent, compared with the current 9.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA EXPECTED TO WIN TRAVEL STATUS FROM BEIJING

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to win travel destination status from mainland China, following 11 months of tortuous negotiations between the two nations.

The Australian Financial Review on Saturday quoted a spokesman for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade as saying that Australia and mainland China are soon to sign a bilateral agreement under which mainland Chinese tourists will be permitted by Beijing to visit Australia.
It is understood that New Zealand would also win the same status.

Mainland Chinese tourists are not allowed to travel abroad freely, but can only travel to countries approved by their government. The United States and Canada are also negotiating their travel designation with the mainland authorities.
The Australian tourism industry is reeling from the impact of the economic crisis in Asia, and the new agreement will be a welcome shot in the arm.
The spokesman said that, barring unforeseen problems, the agreement should be finalized by early November.

DOC.HEADLINE: OBESE AUSTRALIANS AT RISK OF HEART DISEASE, DIABETES

TEXT.P: More than 50 percent of all adult Australians are overweight, and doctors are worried that these obese people are at risk of obesity-related afflictions such as heart disease and diabetes.
The figure represents a startling 30 percent increase in the number of Australians whose weight constitutes a potential health risk, according to the Australian Society of Obesity.
Associate Professor Lesley Campbell, president of the society, said Australia is on a par with the notoriously overweight United States, and attributed the obesity to inactivity rather than diet.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM DECLARES WAR ON DRUGS

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard has declared war on drugs, vowing he will have "zero tolerance" for drugs in Australian schools.
He said his government will give the war on drugs a top priority, and said he is personally determined to combat the "human misery."
Howard's declaration followed a series of high-profile drug raids by Australian police.
Australia has become a dumping ground for smuggled drugs due to lax regulations on drug users, and hundreds of young Australians die of drugs every year, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITIAN FOREIGN MINISTER REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO ROC

TEXT.P: Haitian Foreign Minister Fritz Lonchamps on Saturday telephoned his Republic of China counterpart Jason Hu to clarify speculation about his country's engagement with mainland China.
Lonchamps was quoted as having assured Hu of Haiti's firm commitment to the ROC and its support for Taiwan's bid to rejoin the United Nations.
The Haitian foreign minister also briefed Hu on a recent trip to Haiti by mainland Chinese Ambassador to the United Nations Qin Huasun.
Lonchamps said Qin visited Haiti from Oct. 19 through Oct. 21 in his capacity as mainland China's permanent representative to the United Nations.

During his stay in Haiti, Qin inspected the UN peacekeeping corps which is operating there. Mainland China once threatened to veto the proposal to dispatch the peacekeeping force to Haiti simply because Haiti maintains formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.
Lonchamps assured Hu that Haiti will maintain only commercial ties with mainland China. "This stance will not change," he was quoted as saying.
He also invited his ROC counterpart to visit Haiti. Hu reportedly accepted the invitation, and promised to try his best to make the trip early next year.
Lonchamps said the Haitian government has formally expressed its views on the relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait at the UN General Assembly session.
At this year's UN General Assembly debate session, Lonchamps voiced explicit support for the ROC's UN bid. Meanwhile, Haitian President Rene Preval made a state visit to the ROC in April this year.

Foreign Ministry officials said relations between the ROC and Haiti have been cordial, and pointed out that the two countries forged scores of cooperative agreements during Preval's visit, all of which have been proceeding smoothly.
The officials stressed that they see no signs to support some media reports that ROC-Haiti relations are facing a crisis.

With its status as a permanent member of the UN Security Council, mainland China managed to tempt Saint Lucia, the Bahamas and several other ROC allies to switch diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.

Although Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Koo Chen-fu, made a goodwill visit to mainland China earlier this month to forge cross-strait rapprochement, Beijing has not eased its diplomatic offensive against Taiwan. On the contrary, Beijing has stepped up efforts to lobby the ROC's 27 diplomatic allies to switch diplomatic recognition. Panama, Costa Rica and Haiti are all Beijing's priority targets.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAM DUMPING CHARGES WILL NOT BE DISCUSSED AT TIFA MEETING

TEXT.P: The issue of dumping charges against Taiwan DRAM makers will not be on the agenda of forthcoming consultations between Taiwan and the United States on the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA), US sources said on Friday.

Officials from the US Trade Representative (USTR) Office said no officials from the federal International Trade Commission (ITC) or the Department of Commerce in charge of dumping and related affairs will be present at the upcoming TIFA meeting slated for Oct. 26-29 in Washington.
It would in any case be inappropriate for the TIFA meeting to discuss an isolated anti-dumping-charge case filed by a single company, USTR officials said.

The Taipei delegation to the TIFA meeting has not asked that an anti-dumping charge filed by US maker Micron Technology Inc. against Taiwan makers be brought up at the meeting, ROC liaison officials in Washington said.

Micro Technology Inc., the world's largest DRAM manufacturer which accounts for 50 percent of total annual US DRAM production, filed a petition with the US federal ITC and the Department of Commerce on Thursday, asking the US government to levy anti-dumping taxes on Taiwan-made DRAMs.
The US giant accused nine Taiwan DRAM manufacturers and four chip designing companies of exporting their products to the United States at prices below fair market value or production costs.

Taiwan will raise at least seven major issues during the TIFA meeting, including seeking US support for its bid to join the World Customs Organization; trying to persuade the US to sign an agreement on customs affairs cooperation with Taiwan; and asking Washington to review related polices so that Taiwan can be removed from its Special 301 watch list of countries with unfair trade practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR TO RETURN FROM CABEI MEETING IN ARGENTINA
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Raymond Huang & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The ROC's Central Bank of China (CBC) governor attended the 38th annual meeting of the Central American Bank for Economic Integration (CABEI) on Friday and is due to return from Buenos Aires, Argentina on Saturday.

As the head of the ROC delegation, Perng Fai-nan, who was accompanied by ROC Representative in Argentina Larry Y.Y. Wang, visited the governor and deputy governor of the Central Bank of Argentina. They exchanged opinions on financial systems, banking experiences of both countries and views on world economic situation.

On Thursday, the governor of CABEI hosted a banquet welcoming delegates from the nine-member countries to the annual meeting. Taipei's excellent performance in handling the region's financial turmoil was highly praised at the gathering.

CABEI headquarters are located in Tegucigalpa, capital of the Republic of Honduras. Its founding members are Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Costa Rica while the Republic of China, Argentina, Mexico and Colombia are member-countries outside of region.
CABEI has contributed substantially to the economic construction of Central America since it founded in 1960.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS PEOPLE SUPPORT LEE-JIANG MEETING: POLL

TEXT.P: Over half of Taiwan nationals who conduct business in mainland China are eager to see an early meeting between the top leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Saturday.

The survey was conducted by Lai Shih-pao, a New Party candidate for the year-end Legislative Yuan elections, from Oct. 14-20. The results were based on 104 valid replies from 1,150 questionnaires sent out. Lai attributed the low return rate to difficulty in contacting Taiwan business people on the mainland and their reluctance to media exposure.

Over 56 percent of the respondents said they believed a meeting between ROC President Lee Teng-hui and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin would help boost cross-strait trade and economic cooperation.

Asked about their opinion on the government's current cross-strait economic policy, 51 percent gave a thumbs-up to the government's "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China while 46 percent were opposed to such a policy.
Nevertheless, 62 percent said they felt the "go slow, be patient" policy should be adjusted.

As for problems facing Taiwan business people on the mainland, 76 percent said they are troubled by mainland China's constant tax probes; 65 percent said their factories were once forced to suspend operations because of such tax probes; and 23 percent said mainland authorities once confiscated their production contracts simply because of alleged tax evasion.

According to the survey, 51 percent said they have encountered intentional tax probes by mainland tax officers and 53.8 percent said they felt anxiety over mainland China's forceful and often unreasonable tax probes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER GERMAN CHANCELLOR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is scheduled to visit Taiwan on Oct. 30.

Schmidt, who was in power of West Germany from 1974 to 1982, has been invited by the China Times Cultural and Educational Foundation and the New Environment Foundation for a five-day visit and to deliver three speeches.

Schmidt will make his first speech in Taiwan on Nov. 2 to talk about his experience in administration, while his second speech on Germany's economic and technology development will be delivered later in the day, according to the sponsors.
The third speech is scheduled for Nov. 3 and will cover the European currencies alliance and impact of the Asian economic development.

The German scholar who became co-publisher and editorial writer for the widely-circulated weekly magazine Die Zeit after leaving politics, will also be invited to talk with local university and college student representatives on the challenges of the coming 21st century.
Schmidt was known for his skillful management of economic affairs as chancellor, and was a key advocator of economic cooperation among Western European countries.

His visit to Taiwan is regarded as an opportunity for the island to learn from the German experience in promoting political, economic and technologic development, as well the European nation's efforts in environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAYORAL CANDIDATE QUESTIONS LAGGING OF DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang candidate for Taipei mayor Ma Ying-jeou accused incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of being "all talk, and little action" in terms of urban development in Taiwan's capital city.

During a television debate involving Ma, the Democratic Progressive Party's Chen, and the New Party's Wang Chien-hsien, Ma targeted urban renewal projects in older communities as an example. He noted that of the 160 planned projects, Chen's administration has completed only seven in the last four years.

If elected mayor, Ma said he would make old-community renewal projects a central theme in his urban development plans, giving new life to less-developed old communities, particularly areas adjacent to the Taipei Railway Station.
He also said he would turn the suburban Neihu and Nankang areas into Taipei's "Silicon Valley," making it a new industrial hub with clean manufacturing.
Non-performance public lands would be released to be used as locations for public retirement homes or places for community activities, Ma added.

For his part, Mayor Chen Shui-bian highlighted his blueprint plans to develop Taipei into a multi-core international city. Chen said a plan to develop old communities was passed two days ago by the Taipei City Council.

As long as another city-wide development plan was passed, the number of residential units around the city are expected to be increase three-fold, he added. Top features of the plan include the development of five sub-metropolitan hubs and the renewal development of the traditional Wanhua District.
Wang Chien-hsien, the New Party candidate who is running a distant third in the polls, was nonetheless a formidable performer in the television debate.
He said he was against the idea of overturning all development projects which have been laid out by the current administration.
"As long as the development projects are viable and meant to take care of the interests of all of the city residents, I will follow suit if I am elected," he noted.
Saturday's TV debate was the first of five similar debates to be held in the next 41 days before Taipei residents go to the poll on Dec. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA ATTACKS CHEN FOR LACK OF VISION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang candidate for Taipei city mayor Ma Ying-jeou promised on Saturday to make Taipei a world-class city by improving the standard of living of city residents if elected.

In the first live broadcast public debate among the three mayoral candidates, Ma criticized incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian for preferring a short-run, "show-off" agenda to a long-term and far-reaching program.
After four years under Chen's administration, Taipei is still a regional city rather than an international one, Ma said.

Citing surveys by publications such as Hong Kong-based Asiaweek and the local monthly Commonwealth, Ma said Taipei lags behind other cities in both the world and Taiwan in terms of traffic, security and the environment.
Ma went on to blast Chen for a lack of vision in governing the city and for cutting corners in enforcing the law. This has often resulted in lawsuits over the infringement of civil rights, he added.

Ma described Chen's policy as an ill-thought out patchwork designed to earn votes instead of benefiting the public. He urged voters to elect him, a candidate with the capability and willingness, to lead the city into the next century.

The debate began at 1:00 p.m. and ended at 3:40 p.m. It was the first of five televised debates planned for the run-up to the Dec. 5 elections. Another debate which includes all three candidates will be featured as well as three debates in which each candidate faces off against one other candidate.
Each candidate was given 10 minutes to present their campaign platform then they fielded questions from three journalists.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang praised Ma's performance in the debate as the best of the three after the encounter.
Chang said he was initially worried that Ma would encounter difficulty as he was unfamiliar with city issues, but Ma's articulate speech and aggressive style proved that the concern was unwarranted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES MAINLAND CHINA'S PLANS TO POST REPORTERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Saturday it welcomes mainland China's plans to post journalists in Taiwan for long-term news coverage.

The Cabinet-level council was responding to a newspaper report that said Beijing plans to allow state-owned news media, including Xinhua News Agency, the People's Daily and China Central Television Station, to post resident correspondents in Taiwan.

"We would be delighted to see such a plan become a reality," MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh said, adding he hopes mainland China will cooperate with Taiwan in promoting normalized bilateral information and news exchanges.
Chang said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has long planned to allow mainland media professionals to cover news in Taiwan on a long-term basis.

"As mainland China has never shown a positive attitude toward regular cross-strait news exchanges, the idea has remained on the drawing board," the nation's top mainland policy planner said. "We hope mainland authorities will come up with more detailed measures for our reference."
Local news reports also said mainland China will allow Taiwan media to post resident journalists on the mainland for news coverage when relations across the Taiwan Strait make substantive progress.

In response, Chang said he sees no need for the mainland to set such a precondition. He stressed that Taiwan has adopted an open-minded attitude toward cross-strait news exchanges. "We only hope that cross-strait news exchanges can be conducted on a reciprocal basis."

Chang further said Taiwan has never banned mainland reporters from applying to cover news on the island, adding that mainland journalists are welcome to cover the island's three critical elections scheduled for Dec. 5. -- voters around the island will vote for legislators while those in Taipei and Kaohsiung will elect a mayor and city council.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR CANDIDATES ZONE IN ON TAIPEI'S TRAFFIC IN DEBATE

TEXT.P: Taipei's traffic was the hot issue in the first mayoral debate on Saturday, with all three hopefuls presenting their ideas to solve the city's traffic problems.
New Party candidate Wang Chien-shien, favored the use of mass transit vehicles on chessboard-like routes to ease the jammed traffic in Taipei.

Double-decker buses can carry over 80 passengers while private cars within the city carry an average of only 1.5 passengers, he noted. Wang also proposed levying an extra tax on private cars to finance city bus systems which would deter private car use and encourage public transportation.
Ma Ying-jeou, who is running on the Kuomintang's ticket, promised to combine city bus and mass rapid transit system fares and fix the prices at NT$15 for at least eight years.
Ma balked at Wang's idea of curbing the number of private cars through tax.
Incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian noted the success of the buses-only lanes around the city and promised to open one mass rapid transit line a year until 2000.
He questioned Ma's proposal of freezing the city bus fare at NT$15 for eight years saying it would require substantial government subsidies and drain the city's coffers.
Meanwhile, New Party campaign manager Jaw Shau-kong lauded Wang's performance in the debate and gave him a score of 95 points compared to the other two candidates who only received 75 points apiece.
Jaw said Wang's humor and fluid delivery vindicated the party's decision to support Wang for the candidacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui said "the spirit of new Taiwanese" would not easily admit defeat and would not fear hardship.
The China Times: Three candidates running in Taipei's mayoral election held their first TV debate Saturday.
The United Daily News: Two policemen were involved in the extortion of an underground gambling operator.
The Liberty Times: Three Taipei mayoral candidates took part in first round of televised public debate.
The Independence Morning Post: Candidates running in Taipei's mayoral election held first TV debate.
The Commons Daily: Three Taipei mayoral candidates held first round of TV debate.
The China Post: First round of mayoral debates held.
The China News: Candidates in Taipei mayoral election battle it out on TV.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO CHEN-FU TO GIVE BENEFIT CHINESE OPERA PERFORMANCE IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation, is scheduled to visit Japan next month to give a series of benefit Chinese opera performances.
Koo, a lifelong Chinese opera devotee, will perform to raise money to establish scholarships to encourage young men in Taiwan to go to Japan for advanced academic studies.

Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo just concluded a visit to the mainland. He was invited there by his cross-strait counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait Chairman Wang Daohan.
Koo was entertained with Chinese opera performances during his mainland visit, and he also sang parts of the operas during the performances.

Worried that so many young men in Taiwan have gone to the United States for advanced academic studies in recent years, Koo believes it is important that there be more exchanges with Japan, which is closer to Taiwan geographically, sources said.

Koo's daughter, Koo Huai-chun, who is an executive official with Koo's cultural and educational foundation, said that about 70 performers and stage workers, including her father and famous Chinese opera actor Lee Pao-chun, will travel to Japan Nov. 1.
Koo will give three performances Nov. 2-4 at the Tokyo International Convention Center, opposite the Tokyo Railway Station.
It is understood that 90 percent of the tickets for the performances have already been sold. The proceeds will go to the establishment of scholarships to encourage Taiwan students to study in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY SAYS LITTLE REGARDING TONGA TIES

TEXT.P: The ROC Foreign Ministry said little regarding the country's ties with the Kingdom of Tonga on Sunday, except that the situation is under control.

Roy Wu, spokesman for the ministry, neither confirmed nor denied local media reports that there will be changes in relations between the two countries. He stressed that the Foreign Ministry has done "everything it should" to cement its ties with the South Pacific island nation.

Although Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, returned from a landmark visit there last week, Wu said, Beijing has never relaxed its attempts to bully Taipei in the international community.

Beijing has claimed that it will lure away all of Taipei's 27 diplomatic partners before the end of this century and has spared no efforts to undermine Taipei's relations with its diplomatic allies, he said, pointing out that Beijing has launched a diplomatic offensive to court several of the ROC's diplomatic partners in Latin America.

Beijing tried to entice Costa Rica early this year by purchasing its bananas at prices several times higher than their market value. Meanwhile, Qin Huasun, mainland China's permanent envoy to the United Nations, paid a visit to Haiti recently.

Although the two countries have explained to the ROC government that the scope of their engagement with the mainland was limited to business, Wu said the government must pay more attention to Beijing's attempts to cut Taipei's ties with its diplomatic allies.
Foreign Minister Jason Hu promised to visit Haiti early next year after receiving an invitation from his Haitian counterpart, Fritz Lonchamps, on Saturday.
Lonchamps telephoned Hu to explain that Qin visited Haiti from Oct. 19 to 21 mainly to inspect a UN peacekeeping force operating there.
Beijing had threatened to veto a plan by the United Nations to send peacekeeping forces to Haiti because the Caribbean nation maintains formal diplomatic ties with Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL WARNS AGAINST BEIJING'S 'DOUBLE-DEALING'

TEXT.P: If mainland China continues to squeeze Taiwan diplomatically, it will only drive Taiwan further away from the mainland, a government official in charge of mainland policy said on Sunday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks as the results of a public poll on "democratization in the mainland and cross-strait relations" were unveiled Sunday.

Lin noted that the poll showed that 82.7 percent of Taiwan people disagreed with mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen's remarks that the squeezing of Taiwan diplomatically is a "global trend." Qian, a former mainland foreign minister, made the remarks when he met with Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, in Beijing earlier this month.
Lin said that if Beijing really wants to understand the feelings of the Taiwan people and to win their favor, it must review its attempts to isolate Taiwan in the international community.

Otherwise, Lin said, Beijing's double-dealing -- simultaneously seeking to advance cross-strait relations and isolate Taiwan internationally -- will only distance Taiwan from the mainland even further.

Lin also noted that nearly 80 percent of the public believes it is necessary for Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan before the so-called "three links" -- direct trade, postal and transportation links -- with the mainland can be established. Lin said that the results concur with those from past polls conducted by MAC, showing that national security is the top concern of the people of Taiwan in regard to the three links.

Yen Wan-chin, director of the Department of Chinese Affairs of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), commented on another poll finding: 70 percent of respondents said that even if both sides of the Taiwan Strait reach a peace agreement, they do not believe Beijing would abide by the agreement.

Yen said that with the majority of the public distrustful of Beijing, and in light of the fact that the differences across the Taiwan Strait cannot be resolved in a short period of time, there is a need for continued cross-strait dialogue. The DPP, he added, would like to take an active part in that dialogue.
Mainland China's "one China" principle has become a wedge to isolate Taiwan internationally, he said, adding that it has become the source of tensions across the Taiwan Strait.
Yen stressed that, in the future, differences over "one China" will make it more difficult for Taiwan to gain international understanding and support.
Exchanges between Taipei and Beijing will require the participation of the DPP, he said, reaffirming five party principles in dealing with Beijing.

Those principles state that the two sides are independent of each other; public opinion in Taiwan will be the basis for dialogue with the mainland; Taiwan will use its democratic and policy-making experience to counter Beijing's unification campaign; Taiwan will seek international cooperation projects to break away isolation; and it will stress the need for the proper handling of cases involving the rights and interests of Taiwan people in the mainland.
Among the other major findings in the poll, conducted by the Public Administration Society of the ROC, were:

-- Sixty-six percent said they were satisfied with the performance of Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, during his recent mainland visit, while 9.5 percent said they were dissatisfied;
-- Forty-six percent said that Koo's delegation was "too accommodating," while 3.3 percent said it was "too tough" and 31 percent said it acted "appropriately"; and
-- Sixty-six percent said that the mainland has to undergo democratization before both sides could talk about unification, while only 25 percent said they did not agree.

The survey was conducted between Oct. 21 and 23 by telephone, and responses were obtained from ROC citizens aged 20 or older. Some 1,070 effective responses were obtained, and the poll's margin of error was 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S DOUBLE-HANDED APPROACH MAY HURT BILATERAL TIES

TEXT.P: Mainland China's double-handed diplomatic approach toward Taiwan may eventually hurt the development of bilateral ties, a ranking official with the ruling Kuomintang warned on Sunday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Research Department, made the remarks while answering questions from reporters about local media reports that the Kingdom of Tonga may shift diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Beijing's diplomatic strategy toward Taiwan, masterminded by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen, seeks to block the island in the international community. It has negatively affected bilateral exchanges and is likely to damage the future of two-way ties, Chang pointed out.
He said Beijing's continued bullying of Taiwan may eventually destroy bilateral relations, adding that such a result is one mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin does not wish to see.

Chang, a member of the Taiwan delegation that accompanied Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, on a historic trip to the mainland last week, was also present during the Koo-Jiang meeting last Sunday in Beijing.

Rejecting Qian's recent remarks that Taiwan's narrowed international space is a result of international trends, the mainland affairs expert claimed that the development is the result of Beijing's attempts to isolate Taiwan.

"Taiwan's democratization has won widespread recognition in the international community. But its squeezed international presence is effectively a result of Beijing's persistent efforts to block Taiwan," he said.

Expressing his hope that mainland China's democratization will help stabilize cross-strait ties, Chang contended that only a fully democratic mainland China would honor a peace agreement with Taiwan if the two sides were to ink such an accord.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHTS VISIT MA CAMPAIGN HEADQUARTERS TO SHOW SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Several heavyweights of the ruling Kuomintang, including President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan, went to the campaign headquarters of KMT Taipei mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday to drum up support for him.

More than 3,000 supporters, braving the winds and heavy rains approaching Typhoon Babs is visiting upon the island, gathered at 9 a.m. at Ma's campaign headquarters, located near the intersection of Hsinsheng South Road and Hsinyi Road.
President Lee, in his capacity as KMT chairman, expressed his appreciation of the enthusiasm of Ma's supporters and appealed personally for support for Ma.

Lee said wars of words tend to erupt whenever elections take place, but he added that the race is for Taiwan mayor, not ROC president, and that "there is no use" in discussing issues not related to the city.
Lee, who himself once severed as Taipei mayor, said that he knows best what a mayor of Taipei must do and what kind of man will best serve the interests of Taipei city.
Lee's remarks drew cheers and big applause from Ma's supporters.
Lee, clasping the hands of both Ma and Lien, said action speaks louder than words, dismissing rumors that his support for Ma was not wholehearted.

Lien criticized the lack of public construction and a dearth of space for public activities in Taipei city. He also lauded Ma as a man with vision and the one best poised to turn Taipei into a metropolis.

Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and his wife, Chen Wan-shui, visited Ma's headquarters ahead of Lee and Lien. Soong stayed briefly before leaving for the provincial government's Chunghsing New Village, where he presided over festivities marking Restoration Day, the day on which Japan's occupation of Taiwan ended.

The KMT has shown solidarity amid a tight race for Taipei mayor. KMT Secretary-General John Chang, Ma's Campaign Manager Wu Poh-hsiung, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu all came to Ma's headquarters Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S POLICY COULD DAMAGE CROSS-STRAIT TIES: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The diplomatic policy of mainland China to isolate Taiwan from the international community, masterminded by Vice Premier Qian Qichen, may damage the development of cross-strait relations, a high-ranking Kuomintang official said here Sunday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the Department of Mainland Research of the ruling KMT Central Committee, made the remarks when asked by the press to comment on a news report that Beijing is wooing away the Kingdom of Tonga from Taiwan. The report said Tonga will soon switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. The Ministry of Foreign Ministry neither denied nor confirmed the report Sunday.

Chang, a member of the Taiwan delegation led by chief negotiator Koo Chen-fu to the mainland earlier this month, said he believed mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin would be reluctant to see the damage to cross-strait relations being caused by the diplomatic drive masterminded by Qian. "Jiang and Qian may have different views on it," Chang said.

Jiang and Qian separately received Koo, Chang, and two other members of the Taiwan delegation in Beijing on Oct. 18. During his meeting with the Taiwan delegation members, Qian described Beijing's efforts to "suppress" the diplomatic activities of Taiwan as a "historic trend," and said that "it will continue."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD TAKE PART IN CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUES: YEN

TEXT.P: An official of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday that his party should actively try to participate in the dialogues between Taiwan and mainland China.

Yen Wan-chin, director of the DPP Department of China Affairs, said in a press conference that cross-strait dialogues are important in cultivating mutual trust, and that the DPP should take part in the dialogues.

He pointed out that it will take quite a long time to resolve the basic differences between the two sides. At the present time, the people on Taiwan are distrustful of Beijing. The "one China principle" of Beijing is a stumbling block to the improvement of cross-strait relations, he added.
Yen said that in cross-strait dialogues the DPP will stress "Taiwan and the mainland do not belong to each other," and that the dialogues should be based on the public opinions of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR TOUTS PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT'S ACHIEVEMENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Chunghsing New Village, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Governor James Soong on Sunday stressed the importance of Taiwan Province's achievements to the development of the Republic of China in the past half a century.
Speaking at a ceremony marking Taiwan's Retrocession Day, Soong also lauded the contributions of provincial government employees.
Taiwan was returned to the Republic of China in 1945 after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
Under a newly enacted bill, the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG) will be downsized and made an institution under the administration of the Executive Yuan starting in December.
As the last governor of Taiwan Province, Soong expressed his hope that TPG employees will celebrate this significant day with joy.

"In the 53 years since its restoration," he said, "Taiwan Province has turned prosperous everywhere. Politics have become democratic and have made remarkable achievements and progress, and these achievements are called the 'Taiwan miracle.'"

The governor mentioned the province's outstanding progress in railway and highway construction, as well as developments in the fields of education and medicine. "These achievements are the results of the joint endeavors of the provincial government, the provincial inhabitants and the central government," he said.

Soong borrowed a phrase from a national "Retrocession Day" song -- "Not to forget, but to think always" -- in reminding people not to forget that if there were no Republic of China, there would have been no Taiwan, and vice versa.
Because Taiwan and the Republic of China are intertwined, the TPG's endeavors and the hardships of its employees should not be forgotten, he said.

The governor quoted a portion of President Lee Teng-hui's Retrocession Day message in which Lee said the people of Taiwan must have the will to pursue democracy and liberty, to resist Communist rule and to dedicate their love to their families and the country.
The Retrocession Day ceremony, presided over by Soong, was held at Chunghsing Hall in Chunghsing New Village.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY MEETS WITH OVERSEAS CHINESE IN FRANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Tseng Wen-fui, first lady of the Republic of China, met with overseas Chinese residing in France and relayed President Lee Teng-hui's concern for them.

Accompanied by Lin Cheng-chih, chairperson of the ROC's Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), and Shirley Shaw, wife of Foreign Minister Jason C. Hu, the first lady received overseas Chinese representatives at a tea party held at the Taipei representative office in Paris, the Bureau de Representation de Taipei en France.
Tsai Kuo-tai, president of the Taiwan Businessmen Association in France, said he was deeply impressed by the amiable disposition of the first lady.

Kuo Wei-fan, representative of the office, pointed out that the first lady is visiting France at the invitation of the French side of the joint organizing committee of the ROC-France Cultural Prize. In addition to attending the awards ceremony, she also represented President Lee in viewing ancient Chinese art from Taiwan's National Palace Museum on display at the Grand Palais in Paris.
The ROC-France Cultural Prize, sponsored by CCA, is awarded each year to a French scholar or research institute for outstanding study of and research on Chinese culture.
A native Taiwanese musical group, led by the first lady, performed at the Chinese Information and Cultural Center in Paris on Saturday night and attracted an audience of more than 100 people.

Kuo noted that Tseng's private visit to Paris has not only promoted cultural exchange and enhanced substantive relations between the Republic of China and France but also enabled President Lee to convey his regards to both overseas Chinese and the ROC's interests in France.

Tseng and her entourage arrived in Paris on Oct. 20 and presided over the awards ceremony at the Institute de France on the evening of their arrival. After the ceremony, she met with Jean Poncelet, speaker of the French Senate, who asked the first lady to convey his respects to President Lee.

Tseng and her group will leave Paris for Rome on Oct. 26 after touring museums and other places of interest in France. During her stay in Rome, Tseng, on behalf of President Lee, will congratulate Pope John Paul II on his 20th anniversary as pope.
The first lady and her entourage will then proceed to Vienna for a visit. They are scheduled to return to Taipei on Nov. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND'S HOUSING REFORMS ATTRACT SINGAPORE TRADE MISSION

TEXT.P: The Singapore Trade Development Board is organizing a mission next month to explore opportunities offered by mainland China's housing reforms, according to The Straits Times.
Goh Seow Kwang, commercial counselor in the Singapore Embassy, said the eight-day trip, to begin on Nov., 1 would include visits to Beijing and Tianjin, as well as to the province of Shandong.
Speaking at a business luncheon Saturday organized by the Singapore Club in Beijing, he said more than a dozen Singapore companies had signed up for the mission.
The mainland housing sector promises more business opportunities following Premier Zhu Rongji's announcement in March to implement housing reforms nationwide.
The reforms aim to scrap the decades-old allocation system and encourage people to buy their own homes.

The mainland government is banking on housing construction to be an engine of economic growth this year as other sectors of the economy slow down in the wake of the Asian financial crisis and state-sector reforms.
The government plans to pump more than 170 billion yuan (US$17.6 billion) into the construction of 212 million square meters of low-cost housing this year.

Beijing and Tianjin are among the mainland's most populous cities, with more than 10 million residents each, while Shandong is the country's second most heavily populated province, after Henan, and is home to more than 88 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENERGY SECRETARY RICHARDSON TO VISIT TAIWAN IN NOVEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration will dispatch newly-appointed Secretary of Energy Bill Richardson to Taipei in November, according to a reliable source in Washington.
The source said on Saturday that Richardson will attend the annual joint meeting of the ROC-USA and USA-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils.
Richardson would be the first incumbent US Cabinet member to visit Taiwan in four years. In December 1994 then Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visited Taiwan.
The American side had earlier indicated that a Cabinet member from the Clinton administration would be present at the joint meeting, slated to open in Taipei on Nov. 9.
Representative Stephen S.F. Chen of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States said that he was not aware of Richardson's attendance at the meeting.
He told the media that he has not yet received any notice from the American side as to which Cabinet member will attend.
Richardson served as US ambassador to the United Nations until last summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD SKIP THIS YEAR'S APEC SUMMIT MEETING: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The government should consider skipping altogether this year's summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to protest the organization's refusal to allow President Lee Teng-hui to attend the event, said a lawmaker with the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

In a bid to buttress Taiwan's discontent and the country's character, DPP Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung said the government should consider not taking part in this year's APEC summit, slated for November in Malaysia, if Taiwan cannot take part in the gathering on a footing equal to those of other member states.

A Malaysian envoy came to Taiwan on Saturday to extend APEC's invitation to attend the summit, in which Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P. K. Chiang would participate on behalf of President Lee as a result of pressure from Beijing.
Over the past four years, Taiwan has had to dispatch envoys to represent Lee at the annual APEC summits.

Taiwan's inability to be present at this year's meeting on an equal footing with other member states would be a setback for Taiwan in its bid to improve its international standing and could serve as a bad example, one that may hinder Taiwan's efforts to join the United Nations, Chang argued.

Judging from the current situation, it is obvious that many countries, including the United States, Japan and the Philippines will accept only the representation of mainland China, not Taiwan, at international meetings higher in status than ministerial-level, he said.
Chang said Taiwan should prevent this from becoming a model, calling on the government not to send any representative to this year's APEC summit. "This is a question of principle," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU, JAPAN TO MEET REGULARLY TO PREPARE FOR WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: The European Union (EU) and Japan agreed to hold regular meetings on trade before the World Trade Organization (WTO) resumes new global trade liberalization talks in the year 2000, according to reports from the Geneva-based WTO Saturday.
The new multilateral trade talks follow the Uruguay Round talks concluded in April 1994.
The United States hopes the talks will be held on a sector basis, while Japan and the EU want discussions held on a framework basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD DEMONSTRATE SINCERITY: HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Sunday asked Beijing to demonstrate its sincerity by ending its attempts to isolate Taiwan in the international community.
Hu made the remarks in response to media reports that Tonga, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, is to switch official recognition to mainland China soon.
Foreign Ministry Spokesman Roy Wu earlier in the day said his ministry "would neither confirm nor deny the report."

"Didn't they (the mainland) say that cross-strait relations would improve after the meeting between the heads of both sides' intermediary bodies earlier this month? The new development will just allow everyone to see the truth," he said.

Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, visited the mainland Oct. 14-19 to meet his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, a meeting that paved the way for the resumption of cross-strait negotiations after a three-year hiatus. Koo also visited mainland President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen, separately, during his mainland trip.
"It would be totally wrong for those who have, after the Koo-Wang meetings, harbored the illusion of a rapprochement between Taiwan and the mainland," Wu said.
The fact is that Beijing has not shown a trace of sincerity and goodness toward Taipei even after the meetings, an angry Hu said.

Taiwan has accused mainland China of launching a new round of offensives against the island, also known as the "three empties" strategy -- to lure away all of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, to squeeze Taiwan out of all international organizations and to strip Taiwan of its bargaining chips.
Vice Foreign Minster David Lee revealed days ago that Beijing was wooing a diplomatic ally of Taiwan, seeking to have the ally shift formal recognition within two weeks of the Koo-Wang meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Torrential rains flood northern and northeastern Taiwan.
The China Times: The outer fringes of typhoon Babs brought heavy rainfall to northern Taiwan.
The United Daily News: Government employees are excluded from Labor Standard Law coverage.
The Liberty Times: Northern Taiwan was hit by flood; traffic systems damaged.

The Commons Daily: Will ROC ally -- Tonga -- forge diplomatic ties with China today?
