The China News: Tonga reportedly will cut ties with the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ESPOUSES 'HUMANITARIAN CARE' AT APEC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's chief delegate to a recent science and technology ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum espoused the idea of making humanitarian care the core of high-tech development.

Huang Chen-tai, chairman of the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) of the Republic of China, who represented Taiwan at the meeting held last week in Mexico City, said he introduced Taiwan's policy on humanities-centered high-tech development.

Other ministers were apparently impressed by the introduction, and many of them were "stunned" by the fact that Taiwan not only has the idea but has taken concrete measures to implement it, including the creation of measures to help the handicapped develop high technology, Huang said.
During the meeting, Huang pointed out that the progress of the world's science and technology development should be aimed at raising people's standard of living and improving their well-being.

At a time when the 21st century is right around the corner, with humans being the primary rulers of the Earth, people should bear in mind that science and technology development is incomplete without humanitarian care, Huang said during his remarks.
Participants at the APEC meeting unanimously recognized Huang's comments and agreed to include them into the meeting's minutes.

Ministers and top officials in charge of science and technology development from Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States, Russia, Vietnam and Peru took part in the meeting.

According to Huang, Taiwan is highly interested in hosting the next APEC science and technology ministers meeting, scheduled to be held in 2001. During the just-concluded meeting, the issue of the sponsorship of the next meeting was not discussed, he said.
Meeting participants decided only that Mexico will be responsible for conducting a survey on the willingness of member states to sponsor the next meeting, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO HOLD SEMINAR TO DISCUSS COALITION GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning to hold a seminar to discuss the issue of the formation of a coalition government in Taiwan, DPP officials said on Monday.

The officials said that after year-end legislative elections, the political map in Taiwan is bound to change and that the ruling Kuomintang will lose its dominant position as Taiwan moves toward a truly multi-party political system.

They said that the seminar aims to dispel any misgivings the public may have on the possible formation of a coalition government. Such assurances may make the public more willing to vote for DPP candidates, officials said.
The KMT has said that if none of Taiwan's major political parties -- the KMT, the DPP and the New Party -- win more than half the seats being contested, the nation will be plunged into chaos.

The seminar, to be held Nov. 1, will center on three topics: the systems used by those nations that have formed coalition governments and their suitability to Taiwan; the possibility of Taiwan having a coalition government, based on its constitutional system; and the likely political landscape that will emerge after year-end elections.
Most of the seminar participants will be scholars, DPP party officials said.
Chang Chun-hung, campaign manager of the DPP, said the upcoming election will result in an end to the dominance of the KMT.
It is time for the DPP to consider Taiwan's political picture and the development of multi-party politics, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP MAINLAND ENVOY MAY VISIT TAIWAN NEXT MARCH

TEXT.P: Wang Daohan, Beijing's top negotiator with Taipei, may visit Taiwan next March, his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu predicted on Monday.

Koo, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the forecast at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's foreign, interior, transportation and economic affairs committees.

Koo invited Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time when the two elder statesmen met in Shanghai earlier this month.

"I think Wang should be able to visit Taiwan before the end of March next year," Koo told lawmakers, adding that if Wang can smoothly visit Taiwan next March, it will mark yet another big step forward in cross-strait relations.
The composed, soft-spoken billionaire tycoon said he is convinced that a Koo-Wang meeting in Taipei will score even more achievements than their first meeting held in Singapore in April 1993.

Koo said he hopes Wang's Taiwan visit will herald a resumption of regular, systematic consultations between SEF and ARATS -- the two semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official channels.

Turning to his nearly-two-hour meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing on Oct. 18, Koo said Jiang spent much time explaining the democratic development on the mainland as well as experimental democratic elections in Anhui Province in central China.
"In Jiang's opinion, democracy can be implemented only at grassroots levels and the central government must maintain strong leadership," Koo said.

For his part, Koo said he told Jiang that the essence of democracy is party politics. "Therefore, I suggested that the Chinese Communist Party abandon its one-party dictatorship, respect the public opinion and allow its people to make choices at their free will."
Speaking on the same occasion, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh acknowledged the achievements of Koo's Oct. 14-19 mainland visit.
"We appreciate Koo's devoted service and his achievements in reaching a four-point consensus with his mainland counterpart during his landmark trip," said the ROC's chief mainland policy planner.

The four-point deal included that ARATS Chairman Wang agrees to visit Taiwan at a proper time; SEF and ARATS will gradually resume dialogue, reinforce bilateral exchanges at various levels, and strengthen mutual assistance in handling incidents involving the lives and property of Taiwan people visiting the mainland and vice versa.

Chang said the Cabinet-level MAC, which oversees SEF's operations, set three goals for Koo's ice-melting mainland visit -- pushing for an early resumption of regular SEF-ARATS dialogue and exchanges; fostering an amiable atmosphere to facilitate improvement of cross-strait relations; and publicizing Taiwan's basic platform and its developmental experience to help promote mainland China's democratization.

During his mainland visit, Koo managed to exchange views directly and frankly with senior mainland leaders, clearly explain the ROC's basic stance on some critical issues and introduce Taiwan's achievements in political democratization and present concrete steps for the resumption of regular dialogue and future cross-strait cooperation.

"We think Koo's mainland visit has largely accomplished our original goals," Chang said, adding that the visit has laid a foundation for the restoration of cross-strait communications channels and the opening of cross-strait constructive dialogue.

Nevertheless, Chang said it is regrettable that mainland China has not made any positive response to some of Koo's valuable suggestions, such as immediate opening of talks on several critical issues related to the legitimate rights and interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait; promoting grassroots democratic exchanges, agricultural cooperation; and strengthening cross-strait cooperation in regional affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS NOT FULLY REFLECTED YET IN TAIWAN: THINK-TANK

TEXT.P: If Taiwan appears to have escaped the region's economic crisis -- as many government officials have claimed -- it is only because the full impact of the crisis on the island has not been seen yet, the head of a private economic think-tank said Monday.

Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), said how deeply Taiwan's industrial sector has been affected by the Asian economic crisis will be revealed in the next six months. The number of domestic manufacturing plant closings has hit a record high, he said, as more checks are bouncing and more bankruptcies are being reported.

Citing government statistics, Wu said Taiwan's foreign trade has borne the full brunt of Asia's economic woes. In September the island's exports were down 12.4 percent from year-earlier levels, he said. Exports to Southeast Asia were down sharply, and even those to the United States declined 1.8 percent in September from year-earlier levels.

As for imports, the only sector to register an increase was capital equipment, which rose a year-on-year 14.9 percent in September. Imports of consumer goods and agricultural products fell a combined 13.7 percent to US$8.41 billion, Wu quoted government statistics as indicating.

Wu predicted Taiwan's trade sector will remain in the doldrums in the first second half of 1999 as economic growth in both Europe and the United States is expected to slow. Asian economies, meanwhile, are not expected to recover in the short term, he said.
He said that unless the government can spur demand, domestic growth will stagnate, at least until the second quarter of 1999.
Meanwhile, Tung Ruei-ping, a TIER division chief, forecast that Taiwan's economic growth in 1999 will be no better than in 1998.

An island economy closely linked to international developments, Taiwan cannot expect rosy prospects next year, as economic growth in the United States and Europe is slowing and as Japan's economy begins to sag, Tung said, noting that the US economy is expected to grow by only 2.5 percent in 1999 compared with an expected 3.5 percent this year.

Tung, a monetary expert, said the Central Bank of China should take a hands-off policy toward Taiwan's currency, letting the New Taiwan dollar appreciate unhindered. By doing so, foreign currency holdings will be quickly liquidated and more funds will be released into circulation, driving down interest rates, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN REJECTS BEIJING'S DEMAND FOR CODIFYING '3 NOES': PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Japanese government has rejected a mainland Chinese demand for codifying the so-called "three noes" policy against Taiwan, the Sankei Shimbun reported on Monday.

The Japanese economic daily quoted an unnamed Japanese Foreign Ministry official as saying that Japan will not accept Beijing's request to include the "three noes" into a new joint communique to be issued during mainland President Jiang Zemin's planned visit to Tokyo in late November.

The "three noes" refer to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.

The "three noes" came to the limelight after US President Bill Clinton said in a speech delivered in Shanghai during his high-profile June 25-July 3 mainland visit that the United States will uphold the "three noes" policy.
The Japanese official said since the United States has never enshrined the "three noes" in any official document, Japan will not yield to Beijing's pressure to codify such a policy.

The Sankei Shimbun said mainland China has been pressuring Japan to explicitly throw its support behind the "three noes" policy in the new joint communique to be issued at the end of Jiang's upcoming Tokyo visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WELCOMES INTERIM ISRAEL-PALESTINE PACT

TEXT.P: Australia has welcomed the interim agreement reached between Israeli and Palestinian leaders through the mediation of US President Bill Clinton and Jordan's King Hussein.

"Although this is an interim accord and therefore important steps remain to be taken, it is a crucial milestone on the road to peace," Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said in a statement faxed to CNA Monday morning.
"Indeed, I think it is fair to say that now there is a genuine hope that a just, secure and comprehensive peace in the Middle East is at last within sight," he said.

He said Australia had been increasingly concerned at the lack of progress in the peace process over the past year and at the increasing likelihood that the Middle East will slide back into a climate of mistrust characterized by the rhetoric confrontation.
"This agreement will breathe new life into that process and hopefully rebuild lost confidence on both sides," Downer said.

He said Australia would continue to support efforts to achieve a lasting peace in the Middle East. "We hope, and believe, that today's agreement has made that peace substantially more obtainable," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA'S ECONOMIC PROBLEMS WORRISOME: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: Indonesia is sliding toward social breakdown and any miscalculation, such as postponing general elections in 1999, could plunge the country into chaos, the leader of the world's biggest Islamic group warned.

In an interview with The Sydney Morning Herald's Asia editor, David Jenkins, Abdurrahman Wahid, leader of the 34-million Nahdlatul Ulama, said: "People will take things into their own hands, and there will cease to be viable government in Jakarta. All institutions will lose their meaning, including the army, including the bureaucracy, including Nahdlatul Ulama," he said.
Five months after the resignation of former President Suharto, Indonesians are struggling to cope with a severe economic downturn.

The daily reported the problems have brought Indonesia's industry to a standstill, thrown millions out of work, driven up the price of food and led hungry urban dwellers to attack granaries, rice fields, coffee plantations and chicken farms.
Other Indonesian analysts argue that while there are unmistakable signs of social breakdown it does not follow that the lid is about to blow.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL UNIVERSITY OF SINGAPORE TO REINVENT ITSELF

TEXT.P: In seven years the National University of Singapore at Kent Ridge will be transformed from a traditional place of study into a vibrant university village where undergraduates can shop, dine at an alfresco-style cafe, catch a movie or attend a concert after class.

Under the university's ambitious plans to jazz up campus life, three plots of land will be developed, with the addition of such amenities as cinemas, Borders-style bookstores, a concert hall, cafes, pubs and restaurants, the Straits Times Reported Monday.

The idea is to turn the university into a bustling 24-hour campus where life goes on after office hours. For example, students can go for dinner or catch a movie before returning to campus to use the laboratories at night.
If everything goes according to plan, the campus will be a self-contained village and served by a mini rapid transit system.
Kent Ridge, about 150 hectares in size, has a population of about 30,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA NEEDS IMMIGRATION TO KEEP POPULATION GROWING

TEXT.P: Australia needs a small flow of immigration to keep its population growing because the country's reproduction rate is low at 1.7 per fertile couple, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said.
Without immigration, Australia's current population of about 18.5 million, would begin to contract over time, he added.
"Now, the impact of that with smaller immigration programs, means that Australia in about 30 years time can be expected to have a population of around about 23 million people and stable," he said.
Most Australians would not object to this type of immigration policy because "I don't think that most people would find that an alarming prospect," the minister said.

He defended the government's lower annual immigration of 68,000 since fiscal 1997-98 plus another 12,000 for humanitarian category. The 68,000 intake was much lower than the nearly 100,000 accepted in 1996-97.
Ruddock also said the lower quota was not influenced by One Nation leader Pauline Hanson, who in 1996 demanded that the government cut immigration intake.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DECLINE ON STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but close lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 5.14 points to close at 7,050.32.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,063.44 points, 7.98 higher than Saturday's close, and declined to 7,050.32 at the closing bell.
A total of 2.00 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.38 billion.
Two of the eight major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.

Six other categories registered losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by construction shares at 1 percent, textile issues at 0.9 percent, both cement stocks and plastics and chemical shares at 0.7 percent, and electrical shares at 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were also lower.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for November decreased five points to close at 7,010, with 1,463 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 19 points to finish at 6,981, and March futures dropped 30 points, closing at 6,920. Contract transactions for the two futures totaled 40 and two, respectively.
No transactions were registered for both June and September futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOODY'S TO ISSUE CREDIT RATINGS ON 10 TAIWAN BANKS

TEXT.P: The fundamentals and operations of Taiwan's banks are more healthy than those in other Asian nations, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said.
The CBC made the remarks as officials from Moody's Investors Service arrived in Taiwan to visit 10 domestic banks to access their credit rating.
It is understood that Moody's visit will center on past-due loans and the effect of the region's financial crisis on domestic enterprises.

The past-due loan ratios of domestic banks in the first and second quarters this year stood at 4.16 and 4 percent respectively, or in the range of too high compared with the conventional normal level of 3 percent.

Moody's noted that Taiwan is now facing a sharp decline in its trade surplus, and a slowdown of economic growth. If the New Taiwan dollar continues to depreciate, it will not only undermine the capacity of CBC to intervene in the financial market, but will also be another blow to those beleaguered enterprises that have a high ratio of debts.

The bank rating service also said Taiwan's financial institutions have continued to receive support from the government, adding that it is confident Taiwan, with its low foreign debt and high foreign exchange reserves, is capable of supporting a viable development of its banking system.

Moody's officials will also visit the CBC on Tuesday to gain a better understanding of the economic and financial situation in Taiwan, which they plan to use as reference in delivering the credit rating.
Moody's officials visited three Taiwan provincial government banks -- The Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, and the First Commercial Bank -- on Monday.

They will call on Bank SinoPac, E. Sun Bank, Bank of Overseas Chinese, and United World Chinese Commercial Bank on Tuesday; Bank of Taiwan and Chiao Tung Bank on Wednesday; and The International Commercial Bank of China and Chinatrust Commercial Bank on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH AFRICAN MILITARY ATTACHE MISSES TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By J. H. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former South African military attache to Taiwan McGill Alexander, who along with his family was held at gunpoint by a wanted fugitive last November, said recently in an interview with CNA that he missed Taiwan.
Alexander said he and his family hoped to return to Taiwan sometime to see their old friends.
The Alexanders were hailed for their courage in an ordeal which gripped Taiwan media and audiences as the events played out on live television.

On Nov. 19, 1997, Chen Chin-hsing, who was wanted for the kidnap and murder of the daughter of local celebrity Pai Ping-ping, sneaked into the Alexander residence in suburban Taipei and held the family hostage before surrendering to police.

Col. Alexander retired from his post at the embassy and returned to South Africa early this year. He was stationed in the northern border area of South Africa and was recently transferred to Richmond, a region plagued by political unrest in the eastern region of South Africa to help maintain order.

Alexander, 51, said both he and his eldest daughter Melanie still suffer from pain from the gunshot wounds they received in the incident. Alexander was shot in the leg and he recently underwent surgery to remove blood clot in his leg while Melanie was shot in the back.
Despite the lasting effects of the hostage situation, the Alexanders are celebrating Melanie's impending marriage which is to take place in the United States in December.

Alexander's youngest daughter Christine, whose courage during the 24-hour standoff between Chen and the police was particularly admired by people across the island, also said she wanted to return to Taiwan to see friends and the home they lived in Tienmu.

Alexander, a career soldier who was assigned to the post of military attache of South African Embassy in 1996, said although he and his family had been taken hostage in Taiwan, he thought social order in Taiwan was a hundred times better than that of in South Africa.

He said that during his stay in Taiwan, he traveled around the island, day and night, taking pictures without any fears. But now in South Africa, he is afraid to stop his car while driving, for fear of being robbed.

After the hostage incident, Alexander said he received hundreds of letters of support from friends and strangers alike. He has kept two huge piles of these letters as they offered so much encouragement and comfort that he would treasure them forever.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH MALAWI'S MINISTER OF HEALTH

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China met with Minister of Health of the Republic of Malawi Harry Thomson and his wife on Monday.
President Lee bid a hearty welcome to Thomson and his wife, and exchanged views on cooperation between the two countries.

Lee showed concern over various construction projects in Malawi during the meeting. He said the ROC government is willing to assist the Malawian people in the development of education, medical treatment, agriculture, and irrigation through its own successful experiences in these sectors of development.

The president said he highly appreciated the Malawi government's support for Taipei's bid to enter the United Nations and other international organizations. He also asked the minister of health to convey his best wishes to the president of Malawi.

Minister Thomson thanked the ROC government for its assistance to the Malawian people. He also made note of President Lee's performance and the ROC government's achievements in the political and economic sectors in the past few years.
Thomson noted that the development of the ROC is an excellent example for the Malawian government to follow in the future.

Also at the meeting held at the Presidential Office were Malawi's vice minister of health, Wu Tzu-dan, ROC's vice minister of the ministry of foreign affairs, Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, and Su Chi, deputy secretary-general to the President.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW CALLS EMERGENCY MEETING ON FLOODS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday called an emergency meeting with relevant ministers to work out countermeasures against flooding in Taipei County's Hsichih township and the northern city of Keelung.

Typhoon Babs, the second tropical storm to affect Taiwan in 10 days, brought torrential rains to northern Taiwan over the weekend, submerging Hsichih and many areas of Keelung with flood waters at levels not seen in decades.

Siew, after learning of the disastrous flooding on Sunday, ordered the military, police and fire fighting sectors to stand by to render the quickest and every possible help to neighborhoods and residents in flood-stricken areas.

In Hsichih, a town situated by the Keelung River, people moved around with rubber boats after their ground-floor homes and cars were submerged. Television reporters who were at the scene for live coverage, delivered their reports with only their microphones, heads and chests appearing above water.
Hsichih residents suffered from a serious landslide last year after a hillside residential building collapsed, leaving several dozen residents killed and many families homeless.

Less than 10 days ago, Typhoon Zeb swept through Taiwan with heavy rains and wind. Zeb hit Hsichih with the worst floods seen in the old township where a number of new residential buildings have been developed over the last several years.

After barely finishing cleaning their homes which were either submerged in water or damaged by mudslides, Hsichih residents were battered by Typhoon Babs which brought a second-wave of flooding since late last week.

Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo said there were many reasons behind the heavy flooding in Hsichih. A high-tech investigation is needed to determine which agencies should be held responsible for the unprecedented disaster, he noted.

In Keelung, more than 100 low-lying districts close to the Keelung River were inundated, with Wutu, Liutu, and Chitu being the most seriously affected. Tracks at Wutu Train Station were submerged underwater, forcing the nearby railway service to suspend operations.

In Chitu, an 11-year-old school girl who was reported missing in flood waters mid-Monday was found. As schools closed in the morning due to the floods, all students were sent home. However, the girl went home with a teacher after her parents failed to pick her up at the school. The teacher was unable to contact the girl's family after phone lines were cut by the calamity.

Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan inspected Hsichih Sunday on behalf of Premier Vincent Siew. Liu was earlier stranded in the southern port city of Kaohsiung by Typhoon Babs, said the over-development of residential projects is the culprit of the recent flooding in Hsichih.
Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang on Monday urged the Ministry of the Interior to stop approving development projects up stream from the Keelung River and the adjacent hillside areas.

Su said during 1989 and 1997, the former Magistrate Yu Ching administration approved 1,064 projects of development in hilly areas where previously were prohibited. Of the total, 32 percent or 348 projects were in Hsichi.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR SURGES TO SEVEN-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: Boosted by foreign investors, the New Taiwan dollar climbed to its highest level since March in trading on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, rising NT$0.121 against the greenback to close at NT$32.777.

The rise of the local currency was a result of a weak US dollar which was attributed to the US central bank's interest cut, dealers said, adding that a weak US currency is helping stabilize the Asian financial turbulence.
A further appreciation of the NT dollar is expected, the dealers noted.
The local currency opened at NT$32.891 and fluctuated between NT$32.725 and NT$32.925.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$407 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY TO VISIT HOLY SEE
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Lee-Tseng Wen-hui, wife of President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China, is scheduled to arrive in the Vatican on Monday for a five-day visit.
The Vatican, the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe, is the second leg of the ROC first lady's current European visit.

The ROC Embassy in the Vatican said on Sunday that Mrs. Lee will meet with Pope John Paul II on Thursday. She will, on behalf of President Lee, present felicitations to the pontiff on the 20th anniversary of his coronation, an embassy official said.

During her stay, Mrs. Lee will tour the Vatican Museum, the Sistine Chapel and St. Peter's Basilica, in addition to meeting with Chinese community leaders and representatives of ROC students in Italy.

On Wednesday, a 33-member Taiwan aboriginal choir will sing indigenous tribal songs to pay tribute to the pope in a weekly public papal audience with Catholics from around the world on the St. Peter's Basilica Square.
Mrs. Lee and her entourage are scheduled to leave Rome for Vienna on Friday for a transit stop on their return trip.

Before arriving in the Vatican, Mrs. Lee made a four-day visit to France where she attended a Sino-French Cultural Award presentation ceremony. She also toured the Grand Palais in Paris to view an exhibition of ancient Chinese art treasures on loan from the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei.

Mrs. Lee's current visit marks the first visit to Europe by an ROC first lady in decades. Diplomatic observers said although the trip is of a private nature and focuses on cultural and sightseeing activities, it still carries much significance to Taiwan's efforts to break out of the diplomatic isolation imposed by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONFIDENT OF BIG WIN IN YEAR-END LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: With the successful conclusion of a meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait last week, the ruling Kuomintang is increasingly confident of a decisive win in the year-end legislative elections, political observers said.

Although the elections for mayor in Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two largest cities -- have so far commanded greater public attention, political analysts said the legislative elections slated for Dec. 5 islandwide will be of tremendous significance to the country's development in the new millennium.

The KMT has attached a great deal of importance to the legislative polls early on. President Lee Teng-hui, who is also chairman of the KMT, began campaigning for KMT candidates three months ago in the hope of grabbing an early advantage for the party.

The KMT's dismal showing in last year's elections for city mayors and county and township chiefs served as a warning signal, pushing it to make an all-out effort to defend its seats at the legislature this year, political observers pointed out.
Many people predicted that the KMT might lose its majority at the Legislative Yuan in the coming elections, but the overall situation seems to have turned in its favor a year later, observers said.

Now it is a unified KMT countering a splitting DPP and New Party. The two major opposition parties have both seen their members split or forge new parties over the past several years, while the KMT has seen former members return to their camp.
According to observers, many elements may influence the coming legislative elections.

First, there is an increase of representation in the Legislative Yuan. There will be a total of 225 seats up for grabs this year, up from 165 four years ago. This allows the KMT to field more qualified candidates while opposition parties struggle to present adequate contenders.

Second, there is the so-called "the swing of the pendulum" phenomenon among voters, analysts said. The DPP was the big winner in last year's local government elections, but voters may turn for KMT candidates this year, they noted.
Other external factors, such as the state of cross-strait ties and the country's financial and diplomatic situation, will also play a role in the legislative polls.

The smooth conclusion of a landmark trip to mainland China last week by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, should have injected a boost to the ruling KMT, the analysts said. In contrast, the DPP and the New Party have no bargain chip in this vein to garner votes.

Koo's meetings with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, earlier this month in Beijing and Shanghai were the highest level of contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in nearly 50 years.

According to reliable sources, Koo's meetings with Jiang and Wang have helped stabilize cross-strait relations. Recent surveys indicated that about 40 percent of the people of Taiwan think the KMT is the most capable political party to handle cross-strait affairs, while only 7 percent and 1 percent voiced the same opinion for the DPP and the New Party.
Taiwan's relatively favorable performance amid the Asian financial crisis is another area which the KMT can draw support from, while the opposition lack such resources, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO SUBMIT FLOOD-CONTROL PROJECT IN TWO WEEKS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will meet on Oct. 28 to discuss how to harness the Tamsui River and will submit a flood-control project plan within two weeks, Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang said on Monday.
Chang made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan when answering questions from Legislators Chuan Hsi-chieh and Lin Chung-cheng both from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

After inspecting Hsichih township, which was flooded on Sunday due to heavy rains brought by Typhoon Babs to northern Taiwan over the weekend, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan ordered the MOEA and other related government agencies to submit a project plan to control flooding within two weeks.
Chuan pointed out that the flooding problem in Hsichih has existed for 10 years. He expressed doubt whether the MOEA can solve the problem within two weeks.

Lin, who resides in Hsichih, noted that his home suffered from damage in the flooding. He wanted to know whether the Water Resources Bureau under the MOEA was determined or capable of solving the problem and whether there were any problems in funding.
In response, Chang said both Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming have made site inspections of the damage-stricken Hsichih.
He added that his ministry will obey instructions by Vice Premier Liu, actively study and discuss how best to solve the problem, and submit the project plan within two weeks. (by Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MONITOR OUTPUT RISES BUT PRODUCTION VALUE DROPS

TEXT.P: Taiwan made a total of US$7.9 billion-worth of computer monitors in 1997, making it the world's biggest monitor producer, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Monday.
Citing its latest statistics, the bureau said that Taiwan produced more than 40.7 million monitors last year, accounting for 53.7 percent of the world's production volume in the 12-month period.
From January to June this year, Taiwan's total monitor production volume reached 20.96 million, a 12.9 percent surge compared with the same six-month period of last year.

However, the impact of a strong world trend toward lower-priced computers resulted in a 14.4 percent decline in Taiwan's monitor production value in the first six months of this year against the year-earlier level, with production value totaling US$3.2 billion.

Of the total 20.96 million monitors produced in the six-month period, only 6.46 million units were made on the island, a drop of 25 percent from the same period of last year, with the rest assembled in mainland China and countries in Southeast Asia, Europe, and America, the DGBAS said.

The number of Taiwan monitors assembled in mainland China reached 6.77 million units in the six-month period, a 107.7 percent increase compared with the same period of last year, the DGBAS statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED NOT TO GET INVOLVED IN CONTENTION OF TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu said on Monday his recent remarks about Taiwan's sovereignty were made to remind Japan not to get involved in the cross-strait issue over the island's sovereignty.

During his Oct. 14-19 "ice-melting trip" to the mainland, Koo told Beijing leaders that Taiwan's sovereignty is in the hands of the Republic of China because Japan returned it to the ROC government after World War II in accordance with the 1945 Potsdam Declaration.

Speaking at a joint meeting of four committees of the Legislative Yuan, Koo said he made the statement to let both Beijing and Tokyo understand that Taiwan's sovereignty undoubtedly belongs to the ROC government.

He told the lawmakers that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is scheduled to visit Japan next month which led him to make the remarks to remind the Japanese government to avoid getting tangled in this issue.

Taiwan was ceded to Japan in 1895. In the 1943 Cairo Declaration issued by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, US President Franklin Roosevelt and UK Prime Minister Winston Churchill, the return of Manchuria, Taiwan and the Pescadores was promised to the ROC.

In August 1945, Japan announced its formal surrender to the Allies in accordance with the terms of the Potsdam Declaration of July 1945. Taiwan was returned to the ROC later that year. The People's Republic of China was established four years later in 1949.

Koo said when Japan normalized its diplomatic relations with mainland China in 1972, the Japanese government did not indicate its recognition of Beijing's claim that Taiwan is an inalienable part of the PRC and that the PRC government is the sole legitimate government of China.

Instead, he said, the Japanese government only mentioned that it "respects" and "understands" the Beijing government's stance, and reiterated that it will abide by the eighth article of the 1945 Potsdam Declaration.
Koo pointed out that he raised the Potsdam Declaration during his recent mainland trip because he wanted Japan not to give up its original stance on Taiwan's sovereignty.

Asked whether Japan would accept Beijing's "three noes" policy, the SEF chief said that his personal view was that Japan may agree to only "two noes" -- no support for Taiwan independence and no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan."
He said Japan may not accept the third "no" -- no support for Taiwan membership in international organizations that requires statehood.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN BUSINESS REPRESENTATIVE TO TALK ON BILATERAL TRADE

TEXT.P: Visiting German business representative Michael Fuchs will attend a conference slated for Tuesday in Taipei to talk about Taiwan-Germany economic and trade relations.
Fuchs, who is chairman of a German enterprises council on Taiwan affairs, was invited by the Euro-Asia Trade Organization (EATO) to pay his visit to Taiwan.

He has chaired a German business association for wholesale and foreign trade, and in 1995 served as advisor to The German economics minister. The experience made Fuchs an influence figure in the German economic and political sectors.

At the Tuesday conference, Fuchs will address a number of topics, including how his country has been dealing with the impact of the global financial crisis, and Germany's perspectives in politics and economy in the wake of its September national elections, according to EATO.

Germany is Taiwan's fourth-largest trade partner, and its largest in Europe, with two-way trade reaching US$9.06 billion in 1997, accounting for 22.6 percent of Taiwan's total trade with the European continent, EATO executives said.
As of May, 114 German enterprises have invested a total of US$435 million on the island, while 200 Taiwan businesses have around US$97 million-worth of investments in Germany, according to EATO.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DISSOLVES A GROUP OF INTELLECTUALS

TEXT.P: The Civil Affairs Bureau of Beijing Monday ordered the dissolution of the "China Development Union," an independent organization of intellectuals in Beijing, according to a human rights monitoring group.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that more than 10 public security officers searched the office of the union in Beijing, nabbed three persons in the office, and announced the dissolution of the union Monday morning. The officers said the union was illegal and therefore should be disbanded, because it has not been legally registered in mainland China. The three persons detained were released after three hours of interrogation.

The information center said the aim of the union, which was registered in Hong Kong in August, is to help accelerate the development of mainland China in peaceful ways. It claims to have 4,000 members. The center also said that the union held a national congress in Beijing on Oct. 5, and that it has set up a research office, an organization department, and a publicity department to facilitate its operations. It plans to hold a seminar on "the current situations" every weekend.
The information center said it is doubtful whether Beijing can dissolve the union, because it has been legally registered in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO CONTINUE TO BAN NEW POLITICAL PARTIES: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing will not permit the establishment of new political parties, but will instead encourage the existing eight "democratic parties" to play a more active role, the South China Morning Post reported Monday.
The report said all of the eight "democratic parties" accept subsidies from the ruling Communist Party of China (CPC).

The report quoted an informed source in Beijing as saying that officials at the office of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin were stupefied recently by the efforts of dissidents to establish branches of an unborn independent political party (the China Democracy Party) in more than ten provinces and cities.

It also quoted the informed source as saying that in 1997 some "liberal" members in Jiang's think-tank urged Jiang to lift the ban on the establishment of new political parties. But the Beijing leadership, led by Jiang, has decided that the most they can do is to allow the eight parties to increase their political participation. For example, leaders of the "democratic parties" may appear more often in news reports and give their opinions on the policies of the communist party and the government, the report added.
The eight "democratic parties" will likely be asked to confirm their willingness to follow the leadership of the communist party and to cooperate with "liberal intellectuals," it added.

The report quoted a Western diplomat as saying that Jiang has revealed his intention to initiate political reforms after the first plenary session of the 16th CPC Central Committee is held in the year 2002, when Jiang's heir apparent Hu Jintao becomes the general secretary of the CPC.
The report also quoted the diplomat as saying that many mild and liberal members of the communist party have joined Hu's think-tank, and that Hu will accelerate reforms after 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYORAL CANDIDATES SET FOR NEW TV DEBATE

TEXT.P: The three candidates for Taipei's mayoral election will engage in three head-to-head television debating sessions on Nov. 5-7 as part of an agreement to hold five such sessions before the yearend election.
The debates will be sponsored by the Chinese Journalism Society and the Taiwan Journalists Association.

The three candidates -- incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang, and Wang Chien-shien of the opposition New Party -- agreed earlier to hold five debating sessions before the December election.
The first and the last sessions are to be attended by all three candidates, while the three intervening will be between individual pairs of candidates.
The three one-on-one sessions will be between Wang and Ma on Nov. 5, Chen and Ma on Nov. 6, and Chen and Wang on Nov. 7.
Some 100 invited guests will be present at the debates, which will be televised live.

The three sessions will be hosted by Cheng Chia-ling, president of the Chinese Journalism Society, Prof. Hsiao Hsin-huang of the Institute of Social Sciences under Academia Sinica, and Su Cheng-ping of the Taiwan Journalists Association, respectively.
The first three-way session was held on Oct. 24, while the date for the fifth and final session has yet to be decided.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON BABS DOWNGRADED, BEARING DOWN ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Light typhoon Babs, which was over the seas southwest of Taiwan on Monday, has altered course to head north-northeast in the direction of the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced on Monday.

A storm warning was issued on Monday evening for areas south of central Taichung County in the west, and Hualien County in the east, where the storm was forecast to hit sometime after 8 p.m., and the CWB warned that northern Taiwan could also be affected if Babs shifts its course a little to the north.
Weathermen stressed that areas spared a direct attack should remain vigilant against the heavy seas and torrential rain brought by the outer rim of the storm.

The CWB said that at 3 p.m., the storm, with maximum sustained winds of 30 meters per second, was centered over the sea some 110 kilometers to the north of the Pratas islands, which lie 444 kilometers southwest of Kaohsiung.
The storm, with a diameter of 250 kilometers, was clocked at nine kilometers per hour and moving in a north-northeasterly direction.

Although it had not yet made landfall on the island, Babs dumped heavy rain on northern and eastern parts of Taiwan from late Sunday until early Monday, and triggered flooding in many areas, especially in Hsichih, Taipei County, which was still reeling from heavy flooding of Keelung River caused by Typhoon Zeb on Oct. 15.
The weather forecasters said the rain could continue and intensify throughout the night, and called on the public to be on the alert against possible further flooding.
A storm warning was already in effect for the islands of Kinmen and Penghu, and for seas of the Taiwan Strait and the Bashi Channel.
Girdling for possible further storm-related disasters, Taiwan's Cabinet had an emergency meeting on Monday afternoon, at which Premier Vincent Siew announced a five-point set of instructions:
-- A rescue center at Hsichih should be established immediately by the Taiwan Provincial Government;
-- All those who suffered property damage during the last two typhoons will receive tax relief; and
-- A comprehensive program to dredge the Keelung River should be speeded up.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNGARIAN GROUP TO BUY PLASTICS RAW MATERIALS FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Hungarian business group Grabplast is set to visit Taiwan for the first time to spend millions of US dollars on plastics and chemical raw materials, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) revealed on Monday.

Frank Wu, director of the Taiwan Trade Center at CETRA's Budapest office, pointed out that high-level buyers from Grabplast will come to Taipei to purchase PVC powders, wallpaper, fibers, and other plastics and chemical products.

Wu said that CETRA is arranging business meetings between Grabplast personnel and major local businesses such as Formosa Plastics Corporation, Yuen Foong Yu Paper, China General Plastics, and Union Petrochemical Corp.

He pointed out that as a result of the Asian financial turmoil, Asia's major plastics and chemical raw materials exporters, including Japan and South Korea, have reduced their prices, prompting the Hungarian company, which used to buy its raw materials from European countries, to change its raw material suppliers.

According to CETRA, although South Korean producers have continued to cut their prices since last year, some of their products still cannot compete with Taiwan products, which are higher in both quality and stability of supply.

Wu said the Hungarian business group, the first major Eastern European enterprise to purchase raw materials in Taiwan, is preparing to spend nearly US$10 million. He added that CETRA is planning to use the case as a touchstone for development of the Eastern European market, to try to enlarge Taiwan's market share in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND SWAZILAND FORGE TRADE-PROMOTION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Swaziland on Monday signed an agreement to further promote trade and economic cooperation.

The agreement was signed in Taipei by Kao Yi-hsin, secretary-general of the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and Dr. Sishayi S. Nxumalo, chairman of the Swaziland Investment Promotion Authority. The signing was witnessed by Swazi Minister of Economic Planning and Development Absalom M. Dlamini, and marks CETRA's second cooperation agreement in southern African.
Kao praised the new accord as a historic step toward closer ties between Taipei and Mbabane which will further enhance both economic and trade relations.

Nxumalo said that the Republic of China and Swaziland have maintained a long-standing friendship, and added that the two allies share a similar position regarding the support of human freedom and dignity.

Kao said there is still room for further bilateral cooperation, and cited the case of Taiwan's Tuntex Group, which has built a garment factory in the Matsapha industrial district of Swaziland, creating some 500 jobs for local workers.

Swaziland's King Mswati III arrived in Taiwan last Thursday for a six-day state visit, accompanied by Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Albert H. Shabangu; Dlamini; Mxumalo; and several business leaders.

The visit carries great significance, as this year marks the 30th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the ROC and the Kingdom of Swaziland, which gave its strong support to Taipei's bid to join the United Nations during the 1998 UN General Assembly session.
Mswati III and his entourage are scheduled to conclude their visit on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT WILL ATTEND APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Monday reiterated that he will attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Leader's Meeting which will take place in Kuala Lumpur in November.
He made the statement during an audience with a visiting goodwill delegation from the Singapore Press Club at the Presidential Palace.

Estrada said he plans to meet with Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad at meeting, and that he also hopes to be permitted by the Malaysian government to visit his friend Anwar Ibrahim, detained on sodomy and political charges by the Malaysian authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN BACKS THAI CANDIDATE FOR WTO CHIEF

TEXT.P: Japan has declared its support for Thai Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi's bid to become the next chief of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization, trade officials said on Monday.
The officials said that Supachai's experience in agricultural matters and multilateral trade issues would be of value to the international trade regulatory body.

Supachai, also Thailand's commerce minister, is running to succeed Renato Ruggiero, an Italian whose term will expire at the end of April 1999. In addition to Supachai, three others are vying for the post, including Canadian Trade Minister Roy MacLaren, who announced his candidacy in July.

The Thai deputy minister will arrive in Tokyo on Thursday to hold talks with Japanese government leaders, including Foreign Minister Masahiko Komura, and International Trade and Industry Minister Kaoru Yosano.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT LAUDS ANTI-KIDNAP TASK FORCE

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Monday lauded the Presidential Anti-Organized Crime Task Force (PAOCTF) for the safe recovery of three kidnap victims and the swift capture of at least 17 suspected kidnappers and their leader.
With the arrests, the PAOCTF also resolved seven other outstanding kidnap cases.

Estrada asked the courts to speed up the resolution of the kidnap-murder cases in order to help send a strong message to crime syndicates that the government means business in its latest anti-crime drive.
"With (the) arrests, kidnappings will be minimized," Estrada said at a press conference after the presentation of the kidnap suspects to the media.

The raids, conducted at the height of super typhoon Babs last week, also yielded several high-powered firearms and ammunition, vehicles and communications equipment used in kidnappings, Philippine National Police uniforms, and the personal effects of kidnap victims.
The president also issued a fresh directive to the PAOCTF to concentrate their anti-kidnap operations on the southern island of Mindanao.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAREND ELECTIONS WILL NOT AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official from Taiwan's Presidential Office said on Monday that cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and activities will not be affected by the island's yearend elections.

The official disclosed that following the Oct. 14-19 trip to mainland China by Chairman Koo Chen-fu of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a mission headed by SEF Deputy Secretary Chang Liang-jen has already traveled to the mainland.
Meanwhile, Koo told the Legislative Yuan on Monday that Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) is likely to visit Taiwan in March next year.
The official said that such a visit is quite possible, and added that the Taipei side would welcome Wang.
The official also remarked that some ARATS working-level officials are expected to come to Taipei in the near future to fix Wang's itinerary.
During their meetings in Shanghai on Oct. 14-15, Koo and Wang reached a four-point consensus, including the exchange of visits at all levels between the SEF and ARATS.
The official said that exchanges will be not affected by December's elections for legislators, and Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors and councilmen.

In a related development, reports from Tokyo said that a three-member delegation from Taipei arrived in the Japanese capital on Monday for a five-day tour to report on the results of Koo's mainland trip.

The three delegates -- Tseng Yung-hsien, state policy adviser to President Lee Teng-hui, Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, and SEF Deputy Secretary Tsan Chih-hung -- will meet with Japanese dietmen from all major political parties, researchers, and the media, to explain Taiwan's stance on the development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DISCRIMINATED AGAINST BY INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan said on Monday that it is unfair for the ROC to be shut out of the international community because of its disbelief in and rejection of communism.

In a courtesy call to visiting Swaziland King Mswati III at his Taipei hotel, Lien ridiculed communism as an "endangered" ideology, and said Taiwan has been excluded from the international community because of its refusal to accept it.

Lien was referring to Taiwan's banishment from most international bodies because of its refusal to merge with mainland China under communism. This has angered Beijing, and has caused it to go great lengths to block Taiwan's access to the international community.

Citing the World Heath Organization (WHO) as an example, Lien said that the ROC's ostracization from the non-political organization deprives its 21 million people of the right to the improved health care which comes from the sharing of medical information and expertise with other countries.

In response to questions from Mswati III about the just-concluded mainland China trip by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, Koo Chen-fu, Lien said Beijing should conduct dialogue with Taiwan peacefully and with sensitivity, and should give up any attempts to take the island through the use of force.

Replacing confrontation with negotiation is a worldwide trend, according to Lien, and Taiwan is willing to improve its ties with Beijing, as long as this takes place from a position of equality, he said.
Mswati III arrived in Taiwan last Thursday for a six-day state visit. He is scheduled to leave on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday ordered a thorough probe into unscrupulous land development.
The China Times: Typhoon Babs changes course, will slam Taiwan today.
The United Daily News: A couple in Sanchih township, Taipei County were buried by landslides.
The Liberty Times: Typhoon Babs brought heavy rainfall to Taiwan, leaving one dead and five others missing.
The Independence Morning Post: Torrential rains wreaked havoc in northern and northeastern parts of the island.
The Commons Daily: Japan rejects to codify 'three noes'.
The China Post: Typhoon relief package was unveiled.
The China News: Typhoon Babs changes course.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOONS NOT TO AFFECT TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Despite the devastation caused by a series of typhoons this year, Taiwan's economic growth will not be affected, a government economic planning official said on Tuesday.

Thomas M.F. Yeh, director of the Economic Research Department of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said while typhoons may cause losses by way of property damage, economic growth is built on the increase of individual salary income.
Citing mainland China's flooding this summer as example, Yeh said Beijing has poured at least 200 billion renminbi into its relief package to help stimulate the mainland's economic recovery.

It is expected that mainland China's economy, fueled by relief operations, will grow by more than 7 percent in the third and fourth quarters this year. The figure for the whole of 1998 is also very likely to reach the government target of 8 percent, Yeh noted.
The ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs was cited in local media as saying that Typhoon Babs will not effect Taiwan's consumer prices or exports.

According to the Council of Agriculture, Typhoon Babs has caused about NT$140 million in losses in Taiwan's agricultural sector. Farm damage is estimated at NT$72 million while agricultural and fishery losses are expected to hit NT$50 million and NT$ 16 million, respectively.
