DOC.HEADLINE: BELIZE PRIME MINISTER HONORED

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui honored visiting Belize Prime Minister H. Said W. Musa on Tuesday in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of friendship and cooperation between the two nations.
President Lee bestowed the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon on Musa on behalf of the government and the people of the Republic of China.
Prime Minister Musa said he was greatly honored to receive the medal and expressed the hope that friendship and cooperation between the two nations will continue to flourish.
He also reaffirmed Belize's support of the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.

Musa met with Vice President Lien Chan in the afternoon, and is scheduled to sign a joint communique with Premier Vincent Siew reaffirming the friendship between the two sides in the evening. Siew is expected to later host a banquet in Musa's honor.
The Belize leader, who arrived here Monday, will also visit economic and political development sites on the island in the next few days before leaving on Sunday.
This is Musa's second visit to Taiwan. His first visit to the island was in 1991 in his capacity as Belize Foreign Affairs Minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA LAUNCHES ASIAN EXHIBITIONS

TEXT.P: Australia will launch a series of exhibitions in Asia to promote its multiculturalism, economic, scientific and cultural developments in an effort to improve its international image.

The exhibition, called "All the Best - From Australia," will be held in the Philippines in November as part of the celebrations marking the centenary of the Philippines independence. From the Philippines, the exhibition will proceed to Indonesia, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and Hong Kong.

Projecting Australia's image of being a tolerant and culturally diverse nation, the exhibition will highlight the contributions Asian Australians have made to the social and economic development of Australia.

Apart from cultural and social elements, other aspects of the exhibition will include Australia's scientific and technological achievements, Aboriginal communities and mining industry, Australia's sports lifestyle, products and services in the lead-up to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-PRC STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP CRITICIZED BY ANALYST

TEXT.P: Washington's "strategic partnership" with mainland China has left India feeling insecure, Taiwan betrayed, and Japan ignored, which will cause long-term repercussions for US political and military roles in Asia, an analyst said.

Ted Galen Carpenter, vice president for defense and foreign policy studies at the Washington-based Cato Institute, wrote in the recent issue of Foreign Affairs that in trying to defrost its chilly relationship with China, the Clinton administration has overshot the mark. Its rapprochement with Beijing has sent political tremors through East and South Asia.

Attributing New Delhi's decision to conduct nuclear tests and move toward "weaponizing" its atomic program solely to the evolving US-Chinese relationship is an oversimplification. The 50-year feud with Pakistan, as well as domestic politics, clearly played a role.
However, Washington's insensitivity may intensify, rather than reduce, Delhi's determination to build a nuclear deterrent and adopt a more assertive foreign policy, Carpenter said.
Warming US-Chinese relations have naturally worried Taiwan. In a brief statement during his trip to the mainland, President Bill Clinton affirmed the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan.

ROC Premier Vincent Siew reacted harshly, asserting that China and the United States were not entitled to negotiate Taiwan's political status. This can only be determined by the people in Taiwan, he asserted. Parris Chang, a member of Taiwan's legislature, even accused Clinton of "selling out" Taiwan.

Taiwan worried, first, that China would exploit Clinton's comment and the newly strengthened relationship with the United States for leverage in any cross-strait dialogue about Taiwan's future. Those fears proved well founded, noted Carpenter.

Barely a week after Clinton's Shanghai statement, Beijing expressed confidence that Taipei would "get a clear understanding of the situation." Lest anyone fail to appreciate the substance of the new reality, the official newspaper China Daily quoted a high-level Chinese official as saying that Clinton's comments had "provided favorable conditions" for resolving the Taiwan issue.
Second, the analyst added, Taipei worried that the new rhetorical tilt toward Beijing presaged reductions in -- and ultimately elimination of -- US arms sales to Taiwan.

Carpenter said the growing lack of confidence in US willingness to defend Taiwan from Chinese aggression or intimidation is pushing Taiwan to become more militarily self-reliant. Like India, it is seeking to protect its security in the context of a US-Chinese strategic partnership.

Unlike their counterparts in India and Taiwan, Japanese officials have not yet moved assertively to counter the US-Chinese partnership. But there are indications that Japanese leaders are becoming impatient with their country's dependence on the United States, Carpenter wrote.

Tokyo has been unusually resistant to US pressures to change its economic policies. Similarly, when North Korea conducted its test of the intermediate-range Taepo Dong-1 missile -- flying over Japan in the process, Tokyo showed uncustomary hostility to US attempts to dampen the crisis.

Indeed, the analyst wrote, Japan immediately sought to stem financial outflow to North Korea and hinted that it might conduct a missile test of its own to launch a satellite -- something that would upset Japan's neighbors and the United States.

Whatever the mix of motives, the Clinton administration's China policy is misguided, opined Carpenter. Clinton rightly insists that isolating China would be foolish and counterproductive. Indeed, the United States should seek opportunities to work with China when the interests of the two countries overlap.

Containing North Korea's nuclear program and otherwise reducing tensions on the peninsula would seem like such an opportunity. But engaging China and maintaining a cordial relationship is one thing -- forming a strategic partnership is quite another.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA SEEN BOWING TO CHINA'S DEMAND

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama is expected to make a ground-breaking statement on the status of Tibet to clear the way for a visit to China to meet with President Jiang Zemin, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

Tsewang Tethong, foreign minister of the Tibet government in exile in India, said in an interview the Dalai Lama is ready to bow to Beijing's demand that he acknowledge that Tibet is a part of the mainland.

The groundwork for such an admission came during US President Bill Clinton's visit to the mainland in July. Clinton urged Jiang to meet with Tibet's spiritual leader in exile. Jiang responded by saying the door to dialogue was open if the Dalai Lama acknowledged that Tibet was a part of China, the Herald reported.
"We don't want to miss this opportunity for dialogue," Tethong told the daily through a telephone interview.
Since the Clinton visit, the Tibetan government in exile has been in indirect contact with Beijing leaders "through mutual friends," Tethong admitted.

He said the Dalai Lama -- in his capacity as a Buddhist monk -- wanted to travel to Mount Wutai, a revered Buddhist pilgrimage site in China's Shanxi province. It was hoped a meeting with Jiang could take place there or in Beijing, but the Tibetan leader would not visit Tibet itself, the daily reported. "We believe, at this early stage of the dialogue, going to Tibet would be too sensitive," Tethong said.
Sources within the Tibetan government in exile said the Dalai Lama's statement would probably be issued in the United States to maximize its international impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA IN MIDDLE OF US-EU ROW

TEXT.P: Australia is caught in the middle of a squabble between the United States and European Union over which international organization should control the agenda for talks on the resolution of the global financial crisis.
Australia is fighting to maintain a seat in international negotiations on the creation of a new global financial system, according to the Australian Financial review on Tuesday.
The US is keen for an expanded G7 grouping to take the primary role, but the EU wants responsibility returned to the Interim Committee of the International Monetary Fund.
Australia is pushing for the continuation of the recently formed G22 (the Willard group) and could lose much of its clout in international negotiations under both the US and EU models.
Federal Treasury international adviser Neil Hyden said there had been a shift in the relative importance of particular international organizations as the global financial crisis unfolded.

He said the focus had shifted from the G7, the G10 and the Interim Committee of the IMF towards the Willard Group and its even newer, expanded version -- the G26, which was designed to accommodate some of the EU's concerns.

The EU is worried about the shift in focus and is keen to push negotiations back into the Interim Committee of the IMF. While EU members are well represented in the G7, the G10 and the Interim Committee, the G22 is more heavily weighted in favor of countries hit hard by the Asian financial crisis, Hyden said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORRUPTION IN CHINA SEEN WORSE THAN 50 YEARS AGO

TEXT.P: Corruption in mainland China is worse now than 50 years ago under the rule of the late President Chiang Kai-shek, according to a report by the Australian Financial Review.
The paper's Beijing correspondent Rowan Callick reported that government corruption springs from the very core of the country's political structure: officials are unelected, opaque and unaccountable.

When overseas investors form a joint venture, usually the major and often only contribution of the Chinese partners is the premises. However, the process through which the land is obtained is always complex, and sometimes simply fraudulent, he pointed out.

In some cases, managers of a state enterprise use guanxi with bureaucrats to have a section of the property excised and re-assigned to them personally or to a company they have formed. So long as no one probes or questions the process -- that is so long as everyone involved is rewarded -- the joint venture proceeds unimpeded on premises that are in effect stolen, the paper reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENERGY SECRETARY UNDECIDED OVER TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: No decision has been made over a possible visit to Taiwan in November by US Secretary of Energy Bill Richardson.
Responding to reporters' questions at a seminar on Monday, the former US Ambassador to the United Nations said he was looking into his schedule to see if he could make the visit.
Richardson said he was invited to deliver a speech at the 22nd US-ROC and ROC-US Business Councils' annual joint conference in Taipei slated for Nov. 9-11.

The annual conference is expected to draw 500 business leaders from both the United States and Taiwan. The US-ROC Business Council will hold a news conference before the end of this week to discuss the programs of the forthcoming meeting.

Stephen Chen, representative of Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO), said the Clinton administration has promised to send a Cabinet member to visit Taipei but TECRO has not received word on which Cabinet member will be in attendance.
Sources said the White House has decided to send Bill Richardson to Taipei. If he makes the visit, he would be the first incumbent US Cabinet member to visit Taiwan in four years.
Since Washington switched diplomatic recognition in 1979 from Taipei to Beijing, high-level US officials have been banned from visiting Taipei.
The Bush administration in 1992 broke the ban by sending then US Trade Representative Carla Hills to attend the 16th joint business conference of Taiwan and US.
The Clinton administration sent US Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena in 1994 and Administrator of Small Business Administration Philip Lader in 1996 to Taiwan to attend the same conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP TO DEBRIEF US ON KOO-WANG TALKS

TEXT.P: A three-member group left for the United States on Tuesday to discuss the development of relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait following high-level talks earlier this month.
The group includes Deputy Secretary General to the President Su Chi, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow, and National Unification Council member Kang Ning-hsiang.

Su said the group aims to explain to opinion leaders in the US the results of meetings between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan in Shanghai, and Koo's meetings with mainland President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen in Beijing.
The trio will visit New York, Washington D. C., Boston and San Francisco before returning to Taipei on Nov. 5.
During the "ice-melting" visit of the mainland, Koo reached a four-point agreement with Wang, including an increase in exchanges between the two intermediary agencies they both head.
Shi and Kang were part of Koo's delegation which visited the mainland Oct. 14-19.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.12 against the greenback in Taipei on Tuesday, closing at 32.657.
The local currency opened at 32.745 and was traded between 32.565 and 32.79.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$362.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX FALLS WHILE FUTURES CLIMB

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 13.69 points to close at 7,036.63.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7, 056.51 points, 6.19 higher than on Monday's close.

A total of 2.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.98 billion, an increase from the previous trading session, in which 2.00 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.38 billion.

Half of the eight major categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 0.7 percent, textile issues at 0.2 percent and construction stocks at 0.1 percent.
Three major categories remained unchanged: pulp and paper issues, electrical stocks and bank and insurance shares.
Only cement stocks gained ground, moving up 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were higher.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for November increased four points to close at 7,014, with 2,071 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 22 points to finish at 7,003, March futures increased 32 points to 6,932, June futures surged 38 points to 6,888 and September futures rose 13 points, closing at 6,850.
Contract transactions for the four futures totaled 70, 19, five and two, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BANKING BUSINESS GROWING STEADILY IN TAIWAN: BOMA

TEXT.P: The operations and profits of foreign bank branches in Taiwan increased substantially between July 1997 and July of this year, said the Bureau of Monetary Affairs (BOMA) under the Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Tuesday.
There are no signs Asia's financial turmoil has affected foreign banks in Taiwan, said BOMA, adding that the turnover of the banks' trust operations increased 21 fold from July 1997 to July 1998.

A total of 46 foreign banks were operating in Taiwan as of last July, two more than in July 1997. Meanwhile, the total number of branch offices of foreign banks operating in Taiwan increased from 67 to 73, while the number of people employed at them increased 14 percent, from 7,124 to 8,118.

The combined turnover of foreign banks' in Taiwan in July of this year was NT$52.8 billion, an increase of 43 percent over the NT$36.8 billion figure recorded in July 1997. Pre-tax net profits totaled NT$6.5 billion as of last July, 54 percent higher than year-earlier levels.
Nearly all the banks' operating sectors, such as deposits, loans and warranties, enjoyed significant growth, although foreign exchange volumes declined 17 percent, according to BOMA.
The fact that foreign banks are expanding their operations in Taiwan indicates that the island remains attractive to them, despite the region's financial crisis, BOMA noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK MAGIC BECOMES A RED HERRING IN MURDERS OF JAVANESE MUSLIMS

TEXT.P: The recent killings in East Java are politically motivated, a member of a parliamentary fact-finding team in East Java was quoted by The Straits Times as saying.

The source, who is in East Java with seven other legislators to investigate the more than 150 murders in the southeastern tip of Java, said criminal intent was responsible for the early stages of a "witch hunt" of traditional practitioners of black magic.
But he maintained that black magic was subsequently used as a red herring or ruse to kill several Muslim figures and supporters of Nadhlatul Ulama (NU).
"One of our findings is that this is aimed at instilling terror in East Java and emasculating NU's power base," he said.
He declined to comment on who had ordered the killings that have occurred in 18 out of 21 subdistricts in Banyuwangi, an area with a population of about 2 million.
Murders later spread to other parts of Java, including Jember, Pasuruan, Malang and Madura.

From January to July this year, black magic practitioners or shamans were targeted as a result of what a senior military officials has called "witch hunts" or revenge killings by families cursed by the shamans. The pattern broadened from July to the end of August, as victims came to include prominent Muslim preachers and teachers.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKING-LEVEL ROC-US TIFA MEETING OPENS IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The third working-level meeting under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) between the Republic of China and the United States opened in Washington, D.C. on Monday.
The ROC delegation is headed by Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), while Assistant Trade Representative Robert Cassidy serves the chief US delegate.
Chen paid a courtesy call on Cassidy before the opening of the four-day meeting to foster a good atmosphere for resolving some trade disputes between the two countries.

During the Monday session, the two sides exchanged views on a US complaint that the Kaohsiung City Government has failed to pay an American engineering consulting firm which has won a construction contract for the southern Taiwan port city's mass rapid transit system. The two sides failed to work out concrete measures for settling the dispute.

Taiwan and American negotiators also discussed issues related to the opening of Taiwan's cable television market and the signing of an agreement on mutual recognition of electro-magnetic compatibility.
Other topics to be mulled over the next three days include intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and the pharmaceutical pricing system under Taiwan's national health insurance program.

The ROC delegation is expected to present a package of measures for improving Taiwan's IPR protection systems in hopes that the United States will drop it from a Special 301 "watch list" for alleged failure to eradicate commercial piracy.
Claiming that Taiwan has failed to effectively enforce its IPR protection law, the US Trade Representative Office again put Taiwan on an annual Special 301 "watch list" earlier this year.
Meanwhile, Chen said before the meeting that he will express Taiwan's concern about dumping charges filed by an American computer chip firm against 13 Taiwan DRAM makers.

"I'll take advantage of the current meeting to express our concern and ask American authorities to abide by the World Trade Organization anti-dumping regulations in handling the case. We hope relevant US authorities will follow the principles of transparency, openness and reasonableness," Chen added.

Micron Technology Inc., the world's largest dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip maker, filed a petition with the US federal International Trade Commission and the Department of Commerce on Thursday, asking the US government to levy anti-dumping taxes on Taiwan-made DRAMs.
Micron accused nine Taiwan DRAM makers and four chip designing companies of exporting their products to the United States at prices below fair market value or production costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED TAIWANESE CRIMINAL EXTRADITED FROM THAILAND TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese man suspected of involvement in the sale and smuggling of drugs and firearms was extradited Tuesday from Bangkok to Taiwan under police guard.
The arrest of the man, identified as 42-year-old Ho Chao-jung, was the result of a joint effort by the two countries to track down suspected Taiwanese criminals living in Thailand.
Over the past three months, more than a dozen Taiwanese people have been arrested in Thailand, and all have been returned to Taiwan to stand trial, according to Thai law enforcement officials.

Ho is wanted for his suspected involvement in a number of smuggling operations in Taiwan in 1990. He had fled to mainland China and from there traveled to Thailand. He was living in Thailand under an assumed name, Thai police said.
Police arrested Ho in downtown Bangkok last week after being informed by Taiwan police of Ho's suspected involvement in crimes in Taiwan and of his likely whereabouts.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF NOT CONSIDERING RAISING CAP ON FOREIGN STOCK INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is not currently thinking of raising the ceiling on foreign investment in companies listed on Taiwan's stock market, Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Tuesday.

In consideration of international financial situations and the inflow and outflow of foreign capital on the local bourse, the MOF will not raise the cap on foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market in the near future, he said.

At present, each foreign financial institution is allowed to hold a maximum 15 percent stake in a listed Taiwan company, while the amount of total ownership of a local listed company by foreign institutions cannot exceed 30 percent.
MOF raised the two caps in January, from 10 percent to 15 percent and from 25 percent to 30 percent, respectively.

No foreign financial institutions currently hold a stake of more than 10 percent in a locally listed company, while the total amount of investment by foreign companies in a single company has not exceeded 25 percent, Chiu noted.

Chiu made the remarks in response to a recent suggestion made by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development to raise the ceiling on foreign investment in the local bourse to transfuse new blood into an anemic market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL ACTIVISTS URGE SLOWDOWN OF SLOPELAND DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Local environmental activists on Tuesday urged the government to take measures to stop excessive slopeland development following a string of mudslides which have killed a dozen local residents in the past few days.

Commenting on recent remarks by Vice Premier Liu Chao-hsuan, Green Party whip Kao Cheng-yen expressed the hope that the government will take stringent measures to stamp out illegal mining and logging on hillsides to ensure public safety and the country's continued development.

During a recent inspection trip to Hsichih in Taipei County, Liu strongly criticized the rampant illegal construction and development which have been blamed for serious flooding and mudslides in the area.

Typhoon Zeb, which ripped through Taiwan on Sunday, killed seven people and injured eight in mudslides and rockslides in Taipei County's Wuku Township, while heavy rainfall brought by tropical storm Babs, centered about 250 km south of Penghu as of early Tuesday morning, triggered mudslides on Monday night in several spots in Hsintien and Sanchih, also in Taipei County.
One landslide in Hsintien blocked traffic on a major road, while at least two people were buried by mudslides which rushed down from the hillside behind their house in Sanchih Township.
The bodies of the couple were recovered by rescue workers early on Tuesday morning, while three others remained missing, and seven houses were totally destroyed.

According to estimates by Taiwan Power Company, 17,000 families in the Taipei, Keelung and Hualien areas were blacked out as a result of landslides caused by typhoon Babs, with 3,400 still without power as of 11 a.m. on Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO SHORTEN WORKING PERIOD FOR KEELUNG RIVER PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will implement a project to control the Keelung River in accordance to instructions from Premier Vincent Siew, an official said on Tuesday.
Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming said his ministry is also studying the feasibility of shortening the timeframe for completing the project from four to two years.

The premier instructed earlier in the day that a preliminary project to control the Keelung River should be listed as one of the central government's most important water conservancy cases, and added that the project should be implemented ahead of schedule.

Siew also asked the MOEA to study the feasibility of the Keelung River's Yuansantsu flood-control project, a short-term plan to construct a series of sluice controls and runoffs which should provide immediate flood relief at a crucial narrow point on the river's course.

The Water Resources Bureau under the MOEA has already shortened the timeframe for the entire project to four years from the original schedule of six years, and Yin said the MOEA will conduct further studies to see whether the project can be accomplished in only two years.

Yin, who is in charge of water conservancy affairs at the MOEA, pointed out that the difficulties presented by the Keelung River project are extremely complicated, adding that the engineering work required includes extensive dredging and river bank enhancement.

The Executive Yuan has ordered the MOEA to submit a concrete program which includes a drainage system behind the banks of the Keelung River, reconstruction of bridges along the river, and the removal of houses from flood-prone surrounding areas.
Yin said the MOEA will invite related government agencies to attend a series of meetings this week to discuss how best to cope with the problem, and will submit a project plan as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUBLIC BLAMES SPECULATIVE LAND DEALS FOR FLOODING

TEXT.P: Politicians and land developers who collude in speculative land deals are to blame for the recent flooding in the township of Hsichih, Taipei County, according to the result of a public opinion poll released on Tuesday.
The telephone survey of 1,082 residents of the greater Taipei area, including 101 Hsichih residents, was conducted by New Party National Assembly Deputy Liu Ming-lung on Oct. 25-26.

"The survey is aimed at understanding the public perception of the cause of the inundation of Hsichih by floodwaters brought by typhoons Zeb and Babs in the past 10 days," said Liu, also chairman of the non-profit Environmental Quality and Cultural Foundation.

The poll results showed that 76.7 percent of those interviewed said they believe that speculative land deals by politicians and land developers are the main culprit of the flooding in Hsichih, a newly developed township situated on the banks of the Keelung River.

According to the poll, 68.3 percent of all respondents and 70.4 percent of the Hsichih residents interviewed said they think the government should ban completely the development of hillside plots in Taipei County.
Meanwhile, 46 percent of the Hsichih residents interviewed said poor design of several sections of dikes along the Keelung River was also a factor in the township's recent flooding.
Nearly 60 percent of all those interviewed and about 70 percent of the Hsichih respondents said the government should offer financial compensation for Hsichih residents affected by the flooding.

About 25 percent of those interviewed said former Taipei County Magistrate You Ching and former Hsichih Township Chief Liao Hsueh-kuang should shoulder a greater share of the blame for the town's current woes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN SATELLITE CHANNEL TO BE LAUNCHED NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Association of Southeast Asian Nation (ASEAN) senior officials responsible for information have paved the way for the launch of an ASEAN satellite TV station next year.
The channel will enable ASEAN member states to project their views throughout and beyond the southeast Asia region.

At a two-day meeting in Singapore this week, officials agreed on the operational and financial details for the station. The meeting came after the fifth ASEAN Ministers Responsible for Information Conference, held in Bangkok in July.
The station will initially broadcast programs between six and eight hours each day, and its offerings will include news and current affairs, entertainment, lifestyle, sports and educational programs.
ASEAN member states will make fixed annual contributions toward the station's operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION BRIEFS JAPANESE ON KOO-WANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A three-member Taiwan delegation on Tuesday met with Japanese officials and lawmakers to brief them on relations across the Taiwan Strait following the recent high-level talks.

The Taiwan group, which included presidential adviser Tseng Yung-hsien, the ruling Kuomintang's Mainland Research Department director-general, Chang Jung-kung, and Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng, called at the Interchange Association of Japan and met with association Chairman Toshio Goto for talks on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the political situation in East Asia.

The Interchange Association, which maintains offices in both Tokyo and Taipei, has represented Japanese interests in Taiwan since Japan severed formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China in 1972.

According to Tseng, Goto and other Interchange Association officials had high praise for SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's Oct. 14-19 "ice-melting" visit to Shanghai and Beijing, during which Koo reached a four-point consensus with the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, and also met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

Tseng said the Japanese officials considered it an "advantageous move" that Taiwan espoused democratization and expressed willingness to share its experience in democratic development with mainland China.
They also considered President Jiang's dodging of many questions raised by Koo and his delegation as "insincere," Tseng added.

The presidential advisor said the Japanese officials, who expressed great concern over cross-strait relations, urged the SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to resume regular and systematic dialogue.

Chang Jung-kung, who is also a researcher for Taipei's National Unification Council, said the Japanese officials attach great importance to the easing of cross-strait tensions, which they said will benefit the stability of the Asia-Pacific region.

On Tuesday, the delegation also met with key figures of the Democratic Party, Japan's largest opposition party, and another opposition party, the Komei Party, to exchange views on the latest situation in the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region.

The delegation arrived in Tokyo on Monday on a five-day visit to Japan. The group will meet with members of the supra-party Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council and other friendly organizations on Wednesday for talks on cross-strait relations and other issues of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENTS DETAINED, INTERROGATED

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese public security officers continue to detain and interrogate dissidents in various parts of the country, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Tuesday.

The information center said in a press release that seven dissidents in Beijing; one in Dongping, Shandong province; four in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province; one in somewhere in Hubei province, and one in Gueiyang, Guizhou province were either detained for questioning or interrogated Tuesday.

Some 50 dissidents from 10 provinces planned to go to Dongping Tuesday to stage a protest against police harassment of dissident Xie Wanchun and his wife. Xie, who is one of the organizers of the Shandong branch of the outlawed "China Democracy Party," has been told to move away from his house before Nov. 1. His wife has been deprived of her teaching job. Of the 50 dissidents, at least 20 have been interrogated by policy, the information center said.

At least 40 dissidents have been detained by police in the past three days. Of them, 15 have not been released. Beijing is ruthlessly suppressing dissidents although it has signed the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW: GOV'T WILL HELP VICTIMS OF TYPHOON BABS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Tuesday that the government will give a helping hand to the victims of Typhoon Babs, and see to it that the rehabilitation work is properly done.

Siew made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan when answering questions about Typhoon Babs, which hit northern Taiwan over the weekend. Many houses and crops in low-laying areas were damaged by floods and mud slides.
Siew said some local governments and government officials apparently did not get their anti-typhoon jobs properly done. All those who neglected their jobs will be found out and published.
He also said that the government will take effective measures to help the typhoon. The government will consider giving them tax relief, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY OF ROC VISITS VATICAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Embassy in the Holy See hosted a banquet Monday evening in honor of Tseng Wen-hui, wife of the ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
The first lady is making a visit to the Vatican to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the inauguration of Pope John Paul II on behalf of the people and government of the ROC.

She said at the banquet that the Pope has made very great contributions to the promotion of world piece, and that she wants to express during the visit the respects of ROC government and people to the Pope.

Ambassador Raymond R. M. Tai said at the banquet that President Lee is very respectful to the Pope. Lee told Tai recently in Taipei that the Pope is one of the greatest spiritual leaders of the world. He leads the world in promoting human rights and world peace, Tai quoted Lee as saying.
More than 100 overseas Chinese leaders, students, and members of a religious group from Taiwan participated in the dinner meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TAKES DELIVERY OF NEW PLANE
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) on Monday received the first of an order of Boeing 737-800 jetliners.

The plane, the newest of Boeing 737 series, is the first of its type in Asia. The delivery was the first step of the former flag carrier's efforts to upgrade flight services and flight safety, CAL Vice President Liu Ko-yia said.
CAL has ordered 10 of the new planes in order to enhance its existing fleet of Boeing 737-400s. The company will receive the rest of the planes over the next two months, said Liu.
The aircraft, bearing the serial number B-18601, is being flown to Taiwan by pilots from CAL and Boeing, via Hawaii and Saipan. It will arrive in Taipei on Thursday, and begin service by Nov. 6.

The Boeing 737-800 is the third generation of the 737 series. Its large wings and the CMF-56-7 engines which give high thrust mean the airplane can uses 10 percent less fuel than the 373-400, according to Boeing.
The new airplane is capable of making a six-hour flight without refueling, and has been contracted for use as new presidential plane of the Republic of China.
Taiwan has bought a total of 49 passenger planes from the United States over the past two years, at a cost of US$4.159 billion.
In related news, the island's UNI Airlines will obtain four new MD-90 aircraft in the next two months, while Far East Air Transport Corp. will receive two Boeing 757s.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING INDEX OF TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC PROSPECTS UP IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: The leading index of Taiwan's economic prospects increased in September for the first time in eight consecutive months, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced on Tuesday.
The index of leading indicators, which is designed to forecast economic prospects three to six months in advance, rose 1.7 percent from August to 97.6 points in September.

The CEPD has devised a color-coded rating to define Taiwan's economic status. Blue represents recession, yellow-blue means economic slowdown, green is steady growth, yellow-red indicates an economy that is heated, and red is one that has overheated.
CEPD figures released on Tuesday indicate the island's present condition falls within the yellow-blue range for the sixth consecutive month.

Statistics compiled by the CEPD in September showed that four finance-related indicators, including the check-default rate, the M1B money supply, stock prices and bank lending, all received a bleak blue rating.

While three other indicators, including industrial production, new export orders, and non-agricultural employment received green, red, and green ratings, respectively, the export value indicator dropped from red in August to blue in September.
According to a recent CEPD poll of domestic manufacturers, 15 percent of those surveyed think business will pick up in the next three months, compared with 14 percent in a similar poll in August.
As high as 22 percent of the respondents say business will take a turn for the worse, against 33 percent in the previous month.

Thomas M.F. Yeh, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said on Tuesday that the International Monetary Fund has estimated that Asia's economy will start to recover in the middle of next year.

He added that since Taiwan has suffered relatively little during the Asian financial turmoil, its economic slowdown is expected to bottom out in the fourth quarter of this year, and will start to climb at the beginning of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT MEETS BELIZE PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that the Republic of China cherishes its cordial friendship with Belize, and would like to contribute further to bolster bilateral cooperation.
Lien made the remarks during a meeting with Belize Prime Minister Said Wilbert Musa, who is currently visiting Taiwan with his wife.

Lien and Musa were nostalgic when they recalled that nearly a decade ago, when they were both foreign affairs ministers, they represented their respective governments in signing an agreement to establish formal diplomatic relations in 1989.

Introducing Taiwan's economic development since then, Lien said high-end information technology industries are now the backbone of Taiwan's economic growth, while traditional labor-intensive manufacturing industries have mostly relocated abroad. At present, half of the island's exports are high-technology products, he added.
Taiwan is also the seventh-largest investing country in the world, with numerous Taiwan-invested companies providing job opportunities around the globe, Lien told Musa.

Lien said he hoped Musa will take time during his visit to contact more government officials and private company executives with the aim of bringing new cooperative projects back to his country for the mutual benefit of both sides.

Musa, who is on his fourth visit to Taiwan, invited Taiwan businesses to invest in his Central American country, and welcomed more Taiwan tourists to visit the tiny nation on the shores of the Caribbean Sea.
The Musas were accompanied by Ralph Fonseca, Belize's minister of budget, management, development, investment and trade.
Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday evening hosted a dinner in honor of Musa and his entourage.

During the dinner, Siew expressed Taipei's gratitude toward Belize for its long-term support for Taiwan's bid to join international organizations. Siew was particularly effusive in his appreciation of Musa for his efforts to push for the establishment of formal ties with the ROC during his tenure as foreign minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BRACE FOR LAUNCH OF EURO

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses had better prepare themselves for a new situation in Europe in 1999, when all merchandise will be priced by the euro, Europe's new single currency, a former German government adviser said on Tuesday.

Dr. Michael Fuchs, a former economic adviser to the German Economics Ministry, said at a press conference that the euro will enhance economic activity in Europe by eliminating the need for the exchange of currencies.
Fuchs, who was invited to Taiwan by the Taipei-based Euro-Asia Trade Organization, also said Germany is in urgent need of Taiwan's hardware and machinery.
He also suggested that Taiwan's computer manufacturers should make Germany its European maintenance center to boost sales in Europe.

He predicted that the worst of the Asian financial crisis is over, and said the possibility of a rerun of the depression of the early 1930s is dim, although Russia is still mired in recession, with no sign of an upturn in sight.
Fuchs said that because Taiwan and Germany are at different stages of economic development, their industries can supplement each other.
According to government statistics, 114 German firms had invested a total of US$435 million in Taiwan, while 200 Taiwan firms had invested US$97 million in Germany as of the end of May.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING PUTS WTO MEMBERSHIP ON BACK BURNER

TEXT.P: Twelve years after Beijing signaled its wishes to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), negotiations for its accession continue in fits and starts, according to reports from the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body on Tuesday.

Several occasions seen as most appropriate for Beijing's entry -- including the inauguration of the WTO in 1995, and the 50th anniversary of its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, in May this year -- have come and gone.

Now it is hoped that accession negotiations between mainland China and its major trading partners, as well as with the WTO working party, will be completed in time for its entry by the next ministerial meeting, scheduled for the end of next year. This would allow mainland China to participate in the next round of multilateral negotiations.

Of course, there is no real reason for having such deadlines. The simple fact is that bringing mainland China -- the world's 10th-largest trading nation -- into the rules-based organization would itself be something of a momentous occasion.

More to the point, mainland China's accession will be followed -- perhaps just minutes later -- by the accession of Taiwan, which has already almost completed negotiations with its trading partners and the WTO working party.

Taiwan has been frustrated by the length of time taken for its entry into the world body, believing that the conclusion of its own negotiations has been drawn out for political reasons -- to accommodate mainland China, the WTO report said.

It is true there is understanding in the terms of reference of the working party set up to negotiate with mainland China, that while the two sets of negotiations would proceed independently of each other, Beijing would be admitted first.

Taiwan has concluded its bilateral negotiations with all but three trading partners, and WTO sources say a large number of Taiwan's commitments are being implemented -- making it much easier to advance the process.
The key outstanding issues with Taiwan, say the source, are in subsidies (incentives or promotions) to both the industrial and agricultural sectors.

Other issues include harmonizing of standards with international standards, tariff quota rates on certain commodities (including rice), and amendment of laws like the foreign trade act and companies law to bring them into conformity with WTO rules.

Some WTO members want Taiwan to amend those laws at least six months before accession, while Taiwan says it will change them once it becomes a member. Mainland China, by contrast, is not as focused as Taiwan in its pursuit of WTO accession.

The WTO report said that right now, mainland China is not as fired up as it has been in the past. "Beijing is distracted by its own domestic problems: the reform of heavily-indebted state-owned enterprises; reconstruction of wide areas damaged by recent floods; and the impact of the Asian financial crisis."

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA OFFERS TO TRANSFER TECHNOLOGY TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Russia is seeking to create business opportunities in Taiwan by offering to transfer as many as 69 technologies to local industries, economic officials said on Tuesday.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will sponsor a presentation on Oct. 28 to introduce these technologies to local businessmen, the officials said, adding that the development is a result of a European trip undertaken last September by Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade.

More than 150 local businessmen will attend the two-day presentation which is to be jointly presided over by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu and Russian Representative to Taipei Victor Trifonov.
Five Russian experts will give presentations on purification of drinking water, treatment of industrial waste water, recycling of tires and polymer products, and many other subjects.

Russia, currently in the throes of a deep recession, is eager to earn hard currency by selling its advanced technology, and the economic officials said that now would be a good time for Taiwan to bring in Russian hi-tech know-how.
Taiwan imported some US$1.2 billion-worth of goods from Russia in 1997, while exports to Russia totaled US$103 million. Two-way trade plunged to US$600 million in the first six months of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO-BEIJING JOINT STATEMENT WILL NOT MENTION TAIWAN: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A joint statement which will be issued when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin visits Japan next month will not refer to the Taiwan issue, according to a Japanese newspaper report on Tuesday.
Jiang is scheduled to arrive in Japan for a state visit on Nov. 25. At present, Tokyo and Beijing are negotiating the content of the joint statement which will be signed on the occasion.
The mass-circulation Yomiuri Shimbun cited foreign officials as reporting that the two countries have yet to decide on the exact wording of the statement.

The mainland side has revealed on many public occasions that the document will refer to Taiwan, the newspaper said, adding that mainland Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan has told Japanese journalists stationed in Beijing that mainland China expects Tokyo to declare its "three noes" policy more forcefully than did US President Bill Clinton during his mainland trip in June.

The "three noes" refers to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for the "one Taiwan, one China," or "two Chinas" formulas, and no support for Taiwan's membership of any organization for which statehood is a requirement.

The Japanese daily pointed out that although Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, it did not indicate its recognition of Beijing's claim that Taiwan is an inalienable part of the People's Republic of China.

Instead, the newspaper said, Tokyo only mentioned that it "respects" and "understands" the stance of the Beijing government, and that it respects the 1945 Potsdam Declaration, in which Japan declared it will give up the right to participate in discussions related to Taiwan sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Law enforcement authorities will probe illegal land development.
The China Times: The government will suspend issue of construction licenses for some controversial areas.
The United Daily News: The government is considering a total ban on construction projects along the Keelung River.
The Liberty Times: Construction in Hsichih's non-urban districts will be banned before flooding problems are resolved.
The Independence Morning Post: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday it is regrettable to see the authorities concerned, whether at the national or local levels, trying to avoid blame for the recent flooding in some areas by pointing their fingers at each other.
The Commons Daily: Premier Vincent Siew blasted fingerpointing among government agencies at various levels over the cause of the recent flooding in the northern township of Hsichih.
The China Post: Premier Vincent Siew blasts 'excuses' in the wake of floodings.
The China News: Serbs leave, NATO wary.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA PASSENGER PLANE HIJACKED TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese passenger plane, with flight number CA905, was hijacked by its captain to Taiwan on its way from Beijing to the southwestern city of Kunming, the Civil Aeronautics Administration reported on Wednesday.
The hijacked plane is expected to land at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at around 11:30 a.m. Taipei time.
The Ministry of National Defense said the situation is under control, but it would not confirm the hijacking before the plane lands at CKS Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE FIGHTERS SCRAMBLE TO ESCORT HIJACKED MAINLAND PLANE

TEXT.P: Four ROC Air Force jet fighters were sent to escort a hijacked mainland Chinese passenger plane to Taiwan, the Air Force General Headquarters reported on Wednesday.

Air Force authorities dispatched two F5E jet fighters from the Taoyuan air base in northern Taiwan and two IDF jet fighters from the Chingchuankang air base in central Taiwan to escort the hijacked plane to the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan. They are scheduled to land at around 11:30 a.m. local time.

The Air China CA905 plane was hijacked by its captain on its flight from Beijing to the southwestern city of Kunming. A total of 95 passengers and crew members, including 20 foreign nationals, were aboard the plane.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration said it was notified of the hijacking by the Beijing-based Civil Aviation General Administration of China. Beijing authorities said some one on the plane asked the pilot to fly to Taiwan when the plane was flying over Xiamen, a port city in the southeastern province of Fujian, which lies opposite Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO HELP ECONOMICALLY-BATTERED NEIGHBOR ECONOMIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan has offered to help its neighboring countries which have been battered by Asia's economic woes, Jeffrey Koo, one of Taiwan's most prominent business magnates said in a regional meeting in Bombay on Tuesday.

Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce (CNAIC), announced Taiwan's offer to help in his speech to the 17th annual meeting of the Confederation of Asia-Pacific Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CACC).
Koo and Indian Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha each delivered speeches on how to revive the economically-battered Asian economies.
Business leaders from 21 countries in the Asian-Pacific region are taking part in the annual meeting, pooling their wisdom and offering solutions to the Asian economic crisis.

In addition to discussing financial and investment issues, the Asian business leaders will also witness the changeover of new CACC chairman and elect a new vice chairman, CNAIC officials cited CACC sources as saying.

R.P. Goenka, CEO of India's renowned RPG Group, will be sworn in as the new CACC chairman in a ceremony on Wednesday. Leslie Koo, 44, chairman of the Chinese-Philippine Business Council, is expected to be elected CACC vice chairman. Leslie Koo is the son of Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu.

On Wednesday, the last day of the meeting, Jeffrey Koo is expected to meet with Dr. Bimal Jalan, governor of the Central Bank of India, to exchange views on the Asian economic turmoil and issues of mutual concern, CNAIC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIJACKED MAINLAND PLANE LANDS AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A hijacked mainland Chinese passenger plane landed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan at 11:17 a.m. on Wednesday, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported.

The Air China CA905 plane was hijacked by its pilot, identified as Yuan Bin, on a flight from Beijing to the southwestern city of Kunming. A total of 95 passengers, including 20 foreign nationals, and nine crew members were aboard the Boeing 737.

CAA officials said the Beijing-based Civil Aviation General Administration of China informed the CAA at 10:20 a.m. that the plane was hijacked and would land at CKS Airport. At that time, the plane was flying over the Fuzhou Flight Information Zone in southeastern China.
Four ROC Air Force jet fighters -- two F5Es and two IDFs -- scrambled to escort the mainland plane to land at a special runway at CKS Airport.
Mainland authorities have asked Taiwan to repatriate the plane and all passengers and crew as soon as possible.
The pilot and his wife were taken to an airport office for questioning shortly after the plane landed.

Following previous practices in such cases, the pilot will stand trial in Taiwan while the plane and all other people on board will be permitted to leave Taiwan after finalizing certain formalities. Investigators are still probing whether the pilot's wife was involved in hijacking.
Taiwan's flagship China Airlines has offered refueling and catering services for the hijacked mainland plane.
CAA officials said they may ask mainland China to send a pilot to Taiwan to fly the hijacked plane back to the mainland.
The hijacker was quoted as saying that he had hijacked the plane mainly because he was dissatisfied with mainland China's civil aviation system and his living conditions.

It was the 13th mainland passenger plane hijacked to Taiwan over the past five years. As 10 cross-strait hijacking cases occurred in 1993 alone, the ROC government unveiled a package of regulations governing the handling of hijacking cases in August that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG, MACAO GROUPS TO BE INVITED TO WITNESS TAIWAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Representatives from Hong Kong and Macao will be invited to observe Taiwan's year-end elections, a showcase of the island's full-fledged democracy, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Wednesday.
The MAC, Taiwan's top agency in charge of mainland China policy, said at least nine political, academic and media groups from Hong Kong and Macao will visit Taiwan to observe the Dec. 5 elections.

Of the nine groups, eight will come from Hong Kong. Of the eight, four groups will be represented by political parties, including the Hong Kong Democratic Party and the Frontline Party. The four other groups will be represented by scholars, media, and news commentators, said the MAC official.
Meanwhile, the Macao group will include members of the Macao media.
Delegations from Hong Kong and Macao are expected to arrive beginning Nov. 28.
On Dec. 5, voters around the island will go to the polls to elect legislators in national-level elections, and mayors and city councils for the two metropolitan areas of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
