DOC.HEADLINE: CBC CAUTIOUSLY OPTIMISTIC

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) on Tuesday said it will maintain a loose monetary policy to prop up Taiwan's economy and that it is cautiously optimistic about Taiwan's economic prospects.
Shih Chun-hua, deputy director general of the CBC's Economic Research Department, said the bank will continue to maintain the stable value of the New Taiwan dollar.

Shih made the remarks in a meeting with a team of financial researchers from the US-based Moody's Investors Service. The two sides exchanged opinions on the CBC's monetary policy, the CBC's view of the Asian financial crisis and the future of the local banking industry.

Regarding the impact of Asia's financial problems on the local banking institutions, Shih admitted that financial institutions from the grassroots level have encountered more problems. However, the overall operating structure of the local banking sector remains sound as the overdue loan problem in Taiwan's banking system is more slight compared to other Asian countries, he added.
Citing CBC statistics, Shih told Moody's that the rate of overdue loans in South Korean banks averaged at around 50 percent, while the ratio for Taiwan's banks stood at only 4 percent.

Tseng Kuo-lie, deputy director general of the CBC's Banking Examination Department, pointed out that the impact of the global financial woes has been limited in Taiwan banks and the overall situation in the local financial system has not showed signs of deterioration.

Although Northeast Asia, Russia and Latin America sank successively amid the financial turmoil which originated in Southeast Asia in the second half of last year, Taiwan's banks were able to escape the plague because of their thin business relations with Russia and Latin American countries, Tseng added.

Taiwan-based banks maintain closer business ties with Southeast Asian countries but investment and loans provided by local banks in such countries accounted for only 1 percent of their total assets, according to Tseng.

Pre-tax profit for Taiwan banks in the first eight months of this year reached NT$82.5 billion (US$2.5 billion), an increase of 33 percent over the same period last year. In 1997, the banking sector made pre-tax profits totaling NT$132 billion for the whole year, a growth of 26 percent on a year-to-year basis.

In the meantime, per-capita business revenue in the banking sector rose from NT$11.9 million in 1996 to NT$14.1 million in 1997, an indication that operations in local banks remained efficient, Tseng said.
Furthermore, the ratio of bad checks has decreased, dropping to 0.29 percent in the first eight months of the year, from 0.32 percent in 1997 and 0.44 percent in 1997, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGER SAFETY TOP CONSIDERATION, SAYS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Passenger safety should be the top priority in handling a hijacking case, Premier Vincent Siew said on Wednesday after a mainland commercial plane was hijacked to Taiwan.

Speaking through government spokesman Chen Chien-jen, Siew said Taiwan will never condone any hijack attempt no matter how sympathetic the culprits' motives might be. Hijacking is unacceptable by any standard of domestic or international law and convention, he added.
Premier Siew has instructed relevant officials from the ministries of transportation and the interior as well as the Mainland Affairs Council to handle the hijack case, Chen said.

Air China flight CA905 from Beijing to the southwestern city of Kunming was hijacked by the pilot, identified as Yuan Bin, at around 10:00 a.m. A total of 95 passengers, including 20 foreign nationals, and nine crew members, were aboard the Boeing 737.
After the aircraft landed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan at 11:17, the pilot and his wife were taken away for questioning.
Yuan was reportedly unhappy with mainland China's civil aviation system and his living quarters allocated by authorities. It is unclear whether his wife was an accomplice in the incident.
The case will be handled under international law and convention and Taiwan's consideration of the cross-strait situation, Chen noted.
He added that it would be better for him and the premier to gain a more thorough understanding of the incident before commenting any further.

Taipei may abide by the provisions of the Hague Convention, which requires separate treatment for hijacked aircraft and hijackers. It would mean that the plane, its passengers and crew will be returned soon to the mainland while Yuan Bin will be prosecuted and incarcerated in Taiwan.

Taiwan's intermediary body with mainland China, the Straits Exchange Foundation, informed its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, about the hijacking and Taipei's possible handling of the matter.

Meanwhile, Chin Chieh-shou, a Taipei County councilor who has long advocated establishing the three direct links across the Taiwan Strait, led supporters to the CKS airport. They waved banners which read "peace across the strait, no more hijackings," and "direct links, not hijacking." Taiwan currently bans direct trade, postal and transportation links with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA REJECTS EAST TIMOR'S RIGHT TO SELF-DETERMINATION

TEXT.P: Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy rejected calls for a public statement in support of East Timor's right to self-determination.
Instead, Axworthy issued a statement welcoming the Indonesian government's offer of limited autonomy to the territory.

In a meeting with Axworthy on Monday, Dr. Jose Ramos-Horta, co-laureate of the 1996 Nobel Peace Prize and a leader of the East Timorese resistance, asked for Canada's support for East Timor's right to self-determination. That support was not forthcoming, Ramos-Horta said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA USING ASIAN STARS TO ATTRACT YOUNG TOURISTS FROM ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia has recruited three popular artists from Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong to help the country attract young tourists from Asia.

The Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) is spending US$7.5 million to join recording giant Warner Music International in signing up Singapore's Ann Kok, Malaysia's Nora and Hong Kong's Jack Wu for a record deal.

The release of Love Snack, with its music video filmed in Queensland, will be promoted with a 40-concert tour. The promotion is aimed at exposing Australia as a tourist destination to fans, an ATC official said.

The number of Asian tourist arrivals, excluding Japan, plunged more than 24 percent to only 801,508 in the first seven months of 1998 from the same period last year. The number of Japanese tourists, Australia's biggest market, dropped 6.2 percent to 440,567 during the same period, according to the latest ATC figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO PROMOTE SALE OF LNG IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A high-level delegation from Western Australia and the Northern Territory has left for mainland China to promote the sale of Australia's liquefied natural gas.

The delegation will include Premier Richard Court of Western Australia and Chief Minister Shane Stone of Northern Territory, as well as executives from Texaco, Chevron, Mobil and Shell, all major producers and exporters of LNG in Australia.
The mission is expected to meet Premier Zhu Rongji in Beijing and other senior Chinese officials to discuss the possible sale of Australian LNG to China.
Australia currently exports its LNG to Japan and South Korea. Taiwan has also planned to buy LNG from Australia to diversify its import sources from Indonesia and Malaysia in the future.

Korea has been a major buyer of Australian LNG but since the financial crisis hit over a year ago, demand had decreased. In the long term, Korea is expected to rebound and once again be a major market for LNG.
The Australian delegation also hopes the mainland will eventually invest in LNG exploration in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASSROOTS REVOLT AGAINST ONE NATION LEADER PAULINE HANSON

TEXT.P: Australia's controversial One Nation Party is facing a grassroots revolt with party members drafting a new national constitution to strip its leader and two of her advisers of their powers.

The draft is designed to see Pauline Hanson step down as party leader because she lost her re-election bid. It also aims to strip Hanson's two advisers -- David Oldfield and David Ettridge -- of their positions.
A meeting will be held in New South Wales on Saturday to vote on the draft's contents, according to media reports.

Under the proposal, the company that currently runs One Nation Party with Hanson, Oldfield and Ettridge as directors would be scrapped so they would not be entitled to use or gain the majority control of the party's trust fund that administers US$1.9 million.
The US$1.9 million was given by the federal government to One Nation because the party won an 8 percent of support from the election despite its defeat.
Hanson and the two advisers have been criticized for their "undemocratic" party structure as they run the party as a company not a political group.

One Nation, considered racist for advocating anti-Asian immigration, anti-Aboriginal, anti-foreign investment and anti-multicultural policies, won 11 seats in elections for Queensland State Parliament on June 13. However, it was the biggest loser in the Oct. 3 federal election, only winning one Senate seat, falling far short of Hanson's prediction of up to 12 seats in the federal parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S PRIME MINISTER PUTS OFF OFFICIAL VISIT TO RUSSIA

TEXT.P: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien announced on Tuesday the postponement of his official visit to Russia scheduled for January 1999.

The postponement comes on the heels of reports that Russian President Boris Yeltsin told Chretien not to come if Canadian business leaders are not included in his official delegation, according to the National Post.
Chretien's scheduled visits to the Ukraine and Poland remain unchanged. He had planned to extend his tour to include Russia after dropping off the trade portion of his entourage.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN CHINESE FEAR NEW VIOLENCE WHILE FACING HOSTILE GOV'T

TEXT.P: Ethnic Chinese in Indonesia now fear a new eruption of violence as they face a hostile government under President B.J. Habibie, according to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald.
Across Indonesia, the Chinese are cowered, frightened and dismayed by routine reports of looting and arson, fearing that further violence may be on the way, Asian editor David Jenkins reported.
Resentment of the ethnic Chinese, who account for 3 percent of Indonesia's 211 million population but are said to control 70 percent of the nation's corporate wealth, is never far below the surface.

Habibie is seen courting anti-Chinese members for his Cabinet and advancing the interests of indigenous businessmen so they can replace ethnic Chinese who permanently fled the country during the May riots which toppled the Suharto government.

In an attempt to advance his agenda, Habibie has arranged for the State Logistics Agency to cancel rice and cooking oil distribution arrangements with hundreds of ethnic Chinese businessmen and award them instead to indigenous Indonesian entrepreneurs, some of whom have little or no experience in the field, the report said.

Indonesia's rice distribution network, formerly dominated by Chinese traders, is now in disarray because some Chinese who fled the country have not returned and others have been encouraged to drop out of the network.

The most obvious solution to the food problem would be to encourage the Chinese to get back into business, providing them with guarantees that the Habibie government is serious about their safety. But this is unlikely to happen, Jenkins reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REAFFIRMS SECURITY COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US administration has reaffirmed its commitment to Taiwan's security in recent talks with officials from both Taiwan and mainland China, a senior US official said on Tuesday.
Kurt Campbell, deputy assistant secretary of defense, also said a top ROC military official met with Defense Secretary William Cohen during a trip to Washington last week.

Campbell said he had held "extremely good discussions" with Gen. Tang Fei, the ROC chief of general staff, who also met with Cohen, Chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Henry Shelton and senior officials responsible for Asia.
Without going into details, Campbell told Taiwan reporters both sides "discussed all aspects of our security relationship" in the meetings.
"And we affirmed our intention to stand by the Taiwan Relations Act," he added.
The question of Taiwan's possible participation in the US-led development of Theater Missile Defense system also came up during discussions.
Campbell said Tang showed interest in being able to study the system. "We stand by our commitment to talk with Taiwan about this and study it intensively," he said.
The United States has in the past had discussions with Taiwan about TMD, a technology still on the drawing board, but Taiwan remains uncommitted mainly because of a steep price tag.
Tang left Washington on Oct. 25 after a low-profile, week-long visit.

Asked whether the question of US arms sales to Taiwan came up during separate talks between US and mainland Chinese military officials earlier this month, Campbell emphasized that the United States stands by its commitments to Taiwan.

He said Undersecretary of Defense for Policy Walter Slocombe, "as every senior American official always does, made clear that the United States will stand by its commitments, particularly those made in the TRA".
Slocombe led a delegation to Beijing in mid-October for a new round of annual bilateral defense consultative talks.
This year's agenda included a whole range issues, including the status of military-to-military contact programs and developments on the Korean Peninsula.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 74.54 points to close at 6,962.09.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,060.74 points, 24.11 higher than Tuesday's close, and experienced a low of 6,937.88 before climbing to 6,962.09 at the closing bell.

A total of 2.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$90.83 billion, increasing from the previous trading session which saw 2.13 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$79.98 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only electrical shares remained unchanged.

All other major categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.7 percent, both cement stocks and plastics and chemical shares at 1.5 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 1.1 percent.
Meanwhile, stock index futures were also lower.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for November dropped 100 points to close at 6,914, with 2,947 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 87 points to finish at 6,916, while March futures decreased 62 points to 6,870, June futures declined 51 points to 6,839, and September futures dropped 75 points, closing at 6,775.
Contract transactions for the four futures totaled 121, 18, four, and three, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MUST NOT CHOOSE SIDES IN TAIWAN-MAINLAND RELATIONS: REPORT

TEXT.P: The resumption of talks between negotiators across the Taiwan Strait is a positive development for the United States but it must remain a neutral party in the dispute, a US China affairs expert said in a report.

Harvey J. Feldman, senior fellow for China policy at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, said Washington must now urge mainland China to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and encourage cross-strait dialogue. But it must avoid getting involved to best advance US interests in preserving peace in the region.

Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, was received well by his counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, and PRC President Jiang Zemin. However, many difficult issues remain to be resolved between the two sides, including the matter of sovereignty over Taiwan, mainland China's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, and mainland China's refusal to allow Taiwan to participate in international organizations, Feldman noted.

The retired US ambassador said it is in the US' best interests for cross-strait dialogue to continue and produce results that do not endanger Taiwan's democratic or economic freedoms. The key to ensuring this result is to pursue a policy that does not force the United States to choose sides.

Feldman said President Bill Clinton made a dangerous move by affirming the "three noes" policy -- no support for Taiwan independence; no one China, one Taiwan formulation; and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations requiring statehood for membership.

The US should return to its previous policy of refusing to state a preferred outcome on these specific issues. Washington should encourage cross-strait dialogue but only state its conviction that differences must be resolved peacefully in a way that does not prejudice freedoms on Taiwan, according to the former Department of State official in charge of Taiwan affairs.

While avoiding the temptation to become involved as a mediator, or to propose "solutions," Feldman continued, the US can tell Beijing that its campaign to squeeze Taiwan completely out of international life, such as its refusal to allow Taiwan's participation in international humanitarian organizations like the World Health Organization, only strengthens sentiment on Taiwan for a declaration of de jure independence.

The US should point out that a relaxation of this stand, perhaps even agreement to sponsor Taiwan's participation in organizations like the WHO, would have a very positive effect on cross-strait relations.

He added that to urge mainland China to renounce the use of force against Taiwan is another important confidence-building measure Washington can promote. Beijing has argued that such a renunciation would be a limitation on the sovereignty it claims over Taiwan, and in fact might encourage independence sentiment on the island.

But Beijing's acceptance of the principle that reunification cannot be imposed by force, and can come about only on terms agreed by the people of Taiwan, would have a positive effect on relations between the two sides, explained Feldman.

Moreover, he noted, as stated in the Taiwan Relations Act, America's decision to establish diplomatic relations with the mainland "rests upon the expectation that the future of Taiwan will be determined by peaceful means," and "any effort to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, including by boycotts or embargoes, (would be considered) a threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific area and of grave concern to the United States."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLDWATCH INSTITUTE WARNS AGAINST BIOLOGICAL POLLUTION

TEXT.P: Biological pollution is sweeping the planet as global trade carries exotic species across all boundaries, the US-based ecological organization Worldwatch Institute warned in a report issued earlier this month.

The institute said the bio-invasion -- the spread of exotic species -- has become the second greatest threat to biological diversity. Natural boundaries like mountains, deserts, and ocean currents used to isolate one ecosystem from another, but trade, travel and other human activities are moving more and more organisms around these boundaries, touching off more and more invasions, the report said.
Bio-invasion is a kind of "smart pollution," because it brings the intelligence of evolution to bear, Chris Bright, researcher and editor at the institute, indicated.

Compared to living things, chemical spills are "dumb," but when an exotic species establishes a beachhead, it can proliferate over time and spread to new areas, and can also adapt to get better and better at exploiting an area's resources and at suppressing native species.

This biopollution, combined with international releases of certain exotics, is pushing invasion rates far beyond their natural background levels. In some areas, particularly islands, current rates of invasion may be more than one million times their natural levels.
No ecosystem can stand up to that kind of pressure indefinitely. The bio-invasion is becoming a new measure of unsustainability within the current economic order, Bright stressed.

The need to act is growing more acute, because time does not heal invasions and there are many potential emergencies just waiting in the wings, Bright asserted, the biggest danger of all is global ecological disruption.

He suggested that a counterinvasion strategy should include: repairing loopholes and strengthening relevant international treaties; plugging the pathways through which exotics move; developing international monitoring systems and databases to overcome the fragmentation of information about invasive species; ending the introduction of exotic species by natural resource managers; and developing ecological literacy in the population as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA CHANGES TACK

TEXT.P: Mainland China's decision to allow foreign investors to borrow local currency to support their joint-venture operations is a welcome sign that the leadership there does not underestimate the Asian economic crisis, Singapore's The Business Times said in its Wednesday editorial.
Finally, it seems, Beijing's leaders have been compelled to take steps to make the nation's investment environment more competitive and business-friendly, it said.

Mainland China has thus far escaped the worst of the crisis, but it is nevertheless feeling its sting. Foreign direct investment (FDI) is stagnating as funds from Asian countries have dried up. Before the crisis hit, Asian investments accounted for some 70 percent of the mainland's FDI inflow, the paper said.
Officially, the mainland's FDI stands at US$20.5 billion for the first half of this year -- a dip of a mere 1.3 percent over the corresponding period of 1997.
Given that the mainland also had a trade surplus of US$22.4 billion for the same period, the country appears well-cushioned from the current crisis.
But appearances can be deceptive. Mainland China's currency is convertible only for trade and services payments, and investment capital flow is tightly controlled.

But the fact remains that whenever there is capital control, there are leakages. In the past, the amount under the entry of "errors and omissions" in its capital account -- considered a reasonable estimate of capital flight -- was around US$20 billion per year.

This year, despite repeated official pledges not to devalue the yuan, persistent market rumors of such a move have greatly exacerbated capital flight; domestic institutions and individuals hoard hard currencies, and foreign investors hold back their investment plans, and it would be unrealistic to expect them not to do so, the editorial said.
Therefore, the decision to allow foreign investors access to yuan-denominated capital loans will do far more to lure foreign funds back to the mainland market.

By shifting the exchange rate risk from investors to the mainland banks, the authorities are sending a powerful signal that they intend to maintain the value of the mainland currency, the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH OFFICIAL TO COURT TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Andrew Fraser, chief executive of the Invest in Britain Bureau is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Thursday for a three-day visit, the Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office said on Wednesday.
While here, Fraser will visit ROC trade officials and meet with Taiwan business leaders in a bid to court Taiwan investment.

Since assuming the post in July 1994, Fraser has so far handled more than 2,000 investment projects by foreign investors. According to Fraser, Asian economies will eventually recover from their current sluggishness, and Britain is the best choice for Asian businesses wishing to edge into the European market.

Currently, Britain is the most popular European investment destination among foreign businesses, and is the European country which has absorbed the highest amount of Taiwan capital, Fraser pointed out.

A total of 91 Taiwan companies already have operations in Britain, 53 of which are involved in the hi-tech information industry, including Acer Peripherals Inc., Delta Electronics, and Hon Hai Precision Industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIJACKED AIR CHINA PLANE LEAVES TAIWAN FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Air China plane hijacked to Taiwan on Wednesday morning left Chiang Kai-shek International Airport for mainland China at 6:01 p.m.

It was piloted by the original crew members minus the plane's captain Yuan Bin, who has been detained by Taiwan authorities along with his wife, Xu Mei, and was scheduled to return to the mainland via a third country, in compliance with Taiwan's ban on direct air links with mainland China.

A Cabinet-level crisis management panel, chaired by Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, had an emergency meeting at noon, after which Huang told a press conference that the government condemned hijacking as an international crime and emphasized that Taiwan will stick to international precedents regarding the treatment of the aircraft and the hijack suspects.

The plane was hijacked to Taiwan on Wednesday morning while on a domestic flight from Beijing to Kunming, Yunnan Province. Yuan told investigators that he carried out the hijacking because of a personal grievance against the airline, and that no one except his wife was aware in advance of his intention.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL PILOT SET EXAMPLE OF PILOT HIJACKING IN 1986

TEXT.P: Yuan Bin became the first mainland Chinese civil aviation pilot to hijack a commercial airliner across the Taiwan Strait on Wednesday, when he flew an Air China Boeing 737, with 104 people aboard, to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan.

But Yuan was not a trendsetter. Back in 1986, a pilot from Taiwan's flagship carrier China Airlines (CAL) diverted a Boeing 747-200F cargo plane to the southern mainland city of Guangzhou on a flight from Bangkok to Hong Kong.
Wang Hsi-chueh flew the plane to Guangzhou's Bai Yuan Airport on May 3, 1986, after he managed to overpower co-pilot Tung Kuang-hsing and engineer Chiu Ming-chih with an ax.

At that time, cross-strait relations remained tense and Taiwan still adhered to its "no contact, no negotiation" policy. Mainland China seized the opportunity to pressure Taiwan to conduct direct talks and used the incident for its "united front" propaganda purposes.

Mainland authorities gave Wang a hero's welcome when he arrived in Beijing aboard the hijacked plane. CAL first commissioned Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways to negotiate with Beijing for the return of the plane, but was later forced to negotiate directly with mainland China's civil aviation authorities. They finally struck a deal under which a mainland crew flew the plane to Hong Kong for return to CAL.
Tung and Chiu were allowed to return to Taiwan, but as for Wang, mainland authorities failed to indict him on charges of hijacking in accordance with the international civil aviation agreement.

Instead, he was appointed deputy director of the Beijing branch of the Civil Aviation General Administration of China in June 1986. Later that year, Wang was also named a vice chairman of the Beijing-based Civil Aviation Professional Commission, and even served as a standing committee member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.
Wang had been an ROC Air Force U2 reconnaissance aircraft pilot before he retired from the military and joined CAL. Today, his family still cannot fully understand why he defected.

Wang has now retired from all his mainland positions, and lives in Beijing, unable to return to Taiwan as he is still wanted by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office for his defection. His wife and children still live in Taiwan.
The cargo plane hijacked by Wang crashed into mountains in the northern Taiwan township of Wanli on Dec. 29, 1991, killing all of the five crew members aboard.
As cross-strait relations have eased since the late 1980s, the mainland pilot who hijacked his own plane to Taiwan faces a different fate to that of Wang.

Yuan has been transferred to the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office for questioning, where he faces charges of hijacking. Yuan's wife, identified as Xu Mei, an elementary school teacher, has also been detained for suspected involvement in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC AMBASSADOR TO NICARAGUA NAMED

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee on Wednesday approved Premier Vincent Siew's appointment of Antonio T.S. Tsai as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Nicaragua.
He will succeed Ambassador Augustine C.T. Wu.
Tsai, 59, a graduate of National Chengchi University, is a career diplomat who has been stationed previously in Colombia and Bolivia.
Prior to his new appointment, Tsai was ROC representative to Ecuador, serving with the Oficiana Comercial de la Republica de China in Quito, Ecuado.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR SOARS TO SEVEN-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: Boosted by an infusion of foreign capital into Taiwan, the New Taiwan dollar posted gains for the third consecutive day Wednesday on the Taipei market, soaring NT$0.142 against the greenback to close at NT$32.515, its highest level in the past seven and a half months.
Dealers said foreign capital, which has been leaking out of Asia since the region's financial meltdown began in the summer of 1997, is now returning, at least to Taiwan.

The Central Bank of China's decision not to stem the rise of the local currency is also partly responsible for its present gains, dealers added. If the NT dollar appreciates too quickly, though, the central bank will likely intervene, they added.
The local currency opened at its low of NT$32.601 to the US dollar and peaked at NT$32.485 in Wednesday day's trading.
Interbank US dollar trading expanded to US$536.5 million compared with US$362.5 million on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE SEEKS WIN-WIN SITUATION FOR ECONOMY AND ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, who is concurrently chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Wednesday called for the simultaneous protection of Taiwan's environment and the further development of its economy.

Lee made the remarks at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting in which Tsai Hsung-hsiung, administrator of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), offered a report on efforts to protect Taiwan's environment.

The KMT chairman praised party members within the EPA for working to effect air, water and noise pollution control, as well as to reduce the amount of garbage generated and process more quickly that which is.
He also praised EPA personnel for their efforts to improve the quality of Taiwan's environment and to create a more harmonious atmosphere on the island.

Lee noted that the fourth Conference of the Parties of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, which will be held in Taipei in November, will help enlarge the Republic of China's presence within the international community.
He urged government agencies responsible for planning the conference to develop an appropriate strategy and a concrete plan of action to make the conference a success.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOONS LEAVE TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURAL SECTOR WINDED

TEXT.P: Typhoons Zeb and Babs, which battered Taiwan over an 11-day period during the past two weeks, caused agricultural losses of at least NT$4.37 billion (US$134 million), according to official statistics.

According to the Taiwan Provincial Department of Agriculture and Forestry, losses to crops totaled NT$3.5 billion, while losses to fisheries and agricultural fields totaled NT$326 million and NT$255 million, respectively.

Zeb hit the island in full force on Oct. 15, drenching the island with torrential rains and buffeting it with strong winds. Its entire assault against Taiwan lasted three days, and by the time Zeb moved northward toward Japan, it had caused NT$4.14 billion dollars worth of damage to Taiwan's agricultural sector.
Scarcely leaving the island time to catch its breath, Babs arrived the following Sunday and caused agricultural damage of NT$230 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CHINESE-BORN AUSTRALIAN WINS SENATE SEAT IN OCTOBER ELECTION

TEXT.P: A Chinese-born town planner in Victoria became the first senator of Chinese descent born outside Australia after winning in federal elections held earlier this month.
Tsebin Tchen of Szechuan beat out candidates from Australia's Democratic and One Nation parties to win a seat in the Senate.
Victoria's Liberal Premier, Jeff Kennett, applauded Tchen's election to the Senate according to a report by the Australian Associated Press.

"He (Tchen) is the first Chinese-born Australian elected to the federal parliament. The Chinese have had a very long association with Victoria's development over very many years, so I think it is a wonderful expression of our truly multiculturalism state and the tolerance of Victorian society," Kennett said.
Tchen will assume office in July 1999, at which time he will be the only senator of Chinese origin in Australian politics.
Senator Bill O'Chee of the National Party, born in Australia of a Chinese family, lost his re-election bid and will surrender his seat when his term expires next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO DISCUSS CROSS-STRAIT PRACTICAL ISSUES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Wednesday urged Beijing to consult with Taipei on practical issues arising from increasing exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

The council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the appeal after a mainland Chinese commercial airliner, with 95 passengers and nine crew members aboard, was hijacked by its pilot to Taiwan at 11:17 a.m.
MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng said the incident has once again highlighted the urgency in signing a bilateral agreement on handling cross-strait hijackings.

It was the 13th time that a mainland passenger plane had been commandeered to Taiwan over the past five years. The pilot of the hijacked Air China Boeing 737, Yuan Bin, and his wife, Xu Mei, have been detained for questioning, while the plane and its other crew members and passengers were permitted to return to the mainland in the evening.

Sheu said Taiwan has handled cross-strait hijackings in accordance with international law and practices since it allowed cross-strait civilian exchanges and enacted a statute governing relations between the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1992.
"We have consistently condemned hijacking and done every effort to ensure the safety of innocent crew members and passengers," Sheu said.
The 16 mainland people involved in the previous 12 hijackings between 1993 and 1994 have all been sentenced in Taiwan, serving terms of six to 13 years.

Two of them, Huang Shugang and Han Fengying, were already repatriated in July 1997 after being released on parole. Six other hijackers -- Liu Baocai, Shih Yuehpo, Lo Changhua, Wang Yuying, Yang Mingde and Wang Zhihua -- have also been released on parole and are staying at an illegal mainland immigrant detention center in the northern city of Hsinchu for repatriation.
The remaining eight mainland hijackers -- Zhang Wenlung, Zhang Hai, Han Shuxuei, Li Xiangyu, Gao Juang, Qi Daquan, Lin Wenjiang and Zhou Weijiang -- are still serving their prison terms.

It remains unclear whether mainland China gave additional penalties to the two repatriated mainland hijackers. Mainland China has been reluctant to recognize the Republic of China's sovereign status and its legal jurisdiction.

Partly because of humanitarian considerations, Taiwan has temporarily suspended repatriation of the paroled mainland hijackers for fear that they may face harsh punishment after their return. Some paroled mainland hijackers had protested over their continued "imprisonment" at the illegal mainland immigrants detention house.
Sheu said Taiwan hopes to resolve these issues as soon as possible.

"We hope to work out clear and definite principles or regulations for handling such cases in cooperation with mainland China," Sheu said, adding that Beijing should show sincerity by resuming cross-strait consultations on these urgent practical issues that are closely related to the rights and interests of the people on both sides of the strait.

Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) once discussed principles for resolving issues related to illegal mainland immigrants and cross-strait hijacking and fishing disputes.

The two intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties, however, failed to reach consensus on several key points, particularly those related to recognition of the ROC's sovereignty or legal jurisdiction.

SEF and ARATS originally agreed to further discuss the problems in a planned meeting between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in mid-1995. Beijing, however, unilaterally canceled the meeting and broke off institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue in anger over Taiwan's drive to upgrade its international profile.

Although cross-strait relations showed signs of warming-up following SEF Chairman Koo's ice-melting Oct. 14-19 mainland visit, it remains uncertain when SEF-ARATS talks on practical issues can be resumed.

Sheu said he is convinced that if an agreement on handling cross-strait hijackings can be formally signed, it will help make more mainland people understand that Taiwan is not a haven for hijackers and discourage them from doing so any more.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY REJECTS CLAIMS PARTY MEMBER IS WORKING FOR BEIJING

TEXT.P: Jaw Shau-kong, a New Party heavyweight and manager of the party's election campaign, denied on Wednesday a Taipei city councilor's allegation that a legislator within the party has been recruited by Beijing to sabotage the island's economy.

Taipei City Councilor Lin Rei-tu, an independent, accused New Party lawmaker Yok Mu-ming of having been recruited by Beijing with the aim of toppling Taiwan's economy. To back up his claim, Lin furnished a faxed document that suggests Yok is in Beijing's employ and that the mainland government has a list of specific Taiwan companies whose operations it hopes to destabilize.
Lin said the recent domestic economic turmoil stemming from the financial crises of companies such as Taiwan Pineapple and Tong Lung Metal Industry are part of Beijing's plot.

Recently the New Party released information indicating links between the ruling Kuomintang officials and some companies. But Jaw said Wednesday that information made public by the party originally came from Lin.

Lin, together with Lin Chau-hsin, a candidate for Taipei city council, showed a document to the press Wednesday at the council's offices in which Yok is said to have been praised by Zeng Qinghong -- a member of the Secretariat of the Communist Party of China (CPC) and an alternate member of CPC's Political Bureau. Zeng allegedly complimented Yok on a job well done, although what Zeng was crediting Yok for was not indicated.

The document also contained remarks indicating the campaign to hamstring Taiwan's economy should be intensified in the face of year-end elections. The disclosure of improprieties by Taiwan companies would embarrass and damage the ruling KMT, resulting in further turmoil in Taiwan's financial markets, according to the document.

The material shown by Lin identified 12 companies as targets in the destabilization campaign. Among them are: Feng An Metal, Taiwan Pineapple, China Rebar, the Cathay Group, the Evergreen Group, Hua Eng Wire and Cable, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and United Micro Electronics.

Yok dismissed Lin's claims as ridiculous, arguing that the information released by the New Party indicating the links between the KMT officials and local companies was proven true during a subsequent government investigation.
Meanwhile, Jaw said that all the information released by the New Party was obtained from Lin himself. If anyone is working as Beijing's operative, he said, it is Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAST BATCH OF MIRAGE FIGHTERS DELIVERED TO ROC AIR FORCE
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, Eastern Taiwan, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The last batch of eight French-made Mirage 2000-5 fighter planes were transported to Hualien Harbor in eastern Taiwan aboard a French freighter on Wednesday.
The disassembled fighters were unloaded soon after the freighter entered the harbor and were towed to an ROC Air Force air base in Hualien for examination on Wednesday evening.

Under its "Flying Dragon Plan," the ROC Air Force purchased 60 Mirage 2000-5 fighter planes from France. They were separated into nine batches and shipped to Taiwan, with the first batch arriving in May 1997.
The last batch of the fighter planes, once assembled, are expected to join the Mirage squadrons at Hsinchu air base in November.
Besides the Mirage fighters, the indigenous Ching-kuo fighter interceptors and American-made F-16 fighters constitute the ROC Air Force's main weaponry.

DOC.HEADLINE: URUGUAY HAS A CHANGE OF HEART REGARDING ROC'S UN MEMBERSHIP: MOFA

TEXT.P: Uruguay has changed its attitude toward the Republic of China's bid to join the Untied Nations, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.

MOFA made the remarks after Didier Opertti, Uruguay's foreign minister, said in a recent radio interview that there is growing support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, despite Beijing's persistent opposition.
Opertti's remarks were made in an interview with Sonia Breccia, host of an afternoon program broadcast on Radio Sarandi in Montevideo, Uruguay.
Opertti, who was chairman of the General Assembly of the United Nations in September, spoke of his experience in presiding over the assembly's general debate and of Uruguay's political situation.
The problem of Taiwan's UN membership would probably be solved if a consensus with mainland China could be reached, he said.

MOFA said that as Uruguay has always observed a "one China" policy, it has not been very supportive of the ROC's bid to join the international organization. Opertti's remarks, however, indicate a change in attitude, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE MISSING IN FIRE ACCIDENT OF HSINCHU FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: Five crew members of a Hsinchu-registered fishing boat remained missing as of Wednesday night after their boat caught fire, marine police said.
Marine police and the military are continuing their search for three local and two mainland Chinese fishermen, although weather conditions in the region are reported as poor.
Two other crew members were rescued by another boat Wednesday evening and are recovering at a local hospital.
The ship, Hsinlungyuan, left Hsinchu Harbor at 9 p.m. Tuesday evening. Family members of the crew became concerned when the crew failed to contact them by radio, as was customary.
Another fishing boat, Mingsheng No. 2, called a coastal service center Wednesday morning to report that it had seen the Hsinlungyuan ablaze.

Crew members aboard Mingsheng No. 2 saw two members of the Hsinlungyuan, later identified as ROC national Peng Te-hsien and Chen Dengping, a mainland Chinese crew member, floating in the water. The two were rescued, although a third body nearby could not be retrieved.
Mingsheng No. 2 arrived at Hsinchu Harbor at 3:45 p.m. Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD BANK CHIDES WEST OVER TRADE

TEXT.P: A top World Bank official blasted major industrial powers for not doing enough to help the poorest nations to engage themselves fully through trade and investment.

Joseph Stiglitz, the World Bank's senior vice president and chief economist, said that the West has advocated a trade policy agenda for developing countries that has demonstrated a single-minded focus on liberalization through the reduction of trade barriers.

Stiglitz urged Western nations to fulfill a moral obligation to global growth. He argued that rich nations have effectively reneged on their responsibilities, reinforcing a perception of hypocrisy and unfairness in which developed countries preach openness while engaging in restrictive practices.

While instructing developing nations on liberalization developed nations "use anti-dumping and safeguard measures to protect their own industries that are adversely affected" by such liberalizing measures, Stiglitz said.

The Uruguay Round of trade liberalization talks did not do enough to open markets to exports from developing countries, he said. In the case of Africa, he said the talks "offered relatively little in the way of new market access."

More needs to be done to stem the wave of new protectionism in the West, he said. In recent years, new measures to block imports have arisen along with laws that do not make sense economically, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA OFFICIAL LAUDS RUSSIAN TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said on Wednesday that Russia's national defense technology is quite advanced and that it will be conducive to upgrading Taiwan's hi-tech level by commercializing the technology.
He made the remarks at the opening of a two-day Sino-Russian technical cooperation meeting jointly presided over by Lin and Russian Representative to Taipei Victor Trifonov.

More than 100 people, including Lin Neng-chung, director-general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA); Hsieh Fa-ta, director-general of MOEA's International Cooperation Department; representatives from private enterprises, and from the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park; attended the meeting.

Lin pointed out that two-way trade between the Republic of China and Russia has grown from US$1.19 million in 1990 to US$1.4 billion last year, but was affected recently by the onset of Asia's economic crisis. However, Lin said, there remains ample room for economic and trade development between the two countries.

Meanwhile, Trifonov noted that as there are still no Taiwan banks in Russia, the main difficulty for both sides is the lack of a financial channel between them. The two countries may, however, engage in technical cooperation projects to promote economic relations.

Russia, which is in the throes of recession, is eager to earn hard currency by selling its advanced technology, and the MOEA, which is setting its sights on ensuring the market's long-term success, believes now is a good time for Taiwan to import Russian technological know-how.

Dmitry L. Zouber, one of five Russian technological experts at the meeting, explained that the financial turmoil in Asia has in turn triggered a crisis in Russia as well. As a result, Russia has come to the meeting in hopes of entering into cooperative agreements with Taiwan.
He said they will demonstrate 69 transferable Russian technologies to Taiwan and will take back to Russia concepts on operating and managing modern enterprises.

Among the technologies presented at the meeting are ones concerned with the purification of drinking water, the treatment of industrial waste water, the recycling of tires and polymers and the establishment of factories to process industrial waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND PILOT HAS NO REGRETS OVER HIJACKING

TEXT.P: Yuan Bin, the pilot who hijacked an Beijing-based Air China airplane to Taiwan Wednesday morning, said he does not regret his actions.
Yuan, 30, who diverted the Beijing-Kunming flight to Taiwan, was detained in Taoyuan by investigators, as the plane was returned to mainland China Wednesday evening.
Yuan told investigators that he felt sad but not remorseful for what he did, adding that he would do it again given his personal feud with the airline's authorities.
Yuan complained to investigators that he had been treated unfairly by the airline and that about half a month ago he and his wife Xu Mei concocted a plan to hijack the plane and fly it to Taiwan.
Xu, a 27-year-old primary school teacher, is in custody in Taoyuan. During the flight to Taiwan she sat behind the co-pilot in the cockpit.
Yuan said he diverted the plane from its normal route to Kunming, in the province of Yunnan as he passed through Taiyuan, located in the province of Sanxi.
After learning what Yuan had done, the co-pilot, Wen Fei, tried unsuccessfully to dissuade him from hijacking the plane.
The plane arrived in Taoyuan at about 11 a.m., and Yuan and his wife alighted under the escort of local police.
The couple admitted hijacking the plane and expressed their willingness to stand trial in Taiwan.
The airplane, a Boeing 737-300, left Taiwan for Xiamen at 6:01 p.m. Wednesday evening.

Before the plane left for the mainland, Beijing had demanded its immediate return, along with the return of Yuan and Xu, in a letter sent by its Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
The letter faxed to SEF Wednesday afternoon also asked Taiwan to arrange for the plane to be flown to Xiamen in Fujian province and to ensure the safety of its passengers.

The plane, carrying 95 passengers, was flown to Xiamen under the control of an Air China relief crew that was to have replaced the original crew once the plane reached Kunming. From there it was to have flown to Rangoon, Myanmar.

Yin Tsung-wen, director of Taiwan's National Security Bureau, ordered Taiwan's intelligence agencies to investigate the hijacking. He issued the order at a meeting of a Cabinet crisis management panel, which convened Wednesday. It was the panel that decided to detain Yuan and his wife while returning the plane to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUA NAN BANK'S LONDON BRANCH STARTS OPERATING
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The London office of Taiwan's Hua Nan Commercial Bank had been elevated to branch status and has started banking operations after a year's worth of preparations.
The bank is the third Taiwan bank to engage in branch-level operations in Britain, following Chang Hwa Commercial Bank and First Commercial Bank.
Chang Sheng-yi, manager of Hua Nan's London branch, said on Wednesday that Hua Nan set up its representative office in 1991 to collect financial information and related data.

He said that the bank recently obtained British permission for elevating the office to branch status. The main operations of the London branch will be issuing international package loans, investments, stock dealings, the drafting of documents, handling deposits and lending.

A cocktail party was held in London on Oct. 26 to celebrate the branch's opening. Prominent figures present at the party included Hua Nan Commercial Bank Chairman Chien Hung-tao and Representative Tzen Wen-hua of the Taipei Representative Office in the United Kingdom.
Besides the three Taiwan banks that have branches in London, the Central Bank of China, Taiwan Bank, Taipei Bank and Chinatrust Commercial Bank also maintain representative offices in London.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC KEEPS ABREAST OF SITUATION IN TONGA: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said on Wednesday that his ministry is keeping abreast of the situation in the Pacific nation of Tonga.
Hu made the remarks while accompanying Premier Vincent Siew to a banquet in honor of visiting Belize Prime Minister H. Said W. Musa in Taichung, central Taiwan.

Hu questioned reports that indicate mainland China is wooing Tonga away from the Republic of China. Noting that the mainland has always kept mum on its diplomatic maneuverings, Hu questioned why the mainland would now choose to publicize its actions and aims.
He said the ministry has kept abreast of the situation in Tonga and that the Republic of China will not fall into any traps laid by the mainland.

Hu said that the mainland has used every means to try to squeeze the Republic of China diplomatically, and he criticized Beijing's double-dealing -- on the one hand courting Taiwan, and on the other trying to further isolate Taiwan internationally.

He urged the public to be mindful of this strategy after the recently concluded high-level meeting between Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CHIEF OF GENERAL STAFF DIES

TEXT.P: Former Chief of the General Staff Gen. Wang Shu-ming died Wednesday morning at the age of 95.
Known as "Tiger Wang," the pilot-turned-general presided over the 8-23 Taiwan Strait Battle in 1958 when the Chinese Communist regime bombed the front-line islands of Kinmen.
After retiring from service, Wang served as the country's military representative to the United Nations and as ambassador to Jordan.
He died after a long illness.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: A mainland Chinese commercial airliner was hijacked to Taiwan on Wednesday; the plane was repatriated about seven hours later.
The China Times: Mainland Chinese civil aviation pilot and his wife were detained in Taiwan on charges of hijacking.
The United Daily News: Air China pilot Yuan Bin and his wife were taken into custody on charges of hijacking.
The Liberty Times: Mainland China's flagship carrier Air China pilot hijacked his own plane to Taiwan.
The Independence Morning Post: Disgruntled mainland Chinese pilot hijacked his own plane to Taiwan on Wednesday; the hijacked Air China Boeing 737 was repatriated in the evening.
The Commons Daily: An Air China passenger plane was hijacked to Taiwan.
The China Post: Hijacked plane returned to PRC on Wednesday.
The China News: Mainland Chinese plane was hijacked to Taiwan on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRECONDITIONS TO ARATS HEAD'S VISIT TO TAIWAN HARMFUL: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: If Beijing were to set preconditions for a visit by its top negotiator to Taiwan, it would only be harmful to the gradually warming cross-strait relations, a Hong Kong-based China affairs scholar said on Wednesday.

Prof. Byron Weng of the Chinese University of Hong Kong made the remark in a roundtable discussion on relations across the Taiwan Strait held at Columbia University. He was referring to a planned visit to Taiwan early next year by Beijing's Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Wang and his Taipei counterpart, Koo Chen-Fu, chairman of Straits Exchange Foundation, met earlier this month in Shanghai and forged a four-point agreement. One of the points was a Taiwan visit by Wang.

Weng said Koo's Oct. 14-19 visit to the mainland was helpful to the cross-strait ties. He added that although Koo's visit to Shanghai and Beijing did not narrow the distance between Taipei and Beijing, it did allow both sides to state their positions much more clearly, which is conducive to redressing the cross-strait differences.

Another factor hampering cross-strait dialogue is US President Bill Clinton's affirmation of Beijing's "three-noes" policy toward Taiwan, Weng noted. The codifying of the policy has only made rapprochement efforts more rigid and limited, he said. The policy's three provisions are no support for Taiwan's independence, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood.
However, Weng said he understood the US made the statement out of consideration of its own interests, and under pressure from Beijing.

There is no rule on separated nations in current international law and convention for Taiwan and the mainland to follow, therefore Taiwan has been deprived of just and equal opportunities in the international community, Weng stated.
He urged the United States, as leader of the international community, to take the initiative in studying relevant rules toward that direction.

Andrew Nathan, a professor with Columbia University, who also took part in the roundtable talk, said the United States' attitude toward China took a turnabout in 1996 after Beijing launched missiles and held live-fire war games in the Taiwan Strait. Washington went from being not concerned to being seriously concerned about a possible break out of war in the strait.
Although President Clinton made the "three-noes" announcement under the United States' own judgment, Nathan said, the decision was made mainly as a result of Beijing's pressure.

Nathan said US engagement with China is apparently not serving Taiwan's interests, because it is shrinking Taiwan's activity arena and forcing the island to return to the negotiating table with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD SUPPORT TAIWAN: OBSERVER

TEXT.P: The United States should support Taiwan because the island represents the best model for mainland China's future, a US observer wrote in the Washington Times on Wednesday.

Mark P. Logan, a research fellow at the Chicago-based Council on Foreign Relations, said the Clinton administration wrongly believes Taiwan is an explosively sensitive issue with Beijing and must not be allowed to sidetrack perceived progress in Sino-US dialogue. This view was highlighted in US President Bill Clinton's affirmation in Shanghai of Beijing's "three noes" regarding Taiwan.

The tilt away from Taiwan began months preceding Clinton's visit to the mainland, Logan stated. To avoid high-level official contact with Taiwan, a group of former Clinton hands went to Taipei in January 1998. They included former defense secretary William Perry, former chairman of joint chiefs of staff John Shalikashvili, and former assistant secretary of defense Joseph Nye. Their message to Taipei was -- don't provoke Beijing with moves toward independence.

The Clinton administration and most foreign policy officials came away with the wrong lesson from the March 1996 missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait, Logan said. While China was lobbing missiles near Taiwan's two principal ports during its first free presidential election, elite opinion believes it is Taiwan which is the dangerous source of provocation.

One lesson of the Reagan era which still applies despite the dissolution of the Cold War is that weakness and ambiguity beget aggression by autocracies, wrote the research fellow. The Clinton administration's self-professed strategic ambiguity about supporting Taiwan only exacerbated the March 1996 crisis -- necessitating deployment of two carriers in the Taiwan Strait at the eleventh hour. "Backing Taiwan is an important part of a regional policy which deters China as a rising military power," he said.

Taiwan is even more significant to the United States on the political front. Taiwan has successfully moved away from a one-party dictatorship to a full-fledged democracy, thereby offering a road map for the mainland to follow, Logan wrote.

Foreign policy and business elites who seek trade in Asia and urge don't-rock-the-boat diplomacy with China often look to Singapore as a model for the PRC's future. In the eyes of Lee Kuan Yew's admirers, Singapore harnesses a potent engine of capitalism with governance which stresses order above all.

However, Logan said Taiwan's openness is a far better model for the PRC. Skeptics about Taiwan cite fisticuffs in its Legislative Yuan and evidence that the Democratic Progressive Party is not ready for the prime time. But intense debate in the national legislature and development of a vital opposition are examples of political competition, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-AUSTRALIA TIES PROGRESSING STEADILY (1)

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and Australia are progressing steadily despite Canberra's strict adherence to its one-China policy, the representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Canberra said.

Liu Po-lun, in an interview with CNA, said there is still room for further improvement in substantive ties between the Republic of China and Australia as the two countries compliment each other. However, there is only limited improvement in high-level contact between the ROC and Australia because Canberra is very careful not to upset Beijing given its one-China policy.
Political analysts agreed, saying there is a limited scope for Taiwan to make any breakthrough in political ties because of China's constant pressure on Australia.

"If Taiwan wants to gain some ground in high-level contact with Australia, it has to keep a low profile in order not to upset Canberra's one-China policy," said Associate Professor C.L. Chiou of the University of Queensland in Brisbane.

He cited the low-profile overnight stay of ROC Premier Vincent Siew in Australia as an example. Canberra allowed Siew to make a stopover in Brisbane on his way to Guam in June this year, making him the most senior official from Taiwan to set foot in Australia.
While Australia considers the mainland as a big country and a huge market, Taiwan continues to offer substantial investment opportunities, TECO's Liu said.

Foreign investment from Taiwan to Australia increased in 1997 after Taiwan Sugar Corp. and Taiwan Pineapple Co. established a joint venture with their Australian counterpart in the livestock industry. Taiwan interests invested in hog raising and prawn farm ventures in Queensland and the Northern Territory. All this followed a 10 percent investment by Taiwan Power Co. in an Australian coal mining venture in Hunter Valley in New South Wales in 1996, he added.

A nearly US$1 billion joint venture by An Feng Steel Corp. of Kaohsiung with its Australian partner Kingstream Resources in Western Australia was launched and is expected to be completed with production beginning in 2000.

In addition, a group of senior executives from Taiwanese computer firms, including Acer Taiwan, arrived in Australia in October for an on-the-spot survey to explore possible opportunities in setting up joint ventures with their Australian counterparts.

Liu said the ROC is strong in IT hardware while Australia is strong in software. Australia is also strong in its health sciences, environmental protection activities, information and biological technologies, all areas of possible future cooperation and exchange.
In addition, the Howard administration is currently undergoing a tax reform, in which a reduction in income and corporate taxes is expected.
"This is good news for our investors because lower taxes would help cut their costs and sharpen their competitiveness in the world market," Liu said.

"There is room for expansion in two-way trade despite the impact of the Asian financial crisis," Liu said. Both Taiwan and Australia are less affected by the Asian crisis, and this reflects a steady growth in two-way trade in fiscal 1997-98.
Australia's exports to Taiwan in 1997-98 rose 17 percent from the 1996-97 level while trade between Australia and mainland China and other Asian countries dropped during the same period.

In calendar 1997, Australia's exports to Taiwan jumped 18 percent to A$4 billion (US$3.22 billion), the highest growth rate for Australia in terms of export growth rate in Asia that year, Liu said. Meanwhile, Australia exports to China plunged 17 percent in the first six months of 1998. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-AUSTRALIA TIES PROGRESSING STEADILY (2)

TEXT.P: In 1997, Taiwan was Australia's fifth largest market, trailing behind only Japan, South Korea, the United States and New Zealand.
In the first nine months of 1998, two-way trade between Taiwan and Australia rose 9.7 percent to A$4.9 billion (US$3.3 billion).

Taiwan continues to be one of the largest buyers of Australian iron ore, coal, lead, copper, agricultural produce, seafood and beef. Taiwan is also a major importer of leather, nickel, zinc, petroleum, woodchip and rotating electric plant from Australia.
Liu predicted the prospects of two-way trade are bright in coming years with Australia.

He said two-way investment remains behind trade volume, but investment from Taiwan in Australia has been showing signs of increasing since 1996 and the trend could continue in the foreseeable future. Liu added that investment from Australia in Taiwan has not increased as rapidly as Taiwanese investment in Australia.
"We hope Australia can increase its investment and use Taiwan as a base to market its products to other Asian countries, including mainland China," he said.

In terms of Australian travelers to Taiwan, the number is far below those traveling in the opposite direction, Liu noted. Although there was some increase in the number of Australians going to Taiwan, most of these visitors were conducting business rather than pleasure trips.

Australian official statistics showed there were 33,255 Australians going to Taiwan in calendar 1997, up 6.64 percent from a year ago. Taiwanese tourists to Australia rose almost 1 percent to 98,915 in the first 7 months of 1998.
The depreciation of the Australian dollar has helped it in terms of higher exports to Taiwan and is attracting more Taiwan students to study Down Under.
"Australia is now more competitive than other educational exporting countries as a result of its currency devaluation," Liu said.
Currently, there are about 9,000 students from Taiwan studying in Australia and Liu hoped Australia will pay more attention to the Taiwan market.
Other ties, including cultural and scientific exchanges, have also increased steadily between Taiwan and Australia in the past year, Liu said.

The Taiwan Provincial Government has sent some of its officials to be trained in Australia and the Queensland government is expected to send its officials to receive training in Taiwan so that each side is familiar with the other which is conducive to the forging of better ties in the future.

"We are glad that our ties with Australia are progressing steadily. And we hope we could do even better to improve our bilateral ties in the coming years so that both countries could benefit mutually," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SETS DUMPING MARGIN FOR TAIWAN STEEL PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The US Department of Commerce announced on Wednesday it will levy preliminary anti-dumping duties on imports of stainless steel plate in coils from Taiwan and five other countries.

The Commerce Department's preliminary determination was that imports of stainless steel plate in coils from Belgium, Canada, Italy, South Africa, South Korea and Taiwan were sold at less than fair market prices in the United States.
Imports from Taiwan received the highest initial anti-dumping duty with 67.68 percent, and South Korea the lowest with 2.77 percent.
Importers will now be required to post bonds to get clearance with the US Customs Service to assure payment of the anti-dumping duties.

The department's investigation was initiated on March 31 when four US producers of stainless steel plate, the United Steelworkers of America, and two independent unions petitioned the US government to look into dumping charges.
A spokesman for the US Specialty Steel Industry of North America said, "We expect these (dumping) margins to go higher after further investigation."

The Commerce Department is expected to make its final ruling early next year. After the final anti-dumping orders are published, imports of stainless steel plate in coils from the targeted countries will be subject to collection of anti-dumping duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA CONTINUES TO SUPPRESS DEMOCRACY GROUP

TEXT.P: Beijing authorities shut down a fledging pro-democracy group and questioned its leaders after signing earlier this month an international human rights treaty, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

Chinese police raided the offices of the China Development Union (CDU) this week, detaining its secretary Peng Ming and two other officials for three hours questioning before ordering them to close, the report said.

President Jiang Zemin was widely congratulated for signing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which guarantees the right to organize political parties and protects the freedom of expression.
According to the CDU, Jiang ordered the closure of the party. "The closing down of the union shows that Jiang has no plans for political reform at all," the CDU said in a statement.

Human rights groups have been skeptical about China's willingness to fully implement the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights after the official media signaled that China would seek exemptions. They also suspected China would delay ratifying the treaty for as long as possible, the daily reported.

Chinese authorities have moved to block other challenges to the Communist Party's monopoly on politics. Dissidents in nine provinces and in Beijing and Shanghai have unsuccessfully attempted to register the China Democratic Party in recent months as activists test the government's willingness to allow more political freedom, the Herald reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CANCELS WAR GAMES WITH INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australia has canceled war games and suspended other contact with Indonesia following damaging reports over human rights abuses by its elite special forces, the Australian reported.

The Australian Defense Force (ADF) has abandoned two major military exercises and other contacts with Indonesia's elite special forces -- Kopassus -- because of its record of systematic human right abuses, the paper said.
Since the fall of former President Suharto in May, the Kopassus abuses, including its repression on dissent, were becoming known to the public.
Aside from canceling the two exercises in Australia, the ADF also abandoned a special armed service exercise in Indonesia in June and the scrapping of planned command-level visits.

The two exercises involving small contingents of troops from Australia's special armed services and Kopassus are designed to train in counter-terrorism and normal war roles in Australia and Indonesia in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S INFLATION UP 1.3 PERCENT IN 3RD QUARTER

TEXT.P: Australia's inflation rate in the third quarter of 1998 rose to 1.3 percent per annum, far below government expectation of between 2 and 3 percent.
Lower inflation helped boost the local stock and foreign exchange markets on Wednesday.
Inflation, measured by the consumer price index, rose 0.2 percent in the third quarter, which translated into an inflationary rate of 1.3 percent yearly compared to the previous year.
The lower inflation rate prompted financial market economists to predict that the Reserve Bank of Australia would further reduce official interest rates by at least 0.25 percentage point.
The All Ordinaries Index rose 32.3 points to close at 2,615.2 on Wednesday from Tuesday's close. The index increased 16.7 points further in Thursday morning trade.
The Australian dollar also rose 0.22 US cents to close at 61.72 US cents on Wednesday from the Tuesday level. The dollar remained unchanged in Thursday morning trade.
Economists predicted the stock and foreign exchange markets could gain further ground if the Reserve Bank reacted to the lower inflation by cutting official interest rates soon.
