DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT WOULD BAR FOREIGNERS WITH AIDS FROM ENTERING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Foreign nationals with AIDS would be barred from entering the Republic of China under draft legislation passed by the floor of the Executive Yuan on Thursday.
Foreigners suffering from communicable diseases and dementia would be barred as well.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the draft is in line with both international trends and the government's plan to turn Taiwan into a regional operations hub.

Another draft provision would enable citizens of nations whose nationals do not automatically receive visa-free entry or landing visas to Taiwan to receive the preferential treatment at the ministry's discretion. Visa-free entry could be granted or landing visas issued in special circumstances or out of humanitarian concern, according to the draft.

The draft also calls for no visas to be issued to foreigners who have criminal records, foreigners who have previously been denied entry to the Republic of China and foreigners who have at any time been expelled from the ROC or have entered the country illegally.
The Republic of China currently offers two-week visa-free entry to nationals of 18 countries and landing visas to citizens of 22 nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SECOND-SAFEST ECONOMY IN ASIA: PERC
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan was rated the second-most stable economy for business of 10 countries and areas in Asia in 1998 by the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. (PERC).

In the findings of a survey devoted to social unrest in Asia, PERC said that Singapore was regarded by respondents as the most socially stable economy in Asia since the region was hit by economic turmoil in late 1997. Taiwan and Japan, meanwhile, tied for second place.

On a scale of zero to 10, with zero indicating absolute stability, Singapore received a rating of 1.5. Taiwan and Japan both received a score of 2, a marked increase for Taiwan, which scored 3.5 in 1997 and 4.5 in 1996.
In the survey Hong Kong received a score of 3.5, the Philippines 4, Vietnam 4.5, mainland China 5.5, India and Thailand 6, South Korea 7, Malaysia 7.5 and Indonesia 9.
Over the last 10 months only Taiwan, the Philippines and Vietnam showed declines in their social unrest index, or improved stability, the organization said.

The survey was conducted in mid-October, PERC officials said, and Taiwan's decline in the social unrest index can be attributed to the reduced number of political protests and demonstrations during the last 10 months.
Despite its rising unemployment, Taiwan has come through the regional crisis relatively unscathed, making it the region's most competitive economy, according to the survey.
Compared with last year, Taiwan is now more socially stable, and that stability is largely related to its democratic development, PERC said.

Taiwan's political system has successfully changed from a single-party to multi-party democracy, it noted. For the most part, emotional and often unreasonable political arguments have been replaced by debates on issues involving social welfare and garbage handling, it added.

PERC said the Asian economic crisis has deepened social unrest throughout the region. From Hong Kong to South Korea, regional economies have been affected by the crisis, although Indonesia and Malaysia have been hardest hit.
In the face of the economic meltdown, some governments adopted tougher financial policies, which scared off foreign capital, further slowing economic growth in those countries, PERC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S MANUFACTURING WAGES REMAIN HIGH

TEXT.P: Singapore's manufacturing wages continued to rank higher than those of other east Asian economies last year, although wages in Taiwan and Hong Kong trailed fairly close behind.
According to the 1998 World Competitiveness Yearbook, the average hourly income of manufacturing workers in Singapore was US$6.70 last year -- the highest in Asia, excluding Japan.

Taiwan and Hong Kong followed close behind, with hourly wages of US$5.60 and US$5.10, respectively, while South Korea's hourly manufacturing wage averaged US$3.90. The figures were based on data from the US Department of Labor and from organizations in Singapore.

Singapore's average manufacturing wage was reported as US$7.30 per hour in the 1997 yearbook, while the average hourly wages in South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong were US$7.10, US$5.60 and US$4.80, respectively. Those figures, however, referred to pay levels in 1996.

For many of the 46 economies tracked in the rankings -- compiled and presented by IMD, an executive management school in Lausanne, Switzerland -- the decline in manufacturing wages in US dollar terms last year was the result of a regional economic slowdown and weaker currencies.
This year's report also indicates Asian workers, excluding those from Japan, are hard-working, yet produce less per person than their European and American counterparts, the figures show.

But Singapore's industrial productivity, adjusted for purchasing power parity, ranked 17th, while South Korea finished seventh. In terms of service, Singapore finished 12th, behind both Hong Kong and Taiwan. In terms of gross domestic product per person employed, Singapore finished 13th at US$47,945 while Hong Kong was ninth with US$51,086.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S RESPONSE TO US CALLS VERY SLOW: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing is reacting slowly to US calls for greater trade balance, cooperation over North Korea, and economic reforms, dubbed the "three slows" in a Los Angeles Times report on Wednesday.
The latest trade figures, made public last week, showed that the US trade deficit with mainland China reached US$6 billion in August -- higher than the deficit with Japan or any other country.

US exports to the mainland have been dropping while its imports from China have been rising, leading Clinton administration officials to becoming increasingly irked at Beijing's efforts to protect its markets for items such as pharmaceuticals.
In recent months, North Korea has fired a missile over Japan and there have been new signs that it may be secretly continuing its nuclear program despite the agreement it reached with the US in 1994.

Yet whenever the US asks Beijing officials to help restrain North Korea, they reply that they have little clout in Pyongyang. That line is beginning to wear thin in Washington even in the Clinton administration, which is far more inclined to sympathize with Beijing's view than Congress.
Clinton administration officials have also begun to voice unhappiness with the way the Beijing regime has retreating from economic liberalization.

As Beijing continues to drag its feet, a bubbling confrontation between it and Washington may be brewing. These problems are not at the moment matters of intense controversy, but they could easily become so when a new Congress convenes in Washington next year, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.01 against the greenback in Taipei Thursday, closing at 32.525.
The local currency opened at 32.509 and was traded between 32.495 and 32.57.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$365.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES, BOTH CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices climbed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index rising 54.8 points to close at 7,016.89.
The bourse opened at 6,983.76, and buying was steady during the day's trading.
Gainers outnumbered losers 230 to 160, with 97 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 1.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.71 billion (US$1.93 billion), compared with the previous session's turnover of NT$90.83 billion.

Financial issues posted the largest gain, rising 1.4 percent. They were followed by electrical engineering stocks, which rose 1.2 percent; paper and pulp shares, 0.5 percent; and chemical and plastics issues, 0.4 percent.
Construction issues dropped 0.3 percent, while cement stocks moved down 0.2 percent and textile shares remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock futures closed higher as well.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for November rose 51 points to close at 6,965, with 1,515 contract transactions.

December futures climbed 33 points to finish at 6,949, while March futures rose 48 points to 6,918, June futures increased 91 points to 6,881 and September futures gained 139 points, closing at 6,889.
Contract transactions for the four futures totaled 113, seven, four and one, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 6,914 for November; 6,916 for December; 6,870 for March; 6,790 for June; and 6,750 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF REAFFIRMS BAN ON BRINGING MAINLAND CURRENCY INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Thursday reminded the public that mainland Chinese currency should not be brought to Taiwan.

MOF officials said that those people in possession of renminbi should report their holdings when entering Taiwan. The currency would then be held by customs officials and returned to the people when they leave Taiwan.
As the number of contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has grown, an increasing number of people are brining renminbi into Taiwan in violation of regulations, officials said.

The officials were speaking in response to an ROC national who complained that customs officials seized some 21,800 renminbi that the person had brought into Taiwan, but failed to declare when passing through customs.
Officials said regulations stipulate that mainland currency, bonds or securities must be declared when brought to Taiwan. By doing so, their owners may reclaim possession when they leave the island.
The officials estimated that the amount of mainland currency seized from Taiwan residents has exceeded 1 million renminbi. What to do with the seized currency has been a nagging question, they added.
The ministry considered and ultimately abandoned a plan to convert the money into US dollars, which would have beeen added to the nation's coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP POLL FINDS PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR KMT MAJORITY IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Public support for the ruling Kuomintang seems to have rebounded after the party suffered a spate of embarrassing electoral defeats in the past few years, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Thursday.

The telephone poll of 1,090 eligible voters residing across the island was conducted by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) between Oct. 22-24 with a view to understand public opinion about major domestic political parties.

Survey results showed that 41 percent of the respondents said they hoped to see the KMT win more than half of the legislative seats up for grabs in the upcoming parliamentary elections, while 34 percent said they would not like to see the ruling party control majority seats in the legislature. Another 20 percent didn't clearly express their opinion.
DPP Secretary-General Chiou Yi-jen said the poll results indicated that local people remain wary of the scenario that no party manages to control half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan.
Chiou pointed out that whether or not the KMT wins half of the legislative seats is tantamount to a choice between "stability" and "instability" or "chaos."
"Those who hope to see the KMT win majority seats apparently opt for stability, while those who choose the opposite prefer to see the government subject to tighter supervision," Chiou explained.

He stressed that if the KMT loses its dominant status in the Dec. 5 elections, it will mark a a new stage in Taiwan's political history. "If no single party manages to control majority seats in the new legislature, our government will then be subject to stricter parliamentary supervision and our political check-and-balance system can therefore be truly substantiated."
Among major domestic parties, 25 percent said they most like the KMT; 23 percent chose the pro-independence DPP; only 5 percent said they most favor the pro-unification New Party.

The main reason cited by the respondents for their affection for the KMT is that they feel the party has the ability to rule; public affection for the DPP lies with their conviction that the party is more reform-minded; while the biggest attraction of the New Party is its clean image.
As for the party most unattractive to those interviewed, 25 percent cited the New Party; 12 percent chose the DPP; only 6 percent cited the KMT; and 58 percent said they couldn't make a choice.

Poll results showed that many DPP opponents perceived the party as "violent, radical and divisive"; while the KMT's most serious shortcomings were corruption and inefficiency; and intraparty squabbling was most detrimental to the New Party's public image.

The survey also found that 70 percent of the respondents have not yet decided which party they will support in the year-end legislative elections; 13 percent said they will vote for the KMT; 9 percent said they will opt for the DPP; 1.9 percent said they will throw support behind the New Party; and only 0.2 percent said they will vote for the burgeoning Taiwan Independence Party.

Generally speaking, those who hope to see the KMT win more than half of the legislative seats age over 40 and are less educated. About 40 percent of male respondents said they do not like to see the KMT win majority legislative seats, but only 28 percent of female respondents said they hope the KMT will lose its majority status in the new legislature.
"The figures indicated that local women still remember the DPP's previous violent, radical image," Chiou said.

Survey results further showed that local people generally feel that the KMT is more competent at handling issues related to national security, economic development, educational reform and diplomatic problems and that the DPP is more good at planning a reasonable social welfare system, environmental protection, crime-fighting and taking care of underprivileged groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNFOI URGES SETTING ASIDE OF CROSS-STRAIT POLITICAL DIFFERENCES

TEXT.P: Both sides of the Taiwan Strait should shorten the process of political discussion and seek to set aside their political differences for the sake of mutual economic development, urged the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFOI) on Thursday.

CNFOI Chairman Kao Chin-yen made the remarks while meeting with a five-member delegation from mainland China. The delegation was headed by Zhou Ruijin, deputy editor in chief of The People's Daily -- an organ under the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China.

Kao expressed his hope that an environment free of political differences across the strait can be created. He likewise urged people on both sides of the strait to prepare themselves to work for sustained economic development over the next 50 years, as the Chinese people will be in the driver's seat of the global economy in the next century, he said.
The just-concluded meeting between Taipei's top envoy to the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, will lead to improved economic development for both sides, Kao said.

If political differences cannot be delt with peacefully, engagements between the two sides will remain fraught with risks, he said, adding that this is not something Taiwan's business community wishes to see.

Kao suggested people on both sides of the strait make economic development, not political discussion, their common goal during the next 50 years, with an eye toward playing the leading role in driving the global economy in the 21st century.

The CNFOI chairman said that if both sides maintained an emphasis on economic development, mainland China and Taiwan's gross national product per capita could amount to US$15,000 and US$30,000, respectively, within 50 years. At that point, reunification between the two sides could be easily achieved, he said. Besides Zhou, the delegation comprised Wang Xien, director of the Liaison Department under the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait; Gao Haihao, deputy editor in chief of the East China Branch of The People's Daily; Yang Zhengwu, deputy director of the science, education and culture section of The People's Daily; and Gai Lihua, general manager of the mainland news company under The People's Daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES

The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The legislature on Thursday passed a bill relaxing qualifications for stipends for elderly farmers.
The China Times: The revised "elderly farmers' stipends bill" canceled the rule that had rejected would-be beneficiaries classified as wealthy -- those with annual incomes above the minimum wage or those with properties worth over NT$4 million.

The Commons Daily: Government expenditures will increase more than NT$30 billion annually due to elderly farmers' stipends.
The China Post: The bill is passed on elderly farmers' stipends.
The China News: Taiwan considers deporting mainland Chinese pilot.
