DOC.HEADLINE: INVENTEC OF TAIWAN EXPANDS ITS UK OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwanese electronics company Inventec is expanding its British operations through a wider range of activities at Inchinnan in Renfrewshire, Scotland.

The plant, which currently repairs laptop computers, was established in February 1997. According to the UK government's Invest in Britain Bureau, the US$2 million-expansion, which will add 150 people to the company's workforce, involves the establishment of a new 70,000 square-foot plant.
Steven Linn, Inventec's director in Scotland, said he is happy to have access to a highly skilled workforce and excellent transport links in the Renfrewshire area.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEES FEWER ASIAN TOURISTS THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Mainland China has become a fast-growing tourist market for Australia, while the number of tourists coming from Hong Kong and Taiwan remain significant even in the wake of the Asian financial crisis, according to the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC).

ATC Managing Director John Morse said in statement Friday that strong inbound tourism growth from both emerging markets, including mainland China, and traditional ones have helped offset the impact of softening Asian markets.

In the first seven months of this year, 45,080 mainland Chinese tourists visited Australia, an increase of 26.5 percent over the same period last year. Meanwhile, arrivals from Taiwan rose nearly 1 percent to 98,915 during the same period as compared with year-earlier levels. The number coming from Hong Kong, however, fell 7 percent to 87,648.
Morse said the slump in Hong Kong tourists was more strongly pronounced at the beginning of this year and that the number coming to Australia has since picked up.

In the first seven months of this year, Australia attracted nearly 2.34 million foreign tourists, down 5 percent from the same 1997 period, he said. Australia's broad tourism marketing strategy enables the industry to withstand a slowdown from any single region, he added.
Arrivals from Australia's largest tourist market, Japan, dropped 6.2 percent to 440,657 in the first seven months of this year compared with year-earlier levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S POPULATION MUST INCREASE: ANALYST

TEXT.P: Australia requires a population of 50 million people to keep pace with technological developments and to develop companies sufficiently large and smart enough to survive the rigors of globalization in the next century, according to John White, chief executive of Visy Industries.

White told the enVision 1998 forum in Melbourne this week that a domestic market of 25 million people would not sustain the technological development needed by Australia to keep pace with Asia or the rest of the world.
The 50-million population figure has also been cited as necessary to the country by Brisbane Lord Mayor Jim Surley, Victoria Premier Jeff Kennett and several academic scholars.
As of March 1998, Australia's population totaled only 18.7 million, smaller even than the 21.1 million population of Taiwan, which is 220 times smaller in size than Australia.
White said Australian companies must develop their own technologies and foster the creation of large companies to survive in this era of globalization.
Globalization means the domination of markets by large US companies, not free trade, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER ON OVERSEAS VISIT

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu has left for an overseas trip, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee confirmed on Friday, without divulging the country or countries Hu is to visit.

Lee said only that Hu is going to a country which does not maintain formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, and pointed out that "as the country does not maintain official ties with the ROC, we cannot divulge any details at the moment."
Despite a thaw in relations across the Taiwan Strait, mainland China has not eased off in its efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international community.

"In the face of Beijing's persistent diplomatic strangulation strategy against the ROC, we cannot simply stay at home, and must instead step boldly into the world arena to forge friendships and relationships with as many countries as possible," said Lee.
He would not elaborate on how many countries Hu will visit during his trip. "The minister's itinerary has not yet been finalized, but his overseas visit will not last for long," he said.

Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said the ministry will brief the press on where Hu has visited, and who he has met, as well as the main purposes of his visit, after he has returned to Taiwan.
Beijing refuses to recognize the ROC's sovereignty, and is very sensitive to Taiwan's engagements with countries which recognize mainland China.

Against this background, senior ROC officials have often kept their overseas travel plans secret, particularly in regard to countries which do not maintain official ties with Taipei. In some cases, ROC officials have been forced to cancel their scheduled overseas trips simply because of strong protests to the host country by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE LOGISTIC COMMAND RECEIVES AS9000 CERTIFICATION

TEXT.P: The Air Force Second Logistic Command in the central Taiwan city of Taichung on Friday became the first Republic of China military unit to receive AS9000 quality certification.

Maj. Gen. Wu Hu-sheng, commander of the logistic command, received the certificate of quality from Tsai Tung-yi, representative in Taiwan of the US-based Bell International Certification Co., in a ceremony held in Taichung to mark the achievement.

AS9000 certification is based on the Aerospace Basic Quality System jointly worked out by the US Department of Defense, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Federal Aviation Administration last year.

The new certification system, patterned after ISO9000 which certifies the quality of general industrial products and commercial services, is aimed at standardizing product and service quality in the newly flourishing aerospace industry.
Wu said the military has for some time consistently asked all of its technological units to meet ISO9000 standards of quality.

"After the AS9000 quality certification system for the aerospace industry was unveiled last year, we stepped up our efforts to further improve our product and service quality to meet its requirements," Wu said, adding that the logistic command's acquisition of AS9000 certification indicates that its efforts over the past year have paid off.

With aerospace-related engineering technology, products and services becoming ever more complicated, Wu said, military logistic units should devote even more effort to quality control in importing, designing and manufacturing aerospace facilities and relevant equipment to prevent mishaps and ensure smooth combat preparedness.

Meanwhile, the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology has signed an agreement with Bell on certifying product and service quality of military logistic and professional service units over the next three years.

Under the terms of the contract, Bell will only collect document fees while exempting all other service charges for certifying work quality of ROC military logistic and professional units. This will help save the ROC military coffers more than NT$10 million annually.
Bell said its generous offer is aimed mainly at helping promote the ROC military's modernization and professionalism.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 84.57 points to close at 7,101.46.
Encouraged by a surge on the New York Stock Exchange, the bourse opened at 7,046.94 points, 30.05 higher than Thursday's close, and continued its upward move until the closing bell.

A total of 2.15 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.65 billion, increasing from the previous trading session which saw 1.59 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$62.71 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only bank and insurance stocks remained unchanged.

All other major categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.2 percent, both cement stocks and plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1.1 percent, construction stocks at 0.2 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures were higher as well.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for November moved up 70 points to close at 7,035, with 2,302 contract transactions.
The TAIEX Index Futures for December rose 71 points to finish at 7,020, while March futures increased 38 points to 6,956, and June futures moved up 50 points, closing at 6,950.
Contract transactions for the three futures totaled 103, 13, and five, respectively. No transactions were registered for September futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 6,965 for November; 6,949 for December; 6,918 for March; 6,900 for June; and 6,889 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.055 against the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 32.47.
The local currency opened at 32.48, and was traded between 32.4 and 32.515.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$581 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, THAILAND INITIAL TAX EXEMPTION PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Thailand finally initialed an agreement on Friday on exempting double taxation on investors from both countries.
The Double Taxation Agreement (DTA) with Thailand was struck after five rounds of talks spanning more than seven years.

The final round of negotiations opened in Bangkok on Wednesday, with Sam D.S. Wang, director-general of the Taxation Department under the ROC's Ministry of Finance, and Sanit Rangnoi, director-general of the Thai government's Revenue Department, serving as chief negotiators.
As the ROC doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties with Thailand, the two sides have spent much time mending their differences over some technical issues, including the title of the agreement.
"We have finally managed to reach agreement based on three key principles -- promoting mutual investment, mutual tax exemption and boosting friendship," Wang said.
The agreement is still pending the approval and ratification of the govenrments and legislatures of the two countries.

After the accord takes effect, Wang said, the tax burden for Taiwan investors in Thailand will be reduced, and vice versa. "The exemption of double taxation is expected to help stimulate Taiwan entrepreneurs' interest in investing in Thailand and may also attract Thai companies, particularly those owned by ethnic Chinese business people, to invest in Taiwan," Wang added.

Similar double taxation exemption agreements the ROC has signed with Singapore, Indonesia, New Zealand, Australia, Vietnam and South Africa have already taken effect. In addition, Taiwan has also initialed similar TDAs with Swaziland, the Gambia, Poland, Paraguay, Malaysia and Thailand, which are still pending legislative approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION IN JAPAN EXPLAINS STANCE ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: A visiting Taiwan expert in cross-Taiwan Strait affairs said Thursday that Taiwan regards the recent Koo-Wang meetings as a constructive beginning to cross-strait dialogue.
Tsan chih-hung, deputy secretary of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) made the remarks while explaining Taiwan's view of the meetings to around 50 local and foreign journalists in Tokyo.

Tsan, along with Tseng Yung-hsien, an advisor to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, and Chang Jung-kung, director general of the Kuomintang's Mainland Research Department, are on a five-day visit to Japan to report on the results of the Oct. 14-19 "ice-melting trip" to mainland China by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
The SEF is a quasi-official organization founded in 1991 by the ROC authorities to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links.

During the 90-minute press conference, Tsan explained Taiwan's next step will be to revive regular cross-strait exchanges, and to plan for a visit by Wang to Taiwan next year, as well as to enhance services for the people of both sides.

Commenting on the meetings, one Japanese political observer expressed his disagreement with the view that Taipei can persuade Beijing to give up the threat of using military power against Taiwan and that it can bring about democracy on the mainland merely by talking.

Chang said he agreed with the doubt, noting that late Beijing leader Deng Xiaoping's reluctance to renounce the use of military force against the island is deeply rooted among the mainland leadership. "It's very difficult for them to change," said the expert in China affairs.

Nevertheless, Chang pointed out that mainland China now needs a peaceful environment in order to carry out economic reforms, while the Taipei authorities are at the same time devoted to easing the tense cross-strait relations.
Although enormous differences still exist between the two sides, efforts have been made on both sides to obtain a better mutual understanding, Chang said.

In reply to a question on whether cross-strait relations will deteriorate after Beijing shows its attempt to undermine Taiwan's position in the international community during President Jiang Zemin's November visit to Japan, Tseng answered that as far as Japan is concerned, the Taiwan sovereignty problem is clearly set out in the 1945 Potsdam Declaration, under which Taiwan was returned by the defeated Japan to the Republic of China.

Echoing Tseng's words, Chang said that public opinion polls in Taiwan show that despite Beijing's strong pressure, most Taiwan people still hold to the idea that the ROC on Taiwan should not stop trying to carve out its international space.
Beijing's pressure can only raise the Taiwan people's unwillingness to reunify with mainland China, the expert said.
Following the press conference, the three-member delegation held talks with representatives from the Chinese society in Japan and the Japanese academic sector.
The delegation arrived in Tokyo on Monday, and visited several Japanese congressmen. The delegation flew back to Taiwan on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ONLY CHANCE FOR NEGOTIATIONS WITH BEIJING: ADVISOR
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Neil Lu)

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is the only leader in Taiwan who can provide Beijing with the chance of negotiations in the foreseeable future, a senior presidential advisor said on Thursday.
Tien Hung-mao said at a seminar at Stanford University that this is because of all Taiwan's senior officials, Lee enjoys the greatest amount of popular support.

The recent visit to mainland China by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), has seen the opening of an "indirect channel of communication" between the leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, said Tien, who is also president of the Taipei-based National Policy Research Institute.

He said that Koo, who is also a senior presidential adviser, was acting as a de facto envoy of the president in the mainland, otherwise he would not have been able to talk with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on national sovereignty and other political issues.

Dubbed an "ice-melting" trip, Koo visited Shanghai and Beijing from Oct. 14-19 to meet with his mainland counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan, Jiang, and Vice Premier Qian Qichen.
Tien said that Lee in turn will receive Wang when he comes to Taiwan in the near future.
Wang, known as a mentor of Jiang, has accepted an invitation from Koo to visit Taiwan at "an appropriate time."

He pointed out that the victory of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the last county magistrate and city mayoral elections has prompted both Washington and Beijing to consider the possibility of the DPP coming into power in the future, and other relevant issues.
This is one of the reasons Beijing allowed Koo's visit to take place, Tien said.

With regard to rumors that Beijing "has no expectations of Lee" as far as cross-strait ties are concerned, Koo's successful mainland trip can be indirectly interpreted as showing that Beijing has somehow changed its past strategy (of no contact with Lee), Tien said.

Given Lee's high reputation both domestically and intentionally, and the great support he has received from even the pro-independence camp, the president is currently the only Taiwan leader who can afford to provide Beijing with a chance of negotiations to improve ties, Tien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO VISIT 115 CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, who is concurrently chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, on Friday began a series of visits to all 115 candidates being fielded by the party to run in the yearend legislative elections.

Chang Hsiao-yen, KMT secretary-general, noted that Lee will spend more than one month on an islandwide trip to provide moral support for all the KMT candidates in their bids for the Legislative Yuan seats.
Lee started his trip by going to the election campaign headquarters of four KMT candidates in northern Taipei City in order to boost morale.
Chang pointed out that few leaders of other countries would personally visit all their candidates, and said the move has shown that the KMT chairman is deeply concerned about this year's elections.

In addition to Lee's islandwide morale-boosting tour, The KMT Department of Cultural Affairs is planning to hold a total of six huge evening parties in Taiwan's major cities. The first will be held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei on Dec. 31.

Chang said that the ruling party, which has never held any such pre-election parties in the past, is hoping to create a spirited atmosphere at the parties, in order to win more votes from women and young people, who are traditionally disinclined to vote for the ruling party.
The KMT secretary-general has also instructed KMT committees in various counties and townships to hold similar activities prior to or after the KMT anniversary, which falls on Nov. 24.

Chang stressed that many people have recognized that if the ruling party fails to win a majority in the year-end legislative elections, the situation in the Legislative Yuan will become de stabilized, which will lead to difficulties in the passing of important bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US SIGN EMC PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the United States on Thursday initialed an agreement on mutual recognition of electronic magnetism compatibility (EMC) certification.

After the agreement takes effect, it will mark the first time that the US Federal Communications Commission recognizes Taiwan's EMC certification for computers, audio-visual, medical and telecommunications equipment and other related facilities.
The EMC accord was initialed during the third annual meeting under the ROC-US Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) which opened in Washington, D.C. earlier this week.
The four-day meeting was jointly chaired by Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, and US Assistant Trade Representative Robert Cassidy.

Wu Hui-mei, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine, said billions worth of Taiwan-made information-technology products exported to the United States annually will no longer be subject to US EMC tests after the accord takes effect.
The EMC accord will be put into force after some legal formalities are completed.
Wu said the EMC pact is a key achievement of the current TIFA meeting.

The two sides also reached a consensus on the signing of an agreement on mutual recognition of telecommunications equipment certification under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum. Both Taiwan and the United States are APEC members.

Negotiators from both sides, however, failed to come to terms on issues related to Taiwan's intellectual property rights (IPR) protection measures and systems. Consequently, the US Trade Representative office has decided to retain Taiwan on its Special 301 "watch list" to pressure the island to take further steps to improve IPR protection.

During the working-level TIFA meeting, US negotiators also expressed concern about Taiwan's pharmaceutical and medical equipment pricing formula under its national health insurance program, the timetable for telecommunications services deregulation and the liberalization of its services market. Continued discussion on these issues is needed to mend bilateral differences, ROC delegates said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, EU TO HOLD INDUSTRIAL MEETING IN APRIL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and European Union will hold a joint industrial cooperation conference in April 1999 in Taipei, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said.
ROC representative to Belgium Huang Yen-chao and EU executive Magnus Lemmel met in Brussels on Friday to clear the way for the bilateral cooperation conference next year.

According to MOEA officials, ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and a ranking official of the European Commission, the executive body of the 15-member EU, will jointly preside over the opening ceremony of the conference.

The two sides will discuss issues related to the transportation, aviation, information, telecommunications and environmental protection industries to explore trade and investment opportunities for both sides, the MOEA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST TAKE PART IN INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The ROC deputy secretary general to President Lee Teng-hui, on Thursday stressed that the ROC must be allowed to take part in the international community.
Su Chi said that the diplomatic blockade by mainland China serves only to antagonize the people of the island.

Su, who was in the US capital to debrief the United States on the recently concluded high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, made the remarks at a seminar at the American Enterprise Institute (AEI).

He said that Beijing must realize the divided state of China, and that its allegation that Taiwan is trying to split the nation is completely wrong. He questioned Beijing's stance, pointing out that since the two sides are not even married, one side cannot be described as trying to divorce the other.
He also said that Beijing's lobbing of missiles and verbal intimidation is no way to create an environment conducive to good relations.

He said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should try to understand each other, so that both can unite willingly. For this reason, he said, bilateral relations should move at a gradual but steady pace.

Su said that 80 percent of the people of Taiwan have reached a consensus that the status quo should be maintained, Taiwan independence should not be declared, and unification with the mainland should not be rushed into.
At least 70 percent of the public also support Taiwan's participation in international affairs, even if the promotion of pragmatic diplomacy affects cross-strait relations, Su said.

Su said that the ROC is the 13th or 14th-largest trading nation in the world, and many other indicators show that the ROC is one of the top 20 nations in terms of national strength in the world. It is therefore entitled to play a more active role in the international community and to participate in international organizations, he added.
However, he stressed that this has nothing to do with Taiwan independence.

On the significance of the high-level cross-strait meeting, Su said that Taiwan believes that the meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, was a success.

The Koo-Wang meeting has improved the atmosphere on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, but it has also exposed big differences, although both sides also agreed to increase exchanges and dialogue, which Su said is a beneficial and constructive development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SECOND-MOST STABLE ASIAN STATE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the second-most stable country among 12 Asian states, behind only Singapore and tied with Japan, according to a survey by a Hong Kong-based consultancy.

The survey conducted by the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. (PERC) said that although unemployment is rising, Taiwan has been able to shield itself from the brunt of the Asian crisis, and public demonstrations arising from social and political issues have declined considerably on the island.
Taiwan was given a score of two on a scale from zero to 10, with zero the highest score. Last year, the island was ranked fourth, with a score of 3.59.

Although the Asian crisis has plunged many countries in the region into social turmoil, leading to some major reshuffling of the rankings, Singapore remains top with a score of 1.5. Japan ties with Taiwan with a score of two.
Taiwan, the Philippines and Vietnam all saw their rankings increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCUSATIONS FLY OVER MAINLAND CAMPAIGN FUNDS

TEXT.P: A New Party legislator accused of being recruited by Beijing in Taiwan's year-end elections said on Friday all evidence regarding such activity should be made public instead of being used as a smear tactic.

New Party Legislator Yok Mu-ming urged national security organizations to investigate whether there is capital from mainland China intervening in the Dec. 5 elections. If this is the case, then the evidence should be made public before the elections for legislators, Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors and councils are held.
He asked that investigators take a special look at those who have had close contact with China-owned enterprises.
Yok went on to accuse Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the KMT's Business Management Committee, of involvement in bribing mainland China's officials during his contact with China-owned enterprises.

There are close relations between the KMT's Liu and mainland Chinese-owned enterprises such as the China International Trust & Investment Corporation Group, and the China Venturetect Investment Corporation, Yok claimed.

Tsai Pi-huang, director-general of the Sun Yat-sen Institute on Policy Research and Development under the KMT, said on Thursday that the National Security Bureau and investigation organizations have confirmed charges made by Taipei City Councilor Lin Ruey-tu. Lin had earlier said mainland-owned enterprises are trying to intervene in the island's year-end elections.
Those who have accepted mainland funds are not restricted to candidates of the party Lin cited, Tsai added.
Responding to Tsai's accusations, Yok demanded that Tsai clarify which party he believes is guilty of accepting mainland money.

Seeing as security and intelligence organizations have found evidence of intervention efforts by mainland-owned enterprises in the year-end elections, then why have they not taken any actions in the matter instead of letting the city councilor and KMT official make all the allegations, Yok questioned.
He demanded the relevant government bodies during the legislature session make efforts to collect all the evidence and publish it before the elections take place.
Yok went a step further and requested that election offices under the Interior Ministry cancel the eligibility of candidates found guilty of accepting mainland funds.

As for Taipei City Councilor Lin's allegation that Yok is an "operative" of Beijing, Yok said the mainland-issued ID Lin offered as evidence should be examined by the Ministry of Justice for authenticity. Yok said he would take appropriate action himself after the investigation.

Taipei City Councilor Lin Ruey-tu, an independent, on Wednesday accused New Party lawmaker Yok Mu-ming of having been recruited by Beijing with the aim of toppling Taiwan's economy. To back up his claim, Lin furnished a faxed document suggesting that Yok is in Beijing's employ and that the mainland government has a list of specific Taiwan companies whose operations it hopes to destabilize.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S WIFE VISITS JAPAN

TEXT.P: Lien Fang Yu, wife of Vice President Lien Chan, left for Tokyo on Thursday for a five-day private visit to Japan.
The vice president's office did not disclose Mrs. Lien's schedule in Japan, but said she will return on Wednesday and that Lien did not see her off at the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU CURBS ON ANTIBIOTICS TO BE ACCELERATED

TEXT.P: The European Commission will bring forward proposals for restricting the use of some antibiotics in animal feed amid fears that human health is being endangered, the World Trade Organization (WTO) reported on Friday.

Franz Fischler, the farm commissioner, said the European Commission did not expect to have the final results of tests on beef hormones by May, a deadline imposed by the WTO on the EU to comply with a ruling that a ban on beef hormones was unjustified.
His statement will heighten speculation that the EU will push for a continuation of the 10-year hormone ban, claiming support from the scientific tests, the WTO report said.

The EU has been given until May 13 to implement a ruling that a 10-year ban on beef hormones is inconsistent with its WTO obligations. The US, which took the case to the WTO, argues this means the ban must be implemented.
However, the commission has said lifting the ban is not automatic and its action in May will depend on the scientific studies.
The commission announced its plan for antibiotic restrictions after calls by Denmark, Sweden and Finland for a ban on the use of all antibiotic growth promoters in animal feed.

Environmentalists and a growing number of scientists believe that the use of antibiotics in animal feed harms human health because when passed through the food chain, they weaken resistance to antibiotics used in medicines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM ACCUSES JAPANESE FIRM OF BREACHING CONTRACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Petrochemical Development Corp. (CPDC) on Friday accused Japan's Marubeni Petroleum Co. of breaching a contract, saying it will consider taking legal action against the Japanese firm.
CPDC Chairman Kuan Yung-shih said his company signed a contract in September to buy 32,000 metric tons of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) from Marubeni Petroleum Co.
The LPG was to be delivered to Huahsing Petroleum Chemical Co., a CPDC subsidiary in Fujian province, between Oct. 27 and Nov. 4.
Kuan said without his company's consent, the Japanese firm resold the LPG allocated for Huahsing Petroleum Chemical Co. to a third buyer, apparently for higher profits.
Kuan was originally scheduled to preside over a ceremony marking the delivery of the Marubeni LPG at the Fujian subsidiary company on Nov. 1.
Owing to the breach of contract on Marubeni's part, Kuan said the Fujian company will be unable to deliver related products to its clients on time, seriously damaging his company's credibility.
Kuan visited the Taipei office of the quasi-official Japan Interchange Association on Friday to lodge a protest and seek the institution's help in solving the problem.
However, the deputy director of the association, Takashi Inoue, said as a quasi-official institution, his association was not in a position to interfere in business operations.
Kuan said his company will discuss the case with attorneys and consider whether to file a lawsuit against Marubeni.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA: NO FORMAL ANNOUNCEMENT ON CHANGE OF TIES FROM TONGA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has not received a confirmation over the reports that the Kingdom of Tonga is ready to sever its diplomatic ties with the Republic of China, the ministry said on Friday.
If Tonga does issue a formal statement on its intention to switch diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing, MOFA will issue a quick, effective and appropriate response, a ministry official said.
According to an AFP report from Auckland, New Zealand earlier on Friday, Tonga is planning to make a switch in diplomatic ties.

"The move, made by the new Foreign Minister, Prince 'Ulukalala Lavaka Ata, ends a long running dream of his father, King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV, to be the only state to achieve diplomatic ties with both China and Taiwan," the report said.

Commenting on the report, MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the ministry has instructed the ROC embassy in Tonga to confirm the report, but the Tonga government has not made any formal announcement on the matter.

Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Jason Hu is reportedly on his way to an unnamed country which maintains diplomatic relations with Beijing. Wu denied that Hu's trip has any direct relationship with the Tonga issue.

Replying to questions why the ROC would respond only after Beijing or Tonga make their formal announcements, Wu said the ROC values each of its allies and will not easily abandon them until the last minute. However, he added, Beijing has never ceased in its pressure to isolate the ROC in the international arena.

The MOFA official also urged Beijing to clarify three incidents concerning its diplomatic isolation strategy against the ROC if it claims to have goodwill and sincerity in cross-strait negotiations and dialogue. He added that now is the time for negotiation, not confrontation.

On Oct. 17, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee asked mainland authorities to clarify a report that said immediately prior to Koo Chen-Fu's departure for the mainland they had used every possible means to tempt one of the ROC's allies to forge official ties with Beijing within two weeks of Koo's return to Taiwan.

Despite any setbacks, the ROC will continue to try to make friends in the international community, try to turn an enemy into a friend, and will offer its own experiences to developing countries for reference, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO US SPEAKS ON TAIPEI-BEIJING-WASHINGTON TIES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By J. J. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Beijing's "one China, two systems" formula for Hong Kong does not suit Taiwan, and the people of Taiwan will not accept such a scheme, Stephen Chen, the ROC's representative to the United States, said on Thursday.

The Republic of China is willing to consider unification with mainland China on a gradual basis under the framework of freedom, democracy and prosperity, Chen said in a speech at a seminar sponsored by the Boston-based Foreign Policy Institute. More than 100 people attended the event.

The two sides of the Taiwan Strait currently are two independent political entities under separate rule, and wide differences remain in each other's political systems and the way of life, Chen said. However, he added that the existence of differences is not tantamount to separatism or independence.

In compliance with the National Unification Guidelines, Taiwan is willing to share its democratization experience with the mainland by boosting bilateral cultural and economic exchanges as a means of pursuing China's eventual unification.

The ROC de-facto ambassador said Taiwan is not opposed to the US government's engagement with mainland China as long as it is helpful to regional stability and world peace. But the US government should also take Taiwan's interests and position into account in the process, he added.

Chen pointed out that Washington should maintain a parallel relationship with Taipei while seeking to improve its ties with Beijing. He said he believes Taiwan can play a positive role in US engagement with mainland China, as bilateral Taiwan-mainland exchanges are close.

The people of Taiwan have mailed more than 100 million letters over the past decade and paid more than 12 million visits to the mainland since the ROC government lifted a ban on travel to mainland China in 1987, Chen noted.

But he lamented mainland China's reluctance to denounce the use of force against Taiwan. The US' decision to continue selling defensive arms to the island in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act is extremely important to Taiwan's security under such circumstances, he added.
Chen urged the international community to deal the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on an equal footing, which he said will help bring about China's unification in the long run and boost world peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER GERMAN CHANCELLOR ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt arrived in Taipei on Friday for a five-day visit at the invitation of the New Environment Foundation and the China Times.

While here, Schmidt will deliver three keynote speeches on Germany's economic development and environmental protection as well as the impact of the euro, the single currency of the European Union to be introduced next year, on Asian economies.
Schmidt served as chancellor of the former West Germany from 1974 to 1982. He took up a career in journalism after stepping down from the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WITHDRAWS DIPLOMATIC FROM KINSHASA BUT KEEPS OFFICE

TEXT.P: Taiwan evacuated staff from its representative office in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo in August out of safety concerns but did not close it, foreign ministry officials said on Friday.

The two ROC staff as well as six fellow Chinese left Kinshasa aboard a small chartered plane in mid-August as rebel troops were closing in on the capital and western diplomats were fleeing the county.
They ended up in Libreville, Gabon after a stopover in the Congo's Brazzaville, said the officials who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The Foreign Ministry is reviewing whether to keep its Kinshasa representative office given the absence of official ties and rare civil exchanges between the two countries as well as the frequent political upheavals in the Democratic Republic of Congo, but no decision has been made and the office was withdrawn rather than closed.

Beijing's Xinhua news agency reported earlier on Friday that mainland China welcomes the Democratic Republic of Congo's decision to close Taipei's representative office in Kinshasa, praising it as a proof of the Democratic Republic of Congo's commitment to its "one China" policy.
Kinshasa forged diplomatic ties with Beijing in 1972, however, it allowed Taipei to open a representative office there in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOWNSIZING OF PROVINCIAL GOVT TO BE COMPLETED IN THREE STAGES

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will complete the downsizing operations of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG) in three stages, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.
Under a provisional statute promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui on Oct. 28, the TPG will be downsized to become an assigned institution of the Cabinet from Dec. 21 this year.
Premier Siew said the Cabinet's plan is to implement the provisional statute in three stages as follows:

-- From Dec. 21, 1998 to June 30, 1999, the Cabinet will appoint the provincial governor and establish a provincial council. During this period, the current departments and bureaus will remain unchanged temporarily. The governor will be in charge of drafting the transitional budget and related administrative matters.

-- From July 1, 1999 to Dec. 31, 2000, the Cabinet will complete streamlining operations of the TPG's functions, organizations and personnel. The Cabinet will also draft the organizational statute of the provincial government.
-- From Jan. 1, 2001, the downsizing of the TPG will reach the final stage.

Asked about his choice for provincial governor, Premier Siew said the governor should have a wealth of administrative experience and capability. He said the Cabinet has not yet made a final decision on the selection of the governor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG) will be carried out in three stages.
The China Times: Premier Vincent Siew said the TPG downsizing will be implemented in three stages.
The United Daily News: G-7 will offer US$90 billion in relief fund to help battered economies.
The Liberty Times: The TPG will be downsized in three stages; a new system will be instated from 2001.
The Independence Morning Post: A check default crisis is mounting as the domestic economy continues to deteriorate.
The China Post: Swedish disco inferno kills 63 teenagers.
The China News: Luo Chieh Construction Group is in trouble.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXCHANGES VIEWS WITH EU ON STEEL TRADE ISSUES

TEXT.P: Taiwan representatives exchanged views on Friday with their European Union (EU) counterparts over steel trade issues

The dialogue, conducted through the newly established EU dialogue mechanism on steel, was in two parts, with China Steel Corporation President Wang Chung-yu meeting with European steel industry representatives, while an economic official from Taiwan's representative office in Brussels met with his EU counterpart.

The meeting stemmed from complaints filed by some European steelmakers against alleged dumping by some Asian steelmakers, including some from Taiwan. Wang tried to explain how Taiwan sets its steel prices which he said are not unreasonably low, and do not threaten the European steel industry.
An official from Taipei said it is hoped that the biannual dialogue which will be held alternately in Taipei and Brussels will help prevent future trade disputes.

European steel industry officials are alarmed that Asian states, mainly Taiwan, mainland China, South Korea, India, and Iran, exported 285,000 tons of steel per month to Europe in the first half of this year, compared to only 40,000 tons per month one year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HEALTH AUTHORITY ATTENDS MEDICAL CONFERENCE IN VATICAN
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's highest health authority on Friday introduced Taiwan's long-term care project for senile people at the International Medical Treatment Conference in the Holy See.
Chan Chi-hsien, director-general of the Republic of China Department of Health, said the project will benefit over 50,000 aged persons suffering from chronic illness around the island.

The three-day conference, which opened on Thursday, was attended by representatives of health authorities from all over the world, who discussed issues related to the topic of "churches and the elderly."
Chan expressed gratitude at the meeting for the long-term efforts of the Catholic church in upgrading the island's medical services.
Chan arrived in Rome on Monday, and visited his Italian counterpart Rosy Bindi on Wednesday to exchange experiences on the establishment of national health care systems.
During the meeting, Chan also expressed the hope of enhancing medical cooperation with Italy and the rest of the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIAL: RELATIONS WITH BEIJING WON'T HURT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A White House official stressed on Friday that the United States strongly supports cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue, and that better relations between the United States and Beijing will not come at Taiwan's expense.

In an address at the National Press Club in Washington, National Security Adviser Samuel Berger said: "Obviously we strongly support a cross-strait dialogue, and there have been some steps in recent months ... that have been constructive."

But he went on: "This is a matter, obviously, for the people in China and Taiwan to resolve themselves in a peaceful fashion. So we have encouraged all involved to be forthcoming and constructive about that dialogue."

The policy of engagement that the Clinton administration has pursued over the past three years has improved US relations with mainland China, the national security adviser said, adding: "There are still many areas where we have serious differences with the Chinese, but we confront those differences directly with them, face to face."
However, Berger stressed: "In my judgment, better relations between the United States and Beijing do not come at the expense of our relationship with the people of Taiwan."

Over the past 20 years the United States has had generally improving relations with China, and its relationship with Taiwan has also flourished. This has been good for stability in the region and it has been good for both Taiwan and China, "so I think these things do not have to come at the expense of one another," he said.

Berger emphasized that "the cornerstone of our Asia policy remains our longstanding alliance with Japan. A healthy Japan is indispensable for the stability and prosperity of Asia and, indeed, the entire world."

But he said the role mainland China plays "will have a profound impact on the new century, for better or for worse. The president (Bill Clinton)'s trip to China in June advanced important American interests, from seeking peace in Korea to reducing weapons proliferation, to promoting cleaner technologies for our environment."
Berger added that Clinton has not hesitated to speak frankly in mainland China, to say clearly that when it comes to human rights, mainland China remains on the wrong side of history.

Although the US strategy of engagement has brought results, Berger admitted that there is still far to go. Mainland China continues to jail dissidents, even as it has signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. "But China is becoming more open, not just to commerce but to ideas, and our engagement is helping to empower the Chinese people as they seek more freedom," he said.
A strategy of confrontation, by contrast, would likely push mainland China toward isolation, "undermining our hopes for greater democracy and stability in Asia," added Berger.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ANNOUNCES SEVERANCE OF DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH TONGA (I)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China announced on Saturday that it has decided to sever its diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga, effective Nov. 2, 1998.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) made the announcement at a news conference hosted by ministry spokesman Roy Wu.
Wu said the ROC has also decided to terminate all agreements and cooperation with the South Pacific island nation and to recall its ambassador.

Wu read a prepared MOFA press statement which condemned Beijing for its incessant efforts to obstruct the ROC's diplomatic relations by enticing and menacing Taiwan's allies. Such moves indicate that the mainland Chinese authorities lack goodwill or sincerity in improving relations across the Taiwan Strait, the statement said.

MOFA issued the statement after the Tonga foreign minister formally announced at 8 a.m. on Saturday (Taipei time) that his country will switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Monday.

Tonga will be the fourth ROC ally to switch diplomatic allegiance so far this year, following the lead of South Africa, the Central African Republic, and Guinea-Bissau. With the loss of Tonga, the ROC now has just 26 diplomatic allies.

The MOFA statement said Tonga, in a breach of good faith, succumbed to the enticement of the Beijing regime and decided to develop full relations since King Taufa'Ahau Tupou IV made a visit to the Chinese mainland in July 1997.

The ROC government has made every effort, including inviting the King of Tonga to Taiwan in both July 1997 and July 1998, and inviting Princess Salote Mafile'o Pilolevu Tuita in October 1998, to try to dissuade them from having further contact with the Chinese communist authorities. However, despite its best efforts, the government failed to change the course of events, the statement said.

"Based on its national sovereignty," the statement said, "the ROC government holds that the intention and action of the Tongan government has seriously damaged its national interests. To express its firm position, the ROC government must hereby undertake the above-mentioned resolute measures."

The statement went on to say that in recent years the ROC authorities have appealed more than a hundred times to the Beijing authorities to resume normal interaction between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

"In fact, before SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's recent visit to the Chinese mainland, the ROC canceled a military exercise to show its goodwill and to create a `win-win' situation for both sides," the statement said, adding: "Unfortunately, in response, the Chinese communist authorities continued to demonstrate two-faced tactics."

The statement pointed out that communist China has never ceased its efforts to restrict the ROC's international space. On the one hand, it plays to the international community by ostensibly seeking peace talks with Taiwan, while on the other it obstructs the ROC's diplomatic relations by enticing and menacing ROC allies.

"The Kingdom of Tonga is a case in point," the statement said, adding that ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei denied on Oct. 15 that Beijing intended to dislodge all ROC allies by the year 2000, yet before Koo's departure for a mainland visit on Oct. 14, the Chinese communist authorities had been aggressively planning to establish diplomatic relations with Tonga within a week of Koo's visit.
"This indicates that the Chinese communist authorities have no goodwill or sincerity in improving their relations with us," the statement said.

Faced with this situation, the statement said, the ROC government and people will continue to expand their activities in the international sphere with even greater resolve and pragmatism, to the extent necessary for their continued existence and development.

The ROC established diplomatic ties with Tonga in April 1972, and set up an embassy with a charge d'affaires in that country's capital of Nukualofa in June 1975. There has been a resident ROC ambassador in Tonga since 1977.
Over the past years, the ROC has extended many kinds of assistance to Tonga, including the services of an agricultural technical mission. (By Sofia Wu) (TO BE CONTINUED)

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR CANADA CUTTING 1,000 JOBS

TEXT.P: Air Canada will be cutting at least 1,000 jobs before the end of the year, its chief executive officer, Lamar Durrett, announced on Friday.

Durrett said the company is looking for ways to cut costs because of a two-week pilot strike last month which cost the company more than C$200 million (US$130 million). Air Canada lost C$61 million in the third quarter of this year.

About one-third of the cuts will involve full-time workers. Many of these jobs will be eliminated through early retirement packages. The other two-thirds, mostly part-time jobs, will involve voluntary leave of absence, until the airline's finances improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WILL ALLOW MORE URANIUM MINING

TEXT.P: The Australian government is determined to go ahead with plans to allow uranium mining near the Kakadu National Park in Northern Territory and to disregard the findings of an on-the-spot inspection by a UN delegation.

Environment Minister Richard Hill on Friday reaffirmed the government's determination to allow the uranium mining even if the UN delegation declares the Kakadu National Park area in danger due to the mining at Jabiluka, about 20 km from the park.

The fears of endangering Kakadu Park were raised at the UN by Aboriginal traditional owners, scientists, heritage experts and conservationists, but the government on Friday remained unmoved by their concerns.

"We have said that we believe the (UN) mission is unnecessary. We take our world heritage responsibilities seriously. In fact I know of no other country in the world which does as much as we do to meet the spirit of those responsibilities as well as following the letter of the convention," Hill said.
Australia is one of leading uranium producers and exporters in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA URGES INDONESIA TO REDUCE TROOPS IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has urged Indonesia to reduce its troops in East Timor or face problems in its peace negotiations after leaked documents showed an increase in troop numbers in the former Portuguese colony.
Downer told Australian reporters that he has argued for more than two years that a reduction in Indonesian troop numbers is an important component in any confidence-building process in East Timor.

Speculation mounted in Canberra on Friday that a new push to destabilize Indonesian President B.J. Habibie could be behind the leak in Jakarta of confidential Indonesian military documents revealing details of troop numbers in East Timor.

Australian officials said they were not surprised by disclosures in the documents that the troop numbers were much higher than claimed by Indonesia's most senior officials. None of them doubted the authenticity of the documents.

However, Indonesia's Department of Foreign Affairs said officials were checking the authenticity of the documents which showed that 17,834 troops were stationed in East Timor as of August, an increase in numbers despite highly publicized troop withdrawals the previous month.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL LANDMARKS THAT ARE BOOKSTORES AND SO MUCH MORE

TEXT.P: When Robert C.Y. Wu started the first Eslite bookstore back in 1989, selling books limited to mainly the arts and humanities, he was thinking only of sharing his interests and "good things" with friends.

After all, Wu, already a self-made millionaire through his highly successful business of selling catering equipment and supplies to top-notch hotels, restaurants, hospitals, and other large institutions, was dabbling in a completely unfamiliar field.

But Wu has seen his bookstores, unconventional by Taiwan standards, grow and flourish, and is expecting a sales turnover this year of NT$1.6 billion (US$49.23 million), the first time in a decade that his brainchild will have broken even after years in the red.
The 48-year-old entrepreneur, sitting by a large sparkling window in his spacious, elegant office, says that he is planning to list Eslite on the local stock market in between three and five years.

Despite the applause and plaudits he has received from all sides over the years, Wu's feelings are mixed. On the one hand, he says, he is happy, but on the other, he is worried that Taiwan still lacks a cultural establishment to match its economic clout.

Tall, urbane, and always impeccably dressed, Wu peers gently through his spectacles and says modestly: "I was only lucky enough to be able to put my ideals into practice, and still win some accolades."

From the outset, no one expected Eslite to make money, and indeed it did lose money, even as it build its enviable reputation. However, Wu is tenacious -- a trait he says he inherited from his father -- and admits that he was also a little curious himself as to how long his project would last.

When the first Eslite opened its doors on March 20, 1989 on the posh Jenai Circle in the heart of downtown Taipei, it created an instant phenomenon and became a new landmark in Taipei that people wanted to introduce to all their friends.

The first store was devoted mainly to the selling of imported books on fine arts, design and architecture, becoming the first store in Taiwan to excel in both quality and quantity in the field of humanities and the arts, although it was also a gallery, and sold stationery, imported porcelain and ceramics, furniture, and antiques.
The shop, with its cozy atmosphere but spatial design, was a world away from the cramped and musty confines of traditional local bookstores, and soon became a hangout for the local artistic set.

Although it seemed to cater only to a small coterie of clientele, the shop lured many browsers who just wanted to admire the unique bookstore that was an oasis of peace and refinement in the gray concrete drabness of Taiwan's largest city.
Since then, the Eslite name and the distinctive "three squares" logo have become synonymous with discreet style and refined taste.

Wu, however, insists that appearances are unimportant, and says "the most exhilarating part of the store will invariably be its patrons. It is not the store that is tasteful, it is our patrons who are naturally polite and gentle when they step inside, and that is what graces all our shops."

In a way, Eslite seeks not only to cater to its patrons, it wants to pamper them, in the hope that the store will become a "third" place after the office and the home where the public can enjoy spending time.
Wu stresses that a bookstore should not be just a place for the buying and selling of books. "It should impart a feeling of pleasant space and good people around you."

He points out that many of those who step into an Eslite bookstore have no intention of buying a book, but are seeking rather to soak up some of the tranquil atmosphere, a welcome panacea against the stresses of urban life.

The first priority of a bookstore is of course a rich collection of books, he says. Each book sold by Eslite is still carefully selected, and the titles are diversified to meet the needs of a pluralistic society. The flagship Eslite store on tony Tunhua South Road boasts 65,000 titles, and over 1,000 magazines, the largest collection of magazines in Taipei. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL LANDMARKS THAT ARE BOOKSTORES AND SO MUCH MORE (II)

TEXT.P: Eslite is committed to making every one who enters the shop feel good. For this reason, Wu believes that a pleasant space is imperative. Convinced that local designers are highly talented, and that Eslite should be a stage where they can display their talents and creativity, he has commissioned many, including Chen Juei-hsien, Lin Zhou-min and Yao Jen-Hsi, to undertake the interior design of the shops.
Although modern and sophisticated spatial design is one of the oft-cited features of Eslite, Wu is also careful that each branch has its own individual style, with its own distinctive atmosphere.

For example, he says, the Hsimenting branch with its hip, avant garde style, differs from the Tunhua main branch, which is elegant and graceful, and different again from the National Taiwan University branch, which is simple, yet no less delightful.
The individuality doesn't stop with the design, however. "Each Eslite also has a different title mix, a different scale, and caters to a different set of readers," says Wu.

For example, there is a manga section targeted at teenagers in the Hsimenting branch, a hangout for the young and trendy, while the title mix in the suburban Tienmu branch and the NTU branch have an overlap of no more than 50 percent, reflecting the different clientele in each shop -- the former targets the local community where there is a high percentage of expatriates, while the latter is patronized mainly by students from the nearby university.

Wu is vehemently opposed to any attempt to "MacDonaldize" the operation of his bookstores, with each identically designed outlet selling the same uniform products. "We are different and unconventional," he stresses.
Even if it is simply a poster to promote an Eslite activity, it has to be designed in a creative, humorous, off-beat, and unorthodox way, he says.

Wu goes to great length to explain that all the efforts are to ingratiate its readers so that they will enjoy their visits. Consideration of the comfort and convenience of the patrons is evident in each Eslite, perhaps most notably in the provision of sloping ramps built between each floor to help the movement of the disabled, mini bookshelves in the children's sections, and connecting pathways between the children and adult sections to allow parents to watch over their children while they browse.

Each Eslite is ideally divided into five sections, according to Wu -- books, stationery, a cafe, a gallery, and the "Eslite Vision" (activity center). While this format is shared, any other similarities end there.
"Eslite has never intended to promote a `metropolis culture,'" Wu says. Rather, each branch identifies closely with local color and culture, and hopes to contribute to local cultural development.

Wu harbors a fervent love for his country, and does not want his shops to simply win the applause of the local people, but is determined to ensure that each Eslite makes a positive contribution to local cultural development.

He cites as an example the Eslite branch in the northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu, which has a section dedicated to information on local features, personalities, and locally related publications, prominently displayed at the entrance of the store.

He stresses the importance of the galleries and the Eslite Vision centers, noting that an estimated 450 activities will take place in the Tunhua South Road branch alone this year, including lectures, meetings, art exhibitions, performances, wine tastings, and related cultural activities.
Elaborating on his ideas of what Eslite should be, Wu says that he also wants the shop to play an active and positive role in the community.

He believes that Eslite should provide a place that enables interaction between an audience and performers. A place where the people of a community can participate and get a chance to meet each other, as well as have access to local literary and artistic information -- all these, he believes, are services that patrons now expect and deserve from an Eslite store.

Perhaps the most amazing thing about Eslite is that the bookstore was born in Taiwan -- it is a completely indigenous product. Although the store sells many books imported from the United States and Europe with the aim of nurturing a global vision for local readers, it does not cooperate or engage in any technology exchanges with any foreign bookstores.
Wu has often been asked how he accomplished this feat. "It may have started from a midlife crisis," he replies with tongue in cheek. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL LANDMARKS THAT ARE BOOKSTORES AND SO MUCH MORE (III)

TEXT.P: Wu graduated from the Department of Mechanic Engineering at the Taipei Institute of Technology, and joined a food-service equipment and supply company, the forerunner of Faithful Standard Group, at the age of 23.
A diligent man, he worked his way up from salesman to partner until finally taking over the company, amassing fame and fortune. He also witnessed Taiwan's rapid economic growth during the interim.

Although Faithful Standard Group was successful, and to this day still commands about an 80 percent share of the large-scale catering equipment market, Wu said he began to seriously question his life by the age of 35.
He said to himself: "Life is now pretty much routine. Do I want to continue with this kind of life for the rest of my life, day after day?"
Although he is considered aggressive, dynamic and optimistic by his peers, he says this kind of reflection used to leave him with a feeling of total emptiness and uncertainly.

He gradually realized that years of sustained focus and a high-stress lifestyle -- working 12-14 hour days to pursue the growing success of the company -- had drained him mentally and had alienated him from cultural and artistic activities.

"For years, I had focused on marketing and corporate management, and was a stranger to the arts," Wu says. This realization led him to get in touch with more cultural and artistic activities, beginning with music and architecture, then moving to painting and sculpture.
Although he did not understand what was before him, Wu let his intuition be his guide. Little by little, he not only felt invigorated, he also realized that a brand new world was opening up to him.
It was at this point that Wu made the decision to choose something he believed would give him a more meaningful life, even though it would not make him rich.

The opening of Eslite was the beginning of a dream. Wu realized clearly that the bookshop would not be a business that he could depend on for a livelihood, yet he devoted time and money on it "with all my heart."

"I did it willingly," Wu says, adding: "I couldn't be tight with money if I wanted Eslite to be a place and space that would help satisfy the needs and soothe the spirits of hundreds of thousands of people on Taiwan."

That is why he was, and is, meticulous in choosing only the best quality, and spending profusely to create a comfortable setting. Such a concept does not come cheaply, and defies the conventional wisdom in Taiwan at the time that every business should be completely profit-oriented.

By the end of this year, Eslite branches around the island will have increased to more than 20. Pointing to a demographic map of Taiwan showing the population and size of each county and town, Wu says solemnly: "I envision a total of 129 Eslites in Taiwan."

This expansion may come from his dream of influencing more people or, perhaps more importantly, influencing more influential people on the island with the belief that a fertile culture will nurture all other national development, whether it be political, technological, or economic.

He is optimistic that the reading population will grow rather than decline, pointing out that today, there are more young people on the island born after 1945 in peacetime. They have received higher levels of education than their predecessors, which, coupled with the island's rapid economic growth and a strong desire to learn and excel in the world, means that reading and lifelong learning will be a future trend.
He estimates that next year, there will be 20 million visits to Eslite bookstores, and that there will be five million transactions on books.

Looking back at the last 10 years in the trade, Wu says modestly: "There is still ample room for Eslite to improve." However, he is also quick to point out, with some pride, that the management of the company has been greatly improved.

Despite Wu's attachment to his land, and his decision to keep Taiwan as his main priority, Eslite is nevertheless thinking of making inroads into Hong Kong. (more) ZCZC CEP012 10-31-98 LOCAL LANDMARKS THAT ARE BOOKSTORES AND SO MUCH MORE (IV)

Wu says he wants to open Eslite branches in Hong Kong, not because Eslite has won praise from Chinese in Hong Kong, Singapore, and mainland China, but because Hong Kong is an international metropolis, and will give Eslite a unique chance to compete with its newly gained confidence in bookstore management.

Wu's desire to obtain a foothold in Hong Kong, however, is also part of a bigger picture, in that he is also eyeing the mainland market, and hoping the day will come when the ban on exchanges of publications between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will finally be lifted.
"Hopefully, I can open an Eslite in Hong Kong by the end of next year," he says.

After all, he points out, Eslite will have to brace for an impending onslaught in Taiwan by large-scale international book chains from companies such as France's FNAC and Japan's Kinokuniya, and has yet to prove whether it can excel in the face of such stiff competition. Photo captions: 1 Eslite founder Robert C.Y. Wu believes that more cultural establishments are needed in Taiwan to match the country's economic clout. 2 The design of Eslite's flagship shop on Tunhua South Road, in the upscale east section of downtown Taipei, emulates the style of a church and library combined to give it a pompous and elegant aura. Design by Yao Jen-hsi 3 One of the Eslite Tienmu branches has a casual atmosphere that appeals to the local community which has a high percentage of expatriates among its population. Design by Chen Juei-hsien 4 Wu considers a gallery to be an important part of the Eslite experience. 5 The Eslite NTU branch uses less expensive materials for its interior design, but is no less delightful to its patrons. Design by Chen Juei-hsien 6 An Eslite branch located in a department store in Taichung, central Taiwan, features a lofty ceiling and circular bookshelves to create a feeling that books are the accumulation of human wisdom over thousands of years. DOC.HEADLINE: MOF APPROVES ESTABLISHMENT OF TAIWAN INDUSTRIAL BANK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Saturday approved the establishment of a Taiwan Industrial Bank, the first of its kind in Taiwan.
The planned bank is expected to be formally opened in about six months, according to the body charged with preparing for the launch.

Major investors are expected to include Chinatrust Group, China Steel Corp., Yi Chang Investment Corp., and the ADI Corporation. Total capital of about NT$23 billion (US$706 million) will be raised in order to establish the bank.

The preparatory body revealed that the former governor of the Central Bank of China, Samuel Hsieh, will be invited to chair the new bank, which will both provide medium- and long-term loans for manufacturing investments, as well as investing directly in the manufacturing sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose to a seven-month high on Saturday in trading on the Taipei market, prompted by inflow of foreign investments and the fact that a number of foreign currency depositors annulled their contracts.

The local currency climbed NT$0.02 against the US dollar to close at the day's low of NT$32.45. Dealers expect a further appreciation of the NT dollar next week amid a weakened greenback in international trading.
The NT dollar opened at NT$32.402 to the US dollar and rose as high as NT$32.351.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$250.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STOCK PRICES, FUTURES MOVE UP

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and ended high on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rising 64.52 points to close at 7,165.98.
The bourse opened at 7,142.52 and fluctuated between 7,170.69 and 7,111.42.
A total of 2.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$122.18 billion (US$3.75 billion) during the three-hour session.
Gainers outnumbered losers 233 to 193, with 77 stocks remaining unchanged.
Electrical engineering issues gained most at 2.6 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 0.5 percent, and banking shares at 0.2 percent.

Construction issues dropped 0.9 percent, followed by paper making shares which lost 0.4 percent; textile stocks, down 0.2 percent; and both cement stocks and plastic and chemical issues, down 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also climbed.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for November posted an increase of 83 points to close at 7,118, with 2,753 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for December rose 73 points to finish at 7,093, while those for March climbed 54 points to 7,025, and those for June moved up 60 points to 6,990. Contract transactions for these futures totaled 137, nine, and three, respectively.
No transactions were registered for September.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were: 7,035 for November; 7,020 for December; 6,971 for March; 6,930 for June; and 6,897 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERANCE OF TIES WITH TONGA (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Tonga's switch of diplomatic allegiance is a major Blow to Taiwan as the kingdom of some 100,000 people had been the ROC's longest and most loyal South Pacific ally.

MOFA officials said Tonga's unfriendly move is not expected to have a domino effect on the ROC's three other allies in the South Pacific -- the Solomon Islands, Nauru and Tuvalu. "Our relations with the three allies remain firm," said a MOFA official.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENDEAVORING TO SHORE UP TIES WITH SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will step up efforts to cement relations with its three South Pacific allies following the Kingdom of Tonga's decision to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Nov. 2, diplomatic officials said on Saturday.

The officials said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) attaches great importance to the possibility of a domino effect caused by the Tongan move on the ROC's three remaining South Pacific allies -- the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu and Nauru.

"We'll pay close heed to the developing situation, but we are confident that our relations with our three South Pacific allies will remain firm and cordial," said George Jin-gou Chang, director of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department.
Chang said senior Tuvalu, Nauru, and Solomon Islands officials have often assured their ROC counterparts that they will uphold their commitments to Taiwan.
"They have told us that they believe only the ROC can faithfully assist them in their national development," Chang said.
He divulged that several Solomon Islands cabinet ministers will lead large delegations to Taiwan in December when that country's parliament will be in recess.

As for relations with Nauru, Chang said the ROC maintains close cooperation with that country in the agriculture and fishery fields. During the annual meeting of the South Pacific Forum held earlier this year, ROC and Nauru delegates discussed a variety of new fishing and agricultural cooperative programs.
Meanwhile, Chang said, the ROC has decided to set up an embassy and appoint a resident ambassador in Tuvalu in the near future.
Chang also said that the ROC Ambassador to Tonga will lodge a formal protest to the Tonga Foreign Ministry on Monday over its unfriendly and detrimental move towards the ROC.

Since the forging of diplomatic ties in 1972, the ROC has extended many kinds of assistance to Tonga, including the services of an agricultural mission. Nevertheless, Chang said, the ROC has not offered any loans to Tonga.
Chang said Tonga probably switched diplomatic allegiance for two major reasons -- promises from Beijing to help it build and launch satellites and join the United Nations.

MOFA announced on Saturday that the ROC has decided to sever its diplomatic relations with Tonga, terminate all agreements and cooperation between the two countries and recall its ambassador, effective Nov. 2, 1998.

MOFA issued the statement after the Tonga foreign minister formally announced at 8 a.m. on Saturday (Taipei time) that his country will switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Monday.

Tonga will be the fourth ROC ally to switch diplomatic allegiance so far this year, following the lead of South Africa, the Central African Republic, and Guinea-Bissau. With the loss of Tonga, the ROC now has just 26 diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP ROC REPRESENTATIVE IN USA LECTURES IN BOSTON
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 31 (CNA) (By J.J. Hwang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The highest priority of the Republic of China government is to protect China's first democratic society on Taiwan in 5,000 years of history, the top ROC representative to the US said in Boston on Friday.

Stephen Chen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, made the remark in a speech on the latest developments and future challenges of the ROC to some 200 people gathered at Harvard University.
He said people's freedom and well-being on Taiwan must be secured to provide a development model for the Chinese mainland to use as reference.
Chen noted that the promotion of cross-strait relations and the ROC's participation in international affairs are the major challenges the Taipei government faces.
For the sake of national survival, he stressed that the ROC government will continue to practice its pragmatic diplomacy.

As to the development of cross-strait relations, Chen reiterated Taipei's stance of engaging in contact only on the basis of reciprocity and equality to gradually narrow the gaps between the two sides on political, economic and social levels.
He urged Beijing authorities to recognize the existence of differences between Taiwan and the mainland, and to create a favorable environment for ultimate democratic reunification of the nation.
Chen was in Boston to meet with American friends and Chinese community representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
