DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY ARRIVES IN VIENNA
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China first lady Lee Tseng Wen-hui on Friday arrived in Vienna, Austria from Rome for a four-day visit.
This is the final leg of Lee's three-nation cultural trip to Europe. Prior to arriving in Vienna, Lee visited France and the Holy See, where the president's wife was received by Pope John Paul II.
During her stay in Vienna, Lee will attend a welcoming luncheon hosted by Chinese residents of Austria on Sunday. She will then speak with them on the ROC's efforts in overseas Chinese affairs.

Lee is accompanied by Secretary-General to the President Huang Kun-huei's wife Huang Lin-man, National Security Council Secretary General Ting Mao-shih's wife Shi Mei-chang, and Foreign Minister Jason Hu's wife Shau Hsiao-ling.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN NABBED IN SAN FRANCISCO FOR BOMB HOAX ON EVA FLIGHT

TEXT.P: A Chinese-American male was arrested at San Francisco airport on Thursday for making a phony bomb threat on an EVA Airways flight to Taipei.
The man, identified by his surname Chi, was arrested minutes after making a phone call to staff at the EVA airport counter saying there was a bomb aboard the airline's flight BR27 to Taipei.

According to reports, Chi initially approached the airline counter to inquire whether a passenger surnamed Liang was aboard the flight. He left the counter after being told no such person had checked in.

Chi then tried to enter the exit gate area where passengers for flight BR27 were boarding -- under the guise that he was looking for a friend's mother who was sick. EVA security guards intervened and prevented him from approaching the area.
Soon afterward, Chi is believed to have made the call saying there was a bomb aboard the flight as the plane was taxing on the runway in preparation for takeoff.
Since Chi was at the counter minutes before the call, airline staff recognized his voice and called in police to apprehend him.
After being detained, Chi admitted to having made the threatening phone call in a bid to prevent the plane from taking off.
The bomb threat did not cause a delay in the flight as it went ahead as scheduled, and arrived safety in Taipei at about 10:00 p.m. on Friday, an EVA representative said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SENIOR OFFICIAL DENIES BEING BROKER FOR MAINLAND-OWNED BUSINESS

TEXT.P: New Party Legislator Yok Mu-ming on Friday urged the government to conduct a thorough investigation over whether a member of the ruling Kuomintang was a broker for mainland China-owned enterprises entering Taiwan.

Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the KMT's Business Management Committee, has lashed out angrily at Yok's allegations. Liu suggested that the New Party request the Control Yuan, the country's top watchdog, to investigate his possible involvement with the alleged mainland-held businesses in Taiwan.
Liu said he is willing to immediately resign his position if he were found guilty. Otherwise, the legislator making the charges should stop participating in public service, he added.

The opposition New Party held a news conference on Friday during which it demanded the government's security and intelligence agencies investigate possible interference by mainland-owned enterprises in Taiwan.

Yok pointed out that Liu was seen by John Tkacik -- a former senior intelligence official with the US State Department -- as being a secret envoy of ROC President Lee Teng-hui, and conducting a liaison between Lee and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

There has been a close relation between Liu and those groups tinged with mainland-owned businesses, the New Party legislator remarked, adding that relevant organizations of the government should find out whether Liu has been a go-between for the mainland in exchange for funds.
The chairman of KMT's business management committee dismissed the New Party's allegation as baseless, and said he did not and would never play such a role.

DOC.HEADLINE: PIRACY RINGS FOR PURIFIERS, TOYS, CD-ROMS BUSTED

TEXT.P: Several piracy operations were busted and eight suspects were turned over to prosecutors recently, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said on Saturday.
Authorities have broken piracy rings in mobile exhaust purifiers, toys and stationary products, as well as video game CD-ROMs in recent weeks.

Acting on a tip, investigators raided an underground factory in Tamsui on Friday and seized over 2,900 copied mobile exhaust purifiers for well-known Japanese car makers such as Honda, Toyota, and Nissan.

The operator of the ring, identified as Chen Chia-nan, was arrested. After questioning, Chen said he had turned out tens of millions of New Taiwan dollars worth of bogus purifiers a year, and sold them to local mobile components distributors.

In another operation, an owner of a toy store and an owner of a stationary store were arrested on similar charges after the MJIB found them selling copied goods bearing the Hello Kitty, My Melody, and Kero Kero Keroppi brand names. Investigators also apprehended the two suppliers of the contraband items.

The MJIB said its Taipei office confiscated about 140,000 copied video game CD-ROMs in a raid last month in a downtown Taipei commercial building which housed several toy stores. Four store owners were referred to prosecutors to face charges of copyright infringement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC DIETING CLASSES REAP GOOD RESULTS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Oct. 31 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Nantou County government's recent public dieting program has achieved remarkable results with participants reducing their weight by 4-10 kilograms in six weeks.
The program, financed by the Department of Health (DOH) under the Executive Yuan, was offered to 130 participants in Nantou City, Tsaotun Township, Puli Township, Luku Hsiang and Shuili Hsiang.
The six-week free classes consisted of instruction on a balanced diet, reduced intake of calories, improved dietary habits, and regular exercise.
Officials of the county's Health Bureau said they advised participants not to reduce their weight too quickly because it may lead to physical problems.
After the program, participants found that their weight had been reduced by more than four kilograms. Some even lost up to 10 kilograms.

The happy participants pledged to maintain their new weight as they did not want to return to their heavier days. The best way to reduce weight is to have a balanced diet, regular exercise and persevere, they said.

According to a government survey, one in every seven adults in Taiwan suffers from being over-weight. As being over-weight is often linked with high blood pressure, diabetes and strokes, the number of dieting spas has been on the rise. However, the number of disputes between spa operators and clients has also increased.
To let people get an accurate idea about dieting and dieting methods, the Department of Health provided financial support for local governments to sponsor public dieting classes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO REOPEN REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN KINSHASA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will reopen its representative office in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) once the situation there stabilizes, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Saturday.

Wu made the statement after his mainland Chinese counterpart, Tang Guoqiang, said on Friday that Beijing appreciates the DRC government's recent move of closing Taiwan's representative office in Kinshasa in accordance with the so-called "one China" policy.
Wu said the ROC temporarily shut its representative office in the DRC capital in August mainly because of political and economic turmoil in that country.
"When the civil war in the DRC ends and the general situation there returns to normal, we'll consider reopening a representative office in Kinshasa," Wu said.
He said the ROC signed a five-year agreement with the DRC's precursor -- Zaire -- in June 1991 on the opening of an ROC representative office in Kinshasa.

When the bilateral agreement expired in 1996, Wu said the ROC negotiated with Zaire officials for an extension of the accord. Before the two sides could strike a deal, a civil war erupted in that country and rebel leader Laurent Kabila managed to seize power in May 1997. Kabila then changed Zaire's national title to the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
As the DRC's situation has remained mired in instability and chaos, Wu said the ROC has been unable to reach a new agreement with the DRC on the renewal of its representative office's mandate.

In July this year, an army of Tutsi rebels, Rwandan soldiers and disenchanted troops from Kabila's army -- the same people who helped Kabila ousted longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in May 1997 -- staged a revolt against the Kabila regime, triggering a new round of civil war.
With the situation there deteriorating, the ROC evacuated its officials and nationals from the war-torn DRC in mid-August.

"As continued political instability in the DRC in the past few years has hindered work on promoting substantive Taipei-Kinshasa ties, we find no need to reopen our representative office there in the near future," Wu said.
Earlier this month, staff members of the ROC representative office in the DRC took advantage of a slowdown in fighting there to return to Kinshasa to handle some evacuation affairs.
Wu said only two ROC nationals remain in the DRC at present, while all other ROC citizens were evacuated together with the staff members of the representative office on Aug. 16.
The ROC first established diplomatic ties with Zaire in 1960, but cut such ties in early 1973 after the African state switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in late 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATION MARKS ANNIVERSARY OF GENERALISSIMO CHIANG'S BIRTH

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui presided over a memorial service at the Presidential Office on Saturday to mark the 112th anniversary of the late President Chiang Kai-shek's birth.
More than 500 people, including senior government officials, parliamentarians and overseas Chinese representatives, attended the ceremony.

Delivering a speech on the occasion, Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, recounted Chiang's notable accomplishments and achievements. They included leading the eight-year War of Resistance against Japan from 1937 through 1945, assisting neighboring Asian countries in establishing independent republics, fostering the establishment of the United Nations and building Taiwan into an anti-communist beacon.

After the ceremony, President Lee lead a group of high-ranking officials, including Vice President Lien Chan, National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan and Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling, to pay tribute to the late leader at his temporary resting place in Tzuhu in the northern county of Taoyuan, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.
Chiao Jen-ho, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, presided over a rally of overseas Chinese community leaders held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei.

Similar memorial services and commemorative activities were also held in other cities and counties around the island in memory of Generalissimo Chiang, who served as ROC president until his passing in 1975.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CLOSES DOWN ONE MORE DISSIDENT ORGANIZATION

TEXT.P: "Corruptive Behavior Observers," a civilian group organized last month by nine dissidents living in seven provinces, has been closed down by Beijing authorities, a human rights group said Saturday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the Civil Affairs Ministry of mainland Chinese State Council in Beijing Friday ordered An Jun, a dissident living at Xinyang, Henan province, to terminate all activities of the organization, which has nearly 100 members from 11 provinces at the present time.

The order, sent through officials of the civil affairs bureau of Xinyang city, also said that the organization is not lawful, because it is composed of members from several provinces. An and several other dissidents applied with the civil affairs ministry last month for permission to register the organization.
Another dissident organization, the China Development Union, was dissolved by order from Beijing earlier this month. The Beijing-based organization was registered legally in Hong Kong in August.

The information center also said Saturday that dissident Xie Wanjun, an organizer of the Shandong branch of the "China Democracy Party," and his wife have been interrogated by public security officers for 10 hours each day since Oct. 27. The interrogations will continue, the officers said.

Another dissident, Cha Jianguo of Beijing, was detained at Dongping, Shandong province on Oct. 28, because he attempted to join other dissidents in protesting against police harassment of Xie and his wife. After two days of detention at Dongping, Cha was sent back to Beijing under police escort and then released on Oct. 29. But he was interrogated again by public security officers the next day, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INTRODUCE ENGLISH PROFICIENCY TEST IN 2000

TEXT.P: Residents of Taiwan will be given certificates of English proficiency beginning in the year 2000 if they pass the tests given by an authorized language testing center, an official of the Ministry of Education said Saturday.

The official said that tests of speaking, listening, reading, and writing abilities ranging from the junior high school level to the post-graduate level will be given, and that the certificates will be recognized when applying for jobs or for admission to schools.

The program is aimed at encouraging people to continue to study after graduation from school, the official said, adding that Japanese, French, and German proficiency tests will be introduced step by step in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANK TO OPEN PALAU BRANCH NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The First Commercial Bank will open its first branch in Palau on Nov. 2, becoming Taiwan's first bank to open a branch office in the South Pacific island nation.
Bank officials chose Palau because a greater number of Taiwan businessmen have moved their investments there from Thailand, Vietnam and Malaysia due to lower production costs.
The Palau branch will be the First Commercial Bank's sixth overseas branch office opened this year.
The opening will bring the number of the bank's branch offices abroad to 11, including those in Guam, Singapore, London, New York, Los Angeles, Frankfurt, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Phnom Penh.
The bank also maintains five representative offices abroad located in Bangkok, Manila, Ho Chi Minh City, Rangoon and Kuala Lumpur.
